title: EDMUND H. LEWIS OF APPEALS COURT
description: SKANEATELES, N. Y., July 31Former Chief Judge Ed mund H. Lewis of the State Court of Appeals died yesterday at his home. He was 87 years old.

title: Stennis Backs Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) Senator John C. Stennis, dem ocrat of Mississippi, who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, announced today that he would support the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty.

title: Successor Weighed
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 31 (UPI)Sources close to Gov. Edwin Edwards said today the Governor would appoint his wife, Elaine, to serve out the unexpired term of Senator El lender.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FUND MEMBERSHIP IS OPPOSED ANEW
description: The Securities Industry As sociation, a group of 850 in vestment houses, voiced re newed opposition yesterday to the concept of institutional membership on the nation's stock exchanges.

title: Padres Call Up Catcher
description: HOUSTON, July 31 (UPI)  Joseph Goddard, a catcher, has been purchased by the San Di ego Padres from their Alexan dria, La., Texas League farm club. Goddard hit 227 with 25 runs batted in and five home runs in 53 games with Alexan dria.

title: Ruskin Proposes Unit to Police Building Industry
description: Robert K. Ruskin, City In vestigation Commissioner, said yesterday that he favored the creation of a central, powerful unit of city government to al leviate some of the administra tive difficulties that now lead to corruption in the construc tion industry.

title: President and McGovern Attend Rites for Ellender in Louisiana
description: HOUMA, La., July 31The rivals in the Presidential cam paign attended the funeral of Senator Allen J. Ellender to day but seemed to take no notice of each other.

title: Connecticut to Start FlatGrant Welfare System Today, Amid Fears of Massive Evictions of Recipients
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 31 Connecticut's new flatgrant welfare system goes into effect tomorrow amid predictions from town and city officials through out the state that the program could lead to massive evictions of welfare recipients from their homes.

title: 'Greaser's Palace'
description: Back in the days when he made movies for $8 apiece and had them developed at Walgreen'swildly sane movies like "Chafed Elbows" and "No More Excuses" about mother love, war, coping and bestiality, and even when he went comparatively commercial and made "Putney Swope" which is still my favorite film about Madison Avenue, Robert Downey billed himself as "a prince," which he was.Though he was financially strapped most of the time, he remained resolutely game in that lunatic way that identifies the aristocracy of fools and moviemakers. Downey would try anything and if it didn't work, or wasn't funny, it didn't much matter because it hadn't cost a lot and he'd move right on to something else that probably would work.Downey no longer bills himself as a prince, and the surprising news this morning is that he has managed to make his "Cleopatra," his "Mutiny on the Bounty" and his "Star" in the form of one big-budget mistake called "Greaser's Palace," which can be more accurately described as Downey's "The Greatest Story Ever Told." "Greaser's Palace" does to vulgar humor what the George Stevens film did to Christianity: it embraces it with awe and far too many technical resources.The film, which opened yesterday at the Festival Theater, is the gospel according to Downey, set in a Wild West ruled by a tyrant named Seaweedhead Greaser, who collects taxes, keep his mother and his favorite mariachi band in cages and suffers the constipation of the damned. The savior, who arrives by parachute, is a modest young man in a 1940ish zoot suit who simply wants to get to Jerusalem to become an actor-singer. "It's written," he says, "that the agent Morris awaits me."En route he finds himself working miracles ("If ya feel, ya heal"), some of which aren't 100 per cent effective. He "cures" one old man who throws away his crutches and announces triumphantly: "I can crawl again! I can crawl again!"The savior rather enjoys walking on water and is an immense success with his nightclub act, which concludes when he holds up his two bleeding hands, although the agent Morris thinks it's dreadful. In poor taste, really. He's just getting started on a proper show biz career when his father shows up and tells him it's time to go."I don't want to," he says. "I think I've found myself and I really don't trust you."I'm afraid that I've made "Greaser's Palace" sound funnier than it ever is except in little bits and pieces, that is, in gags that have nothing to do with satire or with a send-up of Christian myth. Downey is no Bunel. He's not even an Alexandro Jodorowsky, although there are times when "Greaser's Palace" seems to want to be as intellectually ambitious as "El Topo."The film, I'm told, cost close to $1-million, and it looks it, which depresses me even more than its witlessness. Just a few yean ago, Downey could have made a couple of dozen movies with that moneysome of which were bound to be funny, and to hell with worrying about color photography, large casts, location shooting and all the other things that are known as production values.

title: STATE WARNS CITY ON DAYCARE UNITS
description: The state has warned the city that it will cut off state and Federal aid for 52 interim daycare centers here unless the city reports by Aug. 25 that health and safety stand ards are being met.

title: Port Notes
description: There are three young rail road buffs in town who prob ably owe their lives to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's flying sheriff's posse.

title: 5 THUGS AT PLAZA GET $45,000 GEMS
description: Five dapper robbers smashed open five safedeposit boxes at the Plaza Hotel early yesterday, the police said, and escaped with more than $45,000 worth of jewelry belonging to jewel ers who had come here for convention.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Norman Welton, administrator of the Wire Service Guild, said yesterday that the guild, a local of the Newspaper Guild, has taken no action in endorsing any political candidate this year. The parent guild has endorsed the Democratic Presi dential candidate, Senator George McGovern.

title: 3 Win Individual Titles In AllAmerica Bowling
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)  Two boys and a girl won in dividual championships today in the 12th annual allAmerica youth bowling tournament which drew a total of 151 high school contestants from 48 states and two Canadian prov inces.

title: Liberals Protest at New Trial in Prague
description: PRAGUE, July 31Dr. Milan Huebl, the former head of the Czechoslovak Communist party's political college, went on trial today with two other dissidents for subverting the republic by distributing anti Government pamphlets.

title: Athens Adds More ExOfficers to Regime
description: ATHENS, July 31 Premier George Papadopoulos, who as an army colonel seized power in Greece five years ago, to day reconstructed his 42man Government and gave it a strong military flavor.

title: Personalities: Knicks Add Dotson
description: The Knickerbockers may lead the National Basketball Association next season in at least one department Rhodes Scholars. Heyward Dotson, a star at Columbia University who spent the last two years at Oxford, yester day signed to play with the Knicks. The 6foot4inch guard, who averaged 16.7 points a game through three seasons at Columbia, may have a difficult time whining a spot in the New York back court, however He'll have to prove himself in the training camp, said Red Holz man, the coachgeneral man ager. I have an open mind. We'll be very interested to see what he can do.  If Dotson can make the team, he will be its second Rhodes Scholar. Bill Bradley of Princeton also attended Ox ford as a Rhodes Scholar be fore signing with the Knicks five years ago.

title: Registration Groups Shopping for New Voters
description: The two young men at the card table outside the depart ment store were more busy than many of the salesmen inside.

title: GEORGE WILLISON, HISTORIAN, 76, DIES
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31  George F. Willison, author of Saints and Stran gers and other historical stud ies, died yesterday in Saratoga County Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived on South Hill in Ballston Spa.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Alfons Gorbach, ExAustrian Chancellor
description: GRAZ, Austria, July 31 (AP) Dr. Alfons Gorbach, Chancel lor of Austria from 1961 to 1964 and a former chairman of the Austrian People's party, died here today. He was 73 years old.

title: Defense Says Bremer Was Insane at Time of Shooting
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., July 31The state trial of Arthur Herman Bremer, the Milwaukee busboy accused of shooting Gov. George C. Wallace, began today with his counsel telling a jury of six men and six wo men that Mr. Bremer was in sane at the time he is accused of having fired the shots that paralyzed Mr. Wallace. The at torney raised doubts as to whether Mr. Bremer had fired the shots.

title: Namath, Jets Expected To Sign Pact Today
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 31 The Jets announced to night that a news conference would be held tomorrow at noon at their Hofstra Uni versity training camp at which time Joe Namath is ex pected to sign a multiyear contract.

title: Esterline Elects Officer
description: The Esterline Corporation announced yesterday that Don ald ?? Jones had been elected as president, chief executive officer and a director. He re places Edward C. Mabbs, who resigned as president and a director.

title: Ashe Bents Cox in Final
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 31 (UPI)Arthur Ashe outdueled Mark Cox from the baseline, 64, 64, today to win the $10 000 first prize in the $50,000 First National Tennis tourney.

title: Where Robert King Found Help
description: A 2year old organization that describes itself as a humanizing process which deals with acting out disorders, AREBA (Accelerated Reedu cation of Emotions, Behavior and Atti tudes) is a privatelyrun program to rehabilitate drug addicts.

title: The Godfather
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The an nouncement that production will soon begin on a movie called. The God fatherPart Two must surely rank as the most depressing cultural event of 1972.

title: DeJesus Gains in Juniors
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich, July 31 (AP)Freddy DeJesus of Puerto Rico advanced to the third round in the national junior tennis singles championship to day with a 60, 60 victory over Douglas Austin of Rolling Hills, Calif.

title: Relief Clients Do $18Million Work
description: Budget Director David A. Grossman said yesterday that the city was getting the equiv alent of $18million a year in service from 6,000 employ able welfare clients who were working out their grants in parttime city jobs.

title: Platinum Prices Fall on Auto Article
description: Platinum futures prices dropped sharply yesterday fol lowing a widely discussed arti cle that appeared Friday in the July 28 issue of Science mag azine. It was written by three scientists from Bell Telephone Laboratories.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The American Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broad casting System and the National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that they would carry live coverage of an announce ment by Senator George Mc Govern scheduled for tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: WOMAN SAYS SHE SET 2,000 FIRES
description: A 23yearold Brooklyn wo man arrested early yesterday after she was seen running from a vacant Brownsville building that was on fire has allegedly admitted setting two to four fires every week for the last 12 years, or a total of more than 2,000 fires.

title: Erie Railway Trustees Named
description: CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP) United States District Court Judge Robert B. Krupansky ap pointed two Cleveland indus trialists today as trustees of the Erie Lackawanna Railway Company which has filed for reorganization under the Fed eral Bankruptcy Act.

title: Republic's President Directs the Beating of African Convicts
description: BANGUI, Central African Re public, July 31 (Agence France Press)President Jean Bdel Bokassa led soldiers into Bangui prison today and ordered them to beat men imprisoned for theft with wooden clubs. The Government announced later that several prisoners had died.

title: OTTAWA REJECTS LEGAL MARIJUANA
description: OTTAWA, July 31  The Canadian Government today rejected recent recommenda tions that it legalize the simple possession of marijuana and hashish. However, under a new policy to be proposed to Parlia ment, first offenders would be treated far more leniently than in the past.

title: Ellsberg's Lawyers Ask Rehnquist Ban
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31The tangled court proceedings in the Pentagon papers case were further complicated today when the defense sought to disqualify Justice William H. Rehnquist from taking part in the Supreme Court's consideration of the case.

title: PaulHenri Spaak Is Dead at 73; An Architect of European Unity
description: PaulHenri Spaak, the Bel gian statesman who was one of the chief architects of Euro pean unification and Western solidarity in the postwar era, died of kidney failure yesterday in Brussels. He was 73 years old.

title: Contract Dispute Cancels First Two Racing Days of Freehold Meeting
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., July 31 Today's scheduled opening of Freehold Raceway's 100 day harness race meeting was canceled because negotiations remained deadlocked on a new purse contract between the raceway management and the Standardbred Breeders and Owners Association of New Jersey.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Vote Allocation Under New Plan
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 31Following is a table comparing the votes on the present Nassau County Board of Supervisors with those under proposed reapportionment:

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)Some 2,000 tons of United States linseed oil has been sold to China in what officials said was the first such farmproduct deal since President Nixon's visit to Peking, it was learned today.

title: NETS TOP EXPOS ON DYER BELT, 42
description: The New York Mets said goodby and good riddance to July last night after they de feated the Montreal Expos, 42, on a tworun home run in the eighth inning by Duffy Dyer.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ST. LOUIS, July 31  The National Urban League an nounced today that it would conduct a voter registration drive in 10 moderatesizeo Northern cities, Including Stam ford, Conn., and New Bruns wick, N. J.

description: Man in the News

title: Sales Off Sharply
description: The Boeing Company, pro ducer of commercial and mili tary aircraft and spacecraft had lower profits in this year's second quarter and first half as sales plunged from year earlier levels, the company re ported yesterday from Seattle headquarters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hydrofoil Backing Passed
description: WASHINGTON July 31 (UPI) The House voted today to authorize a Federal guarantee of 87.5 per cent of the cost of a privately financed mortgage for construction of oceangoing hydrofoil ships.

title: At the Plaza, Robbery Was Just Minor Ripple in Day's Activities
description: A uniformed attendant wheeled away the tall silver coffee urn that had served discreetly wisecracking detec tives. After the departure of the television cameras, some one replaced the sign Safe Deposit Box Available for Valuables on the counter of the reception desk. The Plaza had settled back into its ac customed mood of studied elegance yesterday afternoon.

title: SpasskyFischer Play Due to Resume Today
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 31Play is expected to re sume tomorrow in the world championship chess match between Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer.

title: 6 KILLED BY BOMBS AFTER TROOP PUSH ON I.R.A. IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 31  Six persons were killed in terrorist bomb blasts today following a predawn op eration by British troops that smashed the barricades of Ro man Catholic areas in Belfast and Londonderry.

title: Notes on People
description: Daniel (Chappie) James Jr., the highestranking black of ficer in the Air Force, was promoted to major general. In a Pentagon ceremony, Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird pinned two silver stars on each of the general's epaulets as his wife and son, Air Force Capt. Daniel James 3d, looked on. General James, a 52yearold former fighter pilot, is Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for pub lic affairs at the Pentagon. The Air Force's highest rank ing black officer was Benja min O. Davis Jr., who retired in 1970 as a lieutenant gen eral.

title: EL SHAFEI, RAHIM WIN IN BROOKLINI
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., July 31 (AP)Ismail El Shafei of Egypt and Haroon Rahim of Pakistan managed raininterrupted vic tories today before the weather washed out the rest of the schedule in the $50,000 United States pro tennis champion ships at Longwood Cricket Club.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The International Monetary Fund discised today that there were now only 16 countries, most of them small, still pegging their currencies to the British pound and thus currently floating with the pound.

title: Bankers' Acceptances Fall
description: Bankers' dollar acceptances declined $374million in June from the previous month, mark ing the largest monthly de cline in history, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday, Acceptances also dropped $576million from the yearearlier month, the sharpest fall since June, 1932.

title: Lodge Urges Government To Help on Campaign Cost
description: BEVERLY, Mass., July 31 (AP)Henry Cabot Lodge, for mer Ambassador to Vietnam and currently special envoy to the Vatican, says the Federal Government should take over some of the costs of political campaigning.

title: U.S. Seeks Right to Limit Workers in Cargo Areas
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Nixon Administration asked Congress today for new power to protect international cargo at seaports and airports as part of a crackdown on theft and drug smuggling.

title: CHOICE CAPTURES SPA TEST STAKES
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31With today's open ing of the meeting at Saratoga race track, the oldest thorough bred track in the country, the New York Racing Association president, Jack Krumpe, antici pates another successful sea son. The local campaign will run through Aug. 26, for 24 racing days, and will mark the continuation of action here abouts, that started in 1862.

title: CHARLES H. BOLLAS
description: Charles H. Bollas, retired treasurer of the James T. White Company, publishers, and later for several years secretary to Alfred P. Sloan Jr., the philan thropist, died Sunday, appar ently of a heart attack, while visiting in Rehoboth Beach, Md. He was 77 years old and lived at 5 Phillipse Road in Yonkers.

title: HATCH ACT UPSET; U.S. COURT FINDS CURBS TOO VAGUE
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  A threejudge panel of the United States District Court here ruled today that the Hatch Act's pro hibitions on political activity by Federal civil service employes are so vague and broad that they are unconstitutional.

title: 3 Hijack Jet, Collect $1Million and Fly to Algeria
description: Three hijackers comman deered a Delta Air Lines jet yes terday, collected a major por tion of the $1million they had demanded and forced the crew to head for Algeria.

title: LendLease Debts Blocking A SovietU.S. Trade Pact
description: MOSCOW, July 31Persist ing differences over Soviet re payment of a World War II lendlease debt have prevented Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson and toplevel Soviet officials from achieving an overall SovietAmerican trade agreement in 10 days of talks here, diplomatic sources re ported tonight.

title: Business Briefs
description: TimeLife Video, a division of Time Inc., announced yes terday a new videocassette programing service with more than 120 titles. The new system is aimed at the business, education and governmental markets and includes a new speedreading course produced expressly for video cassettes that feature Dick Cavett.

title: 4 Children Drown in Ohio
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 31 (UPI)Four children drowned last night when a car veered into a lake at George Rogers Clark Park here. The victims were identified as Richard Har ford, 6 years old, Angella Brou gher, 3, Tammy Vrettos, 9, and Stephenie Kaeser, 5, all of Springfield. Mrs. Marie Brou gher, who the police identified as the mother of three of the children, escaped from the car and swam ashore.

title: OBSERVER
description: Naturally, I did not want to be Vice President of the United States.

title: Blyth & Co. Signs Agreements With Eastman Dillon for Merger
description: Merger News

title: 26 Establishments Cited as Violators Of Laws on Food
description: The Health Department yes terday cited 26 more restaurants and food establishments for serious violations of the City Health Code.

title: Mrs. Rousseau, Charles Amory Wed in Florida
description: Charles M. Amory of Palm Beach, Fla., and his bride, the former Mrs. Julia Aspuru Rousseau, are paying a brief visit to New York before leaving by air tomorrow for Furope, where they will spend their honeymoon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 31 (AP)Ben Hatskin, owner of the Winnipeg Jets of the World Hockey Associa tion, has announced that an allstar team from the new league will go to Czechoslovakia next spring for a series with the Czech national team. Hatskin said the series, which is to follow three games in North America between the Czechoslovaks and the W.H.A. allstars, would be played sometime after May 15.

title: National General Picks Zax As Senior Vice President
description: The National General Corpo ration announced yesterday the appointment of Stanley R. Zax as senior vice president, general counsel and a director, and Thomas H. Kuchel, former Re publican Senator from Cali fornia, as a director.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Tuesday, Aug. 1 (AP)Derek Sanderson, the colorful center for the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, has reached an agreement to play with the Philadelphia Blazers of the rival World Hockey Associa tion next season, Sanderson's attorney said last night.

title: Creditors Assail Penn Central's Plans
description: Eight of the nation's biggest banks and 12 major insurance, companies petitioned the Fed eral District Court in Philadel phia yesterday to stop listening to the Penn Central Transporta tion Company's plans for reviv ing a viable railroad, presented by the railroad's bankruptcy trustees, and to make sure that the security of creditors is kept intact.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MODENA, Italy, July 31 (AP)Ferrari, the prestigious Italian auto racing factory, announced today it would set free its drivers at the end of the season and stop com peting officially in championship events.

title: Japan's Automobile Exports Declined 31.9% During June
description: TOKYO, July 31 (Reuters) Japan's motorvehicle exports in June declined 31.9 per cent to 103,891 units, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today.

title: BIRMINGHAM CITY BEATS COSMOS, 30
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 31 Trevor Francis of Birmingham City scored a goal and assisted on another to lead his team to a 30 victory over the New York Cosmos tonight in a soccer ex hibition at Hofstra Field.

title: Rachel Eldad Bride Of E. M. Oppenheim
description: Miss Rachel Eldad, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Eldad of Tel Aviv, Israel, was married yesterday to E. Mag nus Oppenheim, New York investment banker. The cere mony was performed at Beit Hamehandes, Tel Aviv, by Rabbi Moses B. Tendler of Yeshiva University, New York.

title: Offshore Tanker Terminal Gets Administration Push
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Nixon Administration has taken a first step toward mo bilizing the Support of Con gress, the oil industry and the public for the construction of offshore, deepwater supertank er terminals that would cost billions of dollars.

title: Executive Changes
description: John W. Culligan has been elected executive vice president of the American Home Products Corporation.

title: Business Briefs
description: Action by Bermudan authorities late last Friday tying the Bermudan dollar to the United States dollar instead the British pound was confirmed yesterday by bank and trade sources here.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Off at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Gov ernment's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Hanging Sculpture Grounded in Madrid
description: MADRID, July 31Almost surreptitiously, Madrid's first outdoor museum opened last weekbut immediately faced the loss of its star attraction.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 The new, restructured Demo cratic National Committee that will choose a replacement for Senator Thomas F. Eagleton as the party's VicePresidential nominee may not be controlled by backers of Senator George McGovern.

title: The Wallace Strategy
description: Governor Wallace's announcement that he will not run for President on a thirdparty ticket makes official a campaign advantage that President Nixon must have been anticipating with relish. So distinct are the poten tial benefits for Mr. Nixonin every section of the coun trythat some political observers hint at an under standing between the President and Mr. Wallace, with a formal link to be established and, presumably, some political reward for the Alabama Governor in the offing.

title: Japan Sees Limitations On Growth of Economy
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Japan's economy is unlikely to resume its rapid growth, which averaged 12 per cent annually during the late nineteensixties, a Government white paper said today.

title: A Pleasant Surprise by the Giants
description: Sports of The Times

title: Waldheim Pays Tribute
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31  Secretary General, Waldheim led the diplomatic community today in paying trib ute to Mr. Spaak Mr. Wald heim, in a message to Belgium's Foreign Minister, Pierre Harmel, called Mr. Spaak one of the bestknown statesmen of his time.

title: European Families Feel The Bite of Rising Costs
description: PARIS, July 31Inflation, which seems to be the inevi table accompaniment of life in a modern industrial society, is changing the habits and atti tudes of Europeans.

title: Color Film Agreement Set
description: Berkey Photo, Inc., announced yesterday the signing of an agreement to market in this country a negative color film made by Konishiroku Photo Industry of Japan, producer of the Konica brand of cameras. It would be marketed under the Berkey name brand with the selling price covering processing charges. It will also market the film under the Sakura brand name of the Japanese manufacturer without prepaid processing charges. Berkey said the film can be used in the Kodak line of Insta matic cameras.

title: Walinsky Calls on Rockefeller To Investigate Mackell's Office
description: Adam Walinsky, a candidate for State Attorney General in 1970, urged Governor Rocke feller yesterday to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the clear possibility of fun damental corruption in the of fice of Queens District Attorney Thomas F. Mackell.

title: Bank Merger Is Approved
description: BOSTON, July 31 (Reuters) The Massachusetts Board of Banking Corporation said today ?? had approved the merger of the First Agricultural National Bank of Berkshire County, the Mechanics Bancorp and the Short Bank, Inc., into a multi bank holding company. Total assets of the new company will exceed $470million.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ROME, July 31 (AP)Giulio Onesti, head of the Italian Olympic Committee, returned from Peking today and said he would propose to the International Olympic Committee that Red China be allowed to participate in the 1976 Olympics in Denver.

title: Offshore Gas Line Proposed
description: The Stingray Pipeline Com pany, a partnership involving subsidiaries of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and the Peoples Gas Company, filed yesterday for Federal Power Commission authority to build 300 miles of new offshore gas supply line in the Gulf of Mexico. The project, spread over three years, represents an investment of about $150mil lion and would have a design capacity of one billion cubic feet a day of natural gas.

title: Welfare Muddle
description: The Administration's welfare reform plan has never been more urgently needed and its legislative prospects have never been worse. The road to this barren point has been paved with selfinterested politics, utopian demagogy, professional timidity and obtuse indifference to human suffering.

title: Communism: 125 Years Later
description: BELGRADE  Communists might have hoped that with their coming to power the incompatibilities between them and the working class would cease to exist. For according to Com munist theory, power should have been only an organ of the working class against conspiracies and inter vention. That organ should imme diately begin to wither away and should completely wither away with the construction of the classless, so cialist society.

title: Display Found in House
description: DETROIT, July 31 (AP)  Federal agents investigating the house of the persons the F.B.I. said hijacked a Delta jet bound for Miami today found a bizar re and ritualistic display left behind.

title: WITNESS DISPUTED IN PHILLIPS CASE
description: Pressing its argument that the murder case against Pa trolman William R. Phillips is one of mistaken identity, the defense yesterday presented testimony that a key prosecu tion witness had privately identified someone other than the patrolman as the murder suspect.

title: Parts of Human Body Found In Bag in Canal Near Miami
description: MIAMI, July 31 (AP)A man and his wife fishing from the bank of a canal near here reeled in a plastic garbage bag stuffed with parts of a dismembered human body, the police said.

title: 2 SLAIN BY CONVICT IN BREAK ATTEMPT
description: NORFOLK, Mass., July 31  Two prison employes were killed and one other critically wounded at the state prison here today by a convicted mur derer who holed up for five hours in a prison dormitory before killing himself and at tempting to kill his wife, prison officials reported.

title: Chapin: Wider Role for Others at Met
description: The general manager's of fice in the Metropolitan Op era House looked aptly bleak and ghostly: no furniture, walls bare and ready for repainting, floor carpetless. Schuyler G. Chapin, desig nated by a twist of fate a few days earlier to run the Metropolitan after Goeran Gentele died in an auto acci dent, paused at the doorway.

description: To the Editor:

title: British Are Pressing for the Completion of Atomic Breeder Reactor
description: DOUNREAY, ScotlandAt a nuclear center perched here on the bleak, northernmost coast of Scotland, vast quantities of sodium are being stockpiled for what the British hope will be the first prototype breeder re actor to generate power out side the Soviet Union.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MACAZINE?ADVT.

title: Air Hijacker Prefers Death To Rest of Life in Prison
description: HAMILTON, Ohio, July 31 (UPI)Richard McCoy Jr., sen tenced to 45 years in prison for air piracy, says he would rather go before a firing squad or go to the gas chamber than spend the rest of my life behind bars.

title: Prisoner Kills Self In Cell in Brooklyn; Panel Plans Study
description: A city prison inmatethe ninth so far this yearhanged or strangled himself last night with a strip of bedsheet in his cell in the Brooklyn House of Detention, according to a cor rection spokesman.

title: Yankees Defeat Orioles, 52, 21
description: BALTIMORE, July 31Sparky Lyle, the confident southpaw with the sharpbreaking slider, produced two more fine relief performances tonight to clinch a double victory for the Yan kees over the Orioles in a twi lightnight doubleheader.

title: Proposals a Basis for Talks
description: PARIS, July 31 (Reuters) French official sources stressed today that proposals by Presi dent Georges Pompidou at last week's FrancoItalian summit meeting for a possible revalua tion in the gold price for cer tain central bank transactions between Common Market coun tries should only be viewed as a basis for discussion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater: Flawed Staging
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It is a brave thing, here and now to attempt Shakespeare's A Midsummer Night's Dream immediately after Peter Brook's realization of the play. Here in Minneapolis, at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater, John Hirsch has staged a new production of Shakespeare's gossamersteel fairy tale. It does not really conic off. It is modern in spirit but not in heart.

title: RIPON UNIT CAUTIOUS ON NIXON PROSPECT
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. July 31 (AP)A national survey by a progressive Republican organi zation says that President Nix on is favored for reelection in 35 states but notes that he has always run well in the summer and clone considerably worse in November.

title: How Did Alan King's Son Become an Addict? Both Try to Explain
description: He is a man with all the attributes of successthe name and face recognized throughout the country, the sixfigure income and the Tudorstyle mansion on Long Island with 22 rooms, nine bath rooms and cigars in the freezer.

title: Connecticut Will Bargain With Employes First Time
description: HARTFORD, July 31 (UPI) Connecticut will begin collec tive bargaining with ite em ployes this week for the first time in history.

title: You'll Always Know Just How to Wash It
description: A ruling by the Federal Trade Commission that all readytowear garments sold in this country must carry a permanently affixed set of directions for the garment's carethe temperature of the water, the kind of soap, the temperature of the iron, whether to bleach, etcwent into effect July 3.

title: Eagleton Quits
description: The withdrawal of Senator Eagleton from the Democratic national ticket was an admirable act of self abnegation designed to permit the Presidential campaign to proceed on the issues, rather than in sterile debate over his own capacity to stand the rigors of the Presi dency in an emergency.

title: OFFER REJECTED BY HOSPITAL UNION
description: Members of a local union rep resenting employes in 35 pri vate, profitmaking hospitals in the city rejected a contract offer by management yesterday, but voted to continue negotiations in an effort to reach a settle ment.

title: Cowboys Deal Thomas To Chargers for Pair
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., July 31 (AP)Duane Thom as, the Dallas Cowboys' con troversial running back, was traded late tonight to the San Diego Chargers in a National Football League deal.

title: Paul Henri Spaak
description: Paul Henri Spaak wrote late in life that he had been rewarded by seeing his dreams come true. Of all the dreams of a turbulent 41year career in statecraft, none gripped him more profoundly than the dream of European unity in close alliance with the United States.

title: MERCHANT IS FREED IN AUTO THEFT CASE
description: Charges of conspiring to transfer interstate forged and fraudulent motor vehicle reg istration certificates against Bernard Rosenthal, a Brooklyn merchant, were dismissed in Federal Court yesterday for lack of evidence.

title: NEW JOBLESS AID FOR 90,000 URGED
description: Raymond R. Corbett, presi dent of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O., called yesterday for emergency measures to aid 90,000 state residents whose extended unemploymentinsur ance benefits had just been cut off.

title: Very Rev. James Griffin, Headed Villanova, 192632
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP)The Very Rev. James Henry Griffin, former president of Villanova University, died Friday in St. Peter's Hospital, Albany. He was 80 years old.

title: GROUP OF INVESTORS SUES MERRILL LYNCH
description: DALLAS, July 31 (AP) Twentyfive Dallas investors have filed a $25million suit against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: Victim Gets $600 Bonus In a Bilking
description: A 78yearold Jamaica, Queens, woman who was a swindling victim of a shady homeimprovement contrac tor was given a check for $2,900 yesterday by Consum er Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson$600 more than she had originally paid.

title: Northwestern Mutual Life Announces Record Sales
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, the nation's seventh largest life in surer reported yesterday that sales soared 18.4 per cent in the first half to $1.3billion, a new high.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Jersey Drops Test Barriers

title: Czech Hijackers Sentenced
description: NUREMBERG, West Germany, July 31 (Reuters)A court here sentenced two Czechoslovak miners today to seven years in prison for hijacking a Czecho slovak airliner last April 18 and forcing it to fly here. The miners, Karel Dolezal, 28 years old, and Antonin Lerch, 24, ad mitted that they had hijacked the plane, because they were dissatisfied with the political situation in Czechoslovakia.

title: 2 ALLEGED ROBBERS SEIZED AFTER CRASH
description: Two of four men who had allegedly robbed the owner of a Bronx clothing store with a shotgun were seized last night after the car in which they fled the police crashed into a tene ment building in the Morrisania section of the borough, the po lice said.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Let ters, telegrams and phone calls flooding into Washington today strongly supported Senator Thomas F. Eagleton and urged Senator George McGovern  vainly, it turned out  to keep him on the Democratic ticket.

title: Broad but Modest Gains Made in Credit Markets
description: Credit Markets

title: Freetex Meets Riva Ridge
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 31 (AP)Freetex, the Ohio Derby and Gotham winner, will meet Riva Ridge, the Kentucky Derby and Belmont Stakes winner, in the $100,000 Monmouth Invita tional Handicap at Monmouth Park on Saturday. Freetex has been assigned 117 pounds to Riva Ridge's 126 for the 1 mile race.

title: NICKLAUS DECIDES TO DEFEND CROWN
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., July 31 (UPI)Jack Nicklaus, say ing The finger feels fine and I feel fine, said today that he was ready to play in the Pro fessional Golfers Association championship, which begins Thursday.The only problem is that I haven't been playing enough golf, so I don't imagine I'll be in the greatest shape, Nick laus said.Nicklaus, who underwent mi nor surgery on his infected right index finger last Tuesday night, arrived at the Oakland Hills Country Club in midaft ernoon today with his sore fin ger covered only by two Band Aids.He shrugged off questions about his condition and went out to play a practice round, insisting he probably would have withdrawn from the tour nament if he had any questions about his finger.I was thinking that was an awful important finger, Nick laus joked. But I went out and hit some balls and I found out I didn't even put that finger on the club.He said he used a relaxed grip and had the finger heavily bandaged when he hit about 40 or 50 balls from a practice tee Saturday and played nine holesagainst his doctor's or dersyesterday at Scioto Country Club in Columbus, Ohio.I played with it like this, Jack said, demonstrating a mock grip with the injured fin ger held away from the club. But I'm not worried about it.Nicklaus, already the winner of the Masters and the United States Open and the tour's leading money winner this year, said his doctor had ad vised him against playing be fore today, but he still played yesterday with his young son, Jackie; a friend, and the friend's son.I had to find out what the darn thing would feel like, he said. I knew what the doctor would say. He said he wanted to see me Monday before I played any. But I hit a few shots Saturday evening and it didn't hurt at all, so I decided to play Sunday.I decided to find out if I could play right then, rather than wait until Wednesday and find out I was still hurting, Nicklaus said. Now, I know I can go out there and play.

title: GOLD PRICE SOARS TO PEAK IN EUROPE
description: LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) The freemarket price of gold soared today to near $69 an ounce in London, Zurich and Frankfurt, and to just under $70 in Paris.

title: A Small City Learns to Live With Big Plant
description: UNION CITY, Tenn.When the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company built a 1.3 million squarefoot tire plant here in 1968, a lot of people were ini tially concerned over its pos sible effects on this small city in the northwest corner of Ten nessee.

title: STOCKS DECLINE; LATE GAINS MADE
description: The stock market declined yesterday for the fifth session in a row as volume slipped to its slowest pace in four weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Thaw in Korea: Seoul Is Hopeful but Wary
description: News Analysis

title: FARM PRICES RISE TO PEAK IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) Further increases for cattle and hogs helped send farm prices in July to a record for the second consecutive month, the Agriculture Department re ported today.

title: Open Selection
description: WASHINGTONWith gleeful antici pation, many Republicans kept wait ing for the Democratic Convention to tear itself apart because of the effects of party reform. They waited but noth ing much happened, and they lost their best hope for eliminating meaningful reform at the Republican Convention.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basket ball Association, has informed the Chicago Bulls that their request for transfer of ownership to Chicago Professional Sports Corporation had been rejected because it failed get the approval of 75 per cent of the N.B.A. owners.

title: Accounting Field Selects Head of New Foundation
description: The accounting profession, moving another step forward yesterday in its program to re form the way corporate finan cial reporting standards are set, named Ralph E. Kent, managing partner of Arthur Young & Co., to be president of the new fi nancial Accounting Foundation.

title: Roundup: Allen Clouts Two InsidePark Homers
description: Dick Allen said recently, This is the happiest I have been in my nine years in the majors.

title: 46,000 U.S. Soldiers Now Left in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31 (AP)American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 500 men last week, to a total of 46,000, the United States command announced today. This leaves 7,000 men to be sent home in five weeks to meet President Nixon's goal of 39,000 men in the country by Sept. 1.

title: Bridge: St. Louis Team Scores Upsets To Gain Tourney Semifinals
description: DENVER, July 31A St. Louis team that includes the first Negro player to reach the semifinals in the Amer ican Contract Bridge League national team championship took a lead of 34 interna tional match points over B. Jay Becker's New York four some after 36 deals in the Spingold Cup knockout event in the Summer Nationals to day.

title: House Votes for Sinking Of Ships to Create Reefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)  Legislation to permit the sinking of up to 144 sur plus Liberty ships for use as offshore artificial reefs to conserve marine life was passed today by the House, 325 to 2.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company disclosed yes terday that a subsidiary, the Aetna Variable Annuity Life Insurance Company, had sold the nation's first variable life insurance policy.

title: JERSEY RACE WON BY INTRODUCTIVO
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 Introductivo, who finished fourth in the Kentucky Derby, won the feature race at Mon mouth Park today, taking the 1 116mile Watch Your Step Purse from Aloft by 1 lengths. Silver Phantom was three lengths back in third place.

title: Eagleton Tells McGovern It Was the Only Decision
description: WASHINGTON, July 31A little after 8:30 tonight, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton left the Marble Room just off the Senate floor for the long walk down the underground corridor to his office building. At his side was Senator George McGovern, the Demo cratic candidate for the Presi dency. When they went into the Marble Room, Senator Eagleton was McGovern's running mate. When they left, Senator Eagleton knew it was all over.

title: STRATTON SEEKING TO BAR PROMOTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Representative Samuel S. Strat ton, Democrat of upstate New York, is seeking to block the promotion of a career United States diplomat accused of having helped suppress news of the Mylai killings.

title: Jonathan D. Springer Dies; Owned ReligiousBook Club
description: HUNTINGTON, LI., July 31 Jonathan D. Springer, who retired in 1970 as owner of the Book Club Guild, Inc., a re ligiousbook club, died yester day in Huntington Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 387 Asharoken Avenue, North port.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: In attempting to deal with an embarrassment of musk rats, the government of the Netherlands has endeavored to persuade the general pub lic that the sweetsmelling rodents, suitably roasted, are toothsome.

title: BID TO CURB I.B.M. BY TELEX DELAYED
description: Federal Court in Minneapolis announced yesterday that it will reserve judgment until noon today upon Telex Cor poration's request for a re straining order to prevent the International Business Machines Corporation from making an in troductory announcement Wed nesday about two new com puters.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., July 31 Mayor Thomas G. Dunn, a Dem ocrat and former chairman of the New Jersey Council of May ors, today announced his sup port of President Nixon's bid for reelection.

title: SCHRODER ADVISES BONNPEKING TIES
description: BONN, July 31Gerhard Schroder, a leading Opposition politician and chairman of the Foreign Policy Committee of the lower house of Parliament, said here today that the time was right for establishment of official tics between Bonn and Peking.

title: Polar Bear Treaty
description: A subcommittee of the House of Representatives has been holding hearings on a resolution calling for an international treaty to save the polar bear from becoming an endangered species. The majestic Arctic animal is not yet in that category but of the possibly 20,000 polar bears believed to he in existence, some 1,200 are killed every year by Russians, Canadians, Danes, Norwegians and Americans.

title: Film:
description: When you know, deep in your soul, that the lie you're tellin' is the truth to you why then you've got it!

title: SUCCESSOR SOUGHT
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, yielding to a request from Senator George McGovern, withdrew tonight from his cam paign for the VicePresidency. He said that he did not wish to divide the Democratic party by continuing as its nominee.

title: For Olympic Wrestlers, Ambition Is Expensive
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 31 Russ Camilleri pointed to the poster on the wall that read: Be Proud, Be a Part, Contribute to the U.S. Olym pic Team.

title: Citizens Panel in Detroit Asks CrossCounty Busing
description: DETROIT, July 31 (UPI) United States District Judge Stephen J. Roth's desegregation panel recommended today crossdistrict and crosscounty busing of nearly 350,000 chil dren in the nation's most sweeping plan for integrating urban schools.

title: Metropolitan Museum Opens Its Doors On Closed Day to Makers of a Movie
description: Yesterday, the Metropoli tan Museum's closed day, about 150 people clogged the Hall of Cypriot Antiquities and the Roman Sculpture Room nearby. Shooting had begun on From the Mixed Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler, a movie being made from a children's book by E. L. Konigsburg and di rected toward a family audi ence.

title: Vikings' Holdouts Fail to Score
description: Pro football's great holdout lingered on yesterday when Charlie West, a widely sought after cornerback, walked out of the Minnesota Vikings' train ing camp at Mankato, Minn., his contract still unsigned.

title: THAILAND CRASH KILLS FIVE ON B52
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 1 (AP)Three United States aircraft, includ ing a B52, crashed during a day of heavy air strikes against, North Vietnam and support missions for South Vietnamese troops, the United States com mand announced yesterday.

title: Nassau Supervisors Unveil Reapportionment Plan
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 31 The Nassau County Board of Supervisors disclosed its reap portionment plan ordered by the state's Court of Appeals  the first such plan in the state requiring more than a simple majority for passage of all leg islation.

title: Aussie Keeps Yacht Lead
description: TRAVEMUENDF, Germany, July 31 (UPI)Mike Bethwaite of Australia won the third heat in the Flying Dutchman race series today to maintain his overall lead in the class at the Travemuende Regatta week. With 2.9 points, Bethwaite led his class over two New Zea landers, John Bilger (6.1) and George Smale (9.9).

title: VANCE HEADS UNIT ON AMEX LEADERS
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday that Cyrus R. Vance, former Ambassador at Large for the United States and former chief negotiator at the Paris peace talks, had been elected chair man of a committee to nomi nate a new board of governors for the Amex.

title: Santamaria Band Adds Latin Touch To Festival of Soul
description: Latin soul was added to the mix of Soul at the Center last night when Mongo Santa maria's sevenpiece band fin ished off a program at Alice Tully Hall that started with Rod Rodgers's Dance Company.

title: Bantam, Paperback House, Sells Hardcover Rights to Maas Book
description: Bantam Books, which ordi narily buys reprint rights to bestsellers, has sold a book it commissioned a year ago to the Viking Press, a leading hardcover publisher.

title: 2 OUSTED IN HARLEM FROM HOSPITAL SITIN
description: The police ousted quietly yesterday the last of a group of East Harlem residents who for more than two months had occupied the Manhattan Up town Medical Center Building in a dispute over alleged un sanitary conditions at the four story center.

title: Ali Joins Cosell Team
description: Muhammad Ali has signed to be a boxing commentator for the American Broadcasting Company's Wide World of Sports coverage on Saturday of the United States Olympic box ing trials at West Point. Ali will team with Howard Cosell, A.B.C. said today.

title: Miss Rukwanichpong Bride Of Jeffrey Race in Bangkok
description: Miss Chumsri Rukwanich pong and Jeffrey Race, au thor and consultant to the State Department on Far Eastern Affairs, were mar ried in the traditional Thai ceremony on July 22 in Bangkok.

title: Continental Illinois to Expand
description: CHICAGO, July 31 (Reuters) The Continental Illinois Cor poration said today it had re ceived approval from the Fed eral Reserve Board to establish merchant banks in London and Hong Kong. The two new banks, along with a liaison office in Tokyo, will open before the end of summer. The London bank will be known as Continental Illinois, Ltd., and the Hong Kong bank, Continental Illinois (H K), Ltd.

title: NESTLE INCREASES ITS COFFEE PRICES
description: The Nestl Company, Inc., raised wholesale prices of its instant and freezedried coffees yesterday by one cent an ounce. The increase applies to all sizes of its Nescaf and Decaf instant coffees and Taster's Choice freezedried coffees, except twoounce sizes, which remain unchanged.

title: Papp Will Produce 13 Plays for C.B.S. in 4 Years
description: Joseph Papp and the New York Shakespeare Festival have entered into an agree ment with the Columbia Broad casting System to produce a series of fulllength plays for network television.

title: Advertising:
description: BBDO International, the parent company of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, has acquired Frank J. Cor bett, Inc., Chicago, an agency specializing in the health care field. Industry sources believe it to be the largest acquisition in this field. It was done through an ex change of stock.

title: Market Place:Underwriters' Track Record
description: Talk to some horseplayers and they'll tell you they bet the jockies, not the horses. Bet a Shoemaker, Cordero or Baezathey'll find the horse for you. That's the idea, any way.

title: Crash Hurts Proxmire Son
description: LANSDOWNE, Md., July 31 (AP) The 24yearold son of Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, was in jured seriously today in a two car accident on the Baltimore Beltway, the state police re ported. Theodore S. Proxmire was reported in fair condition at University Hospital in Balti more, the police said. He suf fered head cuts, the hospital said.

title: 13Man Olympic CanoeKayak Team Picked
description: BLOOMINGTON, Md, July 31 (AP)  America's newest Olympians, the canoe and kayak whitewater slalom racers, may be the first full United States team to arrive in Germany.

title: Tactful Priest Offers Calm as Fischer Second
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 31 Being Bobby Fischer's second in the 24game world cham pionship chess match here re quires the discretion of a priest in the confessional. So it might not have been chance that per suaded Fischer to select the Rev. William Lombardy, a Ro man Catholic priest and old friend, from among 10 United States grandmasters for the job.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ST. LOUIS, July 31Proud and tense, Senator Thomas F. Eagleton stepped into the hot spotlights of the Miami Beach Convention Center 18 days ago, took a deep breath and dedi cated his acceptance speech: This is for M.D.E.

title: Macy's Picks Vice President
description: Wallace Moore, manager of Macy's Huntington. L.I., store, has been named vice president and merchandise manager for women's and misses' dresses and coats for Macy's New York, it was announced yesterday. Aldo Papone has been appoint ed vice president and assistant general merchandise manager for junior readytowear, wo men's and misses' coats and furs.

title: Further Struggle Pledged
description: DUBLIN, July 31The Provi sional I.R.A., in a brief com ment on the British Army's oc cupation of Catholic strong holds in Northern Ireland, said today it had avoided a con frontation to prevent civilian casualties?

title: SOVIET AIDE VISITS A CENTER IN BRONX
description: Armed with a camera, an in terpreter and a pair of eyeglass es in his hand for instant use, Dr. Boris V. Petrovsky, the Soviet Union's Minister of Health, began a 10day visit to this country with a tour yester day of the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Health Center in the Bronx.

title: Cowboys' Top Draft Pick To Be Out Two Months
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., July 31 (UPI)The Dallas Cowboys announced today that Bill Thomas, their No. 1 draft choice, would be side lined at least two months because of complications re sulting from shoulder surgery.

title: 53 Cities, a 15Month Low. Have Unemployment of 6%
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) The Labor Department said today that its list of cities with unemployment of 6 per cent or more declined by one in July to 53, matching the lowest point in the last 15 months. Unem ployment of 6 per cent or more is described by the department as substantial.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE GREAT EXECUTIVE DREAM, By Robert Heller, 294 pages. Delacorte. $7.95.

title: India's Aid Policy Eases Rebel Threat in Nagaland
description: KOHIMA, India, July 20  The Naga tribes here in rug ged northeastern India, once fiercely rebellious, appear to be more interested in a visit by the Rev. Billy Graham later this year than in the independence issue that had pitted the hill dwelling sons and grandsons of headhunters against the Indian Army for more than a decade.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Steel Production Reverses Decline, Posts a 1.6% Gain for Week
description: Steel production for the week ended July 29 reversed the preceding week's decline and posted a gain of 1.6 per cent, the American iron and Steel Institute reported yester day. The industry poured a to tal of 2,356,000 net tons, com pared with 2,318,000 tons in the week ended July 22. The steel production index stood at 96.6. against 95 a week earlier.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI)Congressional Demo crats began a drive today to raise more than $1millionfor the party's Senate and House candidates.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Democratic leaders across the country said last night that Sen ator Thomas F. Eagleton's with drawal from the VicePresiden tial race, while personally sad, would strengthen the party's chances in the November elec tion.

title: Nixon Back In Capital
description: WASHINGTON. July 31 (AP)  President Nixon re turned to Washington this aft ernoon after attending the fu neral of Senator Ellender.

title: STATE IS CHECKING ON GROSS'S LICENSE
description: The last valid driver's license issued to Youth Services Com missioner Ted Gross expired in 1965, a preliminary search of computer records has shown, according to a spokesman for the State Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: SOUL AT CENTER IN CREATIVE DANCE
description: Poised between two esthetics, one of abstraction and the oth er of social action, Ron Rodg ers takes choreographic steps in both directions. Last night at Alice Tully Hall his contri bution to Soul at the Center was a strongly danced program of repertory works showing both sides of his creative pro file.

title: Ban on Voluntary Segregation Ordered by Top Marine General
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  The Marine Corps command ant, Gen. Robert E. Cushman Jr., today ordered an end to the voluntary segregation by race of Marines in living quarters on land and at sea.

title: Uruguay Soccer Shooting
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 31 (UPI)The police here are seeking two men and two wo men who shot two members of a soccer team to prevent them from scoring during a game here yesterday. The players, Julio Cesar d'Oliveira, 22 years old, and Jorge Danie Guerra, 30, were apparently about to score a goal when the four ran onto the field and shot Mr. Guerra in the groin and Mr. d'Oliveira in the ankle.

title: Weekend Fights
description: Kingston, JamaicaBunny Ster ling, 165 pounds, Britain, and Roy Lee, 162, Jamaica, drew, 10 rounds.

title: TARDY MAYNARD IS READY TO PLAY
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I, July 31 Don Maynard arrived in camp last night a full two weeks late, and today the Jets' longtime wide receiver was asked when he would be ready to play. Maynard checked his watch.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Senator George McGovern pro posed today that Congress re ject President Nixon's proposal to increase Pentagon spending. He suggested holding the de fense budget to last year's level.

title: JERSEY SENATE UNIT SETS KUGLER STUDY
description: TRENTON, July 31  The Senate Committee on Law, Public Safety and Defense will discuss on Wednesday allega tions that the office of Attor ney General George F. Kugler Jr., failed to act on information it had in October, 1970, to the effect that Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin tried to fix a state highway contract, until a Federal grand jury began an investigation last April.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Following are transcripts of statements by Senators George McGovern and Thom as F. Eagleton as a news con ference this evening on Sen ator Eagleton's withdrawal as a VicePresidential nominee, as transcribed by The New York Times, and of excerpts from questions and answers at the news conference, as transcribed by The Times through the facilities of A.B.C. News:

title: Advertising:
description: The Italian Line, whose four ships compose the larg est passenger fleet in trans Atlantic service, had a bit of a marketing problem: How do you fill the tourist section designed for immigrants when even the poorest of them go less expensively by air?

title: DR. MARGARET CROSBY
description: WOODSTOCK, Vt., Aug. 1 Dr. Margaret Crosby, a retired archeologist long active in the excavation of the Agora of ancient Athens under the aus pices of the American School of Classical Studies, died Sun day in a Hanover (N.H.) nurs ing home. She was 70 years old and lived in Barnard, Vt.

title: Players Lining Up for a Game Called Mayoralty
description: The game is called Mayor alty. Any number can play, and they already are. One of the features of the game, though, is that no one, not even the other contestants, knows how many, or, except in a couple of casesRep resentatives Mario Biaggi and Herman Badillowho they are.

title: Cannabis in Canada
description: The Canadian Government is not expected to legalize the use and possession of marijuana, despite a special governmental study recommending this step. It is, however, expected to reduce drastically the penalties associated with marijuana. This movement to liberalize drug laws in Canada comes when a countermovement seems to be gaining headway in the United States.

title: GEORGE A. INGALLS
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 1 George A. Ingalls, vice chair man until his retirement last year of AMP Inc., manufactur ers of electric wire terminals and connectors in Harrisburg, Pa., died today in Community Hospital in Glen Cove. He was 72 years old and lived on Whit ney Lane here.

title: Lorin Willis, ExProsecutor Of Fairfield County, Dead
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 1 (AP)Lorin W. Willis, a retired Fairfield County prosecutor whose investigation into irreg ularities in land acquisition for the Merritt Parkway resulted in a series of convictions, died today. He was 79 years old and lived here.

title: City Council Termed Ineffectual by Citizens Union
description: The Citizens Union yesterday branded the 37member City Council as an ineffectual legis lative body dealing in matters of only trifling Importance.

title: Miss Nancy Jane Novogrod Wed to Richard Joseph Ney
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 1 The marriage of Miss Nan cy Jane Novogrod to Richard Joseph Ney took place at the Sunningdale Country Club here this evening. Rabbi Law rence Schwartz performed the ceremony.

title: SWISS BANKERS DEFEND SECRECY
description: LUGANO, Switzerland, Aug. 1Tortuous negotiations be tween Switzerland and the United States to try to reach an accord on the subject of Swiss bank secrecy, which un til recently seemed close to success, are now likely to be prolonged. According to Swiss sources, no agreement is likely before the end of this year.

title: Some Defendants Expected to Agree In Suit on Westec
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1About 20 of the 90 defendants in the $40 million damage suits filed against the Westec Corporation are expected to agree to $1.6 million in partial payments at an Aug. 31 hearing in Federal Court here.

title: Valenzuela Escapes Injury
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 1 (UPI)  Ismael Valenzuela was thrown to the ground today when his mount stumbled in midstretch during a race at Del Mar but the rider escaped in jury. Valenzuela's mount, Sportingly, a 95 favorite in the fourth race, clipped the heels of High Decision nearing the sixteenth pole, stumbled and fell. The rider was pitched over his horse's head.

title: Fischer and Spassky Draw In 9th Game of Title Chess
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 1 Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky played to a draw to day in the ninth game of their 24game world championship chess match. Each player thus gained half a point, making the score 5 to 3 in favor of Fischer. The American chal lenger now needs 7 points to win the title and Spassky needs 8 to retain it.

title: ELESBERG OFFERS 2 VIEWS ON DELAY
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1  Daniel Ellsberg said today that he had not been consulted be fore his lawyers asked Justice William O. Douglas to stay the Pentagon papers trial and that he had initially found the pros pect of a long trial delay ap palling,

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The Nixon Administration has de cided that no matter what may result from the Soviet military withdrawal from Egypt, the United States would gain noth ing by doing anything at this rime about the unfolding situa tion in the Middle East.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: FERNDALE, N.Y., Aug. 1 (UPI)  Officials at Votes Unlimited Corporation, which had manufactured a half million campaign buttons, bumper stickers and ball point pens with Senator Thomas F. Eagleton's name no them, feared the worst when he withdrew from the Democratic ticket.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey to Get Storm Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz today declared New Jersey a disaster area in the wake of Hurricane Agnes. Farm ers' in all 21 counties can re ceive Farmers' Home Adminis, tration emergency assistance.

title: Right to Privacy In Abortion Cases Decreed by Court
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice in Manhattan yesterday struck down a city requirement that the name and address of a woman who undergoes an abortion be included in the fe tal death certificate.

title: Metropolitan Lends 115 Works For Display by Tokyo Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum has lent 115 works of art from its collections to the Tokyo Na tional Museum for a show open ing there Sunday. The largest international loan exhibition in the Metropolitan's history, it in cludes objects from antiquity to the early 20th century and highlights Greek and Roman sculpture, medieval ivories and major paintings.

title: Disney Goes on Parade at the Garden
description: The Madison Square Gar den people were asked early yesterday why the third edi tion of Disney on Parade was opening at 2:00 P.M. in stead of last night. Because it's for the kids, was the reply, pegging the show.

title: Prosecutor on Defense
description: George F. Kugler Jr. was political unknown in Janu ary, 1970, when Gov. William T. Cahill named him New Jer sey's Attorney General.

title: INTERIOR AIDE FEARS GASOLINE SHORTAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) Assistant Interior Secretary, Hollis M. Dole testified today that some parts of nation might experience a gasoline shortage before fall and predicted trou ble, trouble, trouble with all forms of energy.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 1 Gov. Edwin Edwards today appointed his wife, Elaine, to fill the unexpired term of Senator Allen J. Ellender, who died July 27 at the age of 81.

title: Israel Tries 2 Arab Women in Hijacking
description: RISHON LE ZION, Israel, Aug. 1  Two young Arab women accused of participat ing in the hijacking in May of a Sabena airliner bound for the Tel Aviv airport went on trial today before a military tribunal.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STATELINE, Nev., Aug. 1 (AP)  The Minnesota Vikings and Dallas Cowboys in the National Conference and the Baltimore Colts and Oakland Raiders in the American Conference are the favorites to battle for con ference titles in the National Football League this fall, according to Harrah's Tahoe racebook.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Seven leading Democrats from New York and New Jer sey said yesterday that they preferred Lawrence F. O'Brien for the Democratic VicePresi dential nomination as a means of unifying the party.

title: American Plays Black but Sets Game's Tempo
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 1  In the ninth game of the world championship chess match here today, Bobby Fisch er chose a Tarrasch Defense against Boris Spassky's Queen's Gambit.

title: L.I. Trust Is Sought
description: Merck & Co., Inc., the chemi cal and pharmaceutical concern, said yesterday that it had ten tatively agreed to buy the Kelco Company, a privately held West Coast specialty chemical corn pany, for nearly $87million in stock.

title: Market Place Arguments Due In Tangled Case
description: Are the tangled affairs of GambleSkogmo, Inc., and the defunct General Outdoor Ad vertising Company about to be unraveled?

title: Landslide in Spain Kills 4
description: CEDILLO, Spain, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Four Spanish labor ers were killed yesterday and five others were buried and be lieved dead in a landslide on the site of a dam under con struction near here. One man was pulled from the rubble with only slight injuries.

title: WAYS TO DETECT ALCOHOLISM SET
description: The National Council of Al coholism, asserting that only about one in 300 physicians is capable of accurately diagnos ing alcoholism, has established the first set of criteria to help doctors detect and prevent this health problem.

title: An Encore for Ukrainians
description: In response to heavy public demand, the Ukrainian Dance Company will present an addi tional performance at the Met ropolitan Opera House on Sun day at 7:30 P.M., it was an nounced yesterday by Sol Hurok, the impresario who sponsors the group.

title: LILLIAN LITTLE
description: Miss Lillian Little, an actress long active in the New York Association for the Blind, where she directed the Lighthouse Players, died Sunday in Doctors Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived at 51 Greenwich Ave nue.

title: City Parking Garage Opens on East Side
description: The City Traffic Depart ment opened a fivelevel ga rage yesterday at Essex and Delancey Streets on the Lower East Side.

title: Penn Central Fares Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) The Price Commission ap proved today a 19.92 per cent increase in passenger fares on the Penn Central's Harlem and Hudson divisions. The increase went into affect July 1. The extra revenue will allow the Penn Central to recover a greater portion of its costs for furnishing the service to the Metropolitan Transportation Au thority, the commission said.

title: Registering the Voters
description: The strenuous but sporadic efforts being made by volunteer workers to register voters at ramshackle card tables on busy midtown sidewalks reflect both individual enterprise and official neglect. Volunteers perform useful public service by donating their time to this com munity voter registration effort, but the effort would be far less necessary if the State Legislature had enacted overdue electoral reforms.

title: Prague Sentences Three in Leaflets Trial
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 1 (Reuters) Prof. Milan Huebl, former rec tor of the Czechoslovak Com munist party's college, was sentenced today to six and a half years in prison on charges of subversion.

title: 9 in 11 Mackell's Office Cited In a Tax Evasion Inquiry
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens disclosed yesterday that nine members of his staffincluding Assistant District Attorney James D. Robertson, his soninlawwere among those under Federal investigation to determine whether they evaded income taxes on an alleged getrich scheme.

title: Italian Press Dispute Ends
description: ROME, Aug. 1A dispute that caused Sunday and Mon day editions of most newspa pers not to appear for over a month was resolved yesterday when printers and publishers reached a new agreement on Sunday pay rates. The problem had arisen when publishers, say ing that Sunday overtime rates had become prohibitive, cut out Monday editions. Newsmen and printers responded with strikes.

title: Kissinger Meets Privately With Hanoi Aides Again
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The White House disclosed this morning that Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, con ferred privately today for the second time in less than two weeks with North Vietnamese negotiators in Paris.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1  The Soviet press, which has hereto for ignored the Eagleton con troversy entirely, suggested to day that the Senator's liberal views were a factor in his re moval and speculated that Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts might be his re placement.

title: NAUMBURG CONCERT IS LED BY BOYD NEEL
description: Reviews of outdoor concerts tend to become weather re ports. Monday night's program by the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra on the Central Park Mall was no exception. Periodic rainfall during the day and overcast skies kept the audi ence limited to 200 people and 3 dogs. Even the food and softdrink venders stayed away. A fine mist descended at times, but the kind of rain that makes umbrellas suddenly mushroom did not fall until the second part of the program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Communism: 125 Years Later
description: BELGRADEThe crisis of Commu nism will inevitably change the position and the role of the working class indeed it is already changing it. The nature of that crisis shows this more clearly than do the eruptions of work ers' dissatisfaction (Hungary in 1956, Poland in 1970). True, the crisis of Communism and the dissatisfaction of workers ara linked. Moreover, the workers' dissatisfaction makes that crisis more obvious and deepens it drastically. Nonetheless, these dissatis factions are more a reaction against shameful abuse and intolerable condi tions than they are against the social position of the working class or against the monopoly of the dogmatic bu reaucracy over the working class. The crisis of the party bureaucracy is, how ever, a lasting one and Is reflected In the entire society and in its further development.

title: LINDA RONSTADT GIFTED AS SINGER
description: Linda Ronstadt's performance Monday night at Paul Colby's Bitter End underlined some of the contradictions in the work of this fine, countrystyled singer.

title: Wheelabrator Sets Split
description: Stockholders of Wheelabra torFrye, Inc., approved yester day a proposal for a onefor three reverse split of the com mon stock, reducing shares outstanding to 7,856,880 of 30 cents par value from 23,570, 641 shares of 10 cents par value. Authorized common stock was reduced to 16 million from 35 million shares.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 1 (AP)Senator Jack Miller, Republican, scored an easy vic tory in his bid for renomination today, swamping the chal lenger, Ralph Scott, in the Iowa primary election.

title: State Denies Relief Funds to the City For Failure to Begin Incentive Plan
description: The state has invoked its first sanctions against New York City for the city's failure to begin operating a controver sial welfare demonstration proj ect scheduled to start yester day in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: MOST OF MANILA SWEPT BY FLOODS
description: MANILA, Aug. 1 (AP)Rising, flood waters swept across most of the greater Manila area and 14 provinces of Luzon Island today in the worst natural dis aster in Philippine history.

title: SANDERS WINNER IN U.S. MAT TRIAL
description: COON RAPIDS, Minn., Aug. 1 One great wrestler made the Olympic freestyle team tonight because another great one couldn't.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Some people get into fash ion designing for unusual reasons. Take Anne Drew Fox, a slender 21yearold with curtains of dark hair. She started out to be an il lustrator  but people liked the clothes I drew better than the figures I drew them on.

title: TelexMovetoRestrainI.B.M.Denied
description: Judge Philip Neville in Federall District Court in Minneapolis denied yesterday motions by the Telex Corporation seeking to restrain the International Business Machines Corporation from introducing two new com, puler systems today.

title: Phillips, on Stand, Admits Graft but Denies 2 Killings
description: Patrolman William R. Phillips denied in a packed courtroom here yesterday that he had anything to do with the 1968 Christmas Eve murders of pimp and a prostitute and the attempted murder that night of one of the proititute's customers.

title: Executive Changes
description: W. H. Krome George, president of the Alumi num Company of America has been appointed to the new position of chief operating officer.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The forced withdrawal of Senator Thomas F. Eagleton as Demo cratic VicePresidential nomi nee drew intensified criticism today from Missouri politicians. But in Congress, and elsewhere around the country, political comment was generally muted.

title: NICKLAUS RATED FAVORITE IN P.G.A. Sore Finger Regarded by Most as Insignificant
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 1Sore finger or no sore fin ger, Jack Nicklaus is regarded as the man to beat in the Pro fessional Golfers Association championship that begins here Thursday.

title: F.P.C, IS PRESSED ON ALGERIAN GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The natural gas industry, supported by the Department of the In terior, has brought heavy pres sure to bear on the Federal Power Commission to modify what the commission described as consumerprotection clauses in its approval of the proposed importation of liquefied natural gas from Algeria.

title: John Klempner, 74, Novelist And Screen Writer, Dead
description: John Klempner, a novelist and film writer, died Sunday in Redondo Beach, Calif., where he was living. He was 74 years old.

title: In an Ulster Village, Death Takes No Sides
description: CLAUDY, Northern Ire land, Aug. 1  Claudy, as they say here, is only a wee village. Its population of 1,300 is so evenly divided between Catholics and Prot estants that no one can say which is in the majority. Yes terday, when three bombs were set off here, the casual ties were almost as evenly divided.

title: Visit to the Barber an Epicurean Delight
description: There are haircuts and shaves to be had at the bar ber shop called Francois As sociates at 551 Madison Ave nue from 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. But in the middle of the day, everything slops for a super lunch, cooked by the shop's owner Joseph Laporte.

title: Indian Harbor Girls Score In Long Island Sailing Series
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 1  The Indian Harbor Yacht Club crew, with Anne Preston at the helm, won the opening race of the final roundrobin of the 34th annual Long Island (Sound girls championship re gatta today by 1 minute 50 seconds.

title: France Said to Conclude Series of Nuclear Tests
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Wednesday, Aug. 2 (Reuters) France today lifted the ban on flights over the nuclear test area in the South Pacific, con firming that her recent series of tests at Muroroa Atoll is concluded.

title: U.S IS CRITICIZED ON BLACK JOBLESS
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1The Na tional Urban League charged to day in a report on black unem ployment that the Federal Gov ernment misrepresented the jobless rate in the nation's hardcore black poverty areas.

title: S.E.C. to Shift Personnel In OverAll Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON., Aug. 1A reorganization of the Securities and Exchange Commission that will also bring major person nel changes was announced to day by William J. Casey, the commission's chairman.

title: Rurels Change Foreseen
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 1 (UPI)The secretary of Moose Lodge 107 said today that the organization would change its rules rather than comply with the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruling.

title: 5 IN SOUTH AFRICA LEAVE THE CABINET
