description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The na tion's transportation problem can be simply stated. 80 per cent of the peo ple live on 2 per cent of the land. How can these masses be moved about most efficiently in such congested space?

title: Junior Bonner Is a Rodeo Family CloseUp
description: The old West, whose pass ing was so beautifully re called by Sam Peckinpah in The Wild Bunch and The Ballad of Cable Hogue, never really died. It lives on at least on weekends and holidaysas a particularly robust kind of regional show business, the circuit rodeo, whose actors travel in beat up Chrysler convertibles, their horses transported in trailers attached to rear bumpers.

title: Bridge: Becker's Team Easy Victor In Spingold Knockout Fina;
description: DENVER, Aug, 2B. Jay Becker of New York, cele brating his 40th year in na tional bridge competition, and his son, Michael, won the Spingold Cup knockout team championship by 81 inter national match points last night in the Summer Nation als of the American contract Bridge League.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your editorial of July 18 regarding the investigation into rumors of gun running to Northern Ireland all but ignored the outrageous behavior of the Department of Justice. You should have written four editorials, The super ficial one you have already published.

title: SPITZ SETS MARK IN 200 BUTTERFLY
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) Mark Spitz of Carmichael, Calif., shattered the world rec ord for the second time in eight hours in the 200meter butterfly tonight as he led the Olympic qualifying for the event.

title: Advertising:
description: Interviewing a Timesman is a unique experience, especial ly if he's very, very British and his Times isn't your Times.

title: Advertising:
description: The Marine Corps, sempler fidelis, has decided to stay with J. Walter Thompson. So the two organizations will now enter their 25th year to gether with a contract that runs through June of 1976.

title: TRIALS OF LIBERALS DEFENDED IN PRAGUE
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 2 (Reuters) The Communist party news paper, Rude Pravo, today de fended the legality of Czech oslovakia's trials of liberals on charges of subversion.

title: Notes on People
description: Secretary of Defense Mel vin R. Laird mentioned Gov ernor Rockefeller and former Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally as qualified to succeed him at the Penta gon. Mr. Laird, repealing his intention to resign Jan. 20, named Deputy Defense Sec retary Kenneth Rush as an other possible successor. Mr. Laird was careful to say he was not advocating a partic ular successor and that he had not discussed the sub ject with President Nixon. But during a talk with news men in St. Louis, the Secre tary gave the impression that his personal favorite was Mr. Rockefeller.

title: Brother of Sirhan Charged With Disturbing the Peace
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. (AP)A brother of Sirhan B. Sirhan, the assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, pleaded not guilty today to a charge of disturbing the peace.

title: Disease and Rising Water Beset Stricken Luzon
description: MANILA, Aug. 2 (AP)A sharp increase in disease, plus exhausted fuel supplies, mon soon rains and rising flood wa ters, kept Luzon Islanders struggling today with the worst calamity in their history.

title: F.D.A. BANS DRUG LINKED TO CANCER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Food and Drug Administration halted today the introduction into cattle feed of a growth stimulating hormone that has been linked to cancer, and banned its use entirely after Jan. 1.

title: Pupils Demand EqualEducation In a Suit Over School Funding
description: Sixteen publicschool chil dren from school districts throughout the state filed a complaint in Federal Court here yesterday, charging that the state's system of using local property taxes to finance dis trict schools denies them their constitutional right to equal education because rich com munities spend more per pupil than poor communities do.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Justice Department an nounced today a proposed antitrust consent settlement that would prevent a large North Carolina bank from reserving to itself the right to install certain banking facilities in new enclosedmall shopping center. The settlement involved the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company of WinstonSalem. It would take out provisions of a contract with the lessor of space in the Holly Hill mall shopping center that allowed Wachovia to install and maintain a night depository within the mall while barring other banks from doing so.

title: Bridge Repairs Completed
description: Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority officials announced yesterday that the ban on ve hicles weighing more than 7,000 pounds on the Bronx section of the Triborough Bridge had been lifted. The ban was imposed on the section as a result of da mage caused to the structure by a fivealarm warehouse fire beneath the bridge on June 27.

title: Business Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug., 2The Chilean central bank devalued the escudo against the dollar through readjust ments in several exchange rates announced today. The special payments rate, such as that given to foreign visitors, was raised from 42 to 46 for a dollar. The rate for Chileans buying dollars to go abroad was increased from 42 to 85. However, the taxes on foreign travel are such that the effective rate is actually 134 escudos.

title: BIG BOARD FIRM TO FACE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had ordered a public hear ing in a case involving charges of gross misconduct against Middendorf, Colgate & Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, the firm's managing partner, and a former top Republican offi cial in the District of Colum bia.

title: LEWIS FREEDMAN RESIGNS AT P.B.S.

title: Gold Boom
description: In the London and Paris free markets, the price of gold spurted above $70 an ounce this week, an alltime record. But, under the twotier system established by the major industrial nations in March, 1968, the official price of gold is little more than half as much$38. The question raised by the soaring free market price is whether the two  tier system can endure much longer or whether there soon must be a doubling or more of the official gold price maintained by governments and central banks.

Mr. BaduraSkoda and Mr. Dennis, those well  matched masters of the intimate re cital, offered music for solo piano, piano fourhands and two pianos, performing every thing with genial grace and deliberate understatement.

title: 'The Magnificent Seven Ride!' Routinely!
description: Routine Westerns aren't so common these days that I should want to dismiss any one of them out of hand. But George McCowan's "The Magnificent Seven Ride!", which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is a routine Western so perfunctory in its routines that I can't recommend it even to people who, like me, delight in seeing the same thing done all overand overagain.The magnificent seven this time consist of an Arizona marshal (Lee Van Cleef,) a mildly unscrupulous journalist (Michael Callan) and five convicts who the marsal paroles so they can help him defend the women and children of a border town from a band of desperadoes that have massacred all their men.By the time the battle is over, all the right people have been killed (including four of the five convicts) and Lee Van Cleef has fallen in love with the prettiest of the town's new-made widows (Stefanie Powers), and the journalist has also fallen in love and has discovered in himself a sense of moral discrimination. This last has no purpose, but the movie makes rather a thing of it, and perhaps it adds tone to the aura of the happy ending.But the happy ending is a betrayal anyway, signifying that nothing of much importance has happened, despite the 100 minutes and maybe 50 killings that have gone before. Westerns usually deal best with the impermanence of happiness, and "The Magnificent Seven Ride!" would have been no exception if it had been made with the conscience and the care for certain ritual patterns of action that it might have deserved. But as it actually was made, it is sloppy in detail. And in theme, plot and character it is merely trivial.

title: Soul Festival: To See, to Hear, to Enjoy
description: Roland Smith, a 26year old poet, was so moved by the singing of Patti Labelle Sunday night that he jumped on the stage at Philharmonic Hall and began singing and dancing with her. No one pulled him roughly off the stage as fans are handled at rock concerts. Instead, the lead singer of the Labelle soul trio incorporated the young black man into her perform ance.

title: Personalities: Hayes Signs Again
description: The Big E, somewhat re luctantly, signed yesterday for the Big $. It may not be the best we could have done, said Al Ross, the law yer for Elvin Hayes, but it's well in excess of a million dollars for five years. Hayes, a 6foot9inch cen ter, was traded recently from the Houston Rockets to the Baltimore Bullets. The Bullets assumed they would take over Hayes's 10year con tract, worth $1million, In stead, Hayes balked and threatened not to play for the Bullets unless they re negotiated a new deal. The old contract had six years remaining. Ross contended it was invalid since it was signed in California, where contracts in excess of seven years are illegal. Hayes has averaged 27.4 points and 16.3 rebounds through four Na tional Basketball Association seasons. He joins Wes Un seld, also an outstanding col lector of rebounds. I've al ways felt that the best rebounding teams are the ones that win, said Hayes. Right now, I can't see any teams that are going to re bound better than us.

title: Instant Morality:'Kansas City Bomber' Stars Raquel Welch
description: I can see the appeal the roller games had for a movie project like "Kansas City Bomber." Fast, loud, tough and violent, they provide an instant morality play with ready-made good guys, bad guys, comic interludes, and with all the incorruptibility of Saturday-night wrestling. They also provide a certain sado-masochistic kick. At least, that seems the case for this movie, in which gorgeous K. C. Carr, the Bomber herself, gets publicly beaten to a pulp, apparently at five-minute intervals, by competitors on the skating track and yet never stops coming back for more.Raquel Welch plays K.C., a basically nice girl, in the business less for blood than for money. She has two problems: the blandishments of wily roller games promoter Burt Henry and the resentment of aging roller games star Jackie Burdette, whose fading light K.C. is expected to replace. There are other problems as well, such as will K.C. ever be accepted as just part of the team, the Portland (Ore.) Loggers, despite her unpopular eminence and her superior dcolletage. But the first two are the important ones, and they suggest the quite stunning simpleness of what "Kansas City Bomber" is all about.Jerrold Freedman has directed "Kansas City Bomber" with an eye to hard-hitting action and gutsy detail. But I don't think his eye is really sharp enough or fast enough or even wide enough open. His roller-games scenes seem authentic but rather unexciting; and his major stylistic contribution is to indulge a penchant for zooming his camera back, leaving characters trapped behind windows in pretentious and often ludicrous dramatic isolation.At one point he has K.C. get out of a cab, tell the driver to wait, and then waltz off with Burt Henry, and never return to pay the fare. So far as I am concerned, that meter is still ticking.According to the M-G-M press material, Barry Sandler wrote "Kansas City Bomber" especially for Raquel Welch as his master's thesis at U.C.L.A. Whether or not he got his degree, he has created for Miss Welch a part for which she is absolutely adequateallowing her both to show deep emotion and to roller skate. No such laurels for Kevin McCarthy, who plays Burt Henry like a man braving out a suspicion that he has butter on his chin.But the film's one incredible performance comes from Helena Kailianiotes, as Jackie Burdette. Slouching sullenly in doorways, staring moodily into space, cadging booze from a bottle hidden in a skating boot, she goes to the dogs with an inappropriate passion rich enough to suggest an over-the-hill Sarah Bernhardt being traded off to the minors by the Comdie Franaise."Kansas City Bomber" opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.

title: Books of The Times
description: Today we're going back to the beginning considerably short of Genesisto chil dren's picture books. Hold on! Don't turn away. You think you're not interested? You've put on years and pounds and would rather contend with more sophisticated elements of literature? But surely you know a child somewhere, have a son, niece, grandchild, friend or any combination thereof. It is to be hoped that someday they'll be readers, inheritors of the word and world. The picture book is very often their first exposure to art and literature. It is important that first experiences in reading, or being read to, encourage further adventures in books. Bad experiences will leave the child indifferent to literature, turn him to TV, comics, plastics or worse. He'll be a nonreader, ignoring the treasures of the past and the occasional nuggets of the present.

Mrs. Litvinov, according, to ac quaintances, has been pri vately critical of some aspects of the Soviet system, but is not an activist. One of her grandsons, Pavel Litvinov, is serving a fiveyear term in exile in Siberia for taking part in a 1968 demonstration in Red Square, protesting the slovakia.

title: Juilliard Class Gives 18 to New Troupe
description: The Acting Company, a new repertory troupe built around the 18 men and women from the first graduating class of the Juilliard School's drama di vision, is turning professional Sept. 28. It will offer a rotating schedule of six plays at the Good ShepherdFaith Church, 152 West 66th Street.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: Now that Senator Eagleton has raised the question of treatment for mental health for public officials, one may well ask: How many public servants in government today would be willing to undergo an examination of their mental and emotional health?

title: Insults Are Traded at Paris Peace Talks
description: PARIS, Aug. 3Delegates to the Vietnam conference here traded sharp insults at their 153d session today.

title: BUYS, PARKER LOSE IN YACHTING SERIES
description: GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 3  number of undefeated skippers competing in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Asso ciation's Race Week Regatta was reduced to five today with the competition in most of the classes tightening up. Stanley Buys, who had three straight in the Narrasketuck Class, fin ished fifth today in the race captured by Aileen Eppig, while Colin Parker who was a three time winner among the Finns, was second behind Bob Powell.

title: S. E. C. TO EXPEDITE MEMBERSHIP ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Securities and Exchange Coin mission disclosed today its in tention to try to ban institu tional membership on stock ex changes without the prolonged public hearings that had been expected.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 3 (UPI)The Guest in Munich Foundation announced today that it had of fered to pay the expenses of the Sierra Leone team in the Olympic Games.

title: CHARLES GRAVES, 61; CHILDREN'S AUTHOR
description: Charles Parlin Graves, who wrote more than 20 children's books, died Wednesday of can cer in Phelps Memorial Hospi tal, North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived in IrvingtononHudson, N.Y.

title: Fire Base Bastogne Is Reported Retaken
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Aug. 4The Saigon com mand said yesterday that. South Vietnamese troops had reoc cupied Fire Base Bastogne, a Government defense point on the northern front that was abandoned a week ago in the face of intense North Viet namese shelling and ground at tacks.

title: Witnesses Begin a Parley At Aqueduct Race Track
description: More than 27,000 Jehovah's Witnesses gathered at Aque duct Race Track in Ozone Park, Queens, yesterday for the start of a fourday convention.

title: Fischer Expected to Encounter No Trouble in Gaining Victory
Many Black Banks Had 1971 Losses
description: Almost half of the nation's black banksthat is, banks owned and managed by Ne groeslost money in 1971, an analysis of figures published by the Federal Reserve System, showed yesterday.

title: LESTER V. ANTLE, 58, OF LETTUCE CONCERN
description: SALINAS, Calif. Aug. 3 (AP) Lester V. (Bud) Antle, who started and directed the world's largest lettuce growing and shipping firm, died Tuesday. He was 58 years old.

title: BREAK WITH TAIPEI IS SEEN BY TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3The Japa nese Government disclosed to day that it expected Tokyo's diplomatic relations with the Chinese Nationalist Govern ment in Taipei to be broken when Tokyo establishes diplo matic ties with China's Com munist Government in Peking.

title: Would You Buy Used Platforms From Them?
description: PHILADELPHIAPurists are apt to deplore the political imagebuilding that resembles ads for detergents, cars or beer. Analogies nonetheless are in evitable because identical audiences are sought.

title: Screen: 'New Centurions':Police Patrol and Fate Make for Melodrama
description: Richard Fleischer's "The New Centurions" is an intermittently exciting, sometimes preachy, sometimes ironic, occasionally successful film about the lives of some fictional patrol-car cops on the Los Angeles police force. Loosely based on the Joseph Wambaugh novel of the same name, it is an awkwardly modern movie. Modern not so much in its attitudes toward cops (which are really pretty traditional) as in its attitudes towards fate.Thus, when one young policeman on duty turns to another and announces excitedly "I'm getting married!", anybody who has ever seen a movie knows what must happen. But what actually does happen is that within five minutes that other cop is shot to deaththough in fairness to established plot devices I should add that he also was thinking of getting married and that he was, more or less, the hero of the film.Somewhere, not too deep, inside "The New Centurions" is the soul of an old-fashioned B-movie police-force melodrama; the kind with a rookie cop and a kindly old sergeant and perhaps the sergeant's daughter. The traditional roles are much attenuated but they are there in Roy (Stacy Keach), the young patrolman; Kilvinsky (George C. Scott), his philosophic partner, about to retire; and Lorrie (Rosalind Cash), who comes along with the right proportion of sex, warm human values and chicken dinners just as Roy seems ready to go off the deep end because of a divorce, loneliness for Kilvinsky and a lost sense of vocation.Lorrie happens to be black, and she's not the sergeant's daughter, but she does belong to that particular world of hearth and home, of something to be protected, that has always been the moral anchor of the police movie. That she and what she represents have scarcely more than anecdotal importance in "The New Centurions" suggests a partial rejection of some values; and the film has nothing really to take their place. Between Roy and Kilvinsky there is much talk about the end of law and order (the film's title includes an analogy with the decline of ancient Rome), but no dramatic sense of what that might mean.Compared with a real law-and-order tragedy, like Don Seigel's "Madigan" (1967), "The New Centurions" seems an oddly cold and unimpassioned construction. Its adventures are sometimes interesting (there is a fine, brief bank robbery sequence), but they are more often dully exemplary or merely gratuitous. I have rarely seen a movie in which so much could have been cut out without changing anything, and it is difficult to care about an action film that has no ideas about its events.Fleischer's direction is technically adequate and emotionally absent. He does not so much direct actors as provide a void for them to filland among the principals, George C. Scott is almost shamefully good at filling voids and Stacy Keach is not. But it is possible to develop some sympathy for Keach, striving for a plain unmannered performance and impeded half the time by a pair of glasses and a little mustache that make him resemble nothing so much as a younger, trimmer Richard Attenborough.

title: Paul Goodman, Author, Reformer, Iconoclast, Dies
description: NORTH STRATFORD, N. H., Aug. 3  Paul Goodman, the writer, therapist and social critic who has been called the father figure of the New Left, died here at his farm last night after suffering his third heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: Testimony Ends in Phillips Trial Here
description: In what turned out to be the last day of testimony in the Phillips trial, the prosecu tion yesterday rebutted an at tempt by Patrolman William R. Phillips to explain the entry of Case of Smith, which he had made in his police mem orandum book for Dec. 24, 1968  the day he is accused of killing James Smith and Sharon Stango.

title: Ejected Boy Kills Lifeguard
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) A 16yearold boy who had been ejected from a public pool by a lifeguard returned later and shot the lifeguard to death with a pistol, the police say. The victim, Willie Huggins, IS, was pronounced dead at the scene in Exposition Park yes terday. The alleged assailant, whose name was not released, was arrested two hours later and booked for investigation of murder.

title: Alaskan Natives Ponder How to Dispose of $962.5Million From Land Claims
description: ANCHORAGE A vast infu sion of wealth, the greatest ever to go to any North Ameri can aborigines, has started to trickle into the Arctic villages, Indian camps and crude huts out in the Bush.

title: Pat Pazzetti, Football Star, Bethlehem Aide 50 Years
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 3 Vincent J. (Pat) Pazzetti Jr., a football star at Lehigh College 60 years ago who won election to the National Football Founda tion's Hall of Fame in 1961, died today at his home here. He was 82 years old.

title: Market Place: Telex and I.B.M. Open New Bout
description: When you build a tag along company and the be hemoth you are tailing drops a kingsized pebble in the path, you are likely to get tripped up.

title: Wondering Where to Dine? 2 Restaurants Worth a Try
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none). ?? Villa Pensa, 198 Grand Street, CA 68830.

title: Credit Markets
description: A new doubleA corporate bond Issue was offered yester day at substantially lower returns to investors than three similarly rated issues last week, reflecting the gradual but steady improvement in this sector of the credit market in recent sessions.

title: Prospects for Fishing and Boating This Weekend
description: AREA AAlong the Jersey shore bottom fishing for fluke is good, especially with smelts and squid as bait. The blues are starting to move in and can be taken on the Shrewsbury rocks by using smelts and bunker backs. They're running better at night, a mile or two off the beaches. The blues are run ning 3 to 10 pounds.

title: Arts to Rival Athletics at Olympics
description: MUNICH, West Germany The Olympic Games, which will open here on Aug. 26, are likely to come closer to the Greek ideal than any of their modern predecessors in at least one aspect: the ex cellence of the cultural events that will accompany the sports competitions.

title: Executive Changes
description: Herbert Lewis has been appointed vice presidentgroup insurance electronics for the Metropolitan Lifo Insurance Company.

title: Prefontaine Smashes U.S. Mark in 3,000Meter Run at Oslo
description: OSLO, Aug. 3Capping an incredible 24hour double that underscored his Olympic fit ness, Steve Prefontaine shattered his American record in the 3,000meter run tonight.

title: ORDERSFORWHEAT RAISED BY RUSRIA
description: Soviet trade delegates, on return trip to New York, have just sharply increased orders for wheat, it was disclosed yes terday.

title: RESERVE FORCES NOW 2.5% BLACK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Although falling short of the announced goal to double the number of blacks, the National Guard and Reserves added more than 6,000 Negroes to their rosters in the last year, with the biggest gains coming in units in the South.

title: A Universal Humanist
description: Throughout his prolific ca reer. Paul Goodman had to contend with critics who gen erally conceded his brillance and originality, but felt he had spread himself too thin.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 3 (AP)Bobby Isaac toured the Alabama Motor Speedway at 190.667 miles an hour today and earned the pole position for the $135,000 Talla dega 500 stock car race on Sunday.

title: B52's Again on Okinawa
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3 (AP)Eight American B52 bombers return ing to Guam from a raid on Vietnam landed early today on Okinawa for the third time since the island was returned to Japan May 15, officials of the Japanese defense agency said. The agency said the bombers flew to the Kadena Air case because of bad weather over Guam, the same reason given for the previous landings. The Japanese Government has asked the United States to do all it can to keep the B52's away from Okinawa because the Okinawans and the Japa nese are opposed to direct in volvement in the Vietnam war.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)The Treasury Depart ment said today it would abandon an antidutnping investi gation against Japanesemade stainless steel pipe and tub ing but found Japanese cadmium was being dumped in the United States market. The department said it had found that only minimal sales of stainless steel pipe and tubing had been made in the United States at less than the market price in Japan. This is the key element in determining whether an exporter is dumping its goods on the American market.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: Senator Eagleton used a good anal ogy, when he compared psychiatric treatment to a broken leg. Certainly there should be no difference in stigma as between one and the other.

title: TIARA CALLED KEY TO PLAZA HOLDUP
description: Detectives here have begun questioning underworld inform ants in hopes that the em erald tiara and other jewelry stolen from the Plaza Hotel are being fenced offered illegally for sale.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market posted their third consecutive advances yester day in heavier trading.

title: Bridge: FullTime Professional Team May Not Be Truly FullTime
description: The future of the Aces, who have won two world titles for the United States in the last three years, was a subject for considerable speculation during the Sum mer National Championships in Denver that ended this week. Two of the Aces, Jim Jacoby and Paul Soloway, were missing from the Aces' lineup, and were replaced by Peter Pender of Sausalito, Calif., and Grant Baze of San Francisco.

title: Norma Harvester, Professor, Wed
description: In the Chapel of the Resur rection at St. Thomas Epis copal Church here at noon yesterday, Miss Norma Har vester, an associate professor in philosophy of education at Adelphi University, was mar ried to Dr. George S. Catta nach, a neurologist and psy chiatrist in New York. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Fred erick M. Morris.

title: MRS. KING VICTOR IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 3 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King defeat ed Australia's Wendy Gilchrist in straight sets today to gain the quarterfinals of the $25,000 Virginia Slims tennis tourna ment.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board said today it had decided not to include at this time the operation of savings and loan associations on its list of permissible activities for bank holding companies. The board stressed that Congress had created a statutory framework for savings and loan associations that was sep arate from the laws governing commercial banks.

title: A $20Billion Fund Measure Sent to Nixon by Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) Congress put the finishing touches today on a $20.1billion appropriation bill for housing, space, science and veterans' programs for the fiscal year that began July 1.

title: About Pro Football
description: Twelve exhibition games involving all but two of the National Football League's 26 teams will be played this weekend, beginning with four tonight. The exceptions are the Minnesota and Denver clubs but for different reasons.

title: Mrs. Chadsey Gains Final
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn, Aug. 3 Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill, the defending champion, defeated Mrs. Wil liam M. Tingue of New Canaan, 4 and 2, at the Country Club of Fairfield today in the Women's WestchesterandFairfield Golf Association semifinals. Mrs. Robert L. Rau of Scarsdale G. C. won from Mrs. Richard P. O'Leary of Winged Foot, 1 up.

title: Boy, 15, and His Sister, 12, Drown in a Pool in Queens
description: A 15yearold boy and his 12yearold sister drowned last night in a neighbor's backyard swimming pool in the Ozone Park section of Queens. The police reported that both vic tims, William and Martha For gan, of 11135 121st Street, had not known how to swim.

title: McGovern Delays Choice; Hints Monday Is Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3Senator George McGovern said today that his search for a running mate could continue until Monday. His aides thought, however, that the field of Vice  Presidential candidates was narrowing and that a de cision was close.

title: 8 Americans Are Listed As Dead in War in Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (AP)Eight Ameri cans were killed in action in Vietnam last week and 17 were wounded, the United States command announced today in its weekly casualty summary. It added that three more Americans died from noncombat causes and that one was missing in action.

title: GAS CONSUMERS FACE PRICE RISES UNDERNEWPOLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Backed by the Nixon Admin istration, the Federal Power Commission adopted, today a new natural gaspricing policy Xo let producers deliver addi tional gas at prices above the present ceilings.

title: Selling Rate Up 47% for Last 10 Days of the Month
description: Record new car sales were registered by the automobile industry for both the final 10 days of July and the entire month.

title: Economic Analysis
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3The after math of a conference on trade issues between American and Japanese officials a week ago has pointed up two funda mental reasons for the sorry state of relations between Washing ton and Tokyo. The first is that there is a com munications gap nearly as wide as the Pacific Ocean. Each side is listening to the other but is not hearing what is said. Consequently, mis understandings pile on misun derstandings.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: Who would have thought it of George McGovern? Five days after re peating his 1,000 per cent support of Tom Eagleton and stating that he would not be dropped from the ticket, he dumps his personally chosen run ning mate.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: The issue of Senator Eagleton's suitability for the office of Vice Presi dent and the cruel pressures that forced him off the ticket reflect more than just his personal tragedy. Were it not for the historical distortion of the powers and responsibilities of the Presidency itself far beyond what the framers of the Constitution could envisage, the magnitude of the issue now would surely be of a different degree.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: I think that Senator Eagleton's decision to withdraw from the ticket was a wise one although I, myself, would have supported his candidacy. Unfortunately, even in this year of 1972, not all Americans have the maturity to understand his situation.

title: British in Ulster Move To Calm Angry Catholics
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 3The British Govern ment, won led about deteriorat ing security here, has begun urgent political efforts to spur negotiations with the angry Ro man Catholic community.

title: L. B. MICKEL DIES; LED U.P. BUREAUS
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 3 (UPI)L. B. Mickel, former superintendent of bu reaus and manager of election coverage for the United Press for nearly 30 years, died today, he was 83yearsold and lived here.

title: COX BROADCASTING SETS SINGLE UNIT
description: Under a proposed recapital ization plan, the Cox Broad casting Corporation will be separated from its parent, Cox Enterprises, Inc., it was an nounced yesterday by Jack Tarver, president of CEI.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Aug. 3When the language of politics becomes bullets and bombs, ordinary politicians are quickly turned into helpless spectators. But Northern Ireland still has a handful of Roman Catholic politicians who believe they have a role to play in re storing peace. Probably the most important of these is John Hume, a former seminarian who was the repre sentative in the suspended provincial parlia ment for the Bogside and Cregganthe Catholic strong holds here that have gone by the name Free Derry which were occupied this week by British troops.

title: American Motors Models Get Lower Insurance Rate
description: BURLINGTON, Wis., Aug. 3 The American Motors Corpora tion displayed its 1973 automo biles today and contended that its new bumpers were the best in the industry.

title: Perjury Trial of 2 Who Aided Knapp Ends in Hung Jury
description: A perjury trial of two Queens towtruck operators who had, worked for the Knapp Commis sion ended in a mistrial yester day when the jury remained, deadlocked on whether the op erators had lied by accusing two policemen of corruption.

title: U2 Photos Help Fight Coast Fire
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Aug. 3 (UPI)Fire fighters guided by photographs from a U2 spy plane slowed today a forest fire that raged through the Big Sur coastal mountains.

title: PAIR FILES A SUIT AGAINST EXCHANGE
description: Two former partners in the securities firm of Goodbody & Co have filed a counterclaim against the New York Stock Ex change, asserting that the emer gency takeover of the finan cially troubled company in 1970 by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith was an illegal conspiracy arranged by the ex change.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE THIRD DAY IN ROW
description: Strength in retail and auto mobile issues, as well as record prices for International Busi ness Machines, helped to send the stock market yesterday into its third consecutive advance.

title: Harlem 4 Witness Reportedly Recants Earlier Repudiation
description: A Manhattan prosecutor told a State Supreme Court justice that the chief prosecution wit ness in the murder trials of the Harlem Four had said he repu diated his testimony against the four defendants because of threats.

title: Celler and Holtzman Staffs Dig for Errors
description: It's a good thing, this is volunteer work, because if they paid me to do it, I'd quit, Mrs. Ida Miller said. She then adjusted her glasses and returned to flipping through buffcolored voter registration cards, looking for possible irregularities in the Democratic primary last June 20.

title: Screen: 'La Salamandre':A Swiss Import Evokes an Age of Discovery
description: Alain Tanner's "La Salamandre," the Swiss film (French dialogue with English subtitles) that opened yesterday at the Paris Theater, was made in 1970 but it takes us back to the early 1960s.' In those days we could discoverat our own speed and without hysteriathe works of Godard, Truffaut, Chabrol and others at those small Manhattan theaters that hadn't yet been pre-empted by Paramount, M-G-M and the rest.Economics were different then. To survive, movies didn't have to be "Godfather" blockbusters or even unequivocal critical hits. As filmmakers could experiment, so could the distributors who released their films. Some went bust, of course, but some were lucky, and there was a remarkably consistent flow of unusual European films to supplement the more commercial American and English movies."La Salamandre," which the Museum of Modern Art showed earlier this year in its New Directors series, evokes that age of discovery. Here is a marvelous new film by a director not yet known in this country (and thus not yet defined by reputation and the dogma of critics), acted by three young performers whose brilliance may be as much a reflection of their anonymity as of their talents.Because the director and his actors carry no baggage, no labels, no associations from earlier films, they can demonstrate in rare, witty, free-wheeling form what "La Salamandre" is all about, namely the quite dumbfounding nature of truthif, after all, there is such a thing.The setting is an unidentified Swiss city, which, in addition to being a location, is a state of mind, a totally normal, peaceful place that runs with the logical predictability of, well, a Swiss movement. Pierre (Jean-Luc Bideau), a journalist, and Paul (Jacques Denis), a writer who has higher aspirations but supports his wife and child by being a house painter, accept a commission to write a television script about a real-life event that, several years before, had made a couple of headlines and then fizzled out.The object of their inquiry is Rosemonde (Bulle Ogier), a pretty seemingly phlegmatic girl who may or may not have tried to kill her uncle with his old Army rifle. The uncle swore she did. She swore that she didn't, that he had accidently shot himself. Because there were no witnesses and because the uncle did not die the case was dropped."La Salamandre" is the story of an investigation that concludes in very un-Swiss confusion. Pierce undertakes to do the research, seeking out the uncle, Rosamonde's friends and finally Rosamonde herself. Paul abhors facts, and prefers instead to exercise his novelist's imagination.For a small fee, Rosemonde, who has been working in a sausage factory with no great esprit, agrees to cooperate. She answers all questions freely and even has desultory affairs with both, but the better the writers get to know her the more mysterious she seems, until at last she becomes practically transparent, someone whose existence is felt while she remains beyond understanding, in effect, unseen.At the same time, Rosemonde is the mythical salamander who lives in fire, not only unburnt but, to the bafflement of Pierre and Paul, also blissfully unperturbed.Tanner's method is clear-eyed and factual, almost dead-panned, growing ever more so as Pierre and Paul find themselves increasingly at a loss with their subject. Its sense of comedy reminds me of both Truffaut ("Jules and Jim") and early Godard, whose love for the young Anna Karina in "Vivre Sa Vie" and "Bande  Part" is recalled by Tanner's fascination with Miss Ogier. She is sometimes beautiful, sometimes brilliant, sometimes a slob, sometimes beyond mortal comprehensionand always infinitely appealing. She is a woman loved.Some of these recollections of the French filmmakers in the sixties are prompted by the look of the film (fine, no-nonsense black-and-white photography that could be Raoul Coutard's), and by the narrative style, but "La Salamandre" is a tough, funny work that acknowledges those masters without aping them. It's an original.

title: Damrosch Park Sounds a Quiet Note
description: Hidden from the streets by the Metropolitan Opera House and lowincome housing project Is an enclave of relaxation and security where the young play, the old dream and the only re minder of the city's tension is an occasional otherworldly police siren filtered through breezestirred trees.

title: WELFARE RULES TIGHTENED BY CITY
description: The city has begun requiring that relief applicants submit documents on their identity, address, family size and earn ings, after a finding that a stateFederal requirement for only a simple declaration of need has been ineffective.

title: Upturn Is Ascribed to Good Shopping Weather in July
description: New York department stores, taking advantage of good shop ping weather last month, achieved their best gain in 15 months.

title: Business Briefs
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday it had begun studies for the use of an existing mine shaft and tailing pond as the site fo ra onemillionkilowatt pumpedstorage power plant. The project, scheduled for completion in the mid1980's, is estimated to cost $250 million, and would be located in the Mt. Hope section Rockaway Township in northwestern New Jersey, near Dover. The utility would work with the Halecrest Com pany of Edison, which has an option to purchase the 1,700 acre tract.

title: Strategic Role of Russians In Egypt Cut, Israelis Say
description: JERUSALEM, Aug, 3Quali fied Israeli sources said today that the pullout of Soviet mili tary forces and equipment from Egypt had gone beyond the withdrawal of men, planes and missiles intended for the de fense of Egypt and involved reduction of military activities carried out in the pursuit of strictly Soviet strategic in terests.

title: BILL BOLAND, $4, WINS BY A NECK
GRAND JURY INDICTS 5 IN JET HIJACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) A Federal grand jury indicted three men and two women to day for air piracy in the case of a Delta Air Lines jet that was forced to fly to Algiers on Monday.

title: MRS. LOUISE ROBINSON
description: Mrs. Louise Miller Robinson, a daughter of former Gov. Nathan L. Miller, died Wednes day at her home, 430 East 57th Street. Her age was 62.

title: STEVENSON AND SIX WIN BALLET AWARDS
description: Ben Stevenson, codirector of the National Ballet of Washing ton, and six members of the company have won awards at the Sixth International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria.

title: A Park in Village Is Once Again Site Of Chamber Music
description: The weatherman was coop erating Tuesday night, and warm breezes helped celebrate the return of Free Chamber Music in Washington Square Park. The series, one of the first in the city to offer free sum mer programs, was started by Alexander Schneider in 1953, and flourished until a few years ago, when it gave up the twin struggle against dwindling funds and deteriorating park conditions.

title: Ailey Joins City Center
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will become a permanent constituent of the City Center of Music and Drama, changing its name to the Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater.

title: Changeover Cuts Car Output
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) United Slates car production hit its low point this week be cause of the changeover to 1973 models, Automotive News re ported today.

title: Music: Opera by Cui Revived at Newport Mansion
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 3 After attending only a few events in the Newport Music Festival, which is now in its fourth year, one gets the feeling that this extraordinary little city must have been preparing throughout its long history for precisely the kind of musical celebration it now offers so proudly and persuasively.

title: Mississippi Rejects Grant
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 3 (AP) A $2.1million Federal grant to a comprehenive health center serving poor blacks in Hinds County was vetoed today by Gov. William L. Waller. This was the second time in three months that he rejected grants by the Federal Office of Eco nomic Opportunity for such projects in Mississippi.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.6 From WeekAgo
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 120.3 from 119.7 last week.

title: Now It's Skinny Lib With Loud Protest
description: In a hotel suite filled with glazed doughnuts yesterday, Barry Goldsmith told a sad tale about being a member of America's lost minority. Barry is skinny.

title: 34 GROUPS BACK ECOLOGY BONDS
description: State officials announced yesterday the formation of coalition of 34 environmental, labor and civic organizations to back the Rockefeller ad ministration's $1.15billion en vironmental bond issue.

title: BIG BOARD VOTES NEEDHAM CHAIRMAN
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that James J. Needham, a for mer member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, had been formally elected chairman at a meeting of the board of directors.

title: 1845 LETTER BY POE IS SOLD FOR $3,300
description: An unpublished letter from Edgar Allan Poe in which he indicates that he was an auto graph collector was bought for $3,300 at an auction last night.

title: HALL SETS RECORD IN OLYMPIC TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP)Gary Hall, the Indiana University ace, set a world record in the 400meter individual medley and Mark Spit, a former Hoo sier teammate of Hall's, just missed his own world record in the 200meter freestyle as both captured their second Olympic team berths tonight in the Unit ed States swimming trials.

title: SOCIALIST WORKERS BARRED IN ILLINOIS
description: SPRINGFIELD, lll., Aug. 3 (UPI)Ten candidates of the Socialist Workers party have been barred fom the ballot in Illinois because they refuse to sign the state's loyalty oath.

title: Public Director, Viewing Market, Favors Liberals
description: Dr. Juanita M. Kreps, the first woman ever to serve on the board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange, is a careful, softspoken eco nomist with liberal leanings who considers her family life at least as important as her profession.

title: Rep. Rooney Endorsed
description: The Conservative party or ganization in Brooklyn en idorsed Representative John J. Rooney for reelection last night, a party spokesman an nounced. The endorsement means that Mr. Rooney, whose victory in the Democratic pri mary last June over Allard K. Lowenstein is being challenged in court, will appear on the ballot in November on the Conservative line, the spokes man said.

title: Eight Greeks Are Put on Trial Charged With Being Urban Guerrillas
description: ATHENS, Aug. 3A prose cution witness in the trial of eight Greeks alleged to be ur ban guerrillas said today that the accused had planned to attack the United States Em bassy in downtown Athens with bazookas mounted on truck.

title: Chess Play Adjourned
description: After 40 moves, Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky adjourned the 10th game of their world championship chess match in Reykjavik, Iceland. Play is to resume today. Details on Page 62.

title: Bremer Diary Details Effort to Kill Nixon
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Aug. 3Arthur H. Bremer's narrative of his futile Canadian expedition to assasginate Pres ident Nixon and his subsequent decision to assault Gov. George C. Wallace was read to a spell bound jury today at his state trial for the shooting of Mr. Wallace and three others at political rally at Laurel, Md.

title: Miss Berger Is Bride Here
description: Miss Barbara Berger was married here yesterday after noon lo Stuart Opotowsky. Rabbi James Rubin performed the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Federal Communications Com mission refused today to allow Atlanta broadcasting stations to reject a paid political ad vertisement asking Georgians to vote for white racist J. B. Stoner for U.S. Senator in the primary election next Tuesday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: FREEHOLD, N. J. Aug. 3Closed since last Monday by a contract dispute, Freehold Raceway will open its meet ing tomorrow as a result of an agreement on purses reached today by horsemen and management.

title: Consumer Groups Are Jangling Phone Company Poise
description: Thousands of people who complain each year to au thorities about telephone service have never heard of John O'Sullivan, George Le vine, Janet Stebins, Florence Rice or Gavrille Gemma.

title: Senate Panel Blocks Promotion of Mylai Figure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee has temptirarily dropped from a State Department pro motion list the name of a ca reer diplomat who is accused of helping suppress news of the Mylai killings. The diplomat is James A. May of California, currently serving as adminis trative officer in the United States Embassy in Somalia.

title: MACKELL CLEARED IN HOME INQUIRY
description: Federal authorities confirmed yesterday that the Justice De partment had investigated the circumstances surrounding the construction of a house owned by District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens, but they added that no indictment had been returned.

title: LONGO, ON A 142, IS 2SHOT VICTOR
description: EASTON, Conn., Aug. 3Joe Longo of Briar Hall scored 72, 70142 at the Golf Club or Aspetuck today to win by two strokes the Westchester district championship of the Metropoli tan Professional Golfers' Asso ciation.

title: CARPENTERS ARRIVE AT A CONTRACT HERE
description: The District Council of Carpenters, one of the city's largest construction unions, reached agreement on a new contract yesterday with the Cement League of the Build ing Trades Employers Associa tion, a spokesman for the association announced.

title: Board Appears to Have Ended CityFiremen Contract Impasse
description: An interim decision of the city's Board of Collective Bar gaining appeared yesterday to have cleared the way for com pletion of the contract agree ments between the city and both the Uniformed Fire Offi cers Association and the Uni formed Firefighters Associaton.

title: NIXON IN APPEAL ON WELFARE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3Pres ident Nixon sought today to head off any attempts in the Senate to attach portions of the longstalled welfare reform bill to a pending revenueshar ing measure.

title: TAXI DRIVER SLAIN ON STREET HERE
description: A taxi driver was shot to death by one of three or four passengersincluding a woman in an apparent holdup in the Williamsburg section of Brook lyn early yesterday.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: PEKING MAN. Emp. St. Obs. mig. Funds avail.; no questions. Phone C.G.JAdvt.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: I am deeply concerned by the im plications of James Reston's July 30 column, The Eagleton Tragedy.

title: Astronauts and Space Officials Testify At Inquiry on Exploitation of Souvenirs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Astronauts and top space offi cials gave five hours of secret testimony today to a Senate committee investigating the commercial exploitation of the nation's flights to the moon.

title: JAN DOUBRAVA
description: Jan Doubrava, associate di rector of the art department at the New School for Social Research since 1958, died yes terday at the age of 61. He lived at 463 West Street.

title: Chastising the U.N.
description: It seems hard for Presidents of the United States to accept the notion that the Secretary General of the United Nations has a positive responsibility to speak freely in the interest of a more peaceful world.

title: Chess Game Is Adjourned With Fischer Given Edge
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 3 Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky adjourned the 10th game of the world champion ship chess match tonight in a position favorable to the Amer ican grandmaster.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: Senator McGovern's request to Sen ator Eagleton to withdraw from the nomination of the VicePresidency be fits a man whose manhood is show ing, and who lacks John F. Kennedy's Profiles in Courage. Once in a life time a political decision should be made in which man is superior to expediency.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton said yesterday that inactivity following his 1960 campaign for Missouri Attorney General drove him to an aimless state of depression.

title: New Telethon Planned
description: MIAMI, Aug. 3 (APJohn Y. Brown, who organized the re cent national telethon that net A.ed $4million for the Demo cratic party, said today that he had been asked to underwrite another fundraising effort for the party.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The Treasury Department reported today that savingsbonds sales declined in July for the second consecutive month but still topped redemp tions for the 22cl month in a row. The net cash inflow totaled about $129million last month, down from $149 million in June but ahead of the $94million in July, 1971.

title: 3 Jewish Leaders Back Nixon; Cite Policy on Israel as Reason
description: Three men prominent in Jew ish organizations endorsed President Nixon yesterday, cit ing his policy on Israel as a major reason for their decision.

title: Books of The Times
description: ELEANOR: THE YEARS ALONE. By Joseph P. Lask. 368 pages. Norton. $9.95.

title: 3 ARE SEIZED HERE IN MARIJUANA CASE
description: Three persons were arrested on the Upper West Side last night by detectives who also said they found about 400 pounds of marijuana in their possession.

title: New Analysis
description: The worldwide American war on opiumgrowing and heroin smuggling promises to be at least as protracted, and per haps as inconclusive, as the conflict in Vietnam.

title: Belisle Named Head Coach
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 3 (UPI)The Des Moines Capitals of the International Hockey League today named Dan Bel isle, 35 years old, a former pro fessional player, as coach for the 197273 season. Belisle played briefly with the New York Rangers in 1961.

title: Report Suggests Jersey Regulate Hospital Charges
description: TRENTON, Aug. 3A law yer hired by the state to represent the public interest in a Blue Cross raterise applica tion recommended today that hospital charges be regulated by the state in the same man ner as railroad fares and tele phone and power company rates.

title: 50,000 Signatures Back Restricted Beaches on L.I.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I, Aug. 3 Petitions with nearly 50,000 signatures, advocating that beaches and parks in the town of Hempstead continue to be restricted to residents have been received during the last two weeks, Francis T. Purcell, presiding supervisor, announced today.

title: Joining Nets Was TaylorMade Decision
description: CARLE PLACE, L. I., Aug. 3  Because he didn't want to sit around for a year and worry whether or not there was going to be a merger, Brian Taylor con firmed today that he has left Princeton University for a. pro basketball career with the New York Nets.

title: 101 in South Africa Held After Clashes of Tribes
description: UMTATA, South Africa, Aug. 3 (AP)The police say that 101 men have been ar rested after tribal fighting in which 38 persons were killed last week in the Transkei res ervation, a Government home land for the Xhosa tribe.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The Sen ate's 4947 vote to withdraw all United States forces from Indochina within four months, provided all prisoners of war are released, amounts to a vote of noconfidence in President Nixon's tougher peace terms.

title: Advertising:
description: A couple is flying over New York in a helicopter when she remarks, I wish they'd plant more trees in New York. Obviously prepared for this kind of a remark, he responds, They. Everybody is waiting for they to do everything. But you know what? You are they.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PASADENA, Calif.  Bob Kneedler is a bird dog, which has nothing to do with hunting or stealing somebody's girl friend.

title: MRS. TIBOR KEREKES
description: Mrs. Teresa Kerekes; widow of Dr. Tibor Kerekes, former chairman of the history depart ment at Georgetown University, died yesterday of cancer at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. Her age was 73.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Lady From Louisiana
description: After 36 years of occupancy by the late Senator Allen J. Ellender, the Senate seat once held by the mighty Huey Long now passes to a woman. In the prevailing climate of women's liberation, that might appear to be a matter for real satisfaction, but the circumstances of the succession should make it, on the contrary, a source of dismay to all who resent sex discrimination in politics.

title: Canadian Concern Sued
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had filed suit against the Revenue Properties Company, Ltd., of Toronto for alleged violations of Federal security laws regarding proxies.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A footnote to the history of the 1972 baseball season concerns the young man who climbed into his space suit during the sixth inning of the first game in Tuesday's doubleheader between the Meta and Phillips and took his place outside the centerfield fence along with 3,911 others waiting to exhibit their bedsheet art in Shea Stadium's annual Banner Day competition. Twelve innings and almost three hours later they were still waiting for the run in the bottom of the 18th which gave the Mets a 32 victory and cleared the field for heraldic pomp. When the small astronaut was declared the winner, he was the last to know, for by that time he was asleep in his mother's arms. This was heartening evidence that although the fortunes of the Mets have been failing, no cracks are showing in the patient fortitude of their followers. For staying power, the clientele of Payson Place has been an example for all of baseball ever since the club set up shop on Long Island. On May 31, 1964, a hardy band sat through the first game of a doubleheader with the Giants, which was concluded in an unremarkable 2 hours 29 minutes; after a suitable interval for meditation, prayer and hot dogs with mustard, the customers returned to their seats and some stayed put for another 7 hours 23 minutes, or until San Francisco won the second game, 86, in 23 innings.

title: KENNETH S. G. DEWEY OF ACTION THEATER
description: ORANGE, Conn., Aug. 3 Kenneth S. G. Dewey, president of Action Theater, Inc., of New York, died yesterday when the singleengine plane he was fly ing in alone crashed in a heavily wooded area near here. He was 38 years old and lived in New Paltz, N. Y.

title: NoGo in the Mind
description: The renewal of violence in Northern Ireland so soon after British troops invaded terrorist sanctuaries in Cath olic nogo areas confirms Prime Minister Heath's recent warning that those who suppose that the Government or the army or the other security forces can by some sudden move or change of tactics bring violence to an end are living in an unreal world.

title: J. STERLING HALSTEAD
description: J. Sterling Halstead, a retired New York lawyer who most re cently was counsel to Putney, Twombly, Hall & Skidmore, died yesterday in Washington, where he lived. His age was 77.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: The national outcry over the Eagle ton affair clearly has more profound causes than the Senator's psychiatric history alone. During just the last year, there was calm acceptance of the Presidential candidacies of Senator Harold E. Hughes, an exalcoholic, and Governor George C. Wallace, whose World War II service left him with a disability for combat fatigue.

title: In the Heart of Connecticut, Acres of Tolstoy's Russia
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn.The fieldstone chapel with its gilded onion dome and icon over the doorway rests in a shady glen, dwarfed by tall trees.

title: SARDINES RECALLED, FAULTY CANS CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Food and Drug Admini stration announced today the recall of 100,000 cases of im ported Danish sardines, some of them decomposed because of defective can seams.

title: I.C.I. Names Officer
description: William B. Duncan, president and chief executive officer of I.C.I. North America Limited, the holding company for Im perial Chemical Industries Limited, has been named chair man and I.C.I. territorial direc tor for North America on the main board of directors in London. Mr. Duncan will re main chairman of I.C.I. Ameri ca, Inc. Edward J. Goett will succeed Mr. Duncan as presi dent and chief executive officer of I.C.I. North America and retain the same positions with I.C.I. America, Inc.

title: An Industry Grows in India's Wettest Area
description: CHERRAPUNJI, India  A new, rapidly expanding state cement industry has up graded life sharply for the several thousand frequently drenched residents of this little mountain settlement, which Indians call the wet test spot on earth.

title: Strip Miners Save Worker
description: BROWNSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP) Cecil Clark, 65 years old, was pulled to safety today by fellow strip mine workers who saw him buried accidentally after a dynamite blast.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MILAN, Italy, Aug. 3 (AP)  United States' teams reached the semifinals in five events of the World junior rowing championships today in repechages after failing in elimination heats yesterday.

title: Laggard Council
description: Yesterday, months after the wide disparities in official estimates of welfare chiseling first appeared, the City Council called in State Welfare Inspector General George Berlinger and City Human Resources Administrator Jule Sugarman to explain why their ineligibility figures differ so markedly. It has been Mr. Berlinger's contention that from 20 to 30 per cent of the 1.25million people on the city's welfare rolls are not eligible to be there. Accord ing to Mr. Sugarman, the number of ineligibles is shade over 5 per cent.

title: OPTIMISM VOICED BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3Vernon E. Jordan Jr., in office only eight months as executive di rector of the National Urban League, has begun fashioning the direction and operation of the league to fit his own back ground and beliefs rather than those of the late Whitney M. Young Jr.

title: RECORD SALES YEAR MARKED BY SOTHEBY
description: Sotheby & Co. Of London and its five houses here and abroad rang up $108,242,250 in the same period, a record that went over the 1971 figure by $22, 333,744. Two branches, one in ZurichSotheby's first on the Continentand another in Lon don's Belgravia section, were opened this season. They con tributed $4,808,591 and $3,973, 591, respectively, to the total.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 3 The American party opened its first national convention today with a plea from its chairman, T. Coleman Andrews Jr., that the delegates not nominate Gov. George C. Wallace of Ala bama to run for President.

title: Rail Traffic Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Association of American Rail roads reported freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 14,9 billion tonmiles, 35.3 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. The A.A.R. Also re ported carloadings last week totaled 499,150 cars 28.2 per cent above last year. The Amer ican Trucking Association, Inc., reported intercity truck ton nage was 6.3 per cent below last year.

title: Belisle Named Head Coach
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 3 (UPI)The Des Moines Capitals of the International Hockey League today named Dan Bel isle, 35 years old, a former pro fessional player, as coach for the 197273 season. Belisle played briefly with the New York Rangers in 1961.

title: Politics Is Not All or Nothing
description: WASHINGTONOne of the most disturbing qualities about the political process is its all or nothing quality. The days in which issues were ad dressed with due regard for their com plexity appear to be on the wane, or perhaps they never were. But it seems to me that one of the signs of a func tioning and healthy political system is an awareness that gray shades into both black and white. Tolerance for the views of others requires an under standing that out of Vietnam before 1973 is not the ultimate in political and social wisdom but only its begin ning.

title: Taxi Agency Prodding Detroit To Make Safe, Comfortable Cab
description: The city's Taxi and Limou sine Commission has moved to prod Detroit into producing a New York taxicab in which riders would have less trouble getting in, have less chance of bumping their heads or bang ing their knees and would not have to swelter on hot days.

title: Satellite Unit Set by W.U.I. And Fairchild Industries
description: Fairchild Industries, Inc., and Western Union Inter national, Inc., announced yesterday their agreement to form a domestic communications satellite business. Such a sys tem, based on a network of satellite earth stations provid ing services for television and other communications, would be the first commercially operated in this country for domestic purposes.

title: ASHELUTZ GAINS U.S. SEMIFINALS
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 3 (UPI)Arthur Ashe and Bob Lutz, seeking their second straight doubles title, upset the secondseeded team of Marty Riessen and Tom Okker, 46, 7.6, 75, tonight to move into the semifinals of the $50,000 United States professional ten nis championships.

title: Cairo Hails Plan With Libya; Other Arab Capitals Cautious
description: CAIRO, Aug. 3Cairo news papers, using their biggest ban ner headlines, today praised as a historic event the agree ment yesterday between Egypt and Libya to set up a united political leadership to work out the foundations of unity between the two countries during the next 13 months.

title: Torture as an Institution
description: GENEVAI have just learned that a friend, Stephanos Pandelakis, a Greek pediatrician, has been tortured. For nine days after his arrest in Athens in April, no one knew where he was. He was alternately kept in a dark hole and beaten, which he was able to stand, and then tortured with elec tricity which he was not able to stand.

title: STANLEY J. CAPELIN
description: Stanley J. Capelin, president of the S. J. Capelin Associates companies of New York, Geneva and Sao Paulo, Brazil, died at University Hsopital Wednesday while on a business trip here. He was 59 years old and lived in Paris.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor:

title: NIXON VIEW GAINS IN BUSING RULINGS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 3  The Nixon Administration made headway with its campaign against busing in two major school desegregation decisions yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

title: The Unmaking of a Candidate
description: To the Editor: The lesson to be learned from the Eagleton affair is that the method of selecting the VicePresidential candi date is totally inadequate. We have long recognized, and ignored, the un democratic nature of the running mate's anointment by the Presidential nominee.

title: Red Cross Has Removed Relief Team From Burundi
description: GENEVA, Aug. 3The Inter national Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it had withdrawn a relief team from the African nation of Burundi.

title: More Partial Selloffs Planned; Grace to Sell 5% More Chemed
description: More and more corporations are selling off minority inter ests in profitable subsidiaries to raise money and to enhance their image among investors. W. R. Grace & Co. yesterday announced that its board of directors has approved a pro posed sale of up to 500,000 shares of capital stock of the Chemed Corporation, a 95 per centowned subsidiary whose earnings increased 16 per cent last year.

title: Grumman Meets North American On Shuttle Work.
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 3 Top executives of the North American Rockwell Corpora tion and the Grumman Corpo ration met for nearly an hour here late this afternoon to dis ccuss Grumman's potential role as a subcontractor in the $2.6 billion spaceshuttle program.

title: Soviet Reports Decision
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3The So viet Union, long at odds with Colonel Qaddafi and recently rebuffed by President Sadat's expulsion of Its military per sonnel, gave no indication to day of its attitude toward their decision to pursue Egyptian Libyan unification. The press gave brief straightforward ac counts of the merger decision on inside pages today without commentary. Soviet leaders in recent months were said to have privately criticized Arab efforts at unity built primarily on corn mon Arab and Islamic founda tions and have sought vigor ously to promote a common front of Socialist, Communist and other radical elements in the Arab world.

title: Drop in Radiation Levels
description: UPTON, L. I., Aug. 3Radia tion levels in humans have been steadily decreasing since the treaty prohibiting nuclear tests in the atmosphere was signed in 1963, according to a 12year series of scientific tests per formed on individuals at the Brookhaven National Labora tory here.

title: GIANTS GET FERRIS FROM THE STEELERS
description: WEST LONG BRANCH. N. J., Aug. 3Denny Ferris, a 6foot 1inch, 200pound running back from the University of Pitts burgh, was picked up on waiv ers today by the New York Giants from the Pittsburgh Steelers, but he won't be going to his new team right away. The team will be coming to him.

title: Harrelson Is Placed on Disabled List
description: At a time of year when the Mets should be healthy and hit ting to promote a challenge against the Pittsburgh Pirates, they continued injuryridden and feeble at the plate yester day at Shea Stadium against the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Merger News
description: AMF, Inc., announced yester day that it had agreed to pur chase for an undisclosed amount of cash the business and assets of the marine di vision of the North American Rockwell Corpora tion. Informed trade sources esti mate the transac tion at more than $20million. The marine division consists of three boat companies, the Hat teras Yacht Company, Crest liner and Whitcraft. The boards of both AMF and North Ameri can Rockwell have approved in principle the transaction that is expected to be completed on Nov. 1.

title: POST LOSES A FIGHT TO RESCIND PAY RISE
description: A challenge by The New York Post of an 11 per cent deferred wage increase due its unionized employes effective last March 31 under existing collective bargaining agreements has been denied by the Federal Pay Board.

title: BRITAIN DECLARES DOCK EMERGENCY
description: LONDON, Aug. 3A state of emergency was declared in Britain today as the dock strike that has shut most of the coun try's ports went into its sev enth day.

title: Mass Executions by Enemy Reported in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3  Allied intelligence of ficials say that Communist po litical officers have publicly ex ecuted hundreds of Saigon Gov ernment officials and impris oned thousands during their occupation of Binhdinh Prov ince, on the central coast of South Vietnam.

title: INSTITUTE IN JERSEY IS GIVEN $1MILLION
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 3 (AP)The Institute for Ad vanced Study has received $1million gift from the 1907 Foundation to endow a profes sorship in the institute's new program in social science, it was announced today.

title: Hospitals and Union Reach Pact On Deadline, Averting a Strike
description: Negotiators for 8,000 union ized hospital workers and an association of 27 private hospitals here agreed on the terms of a new twoyear con tract yesterday, averting a strike that could have affected 5,000 patients.

title: A $3 Air Departure Tax Is Imposed by Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 (AP) A $3 tax on all departing passengers at Philadelphia In ternational Airport was ap proved today by City Council.

title: BEST GO WINS BY 2 AT MONMOUTH PARK
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 3 (AP)  R. S. West's Best Go overtook the leaders heading into the stretch and galloped off to a twolength victory in the $8,500 feature at Monmouth Park today.

title: HOUSE UNIT APPROVES PUBLIC TV FUND PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The House Commerce Com mittee agreed yesterday to join the Senate in supporting a sin gleyear funding plan for public radio and television. Earlier, President Nixon had vetoed a twoyear, $155million authori zation bill for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Linda Hopkins and Taj Mahal Mix Blues and Gospel at Center
description: Soul at the Center got down to the roots of soul last night at Alice Tully Hallblues and gospel but they were dressed up in contemporary fashion by Taj Mahal, a sophis ticated performer of basic blues, and by the gospelbred but very worldly voice of Linda Hopkins.

title: Executive Changes
description: Richard T. Lindgren has been elected executive vice president of the Mead Corporation. He was formerly group executive and vice president of the agricultural equipment group of AllisChalmers.

title: Hospital Pact Ratified
description: Members of Local 144 of the Hotel, Hospital, Nursing Home and Allied Health Services Union yesterday ratified a new contract reached Thursday with the Association of Private Hos pitals, Inc. The ratification meeting at the Diplomat Hotel was attended by about 400 of the 8,000 members affected by the settlement.

title: Fischer Wins Again; 63 Lead Dims Hopes for Spassky
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 4 Bobby Fischer won today's adjourned game from Boris Spassky, pulling far ahead in the world Championship chess match.

title: 900 Adherents Paroli in Esperanto
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 3 The strange but vaguely fa miliar sounds of Esperanto rang through the lobby of the Portland Hilton the other day and a burly bellman strained to make out the melodious words. I guess it would be a good idea if everybody learned to speak it, but I don't know. . . . he mused, then dismissed the idea with a shrug.

title: JENKINS TRIUMPHS WITH TWO MOUNTS
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 4 As Expected, Tranquility and Kat Mandu, both ridden by Rod Jenkins, won the preliminary and intermediate jumper cham pionships, respectively, today at the Orange County Horse Show.

title: Cardinals Beat Bills
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 4 (UPI) Gary Cuozzo threw one touch down pass and Mike McGill, linebacker, turned an intercep tion into another score to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to an easy 2710 victory over the Buffalo Bills in a preseason game tonight.

title: DR. JAMES G. WALL A.T.&T.PHYSICIAN, 47
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4Dr. James G. Wall, medical director for general depart ments of the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company, died today, apparently of a heart attack, while vacationing in Allenhurst. He was 47 years old and lived in this community.

title: Econotnic Analysis
description: PARIS, Aug. 4Negotiations to reform the international monetary system are like a chess gameboth need silence. The financial leaders of the West have been giving consid erable thought of late to ways to achieve it, including even the possibility of a pooled effort to support the United States dollar. In monetary terms silence means the absence of crisis or to put it another way, the reduced likelihood that all those footloose green backsabout $60billion in the overseas dollar market at latest countwill mass against one currency or another and crush it.

title: MONSERRAT CALLS FUENTES RACIST
description: The controversy over the appointment of Luis Fuentes as superintendent of the Commu nity School Board for District 1 on the Lower East Side heated up yesterday when Jo seph Monserrat, president of the central Board of Education and a Puerto Rican, said that the record showed Mr. Fuentes to be a racist.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reuters)The United States remained at the bottom of the inflation league among industrial nations in May while the Netherlands kept its position at the top of the table, the International Monetary Fund reported today. The August issue of the fund's Inter national Financial Statistics Bulletin also showed that the cost of living in nearly all European industrialized countries was outsprinting the inflation rate in the United States, Canada and Japan.

title: Pincay Wins Debut at Saratoga With Fleetaglo, $6.80
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4Laffit Pincay picked up virtually where he left off last year as he made his Sara toga riding debut today. The Panamanian star, who led the 1971 Saratoga meeting with 25 winners, had to delay his first appearance here because of in juries. But in the first race on today's card, he demonstrated that he has lost little of his ability.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A question to Mayor Lindsay and those of the Board of Estimate who voted for Manhattan Landing  Who is going to supply the electricity to this project?

title: MAOIST MOVEMENT DECLINING IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 4Lead erless and losing popularity, the extreme Maoist organiza tion in India known as the Naxalite movement is fac ing extinction.

title: Saigon Admits Its Marines Are Stalled In Their Drive for Citadel of Quangtri
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 5 (AP)South Vietnamese marines reported that they killed 44 North Viet namese soldiers in fighting around Quangtri yesterday, but that their drive to isolate the walled Citadel, in the heart of the city, was at a standstill.

title: Business Briefs
description: ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it was proposing exchange offers for its two outstanding deben ture issues. The first proposal offers for each $1,000 of its 6 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due April 1989, $600 in principal amount of new 10 per cent deben tures due Dec. 31, 1985, and 20 shares of common stock.

title: Wife of a Doctor Is Sought On MethadoneSales Charge
description: A Federal magistrate here issued a warrant yesterday for the arrest of the wife of a doctor who last month closed his private, midManhattan methadone clinic because of alleged harassment by Federal agents.

title: 3YearOld Seeking to Move Up to 13th on Earnings List
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 4 Meadow Stable's .Riva Ridge is the oddonfavorite to win the fifth running of the $100,000 Monmouth Invitation Handicap tomorrow. A victory in the race, which awards a first prize of $65,000, would move Riva Ridge into 13th place on the list of thoroughbred money winners.

title: Jersey Suspect Linked to Police Attacks Here
description: A man arrested in Newark early Thursday in connection with the shooting of a police man there was said by the New York police yesterday to be wanted in connection with the shooting of a total of four po licemen on two separate occa sions in New York City.

title: LABOR PACT IS SET AT CLYDE SHIPYARD
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Aug. (UPI)  Workers at the Upper Clyde shipbuilders yard today approved a new fouryear labor agreement under which the yard will be operated by a com pany from Houston.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Mayor Lindsay has issued a proclamation at City Hall desig nating today as Stop the Bombing Day in the city. The proclamation was presented to Shirley A. Siegel, national coor dinator for the National Peace Action Coalition, who said the group would hold a demonstra tion in Duffy Square, Broadway and 47th Street, at 2 P.M. and a rally at the Mall in Central Park at 4 P.M.

title: Computer Chess Contest Set
description: The third annual computer chess championship is sched uled to be held from Aug. 13 to Aug. 15 in Boston, the Con trol Data Corporation, sponsor of the meet, announced here. Eight teams have entered the tournament, which will be di rected by David Levy, a master now, living in London.

title: Philippines Fears Food Riots as Floods Recede
