description: MANILA, Aug. 4 (AP) President Ferdinand E. Marcos warned today that food riots and related violence might fol low the monthlong rains and floods on Luzon Island now that the water was receding. He reported severe shortages of food and fuel in the stricken areas and ordered the army to seize hoarded stocks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 4 (UPI)The Ohio Secretary of State, Ted W. Brown, ruled today that Gus Hall, secretary of the American Communist party, can be placed on the Ohio November election ballot as an independent candidate for President.

title: Standing on Ceremony
description: WEST MEDFORD, Mass.In Octo ber, 1968, I turned on the TV one morning to find a thickset young man talking about the Olympic games which had been held that summer in Mexico City and in which he had been a com petitor. The man was Hal Connolly, winner of the 1956 gold medal in the hammer throwing contest.

title: Price Commission Challenges Auto Makers' Proposed Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Price Commission announced today that it had challenged proposals by the four domes tic automobile manufacturers to increase prices on 1973 models.

title: '4 Flies on Grey Velvet,' Suspense Film
description: "Four Flies on Grey Velvet," is the third suspense thriller from Italy's Dario Argento. It has striking, imaginative color photography and deep-freeze pacing and atmosphere. But they're simply not enough, even in such a classy, handsome production.The plot and dnouement are not only old but farfetched, and the dialogue is banal. The characters are generally a flabby lot, ranging from young urban jet-setters to scruffy bohemians.Nor are the performances of Michael Brandon, as the jittery, badgered hero, and Mimsy Farmer, as his wife, especially compelling, though Miss Farmer does handle one scene brilliantly. Mr. Argento injects some sourly wry humor with the appearance of a fluttery private detective, an admitted homosexual and sleuthing flop, played by Jean Pierre Marielle. The nearest thing to sensibility and balance is a raffish sage alertly underplayed by Bus Spencer. And Francine Racette, as the hero's pretty mistress, does well in one scene of whimpering terror.A spine-tingling sequence of a doomed, blackmailing servant trapped in a park at dusk is superb and typifies Mr. Argento at his chilling best.In the guesswork department, Mr. Argento and his two writer colleagues simply aren't fair. All that circuitous teasing and those red herrings don't produce a shred of real evidence to nibble on. You're on your own, in pure hit-or-miss speculation.Furthermore, except for one brief segment cueing in the title (a "scientific" conjecture nobody will swallow), where on earth are the police? With four murders clearly leading to the hero's doorstep, his unguarded attractive residence (apparently in midtown) should be blazing with lights. Instead, Mr. Argento seals it off, in shadows and eerie sounds, like a Wuthering Heights.But you'll hang on, we guarantee, to see and hear the culprit at the end. There, emphatically, M. Agento has us.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Proxmire Sees Jobs Gain In Shift From Defense Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reu ters)Senator William Prox mire, chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, said today that he had proof that money spent on local or state jobs or education produced twice as much em ployment as money spent on defense projects.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 4The first Congressional contest in Tennessee between a black and a white candidate was assured yesterday in the state primary election.

title: REPORT IN CAIRO SAYS YEMEN OUSTS SOVIET
description: CAIRO, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Yemen has asked the Soviet Union to remove its strategic bases and recall experts work ing there, the Cairo weekly newspaper Akhbar elYom said today.

title: MARKET RALLIES IN LATE TRADING
description: Stock prices rallied in late trading yesterday, following a brief spate of profit taking in midsession, to provide the market with its fourth gain in a row.

title: CAVETT STAYS ON, PAAR COMES BACK
description: The Dick Cavett Show, which had been threatened with cancellation as of Sept. 30 because of poor ratings, has been extended through Decem ber, but after that Mr. Cavett will be seen on the American Broadcasting Company televi sion network only one week a month.

title: FRENCH RETREAT FROM GOLD IDEA
description: PARIS, Aug. 4  French sources have quietly back tracked from official hints a week ago that Paris was pro posing a sharp rise in the gold rate for settlements among Common Market countries.

title: Bridge: The Unblock Is Usually Right, Even if You Don't Know Why
description: An experienced declarer makes certain routine techni cal plays without necessarily foreseeing the advantage that he will derive from them.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: LOUISVILLE, Aug. 4A tele phone call from Gov. George C. Wallace dissuaded his Ameri can party supporters from try ing to nominate him for Presi dent today, and the conserve tive new party turned instead to a lameduck Republican Congressman from California, John G. Schmitz.

title: GUARDS UNSHAKEN BY BREMER DIARY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Secret Service is not particu larly shaken by Arthur H. Bremer's disclosures in his diary that he tried to assassinate President Nixon in Ottawa last April.

title: Heard, With 70 for 139, Leads P. G. A. by Shot
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 4 Jerry Heard, who says he dropped out of Fresno State College when he found the curriculum interfering with his golf, set the 36hole pace in the Professional Golfers' Associa tion championship today at 139.

title: Notes on People
description: Governor Rockefeller, who is chairman of the New York Committee to Reelect the President, announced the ap pointment of Harry J. O'Don nell as director of communi cations for the New York campaign. Mr. O'Donnell, who has worked for the late Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, Mr. Rocke feller and Mayor Lindsay, is considered one of the most astute political advisers and public relations men in the country, his only apparent weakness being an addiction to arcane baseball statistics. Mr. O'Donnell will take an unpaid leave of absence from his position as First Deputy Commissioner in the state Commerce Department dur ing the Nixon campaign.

title: FOOD PRICES RISE BUT JOBLESS RATE IS STEADY IN JULY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The nation's unemployment re mained in July aL the reduced June level, but another jump in farm and food prices caused a significant increase in the Wholesale Price Index, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: Thayer, Parker Score Victories In Regatta Week
description: GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 4 Four skippers clinched class championships today in the Great South Bay Racing Asso ciation's Race Week regatta, which ends tomorrow. Two of them, Wayne Thayer in the Beetlecat Class and Jeff Horn in the Blue Jay Class Junior Division, posted their fifth triumphs to remain the only undefeated skippers.

title: Occidental Oil Elects
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation elected yesterday Donald M. Morgan as vice pres identfinance, replacing Dorman L. Commons who has resigned from that post and as a direc tor. Mr. Commans, who had become a director in June, 1971, will remain in an ad visory capacity until June 30, 1973.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 4 (UPI)The Communist party slate for the November election was barred from the Illinois ballot yesterday because the candidates refused to sign the state's loyalty oath declaring they were not associated with Communist organizations.

title: CASTRO PAIR GAINS IN ROWING
description: KENT, Conn., Aug. 4  A blustery headwind ruffled the usually calm waters of Lake Waramaug today as 31 crews fought their way through the Tepechages and semifinals to qualify for tomorrow's finals of the Olympic rowing trials.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug. 4 (AP) Vice President Agnew credited President Nixon tonight with thaw in the cold war that has given new heart to people everywhere.

title: Patricia Boyd, Eloy Alfaro Jr. Wed in Panama
description: Miss Patricia Boyd, daugh ter of Dr. Aquilino E. Boyd, Panama's Ambassador to the United Nations, and Mrs. Boyd, was married in Pan ama City yesterday afternoon to Eloy Alfaro Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfaro of Panama City. The Rev. Alberto de la Serna performed the cere ceremony in the Cristo Rey Roman Catholic Chapel.

title: Boy, the reformers at the convention really did it this time (1940)they nominated an antiestablishment outsider with the cry, We want Willkie.
description: The overturn by Senator McGovern and his supporters of the established machinery of the Democratic party is the third time in the last 32 years that a comparable revolution has taken place at a national convention. The next most recent occasion was the nomination by the Republican party in 1964 of Senator Goldwater. The first timeand the occasion most compar able in spirit to the McGovern conven tionwas the nomination by the Re publicans in 1940 of Wendell L. Willkie.

title: Market Place
description: Midlantic Banks, Inc., one of the larger New Jersey bank holding companies, has ambitions to become even biggerfast. But the Federal Reserve Board may slow things.

title: Four World Marks Set In U. S. Swimming Trials
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP)  Deena Deardurff, Mark Spitz, Kurt Krumpholz and Shirley Babashoff set world records tonight in the United States Olympic swimming trials at Portage Park.

title: San Francisco Fed Picks Economist as New Chief
description: John J. Balles, 51yearold chief of, corporate and eco nomic planning for the Mellon National Bank and Trust Com pany, was named president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco yesterday.

title: J. Herbert Case Is Dead at 99; Headed Federal Reserve Here
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 4 J. Herbert Case, a banking ex pert, former chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and father of two college presidents, died today at his home here, 970 Madison Avenue. He would have been 100 years old Aug. 20.

title: Analysis of Busing Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports News in Brief
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 4Freehold Raceway, which was scheduled to open last Monday but was delayed by purse negotiations, ran into more trouble today when a totalizator failure resulted in the cancellation of the sixth race. A crowd of 4,482 was on hand.

title: O.E. C.D. ASSESSES GERMAN ECONOMY
description: PARIS, Aug. 4 (Reuters) The major task for West Ger many in the short run is to achieve a recovery of economic activity and simultaneously a better price performance, the Organization for Economic Co operation and Development said today in its annual review of the German economy.

title: Fullback Set to Start
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 4 Now that Joe Namath and Matt Snell are healthy again, you don't hear the following commercial on your radio any more:

title: Rumania Ties Aussies
description: BUCHAREST, Aug. 4 (AP) Ilie Nastase, Rumania's No. player, defeated Colin Dibley in straight sets today after Mal Anderson of Australia rallied from a twoset deficit and up set Ion Tiriac in the opening singles matches of the Davis Cup interzone tennis series.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (AP) The leadership of the United Steelworkers of America, the nation's third largest labor union, has aligned itself behind the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations and voted to sit out the November Presi dential election.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Aug. 1 as follows:

title: DWIGHT L, MOODY, FINANCIAL WRITER
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 4  Dwignt L. Moody, for many years a member of the editorial staff of The Jour nal of Commerce of New York and in recent years a Consult ant to the newspaper, died Wednesday at the home of daughter, Mrs. Margaret White, 22 Lincoln Avenue. He was 72 years old and lived in Punta Gorda, Fla.

title: The Other Constitution
description: WASHINGTONAs this legislative year staggers through the humid months of summer, it has become ob vious that the unusual number of se rious misunderstandings between the Administration and Congress is the re sult of a minor oversight by the Ad ministration.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 4 (UPI)  George C. Wallace's campaign manager, Charles Snider, said today that he had turned down an offer to head an independents for President Nixon movement. The offer, he said, had been coupled with a promise of a subCabinet post in the Nixon Administration.

title: Athens Army Court Sentences 5 Greeks As Political Plotters
description: ATHENS, Aug. 4 (Reuters) An Athens army court tonight sentenced five Greeks to prison terms ranging from seven months to 39 months on charges of plotting terrorist ac tivities in Greece, including the kidnapping of the 11year old son of President Kennedy.

title: Books of The Times
description: UNDER THE GUNS: New York 17751776. By Bruce Bliven Jr. 397 pages. Harper and Row. $10.

title: NANSEMOND WINS GOOD TIME PACE
description: YONKERS, Aug. 4  Nanse mond and Isle of Wight, billed as the greatest equine full brother act since Irvin Paul and Stephan Smith, were pleasing harnessracing fans a decade ago, did not put across a 1, 2 finish, as had been predicted by many tonight at Yonkers Raceway. But the Herve Filion steered Nansemond saved the chalkplayers among the 23,354 fans by rallying to capture the $54,500 Good Time Pace for an acrosstheboard return of $2.60, $2.10 and $2.10.

title: MERGER PACT SET BY CHESEBROUGH
description: Merger News

title: ANTIPOVERTY UNIT BUYS A COMPANY
description: As part of its economic de velopment plan, a Harlem anti poverty agency has purchased the Shultz Company, Inc., Harlembased manufacturer of wood, metal and plastic interi ors for supermarkets, for $1 million.

title: India Closes Its Doors
description: I want our doors and windows to be opened to the world, the late Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru once said, to let fresh air blow in from all sides.

title: N.Y. Yacht Club Sails Set for Start of Cruise Today
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 4  When a black and white sea plane skimmed to a stop 100 yards from the dock at New port Ship Yard today, the chairman of the New York Yacht Club's race committee, casually raised his binoculars.

title: 2 New Quakes Felt in Sitka
description: SITKA, Alaska, Aug. 4 (UPI) Two earthquakes were felt here early today, but neither was as strong as the temblor that caused about $4,000 in damage here last Sunday. The quakes today occurred at 2:48 A.M. and 4:38 A.M. The first was measured at 4.6 and the second at 6 on the Richter scale, which had egistered 7.3 Sunday. No damage was re ported.

title: Hogan Says He Backed Mackell Inquiry
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan said yes terday that he had authorized in general terms the investi gationnow endedinto the Queens District Attorney'a of fice. That led to his public apology to District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens earlier this week.

title: Business Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 4 (Reuters)  The Chilean central bank raised today to 20 escudos per United States dollar from 12.21 the exchange rate used for the purchase of essential food imports. On Wednesday, the exchange rate on the financial market was increased to 46 escudos per dollar from 28 and the rate for paying air fares and traveling expenses abroad was increased to 85 escudos from 42.

title: Soldier Shot Dead in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 4 (Reuters)A British sol dier was killed by a sniper here today, the first member of the security forces to die in a shoot ing incident since the army oc cupied Catholic areas of North ern Ireland four days ago. The soldier was hit by a single shot as he was taking part in a search for arms in a former Belfast stronghold of the Irish Republican Army. Minutes be fore, his patrol had found carbine and a rifle hidden un der a hedge.

title: Senator Ribicoff Weds Mrs. Lois Mell Mathes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut and Mrs. Lois Mell Mathes, a Miami civic leader, were married here this morningin time for the bridegroom to attend the afternoon session of the Senate.

title: SOUL AT CENTER HITS A LOW NOTE
description: The Soul at the Center series very nearly came a cropper at last night's Alice Tully Hall concert. Only two acts were presenteda singer, Esther Marrow, and a soul group called Chairmen of the Boardand neither was really up to the qualitative standard that has prevailed until now.

title: China Hails Discovery of 2,100YearOld Han Tomb
description: PEKING, Aug. 4The discov ery of a western Han Dynasty tomb dating back more than 2,100 years is being hailed in China as one of the most im portant archeological finds in decades.

title: That Quick Fox Has E ditor on Go
description: True to type, untiringly, for something like the last century.

title: New Image in Question
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4The New York Giants will make their second foray into exhibi tion football tomorrow night, playing the Pittsburgh Steelers at Three Rivers Stadium, but this time there will be no sat isfactory performance in de feat as there was in last week's 2317 loss to the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Contempt Citation Upheld
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 4 (AP) The Maryland Court of Spe cial Appeals today upheld the civil contempt citation of Baltimore Evening Sun reporter who refused to reveal to grand jury a store where he had been offered marijuana. The reporter, David M. Light man, had gone to the store, the court said, as a private citizen and did not identify himself as a reporter.

title: Clark Sees Dike Damage
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 4 . (Agence FrancePresse)  A former United States Attorney General, Ramsey Clark, visited a hamlet yesterday that the North Vietnamese said had been bombed by American air craft less than two weeks ago. He also watched villagers re pairing damage to a dike.

title: GLADYS M'PEEK
description: Miss Gladys McPeek, since 1950 executive director of Hart ley House, 413 West 46th Street, died there Wednesday of a heart ailment. Her age was 78.

title: SCOTT PANEL WINS TEST ON TESTIMONY
description: All city employes called to testify publicly or privately be fore the Scott Commission must comply even if none of the five commissioners are present, State Supreme Court Justice Margaret Mary Mangan ruled yesterday.

title: Korean Red Cross Officials Postpone Full Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. The Red Cross talks between North and South Korea on the reunion of divided families, which had been scheduled to open tomorrow, were indefinte ly postponed today.

title: City Opens Astoria Cleanup In CommunityBacked Drive
description: The city's Sanitation Depart ment yesterday began a three week, intensive cleanup cam paign in the Astoria section of Queens designed to influence residents and businessmen to keep the area tidy after the campaign ends.

title: Mets Defeat Cubs; Mays Gets 3 Hits
description: There was a little touch of Willie in the night air at Shea Stadium last evening and the Mets found it refreshing.

title: Westinghouse Gets Contract
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day receipt of an order for approximately $20million for four gasturbine generator units from the Northern States Power Company, Two of the units will be installed in the utility's Wheaton packing plant near Eau Claire, Wis., while the other two will be located in the French Island site near La Crosse, Wis. The first two are expected to be operating next May and the second two a year later.

title: Men's Clothing Surge Is Seen by Producers
description: With the wholesale selling season for next spring's men's tailored clothing about to officially open at mid month, producers are look ing forward to their greatest volume year since 1969.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP)The Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League filed suit in Suffolk Superior Court today to prevent two former members, Gerry Cheevers and Derek Sanderson, from playing in the new World Hockey Association. Sanderson and Cheevers, standouts on the team that won last season's Stanley Cup, recently signed contracts with the new league.

title: PHILIP WASSERMAN
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 4Philip Wasserman, an execu tive and a partner in Rotanelli Foods, Inc., a manufacturer and distributor of specialty foods in Yonkers, died today in New Rochelle Hospital of a coronary attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 108 Lawn Terrace.

title: Treasury Hails Results
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Reu ters)Richard V. Adams, spe cial assistant for debt manage ment of the Treasury Depart ment, said today the Treasury was pleased with the results of the refunding and added that the department had accom plished what it set out to do with the exchange offerings.

title: 3 Oil Reservoirs Near Trieste Burn After 4 Explosions
description: ROME, Aug. 4Three oil res ervoirs near Trieste, Italy, caught fire early today after four explosions, and Govern ment investigators said later that at least one of the blasts was caused by an explosive charge, possibly a time bomb.

title: To Regain the Past
description: If the People's party looks dreamily to the future, the American party convention in Louisville looks wistfully to the past. Its delegates hoped against hope that Gov. George C. Wallace would suddenly appear on the rostrum, hale in body and spirit, and accept again their nomination. And in a way it is a pity he could not oblige. Through him, they had a voice and a sense that they could still work within the system. Without him, some will probably follow even less predictable champions than the Alabama Governor while others fall victim to the apathy frustration.

title: Swedish Trains Collide
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 4 (Reu ters)A Stockholmbound ex press collided tonight with a freight train and at least two people, the engineers, were killed and about 20 injured, the police reported. Both locomo tives were thrown off the track upon impact and five passenger cars piled up in a pyramid, the police said.

title: Spains'Miracle Wins No Cheers in Segovia
description: The Talk of Segovia

title: Shore Road Entry to Close
description: The Traffic Department said yesterday that the westbound entrance to the Shore Parkway at Fourth Avenue and 101st Street in the Fort Hamilton sec tion of Brooklyn would be closed for about a week begin ning at 9 A.M. Monday, while the ramp is reconstructed. Westbound traffic may enter at Bay Eighth Street and at 65th Street, the department said.

title: Roundup: Tigers Drop 4th in Row, 10, Orioles 3d in Row, 20
description: The Detroit Tigers lost their fourth straight game last night, 10, but the Ameni can League Eastern Division leaders did not lose any ground. The Baltimore Ori oles, the secondplace team, were beaten by the Boston Red Sox, 20. The loss was their third straight and sixth in the last seven games.

title: Ali MacGraw Seeks Divorce
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 4 (Reuters)Ali MacGraw, star of the movie Love Story, to day filed suit for divorce here from Robert Evans, a film ex ecutive connected with Para mount Studios in Hollywood. The couple married Oct. 24, 1969, and separated yesterday. They have one child, Joshua, who is 19 months old. Grounds for the divorce were said to be irreconcilable differences.

title: SLIGHT INCREASE IS MADE BY AMEX
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market man aged to finish with slight gains yesterday in moderate trading.

title: STATE COURT VOIDS STEWART'S VICTORY
description: State Supreme Court Justice Anthony J. DiGiovanna ordered a new primary election yester day for the Democratic nomi nation in Brooklyn's 18th Sen atorial District because there were so many irregularities in the June 20 contest that it was impossible to tell who really won.

title: McMillan, Miss Nero Win
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) Frew McMillan and Jaime Pinto Bravo gained the men's semi finals and Linda Tuero advanced to the women's semifinals in the Western tennis champion ships today.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 4 (UPI)The current rate of expansion in world oil production is at one of its lowest levels history, according to the Petroleum Press Service. Global output from January through June was 50 million barrels a day, up 3 per cent from the yearearlier period, the service said today. The growth rate for oil from the non Communist world alone was only 2.3 per cent, one the lowest ever recorded, it added.

title: Columbia Gas Net Rises In Half, but Quarter Lags
PEEP SHOWS SHUT AT TIDIES SQUARE
description: Peepshow movies in the Times Square area have been closed down after a series of police raids that resulted in at least 20 arrests for obscenity since Tuesday.

title: Ballet: Tudor Tradition
description: Antony Tudor has only a handful of works still in the repertory of the American Ballet Theater, but somehow it is this handful that does much in giving the company its special character. In something of the same way although to nothing like the same extent, Mr. Tudor even now represents the Ballet Theater just as George Balan chine represents the New York City Ballet.

title: Killing of Twenty Guerrillas Announced in Mozambique
description: BEIRA, Mozambique, Aug. 4 (Agence FrancePresse)Twen ty African guerrillas were killed and 11 were wounded by Portuguese forces in operations in central and northern Mozam bique since July 21, it was an nounced here today.

title: Music: Newport's Touch
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 4 One of the things that dis tinguishes the Newport Mu sic Festival from so many others is that there is enjoy ment in its concert halls as well as outside them. The performers are serious about their musicmaking, but the works they perform do not necessarily have to be of the grave; browfurrowing va riety that marks most such programs elsewhere.

title: A.E.C. Dismantles Aleutian Test Site of Controversial 71 Underground Blast
description: AMCHITKA, Alaska  The Atomic Energy Commission has started to dismantle the bomb testing range that was a center of world attention for a few days last November at the time of the Cannikin bomb explosion beneath this 42mile long island.

title: I.M.F. Won't Sell Own Gold
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Reu ters)The International Mone tary Fund does not intend to sell any of its own gold on international bullion markets, informed sources said today. The I.M.F. declined to issue an official comment on British press reports that it might sug gest selling stocks of its own monetary gold reserves to de press the freemarket price.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Shortly before Senator Thom as F. Eagleton withdrew as the VicePresidential nomi nee Monday night, he re ceived some conflicting ad vice from two Democratic representatives from New York.

title: Rights Panel Given A Role on Sex Bias In Senate Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP)The Senate passed today a bill extending the life of the United States Civil Rights Com mission and authorizing it for the first time to investigate sex discrimination.

title: To Win the Future
description: Most of electoral politics can fairly be called the art the possible because candidates and their supporters are preoccupied with winning the election immediately ahead of them. But there are candidates and parties concerned only with pushing back the boundaries of the possible. Their objective is not to win the next election but to in fluence the thinking of the next generation.

title: Jobs and Prices
description: The economic recovery is gathering momentum, but the latest official statistics show how far. President Nixon is from having solved the problems of unemploy ment and inflation.

title: ALBERT N. LEMAN, HEADED MCLURES
description: ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 4 Albert N. Leman, former editor in chief of McClure's News paper Syndicate and an aide in the election campaigns of Dwight D. Eisenhower and Richard M. Nixon, died today in AddisonGilbert Hospital, Gloucester. He was 75 years old.

title: COMMUNITY AIDES CURBED IN DEALS
description: Thousands of unpaid city of ficials were barred yesterday from doing business with the city within their jurisdictions.

title: Catherine Spaak Is Wed
description: MEDA, Italy, Aug. 4 (AP) Catherine Spaak, the actress, and the Italian entertainer Johnny Dorelli were married today at the City Hall in Meda, a town near Milan where the singer spent his boyhood. It was the second marriage for Miss Spaak, who was divorced in 1968 from the Italian fashion designer Fabrizio Capucci. Miss Spaak, a niece of the late Bel gian statesman Paul  Henri Spaak, has a 9yearold daugh ter from that marriage.

title: U.S. Hijackers in Algiers Said to Have Been Freed
description: ALGIERS, Aug. 4 (AP)A Black Panther spokesman said today that the Americans who hijacked a Delta Air Lines jet with $1million ransom to Al geria this week had been re leased from government cus tody. Big government sources said the hijackers had been free to move about as they wish since their arrival.

title: 10 Senators Seek Halt to Dike Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Declaring there has been de liberate United States bombing of the North Vietnamese dike system, 10 Democratic Senators today asked Congress to go on record against it.

title: U.P.I. TO SEEK PACT ON VISIT TO PEKING
description: United Press International announced yesterday that party of newsmen led by Roderick W. Beaton, president of the news agency, plans to visit China this month to discuss a news and newspictures agree ment with the official Hsinhua press agency and to write a series of articles.

title: Sally Snow Is Wed To A. B.Warrick Jr.
description: SACO, Me., Aug. 4Miss Sally Adrienne Snow was married this evening to Alex ander Bowen Warrick Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Warrick of York Harbor. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Philip Porter Snow of Saco.

title: U.S. Tells of a 2d Pipeline From China to Fuel Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  Sehior Defense Department of ficials said today that North Vietnam had virtually com pleted a second new fuel pipe line from China to Ken, a town 30 miles northeast of Hanoi.

title: MARJORIE C. SMITH, EXSYRACUSE DEAN
description: NORTH CONWAY, N. H., Aug. 4 (UP1)  Marjorie C. Smith, Dean of Women at Syracuse University from 1949 to 1969, died yesterday in a hospital here.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 4 (AP)  Dave and Jim Haze winkel of Coon Rapids, Minn., twin brothers, were among five wrestlers who won berths on the United States Olympic GrecoRoman team last night.

title: Mrs. King Triumphs
description: COLUMBUS. Ga., Aug. 4 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King ral lied to beat Helen Gourlay, 06, 63, 63, today and move into the semifinal round of the $25,000 Virginia Slims women's tennis tournament.

title: Senators Press Nixon on Jackson Proviso
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to seek an unequivocal public statement from President Nixon on whether he supported inter pretations that Senator Henry M. Jackson is proposing to at tach to, the offensiveweapons agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: The Bremer Verdict
description: The diary of Arthur H. Bremer, read to a jury in a Maryland court, is the story of a man who wanted des perately to shoot President Nixon but, failing that, was willing to settle for Governor Wallace, Senator Mc Govern or even a couple of Secret Service men. The jury nevertheless found him sane, and therefore legally accountable for his abominable assault on the Alabama Governor.

title: 3 Midlands Children Dead
description: SPALDING, England, Aug. 4 (Reuters)Police recovered the bodies of three small children from a muddy river near this eastern Midlands town today and said that a housekeeper had been charged with murder.

title: JERSEY CITY WORKER SLAYS WIFE AND SON
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 4  A 52yearold factory worker shot his wife and a son to death during a family quarrel last night and then committed suicide, the police said today.

title: JAMES N. DUNLOP
description: James Nathaniel Dunlop, a retired lawyer who had been with Winthrop, Stimson, Put nam & Roberts here, died Thursday at the New York Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 535 Park Avenue and Point O Woods on Fire Is land, L.I.

title: City's Patrol Force Smallest Since 1968
description: Donald F. Cawley, the chief of the Police Department's pa trol force, disclosed yesterday that the number of uniformed patrolmen in his command had fallen to 15,740the lowest level in about four years.

title: Travelers Corp. Net Up
description: Net income of the Travelers Corporation rose in the second quarter to $35.5million, or 77 cents a share, from $19.3 million, or 41 cents a share, year earlier, the insurance hold ing company said yesterday. Results exclude realized gains.

title: Whitelaw Tells Irish Aide He Still Plans Ulster Vote
description: LONDON, Aug. 4The Irish Foreign Minister, Dr. Patrick J. Hillery, met today with Wil liam Whitelaw, Northern Ire land's administrator, to discuss Dublin's delicate role in the Ulster crisis.

title: Personalities: Skaters Organize
description: The newest pro sports league was created yesterday when Ard Schenk, who has the distinction of being the world's bestknown speed skater, and 13 other racers signed with a speedskating league in Stockholm. The league is funded by a South Carolina investor named Wil liam H. Moore, who recently was introduced to a Swedish businessman by their mutual friend, Jack Nicklaus. The Swede was looking for back ing and Moore provided it.

title: SOYBEANS CLIMB BY 10CENT LIMIT
description: Soybean futures attracted a large amount of commercial buying yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade, especially by one grain company. It ap peared to some observers that the recently reported interest of the Soviet Union in soy beans and soybean meal had resulted in a deal.

title: Prisoners in Britain Stage Protests Over Conditions
description: LONDON, Aug. 4At least 10 per cent of Britain's 40,000 prison inmates staged 24hour sitdown demonstrations today to protest prison conditions.

title: Costly and Controversial F111 Is Fully Accepted by Air Force
description: WASHINGTONAny time there's anything wrong with on F111 it's all over the news papers, said Lieut. Col. Robert Morrison, but believe me, I've put in plenty of hours on it and the F111 can do more things, things the Air Force needs, than any other aircraft and it's stable and safe, too. Born in controversy and reared in criticism, the F111 has been plagued by the bugs common to all aircraft that embody technological break throughs. But the F111 and the fighter bomber version, the FB111, are fully accepted by the Air Force.

title: Pontiac Division Calls Back 43,000 Grand Prix Models
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Aug. 4 (UPI)  General Motors' Pon tiac Division announced today that it had recalled 43,000 of its 1972 Grand Prix models to eliminate a battery cable prob lem that had resulted in 26 re ported fires.

title: Seagren Is Highly Upset Over Pole Vault Dispute
description: OSLO, Aug. 4 Bob Sea gren charged today that pres sure politics had forced in ternational officials to out law his fiberglass pole only one month before the Olym pic Games.

title: $8.1Billion Is Exchanged In Big Treasury Refunding
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Treasury announced today that the public had exchanged grand total of $8.1billion of securities maturing between Aug. 15 and early 1975 for three new issues offered in exchange.

title: New Subway Maps Introduced; To Be Distributed Next Monday
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority displayed a new series of subway maps yes terday in an attempt to un tangle a system that on paper often looks as confusing as a mass of spaghetti.

title: A Senator Proposes Bill to End Secrecy In the Government
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  Senator Lawton Chiles, criti cizing Government decisions made in secret, proposed today what he called a government in the sunshine law.

title: Ackles Blends His Vocal Style To Transcend Era at Bitter End
description: David Ackles, singer and songwriter, must be one of the most unusual performers in to day's world of pop music. Like an anachronism, he turned up at Paul Colby's Bitter End Wednesday night, singing origi nal songs in a style and man ner that had as much to do with 1940 and 1950 as with 1972.

title: SPAIN LEADING U.S. IN CUP TENNIS, 10
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 4 Andres Gimeno, who got his birthday presents yesterday when Manuel Orantes Injured his back and dropped out, put the icing on the cake today by beating Stan Smith to give Spain a 10 lead over the Unit ed States in the Davis Cup in terzone semifinal round.

title: Miss Moffett Bride of R. N. Rubey
description: LITTLE COMPTON, R. I., Aug. 4Miss Sheila Moffett was married here at noon today to Robert Neal Rubey. Only members of the im mediate families attended the Episcopal ceremony, per formed by the Rev. Robert R. Hansell at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mor ris Phelps, stepfather and mother of the bride. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Munro Longyear Lyeth of Aspen, Colo., and the late William Bonner Rubey.

title: The Warheads and Systems Slated to Be Improved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  The Administration's moves to develop but not deploy, better strategic missiles in volve the following improve. ments and systems:

title: MAJORWAR PLANS ARE BEING REVISED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4  The Nixon Administration is quietly moving to shift the em phasis of American strategic planning in case of a major war and to develop bigger, more accurate warheads and other weapons to carry out such plans.

title: 'Super Fly':Ron O'Neal Has Lead as Narcotics Dealer
description: "Super Fly" is the story of Priest, a successful black New York narcotics dealer who decides to quit the businessand does it. To finance his retirement he means to deal $300,000 worth of cocaine into a $1-million profit, and so "Super Fly" belongs in the company of all those crime movies that have had as their subject the one big last job.That it does not also belong with those movies portraying the evils of drugs, must be the result of very intelligent calculation; for there is no moralizing, not even the subtle silent kind, and the film's most eloquent spoken passage is given to Priest's partner when he defends dealing as a way of life."Super Fly" is almost exclusively an action movie, but with the distinction that all the action means something, and is not simply a lot of running or driving or flying around for the mechanical titillation of the customers. The film's gut pleasures are real, and there are a lot of them. But, they always connect with one another in a world so precisely, cruelly, excitingly balanced that there is no movement without countermovement, no pressure without a greater pressure in return.It is a world of the most limited optionsall leading to the question of being in or getting out. For Priest merely to win some time to make choices, he must engineer an escape that inevitably creates a prison for somebody elsethe bad guy as it happens, the Man, the biggest dealer of them all. But a feeling for absolute and fateful interdependence has always been the special glory of the best crime movies. The world of "Super Fly" may be hell, but it also makes sense.Tall, handsome, with flowing hair and coat, with flashing eyes, and with a gold cross around his neck that he uses to sniff his own cocaine, Priest must embody a lifetime of fantasies, with his mammoth car, his apartment downtown, his rich and elegant women. Ron O'Neal lives the part with a kind of furious authority that is sometimes excessive; more often expressive of a role that belongs as much to current myth as to reality. Carl Lee as his treacherous, timorous partner is even more impressive, partly because he speaks, whereas Priest mostly acts, and he happens to get the best lines.It would be possible to fault "Super Fly" almost scene by scene for its minor blunders. As a director, Gordon Parks Jr. shares with his celebrated father a difficulty in managing simple exchanges between actors, a tendency sometimes to misjudge camera placement, an occasional weak reliance on handsome cinematography. But he has gotten so many more important things right and, in his first feature, he has made such a brilliantly idiomatic films, that it would be ridiculous to do less than praise him."Super Fly," a very good movie, opened yesterday at the Loew's State I and Loew's Cine theaters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET SAID TO HALT HEART TRANSPLANTS
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 4 (UPI) A distinguished Soviet doctor said today that Russia had discontinued heart trans plants. He said that Russians did not accept the American definition of death.

title: At Concert, They Showed It Can Still Be Fun to Dress Up
description: Who says nobody gets dressed up to go to the theater these days? The audi ences at Lincoln Center where the Soul at the Center festival has been going on during the past two weeks, proved that making a special effort is not a lost virtue.

title: SPECIAL LIBRARY HELPS EDUCATORS
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Aug. 4  When Oliver Redington needed to learn all about class rooms he did not have the time to pore over books and maga zines at the public library.

title: Slam by Yanks' Mercer Helps Beat Brewers, 94
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4  A grand slam by Bobby Murcer in the seventh inningthe first for New York this season  pro vided the big moment tonight as the Yankees defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 94, in the opener of a fourgame stand.

title: Antiques: Real Thing
description: If you develop a knowl edge of 18thcentury French furniture styles, you can buy authentic pieces for virtually the same prices that others are paying for old reproduc tions.

title: M'GOVERN OFFERS MUSKIE 2D PLACE IN 2HOUR PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senator George McGovern has offered the Democratic nomi nation for Vice President to Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, and Mr. Muskie said tonight he was looking for reasons to do it.

title: State Farm Sales Increase
description: The State Farm Mutual Auto mobile Company, the nation's largest automobile insurer, re ported yesterday that its sales during the first six months of the year jumped nearly $95 million to $991million from $896.2million a year earlier. State Farm is a mutual com pany and has no stockholders.

title: Ashe, Lutz Triumph and Gain Semifinals in U. S. Pro Tennis
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 4 (UPDArthur Ashe, ex tending his victory string to seven, was pushed to the limit today before beating Tony Roche of Australia, 36, 75, 64, and advancing to the semifinals of the $50,000 United States professional tennis champion ships.

title: Egypt, Israel and the Zionist Man's Burden
description: To the Editor: I do not know just what lay behind the de parture of Soviet military advisers from Egypt, though, judging from con versations I had with con servative Egyptians in Cairo several months ago, I would suspect that it is linked with a desire on their part to achieve a rapprochement with the United States in order to curtail radical tendencies in their country.

title: Wines of California Gain in Glamour
description: ST. HELENA, Calif.The vast increase in wine drink ing In recent years has worked extraordinary changes in the California vineyards. Wineries that once sold all their product in tank car lots now strive to produce rare and elegant wines to compete with the best of France.

title: Half a Million Does His Laundry
description: Sports of The Times

title: BILL WOULD EASE BOXCAR SHORTAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Senate passed a bill to day by an 81.0 vote to provide railroads with loan guarantees totaling $2billion in an at tempt to end the perennial box car shortage.

title: New Fees Halving Reynolds Charges
description: Reynolds Securities, Inc., major brokerage concern, indi cated yesterday that the abo lition of fixed commission charges on large stock trans actions was having a major im pact in the securities industry.

title: SAMUEL FINE
description: Samuel Fine, a retired men's clothing manufacturer, philan thropist and community leader in the Boro Park section of Brooklyn, died Wednesday night in Maimonides Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived at 1458 50th Street, Brooklyn.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The Justice Department announced tonight that it had dropped perjury indictment against Leslie Ann Bacon in connection with the bombing of the United States Capitol March 1, 1971.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4The State Department, in its annual survey of Soviet military aid. reported last month that 100 Soviet military personnel were stationed in Yemen. It esti mated that from 1955 to 1971 the Soviet Union extended $75million in military assist ance.

title: Show of Schwitters's Art Has Sparkle And Irony
description: The Museum of Modern Art's new Kurt Schwitters exhibition, which opened Monday and will close Sept. 10, is a sparkling show that points up, perhaps without meaning to, the major irony and half a dozen other con tradictions upon which this formidable 20thcentury rep utation rests.

description: A request for an injunction to halt construction of a Con solidated Edison power plant in Queens was rejected yes terday by Federal Judge Morris E. Lasi er.

title: Lion's Owner Faces Trial After a Child Is Mauled
description: DENVER, Aug. 4 (UPI)The owner of the pet lion that mauled a 3yearold child on Wednesday had been told to get the animal out of town last month and will now be prose cuted in criminal court, City Councilman Larry 3. Perry said yesterday.

title: Bill Would Help Exchanges. Solve Paperwork Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Senate passed by voice vote and sent to the House today a bill designed to help overcome the paperwork prob lems of the securities Industry.

title: JOB SAFETY LAW: HOW EFFECTIVE?
description: Results of a yearold, tough Federal job safety and health program covering some 57 mil lion workers in more than four million industry establishments have been satisfying, a top Labor Department official said here this week.

title: 10thGame Loss a Foregone Conclusion
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland,, Aug. As expected, Boris Spassky had no chance after the re sumption of the 10th game here today in the match for the world championship.

title: REDSKINS CONQUER COLTS IN FLORIDA
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 4 (AP) Billy Kilmer, Redskins' quarter back, tossed a pair of touch down passes to, fire Washing ton to a 333 victory over the sluggish Baltimore Colts in a National Football League pre season game tonight.

title: U. S. Tightens Sulphur Controls
description: HELENA, Mont., Aug. 4The Federal Environmental Protec tion Agency has upheld the high sulphuremission control re quirements for two Montana metal processing plants that have been the subject of con troversy since last December.

title: If I Were President
description: It seems a little absurd for one in my position to be asked, or to answer the question as to what I would do or would not do if I were President of the United States, since no such contin gency has even one chance in sixty million to be realized. But, if that chance should happen, it would prob ably be my experience and my misfor tune to make as many blunders and give just cause for as much criticism as any one, who has ever occupied the Presidential chair. One thing however I would do or try to do. I would em ploy every means supplied to the Pres ident by the. Constitution of the United States, to secure to every citizen of the United States, without regard to race, color, sex or religion, equal protection of the laws. No citizen, however poor or despised, should be able to say at the close of my administration that he had suffered any injustice or had been in any way oppressed or injured by any act of mine while acting as Presi

description: PARIS, Aug. 4  A new French law has just taken effect according children born out of wedlock the same legal rights as those whose parents are married.

The Newark Boys Chorus, appearing on the series known as Five Summer Evenings on the Mall, had got ten to the end of their program and were swinging away on such lively gospel tunes as I Hear Music and I Want to be Ready When You Call My Name.

description: If the woman question seems trivial, Simone de Beauvoir has said, it is because masculine arrogance has made of it a quarrel' and when quar relling, one no longer reasons well.

description: Jerome Minskoff, a member of the real estate family con structing the office building and theaters on the site of the old Astor Hotel, has joined forces with Albert W. Selden and John Forsythe in the production of Abraham's Mask, the work ing title of a play by Vincent J. Longhi.

title: Tigers Get Dodgers' Sims
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP) Duke Sims, a Los Angeles Dodger catcher, was sold today to the Detroit Tigers.

title: JURY SAID TO CALL MACKELL'S AIDES
description: A series of subpoenas, pos sibly as many as 20, were issued to members of the staff of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens yesterday for appearances before a Fed eral grand jury in Brooklyn starting on Monday, according to sources close to the jury.

title: On Mountain of Gold, Seamstresses Find Pay Is Low
description: In Hong Kong not too many months ago Mrs. Mei Wong and her husband op erated a wig business and were making what she called good money. Then her husband decided to come to Gum San, the mountain of gold, as the Chinese in Hong Kong call the United States, and his wife, though she was happy making wigs, agreed.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Members of a coalition of anti war organizations outlined to. day their plans for protest activities at the Republican Na tional Convention in Miami Beach and pledged that there would be no violence.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI)George Meany, in a little noted speech earlier this week, said that the decision of the A.F.L.C.I.O. executive council to be neutral in this year's Presidential election was a declaration of inde pendence from the Demo cratic party.

title: Exchange Students
description: HARTFORDAn I.B.M. vice presi dent will be working for the Connecti cut Department of Environmental Protection this year under a company program of oneyear paid leaves of absence for qualified executives to serve worthwhile public, civic and governmental causes.

title: Japan to Increase Price
description: TOKYO, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Japan will raise her domestic price of gold for nonmonetary use next month in view of rising overseas prices, the Fi nance Ministry said today.

title: FreeMarket Prices Down
description: LONDON, Aug. 4 (UPI) Profittaking sales by specula tors pushed the price of gold lower in European free mar kets today but new buyers ap peared once the metal retreat ed from its nearrecord levels.

title: FRANK A. CORBET
description: VENICE, Fla., Aug. 4Frank A. Corbet, retired president of the dCon Company, Inc., a subsidiary of Sterling Drug, Inc., died yesterday at his home here. He was 66 years old.

title: Paper Under Bias Inquiry
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 (AP)On the complaint of two women's groups, the state Fair Employment Practices Corn mission has ordered an investi gation of the hiring practices of The Los Angeles Times.

title: Bremer Guilty in Shooting Of Wallace, Gets 63 Years
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Aug. 4Arthur H. Bremer was found guilty and sentenced to 63 years in prison today for the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama and three other persons at a political rally Laurel, Md., May 15.

title: John Huston: Musings on Tat City and Other Pursuits
description: It was a party for John Huston in the courtyard of the Museum of Modern Art on a warm night. Mr. Huston was moving about in a seer sucker suit, smiling over his short beard, extending his hand and saying over and over again, So glad to meet you, so glad.

title: HEATH AND CABINET ASSESS DOCK STRIKE
description: LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) Prime Minister Heath held an emergency meeting with the Cabinet today to assess the ef fect of the weekold dock strike on Britain's economy and food supplies.

title: Art: The Human Figure in Oceanic Sculptures
description: A museum like the Met ropolitan must always be on the lookout for art works not only of quality but also of historical importance. It must be a showcase for the best in artistic expression through the ages. In two unrelated summer shows, the museum effectively demonstrates how it meets these demands. One is an exhibition devoted to Oceanic sculpture and the other is devoted to recent ac quisitions of American paint ings of the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Thoughts on the Young
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Throughout history, the old and the middleaged have tried to reach across the genera tions and share the benefits of their hardwon experience with the young. It is an effort which can never entirely succeed. Not all of yesterday's wisdom exactly fits today's problems. Each of us has to make some mistakes on his own. Yet not all of the mistakes of the past have to be repeated. Indeed, human progress, if it is possible at all, is possible only because we benefit from the incremental wisdom of the past.

title: Dublin Reports Decrease in Tourism
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 5  The Irish Republic's tourist industry and drive for industrial develop ment have suffered severe set backs because of the conflict in Northern Ireland.

title: U.S.PLANS DETAILS FOR P.O.W.RETURN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Al though neither an end of the Vietnam war nor a release of prisoners seems imminent, the Administration has quietly drawn up a detailed program, codenamed Operation Egress Recap, for the eventual return and rehabilitation of the more than 500 Americans believed held captive in Southeast Asia.

title: Bloodbath in Binhdinh . . .
description: The public execution of an estimated 250 to 500 Saigon officials and others by Communist forces during their occupation of Binhdinh Province adds another sordid chapter to the bloody history of the Vietnam war.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  George McGovern had called it the sweet harvest when he accepted the Democratic nomination for President last month, but during most of last week it seemed more like a case of disastrous crop failure, His head start on the Republicans had with ered away, his hopes of party unity had been blighted, and his campaign had failed to sprout.

title: Justices Decline to Upset Stay of the Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger announced today that the Su preme Court had declined to upset Justice William O. Doug las's stay of the trial of the Pentagon papers case.

title: Lions Beat Dolphins, 3123
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5 (UPI)Lem Barney and Mel Farr scored touchdown each in the second quarter tonight to lead the De troit Lions to a 3123 victory over the Miami Dolphins in preseason game.

title: RIDGEFIELD FACES A HOUSING BATTLE
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 5 The Suburban Action Institute has taken an option to buy II acres in this northern Fairfield County residential community for the construction of 160 apartment units for low income and middleincome families.

title: Thayer Is Undefeated in Bay Regatta
description: GREAT RIVER, L. I., Aug. 5 Wayne Thayer sailed to his, sixth straight triumph today in the Beetlecat Class to become the only skipper competing in the Great South Bay Racing As sociation's race week champion ship to make a clean sweep of the series.

title: Hiroshima Marks Bomb; Mayor Pleads for Peace
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Sunday, Aug. 6 (Reuters)With a fer vent plea for peace and the abolition of nuclear weapons, Hiroshima today marked the 27th anniversary as the world's first atomic bombing.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Bobick Wins Heavyweight Berth on U.S. Team
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Aug. 5 (AP)Duane Bobick earned the heavyweight berth on the United States Olympic boxing team today when his weary opponent, Larry Holmes, was disqualified for holding in the third and last round of their bout in the final American trials.

title: The Claims Are Small, But Issues Are Large
description: I've got a friendly word of advice for all of my Forest Hills neighbors, as well as for all of the merchants in the area: Don't cross me. And that goes for my wife, too.

title: Chiefs, After Falling Behind by 100, Rally to Turn Back Bears, 2410
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 5 (AP)Len Dawson's touchdown pass to Wendell Hayes in the third quarter put Kansas City ahead by 1710 and the Chiefs went on to defeat the Chicago Bears, 2410, in a National Foot ball League preseason game to day.

title: Black Catholic Churches Are Mixing Jazz With Their Traditional Services
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5 It was unquestionably a Roman Catholic church. There was the Virgin, there the figure of the crucified Christ, around the walls the stations of the cross, up front the sanctuary rising to high stained glass that captured and held the sun that bright Southern morning.

title: Drug Traffic: Furor Over the Asian Pipeline
description: WASHINGTONA bill to cut off $100million in military and economic aid to Thailand as a penalty for failing to halt the flow of narcotics to the United States will come before the House on Tuesday. It is unlikely that the measure will ever become lawit has already been defeated in the Senate but it does reflect a furor in Wash ington over official handling of the Southeast Asian drug traffic problem.

title: Shane, Irish Wolfhound, Named Best Among 1,258 Dogs at Penn Ridge Show
description: HILLTOWN, Pa., Aug. 5 The Irish wolfhound, its breed ers say, has a history of more than 2,000 years. In 391 A.D. it is said that Quintus Aurelius Symmachus wrote to his broth er Flavianus, thanking him for sending him some of the giant dogs saying, All Rome viewed them with wonder.

title: Rachner Team Captures 4Day MG Car Club Rally
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 5  The husbandandwife team of Jeanne and Ed Rachner of Livingston, N. J., won the 20th annual MG Car Club interna tional rally that ended here to day after four days of driving.

title: Huston's Fine, Lean Fat City
description: FAT CITY, John Huston's fine, lean film version of Leonard Gardner's fine, lean novel, which Gardner himself adapted for the screen, seems to be about two smalltime boxersBilly Tully (Stacy Keach), a Skid Row bum who, at 30, makes a brief, agonizing comeback, and Ernie Munger (Jeff Bridges), a cleancut, 18yearold hopeful with a long reach and a soft center. Billy and Ernie live on the perimeter of a perimeter. The setting is Stockton, Calif. (pop. 113,000), which is not exactly the center of the fight game, and Billy and Ernie exist on the outer edges of Stockton's consciousness, in its hamburger joints, its gyms, its barrooms and cheap hotels, occasionally making ends meet by signing on as day laborers to pick lettuce or onions or walnuts in the San Joaquin Valley.

title: Satellite Scanning State's Shore
description: TRENTON  New Jersey, smile: you're on camera!

title: Court Denies Right Of President's Aide To Federal Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) A Federal judge has ruled that Charles W. Colson, special counsel to President Nixon, cannot be represented by a Jus tice Department lawyer in civil suit connected with the breakin and alleged attempted bugging of Democratic head quarters here.

title: SAIGON REPORTS CAMBODIA DRIVE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 6 (AP)South Vietnamese troops have opened a new drive against North Vietnamese and Viet cong forces in the Parrot's Beak region of Cambodia, the Saigon command announced yesterday.

title: Hudson's G.O.P. Hopeful
description: JERSEY CITY  A recur ring obstacle that Jeremiah Healy has to overcome in his quest for political recogni tion is skepticism. For Mr. Healy, young, ruddycheeked and Irish, and now a candi date for county freeholder, is a former vice chairman of the Young Republicans of Hudson County.

title: The World
description: MANILALast Wednesday, as dis astrous floods on the island of Luzon swept into their third week, St. Anne's Catholic church on a high point in Taguig, a town southeast of Manila, held almost 3,000 residents, plus a few pigs and chickens rescued from the rushing waters.

title: TIGERS WIN IN 11TH ON SIMS'S SINGLE
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 (AP) Duke Sims, just back in the American League after being acquired from the Los Angeles Dodgers, homered for Detroit's first run and singled home the winning run with two out in the 11th inning today to give the Tigers a 43 victory over the Cleveland Indians and Gaylord Perry.

title: Astros Defeat Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5 (AP)  Tommy Helms scored from third base as Cesar Ce deno bounced into a bases loaded force play in the ninth inning today, giving the Hous ton Astros a 43 victory over San Francisco despite three home runs by the Giants.

title: OGILVY'S ETCHELLS WINS SIXTH RACE
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 5C. Stanley Ogilvy strength ened his lead for the Etchells22 Class Yacht Racing Association championship today by winning his sixth race of the season with Flame as the Oriente Yacht Club conducted the sea son's 25th Y.R.A. regatta for a fleet of 84.

title: C. M. Heller Weds Mary Blackmon
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 5  In the Garfield Memorial Meth odist Church here this morn ing, Miss Mary Ellen Black mon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence George Black mon of Stamford, Conn., was married to Clifford Mayo Hel ler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred erick C. Heller of Rocky River. The Rev. Dr. George R. Parsons Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Art;Out of the River and Into the Palace at Pella
description: PELLA, in northern Greece and easily reached from Salon ica, was the birth place of Alexander the Great, and today let's write about the pebble mosaics re cently uncovered (and more to come) in the ruins of the palace there. Anyone who writes a column once a week deserves a break during Au gust in the form of one col umn devoted to a subject of his choice totally unrelated to the current scene. This is mine for 1972. Pebble mo saics.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONOne morning last week a reporter here received a call from a senior White House official. The official quarreled with the report er's rather gloomy assessment, based largely on opinions furnished by the State Department, that Henry A. Kis singer's meeting in Paris with Hanoi's top negotiators last Tuesday had pro duced no evidence of progress. The reporter asked: Can it be written, then, that there was progress? No, the official replied, my point is simply that it would be wise to withhold judgment.

title: Law
description: LOS ANGELESIf happiness is man facing a possible 115year prison term who gets his trial delayed, Daniel Ellsberg wore a surprisingly long face last week. If they'd lost, he said, I would have felt better.

title: Solomon Defeats Gisbert; U.S. and Spain Tied at 11
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 5Harold Solomon nervously paced up and down, the nerve endings showing as clearly as the catgut on his racquet.

title: World News Briefs
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 5 President Idi Amin announced today that all Asians with Brit ish passports would have to leave Uganda within three months. He said his decision would affect about 80,000 Asians.

title: The New Democratic VicePresidential Choice
description: Man in the News

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Following is a transcript of the address by Senator George McGovern on television last night from the Capitol in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Help Needed
description: MAN'S relationship with the purple martin has been long and profitable. From earliest times, the bird has been attracted away from its natural nesting sites in tree and rock cavities to live in close harmony with man. Gourds hung from trees are still used widely in the Southeast. The more formal purple martin apartment house graces thousands of North American yards. In fact, in the eastern half of North America, the purple martin now nests almost ex clusively in houses provided by man.

title: Planning an Itinerary
description: Arrangements for individual or group travel to Ngorongoro at all price ranges can be made in Nairobi, Kenya, and in Arusha, Tanzania, the latter about 80 miles by road from the crater. If one wishes to fly to Ngoron goro, a deal could be struck for a trip in a light aircraft, but rented cars or the public bus from Arusha to the crater (about $1.50 each way) are sufficient. A hotel room at Ngorongoro runs $20$30 a day, double, but there is also a youth hostel ($1 a night) and campsites available in both the crater area and on the Serengeti plain. One caution: Because of its altitude, the nights are chilly at the crater and a heavy coat is advisable.

title: WALL STREET
description: It is said in Wall Street that when I.B.M. hits a new high, all is well in the stock market.

title: Miss Muscio Bride Of Donald Mowat
description: ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 5In St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Marguerite Muscio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. U. V. Muscio of Old Brookville, was married to Donald B. Mowat, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Mowat of McLean, Va. The Rev. James Reid performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass.

title: Path Building, the Easy Way
description: AT first, we didn't think of paths. But the long er we lived in our woodsy Connecticut home, the more we realized that much of the four acres was so inaccessible that it might as well not even exist.

title: CARDI CANDIDATE FOR P.G. A. POST
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 5  Frank Cardi, professional at the Rockaway Hunt Club, Cedarhurst, L.1., an outspoken critic of some Professional Golfers Association policies, has been nominated for the presi dency of the P.G.A. it was learned here.

title: Orioles Lose to Red Sox
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)Rico Petrocelli drove in six runs with his third grand slam of the year and a tworun double as the Boston Red Sox whipped the Baltimore Orioles, 63, today for their fourth straight victory.

title: Miss Ruth Pennington Wed to David Bright
description: Miss Ruth Ferne Penning ton was married here yester day afternoon in the Marble Collegiate Church to David Eugene Bright, corporate di rector of quality assurance for the American Hospital Supply Corporation in Evans ton, Ill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Doug lass Smith.

title: Royals Triumph, 21
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 5 (AP) Gail Hopkins drove in the tying run with a pop fly single and then Fred Patek delivered the gamewinner with another base hit as the Kansas City Royals rallied for two runs in the ninth inning today to beat the California Angels, 21.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Too many chickens produc ing too many eggs are pro ducing too many headaches for the nation's egg pro ducers.

title: 3 Slain in Oaklahoma City
description: OAKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 5 (UPI)Gunmen methodically executed last night a 30yearold man, his wife and their 6year old son in a grocery with one bullet each through the back of the head. The police arrested three suspects today.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONOnly a day after five men were caught breaking into Democratic headquarters in the Water gate apartments here last June, one of them was identified as a security agent for both the Republican National Committee and the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: Thai Held on Drug Charge
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 5 (UPI)United States narcotics agents and Thai policemen com bined to arrest a Bangkok widow with $5million worth of heroin, a spokesman said to day. The spokesman said the woman, a mother of five, was charged with producing heroin. About 11 pounds of heroin was found in her downtown Bangkok house along with drugproduc ing instruments, chemicals and weighing machines, the spokes man said.

title: Soviet Withdrawal From Egypt Is Almost Complete
description: CAIRO, Aug. 5Three weeks after it began, the exodus of approximately 20,000 Soviet military advisers, pilots and missile crews from Egypt has been virtually completed.

title: The Forecast for Paris: A Wet Weather Bureau
description: PARIS, Aug. 5The Paris weather bureau has developed a leaky roof, papers here re ported this week.

title: IMPERIAL WIZZARD WINS IN JUMPING
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Aug. 5 Alex Potter rode Imperial Wizzard to the preliminary jumper championship today at the Litchfield Hotse Show.

title: Thomas Is Ordered Off After Dispute on Airliner
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 (AP)Duane Thomas, re portedly absent from the San Diego Chargers' training camp since a midweek trade, was ordered off a plane late last night in a row with American Airlines' officials.

title: M'GOVERN ASSAILS NIXON ON JOBLESS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Sen ator George McGovern charged today that President Nixon's economic policies had thrown nearly five million people out of work and added $450 a year to the grocery bill of the av erage family.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONLate one night last February, as his jet plane bounced through a Florida thunderstorm, the weary Governor of Alabama and bonetired journalist were mutually lamenting the rigors of a Presidential campaign.

title: DECISION HAILED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Sen ator George McGovern chose Sargent Shriver as his Vice Presidential running mate today after Senator Edmund S. Mus kie had rejected his invitation to join the Democratic ticket.

title: Notes: Machu Picchu
description: THE rarefied air of Machu Picchu, the preIncan city high in the Andes Mountains, is crackling with controversy these days following the Peruvian Government's announce ment that it will build a $3million, 200room hotel just 500 yards from the ruins. Archeologists and environmental ists have joined forces to denounce the project, contending it will constitute a major threat to the esthetics of one of the continent's greatest wonders. No matter what design is adopted for the facility, which is being sponsored by Peru's National Agency for Tourism, op ponents argue, it will still scar the land scape. The new hotel has been proposed to replace an 18room inn that has proved too small to accommodate the increasing number of visitors who wish to stay at the site overnight. At present, most tourists stay at Cuzco, 50 miles southeast of the ruins. In light of the controversy, a commission is studying to build the hotel farther away.

title: Panel in Kuwait Urges Loans for Bachelors
description: KUWAIT, Aug. 5 (AP)A government planning board is urging state help for the oppressed bachelor's of Ku wait. It suggests loans to en courage marriage.

title: Proposed State Law Would Require Dogs to Be Tattooed and Kept Under the Direct Control of Owners
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5A law has been proposed to control all dogs in New York State, ex cept those in New York City, under a system requiring that dogs be tattooed for perma nent identification, rabies shots become mandatory and dogs be kept on a leash or under the direct control of their own ers.

title: Science/ Medicine
description: WASHINGTONIn the last few years, the amount of medical informa tion exchanged by the United States and the Soviet Union has varied in versely with the degree of political invective poured out by the govern ments of both countries. Last week new accords offered further proof of the continuing thaw in their relations.

title: Bloop Single by Hickman Drives In 2 Chicago Runs
description: The New York Mets lost ground in two directions yes terday when they dropped a 32 decision to the Chicago Cubs on a looping little single by Jim Hickman with two down in the eighth inning. The sin gle was a kind of mortar lob behind third base off Danny Frisella, the kind that might be caught by three people or that might just drop in. in the eighth inning. The sin gle was a kind of mortar lob behind third base off Danny Frisella, the kind that might be caught by three people or that might just drop in. It just did drop in, two runs scored and the whole game was turned around.

title: State Bans Expansion Of Realtors In Laurelton
description: In an attempt to quell residents' fears of unscrupu lous practices by real estate brokers, John P. Lomenzo, the New York Secretary of State, has announced that he will not permit the establish ment of any more brokerage offices in the Laurelton sec tion of Queens.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Boston looking for the Irish, there is an event next week end that is expected to bring them out in force, On Aug. 12 and 13 the Columban Fathers are staging their own benefit on their grounds in the suburb of Milton. (Call 6173330600.) This annual affair, which one of the Columban Fathers describes as the original happening, brings together Bos ton Irish families from various parts of the city for Irish dancing and singing and refreshments un der the trees. There will be chicken dinner on Sunday, the 13th. No one, a spokesman for the Columban Fathers said, is quite sure when the benefit starts and no one is sure when it ends.

title: Editorial Article 2  No Title
description: EUGENE, Ore.There is one cer tainty about the House resolution in which five congressmen seek to im peach President Nixon for high crimes and misdemeanors the resolution will never be placed before the House by the Committee on the Judiciary.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: From the advertising of drugs, to the overuse of drugs, to drug abuse  that chain of causality has by now become axiomatic among critics of the advertising, communications and pharm aceutical industries. Are these individual links in that chain really connected as logically as we are told?

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: IN RETROSPECT, as the first anniversary of the Ad ministration's New Economic Program approaches, it is clear that the chief beneficiary among domestic industries has been the nation's automotive business.

title: KLECATSKY WINS IN SENIOR SCULLS
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Aug. 5Larry Klecatsky of the New. A.C. scored his fourt straight victory today in the senior 155pound single sculls championship in the 90th Royal Canadian Henley Regatta. Klecatsky, a New Rochelle, N.Y., physician, won by six lengths over Ted van Deusen of the Riverside Boat Club of Cam bridge, Mass. In third place was Paul Fuchs of the Detroit B.C.

title: Jetport Plan for Grand Teton National Park Is Opposed
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 1Against a backdrop of soar ing mountain peaks, meander ing rivers and exquisite wilder ness lakes, the people of this historic valley are engaged in a bitter battle over community values  and the future of Grand Teton National Park.

title: Religion
description: A lot of our people are wonder ing whether the churches have gone too far in jeopardizing our own sur vival for the sake of serving society.

title: Building Contractors See No Early End to City's 5WeekOld Construction Strike
description: Building contractors here are not optimistic about the pros pects for an early end of the fiveweekold construction strike, although they derived some encouragement last week from settlements with the ce ment workers, particularly, the big carpenters union.

title: For Mrs. Abzug, a Hatful of Donations
description: CUTCHOGUE, L. I.It was, for this Suffolk County town of registered Republi cans and closet Democrats, an unlikely afternoon of mu tual political tolerance.

title: Boston's Irish Aren't hat They Used to Be They're Something Else Again, and Never Dull
description: BOSTONThere are little red foot prints painted on the pavement to mark Boston's Freedom Trail. Follow them and they will lead you to the Old North Church and Paul Revere's House and some of the other places of Revolutionary War fame that every American child learns of in gram mar school. They are Historic Places; they can be marked as such, and visit ed, and venerated, because they are safe. Enough time has passed between Then and Now to turn passions into marble monuments.

title: GHANA GIVES GIFTS FOR BIRTH CONTROL
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 5 (Reuters)Housewives in rural Ghana are being offered free cans of powdered milk as an incentive to use contraceptives and help keep the birth rate down, a United Nations semi nar was told here.

title: Vacationers Desert Pets
description: OCEAN CITYAnimal shelters here and throughout South Jersey are concerned about the coming exodus of summer folk and the accompanying abandonment by many of them of dogs, cats and other pets.

title: Gardens
description: Cement rectangles sunk in the fern garden show the way. Stepping stones and pebbles are an interesting route for exploring a Japanesestyle garden while a prim rose bordered natural woods path leads to more views.

title: OPERA BY SMYTH SUNG AT NEWPORT
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 5 Part of the fun of attending the Newport Music Festival is read ing the program book. Each concert has a musical, histori cal or literary theme and title, and John Stranack, the man in charge of research and pro gramming, came up with a real winner this last week.

title: SHOP TALK
description: MENDHAM  This small, serene borough has roots that go back to some of the most colorful events in col onial history, and it has the buildings to prove it. The Black Horse Tavern, built in 1742 (one of the few pre Revolutionary inns still open in New Jersey), isn't even the oldest building in town.

title: Accident Restores Vision To Man Blind for 16 Years
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 5 (UPI)  Eugene W. Phillips stumbled and fell from his porch, punctured his back with a stick and slammed his head against the ground. It was about the best thing that ever happened to him.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BELGRADEIf Russia withdraws its forces from Egypt to the full extent that appears likely, leaving behind but token contingents, some reduction in the rate of U.S. arming of Israel might well be looked for. Confirmation of such speculation could only come in the futureafter this year's Presiden tial elections.

title: Priest Gets Year Leave To Work for Mayor
description: BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP)A Roman Catholic priest who is an aide to New York May or Lindsay has been granted a oneyear leave of absence from the Boston Archdiocese.
