title: NEW BREED ASKS HELP FOR ADDICTS
description: Representatives of several community  based therapeutic programs for drug addicts banded together last week into an organization called the New Breed Federation to lobby for increased Federal subsidies for the treatment of what they said was an alarmingly growing number of addicted veterans in the city.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Music
description: SOME mistakes can be lived with more easily than others, such as the one made by the no doubt ap ocryphal man who was invited to attend what he understood to be a party for the Swingle Singers but which turned out to be for Single Swingers. In the same category falls the concert review by a British critic in The Guard ian net long ago, which mentioned an excellent performance by the City of Birmingham Orchestra of Britten's Lazy Luminations. Mortifying though this must have been for the critic to read the next day, he must have been con soled somewhat by the realization that many readers would assume that Brit ten actually had written such a piece. And a few others would not only un derstand that he had referred to the song cycle, Les Illuminations, but that nowadays one of the critic's occasional hazards of employment is having to dic tate reviews by telephone. Furthermore, how many of us in our reviewing life times are granted the chance to pro vide as much delight to the reader as The Guardian's man did in this instance?

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . on an art tour of New Eng land, you can pinpoint exactly what you want to seecurrent art, old masterpieces,, where the artists work and howor you can take it all in the way we did. The New England states are very helpful.

title: FULMER'S AUTO TAKES POLE SPOT
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 5 For the Midwestern racing fan this weekend, happiness is CanAm race with a reasonably strong, field, perfect weather, congenial venue and enthusias tic company.

title: U.S. 5th in Rowing
description: MILAN, Aug. 5 (AP)The United States finished fifth in the pairs without coxswain of the World Junior rowing cham pionships today on the Idorscalo Artificial Lake. It was the only event in which the Americans had reached the final.

title: Alcoholism: Difficult To Diagnose
description: He gulps his drinks.. . drinks in the morning.. . drinks to relieve anger.. . drinks surreptitiously. Is he an alcoholic? Probably, but possibly not. Alcoholism is one of the most dif ficult diseases to diagnose. In fact, ac cording to the National Council on Al coholism, only one physician in 300 is capable of an accurate diagnosis.

title: World News Briefs
description: TRIESTE, Italy, Aug. 5An other oil tank exploded today at the burning Transalpine pipe line terminal near Trieste, add ing to destruction that the po lice attributed to terrorist sabo tage. It was the fifth tank of 25 to explode at the big terminal.

title: Laura Baugh Gets Last Chance In U.S. Girls' Junior Golf Play
description: Can Laura Baugh of Long Beach, Calif., win the 24th an nual United States girls' junior golf championship?

title: Black Panther Is Indicted On Charge of Jumping Bail
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) Felix Pete O'Neal, a Black Panther party leader now be lieved to he in Algeria, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury in Topeka, Han., on a charge of jumping bail, the Justice Department announced.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Whether we call it quality of life or the more familiar term, standard of living, few people would argue that today the people of the United States enjoy the high est standard of living in the world. But that standard of living is now in danger be cause the United States does not have the metals and energy we will need in the future.

title: Television
description: ALBANY.

title: Welfare Reform S.O.S.
description: Welfare reform is apparently not an orphan after all. President Nixon's strong letter to the Senate urging that it not eviscerate the reform bill revives hope that he will not let the most innovative social proposal of his four years in the White House die without a struggle.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5 Chi cago's Midway Airport, once the nation's air transport hub and the busiest airport in the world, is now handling fewer flights than Niagara Falls, N.Y., or Madison, Wis.

title: Gerulaitis Loses to DuPre In Junior Tennis Tourney
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 5 (AP)Patrick DuPre of Bir mingham, Ala., beat Vitas Geru laitis of New York, 46, 75, 61, today in a semifinal o the National junior and boys tennis championships.

title: ALEX GROSSHANDLER
description: YONKERS, Aug. 5Alex Grosshandler, a retired music teacher who recently played the violin with the Yonkers Phil harmonic Symphony Orchestra, died today in Yonkers Profes sional Hospital. He would have been 96 years old on Aug. 20. His home was at 92 Minerva Drive.

title: Chanteuse, chanteur and ghosts
description: In reading memoirs by or about popular entertainers, I have never ceased to be amazed by the amount of remembered dialogue, by conversa tions about even trivial matters that are set forth with every evidence of fidelity. It is as if the authors had all employed the same ghostwriter who was certain that an abundance of quotation marks conferred authenticity on the words written between them. And I get this feeling very strongly about these two books a biography of that wondrous chan teuse Edith Piaf by Simone Berteaut, her halfsister, and Charles Azna vour's account of his career as lyricist and singer.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: Fifteen physicians were killed in 1971 when the light planes they were piloting crashed. In all 15 cases, the pilot committed a highly un safe act that was deliberate and premeditated, according to a Federal Aviation Ad ministration official.

title: MOVES FOR AMITY SET BACK IN KOREA
description: SEOUL, South Korea Aug. 5 The new movement toward improving relations between the two Koreas has been stalled by the indefinite postponement of a major meeting between Norh Korean and South Korean teed Cross delegations that was scheduled to have begun today.

title: Galitzine, the Rome Couturier, Settles Into Stylish Apartment
description: ROMEFrom the terrace, there is a view of the Spanish Steps and practically all Romeor at least the prettiest part.

title: Jane D. Hogeman Bride of J. A. Yaker
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 5.Miss Jane Danter Hoge man was married here this afternoon to Jeffrey Alan Yaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Yaker of Summit, N. J. The Rev. Dr. Wallace Robbins performed the Uni tarian ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Hoge man of Worcester and Strat ton, Vt.

title: Hospital Strike Passport
description: With only a few weeks of politically suffused delibera tions left to the expiring Congress, an effort is well advanced on Capitol Hill to nullify the statutory safe guards adopted by New York State to prohibit hospital strikes while assuring equity to hospital employes.

title: Mrs. Scott Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Scott of Fort Lee, N. J., on July 25 at the New York University Medical Center. Mrs. Scott is the former Miss Joan Honig of South Orange, N. J. The child has been named Steven Eric. Mr. Scott, a newscaster for the Mutual Broadcasting System.

title: 2,500YearOld Statues Discovered Near Athens
description: ATHENS, Aug. 5Two paint ed marble statues of a young man and a young woman, made some 2,500 years ago, have just been discovered by Greek ar cheologists exploring ancient graves near Athens. Experts have acclaimed them master pieces of ancient art.

title: A's Finley Fined $500
description: CHICAGO, Aug, 5 (AP) Charles O. Finley said today he had been reprimanded and fined $500 by Baseball Com missioner Bowie Kuhn for re marks the owner of the Oakland A's made be fore the signing earlier this season of Vida Blue, the A's star pitcher. Finley said he would have 10 days in which to pay the fine, but hadn't decided yet if he would. How ever, Finley added that if he did pay the fine, he would do so under protest. The owner of the A's said he first heard of the reprimand and fine yesterday in a letter from Kuhn. The commissioner is sued a statement saying Fin ley was reprimanded and fined for remarks critical of the commissioner's role in the Blue signing and whic were found by the commissioner not to be in the best inter ests of baseball. Blue had held out this year for $115, 000. He eventually signed for a reported $63,000. of the A's said he first heard of the reprimand and fine yesterday in a letter from Kuhn. The commissioner is sued a statement saying Fin ley was reprimanded and fined for remarks critical of the commissioner's role in the Blue signing and whic were found by the commissioner not to be in the best inter ests of baseball. Blue had held out this year for $115, 000. He eventually signed for a reported $63,000.

title: Women in Taverns Decried
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP)  A state law taking effect next January will allow women to patronize Massachusetts tav erns, which have been a pre serve for men. The Retail Liquor Dealers' Board of Trade is opposed to the change. We'll file a bill to bar them perma nently, said Robert S. Lufkin, the 76yearold president of the board.

title: Actor Commune Is a Hit in Suffolk
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I. Every Sunday night, a group of people hold a business meeting in a restaurant park ing lot on the outskirts of town. The purpose? To divide among them the weekend's take.

title: Hitchcock Chair Finds a Home In Connecticut ChurchMuseum
description: RIVERTON, Conn., Aug. 4 An old stone church has been restored and rejuvenated here to serve as a museum for the stenciled Hitchcock chair, pro duced from 1820 to 1848.

title: Fair Day in Springs Means Just That
description: THE SPRINGS, L. I.God must love The Springs be cause it never rains on a fair day.

title: G. L Wakelin Weds Miss Verbeck
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Aug. 5 Miss Stephanie Bauer Ver beck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guido Fridolin Verbeck Jr., was married here this afternoon to Gordon Levearn Wakelin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Wakelin of Lindsay, Ont. The ceremony in the Hotchkiss School Chapel was performed by the Rev. Fred erick Burnham Stimson, rec tor of Christ Episcopal Church in Sharon.

title: Rap Sessions Aim at Tension
description: TRENTONHoping that communication can pierce the strongest barriers of mis trust and hatred, community leaders in this racially divided city have begun rap ses sions between the police and black youths to ease tensions.

title: Victor Prall 3d Weds Winifred Solleveld
description: SHERMAN, Conn., Aug. 5 Miss Winifred Jean Solle veld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes Solleveld of New York and Sherman, was married here today to Victor Oscar Prall 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Prall Jr., also of New York and Sherman.

title: Katharine D. Moyer Has Nuptials
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Aug. 5Miss Katharine Dana Moyer, daughter of Mrs. Mil ton Sands Dillon Jr., was married here today to Peter Francis Freeman Kissel Jr., son of Mr. Kissel of Indian Creek Island, Fla. The cere mony was performed in the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain by Canon James S. Johnson.

title: Pointer Named Top Field Trial Dog
description: News or Dogs

title: Greece Suspends Sentences For 3 Convicted Guerrillas
description: ATHENS, Aug. 5Sentences of three of the five Greeks con victed as urban guerrillas by a military tribunal yesterday have been suspended.

title: ...And The House Wyeth Painted, Too
description: CUSHING, Me.Art and reality meet here, amicably. This is An drew Wyeth country, its land scape made familiar by his paint ings. One of those paintings is 1:11,, haunting Christina's World, whirl shows the pinkclad figure of crippled Christina Olson at the bottom of sweeping brown bill looking up at her gray, weathered house outlined against the sky.

title: How Nixon will win
description: Richard Nixon is the heavy favorite to win in November for several reasons. In the first place, he is the incumbent, respected albeit not loved, with the powers of the Presidency at his com mand during the next three months. Secondly, the United States is in the midst of political upheaval, and the forces of the New Politics are not nu merous enoughdespite McGovernite predictions to outvote the realigning elements of the existing electorate.

title: The Good Word
description: The lives of the wits make grim reading these days. To judge from John Keats's You Might as Well Live, Dorothy Parker had a wretched loveless childhood, got her own back at the world with some fine wisecracks and came to a miser able end. According to Howard Teichmann's George S. Kaufman, little George was coddled and frightened into helplessness, learned to fight back with some splendid wisecracks and came to a pitiable end.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 5 The Palestinian Black Septem ber Organization said today that its commandos had carried out the sabotage at the oil storage center in Trieste, and that it was aimed at Zionist and im perialist interests which are the enemies of our Palestinian peo ple.

title: 2810 Setback Discouraging
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug 5There is only one word for the result of the football test the New York Giants took against the Pittsburgh Steelers in tonight's preseason game at Three Rivers; Stadium. The word is flunked.

title: For Suffolk Family, It's Us on a Bus
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L.I. When the Cartee family of Pulaski Road leaves today for an extended vacation in Can ada, their departure will mark the culmination of a fouryear dreamand four months of pounding, drilling, sweating and hopingfor 32yearold David Cartee, who has cre ated a fully equipped, 35 foot mobile home out of a Fire Department band bus at a total cost of $1,455.23, bus included.

title: Notes on a revolutionary dinosaur
description: The returns aren't all in yet, but it looks as if bigness is in trouble. Growth, it would seem, does not necessarily mean progress. The biggest isn't the greatest. The SST has been banished back to Seattle. The C5A is a joke. Tall Texans drive Datsuns and Toyotas and Beetles; all American kids daydream about 10speed lightweight bikes instead of four on the floor. Even in the mat ter of skyscrapers, the longand underoccupied reign of the Empire State Building seems to have proved that the tallest building in the world isn't necessarily the greatest building in the world.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Justin Lipman, a second generation manufacturer of women's coats, has success fully combined coat produc tion with that of dresses, skirts and pants. His com pany Cuddlecoat, Inc., also has become a factor in Paris fashions for the American market.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR

title: Pay for Grads: Still Not So Rosy
description: A survey released last week con firmed what most young people already knew: The job situation for recent college graduates is far from rosy.

title: A Witchmobile Warns of the Occult
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 5  An antioccult mobile unit, spon sored by Morris Cerullo, an evangelist, will begin a nation wide tour of 45 cities next week to educate teenagers about witchcraft and Satanism.

title: They've got that oldtime religion
description: Some traditionally dominant Amer ican religious institutions are on the skids. Standardbrand Protestant membership and vitality are waning; Roman Catholicism beset by internal machinations.

title: Nelson, Nunes Tie in Lightnings
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 5 Macy Nelson of Black Rock Y.C., Bridgeport, placed first and second with Aegis, and Ned Nunes of Belle Haven Club, Greenwich, placed second and first with Muma Works on Long Island Sound off Cedar Point Y.C. today to tie for the lead in the ConnecticutRhode Island District Lightning Class cham ponship regatta.

title: Lawyers Accuse Justice Department of EqualRights Laxity
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5A group of lawyers involved in civil rights and civil liberties cases has published an 80page study accusing the Justice De partment of failing to enforce the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment and the rights laws enacted under it.

title: SCHMITZ DETAILS THEORY ON PLOTS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 5 On his first full day as the Presidential nominee of the American party, John G. Schmitz advanced the theory today that most public events could be explained in terms of a conspiracy.

title: Thwacks and zonks
description: If you'll remember when we left off reading picture books, things did not look good for our hero, the child. The three witches, Boring Book, Ugly Artless and Tired Theme were about to put him in a trance, Their hydraheaded running dog, Import, salivating phosphorescent inks was nipping at his ankles while the evil wizard High Price was concocting brew to poison our hero's parents.

title: Environment
description: UPTON, L. L.  In 1960 a small group of scien tists, growing increasingly concerned over the fallout from nuclear weapons tests then being conducted in the upper atmosphere, began a program to monitor the levels of fallout in mana program they feared might become a death watch.

title: Muhammad Ali Pays a Visit to the ArmyFor the Olympic Trials
description: Sports of The Times

title: Dec. 17 Bridal For Jane Grant
description: RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5Dr. and Mrs. George H. Grant have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Margaret Grant, to David Alan Mayer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Mayer of New York.

title: 6 ULSTER CATHOLICS GET DEATH THREATS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 5 (AP)Six of Northern Ireland's leading Roman Catho lic politicians received assassi nation threats today. Sources close to the British security forces said the threats had come from the Ulster Volun teer Force, an outlawed Prot estant secret society set up in opposition to the Irish Republi can Army.

title: Baby Terns Desert Popular Suffolk Beach
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I.Ho bart Beach, one of this area's most popular beaches, has be come the site of a mass hatching of tern eggs. Last month, about 1,000 baby least terns were born on a sand spit at the southern end of the beach, known as Sand City.

title: Eric Peniston Jr., a Realty Man, To Marry Deborah P. Haslam
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Aug. 5Miss Deborah Page Haslam, an assistant cashier with the First National City Bank of in New York, and Eric Walker Peniston Jr., a vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, Inc., the New York real estate concern, plan to be married on Sept. 9 in St. Bartholomew's Epis copal Church in New York.

title: Coins
description: SOMETHING For Ev eryone is the theme of the auction which will be one of the highlights of the American Numismatic Association's 81st anniversary convention in New Orleans this month. The big annual show will be held Aug. 15 through Aug. 19 at The Jung Hotel, 1500 Canal Street.

title: Youth Dropout Rate Is 26.1% in Newark
description: More than a quarter of all Newark young people be tween the ages of 16 and 21 at the time of the 1970 census had dropped out of school before completing high school.

title: Coach Takes Vermont Posti
description: R. Bruce Craddock, an offen sive line coach at Northeast Missouri State College, has been named offensive line coach at the University of Ver mont, Craddock replaces Carl Falivene, who accepted the position of head coach at Ver mont last month when Joe Scannella moved to the Oak land Raiders as an assistant coach.

title: HANRAHAN APPEAL STUDIED BY JUDGE
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5Judge Philip Romiti has under advise ment this weekend a motion to dismiss charges against Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County State's Attorney, and 13 other persons accused of conspiring to obstruct justice in the wake of a police raid on the Black Panthers.

title: Science/ Medicine
description: During the Han Dynasty, more than 21 centuries ago, the Chinese used to secure the cavernous tombs of no bility with footthick layers of char coal, sealed in by while clay, or with molten iron. This practice is now permitting a series of windows to be opened into the remarkable culture of that time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Buddy Rich Plays Music for Dancing At St. Regis Roof
description: Buddy Rich is taking a forth right attitude about his band's engagement at the St. Regis Roof, where the current policy is to have jazz bands such as Count Basie's, Woody Herman's and Mr. Rich's play for dancing as well as for listening.

title: Home Improvement
description: HOMEOWNERS or apartment dwellers who go shopping for an air conditioning unit have a number of dif ferent factors to consider  if they want to make certain that they will get all of the beneficial results hoped for from an appliance of this kind.

title: A Good Woman Is Hard to Find
description: The vice president of one of the betterknown execu tive search firms has been calling up writers, academi cians and publicized femi nists, inviting them to his male  membership club for lunch and, over his first vodka on the rocks, importuning them: Can you tell me where we can look for lad ies? We never looked for ladies before.

title: Doing God's work in the East Room
description: Nelson Aigren's epitaph for Presi dent Dwight Eisenhower, that he was that man who melted like cotton candy in the mouth of history, may not have been appropriate for every thing that Ike represented in his White House years. But it did seem to apply to his religion: gossamer, sweet, sticky, yet fascinating as was. In the 1950's, postwar, anti Communist America was sinking new roots and justifying itself. The reli giosity of an obviously wellinten tioned, crusading President seemed attractive. The result was a product that William Lee Miller aptly de scribed as Potomac Piety.

title: FREETEX SCORES; RINA RIDGE IS 4TH
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 5 Local horseplayers lovingly re fer to Monmouth Park as our graveyard of champions and relish a chance to see one of the highriding horses take on a test at their seaside race track.

title: Stamps
description: AMERICA's postal tribute to the XX Olympic Games, a fourstamp issue from designs by Lance Wyman of New York, will be released in Washing ton Aug. 17. Two of the stamps will he a late recog nition of the XI Winter Olympic Games earlier this year in Japan. The others will note two of the Summer Games events which begin in Munich, Germany, Aug. 26.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Halt Tombigbee River Project
description: ABERDEEN, Miss., Aug. 5 (AP)A Federal judge refused today to halt construction of the Tennessee  Tombigbee Water way, ruling against a suit that had contended that the 253 mile project would damage the environment.

title: NEW BREED ASKS HELP FOR ADDICTS
description: Representatives of several community  based therapeutic programs for drug addicts banded together last week into an organization called the New Breed Federation to lobby for increased Federal subsidies for the treatment of what they said was an alarmingly growing number of addicted veterans in the city.

title: Woman Antipoverty Aide Slain In Bronx Office in Money Row
description: Mrs. Maria Estella, the 40 yearold director of the Simp son Street Development Asso ciation, a South Bronx store front antipoverty agency, was fatally shot yesterday by a re pairman who had demanded payment for plumbing work he did, the police reported.

title: TOP CHINA POSTS IN FORCES VACANT
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 5The 45th anniversary this week of the Communist armed forces in China has come and gone, but the military machine is still without permanent leaders in many toplevel positions.

title: Richard Eric du Pont Marries Mrs. Beverly Maness, Classmate
description: CECILTON, Md., Aug. 5 Richard Eric du Pont and Mrs. Beverly Hodgson Maness, classmates at the University of Corpus Christi in Texas, were married here this after noon at Hexton Farms, home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Francis du Pont. The bridegroom's father, a greatgreatgrand son of Eulethre Irne du Pont, who founded the fam ily chemical concern, is Sheriff of Cecil County.

title: Environment
description: For Fred Danback, an as sistant foreman with the Yonkers Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, the brief ceremony in the Federal Building in New York last Tuesday marked the end of a long effort to stop the pollution that had been pour ing from the Anaconda Wire & Cable Co. into the Hudson River at Hastings. The cere mony also made him $10,000 richer and raised new ques tions about paying bounties to citizens to ferret out polluters.

title: Applicable to others about to emerge
description: Already, only two years after his death, Egypt's President Nasser has attracted more biographers than any other figure of recent history Adolph Hitler, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill or even, so far, Charles de Gaulle. Most of the biog raphies are in Arabic, of course, but there are also books about Nasser by a wide range of writers in French, German and English, from the brilliant French journalist, Jean Lacouture, to the thoughtful Robert Stephens of the London Observer whose contribution was reviewed in these pages on May 21. The total number of biographies, by my count, is well over 50; the total number of words written about Nasser, includ ing articles in scholarly journals and Ph.D. theses in leading universities, could easily be 20 million.

title: ARTS MANAGERS LEARN BUSINESS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Some 85 managers of museums, gal leries, orchestras, theater and dance companies, community arts centers and other artistic ventures have recently com pleted a fourweek course in modern management tools.

title: CHINA IS SEEKING MORE RADIO LINKS
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 5  A Chinese delegation is expected to visit Hong Kong later this year to conclude an agreement for expanded radio communica tions between this British colony and Canton, the capital of China's Kwangtung province.

title: Congress Checkups Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) A bill to require annual physical examinations for Rep resentatives and Senators, with the results to be a matter of public record, has been intro duced by Representative Louis C. Wyman, Republican of New Hampshire. Those who don't want their condition known have an easy solutiondon't he a candidate for public of fice, he told the House on Wednesday.

title: Political Parties Required To Pay Deposit for Phones
description: ALBANY, Aug. 5 (AP)Po litical parties will be required to put up a security deposit before they can get campaign telephone service, according to a regulation adopted by the state Public Service Commis sion.

title: Carol Schwartzreich Is Betrothed
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 5  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan Schwartzreich of Larchmont and Boca Raton, Fla., of the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Carol Schwartzreich, to M. Roch Hillenbrand, son of Mrs. Henry Melvin Hillen brand of Oshkosh, Wis., and the late Dr. Hillenbrand.

title: EQUATION IS FIRST ON N.Y.Y.C. CRUISE
description: POCASSET, Mass., Aug. 5 After an unwanted fishing trip for air off Cuttyhunk, a record fleet of 87 sailboats rode home together under spinnakers to day on the opening squadron run of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: INCREASED ORDERS for wheat by the Soviet Union pushed up the price of wheat futures on the Chicago Board of Trade by more than 13 cents a bushel. . . . Gold prices eased at the weekend after hitting postwar highs of more than $70 an ounce in the Zurich market on Wednesday. The week's clos ing price was $68.25. . . . British reserves fell by $883 million in July to a total of $6,082,000,000.

title: Miss Ellen Jaehnig Wed to J. T. McGinn
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Aug. 5Miss Ellen Louise Jaehnig and John Terrence McGinn were married here this after noon. The Rev. Richard B. Andersen and the Rev. John A. McGinn, uncle of the bridegroom and a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the ceremony in Christ Epis copal Church.

title: Miss Shoemaker Wed to Physician
description: HAMMONDSPORT, N. Y., Aug. 5Miss Linda Carolyn Shoemaker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Perry M. Shoemaker of Tampa, Fla., formerly of Westfield, N.J., was married here this afternoon to Dr. Maurice Wolfberg, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wolfberg of London. The Rev. Paul Swarthout per formed the Unitarian cere mony under a canopy in the garden area between the cot tages on Keuka Lake belong ing to the bride's parents and grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Shoemaker.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINE?ADVT.

title: SchoolHaters Find RocketMaking Fun
description: PRINCETON  Fifty 11 to15yearold Princeton chil dren who tend to find for mal schooling a bore and a bother went to Princeton University this summer and discovered that education could be fun and reward ing.

title: Nor' East Loses to Boston
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP)The Boston Astros kept their Ameri can Soccer League playoff hopes alive tonight by defeat ing Nor' East United of New York, 40, at Boston Univer sity's Nickerson Field before 1,800 fans.

title: Miss Becker Married in Suburb
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 5Miss Kathleen Marie Becker and Paul Joseph White 3d were married here today in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection by the Rev. Henry J. Erhart.

title: '72 Blueberries: Washout
description: HAMMONTON  Duke Galleta, a short, wiry man in his mid 50's, carefully walked through the 6foot high blueberry bushes on his 1,000acre farm here.

title: Susan Blaisdell Is Bride Of Alexander Wharton
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Aug. 5Christ Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Chase Blaisdell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ferren Blaisdell of Middletown and Harbour Is land, the Bahamas, to Alex ander Barclay Wharton, son of Joseph Samuel Lovering Wharton 3d of Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, and Mrs. Richard Odd Bierregaard of Mount Kisco, N. Y.

title: In the Mailbox
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography
description: THIS summer, unlike last, the photography galleries are almost as busy in August as in October. So here, for stranded New Yorkers and for the out oftowners who inexplicably visit New York in August, are three summer shows not pre viously noticed in this space.

title: The Nation
description: It was the familiar old script: The captain of a Delta Airlines DC8, fly ing from Detroit to Miami last Mon day, looked up from his instrument panel into the muzzle of a snubnosed revolver. A few hours later, the plane, the pilot, the rest of his crew, a hijack party of eightand $1million paid as ransomwere in Algeria.

title: Black Paper in Newark Area
description: EAST ORANGE  Each Thursday for the next few months a group of about 20 young residents of Essex County plan to troop out of a converted, twostory frame house here to distribute copies of what they say is this area's first locally pub lished black newspaper in 10 years.

title: Cheap Yachts Put England's Masses at Sea
description: HAMBLE, England  The British yachting world was predictably bedazzled and transfixed last week end as flotillas of fine sailboats con verged on the Isle of Wight for the renowed Cowes regat ta, which furnishes yachts men and ambitious society ladies the toughest competi tion of the summer.

title: Bad Dream Comes to End For McGovern Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  Weeks of intense frustration for the campaign staff of Senator George McGovern ended today as he selected Sargent Shriver as his new running mate.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: NOMANS LAND ISLAND, Mass.As we ran the inside channel from Menemsha Bight around Gay Head into Vineyard Sound, we saw a small knot of terns working fiercely in the tide.

title: Riggins Score Decisive
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla Aug. 5 Using Joe Namath as bait, the New York Jets lured 41,920 people into the Gator Bowl to night and then put the hooks into San Francisco, defeating the 49ers, 1710, in the first preseason game for both teams.

title: CITY CITES SAVING IN RELIEF HOUSING
description: So tangled a web does the welfare system weave that the City Housing Authority now as serts that the rents charged for welfare families in its proj ects  rents that are higher than those paid by nonwelfare tenantsactually lead to sav ings for the city.

title: Puppets Are Used To Warn on Drugs
description: An Innovative educational program that utilizes puppets to warn children of the dan gers of drugs is traveling from Brooklyn to camps this summer.

title: Rangers Rout White Sox
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP)Ted Ford's threerun double high lighted a fiverun fourth inning as the Texas Rangers walloped the Chicago White Sox, 115, today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Dr. Alvin M. Lashinsky [Letters to the Editor, July 9] claims that welfare families, with their social pathology, would destroy middleincome neighborhoods if scatter site housing were put into effect.

title: Legal Aid Society to Open BedfordStuyvesant Office
description: The Legal Aid Society an nounced yesterday a community criminal law office would be opened in the BedfordStuy vesant section of Brooklyn, probably in September.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: PETOSKEY, Mich., Aug. 5  Prison labor and surplus Government machinery are being used in northern Mich igan's Emmet County to help find a solution to the nationwide problem of junked automobile hulks lit tering the landscape.

title: Schwitters: The Man Behind The Merz
description: THE Museum of Modern Art has mounted an other of those terrific smallish shows for which we have its now seem ingly chronic budget crisis to thank; 50odd Kurt Schwit ters' items from the perma nent collection. The exhibi tion is scarcely thorough in a retrospective sensethe mu seum's holdings of this mas ter collagist, whose genius grew and refined itself stead ily until his death in 1948, are sadly sparse after about 1926 and many of the works dis played are less than master pieces. But the show does succeed in representing the full range of Schwitters' protean creative activity, from Dadaist poetry to com mercial, advertising layout, in the formative years of his esthetic attitude.

title: COAST FIRE HALTED; 4,100 ACRES CHARRED
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Aug. 5 (AP) Firefighters headed home to day after conquering the coastal Big Sur region's worst fire in 20 yearsa brush and timber blaze that blackened 4,100 acres.

title: Vocal Music From Schutz to Liszt
description: Recordings

title: Goldenrod
description: We usually think of goldenrod as belonging to autumn, but the fact is that several species regularly bloom in late July and by the time August reaches its midpoint there is a goldenrod haze on many a rural hillside. From now until late September goldenrod will be in bloom along almost every country road, for a few weeks com peting with the asters for attention. The asters will outlast the goldenrod, but not really outshine it.

title: Success in Racing by Wyer Cars May Make Ferrari Shift Again
description: About Motor Sports

title: Carter and Wallace Seek To Aid Local Democrats
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. (UPI)Govs. Jimmy Carter of Georgia and George C. Wallace of Alabama are planning ways of helping state and local Dem ocratic candidates win even if the South goes for President Nixon in November.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: 4 MORE WINNERS RIDDEN BY JENKINS
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug 5 Rod Jenkins spreadeagled the field today when he rode the first four finishers in the East Coast Challenge Trophy Class for jumpers, the final event of the eightday Orange County Horse Show.

title: Karen L. Sornmarstrom Engaged
description: Miss Karen Lisa Sommar strom, an investment execu tive with Scudder, Stevens & Clark, and Jack P. Jefferies, a partner in Lord, Day & Lord, law firm, will be mar ried Oct. 14 in Sneden's Landing, N.Y.

title: Roving Safety Check Surprises Drivers
description: LAURENCE HARBOR  Here today and who knows where tomorrow, several dozen Jerseyans are stretch ing their legs by the road side for an anxious five min utes while state examiners give their cars a surprise safety checkup.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: The Summaries

title: How 28 Instant Millionaires Can Be Created
description: When Levi Strauss & Co. went public on March 1971, the offering created at least 28 instant millionaires, based on their stockholdings. This group comprised nine Levi Strauss directors [four of them descendants or in  laws of the founding family), five honorary directors (all retired company officers) and 14 other company executives.

title: Anyhow, the Food Was Good
description: Dance

title: Air Routes Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board has given Southeast Airlines, Inc., an airtaxi service, a two year permit to provide sched uled service to Freeport, Ba hamas, from Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 5 (AP)  Sargent Shriver told wellwishers tonight that he was very happy and very proud to be joining the Demo cratic Presidential ticket with Senator George McGovern. He then boarded a small airplane and headed toward Washington for a meeting with Senator McGovern.

title: Letters to the Editor,
description: The article, LR Giving Way to panld fam rm w/ fplc July 231 reinforced my thinking about a trend I discovered more than three years ago when I was marketing manager at Levitt & Sons.

title: The World
description: CAIRO  Muammar elQaddafi is a moody, impulsive young Libyan Army colonel who lives frugally in his barracks while presiding over poulation of two million (mostly Bed ouin), a vast expanse of sand and collection of wealthproducing oil wells. He is a glowing panArabist, seeing himself as another Gamal Ab del Nasser laboring to unite the Arab world. Since the Moslem religion is the primordial force in his life, he wants that unity to be achieved in the name of a revived and purified Islam.

title: Unusual Artifacts on View in Queens
description: An extensive collection of hundreds of native artifacts from New Guinea, the New Hebrides Islands and North ern Australia are displayed in an unusual gallery near the waterfront in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Woman Sergeant Sues To Get Spouse Benefits
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 6 A woman staff sergeant in the Air Force, who said that she has been denied full al lowances and benefits for her civilian husband, has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court here charging the military with sex dis crimination.

title: RABBIS WILL SEEK ALIENATED JEWS
description: A task force of Orthodox rabbis, educators and scholars will visit at least 20 college campuses this fall to lure alienated young Jews back to the synagogue and to coun teract the attraction of Jesus freaks and mysticism.

title: Train Wreck in Pakistan, Country's Worst, Kills 57
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 6 Rescue teams have dug out 57 bodies from a Karachibound train from Rawalpindi that early today plowed into the rear of a freight train standing at the Liaquatpur railway sta tion, 400 miles northwest of here.

title: Susan Fischel Marries
description: Miss Susan Jane Fischel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Fischel, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Stuart David Schiff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schiff of Oceanside, L. I., in the Fifth Avenue Synagogue by Rabbi Ralph Neuhaus. The bride is a medical tech nician at tile Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Her husband is a graduate of the School of Dentistry of Columbia University.

title: DeMont, Jo Harshbarger Swim to World Records
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP)  Rick DeMont, a 16yearold distance specialist from San Raphael, Calif., slashed more than four seconds off the world 1,500meter freestyle record today in the closing event of the United States Olympic swimming trials. The fiveday session produced 13 world marks and one record was tied.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: DETROIT, Aug. 6I think it [the Presidential election] can be won, but it's important even if it's lost that it be lost by the smallest possible margin, Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Work ers, told a union political con vention here today.

title: UPWARD MOVEMENT IN STEEL FORECAST
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6Steel mills were moving toward the plus side of the year last week. The mills had reached the point where rising activity will be compared with an abrupt decline in demand last year.

title: S.E.C. CONSIDERING ACTION ON PENNSY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The Securities and Exchange Com mission has announced it is con sidering possible action against former officers of the finan cially pressed Penn Central in connection with sales of the railroad's stock.

title: Fingerprints May Be Lead In Slayings of 4 in Illinois
description: BARRINGTON HILLS, Ill., Aug. 6 (AP)Fingerprints lifted from an automobile appeared today as the strongest lead in the slayings of a retired ex ecutive and three other per sons, the police said.

title: Soviet Order Is Announced
description: The International Systems and Controls Corporation has announced the receipt by French subsidiary of a $6.4mil lion order for oilprocessing equipment to be shipped to the Soviet Union's machinery and equipmentimport trade organi zation.

title: 24 Hurt in Kentucky Prison As Blacks and Whites Battle
description: LA GRANGE, Ky., Aug. 6 (AP)More than 300 black and white inmates at the Kentucky State Reformatory fought with knives, bricks and baseball bats for 15 minutes today before guards put down the disturb ance, the authorities said.

title: Trieste Oil Fire Controlled; Sabotage Is Investigated
description: TRIESTE, Italy, Aug. 6 (AP) Officials said today that the fire at Trieste's transalpine oil pipeline terminal had been brought under control after causing damage placed at $7 million.

title: COSMOS GAIN TIE WITH METROS, 11
description: After his performance with the New York Cosmos against the Toronto Metros in Toronto yesterday, Josef Jelinek's lim ited English vocabulary should be expanded to include one more word: Star.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Smith
description: Sports of The Times

title: Kathy Whitworth Is 4Stroke Victor In Knoxville Golf
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 6 (AP) Kathy Whitworth shot par 71 today for a 54hole score of 210 and a fourstroke victory in the Knoxville women's golf tournament.

title: John Costigan, Artist, 84, Dies; Known for FarmLife Paintings
description: ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Aug. 6John Edward Costigan, a figure and landscape artist known for his scenes of farm life, died yesterday in Nyack. He was 84 years old and lived here.

title: Advertising:
description: As a prominent nutrition ist, Dr. Jean Mayer feels that advertising tends to be counter productive because the least nutritional products tend to be the most pro moted.

title: Bank Compliance Alleged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said to day that two of America's largest banks possessed in sider information on the financial plight of the Penn Central Transportation Com pany when they sold their stock in the railroad shortly before it filed for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act.

title: DuPre Captures Final
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. (AP)Patrick DuPre of Birming ham, Ala., won the national junior singles title today.

title: Dance: Vienna State Ballet in Capital
description: Last month I went to the Temple University Music Fes tival, just outside Philadel phia, to see the Vienna Stale Opera Ballet. I was not par ticularly impressed. However, the repertory was not stand ard. It included, disastrously, two ballets by the company's director, Aurel Von Milloss. Thinking to give the com pany a better chance on major United States tour, which sensibly and happily is not including New York on its itinerary, I went to Wash ington to see it in Giselle and Paquita.

title: Personal Finance
description: Some years ago, Mrs. Rosa Washington quarreled with her divorced husband, a lo cal deputy sheriff in Penn sylvania, over the custody of their son. Her exhusband, who apparently knew how to use the law to advantage, obtained an order to seize the boy's clothes, furniture and toys.

title: Toby Blumenfeld Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Miss Toby Judith Blumenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Blumenfeld of Jamaica Es tates, Queens, to Matthew K. Holtzman took place in Temple Sholom in Flushing, Queens, at noon yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of State Supreme Court Justice Lester Holtzman and Mrs. Holtzman of Great Neck, L. I. Rabbi Gershon Levi performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his debate with Douglas Cater regarding public television (OpEd, July 21), Jeffrey St. John rather glibly consigns public TV to starvation. At one point he condemns it for serving not the public but an Midst audience of students, academics, intellectuals, professionals and politicians. Then he concludes that public broadcasting should get no Government money and should go elsewhere for its funds.

title: Lower East Side Is Watchful as Fuentes Takes School Post After FourYear Fight
description: Luis Fuentes took over as superintendent of District One schools on the Lower East Side last week, marking a political as well as an educational vic tory for some residents of the mostly Puerto Rican area.

title: Soul Finale Wraps Black Music Scene In Bright Package
description: Soul at the Center came to a rousing close early yesterday morning with a midnight show that packed Philharmonic Hall. The program included a group of starsEsther Phillips, Car McRae and Jerry Butler and his revue  running the gamut of contemporary black music.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DOMINATION OF NATURE. By William Leiss. 242 pages. Braziller. $6.95.

title: Poisoned Pawn's Return Surprises the Kibitzers
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. Experts, psychologists and just about everyone else here expressed surprise today when Bobby Fischer fell into the poisoned pawn variation of the Sicilian Defense again and lost to Boris Spassky on the 31st move.

title: Bethpage Beats Aiken, 65, In L.I. Polo League Match
description: BETHPAGE, Li., Aug. 6 Ted Brinkman and Dave Rizzo each scored two goals today as Bethpage defeated Aiken, 65, in a Long Island Polo League match at Bethpage State Park.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: FRANKFURTA group of politically active women has taken Chancellor Willy Brandt's decision to hold na tional elections before the end of the year as the oc casion to strike the first organized blow at male domination of West German political life.

title: State Prison Holds a FatherSon Picnic Inside Walls
description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 5 When Billy James was 2 months old, the state took his father away to serve his time at Green Haven. Today, 14 years later, in a sunlit corner under the state prison's gray, 30foot walls, father and son had their first mantoman talk.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The brief passage of Thomas F. Eagleton aboard the Democratic national ticket has roused lead ers of both parties to call for some more rational and less risky system of choosing Vice Presidential candidates.

title: Rev. Edmund R. Laine, 83; Rector at Ascension Church
description: The Rev. Edmund Randolph Laine, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Stock bridge, Mass., from 1926 to 1949 and subsequently asso ciate rector of the Church of the Ascension here, died yes terday at his home, 250 West 24th Street. He was 83 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative  Republican of New York, called on Republi cans today to write a platform rejecting quotas for blacks in jobs or schools.

title: McCune Leads Pro Bowling
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Aug. 6 (AP)Don McCune of Munster, Ind., took a 141pin lead today in the $55,00 Columbia 300 howling tournament. The 35 yearold righthander shot games of 155. 254, 225, 279, 280 and 235 to give him a six game pinfall of 1,,155.

title: Welfare Island's Busy Coler Hospital Seeks to Change Image Rooted in Past
description: The Bird S. Coler Memorial Hospital and Home on Welfare Island is now 20 years old, and for the last 13 it has been home to Bernie Lighte, a victim of cerebral palsy. He wonders why so many people view it as a depressing institution of last resort.

title: Major Recommendations
description: Following are the major recommendations in the report of the Knapp Commission:

title: CITY LOSS CITED INPROPERTY SALES
description: State Controller Arthur Le vitt contended yesterday that the city may be losing large amounts of money from de lays in selling unneeded prop erties foreclosed after non payment of real estate taxes.

title: Economic Seers Preview '73 as Another Bumper Year for Business
description: Another bumper year appears to he in prospect for the Ameri can economy in 1973.

title: Full House
description: With the designation of Sargent Shriver as the Democratic VicePresidential nominee all but official, American voters can begin to give full attention what both President Nixon and his Democratic challenger, Senator McGovern, have rightly called the clearest political choice of the century.

title: Williams Leads Qualifiers For Olympic Archery Team
description: OXFORD. Ohio, Aug. 6 (UPI) Army Pfc. John Williams of Cranesville, Pa., unofficially bettered his world record for a doubleround yesterday and led the qualifiers for a berth on the United States Olympic archery men's team.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Homespun Motivation
description: Follow me and you'll wear diamonds, William Thomas Grant told some of his first employes shortly after he founded the W.T. Grant Com pany. This type of homespun motivation by the founder of one of the nation's bestknown general merchandise chains in spired not only the initial em ployes, but also thousands of others who joined the company during its 66year history.

title: Loomis's Sloop Defeats Cascade for Astor Cup
description: HADLEY'S HARBOR, Mass., Aug. 6On a day when the fleet surgeon needed first aid from the Coast Guard, a 37 foot sloop named Boo won the New York Yacht Club's presti gious Astor Cup today.

title: Wave of Killing in Belfast Takes Victims at Random
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 4  David Fisher, a 301 yearold bus conductor who still lived with his parents in a dingy row house on solidly Protestant Nore Street, told his mother that he and and his friend Hugh Clawson, a truck driver, were going out to an allnight dance.

title: Thieu Ousts Defense Minister in Scandal
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6 (Reuters)President Nguyen Van Thieu has dis missed his Defense Minister, Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Vy, following a financial scandal involving mismanagement of South Vietnam's big military savings fund.

title: What's Ahead for Gold?
description: Economic Analysis

title: Jackson's SALT Ploy
description: It is a truism of politics as well as economics that events are determined on the margin. Possessors of the last few votes needed to pass a law or win an election often can determine policy for the majority. But the price the Administration has been paying to its conservative supporters for acceptance of the historic strategic arms limitation (SALT I) agreements with Russia evidently is beginning to seem excessive even to the electionminded White House itself. The over hasty Administration support given to reservations in a resolution proposed by Senator Henry Jackson report edly is being reconsidered. It has to be seen whether compromise language really can be found that does not undermine the SALT I pacts and, even more, the pros pects for mutual reductions of nuclear weapons SALT II.

title: City Counsel Aide Named
description: John R. Thompson, who helped develop the city's antitrust pro gram to win triple damages from companies rigging the prices of drugs and other mate rials sold to the city, was named first assistant corporation coun sel yesterday. He succeeds Nor man Redlich, who became Cor poration Counsel on Aug. 1.

title: Miss Casals Triumphs
description: COLUMBUS, Ga, Aug. 6 (AP) Rosemary Casals of San Francisco beat Francoise Durr of France, 67, 76, 60, in to day's final of the $25,000 Vir ginia Slims tournament.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Boy, 6, Is Tortured; 2 Youths Held Two 12yearold youths were charged with juvenile delinquency yesterday after they allegedly had burned and beaten a 6yearold boy while he was visiting in the apart ment of a friend of his mother on the Upper West Side, the police reported. The victim, Chauncey Cummings of 321 West 48th Street, was in critical condition in St. Luke's Hospital, they said.

title: U. S. Wins Tennis Doubles, Leads Spain, 21
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 6 Stan Smith told Erik Van Dillen what to do. The 21year old San Mateo, Calif., player did it and the United States is almost in the Davis Cup final round for the 48th time.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: FREEHOLD, N. J, Aug. 6The New Jersey Standard bred Breeders and Owners Association at a general mem bership meeting in the American Hotel voted today to ratify a fouryear contract with Freehold Raceway covering purses and other benefits. Freehold's opening was delayed four days by the stalled negotiations. Racing began last Friday.

title: Banks Wish B.P. Loan Were Bigger
description: LONDON, Aug. 6The larg est private bank loan ever to be negotiated$882million to help the British Petroleum Company exploit its rich North Sea Oil findhas turned out to be not quite big enough to satisfy all the banks that want a share of it.

title: Blast Breaks Bank Window
description: A small pipe bomb exploded at 5:15 A.M. yesterday on a windowsill of the Williams burg branch of the National Bank of North America in Brooklyn shattering a pane of glass but doing no other dam age. No one was injured. The fourstory building is at Broad way and Ellery Street. The po lice said they found a crudely scrawled message reading: Free all political prisoners beneath the shattered window.

title: Los Angeles Officials Insist the Air is Getting Cleaner
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 When Ralph B. Perry, head of a coalition of environmental groups in California, drew back the curtains in his 24th floor office not long ago, a look of surprise came over his face.

title: NEWVOTER FORM STIRS MISSISSIPPI
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 6 Civil rights forces plan to file a lawsuit against the state of Mississippi in an attempt to throw out a voter registration requirement that they describe as a subterfuge to make voting difficult.

title: Elections Do Not Change Much
description: Real change is supposed to come about through our democratic political system. If you want to make a change you are supposed to offer yourself as a political candidate, or support a can didate who shares your idea.

title: Follmer Leads From Start And Wins CanAmin Ohio
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 6 The sponsor buttons distributed among the spectators said Let George Do It. And George Fol lmer did it, leading the Buck eye CanAm from start to fin ish for his second CanAm vic tory of the season.

title: Popular Spanish Bandit Gone Again
description: MADRID, Aug. 6El Lute and his brothers Toto and Lolo have once again van ished after one of the biggest manhunts in recent years. If the Spanish police are red faced, more than a few ordi nary Spaniards are admiring the latest feat of Spain's most notorious bandit.

title: Air Police Intercept A S.I. Student Flier Accused of Buzzing
description: A small yellow airplane that allegedly had been buzzing a dozen Staten Island commu nities over the weekend, rattling the nerves and windowpanes of homeowners, was intercepted by a police helicopter yesterday and forced to a landing at Linden Airport in New Jersey.

title: GAMBLING BACKED
description: The Knapp Commission, com pleting a twoyear investiga tion of police corruption here, recommended yesterday that Governor Rockefeller appoint a special deputy attorney general to mount a fiveyear war on corruption among New York's policemen, prosecutors and judges.

title: Fire Delays Penn Central
description: A fire in a traction motor of a Penn Central train in up per Manhattan disrupted New Haven division service last night. Electric power was shut off at about 9:25 P.M. to allow firemen to extinguish the blaze, a Penn Central spokesman said. The fire was declared under control at 9:48 P.M. Power was restored at 10 P.M.

title: Foe Takes 5 Hamlets
description: SAIGON, Aug. 6 (AP)A North Vietnamese force esti mated at more than 100 men seized five hamlets near Hue today in what senior United States officers said might be the first move in a possible at tack on the city.

title: Moscow's Smile
description: MOSCOWWe don't have to like each other to do business and cooper ate. I am for improved SovietAmeri can relations because I am a Soviet patriot and I know improved relations would be good for my country. I think the same thing applies to you Americans. Yuri Arbatov, the Krem lin's chief Americanologist, was speak ing for himself when he made these remarks, but there is mounting evi dence that similar ideas form the back bone of Leonid I. Brezhnev's policy toward the United States.

title: EXCHANGES TESTING NEW DELIVERY PLAN
description: The New York Stock Ex change, American Stock Ex change, Midwest Stock Ex change and Boston Stock Ex change announced jointly over the weekend that they were pilottesting a new intercity securities delivery system.

description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Aug. Miss Susan Andrea Slutsky and Dr. Marvin Klein of Manhattan, son of Mrs. Wil liam P. Klein of Miami Beach and the late Mr. Klein, were married this evening at Con gregation Ahavath Torah in Englewood by Rabbi Isaac L. Swift.

title: Nancy Robbins Becomes Bride
description: Miss Nancy I. Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Robbins of New York and Larchmont, N. Y., was married here yesterday to James Peter Druckman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Druckman, also of New York, The ceremony was per formed in the Versailles Suite of the St. RegisSheraton by Rabbi David J. Seligson of the Central Synagogue.

title: Personalities: Wynn Once Again
description: When baseball's newest immortals are inducted in the Hall of Fame today, they will enter a building that has a new leader. Warren C. Giles, the former longtime president of the National League, was named yesterday as the chair man of the board of the hall and museum.

title: RICHARD GREENEBAUM
description: Richard M. Greenebaum, ex ecutive vice president of M. H. Greenebaum, Inc., a foodim porting subsidiary of John Mor rell & Co., meat packers, died of complications following a heart attack Saturday in the BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 16 Fox Meadow Road, Scars dale, N. Y.

description: The New York Mets won another game but lost another player yesterday while stag ing a 122 uprising and beat ing the Chicago Cubs before 37,867 customers in Shea Sta dium.

title: Italians Work Hard at Their Vacations
description: ROME, Aug. 6The eco nomic indicators remain gloomy, the political outlook is clouded, new labor tem pests are looming, even the weather has been untypically fickle so far this summer. Yet Italians are enjoying their long vacations with enviable gusto.

title: Railroad Association Elects
description: William F. Betts has been elected vice president of the Association of American Railroads in the economics and finance department. Henry G. Allyn Jr., chairman and president of the Pitts burgh and Lake Erie Rail road, has been elected a di rector of the association.

title: PublicityShy Mrs. Cahill Easing Into the Limelight
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 6  When Elizabeth M. Myr tetus married William T. Ca hill on Feb. 1, 1941, he was a lawyer with a promising future and she was a young secretary for the Camden Trust Company, a job she had held for nine years and one she promptly put behind her.

title: Residents Pelt Police Cars With Debris in Morrisania
description: Bricks and bottles were hurled from roofs at two police cars in the Morrisania section of the Bronx last night mo ments after a man was slightly injured by a stray bullet, the police said.

title: Why Does Your Memory Go Blank?
description: A noted publisher in. Chicago reports there is a simple technique for acquiring a powerful memory which can pay you real dividends in both business and social advancement and works like magic to give you added poise, necessary selfconfi dence and greater popularity.

description: The third annual insomniac bicycle tour got under way from Yankee Stadium at 2:30 yesterday morning and ended five hours later with 110 cyclists observing the sun rise from a rocky promon tory at Orchard Beach.

title: Troops Disperse 400 Youths in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 6British soldiers today had to call in reinforcements to disperse 400 stonethrowing youths in the worst clash in Northern Ireland since troops occupied Roman Catholic quarters a week ago.

title: Encephalitis Outbreak
description: BEDFORD, Ind., Aug. 6 (AP) Ten children, ranging in age from six months, to three years, have been admitted to Law rence and Orange County hospitals within the last week suffering from encephalitis, sleeping sickness. Health offi cials reported yesterday that all 10 were out of danger.

description: The merger of Blyth & Co. and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities & Co. has been ap proved by the New York Stock Exchange and becomes effective today, the two firms announced over the weekend. title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) The Republican party for mally asked today for free television and radio air time to respond to the campaign speech of the Democratic Presidential nominee, Senator George McGovern, broadcast last night by the networks. Senator Robert J. Dole, chair man of the Republican Na tional Committee, made the request to the presidents of the American Broadcasting Company, the National Broad casting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the Mutual Broadcasting System.

title: Man With Grafted Toe on Hand Seeks to Retain Job as Fireman
description: ATHERTON, Calif., Aug. 6 A fireman here whose right big toe was successfully sub stituted for his severed right thumb in an experimental transplant operation is trying to get his job back despite ruling that declares him med ically disabled.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 If you live in a large state, are eligible to vote and are not yet registered, the Democrats hope that something like this will happen to you in the next few months:

title: William T. Grant, Store Founder, Dies
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 6 William T. Grant, the founder and honorary board chairman of the W.T. Grant de partment store chain, died to day of heart disease in Green wich Hospital. He was 96 years old.

description: To the Editor: On June 27 we started our odyssey on Amtrak and it does not coincide with your Special to the New York Times article on July 16, Page 60.

description: Like the engineer in the famous cartoon, watching a huge aircraft crash in flames, the Giants today could only say with ghoulish good cheer, Well, back to the drawing board.

title: Advertising:
description: What man has joined together, man can pull asunder. And in the case of Paccione, Hurvis, Churchill & Launey Advertising, asunder it will bereturning to the component parts that existed prior to the February nuptial event. So once again we have PaccioneLauney in New York and Hurvis, Binzer & Churchill, in Chicago.

title: 2 Parties Push Nonpublic School Aid With Bill for Tax Credits to Parents
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 The Nixon Administration and the Democratic partythe lat ter in the person of Repre sentative Wilbur D. Mills  are vying for the Roman Cath olic vote with a plan for a new form of tax assistance to parochial schools.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Many Democratic National Committee members from New York, New Jersey and Connec ticut yesterday praised Senator George McGovern's choice of Sargent Shriver as his Vice Presidential running mate and indicated they would vote for him when the committee meets tomorrow in Washington.

title: SPRINGER SPANIEL TAKES TOP AWARD
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 6 A liverandwhite English springer spaniel, Ch. Salilyn's Tennessee Squire was chosen best today in a field of 1,221 dogs at the Hunterdon Hills Kennel Club show on the Flem ington Fairgrounds. The victory was his second in eight days and his third top award.

title: Publicizing of Bribe Arrests Urged
description: The commission was struck by the apparent immunity from arrest enjoyed by givers as opposed to the takers of bribes. If the Police Depart ment procedures in the past have been inadequate to ap prehend members of the force who accept bribes, efforts to bring to justice those who give them have been almost nonexistent.

title: An Unlikely Coalition Backs Israeli Arabs
description: BEREM, Israel, Aug. 5 Within sight of Lebanese vil lages from which Palestinian guerrillas have recently shelled and raided northern Galilee, Arabs today hoisted Israeli flags, with Christian crosses attached, on the roof of a dilapidated Greek Catholic church. Israeli politicians and intellectuals faced the splendid, ruins of El thirdcentury syna gogue and, in bitter words, de nounced their Government's policy toward Israeli Arabs. And an Arab archbishop exclaimed to a cheering crowd, Long live Israel!

title: RIVER APPROVAL IS DUE TOMORROW IN A SPECIAL VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  Members of the Democratic National Committee predicted today that the committee would nominate Sargent Shri ver for Vice President by ac clamation on Tuesday.

title: Old Vaudevillians Star Once Again
description: Vaudeville is dead, long dead, but a few vaudevillians live on. Some still stay in the nearly anonymous hotels off Times Squarea stroll from the lights of Broadway, yet decades removed from the days when the brassy pit bands piped them on.

title: Lyle Saves Opener, Is Victor in Second Against Brewers
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6The New York Yankees, who sud denly are beginning to show signs of developing pennant fever, provided more evidence! today that they may be suf fering with good cause by heating the Milwaukee Brewers in both ends of a doubleheader.

title: Communism: 125 Years Later
description: SAN DIEGOThe prevalence of nonrevolutionary  nay, antirevolu idnaryconsciousness among the ma jority of the working class Is con spicuous.

title: Bridge: Polish Organization Produces Strong Teams for World Play
description: Eastern Europe has pro duced many great bridge play ers in the last 40 years. The focal point was once Hun gary, but nowadays it is Poland, which has 7,000 tour nament players.

title: Nuptials Here for Anne Graf of F.D.A.
description: Miss Anne Elizabeth Graf, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Charles Howard Graf, rector of St. John's in the Village Episcopal Church, and Mrs. Graf of Manhattan, was mar ried here yesterday afternoon to Russell Brian Ephraim. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Jay Ephraim of Little Neck, Queens.

title: Solar Flare Today Is Expected To Cause Big Magnetic Storm
description: BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 6 (UPI)Scientists predicted to day that another solar flare an explosion of gases on the surface of the sunwould occur some time tomorrow, causing an intense magnetic storm on the earth later in the week.

title: Daniel Kaufman, U.S.A.F., Weds Pamela L. Foley
description: Miss Pamela Lynne Foley and Sgt. Daniel Wise Kauf man of the Air Force, both 1968 graduates of Nathaniel Hawthorne College in Antrim, N. H., were married here yesterday afternoon.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PARISThe laments vary. After living here for three years, complained one wom an, I still can't identify with the French women's libera tion movement.

title: Basso Wins Pro Cycling
description: GAP, France, Aug. 6 (UPI) Marino Basso of Italy defeated Franco Bitossi, also of Italy, to win the world professional road cycling title today. Basso won by about a half wheel. Cyrille Guimard of France finished third.

title: Soul at Center Message Is Right On
description: There was a lot of handshak ing, hugging and hallelujahs at Lincoln Center shortly after 3 A.M. yesterday as nearly 3,000 blacks, whites and Latins eased slowly out of Philharmonic Hall.

description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. T. H. ENDICOTT
description: WALPOLE, N. H., Aug. 6  Mrs. Ellen Bellows Endicott of Boston, widow of Thorndike Howe Endicott, an executive of Stone & Webster, Inc., died to day at her summer home here. She was 92 years old.

title: Philippine Flood Deaths Rise To 427 as Waters Recede
description: MANILA, Aug. 6 (AP)The death toll in the Philippine's month  old flood disaster reached 427 today, but flood waters were receding in most areas after a break in the mon soon rains,

title: PATERSON YOUTHS PUSH RAT CONTROL
description: PATERSON, N. J., Aug. 6  Rats like molasses and peanut butterflavored poison, as well as apple, fish, meat and coco nut. We have it in all flavors.

title: L.I. Man Held in the Murder Of His Widowed Mother, 57
description: SOUTH SETAUKET, L. I., Aug. 6A man charged with murdering his widowed mother here last night was jailed with out bail and was ordered today in Suffolk County District Court to undergo psychiatric examina tion.

title: WADE RESIGNS JOB IN M'GOVERN RACE
description: Richard C. Wade, who has headed Senator George McGov ern's campaign organization in New York for the last 18 months, resigned last night in a move he said was intended as a unity measure and a peace offering to regular organization Democrats.

title: Screen: Woody Allen Scores in Sex Answers
description: Because we've all seen Dr. David Reuben on television at one time or another, and be cause reliable reporters have interviewed him in the flesh, (so to speak), one must as sume that the doctor is real, but is his bestselling book?

title: 40,000 in Hiroshima Mark Bombing Date
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 6 (UPI)  Thousands of Japa nese mourners today at tended solemn peace cere monies at the spot here where the United States dropped its first atomic bomb Aug. 6, 1945.

title: Following are excerpts from the first section of the Knapp Commission's final reporta summary of general findings and recommendationsthat was reelased yesterday.
description: Corruption, although wide spread, is by no means uni form in degree. Corrupt po licemen have been described as falling into two basic cate gories: Meat  eaters and grasseaters. As the names might suggest, the meateat ers are those policemen who, like Patrolman William Phil lips, who testified at our hear ings, aggressively misuse their police powers for personal gain. The grasseaters simply accept the payoffs that the happenstances of police work throw their way. Although the meateaters get the huge payoffs that make the head lines, they represent a small percentage of all corrupt po licemen. The truth is, the vast majority of policemen on the take don't deal in huge amounts of graft.

title: Mrs. Ruth Kass Colan Is Wed to Julian Bush
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 6 Mrs. Ruth Kass Colan, president of Ruth Colan Travel of Great Neck, was married here this afternoon to Julian S. Bush. Surrogate Millard L. Midonick of New York performed the cere mony at the home of the bridegroom, who is a partner of the New York law firm of Bush & Schlesinger.

title: For 30 Sidewalk Troupes, Top Lincoln Center Billing
description: The theater of poverty will occupy a setting of unac customed grandeur in two weeks when the Annual Community Street Theater Festival settles into Lincoln Center for 14 days.

title: U.N. Publications Will Omit Taiwan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 6 At the insistence of Peking, the United Nations has agreed to drop any mention of Taiwan, the seat of the Chinese Nationalist Government, from its publications and documents.

title: CLARK DESGRIBES DAMAGE TO DIKES
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 6Ram sey Clark, the former Attorney General, who is on a visit to North Vietnam, told the Hanoi radio today that he had seen a dike, a sluice gate, a hos pital for lepers and a children's school that had been bombed by United States planes.

title: Muncey Breaks 2 Records, Wins Seattle Hydro Race
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 6 (AP)Bill Muncey broke lap and course records today as he won the $30,000 Seattle Seafair trophy race for unlimited hydroplanes and wrapped up his fourth na tional point championship.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 One month before the Repub lican National Convention was to open in Miami Beach on Aug. 21, the White House sent platform writers a draft of what President Nixon would like to see in the party's 1972 statement on issues.

title: An Intense Group Loyalty Found
description: Although this special con cern is justified, public pre occupation with police cor ruption as opposed to cor ruption in other agencies of government inevitably seems unfair to the policeman. He believes that he is unjustly blamed for the results of cor ruption in other parts of the criminal justice system. This sense of unfairness intensi fies the sense of isolation and hostility to which the nature of police work inevitably gives rise.

title: Nixon Strolls on Beach In Visit to Assateague
description: ASSATEAGUE ISLAND, Md., Aug. 6 (AP)President Nixon took a leisurely two mile stroll along the beach today during a weekend of relaxation at a newfound retreat on Maryland's East ern Shore,

title: G.O.P. Aide Ousted Over Report That He Got $5,000 for a Favor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6An assistant to the cochairman of the Republican National Com mittee learned today that he had been dismissed as the re sult of allegations that he was paid $5,000 for helping to se cure a $500,000 Ioan.

title: GROUP IS TRYING TO SAVE OLD HOME
description: SCARSDALE, Aug. 5  George Washington never slept in the preRevolutionary War Caleb Hyatt House here.

title: Navy Jets Hit Truck Depot Two Miles South of Hanoi
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Aug. 7United States Navy jets bombed a large re pair center for trucks and con struction equipment two miles south of the city limits of Hanoi Saturday, an American military spokesman announced.

title: Owen Jackson Weds Pamela Mosley
description: Miss Pamela Arleen Mosley, daughter of Mrs. James John son Edwards and John Wilson Mosley, both of St. Albans, Queens, was married yester day afternoon to Owen Regi nald Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Occie Jackson of Ana huac, Tex. The Rev. Robert Ross Johnson performed the ceremony in the St. Albans Congregational Church.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Under the guidance of Bill Hartack, the gray colt proved far superior to five other 3yearolds; scoring by six lengths and winning $18,135 for his owner.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The final environmental impact statement on the proposed trans Alaska pipeline is a documented report on how systematically to abuse nature and destroy a wilderness. Only in a society such as ours that is shockproof to violence  whether against nature or man  could such a report be tolerated.

title: WALTER GORMAN, TV DIRECTOR, DIES
description: LITTLE. COMPTON, R.I., Aug. 6T. Walter Gorman, a network radio and television director in New York for more than 20 years, died yesterday at his home here, after an ill ness of several years. His age was 56.

title: OKKER IS BEATEN BY LUTZ IN 4 SETS
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 6 (UPI)Unseeded Bob Lutz, who has played for years in the shadow of other American stars, scored the biggest tri umph of his career todaya 64, 26, 64, 64 upset of Tom Okkerand captured the 45th United States professional ten nis championship final.

title: Phelps Dodge Appoinitments
description: Orlando G. Gonzales, pres ident of the Phelps Dodge International Corporation, headquartered in New York, will take over the additional office of president of the Phelps Dodge Puerto Rico Corporation. John McCaa Jr. has been appointed ex ecutive vice president and elected a director of the Puerto Rico operation and Julio Baque has also been elected a director.

title: TENANTS CENSURE HIGHRENT UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 The National Tenants Organi zation, which has been con cerned with improving condi tions for lowincome renters, is taking tentative steps to ward organizing middle and upperincome tenants who find that high rents no longer shield them from the problems of the poor.

title: British Criminal Justice Assailed
description: LONDON, Aug. 6Britain's system of criminal justice, viewed as a hallmark of British society and extolled for its hon esty and fairness, is coming under intense attack from the police, senior judges, Conserva tive parts politicians and others worried about rising crime.

title: PRESSURE HEAVY AGAINST NOFAULT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) The nation's trial lawyers, insurance companies and the White House are still applying heavy pressure to prevent nofault automobile insurance bill from becoming law, Senate sources said today.

title: INDIA ORDERS AID TO AVOID FAMINE
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 6  A prolonged dry spell in 13 of 21 Indian states is causing serious concern in New Delhi, and the Government has ordered emer gency relief measures to ward off famine.

title: White House Reported To Invite Fischer Visit
description: President Nixon has invited Bobby Fischer to visit him in the White House after the world championship chess match is over, according to an article in the Aug. 11 issue of Life magazine.

title: Chinese Show a Movie On PekingCanton Flight
description: CANTON, China, Aug. 6 (Agence FrancePresse)Pas sengers flying from Peking to Canton last night aboard Chinese airliner were shown a movie, apparently for the first time.

title: Community Program on Coast Seeks to Make Punishment Fit Young Offenders
description: EAST PALO ALTO, Calif, Aug. 6  Diane, a 17year old girl accused of shoplifting, sat clown with her mother across the table from six young people.

title: Weapons TurnIn in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 6Almost 1,500 pistols, revolvers and highcaliber rifles have been handed in to authorities during the last four days, the Irish po lice said today.

title: Cable Damage Stalls Trains
description: Thousands of subway pas sengers were delayed for two hours yesterday morning while emergency crews repaired sub way cable damage on the IND A line from Manhattan to Rockaway Beach. The damage was caused by a water main break at Tompkins Avenue and Fulton Street in Brooklyn. Service was suspended at 9:20 and resumed at 11:40. A Tran sit Authority spokesman said the damage was not serious.

title: 30% of the Drug Addicts in StateOrdered Treatment Programs Drop Out
