description: CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 9 (AP)  There was no evidence whatsoever of any conspiracy or accomplice in the slaying of six persons June 21 in a Cherry Hill office building, the assist ant Camden County prosecutor, Mario Lavicoli, said today. Ed win J. Grace of Brooklyn, the accused slayer, died July 8 of a selfinflicted gunshot wound, he added. Six other persons were injured in the incident.

title: Romney and Shapp Clash Over Flood Relief Plans
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Aug. 9. (AP) A threesided shouting match erupted today between George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Devel opment, Gov. Milton J. Shapp, and a crowd of flood victims.

title: City Takes Steps to Create an Authority to Persuade Knicks and Rangers to Stay
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day there was a good chance that the city would submit legislation to Albany for a sports authority aimed at making it more comfort able for the Knicks and Rangers to stay in New York. There has been speculation, not discouraged by Garden officials, that the teams might move to New Jersey to take advantage of tax relief.

title: 6Term Member Wins
description: DETROIT, Aug. 9 (AP)Rep resentative Jack McDonald, thrown by reapportionment into a Republican contest with Rep resentative William Broomfield, lost his chance to run for re election in the Congressional primary in Michigan yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Sets Suspensions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) The S.E.C. announced that it had suspended, with certain ex ceptions, overthecounter ac tivities of the principal office of W. E. Burnet & Co. of New York for 15 days.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN FOR COMMODITIES
description: After the hectic trading and sharp price rises for wheat, corn and soybeans in recent sessions, prices declined yester day.

title: MISS EVERT LEADS ADVANCE ON CLAY
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 9 (AP) Chris Evert of Fort Lauder dale, Fla., reached the women's quarterfinals of the United States open claycourt tennis tournament today with a 63, 60 victory over Corinne Moles worth of Britain.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)A spokesman for the National Football League Players Association testified today that N.F.L. owners might try to destroy the Canadian Football League by expansion into Canada.

title: PACK, POET, TO HEAD BREAD LOAF PARLEY
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Aug. 9 (AP)The 47th annual session of the Bread Loaf Writers' Con ference is to begin Wednesday at Middlebury College with John Ciardi, the poet, in his final year as director.

title: Nyquist Agrees to Hold a Hearing on Fuentes Case
description: The State Commissioner of Education, Ewald B. Nyquist, said last night that he was willing to hold a hearing on the charges of racism against Luis Fuentes, the controversial new community school super intendent for District 1 on the Lower East Side.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WALTER STEINBACH
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 9 Walter Steinbach, who was active in the operation of the familyowned Steinbach Com pany department store here for many years, died at his home in Ocean Township yesterday after a long illness. His age was 88.

title: Bar Meeting Opens Today
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 (UPI)The vanguard of 7,500 lawyers arrived today for the 95th annual Ainerican Bar As sociation convention, opening tomorrow, at which the law yers will discuss their own problems and their role in solv ing those of society. The agen da for the weeklong meeting includes such items as decrimi nalization of marijuana posses sion, electronic eavesdropping, women's rights, nofault auto mobile insurance and the con duct of judges.

title: AIRLINE ISSUES UP IN LEVEL MARKET
description: Airline issues and Interna tional Business Machines moved aloft yesterday, while the stock market generally held to its level pattern of the two pre vious sessions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bahrain and Emirates Given Seats at Nonaligned Parley
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 9 (AP)The Union of Arab Emirates and Bahrain, newly independent Persian Gulf countries, were admitted as participants in the conference of nonaligned nations here yes terday, but a bid from the Viet cong ran into resistance. The 64 countries attending the con ference admitted Oman, also on the Arabian peninsula, as an observer.

title: Asylum Question Still Open
description: ALGIERS, Algeria Aug. 9 (UPI) Government officials said to day that Algeria had made no decision yet on whether to grant political asylum to five Americans who hijacked a Del ta Air Lines jet to Algiers Aug. 1.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: OLYMPIC tickets hotels, Reduced rates Tn77700X658Advt.

title: Yanks Topple Tigers, 21, After 60 Loss to Fryman
description: Two Mexican third basemen who used to play against each other back home played prom inert roles yesterday in keep Ing the Yankees and the first place Detroit Tigers three, games apart in the suddenly interesting Eastern Division race.

title: Victors in Missouri
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) Missouri voters have nominated State Auditor Christopher Bond, a Republican, and Edward L. Dowd, a St. Louis lawyer, a Democrat, to run in November for Governor.

title: Shooting for the Second Time Around
description: Sports of The Times

title: PENNSY SETS SALE OF BARCLAY HOTEL
description: Merger News

title: EARL NELSON
description: LAS PALMAS, Canary Is lands, Aug. 9 (UPI)Earl Nelson, a descendant of the brother and heir of Britain's naval hero who was killed at Trafalgar in 1805, died yester day at the age of 79 while visit ing here, according to the news agency CIFRA.

title: Bill Is Introduced to Assist Syphilis Study Participants
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) Alabama's two Senators in troduced a bill today to pro vide compensation to the par ticipants and survivors in an experiment under which more than 600 Negro victims of syphilis did not get treatment.

title: Thaler Says He Will Sue Federal Reserve on Notes
description: Seymour R. Thaler said yes terday that he planned to sue the Federal Reserve System and two banks for failing to recognize that United States Treasury bills he was handling had been stolen.

title: Cahill to Speak at Dinner
description: CLARKSBURG, W. Va., Aug. 9 (AP)Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey will be the fea tured speaker at a fundraising dinner here next Monday for Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. of West Virginia. Governor Moore, a Republican is running for re election against Secretary of State John D. Rockefeller 4th, a Democrat.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)  John B. Connally, the for mer Treasury Secretary, an nounced today the formation of a Democrats for Nixon com rnittee in the Presidential cam paign.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 At the express instructions of President Nixon, the White House's three years of intermit tent conflict with the press has come to at least a temporary halt.

title: Private Business Funds Rescue PhasedOut Neighborhood Fives
description: The private sector began paying yesterday for the City Wide Athletic Association, which sponsors more than 280 neighborhood basketball teams and 3,000 players.

title: SAMUEL TEIGER DIES; EXRESTAURATEUR, 69
description: NEWARK, Aug. 9Samuel Teiger, who opened and oper ated the Tavern Restaurant at Meeker and Elizabeth Avenues from 1929 to his retirement in 1959, died today in Beth Israel Hospital, of which he was a trustee, after a stroke. He was 69 years old and lived at 377 South Harrison Street in East Orange.

title: SOVIET PURCHASE OF GRAIN FROM U.S. MAY TOTAL BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Agriculture Department esti mated today that the Soviet Union would purchase a billion dollars worth of farm products from the United States over the next 12 months. This would raise SovietAmerican trade to unprecedented heights.

title: ARMY TERMINATES COPTER PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) The Army announced today that it had killed the trouble plagued Cheyenne helicopter program, six years and $401 million after it awarded the first contract, and asked Con gress for $40million to start work on a new one.

title: Gambrell and Challenger Face Runoff Aug. 29 for Democratic Senate Nomination in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 9 Two newcomers to statewide cam paigning finished ahead of 13 opponents in the Democratic primary for the United States Senate nomination from Geor gia yesterday and will face each other in a runoff Aug. 29.

title: Market Place:Carat May Help Fatten Savings
description: Not since 1933, when President Franklin D. Roose velt outlawed the purchase of gold, has the individual with a hankering for treasure and a desire to keep it with him had a practical means of hoarding value.

title: RUSSO IS FIGHTING 3D MURDER TRIAL
description: A New Jersey underworld figure, fighting to avoid a third trial on charges that he killed a waiter and a waitress at New Year's Eve party in his home on Dec. 31, 1970, peti tioned yesterday for dismissal of the murder indictments in the Federal District Court in Newark.

title: Internment Policy Assailed in Ulster On Its Anniversary
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland,1 Aug. 9Angry demonstrations and violence today marked the end of the first year of intern ment, the controversial policy of holding suspected terrorists without trial, which has been pivotal in the tragedy of North ern Ireland.

title: Bridge: A Pine Italian Hand Proves To Be Joker for Belladonna
description: A strange episode in the recent World Bridge Team Olympiad in Miami Beach demonstrates that a player can bid accurately, play bril liantly, outscore other players with the same cards, and yet be entirely dissatisfied with the result.

title: McKissick Calls on Blacks To Join TwoParty Politics
description: Floyd B. McKissick, former national director of the Con gress of Racial Equality, said yesterday that blacks must par ticipate in twoparty politics to solve their economic, political and social problems, according to The Associated Press.

title: Work of Police Put At 50% of Potential
description: A senior police commander has said that based on a study six months ago of work per formed in four precincts the New York Police Department. was operating at 50 per cent of its potential.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Concrete Mixers Go on Strike

title: Kugler Asks Weintraub to Name Special Prosecutor for Sherwin
description: TRENTON, Aug. 9Attor ney General George F. Kugler Jr. today formally asked Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of t he New Jersey Supreme Court to appoint a special counsel to prosecute the extortion in dictments against Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two codefendants.

title: BIG BOARD BACKS INSURANCE MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Under Congressional attack for its policymaking practices, the New York Stock Exchange today defended the method by which it had made its decision to let members sell life insur ance.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 9 (Reuters)Senator Jacob K. Javits warned today that a failure by Japan to take fresh initiatives in narrowing its trade deficit with the United States would undermine United StatesJapanese relations and could lead to a further upward revaluation of the yen. In a Senate address on the forthcoming summit meeting Hawaii between President Nixon and the Japanese Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, the New York Republican said that the fate of United StatesJapanese relations was in Japan's hands.

title: Jesuit Artists Share Summer of Ideas at Italian Villa
description: ROMEFor centuries, cler ics from the most distant points of the globe have made their way to Rome to pray in St. Peter's and to seek an audience with the Pope. This summer, however, a group of more than 50 Jesuit artists from 10 countriesmost of whom seem to have left their clerical collars at home have come here to share ideas and work together in their various fields of artistic activity.

title: Progress in Korea
description: The agreement reached yesterday between Red Cross representatives from North and South Korea on proce dures for a fullscale conference on divided families followed a nearbreakdown of negotiations last week. That the way is now open for substantive talks covering mail exchanges, mutual visits and possible reunions of families testifies to the new political atmosphere created by the surprise nonaggression agreement concluded last month by the Seoul and Pyongyang Governments. That atmosphere augurs well for success not only on the fam ily problem but on trade and other contacts to normalize relations.

title: PROTESTERS OCCUPY NIXON OFFICE HERE
description: One of the offices in Presi dent Nixon's state campaign headquarters was taken over peacefully last night by five IrishAmerican demonstrators who accused the Administra tion of favoring British policies in Northern Ireland.

title: Vietnamese Tell of Grim Life After Communists Came
description: BONGSON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6When the Commu nists came a lot of people here were very happy, the bony jawed old farmer said bitterly. Only now, people have had their eyes opened. The Com munists made nice speech es. But look at what happened.

title: 2 GROUPS SUE U.S. OVER FIRE ISLAND
description: A group of leading Fire Is landers, joined by a national environmental organization, filed suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn vesterday, charging the Secrefary of the Interior with violating the Fire Island National Seashore Act by allow ing unchecked development of that narrow barrier beach is land.

title: Fischer and Spassky Draw In 12th TitleMatch Game
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 9 As expected, the adjourned 12th game of the Bobby Fischer Boris Spassky world champion ship chess match ended in draw today.

title: Rooney Aide Says 600 Ineligibles Voted
description: A lawyer for Representative John J. Rooney conceded yes terday that about 600 people not entitled to vote had done so in the June 20 primary in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District, but he did not concede that the votes affected the con test for the Democratic Con gressional nomination.

title: Metropolitan Gets Accreditation Along With 55 Other Museums
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Fiftysix museums, including New York's Metropolitan Mu seum of Art, have joined the roster of institutions certified as meeting the standards of operation established by the American Association of Mu seums. The association's ac creditation commission an nounced the approvals yester day, following two days of closed sessions. The accredita tion panel reviewed applications and the reports of committees that had visited each of the applicants.

title: 4 Vietnam Veterans Jailed In Florida Contempt Case
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 9 (AP)Four Vietnam Veterans Against the War went to jail, today for refusing to answer, questions about alleged plans for violence at the national po litical conventions in Miamil Beach.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Steve Miller of New York and Nick Saviano of Los Altos Hills, Calif., scored upset victories yesterday and advanced to the quarterfinals in the I8yearold division of the Columbia tennis championships for juniors and boys at Baker Field.

title: ART BANK SERVES CANADIAN OFFICES
description: OTTAWAAn art bank, a $5million program to buy and rent out works by contem porary Canadian artists, has been started by the Govern ment.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
TV's Man on the Move Shelbourne Richard Lyman
description: Man in the News

title: LAWYER TO READ HOSPITAL GROUP
description: John A. McMahon, the presi dent of North Carolina Blue Cross and Blue Shield, has been named president of the American Hospital Associa tion, the organization that rep resents the country's voluntary hospitals.

title: Storm's Effects Noted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) The tropical storm Agnes caused 118 deaths and more than $3billion in property dam age while inundating 5,000. square miles of land in its rampage through the East in midJune.

title: Options to Pay Off On Special Phones. Ordered by P.S.C.
description: The New York Telephone Company was ordered yester day to offer refunds or credits to some subscribers who have special equipment such as Prin cess or Trimline phones, bell chimes or tone ringers.

title: Gripped by a Slump, Palmer Alters Grip
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 9 Arnold Palmer returned to the metropolitan area today seek ing to end a victory drought with a new putting style.

title: Advertising: Holiday in Focus
description: Consumers will soon be thinking about Christmas gifts for their families and themselves once the summer is over.

title: Korean Red Cross Teams Agree On Terms for FullScale Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 9  Red Cross negotiators from North Korea and South Korea settled their differences today, reviving hopes that fullscale talks would begin in Seoul or Pyongyang soon, probably this month.

title: American Can Closing Jolts Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 9 City officials and businessmen, jolted by the announcement yesterday that the American Can Company planned to shut down its sprawling plant here, began working today to find other employment for 1,000 workers affected and to attract new industry.

title: Banking Officers Named
description: Ernest A. Rott has been ap pointed a senior vice president and John A. Ronveaux a vice president of the European American Banking Corporation and the EuropeanAmerican Bank and Trust Company.

title: De Profundis
description: Adversity, it has been said, makes a man wiser though not richer. That would appear to be a fair assessment of the impact on the Democratic party the hammerblows its drive to win the Presidency have suffered in the three weeks since the Miami Beach nominating convention.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Personalities: He Isn't Quitting
description: Although he had missed a month of his racing program because of a duodenal ulcer and had thought of retiring, Jackie Stewart, the world champion racing driver from Scotland, said yesterday he would compete in next year's world championship series, The troubles I had with my health this season obviously meant I considered retire ment, Stewart said, but not very seriously. The Scot, who is second in this year's drivers' standing behind Em erson Fittipaldi of Brazil, will drive a new TyrellFord 005 in the Austrian Grand Prix next Sunday.

title: Rate Cuts Ordered Here For Some Auto Policies
description: The State Insurance Su perintendent, Benjamin R. Schenck, ordered rate reduc tions yesterday averaging 18.6 per cent for motorists in the Bronx, Brooklyn, and Manhattan who buy auto mobile liability insurance through the assigned risk plan.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) The Council on Environmen tal Quality said today that it would make public working drafts of three studies that Sen ator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nomi nee, had accused the Nixon Ad ministration of suppressing.

title: Span in North Reported Hit
description: SAIGON, Aug. 9 (AP)United States F4 Phantom jets for the second time in three months knocked out the bridge at Thanhhoa in North Viet nam, the Seventh Air Force re ported today.

title: P.G.& E. OPPOSED BY JUSTICE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)The Justice Department has recommended that the Atomic Energy Commission hold an antitrust hearing on a request by the Pacific Gas & Electric Company to build a $742million nuclear power plant at Mendocino, Calif.

title: Man and Wife Join Navy
description: ALBERT LEA, Minn., Aug. 9 (AP) A married couple en listed today in the Navy. A Navy recruiter, Frank Conwell, said James and Paula Daven port had signed up. Mrs. Dav enport reports to Orlando. Fla., for training Aug. 25, and her husband follows in two weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Confirms Shift In Missile Development
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The Defense Department acknowl edged today that the Admin istration had changed its plans and was now pursuing the de velopment of more powerful and more accurate missile war heads capable of destroying se cure military targets in the So viet Union.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINERADVT.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug. 9 (AP)Developers of a controversial fiberglass pole used to set a world pole vault record have threatened suit unless athletes can use the pole in the Olympic Games.

title: Report Here Backs Using Compact Cars For City's Business
description: A report by the city's Bu reau of Motor Vehicle Pollu tion Control has concluded that the city could have cleaner air and save almost $2million a year if the municipal govern ment used smaller, compact vehicles.

title: Screen: Sabata's Back
description: Gianfranco Parolini, alias Frank Kramer, has now made three Lee Van Cleef Sabata movies; and in so doing he bas established an approach to directing the Italian West ern in which he seems some times to be mounting grand opera, sometimes to be inter preting Kafka and sometimes to be decorating a Christmas tree. I know this sounds like an agreeable combination. The original Sabata (1970) was a good deal of exuberant fun. But Return of Sabata, which opened yesterday at the Victoria Theater, shows the style at a very low ebb, full of coy gimmicks and flaunting a painfully self conscious awareness of its own outrageousness.

title: Prince John Colt Sold for $106,000 At Saratoga Sales
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 9A colt by Prince John out of justakiss for $106,000 topped the second night of the 52d annual FasigTipton year ling sales at the Humphrey E. Finney Sales Pavilion here tonight.

title: Pakistan Arrests 7 Leaders Involved in Language Feud
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 9Seven leaders of two parties feuding over language rights were arrested today.

title: Political DeadEnd
description: The House Education and Labor Committee, its vaunted liberalism blown away by the political winds, has approved an antibusing bill which would be almost as segregationist in impact as the legislation demanded by President Nixon. It would virtually outlaw busing for purposes of integration in the elementary grades and seriously curtail it even in the secondary schools, where most students have long relied on some form of trans portation to get to school.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9The worst part of a Presidential campaign almost always occurs when the candidates start discussing the issues. Partly this is because the issues in Presidential campaigns usually aren't. Partly it is hecause the discussion is rarely a dis cussion, but: usually a rhetorical gruel cooked up by consultants, advisers, gbest writers, press agents, marketing specialists and similar confidence men expert at luring the hicks into the tent.

title: D. M. Schaeffer Weds Joan C. Behr
description: Miss Joan Carol Behr, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving S. Behr of Brooklyn, was married here last evening to Donald Martin Schaeffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Schaeffer of East Hewlett Harbor, L.T. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the cere mony at the St. RegisShera ton.

title: 100 Militiamen Reported Killed in Clash Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 10Nearly 100 Government militiamen report edly have been killed or wound ed in clashes in the jungles and rubber plantations east of Saigon.

title: MAYOR RELEASES PLANS FOR A RISE IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: Mayor Lindsay made public yesterday the first increases in productivity that he will de mand of city departments in the coming year.

title: MRS. A. E. DELVECCHIO
description: Mrs. Mary Roche delVecchio, wife of Albert E. delVecchio, president of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers and second vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, died of cancer yesterday in Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 61 years old and lived at 160 Cabrini Boulevard.

title: Giants Get Message: Have Fun
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 9The Giants have lost nine consecutive preseason football games over a three year span. Maybe if they en joyed themselves in games a little bit more, things might change and the more important regularseason record might im prove.

title: Czechs Jail 7 More for Subversion
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 9 (Reuters). Sever more liberals, includ ing two former Communist party leaders, have been jailed under new sentences handed down in Czechoslovakia's con tinuing series of subversion trials.

title: U.S. Is on Guard for Special Contraband
description: Port Notes

title: Updated Scout Handbook Gives Tips on Survival in the City Jungle
description: In a departure as radical as leaching how to drown instead of how to rescue, the Boy Scouts' new hand hook finally faces up to the perils of the city jungle and to the age of liberations.

title: Senate, 6825, Votes Ban On SnubNosed Handguns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  Spurred by the attempted as sassination of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, the Sen ate voted 68 to 25 today to ban the manufacture and sale of snubnosed handguns.

title: Magnetic Storm Recedes
description: BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 9 (UPI) A magnetic storm from the sun that engulfed the Northern Hemisphere this last week re ceded today, but scientists said that a similar disturbance might await the earth within a month. The National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administra tion said that the area of the solar flare was being faced away from the earth by the sun's rotation.

title: Target: Efficiency
description: New York City spends more than $5 billion a year on wages, pensions and other benefits for its army of municipal workers. That averages out to better than $625 for every man, woman and child in the five boroughs, including the 1.25 million on welfare. How efficiently public employes perform their tasks, from collecting garbage to filling potholes, is a major determinant of both the cost and quality of city life.

title: Feed Grains Are Airlifted to Orkneys As British Dock Strike Enters 13th Day
description: LONDON, Aug. 9As the na tional dock strike dragged through its 13th day today, an emergency airlift of feed grains was begun to the Orkney Is lands to save the cattle herds there, the main prop of the islands' economy.

title: Morton Sets Up U.S.Alaska Land Panel
description: ANCHORAGE, Aug. 9In a nineday visit to Alaska, Sec retary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton surveyed a forest fire nearly threequarters the size of New York City, exam ined huge mineral deposits in three mountain ranges, en dorsed rapid construction of the transAlaska oil pipeline as environmentally safe and dedicated the first stateFederal landuse planing venture.

title: Bodies of Two Men Killed by Bullets Found in Bronx Lot
description: Two young white men were found shot to death early this morning in a vacant lot in the Clasons Point section of the Bronx.

title: PATROLMAN CITED IN PERJURY CASE
description: Bronx District Attorney Bur ton B. Roberts announced yes terday that a patrolman had been indicted for perjury and that, simultaneously, indict ments against 16 persons al legedly involved in a $5million ayear gambling ring had been dropped because the police man's false testimony had led to their prosecution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pendulum Swings Back to Short Hair
description: Hairdressers are predicting that the extended run of long hairlike its namesake mu sicalis just about over. For one thing, sheer boredom with looking the same way for years is making women restless.

title: GRANT GORDON
description: BOSTON, Aug. 9Grant Gordon, an actor who had been appearing at summer theaters in the Boston area, died of a heart attack in his room at the Essex Hotel on Sunday. He was 64 years old and lived in the Westbeth Apartments in New York.

title: Phillips Trial Ends With Hung Jury
description: The trial of Patrolman Wil liam R. Phillips on charges of killing a pimp and a prosti tute was declared a mistrial last night after the jury re ported for the second time in the day that it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: Bank Mergers Are Cleared
description: The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recom mendation of Harry W. Albright Jr., State Superintendent of Banks, approved yesterday the acquisition of the First National Bank of Highland, N. Y., by the First Empire State Corporation. The board also approved the ac quisition of the First Trust Union Bank of Wellsville, N. Y., by the Security New York State Corporation. The mergers must still be approved by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Rail Pension Rise Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) The House voted, 398 to 4, today to provide a temporary 20 per cent increase in railroad retirement benefits to match the increase given earlier this year to Social Security recipi ents. The measure was sent to the Senate. A permanent pen sion level would be decided later.

title: PRICES END MIXED ON AMEX AND OTC
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthe counter finished mixed yester day in slow trading.

title: Big Raid on Town Charged
description: PARIS, Aug. 9 (Reuters) The North Vietnamese News Agency charged in a dispatch received here today that Ameri can bombers carried out an extermination raid yesterday on Haiduong, a town about 30 miles east of Hanoi. It said that the bombs hit a medical school, a factory and cafes, killing and wounding a large number of people.

title: ROBERT S. CONGDON
description: GIRDLETREE, Md., Aug. 9 Robert S. Congdon, who retired in 1966 as executive vice presi dent of Ted Bates, Inc., New York advertising agency, died yesterday after a stroke at his form, Snow Hill. He was 63 years old.

title: Senate RollCall on Handgun Ban
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)Following is the 68to25 rollcoll vote by which the Senate today passed the bill barring the sale of easily concealed handguns:

title: A New Spirit Afoot in the Haight
description: The Talk of Haight Ashbury

title: Chess Game Is Drawn
description: Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky agreed to a draw after 55 moves of the 12th game in their world chess championship match in Reykjavik, Iceland. The 13th game will be played today. Details on Page 71.

title: WILLIAM H. FOALES
description: NEW SHREWSBURY, N. J., Aug. 9William H. Foales, owner and trainer of thorough bred race horses and polo ponies at his Silverbrook Farm here, died yesterday at River view Hospital, Red Bank. His age was 71.

title: Credit Markets Extend Gains, But Investors Turn Selective
I.T.U. Rejects McGovern
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9 (AP) Delegates to the International Typographical Union conven tion today overwhelmingly re jected resolutions supporting Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nomi nee, and calling for immediate withdrawal of American forces from Southeast Asia.

title: National Exchange Elects A 29YearOld President
description: The National Stock Exchange, New York's smallest exchange market, announced yesterday that John D. Girard had been named president to succeed Edward T. McCormick, who retired last November.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SANTA FE., N. M.Former Gov. David F. Cargo, one of the Republican party's few state wide winners here in recent years, is leaving New Mexico for Oregon and a fresh start.

title: Uganda Will Lei Some Asians Remain
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 9 (Reuters)President Idi Amin of Uganda announced today he was determined to go ahead with his plan to expel thou sands of Asians with British passports, adding that nationals of India, Pakistan and Bangla desh must also leave within 90 days.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ib Thomsen has been named president of Good year International Corporation. He had been a vice president and director of the company. Mr. Thomsen succeeds Charles J, Pilliod Jr., who was elected president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Com pany last month.

title: STANWOOD MURPHY OF PACIFIC LUMBER
description: FORTUNA, Calif. Aug. 9 (AP) Stanwood A. Murphy, board chairman of the Pacific Lumber Company, one of the world's largest redwood firms, died yesterday, apparently of a coro nary attack, aboard his private. plane, the coroner's office re ported. He was 53 years old and lived in San Francisco and Larabee.

title: Personal Finance: Jobless Benefits
description: Nearly one million jobless Americans who have been getting emergency unemploy ment checks will soon dis cover that the pay window is no longer open.

title: Alitalia Home Flights Halted
description: ROME, Aug. 9 (AP) A sud den walkout by pilots grounded domestic flights of Alitalia, Italy's national airline, today in the first of a planned series of short strikes. Alitalia said that its intercontinental flights would not be affected.

title: Teachers Stepping Up Contract Talks
description: I With a month remaining be fore the start of the new school year here, the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers are stepping up the pace of their contract negotiations in an ef fort to avert a possible teach ers' strike on opening day.

title: Cooley's Anemia Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)  The Senate sent President Nixon today a bill to combat Cooley's anemia, an inherited blood disease afflicting primar ily Americans of Italian and Greek descent.

title: CHARLES W. MIXER, COLUMBIA LIBRARIAN
description: Charles W. Mixer, an assist ant director of the Columbia University Libraries since 1946, died of cancer yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Wider Apple Law Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP)  A bill extending Federal qualitycontrol marketing re quirements to all appleproduc ing states instead of just major ones was approved today by a House Agriculture subcommit tee.

title: Spain Anxious on Lack of Economic Ties
description: MADRID, Aug. 9Spain is watching with increasing anx iety and tension as Western Europe organizes longterm economic linkswithout Spain.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Michigan Gas Utilities Company said yesterday it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Ex change Commission in connec tion with a previously public rights offering of common stock consisting of 123,118 shares. Kidder Peabody & Co. Inc. heads a group of under writers on the offering under which holders will be entitled to subscribe for one additional share for each ten shares held on the record date which is expected to be Sept. 7. The company's stock was up 14 at 15 at the close yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Business Briefs
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (UPI)The cost of a new home is increasing steadily, the United States Savings and Loan League said in a report issued today. The median price of a new home rose to $25,000 in 1971 from $23,400 1970, according to the trade organization's 1972 fact book.

title: A Meeting in Prague
description: These excerpts are front a discus sion between Antonin Kapeh, First Secretary of the Prague City Commit tee of the Czechoslovak Communist party, and students at the Technical College in Prague.

title: THE 1872 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9On what he called the first day of the campaign for the Presidency, Senator George McGovern sought to demon strate Democratic unity today, shuttling back and forth from Capitol Hill to hotel rooms up town, accompanied by his run ning mate, Sargent Shriver, and making fresh reassurances to party blocs.

title: Strawberries on Chilled Pie
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. War Toll for Week Rises to 7 Dead, 36 Hurt
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (UPI)American com bat casualties increased last week to seven killed and 36 wounded because of enemy rocket attacks on United States bases, military spokesmen said today.

title: N.B.A. Approves Sale of Bulls
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP)The National Basketball As sociation approved today the sale for $5.1million of the Chicago Bulls to a 10member group, including Arthur M. Wirtz, owner of the Chicago Stadium. The action at a meet ing of the N.B.A.'s board of governors ended several months of onandoff sales of the Bulls.

title: Lottery Tickets on Sale
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 10 (AP)  Pennsylvania lottery tickets went on sale today for the first time in a month. About eight million tickets were re ported distributed for the first drawing of the new postflood schedule on Aug. 23. Tickets will be on sale until Aug. 22 for that drawing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Massive Use of Undercover Men Urged To Combat Graft in Construction Here
description: Two experts on police cor ruption urged yesterday that extensive use be made of un dercover agents to combat graft in the building industry.

title: Seoul's Premier Is Alarmed by Speed of Tokyo's Initiatives Toward Peking
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 10  Premier Kim Jong Pil has expressed grave misgivings over the speed with which Ja pan is proceeding to establish diplomatic relations with the Chinese Government in Peking.

title: VIETCONG SEATED BY GUYANA PARLEY
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 10 (AP)The Vietcong and the exile Cambodian regime of Prince Norodom Sihanouk were seated today as members of the conference of nonaligned nations meeting here.

title: MacGregor Mocks McGovern Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Clark MacGregor, President Nixon's campaign director, attacked the Democratic Pres idential nominee with his own words today, imploring Senator George McGovern to come. home, George, from what he termed a giveaway welfare program, massive and reck less defense cuts and a beg ging foreign policy.

title: U.S. Plans to Halt Loans for Panama If Boise Talks Fail
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) A high Treasury Department official said today that the United States would impose economic sanctions against Pan ama in the event of a break down in negotiations for com pensation of a. Boise Cascade Corporation subsidiary in that country.

title: What Is Indochina?
description: To the Editor: When Senator McGovern talks about Indochina, he means Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia. But I, as a Chinese, understand that Indochina is the peninsula in Southeast Asia between the Bay of Bengal and the South China Sea, comprising South Vietnam, North Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, Malaya and Burma. So if McGovern means to withdraw all U.S. forces from Indochina, he cannot leave any military personnel in Thailand. I be lieve the North Vietnamese use the same definition of Indochina that I use.

title: Last Parts of Ecology Study Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Council on Environmental Quality allowed newsmen to day to inspect drafts of three chapters that were not includ ed as part of the council's an nual report on the environ ment.

title: Joseph Halle Schaffner Is Dead; Hart, Schaffner, Marx Director
description: Joseph Halle Schaffner, a di rector of Hart, Schaffner and Marx, the Chicagobased coth ingstore chain, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 61st Street. He was 75 years old and lived at 1 Beekman Place.

title: Harlem 4 Ask Court to Curb Prosecution Access to Witness
description: Defense lawyers in the Har lem Four case charged yes terday that the Manhattan Dis trict Attorney's office had used force and terror to make a key witness support the pros ecution's case.

title: 11% Drop Is Estimated in Corn Crop
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)The Agriculture Depart ment's first full estimate of 1972 corn production today put the size of the crop, on the basis of Aug. 1 conditions, at 4,947,986,000 bushels, down 11 per cent from last year's crop.

title: WAGNER TO HELP M'GOVERN IN STATE
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner will serve as chairman of Senator George McGovern's election campaign in New York State, the candidate's organiza tion announced last night.

title: Prices Continue to Change Little On Amex and OvertheCounter
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market yesterday con tinued to show little change for the fourth consecutive session in slow trading.

title: Renewed Bombing Adds $1.1Billion to War's Cost
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  The extra cost of the Vietnam war, resulting from the renewal of heavy bombing and other United States air and naval ac ivity since the North Vietna mese offensive, will be $1.1 billion in the current fiscal year, the Defense Department disclosed today. This is less than the Nixon Administration previously estimated.

title: U.S. IS WITHDRAWING LAST COMBAT UNITS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, Aug. 11The United States military command an nounced today that the last two infantry combat units in South Vietnam had been with drawn from the field.

title: Freedom and Dignity Revisited
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In a famous passage in Notes From the Under ground Dostoevski insisted that man will never admit that his behavior can be predicted and controlled. He will create destruction and chaos to gain his point. And if all this could in turn be analyzed and prevented by predict ing that it would occur, then man would deliberately go mad to prove his point. Dostoevski was himself making a prediction, of course, and it had the curious effect of cutting off this last avenue of escape, since henceforth even deliberately going mad could be said to have been pre dicted.

title: U.S. AIDE OPPOSES USE OF FREE HEROIN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  The director of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs joined a bipartisan Congres sional committee today to de nounce what they saw as new moves to permit heroin main tenance for some addicts.

title: Hartford Trust Is Planned
description: The Hartford National Corpo ration, parent holding corn pany of the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company, said yesterday it had received ap proval from the New York State Banking Board to estab lish a limitedpurpose trust company in New York City. It will be known as the Hartford Trust Company of New York and will engage in the transfer of securities and related activi ties from headquarters at 63 Wall Street.

title: Republicans Here Said to Obstruct Registration
description: Albert H. Blumenthal, Demo cratic minority leader of the State Assembly, charged yes terday that Governor Rocke feller and the state Republican party were obstructing voter registration.

title: Wilson J. Sweeney Is Dead; Senior Counsel for Texaco
description: Wilson J. Sweeney, senior at torney in the legal department of Texaco, Inc., died Wednes day at his home, 120 East 79th Street. He was 53 years old.

title: School Security Program Called Publicity Gimmick
description: The chairman or a City Coun cil committee investigating vio lence in schools, skeptical that the Board of Education's new director of safety would be given a free hand to combat crime in schools, characterized the new security program yes terday as a publicity gim mick.

title: Bridge:
description: Those who complain loud ly about their bad luck at the bridge table should be careful to avoid being too specific. Somebody might put their claim to the test, and find it wanting.

title: Data on Hope Festival
description: The Festival of Hope rock concert will be held from noon to midnight tomorrow and Sunday at Roosevelt Race way, Westbury, L. I. Seventeen major rock and rhythm and blues groups will participate in the event, benefiting the Nassau Society for Crippled Children and Adults, the local Easter Seals affiliate.

title: Held Job Tor Life
description: Starting in 1947 after repeat ed appeals were denied, Fay began to serve a 7to15 year sentence for taking money from the contractors. He had been elected business agent for life of Local 825 of the Oper ating Engineers Union.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has received a $42.5million Navy award for research and development on nuclear ship propulsion plants, it was announced yesterday. The Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion obtained an $18.5million Air Force award for support of the F104 G pilot training program.

title: News Analysis
description: PARIS, Aug. 10The former Hotel Majestic on Avenue Kle ber, where the American and Vietnamese delegates to the peace talks perform their week ly ritual, seems much more than half a world away from the agonizing realities of the war.

title: Typical Workout in Life Of a Jet Named Namath
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 10 O.K. girls, at the count of three, let's say it, shouted one of a halfdozen preteens at the Jets' workout today. One . . . two . . . three. Joeeee!

title: Saigon Muzzle
description: As President Nixon seeks a preelection finale to the Vietnam war, President Thieu continues to play havoc with political freedom in South Vietnam. After a cam paign of mass arrests, in which thousands of Commu nist and nonCommunist critics of the regime were herded to detention camps, Mr. Thieu has now moved to silence opposition from an already intimidated press.

title: For Ranger, Knick Fans, The Prices Go Up, Up, Up
description: While fans were wondering yesterday whether Madison Square Garden was serious in its hints at moving the Knicks and Rangers to New Jersey, the clubs' ticketholders were busy sending in their checks for the coming season.They may have to send in additional funds if the Garden convinces the Price Commission a ticket increase is necessary.

title: Chase Opens Unit In Vienna to Spur East  West Trade
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it was set ting up a special unit to develop trade and financial links with the Soviet Union and other East European countries.

title: House Committee Refuses To Subpoena Jane Fonda
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) An attempt to subpoena Jane Fonda, the actress, to testify about her Hanoi visit and anti war broadcasts was rejected by the House Internal Security Committee today.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Rose Slightly During Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 121.0 from 120.3 last week.

title: WITNESS APPEARS IN MACKELL CASE
description: Moses Z. Yam, a lawyer sought for several days to testify before a Federal grand, jury investigating the office of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens, appeared in Federal court in Brooklyn yes terday and was quickly served with a subpoena.

title: 102Acre Landfill in Parsippany Is Granted Permission to Close
description: NEWARK, Aug. 10  The Public Utilities Commission to day granted permission for the closing of a 102acre landfill refuse dump at Parsippany Troy Hills that serves more than 80 municipalities as well as commercial and industrial scavengers in northern New Jersey.

title: Patriots Are a Team for All Seasons
description: AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 10 The New England Patriots remain three football teams, one that has gone, one pres ent and one pending. Upton Bell, the effervescent general manager, said with a glint in his eye that he is out to pass George Allen of the Redskins in the number of trades

title: About Baseball
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 10 For those who seek signs of progressive thinking among the men who run baseball, the annual summer meetings that ended here today offered at least a grain of hope.

title: Lawyer Here Will Direct State Criminal Justice Unit
description: ALBANY, Aug. 10 (UPI) Archibald R. Murray of New York City was named by Gov ernor Rockefeller today Com missioner of the state's Division of Criminal Justice Services.

title: Unlted Press International
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 10 (Reuters)  The British High Commissioner in Uganda called at the Foreign Office at his own request today, apparently to deliver another message from the British Government on President Idi Amin's plans to expel 50,000 Asians.

title: SALVATORE T. GAMBINO
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Aug. 10 (UPI)Salvatore T. Gambino, mayor of Peekskill from 1964 to 1966 and the city's first judge when it received its char ter in 1940, died this morning, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Rock Festivals on Upbeat Again,,
description: Rock festivals, after more than two years of economic and spiritual malaise, appear to be staging a remarkable recovery this summer.

title: MALLANO ABOARD 4 JERSEY VICTORS
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 10 (UPI)John Mallano, an ap prentice jockey, capped a four winner day by booting home Life Cycle today in the feature race at Monmouth Park. He also rode four winners last Monday.

title: Weaver, With 64, Leads Golf by Stroke
description: HARRISON, N.Y., August 10 De Witt Weaver Jr., with a new putter and a new attitude, led the opening round of the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic today with a 64.

title: YANKS TOP TIGERS MIND KLINE, 10; TRAIL BY 2 GAMES
TakeOver Bids Set by 2 Big British Companies
description: LONDON, Aug. 10  Two major British companies an nounced todaytake over bids to expand their spheres of oper ation.

title: Macy Resigns as Public TV Head
description: John W. Macy Jr., the em battled president of the Cor poration for Public Broadcast ing, resigned his $65,000ayear job yesterday. He had been at loggerheads with the White House and some elements of Congress over the political and financial directions public broadcasting has taken.

title: . . . and Plugging the Gap
description: In the midst of trying to structure a rational revenue sharing program, the Administration and Congress became aware of a wideopen sluice gate in the jerry built system of existing Federal support for state governments.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on colonialism 10:30 A.M.

title: The Prospects for Fishing and Boating Enthusiasts This Weekend
description: Anglers might wish to cast their eyes heavenward and to the northeast, tonight and to morrow night, and if the skies are clear they will see the annual Perseld shooting star shower. The display reaches Its peak after mid night.

title: Business Briefs
description: DAVAO CITY, the Philippines, Aug. 10 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company introduced today its Asian car that company executives hope will be a successor to the Model T. Officials said the basic model will sell in the Philippines for about $1,195.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 10  As Senator George McGovern opened his Presidential cam paign with a brief stopover here today, the one thing Connecti cut DemocratsMcGovernites and regularscould agree on was that he faced an uphill fight in this normally Democratic state.

title: PEGGY LEE SINGS IN PARK FESTIVAL
description: Peggy Lee brought an un accustomed touch of old fashioned glamour to the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park Wednesday eve ning. On the stage in Wollman Rink, which has been occupied most of the time this summer by rock groups and current pop singers, she appeared in a voluminous, flowing, long, white gown set off by a sparkling choker necklace and bracelets to match.

title: Lavelle's Disability Rating Is Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Representative Les Aspin has charged that Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle, who was removed as the American Air Force com mander in Vietnam after he ordered unauthorized bombing raids on the North, was retired a month later with a 70 per cent disability rating unsup ported by medical evidence.

title: C.A.B. Said to Back U.S. Air Fare Rise
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board has approved an acrossthe board increase of 2.7 per cent in domestic airline fares, gov ernment sources said yester day.

title: Furniture Company Is Indicted On 81 Charges of Fraud Here
description: A major Harlem furniture store was indicted yesterday on charges of conducting a scheme to defraud lowincome consumers by using deceptive advertising, fraudulent sales practices and concealed pay ment arrangements.

title: TAYLOR DEFEATS STOLLE, 76, 63
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 10 (UPI) Roger Taylor of Britain ad vanced to the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Cleveland Tennis Classic today with a 76, 63 victory over the Australian, fired Stolle.

title: Soviet and China Clash on Bangladesh U.N. Bid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 10China and the Soviet Union clashed angrily in the Security Council today over the proposed admission of Bangla desh to the United Nations.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON,. Aug, 10Albert Chambers is on strike be cause he is a man with a shaky future.

title: 2 Young Relatives Of Mafioso Found Slain in the Bronx
description: Two young relatives of Jo seph (Jojo) Manfredi, a reputed Mafia figure and bigtime nar cotics trafficker, were found shot to death yesterday in the Bronx, and the body of a mur dered man, Carlo Lombardi, was discovered beside a road in Sullivan County.

title: RANGERS TO OPEN AT GARDEN OCT. 11
description: The New York Rangers, start ing their 47th year in the National Hockey League, will open their home season on Wednesday, Oct. 11, against the Vancouver Canucks at Madison Square Garden. The game will be the first of 39 at the Garden for the 197273 season.

title: John W. Zischang, 52, Dies; A Television News Editor
description: John W. Zischang, New York television news editor and for mer United Press International and U.P.I. Movietone newsman, was drowned in a swimming ac cident off Yucatan, Mexico, on Wednesday, officials of WCBS TV reported. His age was 52.

title: U.S. Hears Algerian Police Raided Panthers' Quarters
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  The Algerian police surrounded; and then entered the headquar ters of the Black Panther party in Algiers today, according to reports reaching the State De partment.

title: FloodBattered Elmira's Downtown Is Back
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., Aug. 10 Elmira officially reopened its floodshattered central busi ness district today, nearly seven weeks after the rain swollen Chemung River raged over the city's dikes, inundat ing thousands of stores and homes in the worst disaster in Elmira's history.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW GOOD GAINS
description: In anticipation of the Govern ment's crop report issued yes terday after the close of trad ing, wheat futures showed some good gains. The December con tract closed at $1.84 a bushel, up from $1.80.

title: Advertising:
description: The 37 companies that have run newspaper and magazine advertisements this year praising New York City received their reward yester day: a buffet luncheon at Gracie Mansion and a piaque naming them executive en voys.

title: Airing the Presidency
description: The commercial and educational TV stations now have a splendid opportunity to bring the issues and differences between President Nixon and Senator McGovern into the open air. Editorial independence and ingenuity of the sort that occasionally has characterized the boldest docu mentariescan overcome the fears and pressures con sidered inherent in political broadcasts.

title: Advertising:
description: Betty Harragan, who had been a writerpublicist at the J. Walter Thompson Company for eightandahalf years, told her story yesterday of alleged sex discrimina tion at the agency to the State Human Rights Division.

title: American Can Elaborates on Its Plans
description: The American Can Company said yesterday that it has a po tential buyer for three of its pulp and paper plants that were put up for sale as part of a re structuring program announced earlier this week.

title: HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 10George McGovern; acting very much like your amiable Uncle George, is now taking his case to the people, and he seems to be betting on the assumption that they are now ready for another surge of reform.

title: Rockwell's Delays On Contracts Could Cost Grumman Jobs
description: The North American Rock well Corporation said yesterday it would be quite a few months, more likely up to a year, before it would be ready to award any subcontracts on its $2.6billion space shuttle award.

title: Tanzania Bars Expellees
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 10 (Reuters)  Tanzania will not allow Asians expelled from Uganda to settle in this country, the Home Affairs Min ister, Saidi Maswanya, said here today.

title: Executive Changes
description: William E. Conway, vice president of the Dia mond Shamrock Corporation and G. G. Pirrone, president of the Diamond Shamrock Chemical Company unit, have been elected executive vice presidents of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation. William H. Bricker, group vice president, succeeds Mr. Pirrone as president of the chemical company unit.

title: Merger News
description: The Illinois Central Railroad and the Gulf, Mobile & Ohio Railroad moved swiftly yester day to merge into the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad, a com pany with 9,400 miles of track and combined revenues last year of more than $450million. They took the step only one day after a threejudge panel of the Federal Court in St. Louis dismissed complaints of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and the Kansas City South ern Railway. However, efforts to overturn the merger, which was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission last year, may yet be pursued be fore the United States Supreme Court.

title: Pair of Unlikely Needlework Artists
description: Good grief! What's going on at Lord & Taylor?

title: WILLIAM A. BERNS OF WORLD'S FAIR
description: William A. Berns, a television and motion picture producer who served as vice president in charge of communications of the New York World's Fair 196465 Corporation, died of pneumonia Wednesday in New York Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 177 East 77th Street.

title: Miss Feder Married to K. I. Haber
description: Miss Adrienne W. Feder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving J. Feder, was married at the St. RegisSheraton Roof last evening to Kenneth Ivan Haber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Haber. Both families are of Harrison, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Saul Teplitz.

title: Russo Freed in Bail of $25,000 On Jersey's Fugitive Charges
description: Joseph Russo, a reputed un derworld figure, was released on $25,000 bail in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that he fled across state lines to avoid prosecution in a doublemurder in New Jersey.

title: Books of The Times
description: It is a commonplace that any number of colonial peoples had helped liberate themselves by exploiting the ideas brought in by their oppressors. Foreign notions of treedom, of civil liberties, of parliamentary democracy, of progress, of history were used as weapons in the battles for inde pendence. Quite often the leaders of the

title: In the Heat of Summer, Ice Cream Suit Makes a Comeback
description: What do Mark Twain, Muhammad All, Tom Wolfe, Wyatt Cooper and Kevin McCarthy have in common? They've frequently played the role of the Man in the White Suit.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The women's plank that the National Women's Political Caucus will present to the Re publican Platform Committee next week features positions in favor of abortion on demand and comprehensive child care programs, both issues that President Nixon has gone on record against in the last year.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MANCHESTER, N. J., Aug. 10 Senator George McGovern re turned to a Manchester shoe factory today to rekindle the spark he said his campaign had found here in the cold, dark days of the New Hampshire primary.

title: JOSEPH FAY DEAD; EXLABOR LEADER
description: NEPTUNE, N. J Aug. 10 Joseph S. Fay, a powerful labor leader in New Jersey who was convicted in 1943 of extorting $368,000 from contractors working on the Delaware wa tershed reservoirs in upstate New York, died yesterday in the Jersey Shore Medical Cen ter. He was 80 years old.

title: PATERNO: DROP RULEBREAKERS
description: The National Collegiate Ath letic Association should conduct itself so that once a college team is great the public knows it got there without breaking the rules.

title: AILING METS OPEN SERIES WITH CUBS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10  The New York Mets limped into Chicago today for three games against the pursuing Cubs, and everywhere Yogi Berra looked, he saw trouble down the home stretch of a troubled season.

title: FORECLOSURES LAID TO CITY'S POLICIES
description: An apartment owners' organ ization charged yesterday that the city's inept, antiowner administration of rentcontrol laws had led to foreclosure proceedings against 7,500 build ings in Brooklyn, 2,500 in the Bronx and 1,000 in Manhattan, housing 500,000 people.

title: Miss Joan Reeves Is Bride Of Lewis H. Lapham, Editor
description: Miss Joan Brooke Reeves of New York was married here yesterday to Lewis H. Lapham, managing editor of Harper's Magazine. Family Court Judge Harold A. Felix performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Orin Lehman.

title: JOSEPH J. WAGNER
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 10 Joseph J. Wagner, controller of Columbia University for the last two years, died today of cancer at his home, 150 Oxford Boulevard. He was 59 years old.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: REDDING, Calif., Aug. 10 (AP)The Government em ploye who was dismissed under the Hatch Act for being a delegate at the Democratic National Convention has been restored to her job.

title: Mayor Seeks Aid of Regular Democrats
description: A year after he joined the Democratic party, Mayor Lind say is making overtures to reg ular Democratic leaders in what some top party members be lieve could be a prelude to an alliance between the Mayor and the organization leaders in the mayoral campaign next year or the gubernatorial cam paign in 1974.

title: BRITISH TO FLY FOOD TO REMOTE ISLANDS
description: LONDON, Aug, 10 (Reuter) The British Government to clay ordered an emergency mili tary airlift of essential food supplies to remote islands off the north coast of Scotland seriously hit by a nationwide clock strike.

title: FED INTERVENES TODEFEND DOLLAR
description: The Federal Reserve System, acting to support the interna tional value of the dollar, inter vened in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday.

title: Skeptics Find Economic Controls, After One Year, Have Worked Better Than Expected
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  A year ago, when the Nixon Administration imposed the na tion's first peacetime wage and price controls, consumer prices had risen 4.4 per cent in 12 months and wages 7.3 per cent.

title: EXPLODER TAKES SARATOGA SPRINT
description: SARATOGA. SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10Explodent, who had been campaigning on the New Jersey  Pennsylvania circuit, made his season's bow at Sara toga a successful one today.

title: Forest Hills Mediator Urges A Decision on Compromise
description: The mediator in the Forest Hills housing dispute said after a private meeting with Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the fate of his compromise plan rested with Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes.

title: Perspective on Busing
description: To the Editor: The current controversy over school busing represents the greatest threat to America's pursuit of equality since the end of the Reconstruction Period. Wellfinanced forces are exploiting fears based on inadequate, and often distorted, information. (For example, only 3 per cent of the nation's twenty million children who are now bused to school are remotely connected with desegregation efforts.) [Editorial Aug. 10.]

title: Spur to Variable Interest On Mortgages Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today pro posed regulations aimed at spurring the use of variable interest home mortgages in the United States.

title: CLARENCE F. FALK
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Aug. 10 Clarence F. Falk, director of the incoming program for the Experiment in International Living, died here Saturday. He was 62 years old and lived in Dummerston.

title: Jane Winick Is Bride
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10  Miss Jane Betty Winick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Judd E. Winick of Maple wood, was married here this evening to Craig Lewis Jacob of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester E. Jacobs of Skokie, Ill. Rabbi Daniel Franzel performed the ceremony in Temple Israel. The bride's father is presi dent of the industrial prod ucts division of the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company in New Brunswick. The bridegroom's father is presi dent of the Castle Baking Company, Inc,, Chicago.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BELGRADE, YugoslaviaHaving re cently written that 1973 will almost certainly bring significant advances in the importance of Western Europe, is worth appending an analysis of what effect this could have on the United States and its NATO Alliance.

title: BOARD CALLED READY TO ACT ON FUENTES
description: Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the city's Com mission on Human Rights, re ported yesterday that the head of Community School Board 1 had said that the local board was prepared to act on any com plaint of racism that might be brought against the dis trict's new superintendent, Luis Fuentes.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10 (UPI) Senator Thomas F. Eagleton returned to his home town to night for the first time since he withdrew 10 days ago as the

title: General Electric Director
description: Charles D. Dickey Jr., chair man and chief executive officer of the Scott Paper Company, has been elected a director of the General Electric Company.

title: J. HERBERT SMYTHE
description: J. Herbert Smythe, former publisher of The Lamp Journal and The Antique Dealer, trade papers, died Wednesday in Del ray Beach, Fla., where he lived. His age was 74.

title: City Pleased With Trial Of Night Road Repairs
description: When city workmen bring in equipment to pave crumbling streets and snarl daytime traf fic in the process, one question drivers always ask is: Why can't they do this at night?

title: Sports of The Times
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 10The 12th hole on the West Course at Westchester Country Club measures 500 yards if you stretch the tape across the old quarry in front of the green, or approximately nine miles if you're care less. Jack Nicklaus hit a No. 3 mood off the tee and de cided he could get home with a 4iron. The ball stopped just short of the green, so with his sand wedge he chipped it into, the cup for an eagle 3. He had begun on the 10th tee, so the 12th was the third hole for him. On the next 15 he shot five birdies and never yielded a stroke to par, bringing in a score of 65. Until DeWitt Weaver Jr. finished with a 64 at the very end of this breezy, sunny day, Nicklaus and young Steve Melnyk shared the lead for the opening round of the $250,000 Westchester Classic.

title: Port Authority Will Take Over And Run Newark Penn Station
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will take over and operate Newark's Penn Station; subject to the approval of the Federal Court that oversees the affairs of the bankrupt Penn Central Trans portation Company. The Penn Central owns the station.

title: Mrs. Shepard Wed To R. A. Bartlett Jr.
description: In the chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here yesterday after noon, Mrs. Florence Barth man Shepard of Montclair, N. J., widow of Whiting New ton Shepard, was married to Richard Allen Bartlett Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y.

title: RABBI HENACH SENDIC
description: Rabbi Henach Sendic, a spe cialist in remedial reading at Public School 52, Rosebank, S. I., and a certified school psy chologist, died Tuesday of can cer in Scranton, Pa, He was 34 years old and lived at 176 Ardmore Avenue, Willow brook, S. I.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 3 Slayers Escape From Jersey Prison

title: City Acquires the Title To Yankee Stadium
description: The city is now Yankee Stadium's landlordowner.

title: London Considers Ending Ulster Internment Policy
description: LONDON, Aug. 10William Whitelaw, Britain's adminis trator for Northern Ireland, flew to London today to confer with Prime Minister Heath and senior British officials about ending internment without trial in Ulster.

title: Personalities: Barry Undecided
description: Where next? Rick Barry, the New York Nets' out standing scorer, still finds himself asking that question as a result of a court ruling that he must play next sea son with the Golden State Warriors of the National Basketball Association.

title: Who Speaks for The Jewish Voter?
description: To the Editor: I read recently that three Jewish leaders support President Nixon and cite his policy on Israel as a reason.

title: Silver Is Exempted From Price Curbs; Hoarding a Factor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Nixon Administration to day exempted silver from price controls. It acted in response to a request by three Idaho mining companies.

title: Net at Royal DutchShell Plunges 48% in Quarter
description: Earnings of the Royal Dutch Shell Group of companies plunged in the second quarter and first half of this year despite increased revenues and a higher volume of oil sold outside North America, the midyear report disclosed yes terday.

title: No Immediate Impact Here
description: The eventual defeat in Con gress of proposals to open the Highway Trust Fund to mass transit uses would not immedi ately affect New York City's plans for new subways. Funds for the proposed Second Avenue subway, for instance, will conic. from the city itself, from New York Statethrough the 1967 Transportation Bond Issueand from grants from the Urban Mass Transportation Adminis tration, a Federal agency that. disburses funds voted sep arately by Congress and not connected with the Highway Trust Fund.

title: News Guild's Stand Decried
description: SEATTLE. Aug. 10 (AP)  The SeattleTacoma chapter of the Newspaper Guild has voted to divorce itself from the union's international executive board's endorsement of Senator George McGovern, the Demo cratic Presidential nominee.

title: Swiss Yacht Team Wins
description: NIEUWPORT, Belgium, Aug. 10 (UPI)  The Swiss team of Gian Noldin and Ruth Ieland won the fifth heat in the 420 class of the world yachting championships today and moved from fourth to second place in the overall standing.

title: Asia's DurianEaters Follow Their Noses to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 3A Thai princess has re nounced her position in the world's oldest monarchy to become a commoner. The Thai table tennis team is pre paring to go to Peking and perhaps usher in a relation ship with China. The heat is on the opium crop, and the military Government has an nounced a record defense budget.

title: Food for Bangladesh
description: An American public health doctor, back from a three month field trip to Bangladesh, warns that the new Bengali nation faces severe famine in the next few months unless relief efforts are substantially increased.

title: Guest Houses Vanishing in U.S.
description: GENESEO, Ill., Aug. 10. Pearl Hutchinson's tourist home here has no com puterized reservations serv ice, no green glowing mes sage lights, no ice machines, no plastic glasses, no chemi cally treated shoeshine rags, no vibrating beds and no sou venir shop selling plastic ice cubes that entomb fake spiders.

title: Music Fete
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 10 Composers of posttonal music who do not come from the 20thcentury Viennese tradition of Schoenberg, Berg and Webern often find it hard to suggest a sustained mood in their works. The peculiar atmosphere of hot house oppressiveness that largely contributes to the power of Pierrot Lunaire and Wozzeck, for instance, is rarely paralleled. From the Viennese trinityand par ticularly from Webern, of courselater composers have learned to organize their pieces with unbreakable logic and formal purity; but some how the deeper musical mysteries of audience appeal have been more difficult to solve.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 10 (UPI)The release of Gov. George C. Wallace from Spain Rehabilitation Center may be delayed beyond next week by a new abdominal infection, but some feeling has returned to the paralyzed lower por tion of his body, doctors re ported today.

title: REVIVAL OF IRENE TO OPEN THE ASTOR
description: A revival of Irene, the 1919 musical, starring Debbie Reynolds, will inaugurate the 1,600seat Minskoff Theater in Astor Plaza on Jan. 28. The production will also mark the first direction of a musical comedy by John Gielgud, who has staged dramas, operas and operettas in his long theatrical career.

title: Dynamics Loan Authorized
description: At a hearing in Federal Dis trist Court yesterday, Roy Bab bit, referee in bankruptcy, au thorized the Dynamics Corpo ration of America to borrow $3 million from a group of banks headed by the Chase Manhat tan Company. The company filed a petition for reorganiza tion under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act on Aug. 2, listing assets of $79.6 million and liabilities of $62.27 million.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 10The Treasury disclosed today that Secretary George P. Shultz had convened a luncheon meeting of the Group of 10 leading financial nations for Sept. 24, the Sunday before the Sept. 2529 annual meeting here of the International Monetary Fund. This would follow tradition though the group's meeting may not take up any important business. A new chairman will be elected replace Mr. Shultz, whose oneyear term will have expired.

title: BIG BOARD MAKES SLIGHT PROGRESS
description: The stock market was devoid of spectacular gainers yester day, but it made some progress on moderato volume.

title: Dutch Princess Plans Visit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Princess Margriet of the Netherlands and her husband, Pieter Van Vollenhoven, will attend the 125th anniversary celebration or the founding of Holland, Mich., on Sept. 9, the State Department announced today.

title: Panel Bars Road Funds For Building Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10  The Senate Public Works Com mittee voted today to continue to prohibit the use of Federal highway money for the build ing of subways and other rapid rail systems in urban areas.

title: CHAUNCEY F. STOUT, A JERSEY PUBLISHER
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug 10 (AP)Chauncey Field Stout, retired publisher of The Plain field CourierNews, died today at his home here. He was 94 years old.

title: MISHAP TAKES OUT WINDIGO'S STEAM
description: PADANARAM, Mass., Aug. 10 At 12:45 P.M. today, a can nonlike explosion aboard Win digo plunged the crew of that venerable 72foot yawl into crisis.

title: Spassky Seals Move No. 42 In 13th Game With Fischer
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 10 Perhaps refreshed after writ ing a sizzling letter of com plaint about playing conditions, Bobby Fischer today played a strong game against Boris Spassky in their world cham pionship chess match.

title: KEITH S. LYMAN, 51, AN ADAGENCY AIDE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10 Keith S. Lyman, a vice presi dent of Albert FrankGuenther Law, Inc., New York advertis ing and financial publicrela tions agency, died yesterday in the Greenwich Hospital, where he was being treated for heart condition. He was 51 years old and lived on Hendrie Lane in Riverside.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today the acquisition of control of Texas International Airlines, Houston, by the Jet Capital Cor poration, New York City. The C.A.B. found that the acquisi tion by Jet Capital and its owners, Francisco A. Lorenzo and Robert J. Carney, was part of a major refinancing program for the airline.

title: JACKSONPROPOSAL ON ARMS REJECTED BY SENATE GROUP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee overwhelmingly re jected proposals by Senator Henry M. Jackson and others today and cleared the way for a full Senate vote tomorrow on the interim agreement with the Soviet Union to limit offensive missiles.

title: 61 Yearlings Sold, One for $140,000, At Saratoga Sales
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 10A filly by the South American champion, Forli, out of Desk Room topped the third night of the fourday Fasig Tipton yearling sales when she was sold for $140,000 to E. P. Taylor of Canada.

title: BLUE CROSS DECIDES TO BUY NEW BUILDING
description: Greater New York's Blue Cross announced yesterday that it intended to buy the 38story office building being built at 622 Third Avenue, at 40th Street for $47,850,000.

title: Tennis Playoff Set Nov. 27
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP)The $50,000 Commercial Union Mas ters Playoff for men leaders in the union's grand prix of ten nis will start Nov. 27 in Barce lona, Spain, the union an nounced today.

title: In the Army, They Check Credentials
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y.Having emerged from lowermiddlemanagement in General Westmoreland's bureaucracy, I can comment with some knowledge about recent efforts to make Army life more attractive to young officers con sidering a military career. Leaving aside the moral issues raised by the Mylai trials and other causes clbres, I find current organizational change within the Army marginal; it fails to address the basic pathologies of the system.

title: Bruins Sign Hodge for 5 Years
description: BOSTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)Ken Hodge, a wing, rumored ready to sign with the Cleveland Crusaders of the new World Hockey Association, signed a fiveyear contract today with the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League.

title: Thorough Study Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Philip C. Jackson. Jr., presi dent of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, com mented:

title: Health Proposals Criticized
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP)  Representative Shirley Chis holm, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today that none of the healthcare legislation pending in Congress was adequate to meet the needs of the country. She, addressed the American Health Congress.

title: State's Conservative Party Backs Rooney for Congress
description: The state Conservative party nominated Representative John J. Rooney, the Democratic in cumbent, yesterday as its can didate from Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

title: SAN DIEGO SELECTS 2 NETS AMONG 18
description: Gene Moore and Ollie Taylor, who played with the New York. Nets last season, were among 18 players selected by the new San Diego team yesterday in a special draft conducted by the American Basketball Associa tion.

title: Violation of StockMargin Rule Charged Against Tax Lawyer
description: A prominent tax lawyer was indicted here yesterday on a Federal charge of using Bahamian bank to violate mar gin requirements designed to control speculation in the stock market.

title: PRODUCTIVITY STUDY IS ASSAILED BY P.B.A.
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association assailed an un favorable study of police pro ductivity that was disclosed yesterday, calling it an attempt to justify discredited theo ries in support of arrest quo tas.

title: House Unit Votes Renewal Of CopperDuty Suspension
