description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a oneyear extension of the sus pension of tariffs on imported copper.

title: ENDWAR MEASURE BEATEN IN HOUSE BY 228178 VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10In a crucial setback for the anti war movement in Congress, the House of Representatives re jected today an amendment de manding the withdrawal of all American forces from Indo china.

title: Arabella Churchill Bride of Teacher
description: LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) Arabella Churchill, 22year old daughter of Randolph Churchill and a granddaugh ter of Sir Winston Churchill, was married here today to a Scottish schoolmaster, James Barton, 23. Guests at the Uni tarian Church service in cluded Sir Winston's widow; the bride's brother, Winston Churchill, a legislator, and her aunt, Sarah Churchill.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKISG WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCH, DRINK DEWARS William Lawson's 86,8 Proof Blended Scotch Whiskies, Imputed loy Palmer & Lons L??., Syosset, N.V.Advt.

title: Slicing the Pie ...
description: The ingredients are all assembled on Capitol Hill for a nourishing dish of Federal revenue sharing to serve up to needy local governments across the country. The question now is whether Congress will put them together in the most effective mix.

title: Suffolk County May Get Track
description: Sports News in Brief

title: Ann Kiyomura Advances
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 Ann Kiyomura, of San Mateo, Calif., advanced to the semi final round of the United States Girls' 18andunder grass court tennis championship today with a 97, 26, 60 victory over Laurie Fleming of Fort Lauder dale, Fla., at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

title: Phillips Had 10 Acquittal Votes On a Hung Panel, Jurors Report
description: The prosecution in the Phil lips murder case said yesterday that it would put the eyewit ness to the killings back on the witness stand when Patrol man William R. Phillips is retried next falleven though 10 of the 12 jurors in the first trial reportedly voted for ac quittal because they did not believe him.

title: Negotiations Completed
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 10 (UPI) Cook Industries, Inc., of Mem phis announced today it had completed negotiations to sell about $225million worth of soybeans and grain to the Soviet Union.

title: Soviet Asks U.N. to Bar Intrusion by Satellite TV
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 10The So viet Union today proposed an international convention to pre vent nations from directing television broadcasts from sat ellites to private homes in other countries without the countries' express consent.

title: CollierWeeks Pair Captures FatherSon Golf Title on L.I.
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 10 J. J. Collier and Robert Weeks of Sands Point posted a win ning 39, 4079 yesterday in the annual Long Island Golf Asso ciation's fatherandson cham pionship at Hempstead Golf Club.

title: Senate Votes to Prohibit Head Taxes at Airports
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (Reuters)The Senate voted today to prohibit states and cities from imposing on air line passengers head taxes such as the controversial $2 fee for traveling in and out of Phila delphia Airport.

title: Vietcong in Paris Again Insist U.S. End Its Support of Thieu
description: PARIS, Aug. 10 (AP)The Vietcong delegation to the peace talks insisted today there is no other way to end the Vietnam war except for the United Stales to get out and stop supporting the present Saigon Government.

title: Notes on People
description: One of the rare New York politicians who have never before visited the state of Israel finally made it. Gov ernor Rockefeller, on his ar rival for a fourday visit, dur ing which ne will meet with Premier Golda Meir, noted he had last visited in 1930, be fore the nation existed.

title: Javelin Reports on Ore
description: Canadian Javelin, Ltd., said yesterday that drilling at its Cerro Colorado property in Panama had indicated more than one billion tons of cop per  molybdenum mineraliza tion.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A secondary offering of 596, 000 common shares of the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company com mon at $55.625 per share was announced yesterday by Gold man, Sachs & Co. as managers of an underwriting group. Ac cording to the announcement the shares are being sold for the accounts of certain share holders and none of the pro ceeds will be received by the company. The company's stock closed at 57, up 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: AIR FORCE JUDGE WEIGHS SPY CASE
description: TYNDALL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Aug. 10 (AP)Col. Joe E. Peck, a military judge, locked himself in a small court room today and began deliber ating charges that M. Sgt. Walter T. Perkins had tried to smuggle national defense se crets to Soviet spies in Mexico City.

title: West Side Air Terminal To Be Closed This Month
description: The West Side Airlines Ter minal, the starting point for the journeys of millions of New York travelers out of Newark Airport over the last 17 years, will be shut down at the close of business on Aug. 27

title: Market Place :When Patience Offers Rewards
description: It was about five minutes before the close of trading on Wednesday and Marquette Cement, a lackluster perform er on the Big Board, had just traded at 11. Suddenly there was a trade for 15,000 shares at 13 and Sam Skurnick's heart leaped. It was Wednes day's biggest percentage gain.

title: Roundup: Brewers' 10 Victory Stalls Oriole Climb
description: The Milwaukee Brewers, buried in last place in the American League Eastern Di vision, made their presence felt again yesterday in the division race. This time the Brewers beat Baltimore, 10, in Milwaukee, and prevented the Orioles from taking over the lead.

title: JERSEY TEST SEEN ON ABORTION LAW
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 10The Bergen County Prose cutor is apparently conducting a grand jury investigation of Dr. Robert M. Livingston, an Englewood Cliffs gynecologist who has admitted to perform ing abortions in what he says is an attempt to test New Jer sey's abortion laws.

title: TWO UTILITIES PLAN NEW POWER UNITS
description: Two utility projects for pow er generating systems, valued at more than $500million, were announced yesterday. The Ala bama Power Company, an op erating subsidiary of the South ern Company, said it planned to build a $400million steam electric generating plant in western Jefferson County, Ala., 18 miles northwest of Birming ham. Associated transmission lines and terminals will add $65million to the total.

title: Heykal Says Israel In 1970 Shot Down Five Russian Pilots
description: CAIRO, Friday, Aug. 11 (Reu ters)  Egypt's authoritative commentator, Mohammed Has sanein Heykal, said today that five Soviet military planes, piloted by Russians, were shot down in less than a minute by Israeli Phantom jets during a clash over Egypt in June, 1970.

title: Racism in Uganda
description: The British Government has acted with honor and courage in accepting responsibility for an estimated 50,000 Asians holding British passports who have been abruptly ordered out of Uganda by President Idi Amin.

title: Saigon Reports Gains in Quangtri City
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 11 (AP)South Vietnamese forces reportedly cleared the southern sector of Quangtri city yesterday and destroyed 14 North Vietnamese tanks in an air attack outside the northern provincial capital.

title: Credit Markets
description: Investors continued yester day to pick away at relatively attractive bonds in the second ary market while declining to follow Wall Street's lead to lower interest rates on new issues.

title: Little Pentagon Papers Case May Reach Court Before Ellsberg's
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10Until last week, it would have seemed impossible that Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. could be upstaged as legal figures by Arthur Kunkin and Gerald R. Applebaum.

title: Chess Play Adjourned
description: After 41 moves, Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky adjourned the 13th game of their world championship chess match in Reykjavik, Iceland. Play is to resume today. Details on Page 26.

title: It's Not Just Another Hotel Restaurant
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmos phere, service and decor (four triangles to none).  Regency Hotel, Park Avenue at 61st Street, PL 94100.

title: GEORGE S. WALLBURG
description: KENNEBUNK, Me., Aug. 10 George S. Wallburg, retired vice president and treasurer of the W. F. Schrafft & Son Corpora tion, candy manufacturers, of Cambridge, Mass., died in the York Hospital Monday after a brief illness. Mr. Wallburg, who was 81 years old, had lived in Kennebunk since his retirement in 1953.

title: Sudan Envoy Sees Pope
description: ROME, Aug. 10The first Ambassador of the Sudan to the Holy See, Sayed Salah el Din Osman Hashim, presented his credentials to Pope Paul VI today, in a move marking an end to the strained relations between the Sudan and the Vatican.

title: Fiesta at Fordham to Offer Free Music at Lincoln Center
description: A twoweek festival of free outdoor music and dance events will be presented at the Ford ham University Plaza at Lincoln Center from Aug. 20 through Sept. 4 (Labor Day).

title: Mrs. William McC. Blair Sr., Chicago Arts Patron, 82, Dies
description: Mrs. Helen Bowen Blair, wife of William McCormick Blair Sr. and a patron of the arts, died in Chicago Wednesday. She was 82 years old and had been in failing health for two years.

title: $30BILLION BILL IS SENT TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10In defiance of an almost certain veto, the Senate passed today and sent to President Nixon $30.5billion health, education, welfare and labor appropria tion$1.8billion more than he had requested for this year.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ROOTS Of COINCIDENCE. By Arthur Koestler. 158 pages, Random House. $5.95. Near the close of this investigation into the current standing of parapsychology, Arthur Koestler makes a curious point. Picking up a thread of the argument of his previous book, The Case of the Midwife Toadin which he reviewed sympatheti cally the life of Dr. Paul Kammerer, the brilliant but illfated Austrian biologist who was perhaps the last respected adherent to the La marckian theory that acquired phys ical characteristics can be passed on genetically  Mr. Koestler questions once again the prevailing dog ma of the neo Darwinists, who insist that genes cannot be educat ed by experience. Mr. Koestler's brief argument runs roughly as fol lows: The fact that human infants are born with thick skin on the soles of their feet casts at least a ray of doubt on neo Darwinism(!); the rays of doubt that once fell upon Newton's view of the universe have exploded into the light of modern quantum physics; modern quantum physics lends a certain plausibility to paranormal psychological phenomena; therefore the In heritance of Acquired Characteristics ought perhaps to be given the same credence that now surrounds parapsychology. In short, if ESP is possible, then why not IAC?

title: ALFRED M. ELLINGER
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Aug. 10 Alfred M. Ellinger, who re tired in 1959 ass a senior vice president of the Hanover Bank in New York, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge. He was 77 years old.

title: Key Part of Knapp Report Absent in Murphy's Copy
description: The Knapp Commission showed an advance copy of its report to Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, but delib erately withheld the most con troversial recommendation  that Governor Rockefeller ap point a special deputy attorney general to fight corruption in the city's law enforcement agencies.

title: Tanks Used in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug, 10 (AP)A series of attacks by enemy infantry, backed for the first time in Cambodia by heavy tanks, has jeopardized what little is left of the Gov ernment's hold on the east bank of the Mekong River.

title: BEARS' LATE KICK TOPS OILERS, 2017
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 9 (AP)The Chicago Bears converted a free kick into a 7yard field goal by Mac Percival with three seconds to play tonight for a 2017 ex hibition football victory over the Houston Oilers.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP)The price of gold, declining steadily for more than a week in European bullion markets, made a sharp turnaround today to jump between $1 and $2 an ounce. The dollar improved in foreign exchanges, but the British pound was mixed.

title: 5,000 Tickets Are Available for Giant' Game on Sept. 10
description: The New York Giants said yesterday there were about 5,000 tickets available for their final preseason gamea meet ing with the Cleveland Browns at Yankee Stadium on Sunday, Sept. 10

title: Swedes Arrest McCartney
description: GOTENBORG, Sweden, Aug. 10 (Reuters)Paul McCartney, the former Beatle, and the entire British pop group Wings were arrested on drug charges after a concert here tonight. The police said customs men had found nearly half a pound of hashish in a parcel addressed to one of the group's members.

title: Kodes, Connors Move On
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10 (AP) Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia and 19yearold Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., reached the quarterfinals today in the $60, 000 United States claycourt championships.

title: Armagh Center Is Bombed
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 10 (AP)Bombs and gun fire rocked the city of Armagh last night.

title: CITY WILL SCREEN 44 RELIEF CENTERS
description: The city announced tightened controls yesterday on the way its 44 welfare centers handle relief cases. A new, monthly headquarters review will rank each center by relative error rate.

title: Retail Sales Rose Sharply Last Month to a Record
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10Re tail sales rose sharply in July to a record after a dlp in June, the Commerce Department re ported today on the basis of preliminary figures.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SET TALKS ON L. I. R. R.
description: Twelve nonoperating unions threatened yesterday to strike the Long Island Rail Road at 8 A.M. on Sunday, Aug. 20, but Federal officials immediately arranged a meeting in Wash ington for Monday in a further effort to resolve the longstand ing dispute.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It should be recognized by now, in the light of the floating of the British pound, that under present world con ditions, conventional attempts to stabilize foreign exchange rates are not likely to succeed. The pound fell within a mere six months of the very formal Smithsonian agreement. Then too, the relationship of the German mark to the U.S. dollar has changed three times in the last three years, not counting the present crisis.

title: Phone Rate Rise Denied
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) The Illinois Commerce Com mission denied today a request of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company to raise its rates 20 per cent to provide $182mil lion additional in annual rev enue. The ruling came after an 11month study of Bell's re quest. The company serves three million customers in northern Illinois and northern Indiana.

title: Marcos Follower Is Slain
description: MANILA, Aug. 11 (UPI)A political follower of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and four of his companions were killed in a shootout early today with policemen and bodyguards of a suburban mayor at the lobby of the Manila Hotel Interconti nental. Delfin Cueto, a 44year old businessman, and four companions including two Gov ernment agents were killed.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Out on Eighth Avenue, green city buses rumbled past the nine umbrella hotdog stands parked against the sidewalk near the highrise, redbrick Polo Grounds Project apartment house. In the Holcombe Rucker Memorial Play ground at 156th Street, near the Harlem River Drive, about 3,500 spectators had gathered at the asphalt basketball court to sit on wooden bleachers, stand in the aisles, perch in trees or hang atop the wire fence. Virtually all the spectators were black, but there were a few white faces, scattered like grains of salt in a pepper shaker. On the court, famous players were on display. But there was no box office, no ticket taker. Walk in and watch.

title: India to Demand Visas
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 (Reu ters)The Indian Government announced today that Uganda Asians holding British pass ports would require visas to enter India.

title: McGovern on Europe
description: One of Senator George McGovern's major tasks in the campaign will be to convince Americans that his Come. Home, America call does not signify a return to isola tionism in general or abandonment of Europe in par ticular. Ironically, Mr. McGovern recently spoke more eloquently and extensively on these points in a remark able interview with a leading Italian newspaper than he has to date for home consumption.

title: DAYAN SAYS MOVE BY CAIRO REDUCES HIS ARMY'S NEEDS
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 11De fense Minister Moshe Dayan said tonight that the expulsion of Soviet military forces and advisers from Egypt would en able the Israeli armed forces to redeploy along the Suez Ca nal truce line and reduce call ups of reservists for active duty.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHO IS JULIA? By Barbara S. Harris. 309 pages. McKay. $6.95.

title: 246 French Olympians
description: PARIS, Aug. 11 (UPI) France will send from 246 to 252 athletes to compete in the Munich Olympic Games, the French National Olympic Com mittee said today: There were 208 French athletes at the Mex ico City games four years ago.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)George Romney, Secre tary of Housing and Urban, Development, said today that he planned to leave his Cabinet post but had not asked Presi dent Nixon to accept his resig nation.

title: Judge Bars Delay in Democrats' Suit Over BreakIn
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Nixon's major cam paign organization lost today its plea to postpone, until af ter the general election, a $1 million civil suit filed against it and a number of persons in connection with the break in at the Democratic head quarters here.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Tourney Begins At New York Hilton Today
description: Most tournaments consist of at least six separate events. The fact that the Greater New York Bridge Association finds it worth while to devote a complete weekend to a Swiss team championship is clear evi dence of the popularity of such contests. A twoday Swiss begins at the New York Hilton today, with ses sions at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M., and continues tomorrow at 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.

title: Giants Get HalfDay Off As Reward for Ineptitude
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 11The Giants were dismissed today after their morning workout on a strong note of dissatisfaction from their coach, Alex Web ster.

title: From the Lower East Side, a Short Trip to a Faraway Place
description: For Mrs. Gloria Rivera, the trip to the Henry Street Set tlement's poor people's country club in Westchest er County was something like going home.

title: AFTERNOON RALLY PUTS AMEX AHEAD
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market registered their first advance of the week yes terday after an afternoon rally sent most prices higher. Trad ing continued slow.

title: A New Way Found to Set Fossils' Age
description: California researchers have developed a method for dat ing ancient bones and ar cheological remains that seems to fill the most im portant gap in such methods of age determination.

title: 8 MORE CZECHS GIVEN JAIL TERMS
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Eight more Czechoslovaks, including the daughter of a for mer Brno Communist party chief, have been given sen tences ranging up to four years in prison on subversion charges.

title: A. M. A. Chief Plans to Compare U.S. Health Care With Europe's
description: Dr. Charles A. Hoffman, president of the American Medical Association, who has completed a tour of European health care systems, said yes terday that he planned to look, at some innercity and rural services in this country to see how care can be improved.

title: Rogers Asserts Shriver Talks Bunk About War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that Sargent Shriver, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, was talk ing bunk and engaging in political fantasy when he as serted yesterday that President Nixon blew a chance to end the Vietnam war in 1969.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: Power Company yes terday announced it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a pro posed public offering of 1.5 million common shares. The First Boston Corp. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. have been named joint managers of the underwriting group. The company's stock was up  at 30 at the close yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Spassky Proves Tough Foe in Losing 13th Game in Chess Match
Britain Airlifting Food To Her Northern Islands
description: LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) An emergency airlift of essential supplies to remote British offshore islands be gan tonight as talks to settle a twoweekold dock strike reached a critical stage.

title: Dike Bombing Denied By U. S. Carrier Pilots
description: ABOARD U.S.S. SARATOGA IN THE GULF OF TONKIN, Aug. 8The pilots aboard this aircraft carrier swear that they have never tried to bomb the dikes of North Vietnam and they say they are hurt and irritated that so many Ameri cans at home do not seem to believe them.

title: EDITH LEWIS, FRIEND OF WILLA CATHER
description: Edith Lewis, author, critic and lifelong companion of Willa Cather, the Pulitzer Prize winning author who died in 1947, died after a long illness yesterday at her apartment at 570 Park Avenue. She was 90 years old.

title: Grand Jury Notes Opened to Lawyers Of Slain Man's Wife
description: Lawyers representing the widow of a motorist who was shot to death by a state trooper after he failed to stop at a stop sign in Claverack, N. Y., have won the right to examine testimony given by the trooper to a grand jury.

title: Personalities: A First for Robyn Smith
description: Arline Ditmore was re sponsible for a first at Saratoga last week when she became the first woman jockey to win at the Spa (with Milbar Stable's North star Dancer). Now comes word that Robyn Smith, New York's leading woman jockey, will be the first female rider honored in Saratoga by the New York Turf Writers As sociation. Miss Smith will be among those singled out by the writers when they hold their annual dinnerdance their 47th tomorrow eve ning at the upstate resort's Hall of Springs. The pretty brunette, once a model, has won twice in 10 starts during the Saratoga meeting.

title: Wiretaps on Antiwar Units Laid to Federal Agencies
description: BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of In vestigation, Internal Revenue Service, Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird and Attorney Gen eral Richard G. Kleindienst were named as defendants to day in a suit over alleged wire taps on phones of four Cam bridgebased antiwar groups,

title: Canada's Trade Surplus Falls
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 11 (Canadian Press)  Canada had a world trade surplus of $556million in the first half of 1972, down sharply from a surplus of $1.2 billion in the 1971 period, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: Rousseau Starts His Golf Career at the Top
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 11 What is a hockey player doing in a bigleague golf tournament? In Bobby Rous seau's case, he is developing a golf career by starting at the top.

title: Sergeant Is Given 3 Years in Theft of Defense Secrets
description: TYNDALL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., Aug. 11 (UPI)M. Sgt. Walter T. Perkins of the Air Force was convicted today of stealing military secrets for the Soviet Union and was sen tenced to three years in prison.

title: Couple Killed by Own Bomb in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 11Twoteenage members of the Irish Republican Army were killed here today when a bomb they had unsuccessfully tried to plant in a store blew up as they drove off in a hi jacked truck.

title: Luzon Due for More Rain
description: MANILA, Aug. 11 (UPI) Storm warnings were issued for the main Philippine island of Luzon after a tropical de pression was sighted 261 miles off the northern Philippines. Another storm was spotted 1,450 miles east of the Philip pines and was expected to hit the country in two days. The official death toll in the floods caused by recent monsoon rains remained at 536.

title: Katherine F. Berry, 94, Wrote Books About Japan
description: PHIPPSBURG, Me., Aug. 11 Katherine F. Berry of Wor cester, Mass., and Phippsburg, author and newspaper writer, died Wednesday in the Maine (Medical Center at Portland from burns she suffered in a fire in her home July 28. She was 94 years old.

title: Moscow Observance
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 11Thirty five Soviet Jews today gathered at the Moscow crematory and cemetery to mark the 20th an niversary of the execution of 24 Jewish intellectuals in one of the final bursts of Stalinist terror.

title: Tanaka Accepts Invitation To Peking to Discuss Ties
description: TOKYO, Aug. 11  Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan has accepted the invitation of Pre mier Chou Enlai of China to visit Peking to negotiate the establishment of diplomatic re lations between the two Asian powers.

title: Bringing Back Broadway
description: Few things make a New Yorker feel worse than watch ing American and foreign tourists here walk past the Times Square pornopeepshows and dirtybookstores. The impulse is to shout, This is the underlife, not the real city. New York remains the theater and publishing capital of the country, yet these hawkers of filth films, magazines and books outnumber the legitimate theaters and bookstores in the midtown area.

title: PROGRAM IS GIVEN BY CHARLES LLOYD
description: In the mid60's, Charles Lloyd, the tenor saxophonist and flut ist, was one of the top names in jazz. But about five years ago, he seemingly disappeared. There were no personal appear ances in New York and no re cordings except for an odd al bum two years ago on which he performed primarily as a singer of his impressionistic lyrics.

title: Britain's Surplus For Trade Soars; Figures Distorted
description: LONDON, Aug. 11  Britain had a trade surplus of $71 million in July, more than dou ble the June surplus of $34.3 million. However, the gain must be discounted as a statistical vagary related to the national dock workers' strike.

title: Vietnam Mirage
description: The removal from field duty in South Vietnam yester day of the last United States ground combat troops a landmark that unfortunately does not signify meaning ful progress toward peace in Indochina. The rejoicing would be vastly greater if there were genuine evidence of progress in the deadlocked negotiations in Paris if Congress were not throwing up its hands in resigna tion to an Administration apparently still unwilling to recognize that military victory is unattainable for either side in this tragic conflict.

title: Islanders Get Court Order
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Aug. 11 (UPI)The New York Islanders of the National Hockey League announced today they had ob tained a restraining order to prevent Garry Peters from playing with any professional hockey team other than the Is landers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The New York Plan wasn't very much to begin with; as it now ends, it is even less. The target was merely 800 minority group trainees for the construction industrywhich has a total of 100,000 workers. The total in training is reportedly fewer than 300 and thus far only 22 men have re ceived union cards.

title: GOLD PRICE LOWER IN LONDON TRADING
description: LONDON, Aug. 11 (UPI) Moderate speculative selling pushed the price of gold lower today in Europe.

title: Fittipaldi Paces Trials
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 11 (AP) Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil achieved the fastest trial time at the Oesterreichring Race Circuit today by racing his John Player Lotus to an average speed of 138 miles an hour for Sunday's Grand Prix of Austria.

title: Mrs. Birth Says Key Issue In Talks Is Saigon's Rule
description: PARIS, Aug. 11Mrs. Ngu yen TM Binh, the chief Viet cong delegate to the Paris peace talks, made it clear to day that the issue of American withdrawal from Vietnam, the focus of argument in the first years of the longdrawn  out talks, has now been replaced by the issue of organizing pow er in Saigon.

title: Assassination Attempt On Kenyatta Reported
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 11 (AP)President Jomo Ken yatta of Kenya escaped an assassination attempt today, reliable reports said.

title: Peru's Fishing Industry Hits Ecological Snag
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 11A mys terious ecological problem is af flicting Peru's coastal region. If it lasts another few months, half of the country's exports could be wiped out.

title: City Ballet Cheered In Munich Theater As Its Tour Opens
description: MUNICH, Aug. 11The New York City Ballet triumphantly opened a fourday stand here tonight with performances of Jerome Robbins's Goldberg Variations and the Robbins George Balanchine collabora tion on Stravinsky's Firebird.

title: AUSTIN M. DAVIES
description: Austin M. Davies, retired executive director of the Amer ican Psychiatric Society, died Tuesday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title: HADFIELD'S PACT CALLED $1MILLION
description: Vic Hadfield, the captain and star left wing of the New York Rangers, has reportedly signed a $1million, fiveyear contract with the National Hockey League club, his manager dis closed yesterday.

title: End of a Culture
description: The liquidation of the once thriving Jewish culture of the Soviet Union twenty years ago was a deed of mad ness that still haunts the heirs of both victims and per petrators. On today's OpEd Page, Dr. William Korey describes how two dozen prominent Jewish intellectuals were summarily executed by command of Stalin, then in the final grip of the paranoia that preceded his death.

title: 2D INDIA APLANT BEGINS OPERATING
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11In dia's second nuclear power plant began functioning today, almost a year behind schedule.

title: Swimming Record Set By Baster Crabbe, 64
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 11 (AP)Buster Crabbe won the men's 1,500meter free style today in the 60to65 yearold group of the Nation al Amateur Athletic Union masters swimming champion ships, knocking more than 13 seconds off his time in an earlier meet.

title: PERSONAL CLASH IN SENATE. BRINGS A NEW ARMS MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Still another amendment was introduced in the Senate debate on the arms agreement with the Soviet Union today after Senator Mike Mansfield became annoyed with what he regarded as the presumptuousness of Senator Henry M. Jackson.

title: Decker Acquitted of Shifting Philadelphia Bank's Money
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP)Martin M. Decker, the bankrupt real estate developer, was acquitted today of bank fraud.

title: Consequences of Victory
description: TRUTH OR CONSEQUENCES, N. M., Aug. 11 (UPI)Lee Tre vino won the New Mexico Pro fessional Golfers Association tournament today with a final round 65 for a 36hole score of 129. Trevino, who said he came to New Mexico to visit friends and get in some fishing, donated his winnings, in excess of $500, to the Lions Club program for underprivileged children.

title: Swiss Score Treaty
description: GENEVA, Aug. 11 Some Swiss businessmen are raising objections to a proposed legal assistance treaty between the United States and Switzerland because they fear for the se curity of their manufacturing and commercial secrets, Swiss Government spokesmen said today.

title: Sergeants' Pay Pact Is Settled; Salaries Increased to $18,590
description: The Sergeants Benevolent Association and city negotia tors have reached agreement on a new 30month contract that will raise the sergeants' pay to $18,590 a year as of Jan. 1, 1973. The accord is retroactive to Jan. 1, 1971.

title: Gunman Slays 2 Wounds 2 In Restaurant on East Side
description: Two men were shot dead andi two others were wounded at the bar of an Upper East Side restaurant last night when an other patron, a revolver in each hand, began blazing away at them.

title: ZEST AND WAHINI DOUBLEWINNERS
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. II Zest, Wahini and Cascade joined Orpheus today as the only dou blewinners on the New York Yacht Club's cruise by topping their classes in a 25mile race from Padanaram.

title: Two Britons Triumph
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (UPI) Mark Cox of Britain moved into the semifinals of the $50, 000 Cleveland tennis classic today with a 63, 76 victory over Ismail El Shafei of Egypt in an hourlong match.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)Representative Wright Patman said today he would demand that no system variable mortgage interest rates be put into effect until after Congressional hearings. The Texas Democrat is the chairman of the House Banking Committee.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 (AP)A majorleague plan to allow special American vs. National League baseball games has solved the Louisiana Domed Stadium's booking problem for 1975, stadium officials said today.

title: Alice Cooper Plays Rock To Sink Your Fangs Into
description: Black humor is what the rock singer Alice Cooper calls his act. Yes, that's right, his act, because the name is used to describe both the male lead singer and the group called Alice Cooper.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I would like to resolve one apparent contradiction described by Harrison Salisbury in his interesting July 13 article on the current Chinese scene.

title: M'MILLAN BEATS KODES IN UPSET
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 (UPI) Frew McMillian of South Af rica recorded a 75, 26, 61 victory over Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia today and ad vanced into the semifinals of the $60,000 National clay court tennis championships.

title: London Speeds a Negotiator to Uganda on Threatened Expulsions
description: LONDON, Aug. 11  Geof frey Rippon, Britain's chief negotiator with the European Economic Community, flew to Uganda in an urgent effort to ward off the threatened expul sion of some 55,000 Asians with British passports.

title: REDSKINS DOWN BRONCOS, 41 TO 0
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Tommy Mason scored two touchdowns, one on a 65yard pass play, as the Washington Redskins routed the Denver Broncos, 410, tonight in a Na tional Football League presea son game.

title: THOMAS H. TRACY
description: Thomas H. Tracy, lawyer and writer, died of a heart at tack Wednesday at his home, 118 East 60th Street. He was 72 years old and had an office at 420 Lexington Avenue.

title: Hot Dogs Will Be Redder With U.S.Approved Additive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Government gave meat packers permission today to start adding a compound to hot dogs to make them look more redand presumably more ap petizing.

title: Scrimshaw and Chrisaway Win at Spa
Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Although they were defeated in efforts to keep a deadline for the withdrawal of Amer ican forces from Indochina in a foreignaid bill on the House floor yesterday, most of the more liberal Democratic Rep resentatives from New York City voted to pass the aid bill any way. A major reason was that the meas ure, authoriz ing $2.1billion in foreign military assistance, contained $350million for Israel, mostly for credit pur chases of planes and other weapons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Truman D. Weller's letter (Aug. 3) regarding the earnings limitation for Social Security beneficiaries under 72 years of age prompted me to offer the following suggestion concerning this inequity which, I believe, our na tional legislators would be inclined to consider.

title: New York's Quintet Wins Twice in U.S. Youth Games
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) New York moved two steps to ward a basketball champion ship in the sixth annual United States Youth Games today, downing St. Louis, 8650, and Washington, 6756. Nine cities sent 620 innercity athletes to the games.

title: Enemy Steps Up Attacks Throughout South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Aug. 12  Commando I raids, shelling and ground as saults by the North Vietnamese and Vietcong stepped up all over South Vietnam in the last 24 hours.

title: China Veto on Bangladesh Is Averted by Delay in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11A veto by China of Bangladesh's application for admission to the United Na tions was averted todayat least for the presentby put ting off consideration of the matter until Aug. 21.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Aug. 11 (UFOThe president of the World Hockey Association said today that within two weeks the W.H.A. will file a $48million Federal antitrust suit against the National Hockey League, asking that the. N.H.L. reserve clause be overturned.

title: U.S Olympic Five Tops Pro AllStar Team, 8471
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 11 (UPI)Tom Burleson and Jim Brewer sparked the United States basketball team to an 8471 victory over the Kentucky pro allstars tonight.

title: Woman Truck Driver Killed
description: LIVE OAK, Fla., Aug. 11 (UPI)The only woman truck driver employed by the M R & R Trucking Company, was killed today when her tractor Wailer rig plunged off Inter state Highway 10 into a creek. Harriett Miller, a 45yearold resident of Jacksonville, was pinned in the wreckage of the truck and died at the scene.

title: NAMATH TO START FOR JETS TODAY
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 11Delayed a couple of hours by a faulty landing gear discovered before takeoff, the New York Jets finally got here late this after noon for tomorrow's game against the Pittsburgh Steelers at the University of Washing ton's Husky Stadium.

title: Man in the News
description: On Wednesday night, Rob ert Ferdinand Wagner was sitting in the living room of his waterfront summer home in Sands Point, L.I., watch ing the Yankees on televi sion, when the telephone rang.

title: TWO ARE ACCUSED IN THEFT OF BONDS
description: Two Brooklyn men, one of whom said in court that he had served more than 19 years in prison for murder, were charged yesterday with con spiracy to transport two $100, 000 Postal Service bonds in in terstate commerce.

title: OCONEE CAPTURES HUNTER LAURELS
description: BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Aug 11  Oconee, who used to spell trouble for Christien Platten, spelled success all the way today and won the amateurowner hunter cham pionship at the Sussex Coun ty Horse Show.

title: Vietnam Hijacker's Father Is Freed Quietly by Police
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 (AP)  South Viet namese police have quietly re leased the father of Nguyen Thai Binh, an airplane hijacker slain here July 2. Nguyen Van Hai, who supports a wife and eight surviving children as a clerktypist in the civil service, was held without charges for almost a month after his 24 yearold son was shot to death aboard a Pan American 747 he sought to take to Hanoi.

title: Can't Locate a Publication From 1600's? Try 2d Wing
description: The first volume of the sec ond edition of the Short Title Catalogue of Books Printed in England, Scotland, Ireland, Wales and British America and of English Books Printed in Other Countries 16411700 is about to be published.

title: PAPPAS OF CUBS DEFEATS METS,72
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 11Despite the threat of rain, a Ladies' Day crowd of 23,242 turned out at Wrigley Field today and watched the Chicago Cubs de feat the New York Mets, 72, and move to within one game of second place in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 11 (AP)Seven lawsuits sparked by Jim McDaniels' jump from the American Basketball Asso ciation to the Seattle Supersonics of the National Basket ball Association have been dismissed.

title: QUEENS MAN HELD IN MAJOR SWINDLE
description: A 41yearold Queens man who allegedly swindled hun dreds of investors out of more than $3million in a getrich scheme over the last nine years was arrested on a grand larceny charge yesterday by detectives who quoted the suspect as hav ing said he was unemployed and broke.

title: COUNT MARZOTTO, TEXTILES PIONEER
description: VENICE, Italy, Aug. 11 Count Gaetano Marzotto, a pio neer, in the Italian textile in dustry, died today at his home in Valdagno. He was 77 years old.

title: British Show an Increase In Industrial Production
description: LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) The index of British Indus trial Production in June is pro visionally estimated at 129.7, compared with 130.9 in May, Ithe central statistical office said here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your correspondents from Oakland had such a horrible experience with Amtrak in California that I would like to submit testimony that I have found the New YorkAlbany Amtrak run exemplary of the best in railroad service.

title: WILLIAM MERCUR, 74, OF YIDDISH THEATER
description: William Mercur, press agent for more than 100 Yiddish theater productions here and on tour in the last 40 years, died Thursday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 223 Second Ave nue.

title: August 12: The Anniversary of a Secret Soviet Crime
description: Today marks the twentieth anniver sary of the crime of cultural genocide against Soviet Jewry. On Aug. 12, 1952, a number of leaders of Jewish communal and cultural life in the U.S.S.R. were executed. With one blow, Stalin clearly hoped to render the Soviet Jewish community forever impotent. Yet so meticulously and artfully had Stalin and his successors in the Kremlin managed to suppress the evidence surrounding the crime that even the remarkable cataloguer of Stalinist crimes, Roy Medvedev, obliged by lack of data to treat the episode fleetingly and vaguely.

title: Garden Squeeze
description: Madison Square Garden has joined the parade of sportsmen seeking to coerce the city into a, tax sub sidy. The Garden, owner of both the Knicks basketball team and the Rangers hockey team, has hinted unsubtly that unless it gets some relief from city property taxes it may follow the example of the Giants football team and move its two teams to a proposed sports complex in the Jersey meadowlands.

title: 6 Held in Forgery Of Lottery Tickets That Won $55,000
description: ALBANY, Aug. 11A super vising computer operator in the lottery division of the State Department of Taxation and Finance was among six persons charged here today with forging two lottery tickets that netted $55,000.

title: Chattanooga Busing Order Put Off by Federal Judges
description: CHATTANOOGA, Aug. 11 (AP)Bushing to achieve de segregation of the Chattanooga schools was put off today by United States District Court Judge Frank Wilson Jr.

title: Check on Discounts Begins at Kennedy
description: A team of more than 30 Fed eral agents and International Air Transport Association rep resentatives at Kennedy Inter national Airport last night checked the tickets of hundreds of vacation travelers to Europe, looking for illegally discounted trips.

title: Japan Hopeful of Pact
description: TOKYO, Aug. 11 (Reuters) Japanese businessmen are hop ing to conclude a general agreement for joint Soviet Japanese development of oil fields in western Siberia around next March or April, the Japan Soviet Business Cooperation Committee said today.

title: Market Place: Anta Replaces Four Rseepalsaocuess
description: As well as any other com pany, Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., il lustrates the speculative ex cesses that dominated the stock market in its last great bull phase.

title: Roundup: Grich Homers As Orioles Regain Lead
description: Bobby Grich and Terry Crowley, members of Balti more's younger set, joined the seasoned Mike Cuellar in putting the Orioles back into first place in the American League Eastern Division race last night for the first time since July 10. The Orioles also got important help from the Cleveland Indians, who beat the slumping Tigers, 51, in Detroit.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Federal Reserve'System intervened in the foreign exchange market for the second day in a row yesterday by selling Belgian, francs, according to usually wellinformed market sources.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11A network of pragmatic young novices has reappeared as the core of the McGovern organiza tion in the nearly complete ros ter of state campaign coordi nators. The point was largely eclipsed in the unity meetings with party professionals this week.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11The Justice Department has filed an unusual antitrust suit, charging a conspiracy by domestic industry to head off competition from imports. The suit was filed yesterday in. Pittsburgh against six trade associations in the industry making materialshan dling equipment, with more than 350 manufacturing com panies as members.

title: Lums Elects President
description: The election of William F. Suessbrick as president of Lums Restaurant Corporation was an nounced yesterday. He had been executive vice president of Klemtner Advertising, Inc.

title: New Issues Register Advances, But the Summer Lull Continues
description: Twelve new commonstock is sues began public trading on the overthecounter market in the week ended yesterday. Several registered good gains over the issue price in the socalled after market.

title: Last American Ground Combat Unit Is Deactivated in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11The last American groundcombat unit in Viet nam was deactivated today, a day after one of its com panies returned from a four day mission during which two Men were wounded by booby traps. The unit, the Third Battalion of the 21st Infantry, with supporting ar tillery and a medical detach ment, guarded the big United States air base at Danang. The battalion has 1,043 men. The United States command said that most of the battalion's men would be going home in the next few days, but those with job specialties still needed in Vietnam and those with less than six months' Vietnam service would stay. As of last week 44,600 Amer ican servicemen were left in South Vietnam, not including sailors in the Seventh Fleet off the coast or airmen in Thailand and Guam who fly missions over North and South Vietnam. The first American ground combat bat talion landed in Vietnam March 8, 1965. It was the Third Battalion, Ninth Marine Regiment. At the height of its involvement in 1968, the Unit ed States had 112 ground com bat battalions in Vietnam.

title: Nebel, Brown Quit WNBC
description: Long John Nebel and Ted Brown, two of WNBC's most popular radio personalities, are leaving the station. As of Aug. 28, Mr. Nebel will be heard on WMCA from midnight to 5 A.M., and Mr. Brown will be heard on WNEW from 4 to 8 P.M. At WNBC, Mr. Nebel will be replaced by Alan Doug las, who has been conducting a talk show in Cleveland. He will be heard from 8 to 12 P.M. Mr. Brown is being replaced by Jim Scott, who conducted a talk show in Cincinnati for 12 years. His program will be heard from 3 to 7 P.M.

title: Boy Loses Hand in Blast
description: DANVILLE, Pa., Aug. 11 (UPI)One youth lost his right hand and another was injured early today when they lit a powerful firecracker on Inter state Route 80 near here. Carl R. Frank, 18 years old, of Zanesville, Ohio, was listed in satisfactory condition at the Geisinger Medical Center, where he was taken for treat ment of amputation of the right hand. Leo Shutz, 18, of Miami, Fla., was treated for an eye injury.

title: Max Theiler, Nobel Laureate For Yellow Fever Work, Dies
description: Dr. Max Theiler, whose de velopment of a vaccine against yellow fever won him the Nobel Prize kV medicine and physi ology in 1951, died yesterday of lung cancer at his home in New Maven. He was 73 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Alexander Saunders, chairman of Scenic Hudson Preservation Associa tion, was wrong saying in his Aug. 7 letter to The Times that Con Edison Chairman Charles F. Luce blamed the recent power outages in parts of Brooklyn and Queens on opponents of the Storm king (Cornwall) Project.

title: Black Panther Villa in Algeria Sealed Off After Raid by Police
description: ALGIERS, Algeria, Aug. 11 (UPI)The police sealed off the headquarters of the Interna tional Black Panther party here today, effectively putting those inside, including Eldridge Cleaver, Panther leader, under house arrest.

title: 2 Alleged Traffickers in Heroin Slain by Lone Gunman in Bronx
description: A single gunman, emptying his heavy revolver, killed two alleged heroin traffickers, the Manfredi cousins, when their guard was down after a hearty family dinner, the police re ported yesterday.

title: NIXON SIGNS 4 BILLS AND WEIGHS A VETO
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) President Nixon signed four appropriations bills today, but there were indications that he would veto another major money measure.

title: 3 Policemen in Detroit Acquitted In Shootout With Sheriff's Aides
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11 Three Detroit policemen have been acquitted of charges stemming from a shootout between the police and county sheriff's dep uties.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Since accuracy has always been the hallmark of The Times, I know you'll welcome some facts for your next editorial on the Building and Construc tion Industry. Your July 29 editorial Closed Doors could well be applied to your editorial rationale.

title: U.S. Airlines Plan a Fare Rise of 2.7%
description: The nation's airlines said yesterday that they planned to increase the price of domestic airline tickets by 2.7 per cent about Sept. 5.

title: PENNSY'S LOSSES OVER ESTIMATES
description: The Penn Central Transpor tation Company reported yes terday a $32.1million net loss for June and a $125million net loss for the first half this year. The deficits reflected additional costs of $19million covering damages suffered by the road in tropical storm Agnes.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Thousands of little black clams inundated a fourmile strip of sand at the Rockaway beaches early yesterday morning, attracting flocks of screeching gulls and creating a giant nuisance for 100 city workers who had to haul the clams away.

title: City Bank Reduces Prime
description: The First National City Bank, as expected, reduced its float ing prime lending rate to 5 per cent from 5 per cent, ef fective next Monday. The Mel lon, National Bank & Trust Company; however, left its floating rate unchanged at 5 per cent.

title: GISELLE, DANCED BY DIANA WEBER
description: Giselle demands that the bal lerina exercise a greater vari ety of her talents in a shorter space of time than any other of the classic ballets. It is an enormous assignment and one that is only partially filled at the beginning of one's study of the part. Thursday night at State Theater Diana Weber danced the role for the first time with John Prinz and showed more accomplishment in the sheer dancing aspects of the portrayal than in its natu ralistic acting requirements.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS SHOWS RISE IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) United States car production showed its first weekly up turn since the beginning of the newmodel changeover, the trade paper Automotive News reported yesterday.

title: Privacy Threat Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11A Senate subcommittee opened hearings today on the possible threat to privacy posed by the 1970 Banking Secrecy Act, un der which the Federal Govern ment may require banks to re cord and report financial trans actions it believes to have a high degree of usefulness in criminal and other investiga tions.

title: E. 81st Street Frightened By Drug Scene at Bar
description: One day a year ago this spring, the Sugarman, a sin gles' bar on a quiet block in Yorkville, changed its name to the Tambourine, and the dark, groggy and often vio lent underworld of barbitu rates took over.

title: Woman Heads Mixed Air Force Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)The Air Force, follow ing announcements of expanded opportunities for women in the Army and Navy, said today that it had become the first service to place a female offi cer in command of a major unit composed of men and women.

title: Yanks Beaten, 42, by Brewers
description: George Scott thinks the Yan kees have a good chance of stealing off with the Eastern Division title, but he didn't do anything last night to help with the theft.

title: Delayed Korean Talks to Begin Aug. 30
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 11North and South Korea formally agreed today to open the delayed, fulldress Red Cross talks in Pyongyang on Atig. 30.

title: Albatross Sets Record Of 1:57 at Yonkers
Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: When the Big Apple Was Something Sold on the Street
description: After visiting my broker on Wall Street the other day, I was caught in one of those downpours that ruined many rare days last June. I did find, to my delight, that I could not only buy an umbrella right out on the drenched sidewalks of New York, but at a discount, too!

title: 4 Children Struck By Shotgun Pellets While Chasing Ball
description: Four children were wounded, none of them seriously, in the Crown Heights section of Brook lyn yesterday evening when man allegedly fired a shotgun at them after they climbed fence to retrieve a ball in his backyard.

title: Liberian Paper Hails Move
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 11 (Agence FrancePresse)  Uganda's threatened expulsion of Asians should serve as a warning to those who flock into a developing country, ex ploit its resources and ship the money out without rein vesting any penny there for the social growth of that country, the Government newspaper, Liberian Age, com mented here today. The paper said that it did not agree en tirely with Uganda's approach but it is a sign that the pa tience of Africans is running out.

title: Westbury Preparing For 80,000 Rock Fans
description: WESTBURY, L. I, Aug. 11 Locked and barred gates con fronted the first scattered early arrivals among the 40,000 or more rock music fans expected tomorrow to jam Roosevelt Raceway here in the first ma jor rock festival in suburban New Yorkone that its organ izers hope could become a na tional prototype.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  The Treasury announced today a finding of dumping in the case of imports from Japan of wool and polyesterwool fabrics. The Treasury determined that these products were being sold at less than fair value, which usually means a price in the United States market less than the price in the Japanese home market. Now the case will go to the Tarrif Commision, which will have to determine whether the United States industry is being injured by the imports. If the finding affirmative, special dumping duties will be imposed.

title: Alias Karl Frahm
description: WASHINGTONOur man in Stock holm during World War II years was a skinny, good  looking youngster, an antiNazi German I knew as Karl Frahm whose dispatches, though couched in awkward English, were nevertheless astonishingly informative, often significant and occasionally spec tacular.

title: MARKET SURGES; INDEXES AT HIGHS
description: Stock prices forged steadily ahead yesterday and, by the final bell, placed the market within striking distance of its May high on the DowJones in dustrial average.

title: Peanut Crop Support Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)An increase in the na tional average support level for 1972crop peanuts was an nounced today by the Agricul ture Department. The new level of $285 per ton is $16.50 more than last year, and up $6 from the preliminary support level announced in early April.

title: Asians' Pleas Rejected
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 11 (Agence FrancePresse) Groups of Asians who appealed to the Immigration Department here today became stateless when their certificates of Ugan da citizenship were canceled.

title: Rose Schneiderman Dies at 88; Pioneer Women's Union Leader
description: Rose Schneiderman, a prom inent labor leader who was secretary of the State Labor Department from 1937 to 1944 died last evening at the Jewish Home and Hospital, 120 West 106th Street. She was 88 years old and had lived in the home since December, 1967.

title: LEO BERNSTEIN
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 11 (UPI)Leo Bernstein, former director of the field staff for the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York, died yes terday at the Burke Rehabili tation Center here. He was 71 years and lived at 25 Sutton Place South, New York.

title: Speedometer for Skiers Invented by Neurologist
description: Patents of the Week

title: Sports News in Brief
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 11 (UPI)The football game will be incidental tomorrow night when the Kansas City Chiefs and St. Louis Cardinals help open the 78,000seat Arrow head Stadium.

title: No Longer Do We Belong to Each Other as We Used to
description: After 32 years I went back to the country of my birth. Both of us have changed. My native land is a So cialist country. I am no longer a Pole. We met, looking at each other with many misgivings. I feared a shock; the country may have felt a contempt. After all, we were close relatives meet ing after a period of great family up heaval. But when we parted company we realized that our expectations were false. Neither of us was either shocked or dismayed. And we both realized that we no longer belong to the same family. Why, therefore, not be friends?

title: ART NEWS IS SOLD TO 8MAN GROUP
description: Art News, the oldest and most widely read magazine in the finearts field, was sold yesterday for an undisclosed amount by Newsweek, which had owned it since 1962.

title: BURT FRANKLIN, 68, REPRINTER OF BOOKS
description: Burt Franklin, a lawyer who became an antiquarian book dealer and then a publisher of reprints of rare scholarly books, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 68 years old and had homes here, in Stam ford, Conn., and Fort Lauder dale, Fla.

title: Vietcong Still Collect Taxes Near Saigon
description: BINHLAM, South Vietnam, Aug. 11Despite a decade of pacification efforts throughout South Vietnam, Vietcong agents have apparently been collecting monthly taxes from rubber plantation workers within 20 miles of Saigon without inter ruption since at least 1967.

title: Notes on People
description: Thanks to President Nixon, April 15 will probably con tinue to be an important day in the professional lives of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hall, both of whom are tax law yers. The President nomin ated Mrs. Hall, to a 14year term on the United States Tax Court, subject to con firmation by the. Senate, and appointed Mr. Hall a Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy, ef fective Sept. 1. The Halls are from Los Angeles. He is 44 years old; she is 43. Expected salaries: his, $36,000; hers, $42,500.

title: A Sweet Smell of Success
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 11 A colorful arrangement of four round red onions won the Weston Gardens Outstanding Award last night at a show sponsored by the Fairfield County Horticultural Society. The winning onions, submitted by Russell Greaves, an amateur grower and corresponding sec retary of the horticultural so ciety, were judged as being perfectly shaped, colored and with just the right aroma.

title: Price Curbs Lifted On Sale of Movies, TV Shows, Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The Cost of Living Council an nounced today that it had granted exemptions from price controls for the sale of movies, television shows and live plants.

title: Miss Stone Leads By Stroke With 69 In Ohio Pro Golf
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 11 (UPI)Beth Stone shot a three underpar 69 today to take the firstround lead in the Ladies' Professional Golf Association's $30,000 Pabst Classic on the 6,300yard, par72 Riviera County Country Club course.

title: Wind Destroys Artist's $700,000 Curtain Over Rifle Gap in Colorado
description: RIFLE, Colo., Aug. 11 (AP) Christo's Valley Curtain, a $700,000 art work unfurled across Rifle Gap yesterday, was torn to ribbons by the wind today, a sheriff's spokesman said.

title: Plan to Close Airlines Terminal Is Seen Adding Blight to Area
description: Terrible! Terrible! John W. Ulrich, a Sanitation Depart ment foreman, said as he sat in his storefront headquarters at 412 West 42d Street yes terday and mulled the news that the West Side Airlines Terminal just down the block at 10th Avenue was going to be shut down on Aug. 27.

title: Fischer Wins 13th Game, Leads 8 to 5
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug 11 Bobby Fischer outstayed and outplayed Boris Spassky today, and won the playoff of the 13th game in their world cham pionship chess match.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It is no longer necessary for residents of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn to journey into Manhattan to pick up house furnishings at such stores as Bonniers, Georg Jensen and Blooming dale's. Not since Ann Heller and her husband, Bob, opened ANNDESIGNS some six months ago.

title: REGINALD P. PROUT
description: Reginald P. Prout, a former president of the New York and Cosmopolitan Cricket Clubs, died Thursday in Peninsula Hospital, Far Rockaway, Queens. He was 79 years old and lived at 8510 Rockaway Beach Boulevard, Rockaway Beach, Queens.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company announced yester day the election of Charles W. Bingham and Robert L. Schuyler as senior vice presidents. Mr. Bingham will continue his responsibility for the company's Timberland Management, including the manage ment of the 5.6 million acres owned in fee in the United States; and Mr. Schuyler will continue to handle finance and planning.

title: Park Overshadows Grand Ole Opry
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 11  We didn't want to miss none of the sights down through here, explained Mrs. Neil Plants of Philo, Ohio, as she boarded the orange tram that would take her across the vast concrete parking lot to the entrance of Opryland U.S.A.

title: Screen: 'Brother Carl':Susan Sontag Film Is at the New Yorker
description: "Brother Carl" is Susan Sontag's second movie. But it is the first movie in which she seems to see film as a means to life rather than as a repository for ideas. "Duet for Cannibals" (1969) really dealt with a kind of rarefied mental cannibalism. In a very open way, "Brother Carl" really deals with human relationships.Two women, Karen and Lena, visit an island, a Swedish resort, where Lena's ex-husband, Martin, lives in comparative seclusion with a mentally disturbed ballet dancer named Carl. Carl is brother by guilt rather than blood, for Martin is somehow responsible for his breakdown, and Carl, who totally depends upon him, regards him as an enemy.Lena is young and full of life, and to some extent "Brother Carl" is the story of how she offers her life, first to Karen, then to Martin, and finally to Carlbefore committing it in total and apparently wasteful sacrifice. Karen is older and very tired, and to some extent the film is the story of how her life is saved by the enigmatic Carl, who forms a bond with her own desperately withdrawn young daughter, Anna, and effectively brings the girl out of her private distances and back into the world.I have greatly simplified the story, which is very complex and full of symbolic event and confrontation, and which is also a little foolish. In a sense, "Brother Carl" is all about learning to give, and its climactic "miracle" (Miss Sontag's word) is essentially to evoke laughter from a little girl. These suggest sentiments worthy of Hollywood in the 1930's and 1940's, but that Miss Sontag is willing to treat them openly and seriously is, paradoxically, perhaps her greatest source of strength.There are a directness and an awkwardness of gesture and of larger movement in "Brother Carl" that count among its most attractive qualities, and that go a long way to compensate for its occasionally strained pretensions. It is a very imperfect film, with one bad performance (Genevieve Page as Karen) and several performances that seem to have been directed toward an excessive inexpressiveness.But I think that it indicates the taking of considerable imaginative and emotional risks, as "Duet for Cannibals" did not, and the result is a real movie."Brother Carl" was filmed in Sweden with an English-language sound track. It opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater.

title: Snow in Scottish Highlands
description: ABERDEEN, Scotland, Aug. 11 (AP)  Snow fell over the; 4,000foot Cairngorms in Scot land's Highlands today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: All experienced travelers should sympathize with the discomforts and frustrations that Mr. and Mrs. Dan Lucey report in your Aug. 7 issue about Amtrak service between Oakland and St. Louis. It would hardly comfort them to be reminded that, as they doubtless have the experience to know, air travel too can be just as frustrating and uncomfortable, when foulups occur. Just let me put in my two cents' worth on the other side of the scale and in the context of a different run:

title: St. Louis Reserve Sights 13Billion Budget Deficit
description: The fullemployment Fed eral budget, which most econ omists believe provides the best measure of the impact of the Government's fiscal policy on the economy, should show a $13billion deficit in the cur rent fiscal year, the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis esti mated yesterday.

title: Harold A. MacKinnon, 72, ExVice President of G.E.
description: LACONIA, N. H., Aug. 11 Harold A. MacKinnon, a for mer vice president of the Gen eral Electric Company, died today. He was 72 years old.

title: Antiques: Paperweights
description: Paperweight fanciers will find that dealers everywhere are prepared to supply them with interesting examples, sometimes more odd than old.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation received a $14.1million Navy contract for navigation Systems on Poseidonmissile submarines, it was announced yesterday.

title: COLOR TV BATTLE ERUPTS IN EUROPE
description: ROME, Aug. 11In the wide wide world of television, Italy is still a backward nation. It doesn't have color yet, but salesmen for Europe's two rival systemsthe French SECAM and the German PALare out in force.

title: JAL COOPER
description: Jal Cooper, an international ly known dealer in postage stamps, died on Aug. 2 in Bom Bay, India. An authority on the stamps and postal history of India, he wrote several books dealing with Indian stamps.

title: Boyd Takes Rifle Title
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 11 (UPI)Warrant Officer David I. Boyd, United States Marines, from Quantico, Va. won the small bore position champion ship today at the national rifle matches. Boyd defeated Maj. Lones Wigger, United States Army of Carter Mont., by points with 3,173 of a possible 3,200. Wigger hit 3,166 in the twoday shoot. Boyd had won the anysight title yesterday with 1,594 of a possible 1,600 hits.

title: NEW PLEAS MADE FOR SOVIET JEWS
description: The execution by Stalin's po lice of 24 Jewish intellectuals, among them leading Yiddish poets, on Aug. 12, 1952, will be commemorated today by new appeals to the Soviet authori ties to allow wider cultural freedom to Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: West Sider Is Accused of Paying a Man $1,000 to Kill the President
description: A 27yearold Manhattan man was arrested in Central Park yesterday after he alleged ly paid $1,000 to an undercover agent to kill President Nixon.

title: 2 Women Get Ship Duty
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 11 (AP) The Navy has assigned its first women other than nurses to regular shipboard duty aboard the U.S.S. Sanctuary, hospital ship.

title: JOHN F. KUNC JR.
description: UNION, N.J., Aug. 11John F. Kunc Jr., a scientist in fuel and lubricants, died yesterday at the Overlook Hospital in Summit after a brief illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 2747 Larchmont Road.

title: Nevil Shoots a 65 for 131, Leads Gold Classic by Shot
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 11 Dwight Nevil, a former Dallas fireman and former AirForce golf champion, became the lead er in the $150,000 Westchester Classic today with a record 13 underpar total of 131.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW SHARP RISE
description: Grains and soybeans still held the spotlight yesterday in commodityfutures trading be cause some traders apparently were surprised by some of the Government's cropreport pre dictions.

title: Merger News
description: The Missouri Pacific Railroad and the Kansas City Southern Railway announced yesterday that they were filing notices of appeal to the United States Supreme Court of a court deci sion handed down Wednesday upholding the merger of the Illinois Central Railroad and the Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad. The car riers formally merged yesterday to form a new railroad called the Illinois Central Gulf. Illinois Central Gulf is a subsidiary of Illinois Central Industries. An official of the Kansas City Southern said his road and Mopac had asked threejudge panel in St. Louis to stay for 15 days any action to implement the merger. The Interstate Commerce Commis sion approved the merger last year.

title: Tornado Hits Netherlands
description: NES, the Netherlands, Aug. 11 (AP)A tornado whirled across a camping ground in sand dunes near the North Sea today, killing at least two per sons and injuring more than 100.

title: For Con Edison Chess Players, It's Move They Must
description: A Consolidated Edison util ity cart serves as the playing surface for two workmen who have been locked in battle over the chessboard at lunchtime each day since the more celebrated confronta tion between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky began in Iceland.

title: 0.E.O.RESCINDS EUROPETOUR FUND
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 11  The Office of Economic Opportunity has asked the De partment of Justice to investi gate a tour of Europe and Afri ca taken this summer by 67 poverty level high school students from Monmouth County.

title: KENTUCKY FILLY SOLD FOR $110,000
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 (AP)A chestnut filly by Buckpasser from Glad Rags II by High Hat, bred in Ken tucky and consigned by the Hickory Tree Farm of Upper vine, Va. sold for $110,000 to day at the Saratoga yearling sales.

title: Trade Pact With Soviet Seen by End of Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  Peter G. Peterson, Secretary of Commerce, who returned from talks in Moscow 10 days ago without the SovietAmerican trade agreement the President wants, said today he is confi dent the pact will be achieved by the end of the year.

title: WILLIAM C. LEUTHNER
description: William C. Leuthner, a field director for the city Department of Social Services, died yester day of cancer in Deepdale Hos pital, Douglaston, Queens. He was 59 years old and lived at 160 Gerard Avenue, New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Les Petits Chanteurs Heard In a Concert at St. Patrick's
description: Les Petits Chanteurs de Chaillot, a choir of boys and men from the Jesuit school of St. Louis de Gonzague in Paris, ended a fourweek concert tour of Canada and New York State Thursday night with an appearance at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Official Joins Nixon Council
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) President Nixon signed an order today adding Donald E. Johnson, the administrator of Veterans Affairs, to the White House Domestic Council. The action increases to 16 the mem bership of the council, which coordinates and oversees the Administration's domestic poli cies.

title: Kerry Blue Terrier Selected Best at Mohawk Valley Show
ROVERN PURSUES PARTY UNITY HERE
description: Senator George McGovern, in pursuit of party harmony, introduced former Mayor Rob ert F. Wagner here yesterday as the man who will attempt to unite the party behind his Presidential candidacy in New York State.

title: Music: A Tanglewood Replacement
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 11 Faced with a difficult new score, what does an orchestra do if it discovers as concert time nears that the players do not know the piece well enough to satisfy the com poser or the conductor? Tan glewood provided two differ ent answers to that one during the Festival of Con temporary Music that closed here last night.

title: A FamilyOwned Winery Still Thrives After 77 Years
description: SONOMA, Calif.To hear August Sebastiani tell it, half the visitors to this winery are investment brokers.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Restaurant advertising; which for many years was keyed to the twin considera tions of food and ambiance, has added a third element recently. And this element pricehas helped to change the nature of much of what is seen and heard about out ofthehome dining these days.

title: Son for the Ginzburgs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 A son was born to Mr. And Mrs. Vittorio Ginzburg on July 12 in Doctors Hospital here. Mrs. Ginzburg is the former Miss Elaine Duber stein of Cleveland.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 12Lu theran clergymen have tradi tionally restricted the sacra ments of their churches to Lutherans.

description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N. J., Aug, 12James R. McNitt of the Shrewsbury River Yacht Club took first place in the At lantic Highlands' predictedlog contest in his 46foot Jikarto I with 1.1710 percentage of error.

title: Professionals Sought in Thefts Of Church Art in New Mexico
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 12 Professional art thieves are sus pected in a series of robberies over the last two years in which centuriesold religious objects have been taken from churches and chapels in northern New Mexico.

description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 12  A few hours after the New York Yacht Club cruise ended here today, the club's secretary fired off a telegram to Queen Elizabeth of England.

title: The World
description: BELFASTWilliam Whitelaw, the British administrator of Northern Ire land, was in a fever of activity last week. There were three meetings with the Social Democratic and Labor par ty, which is tied to the Roman. Cath olic minority. There were codferen ces with Protestants, a oneday trip to London to report to Prime Minister Edward Heath, a return flight to Bel fast to report to the Catholics on the London session.

title: Hunting for Land: The Vacation Trip To End All Vacation Trips
description: WOODSMEN will tell you that you're lost without a compass, the safest thing to do is find a brook or a river and follow It downstream to civilization. If, on the other hand, you want to get away from civilization, just turn the advice around and follow a river upstream to the Wilderness of your choice.

title: Solar Salute Triumphs
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 12 (UPI)Solar Salute raced to a stakes record today when he captured the $26,800 La Jolla Mile for 3yearolds at Del Mar by a little more than a length.

title: Bank Run By Blacks In Nassau Lists Gains
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.  The Vanguard National Bank, a blackcontrolled bank that opened for business last May, has reported increases in both its assets and customers.John L. Bates, the presi dent of the bank, disclosed that, as of Aug. 1, the bank's assets were $7.5million, an increase of $1.5million since June 30.

title: Hunter Guides Packers to 14 13Victory Over Dolphins Before 75,372 in Miami
description: MIAMI, Aug. 12 (AP)Scott Hunter, showing thirddown artistry, hit Dave Davis on touchdown passes of 79 and 10 yards tonight and the Green Bay Packers withstood a Miami flurry to edge the Dolphins 1413 in a preseason National Football League game.

title: PEACE CORPS AIDE CLEARED IN COURT
description: A 29yearold teacher has won a court decision against the Peace Corps for dismissing him because he smoked one marijuana cigarette at a party while on vacation.

title: BRAVES CHECK REDS BEHIND REED, 7 TO 2
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (AP) Earl Williams and Ralph Garr hit homers in support of Ron Reed's threehit pitching to night as the Atlanta Braves beat the Cincinnati Reds, 72.

title: New Hawaiian Economy Causes Minority Unrest
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 3  Oblivious to the glory of life around him, Levi Kaupu's ears were deaf to the sea bird cries above the whisper of the waves on the lava beach and the snuffling of pigs In the pen across the road. Nor could he see the stunning colors of the tropical sunset.

title: Ellen M. Gingras Married in Suburb
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 12In St. Theresa's Ro man Catholic Church here at noon today, Miss Ellen Mary Gingras, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Campbell Gin gras of Ossining, was married to James Addison Barkhuff 2d, son of Mrs. Christina Barkhuff of Springfield, Mass., and Dr. Raymond Barkhuff of Hampden, Mass. The Rev. John J. Welch, cousin of the bride, performed the cere mony at a nuptial mass.

title: Sarah Gibbs Hudson Is Married in Garden of Fort
description: FORT TICONDEROGA, N. Y., Aug. 12The mar riage of Miss Sarah Gibbs Hudson and John William Krueger took place here this afternoon in the historic gar den that was the bride's childhood playground.

title: Dutch Sailor Triumphs
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (Cana dian Press)Jean Eric Volle bregt of the Netherlands won the 1972 world 470 Class sail ing championship today as Dutch sailors captured the top three spots in the final race. Vollebregt finished with a first, second, two fourths and sixth.
