title: EAGLES DEFEAT PATRIOTS, 2920
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 (AP)John Reaves, in his first pro starting assignment, direc ted three touchdowns in the second half tonight as the Phila delphia Eagles beat the New England Patriots, 2920.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  We shook 'em up.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BELGRADE, YugoslaviaThe Med iterranean balance of power has been altered by Egypt's eviction of Soviet forces, thus producing both positive and negative reflections here. In the positive and longrange sense, Yugo slavia's independent position is strengthened by the removal of po tential Russian naval pressure that could coincide with military pressure in a crisis. But in a negative and shortrange sense the situation could conceivably become more dangerous.

title: Foresters Slate Meeting
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (UPI)A national conference of foresters and environmentalists will be held in New Orleans Oct. 2226 to devise plans for a planting of more than 60 billion trees throughout the country. The Southern Forest Institute here said that the reforestation proj ect would cover more than 75 million acres of urban and rural lands. The American For estry Association is the organ izer of the conference.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Aug. 12 Richard A. Pearl, a stock broker here, knew he was getting a sixlane superhigh way for a neighbor when he bought a house on Chris topher Street here five years ago. When the previous owner had put the house up for sale the controversial path of route of I684 was finally confirmed.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: A surprisingly strong rally on Friday turned a dor mant stock market into a dynamic one, without the benefit of any specific news developments.

title: The Day Houk Laid It on Line
description: To the New York Yankees, the turning point came on the day when Ralph Houk closed the clubhouse door, denied he was a lameduck manager and told the players that the Co lumbia Broadcasting System would have to fire me be fore he would leave.

title: State Has 13 on Olympic Team
description: PRINCETON  Although New Jersey has never been known as the home of cham pions, 13 residents of the state are among the world class athletes who have been chosen to compete at the Olympic Games in Munich, Germany, from Aug. 26 through Sept. 12.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Thank you for Mavis Gal lant's delightful Paris Letters! Reading her last one (about the Surrealists), I could only think again What fools these immortals be . . . I do not necessarily mean immortal derisively.

title: Ann Gambling, Chris P. Janelli Married on L. I.
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 12 Miss Ann Bradley Gambling was married this evening to Chris Pettengill Janelli, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald E. Janelli of Old Brookville. The cere mony was performed in the Congregational Church of Manhasset by the Rev. How ard M. Lowell, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church of Lattingtown. A reception fol lowed at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John A. Gambling in Plan dome. Mr. Gambling is a radio broadcaster with station WOR in New York.

title: Sparkalark, $9, Wins in Jersey
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 12 Bertram R. Firestone took a liking to the sprightly filly, Sparkalark, last winter and purchased her for more than $30,000 from the British Blood Stock Agency.

title: PANTHERS DEMUR AT CHICAGO TRIAL
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12  The reluctance of several Black Panthers to testify this week slowed the trial of Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County State's Attorney, and 13 other persons on charges that they conspired to obstruct justice following a raid by the state's attorney's policemen on a West Side Panther apartment here Dec. 4, 1969.

title: John H. Mariano Is Dead at 81; Lawyer Wrote Marital Advice
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 12 John H. Mariano, a retired New York attorney and an author, died Friday in Memorial Hospital. He was 81 years old.

description: To the Editor:

title: Zumwalt Believes Soviet Is Building Its First Carrier
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., Chief of Naval Operations, has told Congress that he believes the Soviet Union is building its first aircraft carrier.

title: Sandra Lea Fates Bride in Montclair

This was his New Economic Policy, an aboutface from the policies his Administra tion had pursued through its first two and a half years.

title: Last G.I. Combat Troops Leave Quietly
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12In Danang this morn ing there were no flourishes, not even a parade, as the Third Battalion of the 21st Infantry and other components of what had been Task Force Gimlet said goodby to the war. Maj. Gen. H. H. Cooksey said a few words, pinned on some ribbons and then, for all practical pur poses, the last American ground troops were gone.

Small young peas or limas have more delicate flavor than big old seeds that pack the pods. There are varieties, too, that never do get very big: the French petit pois and Thaxter Baby Limas.

Rhonda Constable, a slight, darkhaired vocational school graduate who enlisted for a year, said Tues day that she was really proud to be one of the first.

I was a guest conductor with the London Symphony. I recorded for Eng lish Decca with Gary Graffman and Julius Katchen. I made the circuit of German orchestras. Then there was crisis at NBC. title: Can man improve . . .
description: The current scare about the dwindling natural landscape seems to be having constructive repercussions. Never has the public been more aware of the fragility of our natural landscape and that awareness has become a concern that is having an impact. Landscape architects and their clients are coming to realize that nothing can compete with the beauty of untouched nature. And more and more landscape design is involved with capturing, or recapturing, the look and the texture of the scenic beauty of the forest glen, the open meadow or the craggy wind swept sand dune. Beside the new ap preciation of unspoiled land, there are other reasons for the growing popu larity of the natural look. Everyone wants a beautiful setting for his home; he is also appalled at the cost in money and time of keeping up the grounds. Natural landscaping cuts down on much of the work. And there's another benefit: Settings pat terned after nature usually improve with the passage of time when nature has added her own brushstrokes to the beginning that man has provided. Much of today's landscaping simply helps nature alongfor instance, planting ground covers and plants that will thrive in the particular con ditions of soil, climate and humidity. And this is not only true of the for tunate few who can afford profes sional landscaping. Much of today's resistance to the ubiquitous housing developments, is a reaction to the stark, unrelieved quality of the final productrow after row of tickytack houses withsometimesa few ever green shrubs to mask the foundations. If the houses were unobtrusively land scaped into the trees or obscured by lush plantings, the developments would appear much less like scars on the landscape. Landscaping can cover a multitude of man's sins and soften many an architect's wellintentioned mistake. We hardly need more talent from architects in building good houses, but what is desperately needed is the integration of these houses into their settings. Landscap ing holds the answer to repairing some of the damage of overdevelopment and restoring the plenet's greenery.

title: New York
description: Two architects who had never met were invited some months ago to the office of City Investigation Commis sioner Robert K. Ruskin for a frank discussion of bribery in New York's building industry. Mr. Ruskin asked them how often they had to make payoffs to inspectors. The older arch itect thought for a moment, then said: Well, there was one fellow I didn't have to pay offin Brooklyn.

But looking back now, it turned out to be one of the high points of my own education and of my academic life.

title: Her heart belongs to Camus
description: Both were trained in philosophy; both, from a very early age, had literary ambitions. Chance brought them together as friends and made them comrades in the same struggle. They had the same ethical passion and seemed to belong to the same literary school. A celebrated feud momentarily divided them; death brought them together again and drove the survivor to cry out that. he had never stopped thinking of his friend. Facing the problems of the day, Sartre has continually asked himself what would Camus have said and how would he have acted. In the end, however, their works are utterly dissimilar; and with the passage of time their dissimilarities increased.

title: Shelter IslandLine Seeks a Fare Rise
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I. The Indians first called it Manhansett aha quash aw a nuch (island sheltered by is ??ands). There was no ferry boat then, as now, but one could always thumb a ride in the next dugout canoe to get to either shore of east ern Long Island.

title: Fair sex for the fair sex
description: My favorite introduction to any nonfiction book I've read this year (or maybe ever) is in Gay Gaer Luce's Body Time: The author tells the reader that if some part of the book bores him he should feel free to skip it. This suggestion would be particularly useful in the introduc tions to three of the above four books. It is very embarrassing for reader to fall asleep several times while reading a sex book. It's also a pity, when there are some good things in the book he should have stayed awake for.

title: Recordings

His nine symphonies have been or are being issued regularly by two companies, RCA, (conducted by Andrd Previn) and Angel (conducted by Sir Adrian Boult).

Sharomar was 13A lengths in front of Majestic Riha, a 301 shot that finished third. Hick ory Gray ran one mile in 1:40 3/5 and paid $3.20, $3 and $2.60 for $2 across the board.

title: Atomic Blast From Brooklyn
description: Now that she has con quered her spring and early summer problems, Cheryl Toussaint is ready to ex plode like a rocket on the track in Munich.

title: Photography
description: PHOTOGRAPHIC prints, though generally less expensive than works in most other visual media, have tended espe cially in the past few years to be over  priced. Twenty five dollars has come to be rock bottom, with the'median somewhere between $40 and $75 even for unestablished photographers. While it is true that there is no way to determine the exact financial value of a piece of creative work, that truth has two edges, and there are precious few photographers whose prices err on the side of hu mility. The audience for pho tography has grown tremen dously over the past five years, but the purchase of work by living photogra phers, particularly young ones, is still infrequent; this suggests, as a determining factor, either an unusually stingy audience or vastly in flated print prices.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE Goodyear blimp America sails through the air with the regal poise of a queen sweeping into her throne room, and her stately passage overhead stirs the thought that maybe the revival of balloon travel can restore genteel grace to the bumpy business of aerial transportation. When this thought struck, the America was hung on a mast at Atlantic City where she was taking the public and espe cially friends of Goodyear tire dealers on Sightseeing hops, and at night flash ing her advertising sign to the populace below. She was to fly thence back to her base at the Flushing, L. I., Airport, thus converting the thought into a test flight.

title: New & Novel
description: Curious, that the things one best remembers in life are its disasters. A. E. Hotchner who subtitles this novel a mem oir, reminisces with paradox ical joy of boyhood in the dreadful year of 1933. The prospects for 12yearold Aaron could hardly be lousier. Trapped in a St. Louis hotel from which they teeter on the brink of eviction, Aaron and his parents can feel the hot breath of the apocalyptic horsemen. Father is a permanently unemployed salesman; mother is suffering from TB. The family subsists on sporadic doortodoor sell ing and occasional manna like the sale of a gold filling; to a dentist.

title: Dr. Blake Faults U.S. on Dike Reply
description: UTRECHT, The Netherlands, Aug. 12The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, general secre tary of the World Council of Churches, said today that the White House's reaction to his recent letter to President Nixon denouncing the alleged United States bombings of the dikes in North Vietnam was unsatis factory.

title: Indian Life of 7,000 Years Ago Is Traced
description: LIVINGSTON  Archeol ogists here believe they have unearthed the remains of a 7,000yearold Indian culture. Preliminary tests done on spearheads and scraping tools found on East Orange Watershed Property indicate the presence of a hunting and gathering society that lived in New Jersey long before the arrival of the LenniLenapes, the tribe com monly associated with this area.

title: Leslie Learned, Lois B. Keating, Teacher, Marry
description: WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., Aug. 12Miss Lois Blanche Keating, a former teacher at the Buckley Coun try Day School in Roslyn, was married here at noon to day to Leslie Stuart Learned, a vice president of the Mu tual Broadcasting Systems and a member of their board of directors.

title: NIXON ALLOWS H.U.D. TO FILL 730 POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 The Department of Housing and Urban Development has been granted permission by Presi dent Nikon to fill 730 job po sitions to carry out housing programs, according to sources close to George Romney, the Secretary of Housing, and Ur ban Development.

title: Blimey !
description: The titles of books about London, as Donald Goddard reminds us, fill three whole volumes of the British Museum Library catalogue. This means, as with Napoleon and Shakes peare, not exhaustion of the subject but inexhaustibility, and we look for ward to three more volumes being filled. The trouble is in the titles themselves, which are not inexhaust ible, but Mr. Goddard's Blimey! (a Cockney euphemistic contraction of May God blind me) suggests whole new onomastic line: Cor Stone the Crows; Watch it Darlin; Wotcher Myte; Rahnd the Dilly, and so on, with London in the sub title. Mr. Goddard has a little glos sary, useful for visiting Americans who expect a fag to be a homo sexual, but it is not a Cockney glos sary. Although he is himself a Lon doner, he is not concerned with dis closing the sempiternally beating spadger heart  that would be gen uinely foreign territory. This is a Lon don for New Yorkers. Mr. Goddard himself lived in New York for 10

title: Most Canadian Immigrants Last Year Came From U.S.
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press)The United States in 1971 became for the first time the major source of immigrants to Canada.

description: NORTHVALE  It's a pleasure to work among friends such as these, John Calabro said, with a gentle sweep of his hand, as the artistsculptor introduced his visitor to the companions he has gathered in the studio of his home here.

title: Two Meet Records Broken In State A.A.U. Track
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 13 Meet records were broken by wide margins in the hammer throw and javelin throw today at the New York State Ama teur Athletic Union track and field championships.

title: Diabetic Children Take Care of Themselves at Camp
description: STILLWATER At 7:30 A.M., 9yearold Robert Row ley of Bricktown marches into the infirmary with a urine speciman, drops an eye dropperful into a test tube and brings it to a desk where a doctor sits.

title: Miss Linda du Pont Donaldson And Austin Kunsman Jr. Marry
description: KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Aug, 12  Miss Linda du Pont Donaldson, youngest of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Don aldson's four daughters, was married here this afternoon to Austin Kenneth Kunsman Jr., son of Mr, and Mrs. Kuns man of Hellertown. The ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Advent was performed by the Rev. Thomas L. McClellan. A reception at Spring Lea Farm, the Donaldson home, fol lowed.

title: BEAME CRITICIZES PARKING BUREAU
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie accused the Parking Violations Bureau yesterday of laxity and inefficiency. Its poor perform ance in collecting parking fines, he said, will result in producing $22million less than the city had projected for the 197273 municipal budget.

title: It's a Barnum Bailey WorldWell, Almost.
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I. The smell of the face paint and the voices of the crowd disappeared like smoke into open air over the enormous, manyacred North Lawn at Old Westbury Gardens. It was the day of the minicircus, a benefit event and one of six such special attractions offered each summer on the 100acre estate of the late John S. Phipps.

title: The Anderson strategy: We hit youpow! Then you issue a denial, andbamiwe really let you have it
description: Few reporters ever go from writing news to being news, and certainly no reporter has made the passage more conspicuously than Jack Anderson 1972. As a result of two journalistic coupsthe publication of secret White House documents show ing the Nixon Administration's duplicity during the IndiaPakistan war and the publication of the Dita Beard memo, which suggested that, in return for $400,000 toward the cost of the Republican con vention, the Justice Department made a favorable outofcourt settlement with International Telephone & Telegraph Corp in an antitrust caseAnderson, whose byline appears under his syndicated Wash ington MerryGoRound column in 965 daily and weekly newspapers in the United States and abroad, has become a frontpage headline: Anderson Urges SecretData Curb, Anderson Accuses Kleindienst of Lying About I.T.T. Case, Anderson Wins Pul itzer Prize.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Jamestown: The Blunder That Started America
description: THE magnificent Williamsburg Restoration boasts 11 public buildings, numerous craft shops, guided tours, hotels, motels and an annual budget that exceeds $7mil lion. Ten miles and a hundred years away is Jamestown Island, turned into a satellite of Williamsburg by an acci dent of geography and decades of neg lect and tied with it into a gigantic myth extolling Colonial America, a myth that exalts out of all proportion the wisdom and achievements of the small band of original Virginia settlers.

title: $2,500 a Month Given To Husband as Alimony
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 12 (UPI)Mrs. James Ed ward O'Neil has agreed to dissolution of her 20year marriage on terms that will give her former husband ali mony of $2,500 a month as long as she lives.

Frederic C. Lawrence, retired Suffragan Bishop of the Diocese of Massachusetts.

title: Politics as Theater of Reality
description: What is it that. People who take up politics actually do? First of all, they talk. For surely if politics is an art, it is one of the performing arts, and not one of the creative ones; Plato noticed this when he compared the politician to the flute player.

description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 12Miss Judith A. Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Worthington Tucker of Chap paqua, was married here to night to Robert F. Schultz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Schultz of Annandale, Va. The Rev. Phil Porter per formed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12  Ann Kiyomura of San Mateo, Calif., showed allaround abil ity today in winning the 55th United States girls 18andunder grasscourt tennis champion ship with a 63, 62 victory over Marita Redondo of Na tional City, Calif., at Philadel phia Cricket Club.

description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 12 (UPI)  Boris Spassky went sightseeing today with his wife, Larissa.

description: The Health Services, Admin istration is exploring the possibility of expanding the testing for high blood pressure into the city's high schools.

description: The Liberal party gave its nominations for President and Vice President yesterday to Senator George McGovern and Sargent Shriver, the Demo cratic nominees.

title: The August Pond
description: MidAugust is a lazy time all around, but especially at the ponds and backwaters. The water itself is almost tepid and gives the place an ancient air, the feeling of that age when life itself came creeping up out of the wetness onto dry land for the first time. There is a steamy smell of ferment, of rotting vegetation, and the water is full of squirming life, mostly larval insects but also larval stages of various amphibians, delayed in their development by the late spring.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: Busing schoolchildren across racial boundaries is now a standard weapon in the desegregationists' meager ar senal. But for all the rhetoric it has in spired on both sides, busing does not challenge traditional patterns of neigh borhood segregation. In fact, as fair housing partisans have observed, by accepting such neighborhood divisions as fixed features on the social land scape, busing programs tend to ratify segregationist custom.

title: Barkum Is Willing To End Jet Holdout
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 12Jerome (Gee) Barkum, No. 1 draft choice of the New York Jets, agreed to terms by telephone today and will report to the Jet camp at Hofstra tomor row. The formal signing will take place in a day or two.

title: At the Special Olympics, All Kids Are Winners
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (AP)For many, their lives have been filled with defeat. This week there will be many moments of triumphmedals to be cherished for years.

description: CHATSWORTH  Any thing you see along the way you can eat. The huckleber ries are particularly good this time of year. There is no pollution here. No poison ivy. So enjoy yourselves.

description: A search began yesterday afternoon for a Manhattan travel agency official after he was accused of taking some $5,000 for airline reservations from Europebound travelers and then failing to provide their tickets.

title: A Hero on Heroin?
description: SOMETIMES a hard head makes a soft behind is a combi nation of a threat and a warning that many Black grandmothers, especial ly Southern ones, use to ad monish their mischievous grandchildren. Loosely trans lated, it means that if you are hardheaded and dis obedient, something bad will happen to you, usually a few wellplaced whacks from the grandmother making the statement.

description: I'd come to London to find myself, to try to find if I existed, says Edward Parkes, an advertising writer from Aberdeen. In the course of this novel, Parkes finds what there is to find of himself, which isn't very much. In fact, you might call him basically a nin compoop.

description: EAST ORANGEThe bank is a success, but the mar keting concept on which it was founded appears to have fizzled.

title: Report on Jobless Compares Chances Among Two Races
description: Unemployment among black high school graduates is nearly twice that. Of white graduates, and a white high school drop out has a better chance of get ting a job than a black youth with a diploma, the Federal De partment of Labor reported last week.

description: She is black. She lives in Harlem. She rides the subways. She has never been mugged. She loves New York City, and she gets paid to tell people why.

title: Art
description: ON a hot summer's day all Harlem moves out onto the sidewalks, and there's a lot to see if you zigzag from the corner of Fifth Avenue arid 125th Street over to Seventh Avenue, and hack and forth as far up as 140th and Lenox. There you can't miss an outdoor mural 14 feet high and 77 feet long the northernmost point of an artandlife tour that begins with a Romare Bearden show at the Studio Museum, located at our starting point, 2033 Fifth Avenue.

title: Daughter for the Kews

Mrs. Kew is the former Miss Lucinda Watson, daughter of Thomas J. Watson Jr., chair man of the ex ecutive com mittee of the International Business Machines Corpora tion, and Mrs. Watson of Greenwich, Conn. Her hus band is with the Arnold C. Gay Yacht Yard here, The child has been named Chris tina Eileen.

description: SEATTLE, Aug. 12  Terry Bradshaw was hot and Joe Namath was cold today as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the New York Jets, 223, before a crowd of 44,038 in the Univer sity of Washington Stadium.

title: The bonus and the onus

But they said that while the easing of tensions reduced the threat of nuclear war, its ef fects were geographically lim ited.

title: Bridge
description: The basic elements in bridge are intelligence and experience, just as the basic elements in life are heredi ty and environment. Clearly a player with great experience and very little intelligence will be ineffectual. But how about a player with great intel ligence but very little experience?

title: Religion
description: ROME  In order to preserve an atmosphere of reverence, entrance can not be granted to men dressed in shorts nor to women wearing a mini gown or a sleeveless dress . . . This commandment printed in five lan guages on two inconspicuous signs at the gate of St. Peter's has been the battle cry of a 28monthold strug gle to keep the tide of modern dis habille from swamping the major tem ple of Roman Catholicism.

description: HONG KONG, Aug. 12 ChineseSoviet trade has shown a big increase in the last three years and will reach a value of $290.4million this year, ac cording to a Chineselanguage broadcast from the Moscow ra dio, monitored here.

title: Words and ways
description: I have a grandson who, scorning all fiction, reads only documented facts. Later he lets them fly, like the arrows of a Cheyenne hunting party, upon his unsuspecting family at unguarded moments. Richard Er does must have had him in mind when he wrote The Sun Dance People for the book is loaded with facts.

title: Travel Notes: For the Literati
description: SO far It has been a good summer for the travelercumbibliophile. A famous old library overseas and a new bookstore at home are adding significantly to his enjoyment.

title: Criminals At Large
description: With Run Down, published earlier this year, Robert Gar rett came up with an original way of organizing a detective story, and he continues the formula in SPIRAL (Athene um, $4.95). The novel moves largely in flashes. There is a bit of actionthen the conti nuity stops, The reader ab sorbs some elapsed time, and the continuity darts off at a tangent. Eventually, everything is tied up.

title: JULE JANOVER
description: Jule Lyon Janover, a general insurance broker with offices in Brooklyn and Jersey City, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 9701 Shore Road, Brooklyn.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: HARDWICK, Mass.As a bald eagle soared overhead in the bright blue sky, Bill Ellsworth of Petersham, Mass., told me to cast to an underwater shoal that ex tended out from the end of a small, island. You'll get one there for sure, he said, but he was wrong.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Locomotive Spotting: To Recall it Is To Feel the Old Stir
description: IF you traveled on the railroads of England or Scot land in the late nineteenforties or early nineteen fifties, you would have seen groups of children, serious as sextons, perched on the banks of green cuttings, leaning over the walls that divided railroad property from the rest of the planet or, windblown and squinting, poking their heads in perilous vigil out of the window of a moving railroad car while waiting for a train to pass by on the other track. They were called spotters, they collected the numbers on loco motives, and for a few years I was one of them.

title: Music; Ambition? Success? Not for Newman
description: THE ultimate chichi garage. Anthony Newman chuckles, rais ing the door by remote control and maneuvering the car in. This is my first house, he says, some what in amazement and disbelief. We just bought it. I'm amazed, too. After talking to Newman during the long drive from New York, I hardly expected to find a maverick of his ilk housed in a typically modern nondescript white ranch. But this was only the first of a series of surprises in store for me.

title: Coins
description: THE Great Copper Rush of 1972 is under way and coin collectors from coast to coast are engaged in an exciting treasure hunt! It all started with the discovery of some doubledie cents among the millions of 1972 dated cop pers that have rolled off the production lines in the Philadelphia Mint. This event recalls the excitement made by the doubledie cents in 1955.

title: Town Fights Neighbor's Waste
description: BRICK TOWNSHIPDoes one municipality have an ob ligation to solve its neighbors' problems? Or, can it shut its door, restricting limited fa cilities for its own use?

title: Religion
description: As an evangelist, Marjoe Gortner, truth to tell, was strictly in the bush leagues.

title: Judith Milliken Fiancee Of Michael Hale Holden
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn, Aug. 12The engagement of Miss Judith Eaton Milliken to Michael Hale Holden has been announced by Mr and Mrs. Walter L. Milliken 2d, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip D. Holden and a greatgrandson of the late Henry Phipps, steel mag nate and business associate of Andrew Carnegie.

title: Peking Article Ties Soviet To AntiMao Plot by Lin
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 12 China is building up a case alleging Soviet involvement in a plot by the late Defense Min ister, Lin Piao, to assassinate Chairman Mao Tsetung that could place a new strain on relations between Peking and Moscow.

title: Guy Bolton: On With The Show
description: REMSENBURG, L. LGuy Bolton has lost count of just how many plays he has written. Somewhere, he believes, there is a complete list, but he is not about to go out of his way to unearth it.

title: HOUSE UNIT MAPS STRIPMINING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  A House committee is completing work on what would be the first national legislation govern ing strip mining, a bill that ap pears to be welcome to at least one leading coal organization.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONA Bangkok news paper last week called it a Thai variation on an American theme. The paper was referring to the Thai Gov ernment's decision to send a table tennis team to Peking later this month, along with a special adviser, Prasit Kanchanawat, known to his country men as the Henry Kissinger of Thai land.

title: The famous little sting
description: The witnesses included a chicken farmer, some students, a pipe fitter, an undertaker and a man who had been a brassiere salesman at the time of the trial of Lieut William Calley but was now a carpet installer. They were once more in the long file of exG.I.'s taking the stand to describe what had happened at Mylai. This time, the accused was Capt. Ernest Medina. It puzzled Mary McCarthy, the novelist and critic who has written this book about the pro ceedings, to see no traces whatever of the crime and its aftermath either in Medina, joking and whispering with counsel or in the men who testified.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Maryland Nine Wins
description: WINDSOR, Ontario, Aug. 12 (AP)Prince Georges County, Md., has earned a berth in the Babe Ruth junior baseball world series by defeating Sara toga County, N. Y., 7.2, today in a regional final.

title: Grambling Five in Tourney
description: Grambling College of Gram bling, La., and North Carolina A. and T. of Greensboro, N. C., have accepted invitations from the Eastern College Athletic Conference Basketball Tourna ment Committee to compete in the 21st annual E.C.A.C. Holi day Basketball Festival at Madison Square Garden Dec 26, 27, 28 and 30, expanding the field to 10 teams. The other eight teams in the field are South Carolina, Michigan, Tennessee, Boston College, Man hattan, Niagara, St. John's and Villanova.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Mayor Names ExecutivePay Panel

title: Christine Biddle Is Wed To Thomas G. Reeves
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 12Miss Christine Mortimer Biddle and Thomas George Reeves were married here this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Richard G. Blaine, mother of the bride. The Rev. Malcolm L. Foster of St. An drew's Episcopal Church per formed the ceremony.

title: Bobby Lobby, Growing At Tourney in Iceland
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 12A steady growth of the Bobbylobby is noticeable here among the chess tour ists who have come to watch the world championship match between the American challenger, Bobby Fischer, and the Soviet world cham pion, Boris Spassky.

title: Views of Review
description: TO THE EDITOR: The article by Iver Peterson in the July 30 edition of The Week in Review quotes Joseph Monserrat as accusing our public schools of doing a dis service to children of Puerto Rican extraction by trying to knock his language out of him. There is no question that students with special problems (and they are all students) need special help. But teaching them the lan guage of the country in which they live will not prevent them from progressing. Since when has it been a handicap to be bilingual?

title: Wandering Minister Records Life on Film
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I. A slender, agile man, he speaks softly and has a gen tle manner about him. He does not look like a backpack er, a global hitchhiker; yet, the chances are that the Rev. Leon V. Kofod has been in just about every city and hamlet in the world.

title: PAUL R. BURKHOLDER, DRUG DISCOVERER, 69
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 12 (AP)Dr. Paul R. Burkholder, an internationally known scien tist who discovered several antibiotics during his 48year career, died yesterday at Univer sity Hospital of leukemia, a disease that his discoveries helped fight. He was 69 years old.

title: AIR UNITS REPORT HEAVIEST ATTACK BY B52'S IN NORTH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12In the last 24 hours B52 bombers carried out what a spokesman described as prob ably their heaviest raids ever over North Vietnam.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Hamandbean suppers are doing well on Cape Cod this season as vacationers shop about for simple, inexpen sive fare and modest en tertainment. Increasing cost consciousness is reported by resort operators in other parts of the country, too.

title: DIETZ TRIUMPHS IN SCULLING DASH
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 12Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club, the United States Olympic singles sculling repre sentative, defeated Jim Butter field of Bermuda by one length in the elite singles quartermile dash today. It was Dietz's last competition before departing for Munich next week, but he had to share honors with mem bers of the Lynch family.

title: ALLSTON BOYER, 60, RESORTS PLANNER
description: Allston Boyer, conservation ist and developer of related resort facilities as a longtime associate of the Rockefeller family, died Friday night at Memorial SloanKettering Hos pital. He was 60 years old and lived at Wheatley Road, Brook ville, LI., and at 532 East 86th Street here.

title: Jeweler Accused of Pouring Acid on Wife and Daughter
description: Detectives arrested a 30year old jeweler early yesterday aft er he allegedly became enraged in his Lower East Side home and poured a gallon of acid on his wife and their 16monthold daughter.

title: Desjardins Retains Title In A.A.U. Senior Diving
description: PLANDOME, L. I., Aug. 12 For the third straight year, Peter Desjardins captured the onemeter and threemeter Met ropolitan Amateur Athletic Un ion senior diving championships today.

title: INFLUENZA TESTS. HINT BETTER DRUG
description: A new laboratory technique that may ultimately lead to the development of live vaccines capable of better controlling in fluenza and other respiratory diseases has been discovered by Government scientists.

title: Behind The Glass
description: In this quasidocumentary, Robert Merle takes the lid off a now familiar can of worms labeled Student Unrest and makes a number of intriguing probes. The time is March 22, 1968, the place is Nanterre Uni versity in northcentral France  and the recipe for riot has since become standard.

title: Times Sq. Cleanup Called Bad for Neighboring Areas
description: The fallout from Times Square, target of a police drive, is driving prostitutes, derelicts and other undesirable characters into other neighbor hoods, a delegation of Manhat tan leaders told Deputy Mayor Edward A, Morrison Friday.

title: L.I. Officials Allege Bias In State Aid To the Cities
description: EAST HILLS, L. I.The concept of a village as a drowsy pastoral community and the thought of a city as teeming with people and torn by problems no longer hold true according to the New York Conference of Mayors.

title: Letters: Views on Adopted Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Girard College May Close As Enrollment Plummets
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12  Girard College, which opened in 1848 and gained national at tention last decade as a walled in school for white boys in the middle of a black neighbor hood, may have to close unless it can reverse a sharp decline in enrollment.

title: Raiders to Open W .H . A . Slate Against Hull' s Club Here Oct.
description: The New York Raiders an nounced yesterday their 39 game home schedule for the 197273 season. The World Hockey Association entry will open at home on Thursday, Oct. 12, against the Winnipeg Jets, led by its playercoach, Bobby Hull. There are 21 week end games included in their home slate at Madison Square Garden.

title: Coke, That Old Symbol of Imperialism, And Pepsi, Too, Now on Sale in Poland
description: WARSAW, Aug. 12 Three men sit in the Fry kas bar in Warsaw, their stomachs bulging and their faces drawn. Empty Coca Cola bottles litter the table.

title: Government Accused of Speech Curb
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and the New York Civil Liberties Union accused the Federal Government yesterday of trying to use the Federal Election Act of 1971 to curb free speech.

title: Panthers in Algiers Meet With Newsmen As Guard Is Lifted
description: ALGIERS, Aug. 12 (Reuters) The Black Panthers in Algiers were back in contact with re porters today after nearly 48 hours under police guard in their headquarters here.

title: There's a Small Hotel...And I, George Brendan, Run It
description: AROUND 1905 a novelist and clergy man named Baring Gould came to stay at the Falcon Hotel in Bude, Cornwall. It was an unpre tentious English inn, established in 1798, headquarters of the fourhorse coaches that connected Bude to other coastal resorts like Clovelly, Bideford, Bos castle and Tintagel.

title: LAW PANEL BACKS TENANTS RIGHTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (AP)A tough new law to pro tect tenants from retaliatory evictions and make landlords responsible for safe and clean living conditions has the tenta tive endorsement of legal drafts men from across the country.

title: QUIET PLEASE WINS TWO SHOW TITLES
description: BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 12 Mrs. Harry Hemphill's Quiet Please, who never made it on the race track, appears to have found his niche in the show ring. The 5yearold chestnut gelding, on the circuit only two years, has developed into the most feared mount in the work inghunter competition.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills Edge Saints, 2421
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 12 (AP)John Leypoldt kicked field goal with five seconds left tonight as the Buffalo Bills downed the New Orleans Saints, 2421.

title: Mrs. Chary Lytel Wed To James P. Griffin
description: REMSENBURG, LI., Aug. 12Mrs. Chary Ann Davis Lytel, widow of Gerald Lytel and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd O. Davis, was married here this afternoon to James L. Griffin of East Patchogue.

title: Volunteers Seek to Cut Crime
description: Car 576 moved slowly through the winding, tree lined streets of Jamaica Es tates: The driver, Stan Dul chin, peered into the shadows of the twilight along the left side of the quiet block. Torn Wriggins, his companion, looked to his right, past the tall, thick shrubbery flank ing the massive homes. Only the cackle of the portable twoway radio in the vehicle disturbed the silence of the summer evening.

title: Television
description: SUSAN, on As the World Turns, has just had a baby. She is not the only one, Turning the day time dial, we see that Chris, on Where the Heart Is, has just had a baby, too. Within the past year, babies have also been born to Janet on Search for Tomorrow, Meredith on One Life to Live, Edie on All My Children, Angel on Love Is a ManySplendored Thing, Diana on General Hospital, Linda on Days of Our Lives, Mary on Where the Heart Is, Carolee on The Doctors . . . and Another World's Pat Randolph has twins.

title: In Defense Of McGovern
description: The McGovern candidacy has evoked more sound and fury from vociferous ele ments or the business com munity than that of any any nominee since Franklin D. Roosevelt. Yet the fact is that Senator George McGovern's views are closely allied with the longrun interests of an enlightened business commu nity and should command its support.

title: Chaperone's Job Is Fun, Games
description: LONDON (AP)I suppose some of the girls think of me as an old dragon, said Marca Hartman with a broad grin. But I've looked after hundreds of them around the world and never lost one yet.

title: MARTIN, FOXWORTH WIN TITLE TENNIS
description: Billy Martin of Palo Verdes Estates, Calif., and Bruce Fox worth of St. Louis, used simi lar styles of smart, steady ten nis yesterday to win the sin gles titles of the fifth annual Columbia tennis championships for juniors and boys at Baker Field.

title: Look what's back in town!
description: Guess what's around again? The chemise. Remember the late fifties when this revolutionary shape jolted the fashion world and was nicknamed the bag and the sack? Well, relax. The seventies' styles are gentle. The chemise now ranges from figureskim ming shifts to soft tentlike smocks. The loosening up of the silhouette is a welcome relief to many women after years of bodyclinging clothes. Not only can they breathe again (there's nothing more comfortable than waistless dress) but they can breathe in style. Also, it's an elegant vote toward the return of the long lost dress. Just look at that evening dress on the opposite pagesoft, flowing and waistless in parchment color rayon jersey. Smocklike, yet ethereal, it has an elasticized neckline that can be worn on or off the shoulders. Bou tique Donald Brooks. It's $165 on the fourth floor at Bonwit Teller. The gray flannel chemise shirtwaist, shown at the left below, is another example of the new chemise. It's ideal for the first fall days. Cut like a safari shirt, it's by Chuck Howard and it's $95 in Young Dimensions at Saks Fifth Ave nue. (They'll have it at the end of August.) Her stockings are by Dior. Next to it is a shirtwaist with an easy skirt in polyester and wool beige and gray check. Designed by John Kloss for 499, it's $75 at Young Dimensions, Saks Fifth Avenue (they'll have it the end of the month). Stockings, Hanes; shoes, Fiorentina. In the photograph at the right, a butterysoft cashmere chemise, left, falls softly from gathered yoke. Long  fringed scarf matches. By Oscar de la Renta. It's $260 at Lord & Taylor (available late this month). The neat shirtwaist in brown and beige men's wear glen plaid skips the waist completely. The skirt is sideslit like a shirt. By Chuck Howard, $110, it is at Beekman Place, on the third floor at Bloomingdale's. Her cloche is by Adolfo. One of the most sophisticated chemises is the tent. This camel  colored version in cashmere and Dacron falls soft and loose from very narrow shoulders and is worn over a beige cashmere turtle neck sweater. By Halston Originals, the dress, $160; the sweater, $80. They will be on the second floor at Berg dorf Goodman in September. Her camel, offtheface jersey cloche is by Don Anderson. Those smashing knee high boots are by Herbert Levine.

title: Constance Miller Wed
description: WESTWOOD, Mass., Aug. 12  Miss Constance Ruth Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman C. Miller, and Stuart Edward Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney E. Robbins of Old Greenwich, Conn., were married here this afternoon in the First Parish of Westwood, United Church, by the Rev. Kenneth A. Boyle of Concord, N.H. The bride's father is a lawyer and a vice president and secretary of the Norfolk and Dedham Mutual Fire Insurance Com pany in Dedham. The bride groom's father is an execu tive in the engineering di vision of the American Tele phone and Telegraph Com pany in White Plains. The bridegroom is a transporta tion consultant with the Boston Transportation Plan ning Review, state agency

title: The case of the O.E.O. office
description: What Anderson has called his worst error before Eagleton occurred on Sept. 22, 1969, when he wrote that Donald Rumsfeld, then Director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, had used some of the money he had saved by cutting anti poverty programs to fit out his office with such luxuries as a bedroom and a private bathroom. No such refurbishing had taken place.

title: In the U. S., It's a Pastime, Too
description: Are there train spotters in the United States as well as in England? Yes, thoudsands of them, though they are usu ally called train watchers over here. What's more, according to David P. Morgan, editor of Trains magazine, the number of train watchers shows no signs of dwindling, despite the fact that this country's rail network is shrinking. In fact, says Morgan, one reason why watching remains popular is the feeling that, with the railroads dimin ishing and aging, they're rather camp. It's all part of the fashion for things nostalgic.

title: NELSON DENOUNCES USE OF A DEFOLIANT
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 12 Senator Gaylord Nelson charged yesterday that several hundred acres of hillside forest land in Grant County had been scarred by a defoliant that has been banned for military use in Vietnam.

title: FITTIPALDI WINS POLE IN AUSTRIA
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 12 Emerson Fittipaldi won the pole position for the Austrian Grand Prix after six hours of trials and 15 minutes of debat ing whether to accept it.

title: An unmolested classicist in China
description: After President Nixon visited Pe king last February, Chinese authori ties released a photograph of greater historical interest than any other taken in the week that changed the world. Only hours after reaching Peking on the 21st, the President, naturally without his retinue of Western reporters and photogra phers, had entered the former For bidden City for a brief conference at the real summit, that is, with Mao Tsetung himself, in the latter's secluded private quarters. In the Chinese photograph Mao and Nixon, with Chou Enlai and an interpreter, are seated in homey, linencovered armchairs.

title: Maya Dancer Picked as Best in Show Over 1,102 Dogs at Amsterdam Event
description: AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Aug. 12 Mrs. Mamie R. Gregory's Maltese, Ch. JoanneChen's Maya Dancer, made his second appearance in the East since Westminster a momentous one today when the elegant 6 pounder was named best of 1,103 dogs at the silver anniver sary show of the Southern Ad irondack Dog Club.

title: Cox Defeats Drysdale
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP) Britain's Mark Cox advanced to the finals of the Cleveland classic indoor tennis tourna ment today with a 63, 36, 76 triumph over Cliff Drysdale of South Africa.

title: InterAmerican Congress Stresses Aid for Indians
description: BRASILLA, Aug. 12Indians should be given the conditions needed to develop themselves, the delegates to an interAmer ican congress on Indian affairs decalred yesterday.

title: Cambodia's Soldiers Get Training in Magic
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 12 (AP)Capt. Mam Prom Mony is the officer in charge of magic for the Cambodian Army's 54th Infantry Brigade.

title: What Chance For McGovern?
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Although Senator McGovern is running far be hind President Nixon in nationwide opinion polls, his chances for success in November may be better than they now appear.

title: The World
description: KAMPALA, UgandaCrowds milled outside the passport office of the British High Commission in Uganda all last week. They were Asians, descendants of settlers from India and Pakistan, and their one desire was to get out of Uganda, be allowed entry into Britain and a chance at a new lifeeven if it meant destitution and starting from scratch.

title: DR. ARTHUR LUBELL
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 12 Dr. Arthur Lubell, a dentist who was a past president of the Norwalk Dental Society, died today at Memorial Hospi tal in New York City. He was 52 years old and lived here.

title: Cost of Angela Davis Trial To California: $1.25Million
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug, 12 (UPI)The Angela Davis trial Icost California's taxpayers $1.25million.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Jackie Oliver's runnerup placement with the UOP Shadow in last weekend's CanAm at MidOhio was not only his best finish ever in the CanadianAmerican Chal lenge Cup, but it also hap pened to be more than the feisty English bantam had hoped for. Jackie started the race deter mined just to finishthat was allbecause lie and his car owner, Don Nichols, were scheduled to meet the next day with their sponsor, Universal Oil Prod ucts, to review the CanAm program and discuss a pro posed Formula One effort for 1973. A good finish pleases a sponsor, and in racing hap piness is a satisfied sponsor.

title: Boxer Fatally Injured
description: SIBU, Malaysia, Aug. 12 (AP) A boxer died in a hospital to day after being knocked uncon scious in the 10th Sarawak amateur boxing championships yesterday. Bujang Mohamad Nor, 26 years old, died of a brain hemorrhage, a hospital spokesman said.

title: A Shoulder Separation Suffered by Staubach
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 (UPI)Roger Staubach, quar terback for the Dallas Cow boys and the National Foot ball League player of the year last season, suffered a shoulder separation tonight in the second quarter against the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Dance
description: WASHINGTON

title: SAIGON TORTURE IN JAILSREPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12Documents smuggled out of South Vietnamese pris ons and extensive interviews with former prisoners paint picture of widespread torture of people jailed by the Saigon Government since the North Vietnamese offensive started four and a half months ago.

title: Some Weeds in the Garden
description: Sports of The Times

title: SPIEZIO'S HOMER IN 11TH DECISIVE
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 12 (AP)Ed Spiezio hit a tworun homer in the 11th inning as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Oakland A's, 31, today and moved into first place in the American League West.

title: Malaysian State Giving Adult Citizens a Share of Timber Prof
description: KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia, Aug. 12 (AP)The government of Sabah has made every adult citizen of the Malaysian state a shareholder in a foun dation that promises to be come one of the biggest busi ness enterprises in South Asia.

title: Shecky Greene Captures $186,700 Futurity by Nine Lengths
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) Shecky Greene, a Floridabred colt named for the night club comedian, scored a ninelength victory today in the $186,700 ArlingtonWashington Futurity.

title: The Best Of Friends By Joy Fielding. 214 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $5.95.
description: On the rebound from a mis carriage, a divorce and an abortion, Carolyn Beacon finds herself in need of psychiatric counseling. In her dialogues with Dr. Lang, it turns out that she has a dirty mouth and an imaginary girl friend who has had similar experi ences, only she is everything that Carolyn isn't. My favorite shocker based on double iden tity is still Such Friends Are Dangerous,

title: Views of Review
description: To The Editor:

title: Architecture
description: THERE is a handsome new municipal swim ming pool in Bedford Stuyvesant called The People's Pool. Chalk up one more achievement for the BedStuy community.

title: The World
description: Over the years Communist countries have relegated officials in disgrace to the status of nonpersons. Last week the United Nations went a step fur ther: the noncountry.

title: Council Panels to Hear Key Officials This Week
description: City Council committees are scheduled to hold two open invitational hearings this week in the Council of fices in City Hall.

title: Man Beaten to Death in Kenya In Belief Kenyatta Was Periled
description: NAIROBI, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  A crowd fearing for the safety of Kenya's President, Jomo Kenyatta, beat to death a man who they thought was out to harm himbut, in fact, no attempt on the President's life was made, the police said today.

title: Califano Resigns as Counsel To Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)Joseph A. Califano Jr., saying that his job has placed an ever increasing burden on his family and law partners, has resigned as general coun sel for the Democratic National Committee.

title: New York
description: I can see it now, Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, said last week. I can see the year 2000 A.D. when New York State will be criss crossed by a thick web of highways and the Second Avenue subway will still not be completed.

title: From Caskets to Cable
description: Almost as naturally as the brown snowshoe rabbit, which turns white as soon as it begins to snow, the conglomerates of the Sixties have been transforming themselves into the Seven ties companies with direc tion.

title: Many Southern Democrats Plan To Back Nixon for Reelection
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 12 A large number of Southern Democrats, including seven former Governors, three big city Mayors and several dozen state legislators, have an nounced in recent days that they will support President Nixon for reelection.

title: CRIME FIGURE SEIZED ON U.S. GUN CHARGES
description: Federal Bureau of Investiga tion agents arrested Alphonse Persico, a reputed Mafia figure, at his horse farm in Saugerties, N. Y., yesterday on charges of unlawfully receiving firearms in interstate commerce.

title: New York
description: Only four and a half years ago the new $50million Madison Square Gar den opened. It was, in the words of the chairman of the board, Irving Mitchell Felt, a testament to private enterprise. Suddenly, the Garden and its topflight teams, the New York Knickerbockers and the New York Rangers, may become a very public enterprise. For the Garden is moaning that its taxes are too high and it may even move its teams to New Jersey, which is seeking a bigleague image for its new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadows.

title: Music: Rock at the Roosevelt Raceway
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 12 About half way through this afternoon's concert at the Festival of Hope, some one threw a Frisbee high above the crowd. It hovered there for a brief moment and then, uncharacteristically, fluttered straight down to the ground.

title: ABBATIELLO WINS HIS 2,000TH RACE
description: YONKERS, Aug. 12Carmine Abbatiello became the 14th Myer since 1939 to win 2,000 races when he steered the favored Hail to Bret to a half length triumph over Nancy Isle tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Brat Alors! U.S. Baying Less French Champagne
description: PARIS, Aug. 12 (AP)  France's champagne exports to the United States declined last year and producers are so concerned that they have engaged a United States re search company to explain the drop.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON Aug. 12A vital allparty conference next month on the future of North ern Ireland will be held in Eng land, William Whitelaw, Ul ster's administrator, announced today.

title: CHURCHES SCORED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Aug. 12A commission sponsored by the South African Council of Churches and the National Christian Institute has published a report highly critical of white Christians and this country's Englishlanguage churches.

title: Television
description: HUMAN beings denied TV can experience psychological withdrawal symptoms which can lead to moodiness, child spanking, wife beating, extramarital af fairs and, at home, a decreased interest in sex. After a yearlong experiment in which subjects were paid for abstain ing from the tube, psychologist Henner Ertel of the Society for Rational Psy chology in Munich, Germany, said that regular TV watchers are negatively in fluenced if one takes the set away. The problem is that of addiction.

title: Today's Campers Bring the Comforts of Home to the OutofDoors
description: FOREST CITY, Iowa, Aug. 9The great American out doors is overflowing these days and nights with vaca tioning campers, most of them smoothing it rather than roughing it.

title: Views of Review
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: GEORGES LEMAITRE OF STANFORD DEAD
description: STANFORD, Calif., Aug. 12 Dr. Georges E. Lemaitre, au thor and emeritus professor of Romance languages at Stan ford University, died Friday at the Stanford Medical Center. His age was 73.

title: Cahill's Son Weds lane McManimon
description: EWING TOWNSHIP, N. J., Aug. 12Miss Jane Elizabeth McManinton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McMani mon Jr., was married here this afternoon to William Thomas Cahill Jr., son of Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jer sey and Mrs. Cahill, of Princeton.

title: Mrs. Swanson's 81 Winsw omen's Golf ; Mrs. Sanford Is 2d
description: Mrs. William E. Swanson of Woodway won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one day Class A tournament at Whippoorwill C.C., Armonk, last Wednssday. Mrs. Swanson was a twostroke victor over a field of only 16 contestants with 40,4181. Second place went to Mrs. Harry Sanford, Whippoorwill, 45,3883, fol lowed by Mrs. Buddy Frank, Glen Hollow, with 41,4485.

title: ADAM POWELL'S SON DISMISSED BY WRVR
description: WRVR, an FM radio station owned by Riverside Church, has dismissed its assistant news director, Adam Clayton Powell 3d, on of the late Harlem Representative and minister.

title: Henry Moore On a Tuscan Hill And Vasarely In a Chateau
description: Two exhibitions of modern art in Europe are proving again that felicitous juxtaposition of the new and the old enhances both.

title: Wives Who Enjoy Being a Dependent but Respected Partner
description: WASHINGTON, D. C.  The Koran teaches that men are the protectors and maintainers of women. Islamic husbands are permitted as many as four wives at the same time, and wifebeating is authorized as a last resort when woman is guilty of disloyalty and ill conduct.

title: John Farago to Wed Miss Cramer
description: GLENCOE, Ill., Aug. 12 The engagement of Miss Sharon Ann Cramer to John Michael Farago has been an nounced by Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Cramer, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Ladislas Farago, author of the current best seller The Game of the Foxes, and Mrs. Farago of New York and New Milford, Conn.

title: BusTruck Collision Kills Man Upstate; 20 Persons Injured
description: A chartered bus carrying 44 persons collided with a pickup truck five miles east of Ma lone, N. Y., yesterday killing one passenger and injuring more than 20 others.

title: What Vonnegut Is and Isn't
description: Kurt Vonnegut Jr. is among the half dozen people I like best in the world. Since this includes men, wo men and children and I'm a family man it ought to suggest a degree of affection too strong for my opinion of his work to be taken seriously.

title: Fat City's Susie Oh, Oh, What a Girl!
description: SHE is barely 26 years old. She has a round cherubic face and a pic ture of Jesus pasted in her scrap book. She comes from New Canaan, Conn., one of the wealthiest suburbs in the world. Her very first theatrical role, in 1963, was as a teen age ingenue.

title: Music
description: EVEN the most casual shopper in the super markets of the arts these days must have noticed that we are in the midst of what the London Ob server, in a caption over a recent roundup of new novels, referred to as the Copulation Explosion. If Jane Austen were starting out now, her Sense and Sensi bility probably would hit the paperback racks entitled Sense and Sensuality, and Proust's Remembrance of Flings Past would come with a center foldout of the Baron Charlus. That explicitness does not necessarily enhance meaningfulness should be ob vious; in fact, the current tendency of novelists and filmmakers to try to pass off clichs as insights, simply be cause their characters utter them in bed, could be reason enough to justify naming ours the age of hardcore cornog raphy.

title: Federal Agency Reports No Corvair Safety Defect
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says it has sent letter to the owners of 196063 Corvairs saying that no safety defects involving in stability had been found in tests of the automobiles.

title: A FESTIVAL TAKES SOPRANO TO HEART
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12If you fancy great singers, and you haven't heard the name of Jessye Norman, don't worry. You will. Miss Norman is a 26yearold black American soprano, and, judging from her first Boston, Symphony appear ance last night at the Berkshire Festival, hers is one of the more important voices to come along in some time.

title: British Runner Sidelined
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP) Peter Stewart, British national recordholder in the 1,500 meter race, pulled out of the Olympics team today because of a back injury. Last month, the 25yearold Stewart set a British record of 3 minutes 38.2 seconds in the national championships.

title: Social Announcements
description: Weddings

title: Maurina Rose's Bridal
description: Miss Maurina Rose and Robert Winslow Meadows were married yesterday in the Park Avenue Methodist Church by the Rev. Philip A.C. Clarke, the rector. Mrs. Meadows is a daughter of Mrs. Ethel Rose of New York. Her husband is a son of Robert Winslow Meadows, also of New York, and the late Mrs. Alice Sullivan Meadows. Mrs. Meadows is a graduate of Hunter College and recieved a Bachelor of Arts degree from Columbia University. She is director of occupational therapy at Bronx Lebanon Hospital. Her husband attends Hunter Col lege and is associate director of aquatics at the Young Men's Christian Association here.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Nixon Administration, warning of a possible need for higher taxes, has sought to mobilize public opinion behind its re quest to Congress for a $250 billion statutory ceiling on Fed eral spending in the fiscal year that began July 1. Outlays now appear to be headed $4billion or $5billion higher.

title: Slaying of Candidate Baffles Police
description: Detectives remained baffled yesterday by the fatal shooting of Robert H. Newmark, candi date of the Republican and Conservative parties for the Assembly from the 69th Dis trict.

title: Olympic Village Starts to Look Like Home to Athletes
description: MUNICH, Germany, Aug. 12 (AP)  The summer Olympic Village is starting to look more like a city.

title: Son to Mrs. Berkowitz
description: A son was born Aug. 1 to Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey C. Berk owitz of Riverdale, the Bronx, at the Mount Sinai Hospital. The child has been named Gregg Michael. Mrs. Berko witz is the former Miss Elaine Potoker of New York. Mr. Berkowitz is assistant gene ral manager of Panasonic in New York.

title: SHOP TALK
description: NEWTONTired of side walksuperintending urban renewal, the boys went snakeskin hunting and found a cast that had been shed by a rattlesnake. This unlikely vignette is taken from true life, proof that city problems and rattle snakes can coexist in Sus sex County.

title: C is for coatswarm and woolly and particularly plaid. Or checked. All full of color. And snuggleup warmth.
POINT OF VIEW
description: The sound and fury of the present political season not withstanding, it is worth re membering that a Presiden tial election is a good time to focus public discussion on the more fundamental issues likely to confront the country in the months and years ahead. The merits of the Administration's econom ic program in general and the future of wage, price and profit controls, in par ticular, would benefit from that kind of serious analysis and debate.

title: The Formidable North Cascades Are Yielding to Visitors
description: FUR hunter Alexander Ross tramped through tough, unexplored coun try in the Pacific Northwest as a matter of course, but even he was impressed by the crusted, folded mountains in the region where North Cascades National Park now dangles from the Canadian border into central Washington. Impressed and awed. A more difficult route to travel never fell to man's lot, he wrote.

title: Nancy Lopez, 15, Captures U.S. Junior Golf Tourney
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Aug. 12 (AP)Nancy Lopez of Ros well, N. M., captured the last two holes to score a 1up vic tory over Catherine Morse of Rochester, N. Y., today in the final of the United States Golf Association's junior girls' tour nament.

title: Aussies Score 394 for 8 In Cricket Test at London
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) Australia pushed its firstin nings lead over England past the 100 mark despite fine bowl ing by Derek Underwood on the third day of the fifth and final cricket test.

title: Science
description: In 1859, an English astronomer, Richard C. Carrington, was charting sunspots which in that year were numerous. The solar image in his telescope was filtered to reduce its blinding brightness, but suddenly in one sunspot group two brilliant spots of light appeared.

title: ROSS NICHOLS

title: WASHINGTON

They will never look more beautiful than they do on this rich tart glazed with raspberry jam. Underneath is a custard flavored with vanilla and powdered macaroons. The crust is a fragile disk flavored with grated orange peel.

An amendment calling for ter mination of all hostilities and with drawal of all American forces from Indochina by Oct. 1, subject to release of American prisoners of war and limited ceasefire, was voted clown by the House, 228 to 178.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 (UPI)The former United States Attorney Gen eral, Ramsey Clark, reportedly said in Hanoi today that the health of American prisoners of war in North Vietnam whom he had visited was better than mine, and I am a healthy man.

title: Behind The Glass

title: Indian State Ends Its Ban Oh the Purchase of Liquor
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 12 (Reu ters)  India's Maharashtra state has announCed that any one over 21 years old can now have a permit to buy liquor.

title: The Last Word
description: In the July 30 Book Review David Kalstone said of Jay Wright: His book [The Homecoming Singer] is partly in formed by a young black's sense of ex clusion. He stands apart from the white society of his childhood . . . but he also, as a child, stood apart from the mysteries of his own blackness. Wright's poetry, then, was cast in a familiar literary mold the alienated artist struggling for rapprochement with his past and with his society. That traditional posture has a further complication for the black artist, for his exclusion from American society is real, not psychological, and, as yet, un resolved. With the increased publication of young black poets, however, one as pect of that dual alienation is being eliminated. Many black poets are accept ing their separation from American soci ety a priori, consequently, their work is focused on reappraising their ethnic ex perience and attempting to shape a positive black consciousness.

title: Eaton of the Giants Is Unlikely to Play In Game With Jets
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 12The Jets will be favored to beat the Giants when these city rivals meet for the fifth time (fourth pre season match) next Sunday at New Haven, even if the Giants get healthy by then. A series of injuries has kept many of Alex Webster's players from getting in some badly needed practice. Start ing with Randy Johnson's bruised ribs and concluding with Scott Eaton's concus sion and double vision, the Giants have minor to serious problems.

title: Town Evacuated in Fire
description: SHASTA, Calif., (AP)A brush and timber fire that had forced the evacuation of 1,500 persons from this historic min ing town was mostly contained today after blackening some 1,200 acres, the authorities said. Five fire fighters were injured yesterday as they battled the blaze, which seared the edge of Shasta, a state historical monu ment.

title: Recordings
description: YOU don't have to go to any impossible lengths and say that oral expression is re placing the kind that is writ ten down on a page. The very fact that you are read ing this and not listening to it is proof in itself. But it is true enough that the sound of the human voice is per meating more writing today than, say, 10 or 15 years ago, and even the most top heavy writers of English find it hard not to try and imitate the spoken word in their work.

title: News of Boating
description: Block Island has always held a special place in the hearts of Storm Trysail Club skippers, but only in odd years, it seems. Block Island Race Week attracts a huge number of contestants every other year, but the races to Block Island and back in the even years have drawn light Race East and Governor's Race West), 31 boats started. In 1970, the number dropped to 23, and this year, in the 100mile race that will begin Wednesday from Larchmont Yacht Club, only 23 boats are entered, according to Mrs. Betty Quimby, the Storm Trysail secretary. ly. When the evenyear races to and from the is land began in 1968 (they are called Governor's Race East and Governor's Race West), 31 boats started. In 1970, the number dropped to 23, and this year, in the 100mile race that will begin Wednesday from Larchmont Yacht Club, only 23 boats are entered, according to Mrs. Betty Quimby, the Storm Trysail secretary.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)  Anatoli Firsov, considered the best hockey player in the So viet Union during the last 20 years, is coming out of retire ment to play for the Soviet Team in its series against Team Canada.

title: The World
description: SAIGONThe American company returned last Thursday from patrol. It had been an uneventful fourday affair; two of the men were wounded by booby traps. It was also the last ground combat mission to be per formed by the Americans in South Vietnam. The next day the company's parent outfit, the Third Battalion of the 21st Infantrythe last American groundcombat unit in Vietnam was deactivated at Danang, the air base where the first American ground combat unit landed in Vietnam March 8, 1965. Most of the men of the Third Battalion are going home.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This is the month to think about lawns: seeding new ones, repairing old ones and later on, one more fertilizer application.... Keep after aphids on roses; lacebugs on broadleaved evergreens. . . . Plant beans, beets, lettuce and spinach for September eating. . . . Plant new iris or divide established beds. . . . Keep after powdery mil dew with a good fungicide.

title: A DRUGLINKED FIRE KILLS MAN IN HARLEM
description: An elderly occupant of a Har lem tenement building died yes terday evening, apparently while fighting a blaze that was intentionally set in an adjoining apartment by men who com plained they had gotten impure narcotics there, Fire Depart ment officials reported.

title: The other July convention
description: Ah, the middle of July, and in romantic, en chantic Atlantic City, down on the old New Jersey shore, 16,346 Elks and their wives have herded together from all over the United States to hold their national convention. Meanwhile, in Miami Beach, some 1,100 miles to the south, the Demo cratic party is in the midst of its national conven tion. But the Elks seem not to have the slightest interest in the goings on in Miami Beach. In fact, while just about everyone else in the country has his eye on Lawrence O'Brien and Gary Hart & Company, the Elks are spending the hot Atlantic City evenings either strolling on the Boardwalk, riding the Ferris wheel on the Million Dollar Pier, making the scene at an endless round of cocktail parties, or whooping it up in the Club Le Bistro, where they are entertained by Sonny Richard and His Panic Buttons, plus the Big Bear Revue.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: As one who has visited the moun tains of western North Carolina for many years, I must take sharp issue with the blanket description of the residents there in the Moonshine Country article (Travel section, July 9). Here is general ization at its worst. Fergus tordewich has taicen five examples (two of them at least guilty of breaking Federal laws, himself an accessory by purchasing il licit liquor) and labeling all the moun tain people by what he saw and heard. The mountain people I have met have impressed me to the point where nine years ago I purchased mountain prop erty on which I plan to live. If one does not try'to impress them with the superiority of visitors from large met ropolitan areas, they are friendly, help ful and pleasant

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the midst of life we are in death. On the merriest weekend the Yankees have known in eight years, a sellout crowd stood with heads bowed yesterday to mourn the passing of a man who played a major part in creating the Yankee legend and was its jealous custodian for 13 years. Seven hours before the gates opened for Yankee Stadium's biggest and most boisterous gathering of the season, George Martin Weiss died in Greenwich, Conn. He was incom parably the ablest baseball executive who ever lived, and perhaps the most selfeffacing. We have been striving to regain the level of excel lence he set, the Yankees' president, Mike Burke, told the fans.

title: Jazz Greats to Give a Benefit Concert For Boy Who Lost Arms in Accident

title: AFRICAN PRESIDENT ASSAILS WALDHEIM
description: BANGUI, Central African Re public, Aug. 13 (AP)Gen. Jean Bddel Bokassa, this na tion's President, who recently ordered convicted robbers to be beaten, today accused Secre tary General Waldheim of in terference in our country's internal affairs. Mr. Waldheim had sent a message to General Bokassa protesting the beat ings, which were followed by exhibition of some of the victims in the center of Bangui. Some of them later died.
