description: A 16yearold girl was killed last night when she was struck by a car in the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn while trying to escape three attackers who had stabbed her several times, the police reported.

title: Berger, Mrs. Butz Win
description: CORRY, Pa., Aug. 13Victor Berger of Springfield, Ohio, and Mrs. Ann Butz of Suffern, N. Y., were the victors of the men's and women's divisions in the sixth annual Professional Arch ers Association tournament to day. Berger defeated Dave Dackson in suddendeath after nine targets.

title: Shelley Leeb Married to Joel Peck
description: Miss Shelley J. Leeb, daugh ter of Mrs. Paul A. Leeb of Milwaukee and the late Mr. Leeb, was married here at noon yesterday to Joel Slo nim Peck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar E. Peck of New York. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP)An Olympic entry and an Olympic crew rowed to victory today in the 81st annual Middle States Regatta on the Schuylkill River. Sheen Drea, rowing champion of Ireland, added to his titles when he won the singles sculling championship for the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia.

title: Dim View From Berkeley
description: BERKELEY, CalifNot a trace of political action remains on Berkeley's Bancroft Strip. Yet it was the demands of University of California students that this strip of sidewalk just outside the campus gates be open to political solicitation that brought the opening salvos in 1964 of what swiftly broad ened into nationwide student rebellion. The issue then was the university ad ministration's attempt to make the strip a kind of political DMZ, free of anti war displays and of recruiting for out side political activity.

title: Master Charge Volume Up
description: Master Charge, through its licensing body, Interbank Card Association, has reported gross volume for the first six months of this year of $2.6billion, up 25.1 per cent from the compar able period a year ago.

title: Sudan Plans Fall Election
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 13 (AP)The Sudan will hold its first general election since Maj. Gen. Gaafar al Nimeiry came to power in coup d'etat more than three years ago, the Government an nounced today. Sometime be tween Sept. 22 and Oct. 4, voters will elect a Peoples Council, which will meet in October to approve a perma ent constitution. The council will sit for a maximum period of six months, but General Nimeiry is empowered to dis solve it and have another one elected within 60 days.

title: Isaac Captures Virginia Racel
description: COEBURN, Va., Aug. 13 (AP) Bobby Isaac of Catawba, N.C., outdueled four other drivers today to win the $11,000 NASCAR Coalminers' 100 Grand National East race at the Lone some Pines international race way.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In these days of equal time, I thought it would be appropriate if someone would answer George Nel son's Aug. 3 OpEd article about an incident involving a cab driver:

title: F.B.I. Man Reassigned
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (AP)Thomas F. Lewis, who was in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation office in Media, Pa., when it was raided by antiwar activists last year, has been reassigned to the F.B.I. office here, officials said. Mr. Lewis was suspended for a month after the Media incident and then was trans ferred to the F.B.I.'s Atlanta office.

title: LAWRENCE J. CARUSO, GYNECOLOGIST, DIES
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 13 Dr. Lawrence J. Caruso, di rector of obstetrics and gyne cology of the FrenchPolyclinic Health Center, died today in St Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 55 years old and lived at 40 Harvest Drive.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Personalities.. Gabriel Recovers
description: Nothing hastened Roman Gabriel's recovery quicker than five interceptions of passes by Jerry Rhome and Frank Walton, his quarter back replacements. After Gabriel watched the intercep tions lead to 20 of the Dallas Cowboys' 27 points Saturday night, he and Coach Tommy Prothro of the Rams talked it over and decided that the 31 yearold quarterback would be back in the lineup next Saturday night in a presea son football game against the Oakland Raiders.

title: Mrs. Elijah Muhammad, 72, Black Muslim Leader's Wife
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) Mrs. Clara Muhammad, wife of Elijah Muhammad, the Black Muslim leader, died yesterday after a long illness.She was 72 years old.

title: India, 25 Years Old, Is Showing Pride as a Nation
description: NEW DELHI Prime Min ister Indira Gandhi is about to open a subdued yearlong cele bration of the 25th anniversary of Indian independence in a country where much, has changed, yet much remains the same, since her father, Jawa harlal Nehru, hailed the new nation's tryst with destiny as Britain handed over power in the first minutes of Aug. 15, 1947.

title: HARRY N. SNOOK, 60, OF WESTERN ELECTRIC
description: Harry N. Snook, vice presi dent for manufacturing of trans mission equipment for the Western Electric Company, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in North Andover; Mass. He was 60 years old.

title: Jets' Loss to the Steelers Can't Compare to Giants'
description: Comparisons were tempting but probably misleading after the New York Jets were beat en by the Pittsburgh Steelers, 223, at Seattle Saturday.

title: 2 DEFT PERFORMERS ENLIVEN DANCE CARD
description: While drawing to the close of its summer season, Ameri can Ballet Theater found time to offer several interesting cast changes over the weekend. Betty Chamberlin turned up in Pulcinella Variations and Daniel Levins in Fancy Free.

title: Recently Uncovered Woodrow Wilson Letters Display Warmth
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 13Woodrow Wilson, long considered by the public a cold and austere President, showed a warm congenial side of his personality in recently uncovered corre spondence with an English painter.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent report on corporation taxes submitted to Congress by Rep resentative Vanik has created at best another adverse opinion on the private industry structure of the American system. At worst it leaves the im pression of imputing deception to cor porate managements.

title: RALPH T. SMITH, 57, EXSENATOR, DIES
description: ALTON, Ill., Aug. 13 (AP) Ralph Tyler Smith, who served in the Senate after the death of Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen, died today at his home. He was 57 years old.

title: Migrant Workers Uniting to Fight Job Abuse
description: GLASSBORO, N. J., Aug. 13Scores of Puerto Rican migrant workers are arriving here daily to pick South Jer sey's tomato crop, ripening now through September.

title: BROWNS BEATEN BY 49ERS, 2013
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 (AP)John Brodie, making his first preseason start, gave the San Francisco 49ers two first half touchdowns en route to 2013 victory over the Cleveland Browns today.

title: Yacht Race Canceled
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 13  The season's 28th Yacht Racing Association champion ship regatta on Long Island Sound, under auspices of the International OneDesign Class, was canceled today because of lack of wind.

title: Mostly Mozart Is Showcase for Young Conductors
description: David Zinman, a young, New Yorkborn conductor who has made a name for himself in Europe, was little known in the United States until he con ducted two concerts last week at the Mostly Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall.

title: Lenore H. Scheinman Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Lenore Harriet Schein man was married here yes terday afternoon to Barry Globerman. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the cere mony at the Regency Hotel.

title: STANFORD BLACKS UNITE AS BUILDERS
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 13 Maurice Turner highstepped onto the drab gray concrete foundation and surveyed two months of progress on the modest housing development.

title: Jeffrey Kehl Weds Shelley F. Sanders
description: Miss Shelley Faith Sand ers and Jeffrey Anthony Kehl were married yesterday after noon at the Hillside House in Queens Village, Queens, by Rabbi Steven Shaw.

title: Four Children and an Adult Die in a Fire in Commune
description: GLEN, N. H., Aug. 13 (AP) Four children and a young woman were killed in an early morning fire today in a com mune in this northern New Hampshire community, the po lice said.

title: Judith A. Cowen Is Bride
description: Miss Judith Ann Cowen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Cowen of Utica, N. Y., was married here yesterday to Bertrand Jay Kahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham L. Kahn of New York. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman of the Central Synagogue performed the ceremony at Carlton House. The bride attended Utica College of Syracuse University. Her father is a distributor of school supplies. Mr. Kahn, an attorney with the Legal Aid Society, was graduated from the Fieldston School and George Washing ton University and its law school. His father is an attor ney and certified public ac countant.

title: Student Weds Doris Obadia
description: The marriage of Miss Doris Elizabeth Obadia, who is studying for an M.S. degree at the Columbia University School of Social Work, to Barry Allan Dubin, a member of the class of 73 at the Columbia School of Law, took place here yesterday after noon. Rabbi Louis C. Ger stein performed the ceremony at Congregation Shearith Israel.

title: Cambodian Road Reopened
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 13 (AP)Cambodian troops pushed through to reopen the highway to the beleaguered provincial capital of Preyveng today, ending a siege that be gan when the highway was cut in April, the Cambodian com mand announced.

title: Sand and Sea's Top Prize Goes To German Shorthaired Pointer
description: LAKEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 13 Ch. Rock Run's Stoney, a Ger man shorthaired pointer, who is equally at home in the show ring or in the field, was named best of 1,758 dogs at the Sand and Sea Kennel Club's fixture in Ocean County Park today.

title: Motorist Killed in Brooklyn As He Goes to Aid 2d Car
description: A 28yearold Manhattan motorist who stopped to help the occupants of a disabled car in Brooklyn yesterday was struck and killed by another auto, the police said.

title: GRAFT STUDY FINDS INACTION BY POLICE IN 72 DRUG CASES
description: The Police Department was accused yesterday of failing to investigate reports given it by a Federal agency between 1968 and 1970 that 72 police menincluding patrolmen, de tectives, sergeants, lieutenants and a captain  were im properly engaged in the nar cotics traffic.

title: FITTIPALDI WINS RACE IN AUSTRIA
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 13  Emerson Fittipaldi, driving a used car of doubtful resale value, won the Austrian Grand Prix by 1.18 seconds today and virtually clinched the world drivers' championship.

title: U. S. tourney in Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 13 (AP)With one eye on their chess boards and the other on Iceland, some 350 chess players from the United States and five other countries made their first moves tonight as the 73d United States Open Chess Champion ship began here.

title: Informer Appears Key to U.S. Case Against 6 Antiwar Veterans
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla Aug, I3The Government's case against six members of the Vietnam Veterans Against the War charged with plotting an assault on the Republican Na tional Convention appears to rest primarily on the testimony of an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who had established a reputation as one of the antiwar group's more militant and vociferous members.

title: Yugoslav Accuses Australia And Austria on Terrorists
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 13Premier Dzemel Bijedic of Yugoslavia accused Australia and Austria today of having tolerated terrorist and sabotage training by Croatian migrs, known as Ustashi, for action against Yugoslavia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The current public display of con cern over the past medical history of Senator Eagleton illustrates the vast task before the American people if ever they are to attain fair and re spectful consideration for those who become ill from mental or nervous strain, particularly if they seek and receive treatment.

title: Box Scores of Yesterday's Major League Games
Russel Corey Leads Roslyn To 93 Victory in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, LI., Aug. 13 Russel Corey scored three goals today to lead the Roslyn polo team to a 9.3 victory over Jericho at Bethpage State Park.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CHAMPAIGNURBANA, Ill., Aug. 13Gail Fitzgerald, Atoms Track Club star, qualified today for a place on the United States Olympic team in the pentathlon. In the process, she broke the American record with 4,305 points during a dual meet between the United States and Canadian women at the University of Illinois.

title: SPASSKY ILLNESS POSTPONES CHESS
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 13The 14th game of the world championship chess match was postponed today after the champion, Boris Spas sky of the Soviet Union, pleaded illness.

title: POWELL DEPLORES SOCIAL CRITICISM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 Associate Justice Lewis F. Pow ell Jr. warned today that persistent and destructive criticism these days of religion, free enterprise and other ele ments of society was eroding the moral authority of Ameri can institutions.

title: 13,500 Departed in 1971
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 Jewish emigration from the So viet Union to Israel last year reached a peak of about 13,500 with most of the migration cc curing in the second half of the year.

title: 15% CITY RENT RISE ASSAILED AS TAX
description: A group of Federal, city and state legislators called yester day for revision of the city's computerized rentcontrol sys tem, charging that the housing and Development Administra tion had disregarded provi sions of the law under which the maximum base rent con cept was authorized.

title: DAVID GOLDSTEIN
description: ASBURY PARK, NI., Aug. 13 David Goldstein, a lawyer and former magistrate who was a United States Commissioner Ifrom 1943 until his retirement this year, died today in the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. He was 70 years old and lived here at 1700 Webb Street.

title: NoLoad Fund Head Says Sales Top Redemptions
description: Net redemptions by share owners have plagued the mutual fund industry during the last year. But a number of noload funds, which levy no sales charges, have avoided the prob lem. Among the noloads is the growthoriented Johnston Mu tual Fund, which holds $282 million in net assets and is now in its twentysixth year. Nathan H. Garrick Jr., president of the fund, was interviewed by Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times last week. The topics ranged from the state of the fund business to the state of the stock market and dwelt also on Mr. Garrick's cur rent portfolio thinking. Portions of their conversation follow:

title: Inquiry Unit Chides Judge and Queens Prosecutor
description: The State Commission of In vestigation criticized a State Supreme Court justice and senior assistant district attor ney in Queens yesterday for the way they handled the case of detective indicted on charges of plotting to sell heroin.

title: Credit Markets
description: Investors became decidedly less willing last week to accept steadily diminishing yields on corporate and taxexempt bonds, raising the prospect that the gradual monthlong market advance may be about over. Nonetheless, analysts do not expect a sharp reversal in the market because of relatively limited financing demands immedi ately ahead and because of large amounts of money available for insti tutional investment. Money rates, meanwhile, are believed by many analysts to have reached their lowest levels in conjunction with the recently completed. Treasury refunding and are now launched on long, upward course.

title: Hanoi Wants to Use P.O.W.'s as Barter, Freed Priest Says
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 13 (AP)  A Vietnamese priest, taken to Hanoi after his parish was overrun in the enemy offensive, says North Vietnam wants to barter Ameri can prisoners for the rebuilding of the country.

title: MISS SMITH WINS IN GOLF BY 6 SHOTS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UPI)Marilynn Smith, playing nearperfect golf, held off a group of challengers with a 70 today to win the $30,000 Pabst Classic by six strokes from Jan Ferraris.

title: 7 Killed in Ohio Accident; 26 Dead in State in Week
description: LISBON, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UPI) Seven persons were killed in a twocar collision west of here today, two days after six mem bers of a Kentucky family were burned to death in another crash near here.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 2 Boys Try to Hold Up Policemen Two boys, 13 and 14 years old, armed with a bbgun, were seized when they attempted to hold up two uniformed Long Island Rail Road patrolmen in an unmarked car, the police reported.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARIS  The mixed choir of Hyeres with Solange Des sane, violin professor at Toulon, as soloist, gave a spiritual concert last week in the church of SaintTro pez. The event was signifi cant, though perhaps not on the musical level: It proved that things are never quite as desperate as the moralists say, and it set off France's summer festival season. There are some 300 of these festivals, of which at least onethird take place on or near the Riviera. Wherever an old castle, a medieval chapel or an ancient ruin can be found, it is turned into a concert hall or theater, to capture some of the 4 million Frenchmen not to mention foreigners currently in the South. The fare includes pop music, min strels, underground plays and, around Vence, casual performances of classical music by strolling musicians.

title: Computer Tax Loss Seen
description: California Computer Prod ucts, Inc., said yesterday that it expected to report a net aftertax loss of up to $12mil lion on total revenues of $53 million for the fiscal year ended June 30, as a result of changes in its accounting policy. For the year ended June 30, 1971, the company had earnings of $2.3million on sales of $44.6 million.

title: Parkway Service Area Open
description: WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Aug. 13 (AP)The Garden State Park way has reopened the Montvale Service Area in the northeast corner of the state after com pleting a $1million renovation project. The restaurant at the center was expanded and re decorated and a cafeteria was added. A larger parking area, with spaces for 265 cars and 29 buses and trailers, was built. The work doubled the capacity at the area.

title: 11 Hurt in Crash On Henry Hudson
description: Eleven persons, including five children riding in a Volkswagen bus, were serious ly injured last night in a head on collision on the Henry Hud son Parkway near 125th Street.

title: Blacks and Varied Pop Star at Festival of Hope
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 13 The Festival of Hope's second day of programs at Roosevelt Raceway was a virtual across theboard survey of the many varieties of contemporary pop music.

title: Satellite Is Sent Into Orbit To Study Space Particles
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Aug. 13 (UPI)The space agency sent another satellite into orbit today to study the hazards that tiny space particles may pose to spacecraft circling the earth for long periods.

title: Controls Trim Some Raises and Alter Unions' Bargaining Goals
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13The first year of the Nixon Administra tion's new economic policies has brought evidence of small er negotiated wage settlements and changed attitudes at the collective bargaining table.

title: DR. HENRY HUBER, 65, OF FRENCH HOSPITAL
description: Dr. Henry S. Huber, who retired in June as medical di rector of the French and Poly clinic Medical School and Health Center, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 5 Westmoreland Place in Doug laston, Queens. He was 65 years old.

title: Final Site for 3d London Airport Is on Land Reclaimed From Sea
description: LONDON, Aug. 13The Gov ernment is planning to build a third airport for London on Maplin Sands, off a lonely stretch of coast north of the Thames estuary that has been used as an artillery range for more than 100 years.

title: Largest U.S. Banks Ease Lending Terms
description: Prolonged monetary expan sion and relatively slack cor porate credit demands have combined in the last few months to produce a signifi cant loosening of lending terms by the nation's largest banks.

title: U.N. and World's Trouble Spots
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 13In his annual re port, Secretary General Wald heim touched upon several successes and frustrations of the United Nations during the last year:

title: THIEU QUESTIONS ES. COMMITMENT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 13President Nguyen Van Thieu, in a major speech, has said that to save South Viet nam, the United States must keep up relentless bombing of North Vietnam for another six or seven months, but at the same time he raised ap parent doubts about Washing ton's willingness to go on bombing at the same intensity.

title: Personal Finance: PartTime Rentals
description: The Internal Revenue Serv ice has just tightened its rules on parttime rentals a move that could affect thousands who own and live for a month or so in resort area houses, condominiums or boats, and rent them to others for the remainder of the season.

title: GENEVA REPORTED MISSILETALK SITE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to hold the next phase of their talks on limiting strategic armaments in Geneva, instead of shuttling back and forth between Hel sinki and Vienna as they did during the first rounds of the talks, wellplaced Administra tion sources said today.

title: Wheat Estimate Steady
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) Agriculture Department offi ials say they expect no imme diate modification of 1973 wheat acreage plans announced last month because of the dramatic entry of the Soviet Union into the United States farm market. The Soviets, ac cording to trade reports, may buy up to 400 million bushels or more of United States wheat. That would be equal to about onefourth of what farmers are producing this year.

title: Gambling Devastating, State Report Cautions
description: The State Commission of Investigation, in its 14th an nual report to Governor Rockefeller, calls illegal gam bling the lifeblood of the underworld.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 13 (UPI)Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas, the Republican Na tional Chairman, termed pre posterous today the charge by Mr. Shrivel that President Nixon missed a golden oppor tunity to end the Vietnam war in 1969.

title: Alleged Holdup Gang Rams Police Car: Patrolman Hurt
description: Three men who allegedly held up a Harlem bar last nightt, and fled toward midtown Man hattan in a stolen gypsy cab crashed the cab broadside into a police cruiser blocking a Times Square intersection, sev erely injuring a patrolman.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 13 (AP)Joe Leonard won his third consecutive United States Auto Club Championship Trail race today, leading the field by at least three laps at the finish of the Tony Bettenhausen 200mile event the Wisconsin State Fair. Leonard earned $14,534 for the victory after recording an average speed of 111.652 miles per hour.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Reach 2d Place; Top Brewers, 53, 54
description: Waving their gift Little League bats triumphantly, many zealous fans among the crowd of 56,238 began a chant during the eighth inning of the second game of yesterday's double header at Yankee Stadium. We're No. 1, we're No. 1, they shouted.

title: Clashes in Berlin Mark Wall's 11th Anniversary
description: BERLIN, Aug. 13 (AP) The police of West Berlin clashed with leftistled dem onstrators today, the 11th an niversary of the Communist wall dividing Berlin.

title: Comment from Clark
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 13 (UPI)Ramsey Clark, re turning from an inspection tour of North Vietnam, said today that he had seen extensive damage, including damage to dikes, from United States bombing raids. He said the bombing could not be justified.

title: Books of The Times
description: PIPPA'S CHALLENGE. By Joy Adamson. 177 pages, illustrated. Harcourt Brace Javano vich. $9.50.

title: Rustic Superhighways...
description: The disdain of the rural population for city folk may have a romantic heritage across the history of the Amer ican Republic, but some of its current outcroppings are as destructive as they are silly.

title: MRS. ELIS HOGLUND
description: Mrs. Helen Klinger Hoglund, wife of Elis S. Hoglund, a retired vice president of Gen eral Motors, died Friday in Chatham, Mass. She was 73 years old and lived in Chatham and New York.

title: Nicklaus 3Shot Victor on 270
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 13 The chef at the Westchester Country Club, Helmut Kischow ski, baked a cake especially for Jack Nicklaus in anticipation of a victory. Hours later, Nick laus added the rrosting by equaling the scoring record of 270 for the Westchester classic and capturing the first prize of $50,000 by three strokes.

title: Times Correspondent Gets Award From News Agency
description: Third World Media News, a news service specializing in news of interest to minority groups, has presented an award to Earl Caldwell, a San Fran ciscobased correspondent for The New York Times, for his stand against the Justice De partment in refusing to answer subpoenas before a grand jury.

title: Fischer Said to Weigh Filming of Last Games
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 13Barry Fredericks, the lawyer for Chester Fox & Co., Inc., said today that Bobby Fischer had indicated inter est in having the last two games of the world chess championship match filmed.

title: U.S. Auto Makers Voice No Regrets in Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 13Automo bile production in Japan has begun slowing down, but Amer ican auto manufacturers who have invested here say they are satisfied, if not overjoyed, with those investments.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Although unisex hair sal ons have been flourishing for the last few years, techni cally they have been illegal in New York State. Now, at long last, they have the bless ing of Albany, provided that they have a licensed barber and a licensed cosmetologist (hair dresser) on the prem ises.

title: Two Storms in Pacific
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 13 (UPI) Celeste and Diana, two hutricanes with center winds near 100 miles an hour, moved across the central Pacific to day. Celeste was about 850 miles southeast of Hawaii, mov ing nearly due west at a speed of 12 knots. About a thousand miles behind her, Diana, the larger of the two, was headed northwestward.

title: Nancy Siegel Bride Of Medical Student
description: MANALAPAN, N. J., Aug. 13Miss Nancy Sue Siegel and Christopher Joseph Dres sel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Dressel of Pittsburgh, were married here this afternoon at the Battleground Country Club by the Rev. Paul Cole man, a Baptist minister. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Siegel of New Brunswick.

title: A Rug So Fine It Cannot Be Repaired
description: Berdj Abadjian, who says he has the biggest and most accomplished staff of rug weavers in this country repair ing and restoring Oriental rugs, acknowledges that he has one rug his people can't work on. But then he doesn't think that anyone else could work on it either. The rug in question is a 5by7foot Is fahan with 2,000 knots to the square inch. Mr. Abad jian, an Armenian who was born in Rumania and came to this country in 1963, fig ures that 12 years were re quired to make the Isfahan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 4 frontpage article about the Taxi Commission Prodding Detroit to Make Safe, Comfortable Cab served only as comic relief to the remainder of the depression that generally charac terizes frontpage news lately.

title: New Problem in Drugs: Addiction to Methadone
description: In New York and other large metropolitan areas, methadone maintenance programs are rap idly expanding and reaching out to help thousands of heroin addicts. But at the same time controversy hounds methadone because more peoplefrequent ly nonaddictsare dying from overdoses of the drug, while an uncertain number of others are becoming primary methadone addicts, bypassing heroin.

title: Mideast Radio Voice Sought for Peace Ship
description: WEST NEW YORK, N. J., Aug. 11From the deck of his converted freighter docked amid the rotting piers and industrial clutter here, Abie J. Nathan can look across the graygreen Hudson to the towers of Manhattan spread. across the skyline.

title: ABRAHAM SHERMAN, NUCLEAR PHYSICIAN
description: YONKERS, Aug. 13Dr. Abraham A. Sherman, director of nuclear medicine at Mor risania and Montefiore Hos pital, both in the Bronx, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 65 years old and lived at 357 North Broadway.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 (UPI)Four persons, including three members of one family, died today in an early morning fire that swept through a house in the Northeast section of the city.

title: . . . and Supertrains
description: For New Yorkers, the mouthwatering description an Francikco's new rapidtransit rail system might look like a promising glimpse into the future. If only it could be so.

title: AIRLINER HITS FENCE IN ABORTEDTAKEOFF
description: A Yugoslav Airlines plane bound for Rijeka, Yugoslavia, with 175 passengers crashed through a steel fence at the end of a runway at Kennedy Inter national Airport early yester, day morning when the pilot aborted the plane's takeoff after hearing a loud noise in the cockpit.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 (AP) Vice President Agnew, in a wideranging defense of Presi dent Nixon's programs, said onight that Senator McGovern's proposals to end the war would result in the forfeit of Amer ican diplomatic credibility.

title: CUBS BEAT METS FOR JENKINS, 74
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 13At first it looked as if Jerry Koosman might go down in history as one of the first pitchers ever to lose a ball game by a nose, but there were other reasons he was taken out in the second inning of the New York Mets' 74 defeat today at the hands of the Chicago Cubs.

title: Mayor Assails Relief Rule; Puts Cost Here in Millions
description: Threemonthold Federal fair hearing requirements have cost millions of tax dollars already in keeping ineligibles on the city's relief rolls for extra weeks and months, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday in mak ing public a formal request for revision.

title: 2 EXU.N. DELEGATES ASSAIL U.S. ON DIKES
description: Two former United States delegates to the United Na tions have accused President Nixon and other Administration officials of misleading the pub lic about the bombing of dikes in North Vietnam.

title: Mine Injures 4 British Soldiers in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 13 (Reuters)Four British soldiers were injured, one se riously, when a land mine ex ploded today in the Andersons town section, a stronghold of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Communism : 125 Years Later
description: When people talk about the working class they frequently have in mind an ideal type something like this: male, white, over 30, blue collar, work ing in manufacturing, mining or con struction, unionized, a member of an old ethnic group, possessing little for mal education.

title: STAUBACH HURT, IS OPERATED ON
description: Roger Staubach, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback and the National Football League's most valuable player last sea son, underwent surgery yester day for a right shoulder sep aration. He was expected to miss eight to 12 weeks of the regularseason play.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  When Senator George McGov ern began his campaign jour neys last Thursday as the Democratic Presidential nom inee, his candidacy seemed to face a fork in the road. By all the rules of logic, lie had either to bear left toward the dream of a liberal young plurality that he pursued in the primaries or veer right toward the security of the conventional old coalition that Franklin D. Roosevelt con structed 40 years ago.

title: MISS EVERT WINS CLAYCOURT TITLE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 13 (Reuters)Chris Evert made a strong comeback after losing the first five games in the first set to go on and beat the top seeded Australian, Evonne Goo lagong, 76, 61, today in the United States claycourt tennis championship.

title: NURSING UNITS GOT FEE WHILE CLOSED
description: State Controller Arthur Lev itt reported yesterday that the city had given $475,646 in ad vance Medicaid payments to nine nursing homes after the homes had closed down be tween 1968 and last fall.

title: Article 2  No Title

description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 13The steel outlook was reasonably bright last week.

title: Films Showing Environment Pollution Exhibited in Capital by Federal Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The Environmental Protection Agen cy has placed on exhibit the first installment of a longrange program to show on film what environmental pollution is doing to America.

title: Slowly, Painfully, the Philippines Dries Out
description: MANILA, Aug. 13Helped by seven days of sunshine, the rich agricultural lowlands of central Luzon are beginning to dry out after six weeks of in undation by the most devastat ing flood in Philippine history.

description: The North American Soccer League regular season ended yesterday with the Dallas Tor nado playing the Montreal Olympics to a scoreless tie in Montreal and the Miami Gatos defeating the St. Louis Stars, 20, at Miami.

title: Jay Time, Strike Out Finish in a Dead Heat
description: MEADOW LANDS, Pa., Aug. 13 (AP)Strike Out, the fa vorite, and Jay Time, a 71 outsider, raced to a dead heat in the final of the $92,110 Adios stakes at the Meadows harness track last night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The many contributions which Dr. William T. Pecora rendered to the nation during his 33year career with the Department of the Interior are well described in The Times' obituary of July 20. Perhaps Dr. Pecora's greatest service came during his final years six as Director of the U.S. Geological Survey and the last as Under Secre tary, when he was my chief adviser.

title: Con Ed Man Gets City Post
description: John M. Daniels, a 52year old Consolidated Edison Com pany executive, yesterday was named deputy commissioner of public works, a city post that pays $30,102 a year. Mr. Dan iels, who will assume his new duties Sept, 1, succeeds the late John W. Hornsey. A reg istered professional engineer, Mr. Daniels has been with Con Edison since 1969 as manager for construction labor relations and manpower control.

title: Air Academy Anticipates 80 Women in Each Class
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 13The class of 1979, enter ing the Air Force Academy in 1975, could have about 80 woman cadets if the 26th Amendment to the Constitu tionthe equal rights amend mentis ratified by 38 of the states.

title: SOVIET'S EXHIBIT LURES AMERICANS
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 13We are showing what we can offer, not what we are producing the Russian explained to the two Americans.

title: The Private Sector
description: Move are under way to scrap this nations healthcare delivery system and buy a new one. The cost of doing this would be astronomical and the expenditure would'be unnecessary. Repairs to the system are needed, but nothing that would justify total Fed eral funding or a Federal bureaucracy to run all health matters in America.

title: Third Husband of Heiress Injured in Fall From Roof
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) Barnet Wade Garrison, the third husband of Candace Mossier Garrison, heiress to a fortune in the millions, was critically injured today in a fall off the steep roof of their threestory home.

title: MARIJUANA USED AT CAPITAL PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The first people's pot conference took place here last week and oilly one arrest was made.

title: Archie Bunker's British Cousin, Alf, Comes to Screen
description: Admiration for the national character isn't a uniquely British proclivity, but it seems more highly developed, more institutionalized in England than anywhere else. It is also more ambitious, and potentially more fun.As E. M. Forster put it while placing his works beside Beethoven's Ninth Symphony and Blake's "Song of Innocence," to commemorate his own centenary in a 21st-century editorial for The Times of London: "Like Beethoven, like Blake, Forster was essentially English, and in commemorating him we can yet again celebrate what is best and most permanent in ourselves."And now, after Forster, after Beethoven, after Blake, comes Alf Garnettas essentially English as any of them, and very permanent. Alf is the hero of "Alf 'n' Family," a movie by Norman Cohen and Johnny Speight, which opened yesterday at the Juliet I. Neither an artist, nor even-quite a thinker, Alf is a man whose opinions are his truest memorial. Of these he has a plentiful supply.The film picks Alf up in 1939 and drops him in the 1970's, during which time the world changesthough he doesn't. A working-class Tory; a patriot; a coward; scorning Hitler, the Pope, "Lili Marlene"; he begins as a loud-mouth fool and, by simply staying himself, ends as something of a loud-mouth hero.Along the way he begets a daughter, gains a son-in-law, loses a house, hangs onto his prejudices and (the film is cagy about this) keeps his principles intact. There are problems inherent in presenting a lovable, laughable old chauvinistic racial bigot; and "Alf 'n' Family" mainly solves them by looking the other way.Thus Alf says he hates "coons" but actually embraces blacks, despises socialism but likes his daughter's Socialist husband, still worships Churchill butwell, whom is there left to worship? By growing firmly out of date, Alf moves into sentimental history. The times have assured that there is all the difference in the world between the braggart idiot on the home front laughing off Dunkirk, and the little fellow more than 20 years later stubbornly holding onto his house despite the urban demolition plans of the Greater London Council.Though it covers a lot of time, "Alf 'n' Family" is really a strung-together succession of short, comic situations. (The same characters appear in a British TV series which was the model for the American "All in the Family.") It follows that some of the skits are good, some not so good, sometoo manyending in a kind of laughter-begging personal embarrassment as Alf discovers that he has jumped to attention without any clothes on, or stuck his foot in hot water or cracked his skull on a window frame.But there are also moments of heart-warming pleasure, such as whenduring war rationingAlf steals milk for his tea from his own baby's bottle. Or, when Alf's wife announces she is pregnant, and the two of them sit in mute astonishment, wondering when the child could have been conceived.Dandy Nichols plays Alf's wife, and Una Stubbs plays his daughter, and they both furnish good conventional British comedy caricatures.As Alf, Warren Mitchell seems to improve as he ages and as he has more detail to put into his role. He is better with such detail than he is with comic invention. But he manages to project beneath his conservatism an undercurrent of sly anarchy; and it is this that allows him in drunken good humor to reduce his daughter's wedding to chaos, or, while praying in church for divine assistance, to cheat God out of a few shillings at the collection box.

title: Few Records Left for Nicklaus, but $300,000 Is One
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 13 Of the 11 million people who play golf in this country, of the 25,000 who make a living at it, of the 250 touring pro fessionals who compete for the $7million in prize money in it Jack Nicklaus stood at the top of the heap today. Where does he go from here?

title: RIPPON, IN UGANDA, VOWS BRITISH ROLE
description: ENTEBBE, Uganda, Aug. 13 (AP)Britain's special Cabinet level envoy, Geoffrey Rippon, ended a 30 hour visit to Uganda today, pledging that London would accept ultimate responsibility for all Asians here with British passports.

title: HOBEAU'S FILLY TAKES HANDICAP
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 13 Blessing Angelica, representing Jack Dreyfus Jr.'s Hobeau Farm, won the $114,000 Dela ware Handicap today for the second straight year, while Ogden Phipps's Numbered Ac count, the 910 favorite, fin ished third in Delaware Park's closingday 1mile fixture for fillies and mares.

title: Coast Fire Under Control After Burning 1,700 Acres
description: SHASTA, Calif., Aug. 13 (AP) A forest fire that blackened 1,700 acres and damaged sev eral buildings in this historic mining town was under control late today, the state Division of Forestry reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John DuVall in his July 29 letter indicates that he has been sucked into believing that there is really no such thing as a Communist menace to America and somehow he has also determined that most Americans agree with him. Moreover, he predicts that President Nixon will wrap him self in the American flag on his Miami rostrum in August and unleash a deluge of manufactured paranoia about the terrible consequences for America's defense if there is a McGovern vic tory.

title: Building Trades Employers Here Move to Aid Legislative Inquiry on Corruption
description: State Senator Roy M. Good man, who is leading a legis lative investigation of cor ruption in the construction field here, announced yesterday a joint effort with employers to identify and revise cor ruptioninducing laws.

title: Man in the News
description: The gate to the Yankee bull pen opens, the pinstriped Dat sun drives out, and Toby Wright, the Yankee Stadium organist, begins playing Pomp and Circumstance. The crowd roars. The car pulls up in front of the Yankee dugout, and Sparky Lyle steps out. The crowd roars even louder.

title: Conor O'Brien Finds His Irish Political Career Enmeshed in Ancient Issues
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 10  When Conor Cruise O'Brien gave up his professorship at New York University three years ago to enter Irish politics, local essay ists hailed him as the most brilliant Irishman of his gen eration and a great symbolic figure of the Irish left.

title: George Weiss Dies at 78; Guided Yankees and Mets
description: George Weiss, who was in fluential in building a New York Yankees dynasty that dominated baseball for years and who later served as first president of the New York Mets, died yesterday at a nurs ing home in Greenwich, Conn. His age was 78.

title: ARMY STUDY IS SAID TO BACK DEFOLIANTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (Reu ters)  Use of defoliants in Western Europe to help stall a Communist attack is recom mended in a secret United States Army study, according to a Washington science writer.

title: Investigation Unit Set Up in 1958
description: The Temporary Commission of Investigation of the State of New York, which issued the report on the Police Department yesterday, was created by the State Legisla ture in 1958 to probe law enforcement, the conduct of pub lic officials and any matter concerning the public peace, public safety and public justice.

title: Black ExPilots Recall Bias in World War II
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13 He was a fighter pilot in World War II, shot down over France. He recalls that a Ger man interrogator asked him why he was fighting.

title: New Business Alliances Urged At Negro Musicians Convention
description: Words and music filled the grand ballroom of the Commo dore Hotel yesterday as some 350 persons from 37 states gathered for the annual con vention of the National Asso ciation of Negro Musicians.

title: Unstable Deterrence . . .
description: In his Slate of the World report to Congress last February, President Nixon expressed the hope that the nuclear arms race with Russia could be halted by a combination of mutual restraint and an agreement SALT, the strategic arms limitation talks. The SALT agreement was signed May 26 in Moscow. But the mu tual restraint. essential to make it work has yet to be seen in Washington. On the contrary, the emphasis seems to be on stepping up the arms race in fields still unrestricted by SALT, despite the adequacy of existing weapons.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BRANCHVILLE, N. J., Aug. 13In an awesome display of horsemanship, Rod Jenkins, a redhaired, 28yearold professional, rode the first five finishers today in the $5,000 added Sussex County Jumper Classic. The event wound up the 36th renewal of the sevenday Sussex County horse show at the Sussex County Fair Grounds.

title: Marcia Eichenbaum Has Nuptials
description: Miss Marcia Eichenbaum was married here last eve ning to James Harald Leh mann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manfred Lehmann of Law rence, L. I. The bride's par ents are Mr. and Mrs. Irving Eichenbaum of Lakewood, N. J.

title: Detroit Wins Youth Games
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) Detroit's host team won the basketball title last night and captured the sixth annual United States Youth Games championship. Detroit's 6346 victory over Birmingham, Ala., gave it 41 points for the two day games, two more than Washington.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  Hard pressed for funds and eager for television exposure, the McGovern campaign is pushing strongly for Congres sional action that could virtu ally guarantee the Democratic national ticket More than $1 million worth of free broadcast time this fall.

title: M'GOVERN PROPOSAL HIT AS ISOLATIONIST
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 13 (UPI)  Representative John J. Rhodes, of Arizona, chairman of the Republican National Con vention Platform Committee, said today that Senator George McGovern's proposed defense spending cuts would make the United. States a secondrate power that would have diffi culty defending even Hawaii.

title: U.S. Exports Lag in World's Trade
description: Although world trade is ex panding, the share of Ameri can exports in the import mar kets of most countries is down sharply.

title: Cities Solve Problems
description: The urban crisis is more desperate than ever. But I'm now afraid that it may have seen its earth day a peaking of attention, followed by little action and subsiding concern. It's as if, like the environmental issue, we had our day on the covers of Time and Newsweek, got our minimal, sym bolic legislation, and then everybody went home.

title: Alaska Newspaper Can Offer Blubber To StateFairgoers
description: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 13 After a dispute between the Alaska Division of Environ mental Health and The Tundra Times, an Eskimo, Indian and Aleut newspaper, muktuk will be available at the Tanana Val ley State Fair that opens here Wednesday.

description: A badly burned body, be lieved to be that of a neighbor hood painter and handyman, was found yesterday near the Shore Parkway in the Sheeps head Bay section of Brooklyn, according to the police.

The Rev. Edward Adkins of Christ Episcopal Church per formed the ceremony.

title: New Yankee Fans Show No Mercy
description: The new Yankee baseball fans, born of nearly a decade of humiliation that followed a long tradition of glory, ex ploded in clamor and fury at the Stadium yesterday, as though their noise would propel the team to its first pennant since 1964.

description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 13I got real gripe, began a recent letter to Theatrice Williams. Please see me next time you're up. The letter did not specify the nature of the gripe but Mr. Williams dashed off a quick note and assured the man an inmate at the state peni tentiary in Stillwaterthat his problem would be carefully investigated.

title: Rose Schneiderman
description: A tiny, redhaired bundle of social dynamite, Rose Schneiderman did more to upgrade the dignity and liv ing standards of working women than any other Amer ican.

title: Bridge: Which Is Best for Preempts  Subtlety or a Sledgehammer?
description: The pros and cons of pre emptive bidding can be ar gued interminably. Those who prefer a gentle approach on freakish hands claim, cor rectly up to a point, that they can locate the best contract more easily than the pre emptive bidder, especially if a slam is a possibility.

description: Mutual restraint or a continued nuclear arms race is the central issue raised by Senator Henry Jackson's effort to attach reservations to the interim fiveyear SovietAmerican agreement limiting strategic offensive missiles.

title: Port Notes
description: Shipping Row along lower Broadway is not what it used to he.

description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 13 It was almost like a Sunday at the ball park or a weekday aft ernoon at Coney Island. The biggest difference was the at traction  hard rock, from Looking Glass to Billy Preston, with Sly and the Family Stone as the feature attraction.

title: McGovern Accuses Nixon Of a Low Road Campaign
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13Senator George McGovern accused President Nixon today of directing subordinates question the loyalty of Ramsey Clark, former Attorney General of the United States, as part of a low road campaign for reelection.

title: City Schools Told To Turn In Names Of StudentAddicts
description: In a reversal of previous policy, Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has directed schools to report the names of students who are known drug addicts to the Department of Health for inclusion in the city's Narcotics Register of addicts.

title: VIETCONG ATTACK NEAR TWO CITIES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Aug. 14 (AP)Viet cong troops blew up two am munition dumps and a bridge near South Vietnam's two larg est cities yesterday in the latest of a series of demolition attacks, the Saigon command reported.

title: Bridal for Barbara Ablon and a Lawyer
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, Aug. I3Miss Barbara Louise Ablon of Shaker Heights and New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Ablon of Shaker Heights and Palm Beach, Fla., was married here this afternoon to Richard Ian Solomon, also of New York, the son of Mrs. Leo Solomon of Grand Rapids, Mich., and the late Mr. Solomon.

title: Miss Resnick, Senior At N.Y.U., Is Married
description: ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 13 Miss Barbara Resnick, daugh ter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene V. Resnick, was married at home here this afternoon to Jacob Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Wagner of Silver Lake, S.I. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Andre Unger, assisted by Cantor Mark Biddleman.

title: An Enigmatic Frenchman Leading Europe in Sugar
description: PARIS, Aug. 14Ferdinand Bghin the crusty 70yearold industrialist and erstwhile stockholder of Figaro, the Paris newspaper, has engineered a merger that makes the F. Beghin Company the biggest producer of sugar in the Com mon Market.

description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner's new policy requiring schools to report the names of students who are known drug addicts to the citys Narcotics Register was criticized yester day by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Youth Group Is Pressing BlueCollar and Minority Voters' Drive
description: Frontlash, a nonpartisan na tional coalition of youth and student organizations, is pressing a drive here to regis ter young and old workers who might not otherwise be qualified to vote in the Novem ber election.

title: GRAIN PRICES CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Profit taking drove most prices lower on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. Af ternoon buying lifted prices from their worst levels.

title: American Party Campaign
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP) Thomas Jefferson Anderson, vicepresidential nominee of the American party, opened a cam paign in Florida today with an attack on President Nixon and Senator George McGovern.

title: MURPHY SUPPORTS KNAPP'S PROPOSAL
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday endorsed the Knapp Commission's recom mendation that Governor Rockefeller appoint a special deputy attorney general to prosecute official corruption, while the city's five District. Attorneys met with the Gov ernor's counsel to oppose it.

description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 14 Marita Redondo of National City, Calif., advanced to the sec ond round today in defense of the United States women's am ateur grasseourt tennis cham pionship. She defeated Janet Hass of Miami Beach, 62, 61, at the Wilmington Coun try Club.

title: DOCKMEN IN BRITAIN TO STUDY NEW OFFER
description: LONDON, Aug. 14The head of the dock workers' union to night summoned worker dele gates to a meeting Wednesday to consider an improved pro ??osal to settle the nationa dock strike, now in its 18th day.

title: Rep. Ichord Requests Laws Covering Jane Fonda Trip
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) If the Justice Department de cides not to prosecute Jane Fonda for her radio broadcasts from Hanoi, it should recom mend legislation to provide criminal penalties for similar cases in the future, the House Internal Security Committee said today.

title: Executive Changes
description: John A. Gearhart has been named vice presi. dentcorporate communications of the Singer Com pany succeeding O. Glenn Saxon who has Joined the Ogden Corporation as senior vice president corporate development.

title: A Rookie at 28
description: Sports of The Times

title: Credit Markets
description: Shortterm interest rates crept higher yesterday, spurred by the decision of several major New York City banks to ad vance the rates they officially offer to pay for certificateof deposit money.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 14 (AP)  Lasse Viern of Finland set a world record for the twomile run tonight with a time of 8 minutes 14 seconds in a preOlympic track and field meet.

title: The Nobility of Chess: Every Grandmaster Is a King
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 14  The grandmasters of chess, those suzerains of the 64 squares, have been here in force, watching Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer slug it out for the world championship title.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP)Frank Heckl, the swim ming star of last year's PanAmerican Games, was awarded the first Jess Hill Heritage Trophy today as the top senior scholarathlete of the year at the University of Southern California. Heckl won six gold medals in swimming the 1971 Games in Cali, Colombia. He graduated with honors as a premedical biology student with a Bplus average.

title: Money Bill Veto May Reopen Safety Exemption Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The expected veto by President Nixon of the $30.5billion ap propriation bill sent to him by Congress last week would re open a controversial and po litically sensitive nonmoney is sue the exemption of small businesses from the tough re quirements of the new occupa tional safety and health law.

title: DR. JOSEPH BASRALIAN
description: HACKENSACK. N. J., Aug. 14 Dr. Joseph B. Basrahan, sen ior attending surgeon and as sociate director of the urology department at Hackensack Hos pital, died there today. He was 71 years old and lived in Has brouck Heights.

title: DR. CARL V. MOORE, HEMATOLOGIST, 63
description: MANISTEE, Mich., Aug. 14 (UPI)Dr. Carl V. Moore, a hematologist and former chair man of the medical depart ment of Washington University in St. Louis, died of a heart attack here yesterday.

title: Saigon's Commanders Say the War Can Last for Years
description: SAI GON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14Provided that Ameri can support of the war effort here is not radically reduced by Congress or the election to the Presidency of Senator George McGovern, South Viet namese commanders foresee an indefinite military conflict with Hanoi that could last years or decades.

title: Oscar Levant, Wit and Pianist, Is Dead
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 14 (AP)Oscar Levant, the pianist and radio and television wit who capitalized on his neu rotic personality but was later felled by it, died today appar! ently of a heart attack at his home here. He was 65 years old.

title: INVENTORY RISE SLOWED IN JUNE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Total business inventories rose less than half as much in June as in May, reflecting mainly a cutback in stocks of automobile dealers, the Commerce Depart ment reported today. The total for June was $184.99billion.

title: Kennedy Criticizes Nixon; Says Agnew Will Be Issue
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy charged the Nixon Administra tion today with dividing the country and said that Vice President Agnew would be one of the major issues of the Presidential campaign.

title: A Clarification
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank is willing to make 10year, non amortizing term loans in which the maximum average interest cost is guaranteed to the bor rower, Robert K. Schell, execu tive vice president of the bank, said yesterday. In clarification of his remarks reported in yes terday's editions of The New York Times, Mr. Schell said that Chase had made formal commitments for a few such loans within the last few days. Earlier, Chase had been reluc tant to extend such new style credits.

title: Observers Closely Watching the Activities of U.M.W.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14At the United Mine Workers head quarters here they whisper the, story of the union official who tried to mail an envelope con taining Xerox copies of three newspaper articles about the union's election campaign.

title: Jan Lowenbach, 92, Musicologist, Dies; ExCzech Arts Aide
description: Jan Lowenbach, musicologist and critic, formerly of Prague, died Sunday in Glens Falls, N. Y. He was 92 years old and lived at 17 West 54th Street.

title: Arizona Bank Elects
description: Robert D. Williams has been elected chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee of the First National Bank of Arizona. Edward M. Carson has been elected chief administrative officer. Sherman Hazeltine, who has served as chairman and chief executive, will continue to serve as board chairman.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: You recently published two contri butions regarding postalrate increases on secondclass mail: Postmaster Gen eral Klassen's Aug. 2 OpEd article and Senator Edward Kennedy's re sponse, the Aug. 8 letter, criticizing the increase.

title: Fischer Asks for Copy Of Spassky's Excuse
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 14Bobby Fischer asked to day for a photocopy of the medical certificate that Boris Spassky submitted yesterday in postponing the 14th game of the $250,000 world cham pionship chess match. The certificate cited only med ical reasons.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The spectators who may have needed a scorecard to identify the political new comers dominating the Demo cratic National Convention will not need one to identify the Republican delegates from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut as they assemble in Miami Beach this weekend.

title: H.E.W. REVIEWING U.S. RELIEF RULES
description: The Secretary of Health, Edu cation and Welfare has been reviewing Federal fairhearing requirements in contested wel fare cases following an appea by Governor Rockefeller that they were costly and excessive in view of dueprocess pro tections already provided by New York State.

title: Worst Air Crash Killed 162 in Japan Last Year
description: The worst commercial air disaster on record was the collision of a Japanese do mestic airliner and a Japa nese air force jet near Morio ka in the Japanese Alps on July 30, 1971, in which 162 persons died.

title: Senate Panel Votes Urban State Gains In Revenue Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The Senate Finance Committee further revised its revenue sharing formula today to help somewhat the relatively ur banized states. But uncertaintly remained as to when the Sen ate would take up the bill.

description: The New York Telephone Company is phasing out its verification service on busy signals because, it said yes terday, it found that the public was using the service too much.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Justice Department asked the United States Court of Ap peals for the Sixth Circuit in Cincinnati today to stay a Dis trict Court order that required massive busing to achieve school integration in Detroit and its suburbs.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (UPI)Ken Henderson of the San Francisco Giants was named the National League's player of the week today, fol lowing a torrid 13 for 21 bat ting spurt which included three homers, three doubles and a triple.

title: Mets' Rauch Beats Red Sox, 41, In Washington Exhibition Game
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Bob Rauch allowed only two hits, stroked two singles and batted in a run during his six inning stint tonight as the New Red Sox, 41, in an exhibition game before a crowd of 32,432.

title: Crocker Bank Sets New Unit
description: The Crocker Bank, San Fran cisco, said yesterday it had ap plied to the Federal Reserve Board for permission to estab lish an international banking subsidiary in Chicago to be called the Crocker MidAmerica International Bank. A number of major banks have established such international banking sub sidiaries in recent years.

title: C.A.B. SEEKS CURBS ON COAST FINANCIER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)  C. Arnbolt Smith, a wealthy West Coast financier, illegally acquired control of a California air taxi company, Golden West Airlines, while in control of various surface transportation interests including the Yellow Cab Company of Los Angeles, the Civil Aeronautics Board's Bureau of Operating Rights said today.

title: Miss Madden, Weisenborn Win Mixed Foursome Golf
description: ESSEX FELLS, N.J., Aug. 14 Aileen Madden of Old Tappan and Thomas Weisenborn of Essex Fells won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's mixed foursome tournament to day.

title: Israel Imposes Life Sentences On 2 Arab Women Hijackers
description: SARAFAND, Israel, Aug. 14 Two Arab women guerrillas were sentenced to life imprisonment by a military tribunal here to day for their part last May in the hijacking of a Belgian air liner flying to Israel.

title: Nixon Prods Auto Makers To Cancel '73 Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The White House has intervened di reedy with the automobile in dustry in an attempt to get the four manufacturers to with draw their proposed price in creases on 1973 model cars.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 14  With no uncertainty left about its 1972 convention, the Repub lican party began drafting to day the rules that will govern the selection of its 1976 Presi dential nominee.

title: CHINA USES TRADE TO COURT LATINS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 14 (Reuters)China is using trade to develop friendships in Latin America.

title: PAUL S. PHENIX
description: OLD GREENWICH, Colin., Aug. 14Paul S. Phenix, a for mer executive of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad and director of the Trust Company of Old Greenwich, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 299 River side Avenue.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Republicans will keynote their convention next Monday with a woman, a black Senator and an urban mayor  plus a 14minute record of the Nixon Admin istration.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: WESTBURY FETE HAS BIG DEFICIT
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 14 The Festival of Hope, the weekend rock festival that was supposed to net its sponsors, the Easter Seal Society of Nas sau Country, more than $300,000, was apparently a fi nancial disaster that may have to be absorbed by the chari table organization.

title: WILLIAM D. HOARD JR.
description: FORT ATKINSON, Wis., Aug. 14 (AP)  William Dempster Hoard Jr., publisher of The Daily Jefferson County Union, died today at a hospital here after a short illness. He was 75 years old.

title: TWO TOP OFFICERS RESIGN FROM H.I.P.
description: The two top executive offi cers of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York re signed yesterday in the latest phase of a running dispute over the future structure and financing of H.I.P., the second largest prepaid health insur ance group in the country.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Picture Traps
description: WEST MILLBURY, Mass. After spending a day afield with Jack Swedberg, official wildlife photographer for the Massachusetts Division of Fisheries and Game, it is dif ficult to imagine how this big energetic man is able to spend countless hours cooped up in tiny blinds waiting for his subjects to appear.

title: RAIDER FIELD GOALS DEFEAT COLTS, 160
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 14 (AP)George Blanda, who will be 45 years old on the opening day of the National Football League season, warmed up to night by kicking three field goals as the Oakland Raiders posted a 160 victory over the Baltimore Colts in a preseason game.

title: TRADING IN L & M. IS INVESTIGATED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange are investi gating recent trading activity in the stock of Liggett & Myers, Inc.

title: A. H. VON SCHRADER, FORMERLY OF C.I.A.
description: Atreus Hargadine von Schra der Jr., who retired in Febru ary after 21 years with the Central Intelligence Agency, died last Wednesday of a heart attack in Bar Harbor, Me. He was 60 years old and lived in Washington and Cazenovia, N. Y.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)  Three companies were chosen today to build nine advanced prototype urban transit buses in an $18million Federally sponsored design competition. Booz Allen Applied Research, Bethesda, Md., prime contractor for the Urban Mass Transportation Administration, awarded subcontracts of $7.2million to the General Motors Truck and Coach Division, Pontiac, Mich.; $6million to the A. M. General Corporation, Wayne, Mich., and $5.1million to Rohr Industries, Chula Vista, Calif.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Tombs for Owners to Join Pets Are Offered in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 14 (UPI)One hundred and four tombs in which the ashes of the owners of pets can rest forever with those of their dogs or cats have been offered for sale by a Japa nese animal cemetery.

title: Mexico, Canada Seniors Gain
description: Teams representing Mexico and Canada advanced to the elimination semifinals of the In ternational senior team tennis competition for the Stevens Cup yesterday at the Town Tennis Club.

title: LABORATORY OFFERS DANCE BY STRETCHER
description: Robert Streicher's Narcissus Descending, presented at the American Theater Laboratory Sunday afternoon, was a mild ly inconclusive solo with an utterly fascinating set of pro gram acknowledgments. Among those given special thanks were D. H. Lawrence, Simone de Beauvoir and Senator Thomas F. Eagleton.

title: Corruption Confirmed
description: The State Commission of Investigation's annual report indicts the whole criminal justice system for failing ade quately to respond to New York City's narcotics problem. Not only does it back up the Knapp Commission's recent finding that corruption within the Police Department is widespread, but it reaches out to note disturbing in adequacies in the approach of the city's school system and its Addiction Services Agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The proposed amendment to the United States Constitution, which was reported to the floor of the House of Representatives by the House Rules Committee on Aug. 1, has been widely characterized as an antibusing amend ment designed to [prohibit] busing to desegregate the schools.

title: Mrs. Boddie Leads Qualifiers In U.S.Women's Amateur Golf
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (AP) Mrs. Barbara White Boddie of Shreveport, La., carded a three overpar 75 today and led after the first of two 18hole quali fying rounds in the 72d annual United States women's amateur golf tournament at the St. Louis Country Club.

title: I.B.M. Will Underwrite Telecast of the Match
description: The International Business, Machines Corporation re sponding to a request for cor porate support, said yester day it would underwrite the production and broadcast charges for the remainder of WNET Channel 13's recrea tions of the Boris Spassky Bobby Fischer chess cham pionship games.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN ?? BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MAGAZINESADVT.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The next big question in politics is whether the Republicans can force Senator McGov ern to run against the President.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 14  The San Juan Racing Association, Inc., announced today that the strike at the El Comandante race track here had been settled over the last weekend. The strike began on July 16 as the result of a controversy over the terms of a new collective bargaining agreement. There was a loss of 13 race days. Racing will resume at the track on Wednesday.

title: SUIT IS DISMISSED ON WILLOWBROOK
description: A Richmond County Family Court judge ruled most re gretfully yesterday that his court had no jurisdiction over horrible conditions at the Willowbrook State School for mental defectives on Staten Island.

title: TWO SLAIN COUSINS ARE BURIED IN BRONX
description: Funeral services were con ducted yesterday in St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church, 312 East 110th Street, for Philip John and Philip D. Manfredi, two nephews of Joseph Man fredi, who is said to be a top lieutenant of the reputed organ izedcrime overlord, Carlo Gam bino.

title: 3 Are Slain in Home Near New Haven
description: NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 14A lumber company presi dent, his wife and their daugh ter were found stabbed to death this morning in their ran sacked home in a fashionable section of this New Haven suburb.

title: NADER UNIT ASSAILS JET SMOKE EFFORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Ralph Nader's Aviation Con sumer Action Project said to day that smoke control pro grams of the airlines actually may increase rather than re duce pollution hazards.

title: Personalities: Rude Awakening
description: When Norman Raben awoke yesterday in his home at Loudonville, N. Y., and opened his mail, he must have been very unhappy. Last Memorial Day, he had sailed his 50 foot sloop La Forza del Des tino in the Storm Trysail Club's aroundBlock Island Race and won an corrected time. It was his boat's first time out. The club, over the weekend, mailed the official standings to the 196 skippers of the yachts that had raced last May, and Raben had been placed third over all, not first. Edgar L. Raymond Jr., race committee chairman, explained the delayand the switchon the unavailability of measurement certificates, which are used to figure the handicaps of each boat. Rab en's craft, being new, had only tentative rating.

title: Murder of Wrong Pair Recalls '39 Slaying in Bronx
description: The morning of July 25, 1939, dawned like any other workday for Irving Penn, a 42 yearold music publishing exec utive of regular habits, modest means and quiet family life. He had, as the police later put it, not an enemy in the world as he emerged from his apart ment house at 250 East 178th Street, the Bronx, promptly at 8 A.M. that day.

title: SOLOMON OUSTED AT CANADIAN NET
description: TORONTO, Aug. 14 (AP) Ivan Molina, a littleknown player from Colombia, upset Harold Solomon, a United States Davis Cup star, 61, 64, today in the first round of the $72,600 Canadian open tennis championships.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It is not at all unusual for a New York store to open suburban branches or even move out to the suburbs, but Steve Israel and Bill Kirksey, both natives of Greensboro, N. C., did it the other way round.

title: Frozen Mouse Embryos Grow in Foster Mothers
description: A technique has been de veloped for mass producing mouse embryos, deep freezing them for longterm storage, and then, at some later time, im planting them in foster mothers for gestation and birth.

title: A.E.C. Weighs Waste Site
description: CARLSBAD, N. M., Aug. 14 (AP)The Atomic Energy Com mission is studying the Carls bad area as a possible burial ground for radioactive waste from the commercial nuclear power industry, an A.E.C. offi cial said today. Dr. Frank Pitt man, the commission's director of waste management and trans portation, told community lead ers here that canisters of radio active waste could be lowered 2,000 feet deep into salt beds that are 200 to 300 feet thick.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press)  Canada had a $118million deficit in its balance of international payments for goods and services during April, May and June this year, Statistics Canada reported today. This brought the deficit for the first half of 1972 to $650million, which compares with a surplus of $181million in the first half of last year.

title: Revision Open for Comment
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today changes in its original rule gov erning the eventual creation of a composite tape or interroga tion system to cover trans actions in all securities mar kets.

title: Opera: Poppea at Lenox
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14 It was a potentially brilliant idea to move Monteverdi's 330yearold opera, The Cor onation of Poppea, Into the indefinite but definitely scary future, as Ian Strasfogel's Music Theatre Project did last night at Tanglewood's West Barn.

title: 18 Food Concerns Cited by City For Violating the Health Code
description: Eighteen restaurants and other foodprocessing establish ments in the city are on the Health Department's latest list of places having healthcode vi olations.

title: Aide Denies Waldheim Sent Protest to African Republic
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 14A spokesman denied to day that Secretary General Waldheim had sent a message to Gen. Jean Bdel Bokassa, President of the Central African Republic, protesting beatings that led to the death of some men serving prison terms for theft.

title: Governor Clarifies Remarks on Exit of Soviet Jews
description: Governor Rockefeller, return ing from a fourday visit to Is rael, said yesterday that there had been a meeting of the minds between Mr. Nixon and the Soviet hierarchy on the emigration of Soviet Jews and that the proof of the pud ding lay in the increased flow of Soviet Jews to Israel so far this year to win over American Jewish voters for President Nixon.

title: Vietnam Withdrawals Now Top 500,000 Mark
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug? 1.4 (UPI)  The with drawal of 2,200 Americans last week raised to more than 500,000 the number of United States troops pulled out of South Vietnam since President Nixon began the military cutback here three years ago, the United States command said today.

title: Guyana Reported Out
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Aug. 14 (AP)Guyana will not be represented at the Olympics because of Rhodesia's partici pation, The Georgetown Daily Chronicle reported in a front page story today.

title: Nixon Back at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., Aug. 14 (UPI)  President Nixon flew back to his Camp David moun tain retreat today for an ex tended stay to wrap up legisla tive and administrative matters before he plunges into his re election campaign.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) George Meany, A.F.L.C.I.O. president, ordered the Colorado Labor Council today to rescind its endorsement of Senator George McGovern, the Demo cratic Presidential nominee, within a week or face disci plinary action.

title: EFFORTS TO CURB GRAFT CRITICIZED
description: The inspector general of the city's Housing and Develop ment Administration conceded yesterday that he had fewer than 10 undercover agents working against graft in the 4,300employe agency.

title: O.E.O. OUSTS AIDES OVER YOUTH TOURS
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J. Aug. 14The district director of the Office of Economic Opportunity for New Jersey and his deputy have been removed from their posts as an outgrowth of the controversy surrounding the trips of 67 Monmouth County high school youths to Europe and Africa.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: If the contents of the letter on the death penalty published July 31 were rated for objectivity, the mark would he equivalent to that of a diatribe by a racial bigot.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Anniuersaries

title: Police Sergeants Back Pact
description: A 30month contract for the city's 2,600 police sergeants was approved by the unanimous vote of delegates of the Ser geants Benevolent Association yesterday. The vote, at Bruck ner Manor, 2778 Bruckner Boulevard, the Bronx, approved terms reached with the city last Friday. The agreement raises base pay, including differential adjustment won previously, from an annual fig ure of $14,235 at the end of 1970 to a figure of $18,590 starting next Jan. 1.

title: U.S. PICKS SQUAD FOR SOCCER PLAY
description: A squad of 22 players was named yesterday to represent the United States against Can ada in the opening game of the soccer World Cup qualify ing rounds. The game is sched uled for Sunday at St. John's Newfoundland.

title: Times Sq. Landmark Returns in Puff of Smoke
description: Times Square, which kicked the smoking habit six years ago, has started puffing again and this time twice as much.

title: Ford Delivers New ArmorPlated Lincoln Continental for the President
description: DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP) The Ford Motor Company and the Secret Service an nounced today that Ford had built a new car for the Presi dent.

title: THAI PAPER REPORTS LAOS TRUCE ACCORD
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Mon day, Aug. 15 (Agence France Presse)The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma and the Pathet Lao leader, Prince Souphanouvong, have agreed on a general ceasefire through out Laos in a move toward what both call national com promise, the Englishlanguage daily The Bangkok Post report ed here today without giving any sources for its information.

title: For Cunningham, New Cougar, Only Names and Shirts Change
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 14  The team's name on a basketball uniform is of little concern to Billy Cunningham. He estimated he has worn more than 100 uniforms of different names, colors and numbers since he grew up in Brooklyn where, he said, playground basketball was war.

title: Discontent Among Youths Reported to Increase Crime in Canton
description: HONK KONG, Aug. 14Dis content among young people in China's Kwangtung Province, arising out of their objection to rural work assignments, has re portedly led to an upsurge of crime in Canton, the provincial capital, and has brought the number of refugees reaching Hong Kong to its highest level in 10 years.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bay State Lake Reopened
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP)Onota Lake was re opened after Dr. Harold Stein, a health commissioner, lifted a twodayold ban on swimming Saturday afternoon.

title: All the Joys of Cooking on a Woodburning Stove
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  In an age when most housewives can't wait to buy a new kitchen appliance, the few owners of woodburning cookstoves are an exception. Woodstove cooks generally hold on as long as they and the stoves last, sometimes 60 or 70 years.

title: Emigration Rise Hailed
