description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The White House to day hailed a recent sharp in crease in the number of Soviet Jews permitted to emigrate to Israel, but denied it had been the result of a secret deal Pres ident Nixon made in Moscow in May.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: Letters to the Editor

title: U.S. Strongly Endorses Soviet Ventures
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Commerce Secretary Peter G. Peterson said today that he saw great promise in the possibility of American com panies engaging in joint ven tures with Soviet enterprises to exploit the Soviet Union's un tapped energy and raw ma terials, such as natural gas, oil, platinum, copper, chrome, zinc and timber.

title: Texas Strike Backed Here
description: The Executive Council of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O and representatives of local ventral labor bodies through out the state have adopted a resolution supporting the strike of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers against the Farah Manufacturing Company in Texas and seeking a boycott of Farah trousers and slacks sold nationally.

title: Swimmer's Appeal Rejected
description: LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP) Britain's National Swimming Association rejected today an appeal by its top Olympic medal hope, Ray Terrell, who was dropped from the squad following allegations of having smoked marijuana.

title: STRIKE IS FACTOR IN PENNANT RACES
description: In calculating pennant races this season, it must be remem bered that all teams will not play the same number of games. The players' strike caused can cellation of all games scheduled before April 15, and these will not be made up.

title: Miss Cooper, By 64, 62, Tops Miss Casals in Tennis
description: DENVER, Aug. 14 (UPI) Jill Cooper, of Britain, playing aggressive tennis, defeated Rosemary Casals today in the opening round of the $25,000 Virginia Slims of Denver tennis tournament.

title: Sardonic Humorist
description: There is a thin line between genius and insanity, Oscar Le vant once said. I have erased that line.

title: Storm's Effects Peril Livelihood Of Chesapeake Bay's Watermen
description: The Talk of the Eastern Shore

title: Aide to Lefkowitz Is One of 3 Indicted in $1.3Million Fraud
description: A $1.3million fraud conspir acy was charged in a Federal indictment here yesterday against two business executives and a former Better Business Bureau employe who is now a public relations assistant for State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Communism: 125 Years Later
description: These are excerpts from a debate appearing in The New Statesman be tween Herbert Marcuse, professor of philosophy at the University of Cali fornia at San Diego, and Raymond Aron, professor of philosophy at the Collage de France.

title: 2 A'S HOME RUNS TOP ORIOLES, 52
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 (AP) Mike Epstein and Joe Rudi slugged home runs and Bert Campaneris scored two Oak land runs after dazzling Balti more with his baserunning as the A's whipped the Orioles, 52, tonight in a battle of base ball's American League divi sion leaders.

title: U.S. Court Asked to Enjoin Construction of Waterway
description: ABERDEEN,. Miss., Aug. 14 Attorneys for the Environ mental Defense Fund and two other Mississippi plaintiffs filed a motion here today asking that construction of the Tennes seeTom Bigbee waterway be enjoined.

title: 2 Olympic Firsts Slated For W. German Woman
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 14 (AP)Heidi Schuel ler, a champion West German hurdler, will become the first woman to deliver the Olympic oath to athletes when the Munich Games open Aug. 26.

title: $10,000 Is Given By The Daily News For Fashion Event
description: The New York Daily News yesterday contributed $10,000 toward the financing of special events for the first Fall Fashion Festival, Sept. 19 to 26, spon sored by the city and all seg ments of the fashion industry.The contribution was pre sented to Mayor Lindsay in his office by W. H. James, presi dent of The Daily News, which will play a major role in a fashion event in the Herald Square area as well as sponsor ing a large theater party.

title: PATROLMAN IS HELD IN SHOOTING CASE
description: A Brooklyn patrolman was arrested and suspended from the Police Department last night for allegedly shooting a man on July 27 and then re porting that the victim was accidentally shot by an un known person, according to the police.

title: Bridge:Spingold Winners Capture Swiss Team Tourney Here
description: A team headed by Jeff Rubens, the victors in the Spingold knockout team championship at the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League last month, won the foursession Swiss team tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel last weekend, with a score of 168 victory points of a possible 240.

title: Lithuania Warns of Religious Backlash
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14Commu nists in Lithuania, faced this year by repeated outbursts of strong religious and nationalist feelings, are being admonished not to antagonize believers with crude, antireligious methods of propaganda.

title: Market Place: Quote Machine Race Still open
description: Whenever the International Business Machines Corpora tion decides to flex its muscles in a new area of business, the companies al ready competing there tend to look very closely at the security of their own posi tions.

title: Residency Law Voided
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP) Judge William T. Hodges of the United States District Court ruled unconstitutional today Florida's 60day residency re quirement for voting.

title: The Media Mob: Now Back to Walter.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14See if you can dream this daydream. It is the bottom of the fifth inning coming up here in the third game of the World Series at Yankee Stadium. The Yanks are trailing the Pirates 8 to 0 and Yankee fans are calling for a rally as Gene Michael steps into the batting box. But this looks like a quiet inning, with the Yanks sending up the tail end of their batting order. So let's switch now to Mel Allen, who is with exCub manager Leo Durocher down in the third base boxes. Mel, is this rumor we have heard up here true that Leo will be managing next season in Oakland?

title: Poppy Jackie Rallies to Win
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (UPI)Last going into the turn, It D. S. Stable's Poppy Jackie circled a sixhorse field, took the lead in the stretch and drew out to a twolength vic tory over the 45 favorite Bless Me Pete, in the feature today at Liberty Bell race track. The victory was the fourth in seven starts here for Poppy Jackie, ridden by Doug Thomas. The 2 yearold filly paid 6.20, 2.60 and 2.80.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 Mr. Kleindienst said at a news conference here that the Justice Department had found no evi dence of criminal violations by Miss Fonda.

title: U.S. CONCERNS SET APPEAL IN CHILE
description: The Anaconda and Kennecott companies said yesterday they would ask a Chilean copper tribunal to reconsider a ruling that the companies owed the Chilean Government $774mil lion for excess profits. They conceded their chances for suc cess appeared slight.

title: College Student Is Seized With Opium From New Delhi
description: A 25yearold senior at State University at Cortland, N.Y., was charged with smuggling two pounds of opium into this country from New Delhi. The tarlike pungent substance is smoked in a pipe.

title: N.B.C,'S $3MILLION WINS FAIR LADY
description: The National Broadcasting Company has acquired televi sion rights to the 1964 movie version of My Fair Lady, starring Rex Harrison and Au drey Hepburn, for a sum re ported to be near $3million.

title: 156 Are Killedin Air Crash In a Suburb of East Berlin
description: BERLIN, Aug. 14An East German airliner crashed in suburb of East Berlin today and all 156 people aboard were killed, the East German press agency reported.

title: Indictments Accuse 2 Men Of StolenStock Scheme
description: Two Pennsylvania men were indicted yesterday on charges of having schemed to use a Bahamian bank account in transactions involving $1.5mil lion worth of stolen securities.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WHEELING, W. Va.. Aug. 14  Sargent Shriver does not simply draw a crowd. Wher Wher ever he goes he seems to reas semble parts of an extended coterie of influential people who will happily drop what they are doing to help him get elected Vice President.

title: HewittMcMillan Duo Wins
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The topseeded team of Bob Hewitt and Frew Mc Millan of South Africa won the United States claycourts tennis doubles title today by defeating Jaime Fillol and Pa tricio Cornejo of Chile, 62, 63. Hewitt had won the singles yesterday.

title: REDS, ON 16 HITS, ROUT BRAVES, 122
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 14 (UPI) Johnny Bench knocked in five runs and Pete Rose drove in three tonight as the Cincinnati Reds defeated Atlanta, 12.2, with a 16hit attack.

title: NIXON AIDES OPPOSE SCHOOLFUND PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Nixon Administra tion said today that it opposed a Democratic proposal to auth orize $2.2billion a year for five years in general aid to public schools. At the same time, it reaffirmed support for a pro posed tax credit of up to $200 a year for each pupil whose parents pay tuition to a private school.

title: Cowboys Call On Reeves As a No. 2 Quarterback
description: DALLAS, Aug. 14 (AP) Coach Tom Landry of Dallas moved a backfield coach, Dan Reeves, into the quarterback role behind Craig Morton today and shuffled Sid Gillman, for mer head coach, from the research and development de partment into Reeves's post.

title: City Becomes a Back Lot for 2 Films
description: Two movies, drawn from major successes in other media, began filming in the city yesterday. Both lay claim to a certain religious derivation and a certain zeal in maximizing the commer cial realizations of their themes.

title: The Two Quarterbacks for the Giants Try Out the Pocket for Size
description: The Giants and the Jets, em barked on a collision course for the bragging rights to New York, engaged in similar work outs yesterday at their respec tive training camps.

title: ExAide to Johnson Heads Texas Campaign for Nixon
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 14 (UPI) Larry Temple, a member of the policy committee of the Democratic National Committee since 1969, resigned today to become Texas state chairman of the Democrats for Nixon organization.

title: MACKELL ASSAILS REPORT OF LAXITY
description: The head of the State Com mission of Investigation and the Queens District Attorney, Thomas J. Mackell, exchanged strong words of criticism yes terday over a commission re port that said Mr. Mackell's office, the police, and the courts had been lax toward narcotics traffickers.

title: Nixon Aide Begins Job Coordinating Flood Relief
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., Aug. 14 The man designated by Presi dent Nixon to coordinate Fed eral flood recovery operation in this area began his assignment today with a briefing, a tour and a news conference.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 14 (AP)Gary Player will not compete in the United states professional match play championship at the Country Club of North Carolina Aug. 2627.

title: PARAGUAY YIELDS ON DRUG SUSPECT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 14  A Paraguayan appeals court to day agreed to the extradition of Auguste Joseph Ricord, de scribed by authorities here as head of one of the world's largest drugsmuggling rings, to face Federal charges of con spiring to import at least $60 million of illegal heroin into the country over a sixyear period.

title: PHILLIPS SEES END OF POLICE INFORMING
description: Patrolman William R. Phil lips, the Knapp Commission in former whose trial on murder charges ended in a hung jury last week predicted yesterday that never again would a po liceman inform on his fellow officers.

title: Foe in Vietnam Blows Up Another Munitions Depot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 15  Another South Vietnamese ammunition dump was blown up early yes terday as Communist com mando attacks, urban terrorism and shelling continued to in crease.

title: Check on Airline Discounts Finds Numerous Violations
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that a fourday old investigation at Kennedy International Airport had un covered substantial numbers of travelers flying on illegally discounted transAtlantic air line tickets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Camping Barred
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (UPI) Communist party officials, seek ing to prevent new fires during the driest, hottest summer of the century, today banned camping in the thousands of acres of forests within Mos cow's city limits, the newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva said.

title: Paolo Cardinal Giobbe Dies; Oldest in Sacred College at 92
description: ROME, Aug. 14Paolo Car dinal Giobbe, who was for 33 years one of the leading mem bers of the Vatican's diplo matic corps, died here today at the age of 92, the oldest mem ber of the Sacred College of Cardinals.

title: East GermanSwiss Pact
description: BERLIN, Aug. 14 (Reuters) East Germany and Switzerland today announced an exchange of trade missions that would have certain consular functions, the East German press agency, A.D.N., reported.

title: AMERICAN Y.C. CREW LEADS MIDGET SAIL
description: WESTPORT. Conn., Aug. 14 The American Yacht Club crew of Rye, N. Y., captained by Peter Becker, gained a 6 point lead yesterday in the qualifying series for the 47th annual Midget sailing cham pionship of Long Island Sound. The leaders had a secondplace finish and won two races off Cedar Point Y. C.

title: Mass Arrests Possible
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (AP)Attorney. General Rich ard G. Kleindienst predicted today that police forces would carry out mass arrests if there were any disruption of the Republican National Conven tion in Miami Beach.

title: Aussies Keep Upper Hand In Bid to Tie Test Cricket
description: LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) Strong batting by England's Barry Wood failed to wrest the advantage from Australia today on the fourth day of the fifth and final test cricket.

title: Penn Central Fallout
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission report on the collapse of the Penn Central Railroad does much more than shed disturbing new light on what brought the company down. It provides guidance on what must be done to prevent similar disasters, whether in railroads or other sectors of the economy.

title: Japan's Opening to China
description: Premier Kakuei Tanaka's decision to visit China late in September suggests confidence, based on sound ings in Peking, that he can reach a meeting of minds first with his allies and then with China on normalization of relations between Tokyo and Peking.

title: Environmental Priority
description: Rivalry between two leading Senate Democrats threat ens to kill for the current session a major piece of environmental legislation supported by the Administra tion, the National Governors Conference, environmental ists and a probable majority of Senators from both parties.

title: PROTESTERS GET MIAMI BEACH SITE
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 14  The City Council voted today to grant the use of Flamingo Park as a campsite for young protestors during the Repub lican National Convention next week.

title: PARK SAYS UNIFYING IS TASK FOR KOREAS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tues day, Aug. 15President Park Chung Hee called on foreign nations today to refrain from interfering with the current efforts of North Korea and South Korea to achieve national unification peacefully.

title: Heller Factoring Concern Improves Offer for a Bank
description: Merger News

title: BURGER ASKS END OF 3JUDGE COURTS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called upon Congress today to abolish threejudge Federal Dis trict courts. Congress created them 62 years ago as a states' right measure but the result has been that the Federal courts have been loaded with addi tional work.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The United States has the choice of site for this year's Davis Cup final against Rumania, Basil Reay, the secretary of the Davis Cup Nations, said today.

title: S. E. C. REQUESTS WIDER AUTHORITY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged Congress to day to broaden the S.E.C.'s au thority to protect securities transactions.

title: New Standard Set To Insure Safety Of Xray Diagnosis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Government announced today the establishment of a, new and stricter radiationpro tection standard for diagnostic Xray machines and components in a move designed to make Xray examinations safer for millions of Americans.

title: U.S. Sailors Back in Villefranche
description: VILLEFRANCHESURMER, France, Aug. 14The hotel guests complained about the noisy American sailors. The hotel owner complained to the prefect and for eight months the sailors did not come back. Then the bar owners and the shopkeepers complained to the mayor. The mayor complained to the ambassador and to the Min ister of Defense, and the sailors returned last week.

title: Books of The Times
description: Well, it's too bad, because I wanted to like The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing wanted, that is, to be able to recommend a crackling good yarn for a lazy August afternoon. But the little gargoyle that hangs on the edge of my imagination just would not stop dripping catcalls and wise cracks and other obstructions to the flight of romantic fancy that Marilyn Durham's first novel demands. So instead of rooting all the way for her pampered lady and mysterious outlaw to escape the clutches of the law and live happily ever after instead of getting lost in Mrs. Durham's Kodacolorprose romance between a good man trying to live down a crime of passion in his past and the woman who is trying to save himI had to sit there wincing in anticipation of the gargoyle's next ob streperous remark.

title: Gardner Takes Two Matches In Southampton Amateur Tennis
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 14John Gardner of Australia began defense of the United States amateur grasscourt ten nis championship today by win ning two matches at the Mea dow Club.

title: Peck's Crew Takes Lead In Junior Sailing Series
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y.Dav id Peck of Niantic, Conn., took a commanding lead today in the semifinals of the North American junior sailing champ ionships being held on Canan daigua Lake.

title: City to Build a Terminal for Trailerships
description: The city took another step yesterday in its bid to recap ture waterfront business that it has lost as Mayor Lindsay an nounced plans for a $16million trailership terminal on Staten Island.

title: Fall of Heiress's Husband Called Accident by Police
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) The husband of Candace Moss ler Garrison, who inherited mil lions of dollars, was locked out of their home and was try ing to enter through a third story window when he fell 40 feet onto a concrete patio, the police said today.

title: Criticism by McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Senator George McGovern said today that it was both cynical and cruel of President Nixon's agent, Nelson Rockefeller, to claim that Mr. Nixon had se cured an agreement permitting 35,000 Soviet Jews annually to migrate to Israel.

title: CRIPPLED MAN CUT AND ROBBED BY 2
description: Two 17yearold youths who, the police said, admitted to be ing drug addicts, were seized early yesterday in Brooklyn after they allegedly had slashed the throat of a crippled 53 yearold storekeeper in a rob bery.

title: Saigon Denies Report Of Torture in Prisons
description: SAIGON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) A South Vietnamese Gov ernment official today denied a report in The New York Times that political prison ers were being tortured in South Vietnamese jails.

title: PIERSON SETS PACE IN GOLF QUALIFYING
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 14Howard A. Pierson of River Vale (N. J.) Golf Club posted a 36hole score of 67, 76143 today and won the medal in sectional qualifying for the United States Amateur golf championship.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Seeks to Curb Gravestone Seller

title: U.S. Announces Selection Of Geneva for Arms Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (Reu ters)The United States and the Soviet Union will hold the second stage of their talks on the limitation of strategic arms in Geneva instead of alternat ing between Helsinki and Vien na, the State Department an nounced today.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION OFF 1.1% IN WEEK
description: Steel production last week totaled 2,418,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel In stitute reported yesterday. This was down 1.1 per cent from the 2,444,000 tons poured in the preceding week.

title: Soviet Finds Ancient Letter
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14 (AP)So viet archeologists found on a Black Sea Island a rolledup lead plate bearing a letter from an ancient Greek trader to his son, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. It said experts dated the plate to the sixteenth century B.C.

title: Sly and the Family Stone At Rock Festival Finale
description: When Sly and the Family Stone closed the Festival of Hope's twoday music festi val at Roosevelt Raceway early yesterday morning the feeling of anticlimax was in air. Sly has been known not to show up for perform ances on occasion, but he was raring to go this time; ironically, his readiness came at a time and place when it really didn't matter very much.

title: 2 Soldiers and a Civilian Slain In Ulster in Upsurge of Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug 14Two British soldiers and a civilian were killed in Belfast today.

title: Sinden Has 18 Days to Turn 35 Stars Into a Hockey Team for Canada
description: TORONTO, Aug. 14The hockey pride of Canada will be riding on the shoulders of 35 National Hockey League players, who started training here today for an eightgame series against the Soviet Union's national hockey team.

title: INVESTMENTS UP FOR SOUTH KOREA
description: SEOUL, Aug. 11 American and Japanese investment con tinued to flow into South Korea during the first half of this year despite chronic economic problems and unsettling politi cal developments here.

title: ZIBA BLUE, $4.60, SCORES BY NECK
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 14 (AP)Ziba Blue rallied from just off the pace to take the lead on the backstretch, then withstood the challenge of Ancient Line to win the $8,500 Drumtop Purse by a neck today at Monmouth Park.

title: Nissen Flyweight Victor
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 14 (AP)  The Australian and Commonwealth flyweight cham pion, Henry Nissen, defeated Italy's former European cham pion, Fernando Atzori, over 10 rounds tonight. Nissen weighed 114 pounds and Atzori 113.

title: Antibiotic Price Is Cut
description: Eli Lilly & Co. said yesterday that it had cut the price of Keflex, a widely used antibiotic of the cephalosporin family, by 13 to 21 per cent. The lower prices were made possible by production improvements, the company said.

title: Plan for Renovation Of Yankee Stadium Includes Elevators
description: The removal of pillars that have blocked fans' views, the installation of escalators and elevators to the upper seats, and shortened outfield dimen sions are part of the city's plans for modernizing Yankee Stadium, a Lindsay administra tion spokesman said last night.

title: City Ballet Lets Down German Critics
description: MUNICH, Aug. 14The New York City Ballet ended its four day visit to Munich tonight with a program of four of George Balanchine's ballets. The company received mixed, but predominantly negative, critical reaction after its two programs on Friday and Satur day.

title: CONTRACT AWARD
description: GREENVILLE, S. C., Aug. 14 (UPI)The Daniel Internation al Corporation said today its Daniel Construction Company unit was awarded a $405mil lion contract to build a 918,000 kilowatt nuclear power plant and a 480,000kilowatt hydro electric pumped storage station in South Carolina.

title: ISLANDERS' SLATE OPENS FAVORABLY
description: The New York Islanders, who will need all the help they can get, have received a mixed blessing by being able to stage their first seven National Hockey League games at home.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 14The Resolutions Committee of the Republican National Convention opened its hearings today in an atmosphere of harmony and with all signs indicating that President Nixon will get almost precisely the platform he wants for his reelection campaign.

title: 12 FENCERS NAMED AS U.S. OLYMPIANS
description: The 12 fencers who will rep resent the United States in the four individual championships in the Olympics were an nounced yesterday by Alan M. Ruben, captain of the team.

title: ASTROS, ON RALLY, DOWN GIANTS, 75
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) Roger Metzger's tworun double and a tworun single by Cesar Cedeno enabled the Houston Astros to overcome a fiverun deficit tonight and beat the San Francisco Giants 75.

title: Child in Parkway Collision Still in Critical Condition
description: One of the five children in Brooklyn family whose Volks wagen bus was in a headon collision on the Henry Hudson Parkway on Sunday night was still in critical condition last night.

title: Black U.S. Troops Clash With West German Police
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Aug. 14 (UPI)More than 100 black American soldiers clashed with dozens of West German policemen Saturday night after the police arrested a black sol dier.

title: S.E.C. Charges Are Denied by Bevan
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (AP)David C. Bevan, former financial vice president of the Penn Central Railroad, broke a long silence today to brand unfair and untrue Govern ment charges he misled the public for personal gain while America's biggest railroad col lapsed in bankruptcy.

title: Sales Gross $338,700
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP)  The Fasig Tipton annual yearling sales disposed of 62 horses of rac ing age today and grossed $338,700, an average of $5,463. There were 14 lots offered that went unsold.

title: DRIVE ON DRUG USE IN MILITARY SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)  Government auditors charged today that the mili tary crackdown on drugs had not been effective and may have driven servicemen from marijuana to heroin and other narcotics.

title: AUGUSTIN DUQUES, CLARINETIST, DEAD
description: Augustin Duques, who taught clarinet at the Juilliard School for more than 20 years and who performed as principal clarinetist with Arturo Tosca nini and the N.B.C. Symphony for 18 years, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 500 West 58th Street and at 91 Neck Road, Madison, Conn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ADIRONDACK GOES TO FAITHFUL GIRL
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14Faithful Girl of the Buckland Farm won the $28, 275 Adirondack by 2 lengths today in a commendable effort against four rivals.

title: Advertising:
description: For advertising and agen cies there was both good news and bad news in the 1972 report issued yesterday by Daniel Starch & Staff on the attitudes and buying hab its of the readers of 75 maga zines.

title: City Opera Tickets on Sale
description: Tickets for all performances of the New York City Opera's fall season at the New York State Theater are on sale at the theater box office at Lincoln Center. The season will open Aug. 30 and run through Nov. 12. It will comprise 87 perform ances of 17 operas among which will be new productions of Mo zart's Don Giovanni and Of fenhach's Les Conies d'Hoff mann.

title: Notes on People
description: Kurt Waldheim, Secretary General of the United Na tions, his wife and their tra veling party toured the Great Wall and one of the Ming tombs on their visit to China.

title: After Adoption, Their Families Are Interracial
description: DOBBS FERRY, N. Y.About 100 Westchester parents who have adopted children of races other than their own held a picnic over the weekend to show their children off to each other and to encourage prospective parents not to be afraid of interracial adoption. The parents are mem bers of Adoptive Families of Westchester, an organi zation that in two years has acquired 120 interracial families, a monthly news letter and, the members hope, a strong lobbying voice for legislative re form concerning adopted children.

title: Amin to Meet Rippon
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 14 (Reuters)  President Idi Amin of Uganda and Geoffrey Rippon, a special British envoy, agreed tonight to meet here tomorrow on the Uganda leader's plans to expel thousands of Asians.

title: Break Up the Yankees?
description: Rooting for the Yankees when they had a monopoly on winning pennants used to be like cheering for General Motors. The players were not ordinary mortals but super men in knickers. In the summers of Ruth, Gehrig and Laz zeri, and later Dimaggio, Mantle and Maris, the cry Break up the Yankees! was heard in the afternoon land. They were unfair to organized baseball players, a closed cor poration of greatness.

title: Legion to Hear Candidates
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (UFO President Nixon and Senator George McGovern will visit the 54 annual national convention of the American Legion which opens here Friday, spokesmen said today. Mr. McGovern is to appear Aug. 23. Mr. Nixon will appear the next day.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A proposed secondary offer ing of 1.2 million shares of com mon stock of Johnson & John son was announced yesterday by Kuhn Loeb & Co. which will head an underwriting syndicate for the issue in the near future, subject to market conditions. The company stock was down  at 130 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Based on this figure, the pro posed offering would have a value of more than $156mil lion. The offer will be made, the announcement said, for various Johnson family trusts, none of which is affiliated with the company.

title: Summer School Course Uses Sports to Inspire Youths to Read
description: In the second paragraph, the teacher wrote on the blackboard, the author speaks of a dynasty. Explain the meaning of the dynasty.

title: AMEX AND OTC CLIMB SLIGHTLY
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market managed yesterday to finish with modest gains after increased selling in the afternoon erased some of the earlier advances.

title: Mayor Rejects Idea to Halt Construction on Forest Hills Project
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that a temporary halt in construction of the disputed lowincome housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, was not necessary, and added he want ed to examine a new proposal to turn one of the three build ings into middleincome hous ing.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Leaders of 25 unions in the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Or ganizations announced today the formation of a national labor committee to work for the election of Senator George McGovern.

title: Philippines Counts the Huge Cost of Flood Damage and Looks Abroad for Aid
description: MANILA, Aug. 14The vis ible evidence and preliminary calculations make it clear that the damage caused by the floods in central Luzon has been enormous.

title: Ironworkers Due to Return To Work After Accord Here
description: The Building Trades Em ployers Association reported another agreement yesterday in the construction dispute here, reducing to eight the member of unions still on strike.

title: Clark Says North Vietnam May Free a Few P.O. W.'s
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 Ramsey Clark, a former United States Attorney General, said here today that he thought that a few American prisoners of war would be released soon by North Vietnam.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: LEARN CHESS WITH YOUR CHILDREN ILLUS. BOOK THE ROYAL GAME SHOWS HOW. AT BOOKSTORESADVT. Vanguard Press, 424 Madtson Ave., N.Y.C.

title: Nixon Gets Bill to Extend Aid to 1971 Disaster Victims
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)The House passed and sent to President Nixon today authority for the Small Busi ness Administration to make disaster relief loans to victims of natural catastrophies dating to Jan. 1, 1971.

title: A Program to Promote Black Patrolmen Into the Police Command Structure Gets Under Way in Dayton
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 14 Responding to demands from its black community, the city of Dayton has embarked on a program to promote blacks into the police command struc ture.

title: Orbiting Lab's LiftOff Set
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Aug. 14 (UPI)America's heaviest and most complex unmanned space observatory was mounted on its rocket today for launching next Monday into an orbit 460 miles high, The 4,000pound Stargazer, an Orbiting Astro nomical Observatory, was bolted to an AtlasCentaur rocket at Launch Complex 36. It is sched uled to take off at 6:28 A.M., Monday.

title: Dow Up 9.33 to 973.51, Its Highest in 44 Months
description: A surge of strength in blue chip stocks yesterday sent the DowJones industrial average the market's bestknown indi catorto its highest level in nearly 44 months.

title: McLain's Wife Files Suit
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (UPI) Sharon McLain, wife of the At lanta Braves' pitcher, Denny McLain, filed for a separation from her husband today on grounds of desertion and mental cruelty. Mrs. McLain, daughter of the baseball Hall of Famer, Lou Boudreau, charged that her husband deserted her and their four children Aug. 4 and re fused to support the family.

title: Fulbright and Jackson Clash in ArmsPact Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Senator J. W. Fulbright and Senator Henry M. Jackson ac cused each other of arrogance today as Senate consideratian of the offensiveweapons agree ment with the Soviet Union be came increasingly caught up in a struggle between the two Democrats.

title: GTE Sylvania to Phase Out Its Buffalo Plant Gradually
description: BUFFALO, August 14 (AP) GTE Sylvania, Inc., announcedi today it would phase out its Buffalo plant, which employs 450, over the next several months.

title: Business Briefs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The Japanese Finance Ministry is considering a plan to supply longterm, low interest dollar loans to enable private concerns here make emergency imports of United States goods, offi cials said today. The plan is designed to cut Japan's large trade surplus with the United States, which is expected to total between $3.5billion and $3.8billion this year, they said. The United States has been pressing for a reduc tion by means of onetime imports.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK SHOWS PROFIT DROP
description: The Chemical New York Cor poration announced yesterday that its net operating earnings dropped 24.6 per cent in July to $4.47million, or 33 cents a share, from $5.9million or 43 cents a share in the year earlier month.

title: Police Say a Hired Killer Slew 2 in Error
description: Two businessmen shot to death Friday night in an upper East Side restaurant were ap parently gunned down by a hired killer who mistook them for members of the Mafia family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., Police Commissioner Patrick. V. Murphy said yesterday.

title: Marijuana Registry Ended
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 14 (AP)  Gov. Ronald Reagan has signed a bill repealing a re quirement that persons con victed of misdemeanor use or possession of marijuana regis ter with the police and nar cotics offenders, his office said today.

title: OUR BACH GROUP PLAYS 4 CANTATAS
description: The performances of four Bach cantatas by the Our Bach Concert Ensemble at Philhar monic Hall Sunday night were neither as proprietary nor as cozy as the name might imply.

title: Advertising: 7 Crown Occasion
description: There's going to be a big celebration next month in Montreal to mark a big occa sion: the 25th anniversary of Seagram's 7 Crown's status as the largest selling liquor brand in the United States.

title: 4 Yankee Errors Help Royals Win, 30
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 14  New York Yankee hitters, who had been doing well lately, found themselves overmatched against Bruce Dal Canton and Norm Angelini tonight, and ab sorbed a 30 defeat at the hands of the Kansas City Royals.

title: ANDERSON SCORES BANKS ON RECORDS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) Jack Anderson, the columnist, gave the Senate Banking Com mittee what he said were memorandums of the Federal Bureau of Investigation on three political activists, Jane Fonda, Dr. Benjamin M. Spock and Floyd B. McKissick, today to prove that the F.B.I. has virtually unlimited access to private bank account records.

title: Jackson Says Russians Lied About Subs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 15 Senator Henry M. Jackson charged today that the Russians had lied to President Nixon at the Moscow summit meeting in May about the number of Soviet missilelaunching sub marines under construction or deployed.

title: Reward Program Pays Off As Bank Suspect Is Seized
description: A 20year old New York City man was arrested by the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation yesterday and charged with bank robbery, through a pro gram offering rewards for as sistance in such arrests.

title: REOPENS EFFORT TO REFORM PLAN
description: The fiveman committee set ??p to manage the Health In surance Plan of Greater New York spent yesterday meeting with representatives of its medical groups as part of an effort to chart an immediate course of action for the finan cially troubled organization.

title: China's First Veto?
description: Mrs. Indira Gandhi celebrated the 25th anniversary India's independence yesterday with a renewed pledge to spur social and economic development for 585 million Indians. Her ability to make good on this promise will depend in large measure on her success in fulfilling another anniversary commitment to establish lasting peace between India, Bangladesh and Pakistan.

title: New Gas Company Planned
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Coastal States Gas Produc ing Company said today it would establish a new parent corporation called the Coastal States Gas Corporation, which would control the Coastal States Gas Producing Company and a new operation engaged in the manufacture of substitute nat ural gas.

title: 46 Banks Are Involved
description: The Leasco Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had completed arrangements to bor row $150million from 46 do mestic and international banks.

title: NOFAULT U.S. LAW OPPOSED BY A.B.A.
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 The American Bar Association opposed today proposed Fed eral legislation that would cre ate a nationwide nofault Sys tem for handling personal in jury claims arising out of auto mobile accidents.

title: Rev. Louis J. Gallagher, 87, Boston College Head in '30's
description: NEEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP)  The Rev. Louis J. Gal lagher, president of Boston Col lege from 1932 to 1937, died yesterday at Glover Memorial Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: Gardner Upset in Amateur
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 8Henry Bunis of Cincinnati, a 19yearold sophomore at Co lumbia University, upset the defender, John Gardner of Aus tralia, 46, 76, 63, today in the second round of the Unit ed States amateur grasscourt tennis championships at the Meadow Club.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Long Island realestate broker was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $2,500 in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday for having submitted false applications and credit information to the Federal Housing Administration. The assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the case, Anthony T. Accetta, said it was the first conviction and sentencing arising from a Federal grandjury investiga tion into F.H.A. loan frauds in the metropolitan area.

title: CLARK DEPLORES SILENCE ON WAR
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 Ramsay Clark said here last night that he had been wrong not to speak out against the Vietnam war when he was Deputy Attorney General and then Attorney General in Pres ident Johnson's Cabinet while the war was expanding.

title: Music: A Memorable Bach Concerto in D Minor
description: Rosalyn Tureck and Szy mon Goldberg play other mu sic, but when one hears their names it is Bach's that comes to mind. The two art ists pooled their talents and expertise at Monday night's Mostly Mozart Festival, and made a memorable splash in Bach's Clavier Concerto in D minor.

title: AUTO MAKERS GET A NIXON DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 The Nixon Administration, in tensifying its pressure on the automobile industry to cancel or moderate proposed price in creases for 1973 models, told the manufacturers today that it wanted an answer by the end of the week.

title: PRICES ARE BOWER ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthe counter market ended lower yesterday for the first time in six sessions as profit taking weakened both lists.

title: Pierre Brasseur Is Dead at 66; French Actor Was Playwright
description: BOLZANO, Italy, Aug. 15 Pierre Brasseur, a popular French actor and playwright, died at a hotel in Brunico, near here, last evening after being taken ill on a movie set. He was 66 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15A State Department spokesman, asked to comment on the Bang kok newspaper article, said to day that his department had not been able to confirm the report.

title: BUILDING INCREASE LAID TO RENT LAWS
description: The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal assert ed yesterday that a 40 per cent increase in authorized new con struction of apartment units in New York City was largely the result of decontrol of vacant apartments enacted by the Leg islature last year.

title: July Industrial Production Rose Slightly; Aug. 110 Car Sales Gained on Daily Basis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Industrial production, partly hampered by the effects of tropical storm Agnes, rose only moderately in July for the third consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Misses Durr, Melville Win
description: DENVER, Aug. 15 (AP)  Francoise Durr of France and Kerry Melville of Australia tri umphed in firstround play to day in the $25,000 Virginia Slims international tennis tour nament.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Things are falling together beautifully for George Foll mer, and they couldn't hap pen to a more deserving driver, In this year's Trans American series Follmer has won the manufacturers's championship for javelin and the personal title for himself; in the CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup, he has won two of the four races run. Now comes word that Foll mer will have a firstclass Indianapolistype car in the California 500 at Ontario on Sept. 3. The ride is made possible by a deal between the two car owners for whom Follmer is working this season. Roy Woods has purchased from Roger Penske the McLarenOffensauser in which Mark Donohue set the qualifying record and, for a while, led last year's Cali fornia 500. Penske will con centrate his Ontario effort on the McLarenOffy driven by Gary Bettenhausen.

title: Theater: The Young Vic
description: LONDON, Aug. 15How to get young people to go to the theater is said to be a perennial problem, although I personally think it is a prob lem easily overstressed. In any event, it has clearly been solved by a very vigorous British theater company called the Young Vic. This is an offshoot of Britain's Na tional Theater and is one of the liveliest troupes, indeed possibly the liveliest, in Bri tain. And young people flock to itthe prices are cheap, the air is informal and prod uctionsare wild, irreverent and adventurous.

title: Bridge: DoubleDummy Play Is Easy If All 4 Hands Can Be Seen
description: In an international cham pionship the commentators and spectators who watch BridgeORama or VuGraph are able to play doubledum mythey can work out the best line of play for both sides without having to judge the position of unseen cards.

title: Meeting of Colombo Aides Linked to Narcotics Trade
description: A major meeting to deter mine whether the Mafia family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. should turn to narcotics to in crease declining revenues was in the making last Friday night at the Neopolitan Noodle res taurant when a gunman killed two businessmen.

title: G. O. P. Panel Widens UrbanState Role
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 15  A new power pattern for the 1976 Republican National Convention that would give more influence to the large urban states was approved tonight after a day long struggle between liberal and conservative party leaders.

title: $90,000 LOSS CITED AT KENNEDY CENTER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) Sloppy management has caused the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to lose at least $90,000, the General Accounting Office re ported today.

title: Youth Said to Be Dying Of I.R.A.Bomb Chemical
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, Aug. 15 (AP)A 19 yearold youth who is a mem ber of the Irish Republican Army is dying in a hospital here because, the I.R.A. is using a chemical for explo sives that can be far more dangerous for the bombers than for the bombed, the British Army said today.

title: MAXIMIN TOUART, LONG A PHYSICIAN
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 15 Dr. Maximin D. Touart, who retired last year after prac ticing since 1920 here and at 30 East 42nd in New York, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, on whose staff he had served for half a century. He was 88 years old and lived on Howe Place.

title: Arts Post Created
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) Mrs. Fannie Taylor, director of arts programs at the Uni versity of Wisconsin, was named today to a newly created posi tion of director of program in formation at the National En dowment for the Arts. An nouncing the selection, Nancy Flanks, chairman of the endow ment, said the post was estab lished in response to the grow ing need for more printed ma terial, films and publications.

title: U.S. Air Force Apologizes For Distributing Editorial
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15 (AP)  The United States Seventh Air Force apologized today for baying distributed to about 25 newsmen copies of an editorial in the Aug. 7 issue of Aviation Week & Space Technology that reflected the official Government position on the bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Philippines in Flood Appeal
description: The Philippine Consul Gen eral, Ernesto C. Pineda, ap pealed yesterday for contribu tions for the relief of more than six million victims of floods that have devastated his country over the last two weeks. Con tributions may be sent to the Philippine Consulate General Flood Victim Fund, 15 East 66th Street, New York, N. Y. 10021.

title: Solar Storm Studied By U.S. Spacecraft
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)United States space craft have discovered a vio lent solar storm that may have produced the highest energy radiation ever record ed from the sun, the National Aeronautics and Space Ad ministration said today.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon nominat ed Representative Frank T. Bow, Republican of Ohio, to replace Robert M. Sayre as Ambassador to Panama. The 71yearold Mr. Bow was elected to the House in 1950 and was ranking minority member of its Appropria tions Committee before an nouncing his retirement from Congress.

title: U.S. Defers Until '73 a Ban On Irish Airlines in State
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) The State Department said today that action on a proposal to bar Irish International Air lines from New York airports had been deferred until next year.

title: VERCHE B. FRENCH
description: WESTON, Conn., Aug. 15 Verche 13. French, a partner in Russell & French, executive personnel agency, died yester day in Roosevelt Hospital, New York. She was the wife of Thomas A. Mealey Jr. and lived here at 21 Broad Street.

title: Diners' Club or Just Dinars, Yugoslav Consumer Is King
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15 In Yugoslavia's variation of Marxism, which risks being termed creditcard Communism by some wag now that the Din ers' Club is enrolling members here, the consumer is king. Nis needs, tastes and whims guide much of the country's economic activity.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Ever since Billy Martin was a street kid in Oakland, Calif., getting into fights under his square name of Alfred Manuel Pesano, he has been characterized by what Joseph Conrad called an open, generous, frank, barbarous reck lessness.

title: $380.MILLION LOSS SEEN ON MEDICARE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) The Federal Government may have paid $380million in excess Medicare claims to hospitals since 1967, Representative Les Aspin said today.

title: McGovern Bars Briefings By Kissinger as Unhelpful
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 15Senator George McGovern declined a Presidential invita tion to be briefed on the Vietnam situation by Henry A. Kissinger because, he said here today, official White House briefings customarily go wide of the mark.

title: CEASEFIRE REPORT IN LAOS IS REFUTED
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  Pre mier Souvanna Phouma today denied a Bangkok newspaper report that he had reached agreement on a general cease fire with Prince Souphanou vong, head of the Pathet Lao antiGovernment forces.

title: Champion Wins in Middle Game, Then Blunders
description: In yesterday's 14th game of the world championship chess match, Boris Spassky outplayed Bobby Fischer in the middle game, winning a pawn. But the champion from the Soviet Union threw away his winning chances by committing a blunder on his 27th move, permitting the Amer ican challenger to equalize.

title: House Votes $1.6Billion in Relief Funds for the Victims of Tropical Storm Agnes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPIThe House unanimously voted $1.6billion in disaster relief for victims of the trop ical storm Agnes today despite, warnings that much of the money might be wasted on fraudulent claims.

title: House Panel Says Polluters Are Not Fought Vigorously
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 15 (AP) A House committee said to day that the Nixon Administra tion encourages pollution of the nation's streams and rivers by not prosecuting vigorously under the Refuse Act of 1899, which is aimed at curbing water pollution.

title: OFFICIALS TO BAR NIAGARA RAFTING
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 15 (AP)Raftriding in the lower Niagara River's rapids will be suspended for several days, it was disclosed today.

title: 920 INNOCENT IN JAIL, SAIGONSENATORSAYS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15 (UPI)An influential South Vietnamese senator said to day that 920 innocent people, mostly women and children, were being held at suspected Communist sympathizers with out trial in the Con on island prison.

title: Boston Bank Cuts Prime
description: BOSTON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) The First National Bank of Boston said today it was reduc ing its base lending rate to 5 per cent from 5 per cent, ef fective tomorrow.

title: Cuts in Aid Threaten Poor in Norwalk
description: NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 15 (AP)As the thermometer goes down, the number of welfare families being evicted or de prived of utilities will go up, legalaid spokesmen predict.

title: Focus of Dispute: Peace Signal in '68 or Politics in '72
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The charge by Sargent Shriver, the Democratic Vice Presidential nominee, that President Nixon blew a chance to end the Vietnam war in 1969 has pro duced a stormy political debate in Washington, but as with many controversies over Viet nam, the historical truth re mains murky and subject to many interpretations.

title: HUNT FOR GUNMAN PRESSED BY POLICE
description: The New York police yester day continued their quest to learn the identity and where abouts of the gunman who killed two businessmen last Friday in the mistaken belief that they were Mafia members.

title: MITCHELL ASSERTS CLARK WAS DUPED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  John N. Mitchell, the former head of President Nixon's re election organization, said to day that RaMsey Clark had been duped during a recent visit to North Vietnam and had al lowed himself to he used by that country in a propaganda campaign.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Henry Kis singer's trips to Paris are good news and good politics, since they suggest that there is some movement toward peace, but the fact is that even Kis singer does not expect any real change in the Paris talks until late in the elec tion campaign.

title: TWO FUND RAISERS ENDORSE SHRIVER
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 15  Sar gent Shriver won the support today of Paul Ziffren and Eu gene Wyman, who have been two of Southern California's most powerful brokers of Democratic funds.

title: Fumbled Opportunity
description: Secretary Rogers, former Ambassador Lodge and the State Department are being disingenuous, to put it mildly, in denying any knowledge of the 1969 chance for peace in Vietnam that Democratic VicePresidential nominee Sargent Shriver and former Ambassadors Harriman and Vance claim President Nixon blew. Interpretations of the events of that period may differ, but there can be little dispute on the facts or the Nixon Administration's detailed knowledge of them now and then.

title: Japan's Payments Surplus Up
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15 (Reuters) Japan recorded a surplus of $410million in its balance of payments for July, the Finance Ministry said in a preliminary report today. This compares with a surplus of $240million in June and $495million in July, 1971.

title: Bateman Eichler Fined
description: A major West Coast broker age house, charged by State Attorney General Louis J. Lef kowitz with 11 violations of New York State securities laws, yesterday was fined $22,000 here and temporarily enjoined from engaging in sonic of its securities business.

title: STOCKS RETREAT IN PROFIT TAKING
description: Stock prices pulled back a bit in profit taking yesterday, after several market indicators rose to record levels on Mon day and the DowJones indus trial average reached a 44 month high.

title: Griffin Takes Three Races In Jolly Boat Class Sail
description: MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 15 Dr. Lloyd Griffin of Elizabeth City, N. C., who three weeks ago captured the Jolly Boat Class Atlantic Coast champion ship, was the victor of all three races sailed today in the series to determine the class's na tional champion. Three more events are on tap tomorrow and another three on Thursday.

title: Business Briefs
description: The NoLoad Fund Association said here yesterday that the 160 funds that levy little or no sales charges on shareholders had recorded net sales in the first six months of the year of $180million, up $10million from the year before. In the same period, it added, the entire mutualfund industry, including noload funds, showed net redemptions of nearly $900million.

title: Market Place: Dow Average Is Understated;
description: The stock market has been dancing around in new high ground lately, but many in vestors do not seem to real ize it. Most of them are waiting for the DowJanes industrial average to con firm what all the other indi cators have been saying.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Dig in School Grounds And Uncover NoSoOld Relics
description: A ragwood and poison ivy choked corner of the George Washington High School campus was the scene of a brief archeological dig yes terday as about 20 students attacked the ground with shovels and hoes in search of buried relics from Fort George Hill's colonial past.

title: Power Failure in Queens
description: About 1,700 Con Edison cus tomers in the St. Albans sec tion of Queens were without power for about 90 minutes yes terday morning because of problems in a feeder cable from the Linden substation. A Con Edison spokesman said power was lost at about 5:25 A.M. and restored to all but 300 cus tomers at 6:40 A.M. The re mainder got their lights back at 7:20 A.M.

title: A.B.C. FILMS SOLD TO ITS EXECUTIVES
description: American Broadcasting Com panics, Inc., announced yester day that an agreement in principle had been reached to sell A.B.C. Films, Inc., its tele vision film syndication subsid iary, to a group of A.B.C. Films executives.

title: PATRICK J. M'AWARD
description: Patrick J. McAward, a retired advertising executive, died Tuesday at the age of 70.

title: Israelis Getting Kick Out of City
description: Zvi Rosen of the Maccabi soccer team of Tel Aviv, which will meet the New York Cosmos in an exhibition at Hofstra tonight, holds two records in Israelhe has longer hair and has come here to play more times than any other Israeli player.

title: Roundup: Gullett Flashes Some of His 1971 Form
description: Don Gullett, the Cincinnati Reds' young pitching sensa tion last season and a near flop this season, came up with a performance last night that could. be considered a morale booster for him.

title: Fischer Gets Draw On Spassky Error
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 15 Bobby Fischer drew a game he should have lost today and inched a halfpoint closer to the world chess championship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The anticipated shift of Jewish voters from the Democratic to the Re publican party can be explained largely by the defense aid channeled to Israel by the Nixon Administration. This overlooks the pressing social problems of that country's Sephardic Oriental population and the monopoly over political power in the hands of East European Jews.

title: Thomas C. Barnes Is Dead; Research Scientist Was 68
description: Thomas C. Barnes, a research scientist, died of cancer at his home, 34 Gramercy Park, on Monday. He was 68 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Boston and the New York Stock exchanges an nounced yesterday an agreement to allow brokerage firms with memberships on both exchanges to deliver securities to each other through the Central Certificate Service. C.C.S. Is a depository and computerized securitiesdelivery system.

title: Prisoner Work Plan Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)  Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, introduced legislation today to authorize pilot programs for two years that would allow Federal prisoners to get union wages for work they do, sup port their families and pay taxes. Under the legislation, private industry would provide work facilities within the pris on, where inmates would be trained and employed on a vol untary basis.

title: P. & G. EARNINGS RISE 16% IN YEAR
Bills Drop Taliaferro
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 15 (AP)  Mike Teliaferro, a quarterback acquired by the Buffalo Bills last week, was placed on waiv ers today by the National Foot ball League club. Buffalo picked up Taliaferro from the New England Patriots. The Bills added Charlie Richards, quarterback from the Univer sity of Richmond.

title: Small Claims Courts Failing Consumers
description: Small Claims Courts are com ing under increasing criticism from judges, lawyers and con sumer spokesmen, Who charge that they have become stream lined mass collection agencies for landlords and retail corpora tions rather than a means of giving the poor man without lawyer his day in court.

title: DONALD K. SHEARER
description: NAPLES, Fla., Aug. 15Don ald K. Shearer, vice president and assistant to the president of the BristolMyers Company International Division, died yesterday after a long illness at his home here. He was 47 years old.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 15State Supreme Court Justice Alexander Berman today ordered Garry Peters, a center recently drafted from the Boston Bruins' farm system by the New York Islanders, both of the National Hockey League, to show cause why he should not be prevented from signing a contract with the New York Raiders of the World Hockey Association.

title: Panel to Seek Root Of Building Bribery
description: A broadbased committee of state and city legislators, municipal officials and mem bers of the construction indus try was formed yesterday to review the labyrinth of laws that many builders contend prompt bribery in their business.

title: Escape Tunnel Found
description: BELFAST, Aug. 1 5 (Reuters) A 100foot tunnel, thought to have been inspired by films of wartime escapes from German prisons, was discovered last night at the Long Kesh inter ment camp near here, where suspected I.R.A. members are held without trial. Guards no ticed a hole in the ground just 15 yards short of the perimeter fence, camp authorities said.

title: Personalities: Staubach's Vow
description: Shielded from the press by club officials since he suf fered a separated shoulder last Saturday against Los Angeles, Roger Staubach, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, will come home today from Baylor Hospital, where his right shoulder was operated on Sunday. Yesterday, how ever, photographers were al lowed into Staubach's hospi tal room, and he did not show a hint of a smile during the picturetaking session. I'll be all right, said Stau ach, who is expected to be out from 8 to 12 weeks. IIl come back stronger. Roger, and out.

title: N.C.A.A. COUNCIL INCREASES FUNDS
description: BOSTON, Aug. 15Despite the increasing financial prob lems in intercollegiate athletics, the National Collegiate Athletic Association's executive commit tee today issued a favorable income report on some of its championships.

title: FRANK A. CELENTANO, INSURANCE OFFICER
description: Frank A. Celentano, a mem ber of the law firm of Lee, Mulderig and Celentano, who served also as vice president, secretary and general counsel of the American International Life Assurance Company, died Mon day in Nassau (L. I.) Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 205 Glenmoor Street in East Williston, L. I.

title: HANRAHAN ACCUSED OF THREAT IN COURT
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (UPD Barnabas F. Sears, special pro secutor in the conspiracy trial of Edward V. Hanrahan, Cook County State's Attorney, told Circuit Court Judge Philip J. Romiti today that Mr. Hanrahan and his brother, William, threatened him as he left the courtroom after a morning ses sion.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Soybean future took a thumping yesterday on thee, Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  The ExportImport Bank reported today that it had supported, directly or indirectly, $9.5billion of United States exports in the 1972 fiscal year just ended, up 38 per cent from the previous fiscal year and more than triple the $2.9billion volume as recently as the 1969 fiscal year.

title: Haggling Is Expected In Stadium Acquisition
description: A City Hall news confer ence is scheduled today to present formally the city's plans for a $21.7million renovation of the Yankee Stadium and to announce the signing of a 30year lease with the Yankees for the ballpark.

title: Deere Returns to Bikes
description: MOLINE, III., Aug. 15 (AP) Deere & Co announced to day that it would reenter the bicyclemanufacturing business after more than 80 years. Offi cials said that adding bicycles to the John Deere line repre sented continued expansion in the field of recreational prod ucts. The expansion began last fall with snowmobiles.

title: 9.7 % Rise in G.N.P. Forecast
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 15 (UPI) The gross national product will rise 9.7 per cent to $1.15 billion this year, with real growth accounting for more than 6 per cent and inflation less than 3.5 per cent of the increase, a survey of 67 econ omists predicted today.

title: U.S. B52's Strike at Positions Of Enemy's Units Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 16 (AP) United States B52 bombers flew heavy raids in the Saigon area early yesterday, striking at enemy positions as close as 24 miles from the capital.

title: Wallace Will Undergo New Surgery Today
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 15 (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will un dergo surgery tomorrow for the drainage of a cavity in the right side of his abdomen, University Hospital said today.

title: 4 White Acts to Bar Ouster as Member Of School Board 1
description: A member of District 1 Com munity School Board on the Lower East Side obtained a show cause order yesterday in an effort to bar a meeting to morrow night that is expected to pass a resolution to eject her from the board.

title: Fox Plans to Sue
description: REYKJAVIK, Aug. 15 (UPI) Chester Fox said today he planned to sue Fischer for every cent we can lay hands on because Fischer would not let Mr. Fox, a movie director, film the world championship chess match on closedcircuit television.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Aug. 16, 1972
description: Commission on Human Rights, subcommittee on pre vention of discrimination and protection of minorities 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Advertising: Chief of Ebony Named Publisher of the Year
description: The 1972 winner of the Publisher of the Year award is John H. Johnson, president of Johnson Publishing Com pany. He will receive this award, presented by the Magazine Publishers Associ ation, next month during its annual magazine week.

title: Fire Snarls Penn Central's A.M. Rush
description: A fire in a Penn Central diesel locomotive halted com muter service for about 40 minutes on two lines into and out of Grand Central Terminal during the morning rush yesterday.

title: MURPHY MODIFIES POSITION ON KNAPP
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday modified his apparent endorsement on Monday of the Knapp Commis sion's recommendation for a special state prosecutor to com bat official corruption in New York City.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BELGRADE, YugoslaviaThe most famous Marxist heretic within this heretically Marxist land is Milovan Djilas, once number two in the hierar chy, who staged an ideological revolt against Tito not long after Tito him self had staged an ideological revolt against Stalin and his monolithic brand of Communism.

title: Mrs. Alfred Baker Lewis, Wife of N.A.A.C.P. Aide
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 15 Mrs. Eileen O'Connor Lewis, the wife of Alfred Baker Lewis, national treasurer of the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People, died yesterday. She was 69 years old and lived at 130 Lancer Road.

title: Linda's Chief Heads Saratoga Field Today
ALASKA PIPELINE BACKED BY JUDGE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 15 (AP) A Federal judge dissolved today the injunction that has blocked construction of an oil pipeline across Alaska for more than two years.

title: Bartending Pastor Offers Spiritual Lift With Spirits
description: Everyone knows that bar tenders are supposed to lend an ear to people's troubles and occasionally offer a bit of fatherly advice.

title: Grim Works Out
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 15Although the sprained ankle Bob Grim suffered in yesterday's practice stiffened up, the wide receiver worked out with the New York Giants at Monmouth College today but didn't go full blast.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Israel Shenker's amusing story (Aug. 5) on the typing exercise sentences that use all letters of the alphabet deserves a footnote.

title: Dravo Wins Contract
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug, 15 (UPI) The Dravo Corporation an nounced today that it had won a contract valued in excess of $20million to build a dam and powerhouse for the Georgia Power Company.

title: Georgia O'Keeffe Wins MacDowell Arts Medal
description: Georgia O'Keeffe, the painter, has been selected to receive the Edward Mac Dowell Medal this year for her contribution to the arts.

title: Free Rock Is the Entree At Mass Picnic in Park
description: It was a free rock concert, a park cleanup, a voter regis tration drive and a mass picnic all in one.

title: The Zippies Are Heard By G.O.P. Platform Unit
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 15A delegation of Zippies a splinter offshoot of the radical  Yippies  testified early tonight before one of the subcommittees consider ing platform proposals for the Republican National Con vention.

title: DECKER ASKS TIME ON REORGANIZATION
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP) A bankrupt real estate man, Martin A. Decker, asked a Fed eral District Judge today for more time to plan the reorgani zation of his multimilliondol lar financial empire.

title: KISSINGER ON WAY TO Soul VIETNAM TO CONSULT THIEU
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 President Nixon's adviser for national security, Henry A. Kissinger, left Switzerland to night for Saigon to consult with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam on efforts to negotiate a settlement of the Vietnam war.

title: Hijacking Move Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (Reu ters)Fiftyone Representatives proposed today barring United States airports to such airlines as Air France that fly to Algeria or any other country harboring American aircraft hijackers. Legislation backed by the 51 was introduced by Representa tive Ogden R. Reid, Democrat of Westchester.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The board of directors of the Sonesta International Ho tels Corporation announced yesterday it had authorized the company to purchase in the open market up to 100,000 shares of its previously issued common stock. The company has 2.5 million shares outstand ing and 3.5 million authorized. The company's stock was up  at 6 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.*

title: Aide Says Peron Will Go To Argentina by Year's End
description: MADRID, Aug. 15The prin cipal assistant to Juan D. Pern said today that the former Ar gentine President would return home before the end of the year.

title: Spying Charges Quashed Against Soviet Translator
description: The Department of Justice has obtained in Federal Court in Brooklyn the dismissal of twocount espionage indictment against a Soviet citizen who was permitted to return to the Soviet Union last May.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)A Federal grand jury today indicted four companies and three executives on charges of conspiring to fix prices in the sale of bakery flour to commercial bakers on the West Coast. Indicted were the Colorado Milling and Elevator Company, and J. Lawson Cook, its president; Fisher Mills, Inc., and its president, Kenneth R. Fisher; the California Milling Cor poration; and the VWR United Corporation and Dugald A. MacGregor, president of its Centennial Mills division.

title: Police Seek Clues In Slaying of Three In Connecticut Home
description: NORTH HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 15Detectives today were ex amining the remnants of a pair of rubber gloves found behind the ransacked house where a wealthy lumber executive, his wife and their daughter were discovered slain yesterday in this New Haven suburb.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington: Events of the Day for the Record
description: Aug. 15, 1972 THE PRESIDENT

title: State Clears Safra's Bank Plan
description: Edmond J. Safra, the inter national financier who is bid ding for control of the $244 million Kings Lafayette Bank in Brooklyn, got a clean bill of health yesterday from Harry W. Albright Jr., the New York State Superintendent of Banks.

title: DISCLOSURE RULES UNDER S.E.C.STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 15 The Securities and Exchange Commission is looking into the possibility of setting stiffer disclosure requirements on companies' debt maturities and contractual commitments to try to give more advance warning in situations such as that of the Penn Central, the commission's chairman, Wil liam J. Casey, disclosed today.

title: SHOP TALK
description: When Marilyn Wolf, a de signer of belts and jewelry, was presented by her hus band, Neil, with a Volks wagen bus painted in a green and white lattice design and filled with cosmetics, she knew exactly what to do.

title: Books of The Times
description: GENTLE GREAVES. By Ernest Raymond. 543 pages. Saturday Review Press. $8.95.

title: 18thCentury Art in Exhilarating Show
description: The current exhibition of 18thcentury French draw ings and prints at the Metro politan Museum of Art is elo quent testimony to the re markable completeness of the collection that the Metropoli tan has assembled in this area as well as to the rich ness and diversity of 18th century art itself.

title: Total Up 41,000 to 196,166Big Four Cite Advances
description: DETROIT, Aug. 15  The United States auto companies, heading into the final weeks of the 1972 model year, sold 196, 166 cars in the Aug. 110 pe Hod, up more than 41,000 units from the yearearlier total of 154,871.

title: JERSEY DASH WON BY IRISH HIGHBALL
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 15 (AP)  Crown Stable's Irish Highball overtook the front running Private Times today to win the $6,500 Cornish Prince Purse at Monmouth Park.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Aug. 15The National Collegiate Athletic Association executive committee selected the Philadelphia Spectrum today as the site for the 1976 semifinal and final rounds of National basketball championship tourna ment. The dates will be March 27 and 29. The selection of Philadelphia is in conjunction with the nation's bicen tennial celebration. Temple will be the host college for the tournament.

title: Uganda Leader Firm on Asians' Ouster
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 15, (Reuters)Geoffrey Rippon, a special British envoy, had al most two hours of talks today with President Idi Amin, but the, Uganda leader said after ward that he stood firm on his 90day deadline for the expul sion of 50,000 or more Asians.

title: NASTASE DEFEATS M'MILLAN AT NET
description: TORONTO, Aug. 15 (UPI) Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Ru mania, afflicted with a flu bug, staved off a determined bid by Frew McMillan of South Africa, today and won 6.4, 26, 76. The victory advanced him to the second round of the Canadian open tennis championships.

title: Cambodians Reach Wounded
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 15 (AP)Cambodian Air Force helicopters reached the be leaguered town of Kompong Trabek for the first time in more than a week today and brought out about 20 wounded. The town, 50 miles southeast of Pnompenh, was attacked by en emy troops and tanks Aug. 6. It is now cut off by troops holding a fivemile stretch of Route I.

title: Pentagon Seeks Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 A Defense Department spokes man said today that depart ment officials were looking for the report described by Mr. Engstrom and that no comment could be made on his charges until the report had been found and reviewed. The spokesman added that a urinalysis study conducted last year among American troops in South Viet nam had showed that 5.54 per cent of those tested used heroin.

title: East Germany Says Blast Led to Crash Fatal to 156
description: BERLIN, Aug. 15 (AP)An explosion aloft preceded the crash yesterday of an East German interflug charter jet in which all 156 aboard were killed, the official East German press agency, A.D.N., said to night.

title: McGovern Rebuffed As Democrats Fail To Unite in Jersey
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Aug. 15 Efforts to unify liberal and reg ular New Jersey Democrats be hind the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern received a sharp setback here tonight when the Democratic State Committee designated Nicholas Caputo, the Essex Sheriff, as New Jersey's fifth Democratic national committee man.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: IF YOU'RE NOT DRINKING WILLIAM LAWSON'S SCOTCII. DRINK DEWAR'S William Lawson's 86.8 Proof Blended Scotch whiskies, Imported by Palmer & Lord, Ltd., Syostel N. Y.Advl.

title: 2 POLICE INDICTED IN BRONX ASSAULT
description: Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts announced yesterday the indictment of two plainclothes men on charges of kidnapping a 20 yearold bantamweight Golden Gloves boxer, beating him, shooting hint in the shoulder and thigh and then filing false robbery and assault charges against him.

title: SOVIET JEWS SAY EXIT FEE IS RISING FOR THE EDUCATED
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15Jewish sources reported tonight that Soviet authorities are institut ing a new system of heavy exit fees ranging from $5,000 to $25,000 for educated Jews who want to emigrate to Israel.

title: Suit Challenges Validity Of Districting in Dutchess
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP)  A suit filed here today challenges the constitu tionality of a reapportionment plan for the Dutchess County Board of Representatives adopt ed last May.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Lawrence F. O'Brien, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, citing un disclosed new evidence, said today that the committee's office had been bugged for some time before June 17, the day five men were seized in the office with electronic sur veillance equipment.

title: Scribner Says Law Is Forcing Schools To Report Addicts
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said yesterday that city laws had forced a change in policy on reporting the names of student drug users, and said the rule may well be inconsistent with current efforts by the schools to fight drug abuse among students.

title: Bloomingdale's Opens Store
description: Bloomingdale's, a division of Federated Department Stores, Inc., opened its first store out side of the New York area in Jenkintown, Pa., yesterday. The store, occupying 100,000 square feet on three levels, will spe cialize in home furnishings, in cluding radios, television sets and stereos. The Jenkintown store is the third in Blooming dale's proposed chain of home furnishings stores.

title: Chinese Opening Toronto Trade Show
description: TORONTO, Aug. 15Stacks of PepsiCola were alongside tables laden with slender bot tles of sunflower sweet white wine and sharp Maotai liqueurs, today as China offered a pre view of its twoweek trade ex hibition, which will open here tomorrow.

title: Lindsay Draws Real and Bronx Cheers in Queens
description: Mayor Lindsay, breezing through Queens yesterday in what he called a display of mayoral presence, drew re sponse's that ranged from angry catcalls of housing pickets from Forest Hills to enthusi astic cheers of black young sters in Rochdale Village.

title: WALTER J. WRIGHT
description: Walter J. Wright a former semiprofessional baseball play er with the New York Black Yankees and basketball play er with the Renaissance Club, died Monday after a series of strokes in Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 63 years and lived at 2560 Seventh Avenue and in Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: TORONTO, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press)Ilie Nastase said today that if the Davis Cup final is not held in his native Rumania, he and Ion Tiriac, his tennis teammate, won't play. If we don't play at home, we don't play at all, said to newsmen during the Canadian open tournament. The Davis Cup final against the United States is scheduled to be played in the United States in the fall.

title: Some Manic Depressive Cases Are Found To Be Inherited Through Genetic Defect
description: New evidence that some cases of manicdepressive ill ness can be inherited through a genetic defect will be reported in Copenhagen today by a team of scientists from the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center here.

title: A Better Idear
description: There was once a time when anyone could easily spot a Brooklynite by his way of talking.
