Brooklyn speech was so distinctive, so markedly different from any other dialect, social or geo graphical, that those who spoke it were immediately identified, as the Gileadites distinguished the Ephrai mites at Jordan fords by the way they pronounced shibboleth, and the Dutch, during World War II, picked out Ger man spies by the way they pronounced Scheveningen.

title: Avoiding Holocaust
description: WASHINGTONThe treaty limiting the deployment of antiballistic missile systems and the interim agreement in offensive weapons is an achievement of the greatest significance for the security of the United States and the Soviet Union and the world.

title: College Names Black Chiefl
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 15 (AP)Dr. James C. Bond will become the first black president of a major western American college or university when he takes over Sept. I as president of California State University, Sacramento. Dr. Bond, 48 years old, is now a psychologist and vice president of Bowling Green State Univer sity of Ohio. His appointment was announced here yesterday.

title: Auto Confrontation...
description: The White House has called in representatives of the four biggest automobile manufacturers to talk over their proposed price increases on 1973 cars. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler intend to raise prices by $85 to $91 a carincreases they call necessary to cover the costs of meeting Federal safety and antipollution standards. American Motors wants to lift its prices by $78 to cover these items, plus $68 for other cost increases.

title: Uganda Offers to Pay Kin of Two Slain Americans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) In a letter to President Nix on, Gen. Idi Amin, President of Uganda, has offered to pay compensation to the families of two Americans killed in Uganda last year.

title: City Panel Relief Inquiry Subpoenas Lavine After He Rejects Invitation
description: City Council investigators opened an unusual challenge to state authority yesterday by subpoenaing the State Commis sioner of Social Services after he had declined an invitation to testify on the extent of in eligibility in the city's welfare rolls.

title: Virus Hits 24 Steelers
description: LATROBE, Pa., Aug. 15 (AP) A virus has hit 24 Pittsburgh Steeler players and six coaches, including the head coach, Chuck Noll. All are under the care of the team physician, John Best.

title: Olympic Quintet Tops Team Of A.B.A. Players, 8276
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Aug. 15 (AP)Doug Collins of Illi nois State scored 32 points to night as he led the United States Olympic basketball team to an 8276 overtime victory over a team of American Bas ketball Association players, mainly Carolina Cougars. It was the fourth straight victory for the Olympians, who leave for Munich Friday.

title: ExOfficer Says Vietnam Report On G. I. Addicts Was Withheld
description: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 15 (UPI)  A former Army cap tain said in an interview yes terday that a 1971 military re port estimating that 25 per cent of the lowerranking en listed men in Vietnam were addicted to heroin had deliber ately been withheld.

title: 3 Belfast Gunmen Invade and Bomb Top Tennis Club
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 15 (AP)Three gunmen forced their way into North ern Ireland's top tennis club today and left a 50pound bomb in a shopping bag under the staircase. The explosion wrecked the wood and brick building, but no casualties were reported.

title: Lettuce Boycott Backed
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 15 (AP)Gov. John J. Gilligan an nounced his support today of the United Farm Workers let tuce boycott. He said it was symbolic of all struggles by minority groups for a decent way of life.

title: A Special Session Asked On Upstate Flood Relief
description: Assembly Minority Leader Stanley Steingut urged Gov ernor Rockefeller yesterday to call a special session of the Legislature to act on a flood relief, plan for the Elmira Corning area. The area was hit hard by tropical storm Agnes in June.

title: SHEPPARD PACE DRAWS 15 HORSES
description: YONKERS, Aug. 14  Two yearold pacers, some of whom have flashed the potential for future stardom, will take over the spotlight at Yonkers Race way Friday night. The occasion, the first major test for juveniles, will be the ninth annual Law rence B. Sheppard Pace, which will be contested in two divi sions, since it has attracted 15 horses.

title: Eagleton Buys Mementos
description: FERNDALE, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP)  Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, has bought 5,000 McGovern Eagleton buttons, 2,000 bumper stickers, 2,000 lapel tabs and 500 pens, a supplier here said today. He plans to give the campaign items to Missouri constituents and friends as mementos of his shortlived run for Vice President. The campaign materials were pro duced by Ross Industries, Inc., here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Many in Taiwan Urge Strong Actions To Stop Japan's Move Toward China
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 15  There is a big difference be tween the reaction of the Gov ernment and that of the peo ple to Japan's overtures to Peking, an electronics manu facturer observed.

title: The Women of ChessSo Far It Hasn't Been Their Move
description: Have women chess players got what it takes to reach the level of a Bobby Fischer?

title: Auto Cup Race to Merzario
description: PERGUSA, Sicily, Aug. 15 (AP)Arturo Merzario of Italy, in an Abarth Osella, won the City of Ena auto race cup to day, the sixth event counting toward the European automak er championship for sports cars up to 2,000 cubic centimeters.

title: Ethiopia Pulls Team Out of Olympics
description: MUNICH, West Germany Aug. 15Ethiopia withdrew from the Olympic Games today because of the presence o?? Rhodesia and made the firs?? significant dent in the com pelitive armor of this world wide show.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee, and his running mate, Sargent Shriver, received sup port yesterday from two major unions, the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the United Automo bile Workers.

title: Royals Beat Yanks Again With 3 Runs in Ninth, 76
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 15  Sparky Lyle proved more im portant than ever by his ab sence tonight as Fred Beene and Rob Gardner of the Yankees failed to hold a two run lead for one inning and lost a 76 decision to the Kan sas City Royals.

title: Hockey Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: NamathBarkum Battery Misses on Some Connections
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 15 Jerome Barkum, the New York Jets' No. 1 draft pick, worked out with the club today for the first time since offi cially signing his contract last night and dropped the first two passes from Joe Namath, an in dication that Barkum has some familiarizing to do.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Two special trains to the GiantsJets preseason football game at Yale Bowl in New Haven on Sunday will leave Grand Central at 10:30 A.M., arriving in New Haven about noon. Shuttle buses will transport fans to and from the stadium. Returning, the trains will leave New Haven 30 minutes after the game.

title: 6 BERNSTEIN FILMS SLATED IN CAPITAL
description: Leonard Bernstein will be the star of a weeklong film festival to be held at Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Gauges Show Gain In Payments Balance
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Two measures of the United States balance of international payments showed improvement in the second quarter of this year, but the underlying pay ments accounts apparently con tinued in heavy deficit, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP. HAS DIP IN ASSETS
description: The Allegheny Corporation reported yesterday net assets on June 30 of $143,473,608, equal to $16.33 a share, com pared with $160,650,548, or $18.19 a share, a year earlier.

title: Crocker Bank Appoints
description: Dr. Roberta Fenlon, who served last year as president of the California Medical Associ ation, has been appointed a di rector of Crocker National Cor poration. She was also made a director of Crocker Bank, the corporation's principal sub sidiary.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: ALBANY, Aug. 15 (UPI)  The average daily handle at this year's spring meeting at Aqueduct race track was down 10 per cent from last year's figure, the State Tax Department announced today. Commissioner Norman F. Gallman said total patronage and betting were up for this year's meet, which ran 35 days instead of the 30 of 1971. However, the average daily handle was down from $3,195, 756 to $2,900,474.

title: With JobSharers, Two Do Work of One, and Then Some
description: BOSTON (AP)  Looking for a compromise between fulltime housework and full time employment?

title: Economic Analysis
description: In the midyear report of the Council of Economic Advisers, the Administration has warmly praised itself for having shown a high order of responsibility, innovations and activism in dealing with its problems. But the Democratic members of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, reacting to the mid year report, con tend that it is not enough for the electorate to ask only what the Ad ministration has for it lately. For the last three years, the group headed by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said, the economy has experienced a prolonged recession brought on through a deliberate policy of reducing the growth of out put and employment in the vain hope that this would reduce inflation.

title: Senate Panel Approves Ban On Additive in Cattle Feed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)  The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee unanimously approved today bill that would prevent farmers from feeding DES, a synthetic hormone, to cattle out of fear that DES causes cancer.

title: Airplane Proves Rock Is Joyous
description: The Jefferson Airplane couldn't have picked a better time to bestow one of its famous free outdoor concerts upon New York rock fans. After the unfortunate experi ence of last weekend's poorly attended Festival of Hope in Westbury, L. I., the roller coaster, successfailure pat tern that has dominated rock festivals for the last few years seemed to be heading toward the downslope once again.

title: Argentine Rebels Raid Jail, Hijack Jet With 96 to Chile
description: BUENOS AIRES, Wednesday, Aug. 16  Leftist extremists raided an armyrun maximum security prison at Rawson in Southern Argentina yesterday freeing a number of political prisoners and taking at least six of them to Chile in a hi jacked airliner, carrying 90 pas sengers and a crew of six.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Those who know him well describe Paul Culliton Warn ke as brilliant, complex and tremendously able words that might fit dozens of other former high govern ment officials or topnotch corporate lawyers in this city.

title: Canadian Official Arrives In China to Open Trade Fair
description: PEKING, Aug. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  Mitchell W. Sharp, Canada's External Af fairs Secretary, arrived today in Canton for a 10day official visit, during which he will open the Canadian trade fair in Pe king Aug. 21.

title: Walt? Clyde? No, It's Frankie Teardrop
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 15Lights! Camera! Action!

title: The Men Who Fight Mafiosi and Killers
description: They are quiet, neat, rather formal men for the most part, and largely of Irish extraction. They choose their friends very, very carefully, and they show a fondness for odd intellectual pursuits  Platonic philosophy and Japanese history, for in stancebesides their main pro fessional interest, which is the law.

title: Rail Retirement Benefits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) A Senate Labor subcommit tee sent to the full committee today a bill increasing Railroad Retirement benefits 20 per cent for one million beneficiaries. This matches a similar increase for Social Security recipients, which takes effect Sept. 1.

title: Kenya Bars Sheltergiving
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 15 Any Kenyan Asian who shel ters refugee Asians from Uganda will be severely pun ished, Daniel Moi, Vice Presi dent and Minister of Interior declared today.

title: Executive Changes
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Corporation announced yesterday the election of Robert W. Lear as presi dent and chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. He succeeds R. J. Schaefer, 72 years old, who will retire after fortyeight years of serv ice. Mr. Lear, 55, has for the past five years been president and chief op erating officer of Indian Head, Inc., until his res ignation on July 25. He will remain a director of Indian Head however. Prior to Indian Head, Mr. Lear held various posi tions at Carborundum, American Standard and United States Steel. Mr. Schaefer started his career with the family brewing concern after graduation from Prinction in 1924 and in 1927 he became presi dent. He will continue as a director.

title: Merger News
description: The Hoffman Electronics Cor poration said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Ad vanced Systems, Inc., Grove Village, Ill., a producer of videotape instructional pro grams, for one Hoffman sharp for either 2.5 or three shares of Advanced Systems, depend ing on Hoffman's market value at the time of closing. The closing is contin gent on Hoffman shares being val ued at $25 to $36, making the transaction worth $10million to $12million.

title: . . . and Wage Stability
description: Without better performance on the price side, it will be impossible to get major wage settlements down to a truly noninflationary level. The Pay Board has decided to stay with its 5.5 per cent wageincrease guideline a yardstick that really comes to 6.2 per cent because of the Congressional addon of allowances for pensions, insurance and other fringe benefits. The board con cluded that, until the Consumer Price Index has been firmly pushed down, it would be unfair to ask workers to absorb additional increases in living costs out of the pay dividend they are supposed to get for rising productivity.

title: Advertising:
description: After more than 18 years of working together for the greater glory of Schweppes, the manufacturer of carbon ated products and Ogilvy & Mather have come to a part ing of the ways.

title: TWO HOMERS HELP METS TOP BRAVES
description: The other team in town the Metsbegan a drive last night to recapture their status as New York's No. 1 topic of baseball conversation, whipping Atlanta, 50, behind the pitch ing of Jim McAndrew and Tug McGraw and the hitting of Ed Kranepool and Tommie Agee.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 15 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird urged Republicans to day to adopt a platform that will reject policies of planned weakness, of whiteflag wav ing, of begging and of aban donment of our nation's role in helping to maintain peace.

title: The D.A.'s Default
description: New York City has been betrayed by its lawenforce ment apparatus. This grim conclusion is inescapable from the findings of the State Commission of Investiga tion, the Knapp Commission and the State's Joint Legis lative Committee on Crime. The lawmakers, under the chairmanship of State Senator John H. Hughes of Syra cuse, put much of the fault for widespread corruption on the fragmentation and lack of coordination in exist ing lawenforcement efforts. The joint committee believes these efforts need some sort of central direction from a council of county district attorneys and from a single state prosecutor's office, which could audit performance.

title: Falling Tree Kills Two
description: SONORA, Calif., Aug. 15 (UPI)  A vacationing father and his daughter were killed and three other family members badly injured when a huge oak tree broke loose and crashed down on their camp site, Tuo lumne County sheriff's officers said today. The dead were James McMichael, 35 years old, of Oakland, and his daughter, Cynthia Ann, 10. Reported in serious or critical condition were his wife, Linda Ann, 32, a sisterinlaw, Mrs. Donna Jean Wetmore, 37, of San Jose, and her daughter, Elizabeth, 11.

title: AN ISRAELI REVUE TO RUN ONE WEEK
description: A musical revue from Israel has been booked into the Pal ace Theater for a oneweek run of 10 performances start ing Oct. 2. The youthful cast of From Israel With Love is made up of 26 singers, actors and dancers, all former mem bers of the Israeli Army En tertainment Corps.

title: Mrs. Edna Lewis, Founder Of Cultural Center in Italy
description: Mrs. Edna Seeligman Lewis, cofounder of the Positano Art Workshop in Positano, Italy, and former director of the Eis man Day Nursery in New York, died Monday in Positano. Her age was 85.

title: Damaged Vehicles Donated
description: DETROIT, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Chevrolet Division of the General Motors Corporation is donating 640 hurricane  dam aged new cars and trucks to school systems in seven East Coast states hit by the tropical storm Agnes last June. The ve hicles will be used in vocational schools and high school shops this fall in Pennsylvania, Mary land, New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Delaware.

title: Albee Stages Moss's Play on L.I.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Aug. 15In the summer the east end of Long Island attracts many writers, artists and ac tors. Most of them are here for relaxation or for solitary creation and not for theater going, As a result, theater has a difficult time surviving.

title: Baeza, On Roberto, Ends British Colt's Bid to Tie Record
description: YORK, England, Aug. 15 (AP)  Roberto, ridden by Braulio Baeza, who saw the colt for the first time just hours, before the race, won the $125, 000 Benson and Hedges Gold Cup today and foiled Brigadier Gerard's bid for a recordequal ing 16 straight victories.

title: Chapter X Is Favored for Pennsy Parent
description: Richard Joyce Smith, trustee of the New Haven Railroad a corporate shell, recommended yesterday to Archibald DeB. Johnson, chairman of the Penn Central Company, that he petition the Federal District Court in Philadelphia for reor ganization of the holding com pany (Penn Central) under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act and ask for the appointment of a disinter ested trustee.

title: TESTS CONTRADICT THEORY ON SCOPE
description: Experiments with one of the two most powerful electron mi croscopes in existence have contradicted a theory that seemed to limit the use of such instruments in probing into the core of the life process.

title: Illinois Couple Contribute $200,000 to Nixon's Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)The Committee to Re elect the President reported to day a $200,000 campaign con tribution from Mr. and Mrs. Foster McGaw of Evanston, Ill.

title: MINTON DENNISON
description: VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP)  Minton (Whitey) Dennison, a top harness racing driver of the nineteenthirties and forties, died of a heart attack yester day. His age was 74.

title: Mays Touches All Bases in His Visit to Rikers Island
description: Willie Mays of the New York Mets rapped out a dif ferent kind of hit here yesterday in a visit to the Adult Remand Shelter on Rikers Island. First, the star outfielder conducted an in formal baseball clinic. Then he held a rap session with the inmates of the correc tional institution. Most of the action took place outside on the playing field. The visit was arranged by the City's Board of Correction, headed by William J. vanden Heuvel.

title: OilPlan Arouses Drilling Controversy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 A spokesman for the California Attorney General's office insist ed today that there was no rea son to conduct a state investi gation of a controversial oil drilling partnership plan in which Attorney General Evelle Younger was an investor.

title: British Union Chiefs Accept Dock Pact
description: LONDON, Aug. 16Official delegates of Britain's longshore men accepted an improved set tlement offer today and voted to end the 20day national dock strike. But militant shop stew ards, meeting later on their own, defied the union's call for a return to work at midnight Sunday and said that the strike would go on.

title: Sweden Takes 20 Lead
description: Torsten Johansson and Aake Eliaesson won both singles matches to give Sweden a 20 lead over Brazil in the inter national senior team tennis elimination semifinals for the Stevens Cup yesterday at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Official Criticizes Expellees
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. I6The Foreign Minister of Uganda said today that the Asians being expelled from his country were leeches suckin on African blood.

title: SWIFT & CO. IS SUED BY SECURITY MUTUAL
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (UPI) The Security Mutual Casualty Company today filed suit in Federal Court against Swift & Co. for $357million in treble damages charging violation of the antitrust laws.

title: New York Called Key City In Heroin Flow Into U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Government said today that New York was the main distribution point for heroin smuggled into the United States through circuitous routes from Europe.

title: Roundup: A's Defeat Orioles, 43
description: The Oakland A's warded off another challenge by the Chicago White Sox to over take them as the American League's Western Division leader with a 43 victory last night over the Orioles in Baltimore.

title: A Reputed Colombo Guard Surrenders
description: The reputed bodyguard to the Colombo Mafia family of Brooklyn surrendered yester day to the Brooklyn Strike Force Against Organized Crime on charges that he falsified his name, address and employment to obtain a $2,200 bank loan.

title: Highest A.B.A. Award Goes to New Yorker
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16  A 77yearold New York lawyer, Harold J. Gallagher, was awarded today the American Bar Association's highest award, the A.B.A. Medal, at the group's annual dinner here.

title: Executive Changes
description: James W. McKee Jr., 50, president and chief operating officer of CPC International, Inc., has been named chief executive officer. He succeeds Howard C. Harder who will continue as chair man of the board and of the executive committee. Mr. Harder said the move was made on his recom mendation and that he expects to devote most of his time to the company's public affairs and planning programs.

title: After Years of Learning, She Plans Her Own Cooking School
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I.  Whitehaired and garrulous, Mrs. Walter Sharp took advantage of her husband's retirement as head of the English department at Memorial High School in this south shore community on the border of Nassau and Suffolk Counties to go back to school herself in France and strength en her credentials for a career of her own In cooking.

title: Meter Readers to Go the Way of the Iceman
description: The utility meter reader is about to ring his last door bell. In his place there may be aircraft flying overhead, an encoder emplaced behind the meter's dials or an out side jack for a cassette re corder.

title: Africans Again Excel In the Distance Events
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 16 (AP)While the Af rican nations threatened to take their teams home in protest against Rhodesia's participation in the Olympics, African runners again domi nated the long distance events today on the second day of a tuneup, meet in Dante Stadium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As chairman of the Senate Commit tee on Aging, I read with great interest your July 17 editorial, entitled Wiser Social Security and Tax Load.

title: CITY MENTAL CHIEF A BLACK WOMAN
description: Dr. June Jackson Christmas, a black psychiatrist, was ap pointed Commissioner of Men tal Health and Mental Retar dation Services yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Yankees Lose Third Straight
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 16Un able to polish off Roger Nelson in the early innings before he found his groove, and unable to keep the Royals from scor ing a tiebreaking run in the seventh, the New York Yankees tonight suffered their third straight defeat, 32, in Kansas City's 90degree heat.

title: FEDERAL'S, INC., BIDS FOR REORGANIZATION
description: Federal's, Inc., operator of 97 department stores in Michi gan, Ohio, New York, New Jer sey and Connecticut, has authorized the filing of a peti tion under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act for an ar rangement with creditors.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Aug. 16 (UPI)Schenectady's offtrack betting corporation, the only OTB operation in the state outside of New York City, announced today it would soon be taking bets from Belmont and Aqueduct race tracks.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A secondary offering of 1, 200,000 shares of Johnson & Johnson common at $125 a share was completed yesterday, Kuhn, Loeb & Co., manager of an underwriting syndicate, re port. The company's stock closed at that price, up 1 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HARRY FRUMESS, LED CUSTOMS UNIT
description: Harry Frumess, assistant re gional commissioner of United States Customs for the New York region since 1966, died at his home, on Tuesday eve ning. He was 59 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Rebels in Argentina End Prison Mutiny; Hijackers Give Up
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 16 (Reuters)A nightlong mutiny in a southern Argentine prison from which a group of leftwing urban guerrillas escaped last night, hijacking an airliner, ended today when the stillim prisoned rebels surrendered aft er an army ultimatum.

title: THEATER SINGERS TAKE CLUB DATES
description: The long runs of Hair and Jesus Christ Superstar, both of which involve large casts of young people, have resulted in a fallout of fresh talent that is moving into nightclubs.

title: Aussies Take Cricket Test; Series With England Tied
description: LONDON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Australia survived an early col lapse and defeated England by five wickets today, the sixth and final day of the fifth cricket test, and squared the series, 22.

title: CHRYSLER ASSAILS NIXON PRICE PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Chrysler Corporation said today that the Nixon Adminis tration's effort to talk the auto mobile industry out of price in creases for 1973 models was an arbitrary and discriminatory request that was not com patible with the law.

title: Chones Moves to a New Home and a New Position
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Aug 16 Jim Chones's mother, four sisters and brothers are ad justing to their new house in Racine, Wis., and soon Chones may have to adjust to a new position with the New York Nets.

title: Run Gangsters Out of City, Angry Mayor Tells Police
description: Angered by the mistaken identity slaying of two business men last Friday night by a gang land killer, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that he had ordered the police to rid the city of mobsters.

title: MOYERS TO COVER MIAMI FOR WNET
description: Bill D. Moyers will serve as commentator for the Public Broadcasting Service gavelto gavel telecasts of the Republi can National Convention next week, it was announced yester day.

title: Kenya Bars 83 Asians Dispatch of The Times, London
description: MOMBASA, Kenya, Aug. 16 Kenya today turned away 83 Asians, 47 of them holding Brit ish passports, after they had arrived here aboard a ship from India, the Mozaffri. None had been permitted to debark.

title: Ryan Is a Distant Third In Slow TwoMile Race
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Aug. 16 (AP)The world recordhold er in the mile, Jim Ryun, fin ished a distant third in a spe cial Olympic tuneup two mile run tonight as Grant McLaren of Canada won the race in 8 minutes 32 seconds, a Canadian record.

title: THOMAS R. CLIFFORD
description: MELBOURNE, Fla., Aug. 16 Thomas R. Clifford, a former New York lawyer, died yester day in the Brevard Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Indian Harbor Beach.

title: Slaughter' Opens
description: Except as another instance in the continued misuse of Stella Stevens, a talented and beautiful actress, there is almost nothing of interest in Jack Starrett's "Slaughter," which opened yesterday at several New York theaters."Slaughter" is a sex-and-violence melodrama  with heavy ambitions toward violenceabout a black ex-Green Beret captain who begins by seeking revenge for his father's gangland murder in Cleveland and ends by more or less demolishing half of Central America for the F.B.I., or the C.I.A., or the I.R.S.or whatever Government agency is supposed to be making use of him. Between that beginning and this ending there is a partly incomprehensible plot that allows Slaughter to travel a bit and that involves him romantically with Miss Stevens and dangerously with many very bad people.All the bad people die; most, 100 or so, shot by Slaughter. And they die poorly. I don't mean that in a moral or religious sense; I mean that they tend to double over before a shot is fired or that, when shot, they obviously leap rather than fall from their rooftop perches. Such sloppy stunt work, combined with the director's penchant for visually distorting his climaxes by means of an an anamorphic lense, gives the film a kind of haphazard pretentiousness that seems exactly the wrong disposition of an action movie.As the principal bad guy, Rip Torn plays as if evil were his only vocation. For the Creature from the Black Lagoon this might be a good characterization. Jim Brown plays Slaughter as if he hated doing it, which is to his credit. Among other indignities, he is subject to racial insults on the order of "Just who do you think you are, boy?"which put "Slaughter" perhaps five years behind current fashions in movie bigotry.

title: Taipei Protests to Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Aug. 16 (UPI)The Chinese Nationalist Govern ment today lodged a formal protest with Tokyo over the Japanese Government's moves to establish diplomatic rela tions with Peking, Foreign Min istry sources said. Japan rejected the protest, and asked for Taipei's understanding of Japan's new China policy, the sources said.

title: STUDY FINDS ELITE DOVES ON THE WAR
description: A survey of 456 of the richest, most powerful and most influ ential persons in the United States reveals a high level of acceptance of Government in tervention in the economy, ap proval of most of the things that make up the welfare state and rejection of hardline anti communism in foreign policy.

title: Hanoi Aide Leaves Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 16Le Due Tho left for Hanoi today after at tempting to dispel the impres sion that his trip had any spe cial significance.

title: Mrs. Irving Will Return Voluntarily To Zurich to Face Swiss Charges
description: Mrs. Clifford Irving agreed yesterday to return voluntarily to Switzerland after a, Federal magistrate ruled here that she could be extradited to face a Swiss charge growing out of her husband's fraudulent auto biography of Howard R. Hughes.

title: Soviet to Buy $40Million In American Tractors
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 16 (AP) The Soviet Union is to pur chase $40million worth of American tractors by the end of 1973 under an agreement signed by Soviet officials and the international Harvester Company, it was announced here today.

title: Aged Aided in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP) The Southeastern Pennsylva nia Transportation Authority approved today a 10cent fare for all persons over 65 years old on bus, trolley and subway lines operated by the authority. The regular fare is 35 cents.

title: Swedish Aide in East Berlin
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 16Rune Nystroem of the Swedish For eign Ministry has been in East Berlin since Monday on, the first official visit to East Ger many since 1949 by a Swedish Government official.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Together with crime and drugs, housing abandonment is one of our cities' most vexing problems and, after welfare, the most costly. Yet, although the effects and costs of abandonment are readily discernible, the process itself is poorly understood.

title: Federal Control Urged for All Airport Security
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP)Secor D. Browne, chair man of the Civi Aeronautics Board, suggested today that the Federal Government take over all airport security be fore we lose an airplane full of people.

title: Notes on People
description: George C. Wallace, the Governor of Alabama, under went surgery for the second time in a month to drain an abcess caused by the gunshot wounds that felled him in May. The operation, at the University of Alabama Hos pital in Birmingham, was completed without compli cations, according to a hos pital spokesman.

title: No Progress Is Reported in City U. Contract Talks
description: Both sides in the contract ne gotiations between the City Uni versity and its faculty and pro fessional staff union reported almost no progress yesterday, with current contracts due to expire Aug. 31.

title: Bridge: Aggressive Bidding Holds Threat of Big Penalties;
description: Those who advocate bid ding aggressively to game contracts produce support ing figures to demonstrate that a game can be bid with much less than a 5050 chance. But their calculation ignores an important factor: When the game is due to fail because of bad breaks, the opponents will sometimes be aware of the fact, and a dou ble will give them a big penalty.

title: TexacoGulf Makes Its First Shipment
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 16 The first export of petroleum from the new TexacoGulf oil fields has left Ecuador. Over night, the shipment314,000 barrelsmade this small South American country the second biggest oil exporter in Latin America after Venezuela.

title: July Housing Starts Fell; Personal Income Soared
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  Housing starts declined in July but remained well above the twomillion annual rate level, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: SENATE BROADENS SCHOOLLUNGH AID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Senate passed 82 to 0 to day a bill revising and liberaliz ing the schoollunch program.

title: NARCOTICS STUDY BY U.S. CONCEDES PROBLEM IS lin
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  The Government, in an unusu ally candid report on world wide drug traffic, said today that despite increased enforce ment efforts the United States and other countries were able to seize only a small fraction of the total illegal flow of heroin.

title: PAYMENTS DATA HELP THE DOLLAR
description: LONDON, Aug. 16 (UP)A brighter picture for the United States balance of payments pushed the dollar higher today on most European foreignex change markets. The pound sterling also moved up, while the price of gold dropped.

title: Fed Manager Appointed
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yester day that Margaret L. Greene, a 29yearold economist, had been appointed a manager in its foreign department. She is the youngest officer in the hank, and nne of only five women who hold official rank there.

title: World Church Leader With a Passion for Unity Philip Alford Potter
description: UTRECHT, the Nether lands, Aug. 16A tall bespec tacled Methodist pastor from the British West Indies, garbed in a shortsleeved white sport shirt and gray slacks, mounted the stage of a conference hall here today to address an international gathering of churchmen. The pastor, the Rev. Philip A. Potter, had just been elected general secretary, or leader, of the World Council of Churches to which more than 250 Protes tant, Anglican and Orthodox churches from around the globe belong.

title: The Longest Day, 1972
description: WASHINGTONAug. 10, 1972 was my most depressing day as a member of Congress. On that black Thursday the House rejected, by 228 to 178, its last clear chance in this Congress to set a date for total U.S. military with drawal from Indochina.

title: Rep. Wayne Hays Becomes a Name to Reckon With in the House
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  Around the halls of Congress, in these waning days of sum. mer, the lawmakers have be gun asking themselves: Who actually controls the House? The mildmannered Speaker, Carl Bert Albert of Oklahoma? Or a brusque Ohio Democrat, Representative Wayne L. Hays?

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)  Most members of President Nixon's family will arrive in Miami Sunday for the Republican National Con vention.

title: TV: A Scrapbook of the Democratic Convention
description: It's not as if the demand for more television material on the political conventions is likely to be pressing. The Democratic marathon in Miami left even the most committed among the party faithful tipping over into ex haustion. Then the postcon vention play, with the ball being fumbled from Mc Govern to Eagleton to Shriv er, contributed its share to dazing the observer. Next week the Republicans will entertain in Miami, complete with four films made to order for the occasion.

title: A.T.&T. DIVIDEND IS RAISED 5 CENTS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company increased its quarterly dividend yesterday by 5 cents to 70 cents a share, The dividend is payable Oct. 2 to stockholders of record on Aug. 31.

title: Katherine Blackburn, 80, Of Democratic Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Katherine G. Blackburn, former assistant to the director of women's affairs for the Demo cratic National Committee, died yesterday in George Washing ton University Hospital. She was 80 years old.

title: McGovern Adviser Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Paul C. Warnke, the former Defense Department official named by Senator George Mc Govern yesterday as his for eign policy liaison with the White House, agreed with oth er Democrats today that Pres ident Nixon blew an opportunity for peace in Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TEACHERS RECESS TALKS WITH CITY
description: The Board of Education and the United Federation of Teach ers have recessed their contract negotiations until Aug. 28two weeks before the scheduled start of the fall term here with both sides reported still far apart but determined to avert a possible school strike.

title: Making Friends With an Alien Culture
description: The remote Dogon people of central Mali became very real this summer to a group of boys who live around cen tral Brooklyn.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT MACCABI BY 52
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 16 Someone was obviously at fault tonight in not telling the New York Cosmos how to treat for eign visitors on a soccer field.

title: ANTISEMITE LEANING LAID TO CANDIDATE
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith charged yester day that the American party and its Presidential nominee, Representative John G. Schmitz of California, were political tools of the John Birch Society who approved of antiSemitism.

title: City Council Shown KnappPanel Data On Prosecution of Corrupt Policemen
description: As the debate over the Knapp Commission's recom mendation for the appointment of a special state prosecutor to fight police corruption con tinued, Michael F. Armstrong, the commission's chief counsel, yesterday released statistics on how the city's five District At torneys have fared in combat ting it.

title: Americans in Paris: A Shopping Spree
description: Sheila Tronn Cooper and Penny Morell Hochman thought they had a good idea and now quite a number of other women think so, too.

title: WHEAT, SOYBEANS RISE, THEN DECLINE
description: Early advances in wheat and soybeans were trimmed yester day in late dealings.

title: Recall in Berkeley Backed
description: BERKELEY, Calif, Aug. 16 (AP)Contributions for a cam paign to recall selfdescribed radicals on the Berkeley City Council in the April, 1973, city election are being accepted, Vice Mayor Wilmont Sweeney said today.

title: The Crown Prince
description: WASHINGTON Throughout most of our history, the Vice President, in office, has been either ignored or ridi culed. Many Vice Presidents have themselves joined in the general down grading. John Adams, who was George Washington's Vice President said: My country in its wisdom contrived for me the most insignificant office that ever the invention of man con trived or his imagination conceived.

title: Gains Seen for Chrysler
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Aug. 16Next year could be just as good or better than 1972 for the automobile industry, Lynn Townsend, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation said today at a previow of the com pany's 1973 models here,

title: Speculation Greets Kissinger in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 17Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser for national security, arrived in Saigon last night amid lightning and rain and much speculation about the purpose of his trip.

title: S.I, Boy, 11, Killed By Police in Chase
description: An 11yearold boy was shot and killed by a patrolman Tues day night after a joyride in a stolen car with two 14yearold companions that ended in a police chase through the New Brighton area of Staten Island.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: DALLAS, Aug. 16 (AP)  Moscow Dynamo, soccer champion of the Soviet Union, will play Dallas Tornado, the North American Soccer League titleholder, tomorrow night.

title: Early Chatterler Will Be Published
description: An earlier and substantial ly different version of D. H.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 16 (AP)The Memphis Tarns have been shifted from the West to the East Division of the American Basketball Association. The move was made to balance the league into two fiveteam divisions.

title: Soviet ABlast Signaled
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commis sion reported today the record ing of seismic signals that pre sumably came from a Soviet underground nuclear explosion yesterday. It said the signals originated at about 11:15 P.M. Eastern daylight time and were equivalent to those of an under ground nuclear explosion in the yield range of 20 to 200 kilo tons, This is equivalent to 20, 000 to 200,000 tons of TNT.

title: Business Briefs
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 16 (UPI)The practice of having to negotiate commissions on orders of more than $300,000 has resulted in a 23 per cent reduction in overall stock commissions, two economists reported today. On an an nual basis, this would mean an estimated $80million reduction in overall commissions, compared to the fixed rate. Before April, 1972, commissions were negotiated only on portions of orders over $500,000.

title: Anthony Newman's Extraordinary Musical Gifts
description: Anthony Newman does not so much play music as con sume it. The young virtuoso gave a harpsichord, pedal harpsichord and piano con cert on Tuesday night at Phil harmonic Hall that left one astonished, as in the past, at his tireless fluency and ability to gobble up famously diffi cult pieces. Whether Mr. New man digests everything is open to question, but his gifts, lavishly displayed in this Mostly Mozart Festival program, are extraordinary.

title: Germanys Open Talks On Normalizing Ties
description: BERLIN, Aug. 16 (Reuters) East and West Germany formally opened negotiations here today on a general treaty that they hope would settle differences and normalize re lations.

title: Moroccan Jets Fire On King's Airliner
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 16 Moroccan Air Force jets fired on the Boeing 727 carrying King Hassan II as it returned froin France today, and later pumped machinegun and rocket fire into the royal palace and strafed the airport.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 16  Senator Jacob K, Javits, who was chosen by Administration leaders to present dissent from the left before the Platform Committee of the Republican National Convention, opposed President Nixon's policies on Vietnam, busing and drugs to day.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 16 Senator George McGovern took his Democratic campaign for the Presidency down some welltraveled roads today in his quest for Illinois's 26 impor tant electoral votes.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, in his first major appearance in support of the Democratic tick et since leaving it two weeks ago, charged the Nixon Admin istration today with having embarked on a course of raw retaliation in Vietnam.

title: A DRAFT VIOLATOR ENDS 4YEAR EXILE
description: Roy Lisker, convicted nearly six years ago of burning his draft card in a Union Square antiwar demonstration, came home yesterday to a sixmonth jail sentence after spending more than four years abroad in selfenforced exile.

title: Backers of Fuentes Denounce Those Who Call Him a Racist
description: A parade of supporters of Luis Fuentes, the new super intendent of Community School District No. 1 on the Lower East Side, spoke in his favor at a district school board meet ing last night. They denounced those who had brought charges of racism against the contro versial educator.

title: Affluence Eludes Blacks, Puerto Ricans
description: After a decade of gains in income and educational attainment for the city's blacks and Puerto Ricans, nearly 900,000 of them are still living in poverty or not far above it.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16Congress neared final action today on legislation extending the President's authority control exports generally, but with a provision that would almost certainly abolish the recently imposed controls exports of hides.

title: Yanks, City Sign 30Year Stadium Lease
description: The New York Yankees will play at Yankee Stadium for the next 30 years under terms of a lease signed yesterday with the city, which will renovate the venerable Bronx ball park into what Mayor Lindsay called the most modern sports arena in the country.

title: RUSK DENIES NIXON MISSED PEACE SIGN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (UPI)  Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk disagrees with some of his former colleagues that the Nixon Administration muffed a chance to end the Vietnam war early in 1969.

title: Inquiry Into 81st St. Bar Bans Drug Testimony
description: Policemen testified at a State Liquor Authority hearing yes terday that they had been called repeatedly to the Tambourine bar at 350 East 81st Street to issue summonses for deafen ing noise.

title: 12 YACHTS BEGIN GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 16 Let's call it a select fleet, a Storm Trysail Club commit tee member recommended today as a dozen yachts answered the starting gun of the club's bi ennial Governor's Race East to Block Island.

title: 4 Hurt on Israeli Jet After Blast Over Italy
description: ROME, Aug. 16Four pas sengers were slightly injured tonight after an explosion in an Israeli airliner soon after it took off from Rome for Tel Aviv.

title: Senate Approves House Bill Funding Public TV for Year
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 16 (AP) The Senate completed Con gressional action today on a bill authorizing $45million for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting for one year.

title: Joseph E. Sullivan, Founder Of Sports Printing Concern
description: LOWELL, Mass., Aug. 16 (UPI)Joseph E. Sullivan, a philanthropist and founder of one of the country's largest sports printing firms, died yes terday at his home here, He was 77 years old.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)The former world middle weight champion, Emile Griffith of New York, and Joe Denucci of Newton, Mass., have signed for a 10round fight here Sept. 16. The bout will be held at the Hynes Memorial Auditorium.

title: Indiana Girl, 16, Is Miss Teenager
description: Carla Tevault of Peters burg, Ind., won the 13th an nual Miss American Teen ager contest here last night. With tears streaming down her face, Miss Trevault, 17 years old, said I'm at a loss for words. It's the greatest honor I've ever received.

title: ROBERT L. GIEBEL
description: Robert L. Giebel, retired chairman of Giebel, Inc., of New York and a past president of the American Machine Tool Distributors Association, died yesterday at his home in West Arlington, Vt., where he had lived since 1966. He was 79 years old.

title: Ramsey Clark in Hanoi
description: Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark used poor judgment in publicly criticizing American war policies while on his factfinding mission to North Vietnam. For one so prominent in American governmental affairs to denounce United States actions in the capital of a nation with which this country is involved in combat was bound to detract from the humane course he hoped to advance.

title: Gentele Buried in Sweden
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 16 (AP) Goeran Gentele, head of New York's Metropolitan Opera, was buried here yesterday. Mr. Gentele and his daughters Cecilia and Beatrice were killed in a car crash on Sardinia last month.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CON ED IS SEEKING INCREASE OF 16.1% IN ELECTRIC RATES
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, which won its last electric rate increase just four months ago, asked the State Public Service Commission yes terday for an increase of 16.1 per cent, or $181million.

title: Tokyo Stocks Set Mark
description: TOKYO, Aug. 16 (UPI)The Tokyo stock market reached its highest level in history to day.

title: Lower Fares for Elderly Said to Need Aid of U.S.
description: Deputy City Administrator Mark Corrigan said at a United States Department of Trans portation hearing yesterday that New York City would have difficulty maintaining its pro gram of reduced transit fares for the elderly without Federal aid.

title: U. S. Aide Visited Paraguay in Drug Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 President Nixon sent a personal emissary to Paraguay last week to impress on Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, the Paraguayan lead er, the importance this country attached to the extradition of Auguste Joseph Ricord, de scribed as the head of one of the world's largest heroin smuggling rings.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 14 Seized in Harlem Burglaries

title: Austin Defeats Amaya
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 16Jeff Austin of Rolling Hills, Calif., the favorite, survived a thirdround challenge today. from Unseeded Victor Amaya of Holland, Mich., and won 3.6, 76, 76, to lead the way into the quarterfinals of the United States amateur tennis cham pionships at the Meadow Club.

title: Pedal Power
description: Standing on a midtown corner these pleasant summer mornings, one can expect to see a halfdozen bicyclists whizzing through the rushhour traffic in the course of a single light changemen and women of all ages and conditions, diligently pedaling their ways to work for the sake of economy, speed, health and environmental protection. Driving out of town on a weekend, one spots scores of bicycles lashed to the rooftops of cars or jammed into station wagons, soon to join the swarms of cycles encountered on almost any country byway these days.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MONTAUK, L. IBlack clouds, a distant, rolling bank of dark fog and a stiff southwest wind greeted us as we ran up the beach from Montauk harbor toward the lighthouse.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) Ramsey Clark, at one point holding up a United States bomblet given him by Hanoi's Mayor, told a Senate subcom mittee today of seeing exten sive damage to dikes, homes and hospitals during his visit to North Vietnam.

title: McGovern Griticizes Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)  Senator George Mc Govern, the Democratic Presi dential nominee, charged today that the Soviet Union, by in creasing exit fees paid by ed ucated Jewish citizens wishing to emigrate to Israel, was holding these people as host ages of the state.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ripe for Imagination
description: Israel has now sent out a signal of recognizing the diminution of military danger in the Middle East, follow ing the expulsion of Soviet advisers from Egypt. Defense Minister Dayan suggests that Israel is ready to act, not just talk, on the assumption that things are no longer what they used to be between Israel and her Arab neigh bors. As such, his remarks in an Israel Radio interview last weekend seem a positive advance over Premier Meir's tentative assessment last month.

title: Nathan Reports Peace Fast Has Netted Half of $40,000
description: UNITED NATIONS; N.Y., Aug. 16Abie J. Nathan said today that since he went on his hun ger strike 10 days, he had raised $21,000 of the. $40,000 needed to send a ship to the Middle East to carry a message of peace and conciliation.

title: Snoopy, Come Home' Is Hilarious Treat
description: After seeing "Snoopy, Come Home," the second animated movie feature derived from the Charles M. Schulz comic strip, "Peanuts," all we can say is, Snoopy for President and Woodstock for Veep! Let's start a campaign here and now.This sprightly, clever and hilarious treatall that a comic strip should be on the screenis even better than "A Boy Named Charlie Brown," which began the series. And wise parents who have been praying for something right for the youngstersneither tame nor icky-pooshould light out immediately for the Guild Theater. The children, with their intuition, probably have already started running.The difference between the two pictures, both written by Mr. Schulz, is the emergence this time of Charlie's flop-eared pet beagle, Snoopy, and his own tiny yellowbird chum, Woodstock, in full glory.What a pair! Yes, they might not make bad public officials with their frisky energy, nimble sagacity and knack for handling intolerance, the human kind. This go-round they skip off to comfort Snoopy's original owner, a cute little hospitalized blonde named Lila.Meanwhile, back at home, Charlie and his playmates learn the worst about the supposed foundling. "Charlie," yelps one lad in horror, "you've got a used dog!" Which owner will Snoopy and Woody pick, that's the question. Find out for yourself, young and young at heart.The unfrilly animated backgrounds glow in pretty pastels, the comic-strip figures move as though "Peanuts" had come to life, and the bouncy, tender flavoring is further enhanced by some really nice tunes. One waltz, "Do You Remember Me?", is beautiful.Most of the time you'll smile or chuckle. The funniest sequence has a disgusted Snoopy being given the stray-dog treatment by a cheerful, blundering little brunette, who collars him and slaps him into doll's clothes, "I think I'll name you Rex," she gushes. Snoopy thereupon gags, seconded by Woodstock. One banquet send-off scene, with Snoopy, his master and his friends bawling over beribboned boxes of bones, is a riot.You're a good man, Charlie Brown. Snoopy and Woody, come on over to my house.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Zapata Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed an application with the United States Maritime Administration for a construction differential subsidy on five carriers for liquefied natural gas. The $400million construction order, before the subsidy, is one of the largest single contracts for commercial ships ever proposed.

title: British Offer $125,000 Reward On Random Murderers in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 16The British Govern ment offered a reward of $125, 000 today to try to break the wall of silence surrounding 54 assassinations in Northern Ire land over the past five months.

title: King Is in Good Health
description: PARIS, Aug. 16  Prince Moulay Abduilah, the brother of King Hassan, declared to hight that the King is in good health and he has the situation in hand.

title: Educator Does His Homework Before Playing Role of a Judge
description: It was toy time in upstate New York last weekend.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Aug. 17, 1972
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CAHILL REJECTS A SHERWIN QUERY
description: TRENTON, Aug. 16  Gov. William T. Cahill today angrily cut off questions and refused to comment on a report that he had discussed Route 46 highway contracts with Secretary of State Paull J. Sherwin and State Transportation Commissioner John C. Kohl in April.

title: Books of The Times
description: FIRE IN THE LAKE: THE VIETNAMESE AND THE AMERICANS IN VIETNAM, By Fran ces FitzGerald. 491 pages. Illustrated with maps, AtlanticLittie, Brown, $12.50.

title: Analysis Puts Fischer Ahead of I.B.M.
description: The computer chess match in Boston proved one thing: com puters have a long way to go before they become internation al grandmasters. But their game was an interesting experiment nonetheless.

title: Albert Gallo, the Kid Brother, Picks Up Mantle for Honor of Mafia Family
description: In the language of the Mafia, young Albert Gallo was never made, police officials say. That is, he was never allowed to go through the old initiation rites, with their flowery oaths and ceremonial spilling of a few drops of blood.

title: Freeholder Says Atlantic County Is Overpaying Vehicle Insurance
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 16  An Atlantic County Free holder has charged that the county holds insurance policies on at least 60 more county vehicles than its inventories show it owns.

title: Antiwar Veterans Go On
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 16 (AP)Forty Vietnam Veterans Against the War, whose leaders are charged with conspiring to disrupt the Re publican National Convention next week marched peaceably through this city today on the way to Miami Beach.

title: A STUDENT PROTEST BROKEN UP IN NEPAL
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 16 (Reuters)Nepalese police used batons and canes to disperse hundreds of university students who tried to march through the center of Katmandu yesterday shouting slogans for widerang ing political reform. An un disclosed number of students were arrested and Tribhuvan University, the only university in this Himalayan kingdom, called off its annual convoca tion, which had been scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: Welfare Check DayIt's Incredible
description: As early as 6 A.M. yes terday, clusters of people, most of them women, gath ered before the stoops of tenements in the area around East 149th Street and Third Avenue in the South Bronx.

title: GEORGE GREGORIEFF, RETIRED TRANSLATOR
description: HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 16 George G. Gregorieff, a retired translator for IBM World Trade Corporation, died yesterday in Hartford Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: Art Dealer Bequeathed $20Million to Hospital
description: WOODRUFF, Wis., Aug. 16 (AP)A wealthy New York art dealer has left about $20 million to a northern Wis consin hospital that was built with $105,000 worth of pennies.

title: U.S. Officials Report Progress in Stopping Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15In a document accompanying the State Department's drug sur vey, the Nixon Administration said today that despite pes simistic forecasts it was mak ing substantial progress toward blocking the flow of heroin from abroad, toward enforcing domestic drug laws, and toward treating the victims of drug abuse.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Republican Conference of the House of Representatives predicted today that if Senator George McGovern's fiscal plans were implemented, they would create a $126billion deficit in the Federal budget by 1974.

title: Attack in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 16 (UPI)Enemy troops fired at least five rounds of 82mm. mortar fire into the internation al communications center 12 miles southwest of Pnompenh today, temporarily cutting off communications with the out side world.

title: In Computer Chess, Blunders Help, Too
description: BOSTON, Aug. 16Just as Bobby Fischer and Boris Spass ky blundered their way to a draw yesterday, a computer in Evanston, Ill., blundered its way to victory last night over a rather slowthinking computer in Pittsburgh to retain its title as the United States computer chess champion.

title: G.M. of Canada to Expand
description: LONDON, Ontario, Aug. 16 (AP)General Motors of Cana da, Ltd., announced plans today to increase locomotive and bus production capacity in its plant here through a multimillion dollar, threestage expansion program that will start imme diately. Included in the plans are two additions to the present plant and the leasing of a ware house for relocation of bus as semblies.

title: Grim Misses Viking Bowl Fever
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 16Bob Grim has only been in the Giants' camp since Saturday but he is al ready getting infected with a slight case of Beat the Jets fever.

title: Lennon Concert Slated Aug. 30 In AllDay Fete to Aid Retarded
description: An allday festival to aid the retarded and handicapped will be held here Aug. 30, start ing with a variety of programs in Central Park at 10 A.M. and ending with a benefit rock con cert in Madison Square Garden in the evening featuring John Lennon.

title: KODES IS BEATEN IN CANADIAN OPEN
description: TORONTO, Aug. 16 (AP) Unseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina scored an upset in the third round of the Canadian open tennis tournament today, beating fourthseeded Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 6.4, 64.

title: Deadline for Voters
description: Politics anyone? The summer is not yet over, the heavy Presidential campaigning has not yet begun, and tens of thousands of potential voters are away on vacation. Yet there now remain only two more weeks of central voter registration for New Yorkers wishing cast ballots in November's election. The cutoff deadline is Sept. 2, and it is entirely too soon.

title: LISETER GOLD COIN RETAINS PONY TITLE
description: READINGTON, N.J., Aug. 16 Liseter Gold Coin, owned by the Liseter Hall Farms of Mal vern, Pa., and ridden by Mary Ann Steiert, won the American Horse Shows Association's na tional small pony competition today for the second year in a row. The event was held at Four Seasons Farm.

title: PRICES DRIFT OFF ON AMEX AND 0TC
description: Prices drifted lower in after noon trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in moderately active turnover.

title: Advertising:
description: The wallaby is a small kangaroo, the kangaroo has a pouch on the outside and a dew handbag by Margolin Handbags has a pouch there, too. Don Wise & Co., Mar golin's agency, thought of a way to put it all together.

title: ABRAHAM GELBFISH
description: Abraham Gelbfish, a proof reader for The New York Times, died Saturday at the age of 75. He had been with The Times since Feb. 1, 1953.

title: For God and Mr. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16The Nixon Administration's lengthy and assiduous courtship of Catholic voters is one of the remarkable features of the political scene. The latest gesture was its en dorsement of a Democraticsponsored bill to give a $200 tax credit to parents or children in parochial and private schools.

title: 3 Arrested and 1 Is Sought In Lottery Ticket Forgeries
description: Three persons have been ar rested and one is being sought in three separate schemes to cash forged state lottery tickets, the Queens District Attorney's office said today.

title: KISSINGER'S MISSION ASSAILED BY SHRIVER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 Sargent Shriver attacked Henry A. Kissinger's mission to Saigon today as late, frenetic and political.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 16 (UPI) Clark MacGregor, chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Reelection of the President, accused Senator McGovern to day of character assassina tion.

title: A.B.A. Votes a Tough Code for Judges
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP)  The American Bar As sociation approved tonight a tough and broadranging code of conduct for the nation's 15,000 state and Federal judges.

title: Credit Markets
description: Underwriters of corporate bonds, apparently optimistic about the market, continued yesterday to bid aggressively for new inventory despite a demonstrated unwillingness by investors of late to accept lower yields. The Southern California Edison Company auctioned $125million of doubleA bonds to a First Boston led underwriting team that set a re turn of 7.40 per cent, but firstday sales were slow.

title: 5 AREA COLLEGES ORGANIZE LEAGUE
description: The formation of the Metro politan Intercollegiate Football Conference was announced yesterday at a news conference at Fordham University's Lin coln Center campus.

title: Convention Protesters Plan SitDown
description: David T. Dellinger and the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan announced yesterday that dem onstrations at the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach next week would include evidence of dike bombing in North Vietnam and would cul minate in a massive sitdown Wednesday outside the conven tion hall.

title: Johnson Backs McGovern Despite Their Differences
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Tex., Aug. 16Former President Lyndon B. Johnson said today that he would support and vote for the entire DemOcratic ticket, from the courthouse to the White House. He en dorsed Senator George Mc Govern for President in a statement sent to weekly newspapers here, with the re quest that it be released to the news services.

title: Nixon Vetoes H.E.W. Bill; Cites Reckless Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 President Nixon vetoed today the $30.5billion appropriation bill for the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare and the Department of La bor.

title: SALINGER TALKED TO FOE ON P.O.W.'S AS M'GOVERN AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Senator George McGovern con firmed today that Pierre Salin ger, the former Presidential press secretary, had met with North Vietnamese negotiators in Paris at his request to dis cuss the prisoner of war situ ation.

title: HOUSE VOTES FUND FOR PUBLIC WORKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) The House passed today a bill authorizing the expenditure of up to $4.4billion over two years to revive an almost dor mant accelerated public works program and to ease the im pact of new industrial pollu tion discharge limitations.

title: GEORGEM REAVES, 74, CONSTRUCTION AIDE
description: CATSKILL, N., Y., Aug. 16 George M. Reaves, a former cold nel in the Army Corps of En (Tuners and a retired vice pres ident of the Turner Construc tion Company, died of a coro nary attack in Greene County Memorial Hospital on Friday He was 74 years old.

title: Film: In and Out of the Middle Ages with Pope Joan
description: In some medieval histories of the Roman Catholic Church there was a gap between the pontificates of Leo IV (847 855) and his successor, Bene dict III. Possibly to explain this gap, a legend grew up concerning a woman, Joan, born near Mainz, educated in Athens, who went to Roine disguised as a monk and so impressed Leo with her wit and learning that, thinking her a man, he appointed her his secretary and made her a cardinal. Upon his death, she was elected pope. But her pontificate was brief for when the people discovered that she was a woman, they barbarously murdered her outside the Lateran Palace.

title: RUSSIAN BIDS PRAGUE GIVE PARDONS TO 46
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 16 (Reuters) The Soviet physicist Dr. Val ery N. Chalidze today appealed to Czechoslovakia's President, Ludvik Svohoda, to pardon 46 Czechoslovaks sentenced for subversive activities in the last month.

title: Market Place: What's Behind A.T.&T.'s Surge
description: American Telephone and Telegraph, the world's most widely held stock and one of the stodgiest of all invest ments in recent years, sud denly leaped out of its rut yesterday and started behav ing like a glamour issue.

title: Texas Is Continuing Production at 100%
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 16For the sixth straight month, Texas oil wells will produce at 100 per cent allowables in September, but it will not be enough to build up heating oil stocks for the winter in the East and North, according to Byron Tun nell, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, who pre sided at today's statewide oil proration hearing. He noted that distillate stocks, the basis for heating oil, are 24.4 million Larrels below reserves of a year ago.

title: NET UP SHARPLY FOR DEERE & CO.
Article 1  No Title
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 16 (Reuters) The Communist party news paper Rude Pravo said today that President Ludvik Svoboda had ordered a halt to the prose cution of 10 young Czechoslo vaks associated with Prof. Jar oslav Sabata, who was sen tenced last week to six and a half years in prison for sub version. The 10 reportedly had asked for pardons.

title: Secretariat Wins at Spa; Linda's Chief Is Second
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16Secretariat removed Linda's Chief from thr ranks of the undefeated in the $27, 500 Sanford Stakes today. The Meadow Stable colt gave a spectacular exhibition as he knifed his way between horses in the stretch to flash into the lead and score by three lengths.

title: Melinda' Arrives
description: I liked "Melinda," a blistering suspense melodrama framed within a whodunit format, even though a beautiful doll named Vonetta McGee, in the title role, drops out of the picture early, slashed to ribbons.Furthermore, the film ambles along for a full 30 minutes without a clue to its aim or content. Finally, in the acoustics department, the language is aggressively monotonously "with it"filthy.The rest is strictly O.K. With a good cast headed by Calvin Lockhart and Rosalind Cash, eagled-eyed direction by Hugh A. Robertson and a nimbly turned script by Lonne Elder 3d, "Melinda" is an engrossing tingler.In "Play Misty for Me," Clint Eastwood had his hands full as a white disk jockey fending off a pretty psychopath, Mr. Lockhart, at the same post, spins off trouble from all directions as a black celebrity. Mysteriously framed for the slaughter of two girls, he finally tangles with the slimy chief of a crime syndicate, who is white and as slimy as they come.To the credit of the movie, the predominantly black gallery of well-defined characters allots cunning and evil on all sides. And the nub of the mysterywhy was Melinda murdered?packs two neat plot surprises. Mr. Lockhart, as the fiery hero, and the expressive Miss Cash, are excellent, with solid support down the line. "Melinda" may miss the bullseye but it does rattle the target.

title: Books of The Times
description: Marriage, like politics and religion, is a subject about which everyone has an opin ionfew of which are dispassionate. In our swinging, sexoriented society it is often maligned as archaic and restrictive of personal freedom. But it also has its defenders, who seek to repel and vanquish the behemoth of youth cult, women's lib detractors, with vicious imprecations. Having once capitulated to the institution, I too have my opinionssuffice it to say that the title of Kathrin Perutz's book had me musing about which circle of Dante's system I had inhabited. But Marriage Is Hell is a misleading title for this book, and one soon discovers that Miss Perutz is not the iconoclast that the appellation suggests.

title: The Screen:'Boxcar Bertha' Tops Local Double Bill
description: Of the new circuit double-bill, the one to catch is "Boxcar Bertha," emphatically not "1,000 Convicts and a Woman." Yes, "Boxcar Bertha," believe it or not. Here is an interesting surprise.Set in the South and Southwest of the Depression years, with old-time clothes and cars, this is the drama of two derelict criminals and sweethearts who finally meet a horrible doom. Does that sound familiar? Well, "Bonnie and Clyde" still leads the parade.However, while there is a striking similarity in general content, background, fine color photography and even the use of hillbilly music, the new, more modest film stands curiously on its own.The main reason is the character of the hero, a kind of stumblebum union organizer, whose battered altruism sharply reflects the labor despair of the era, even as he detours into crime and wars on the railroad bosses. David Carradine is excellent in this role. Matching him, as the childlike boxcar itinerant, is Barbara Hershey. Fine, too, as their confederates, are Barry Primus and Bernie Casey.The thoughtful, ironic script by Joyce H. Corrington and John William Corrington thins only toward the middle and the whole thing has been beautifully directed by Martin Scorsese, who really comes into his own here.The picture credits as its source an autobiography by Boxcar Bertha Thompson. I can't vouch for the facts. Bertha was before my time.But this is for sure. You'll be wasting time and money on junk like "1,000 Convicts and A Woman." Subtitled "The Story of A Nympho," it has a warden's poisonous, teen-age daughter wiggling around a kind of country-club prison until the joint more or less caves in. About seven panting inmates are all we see, not 1,000. That's seven too many.

title: Books of The Times
description: The striking quality of this impressive first book is a verbal brio, a metaphorical daring that is as exciting as it is satisfying. At a time when a great deal of poetry is assertive in an unassertive way, when flat, cool tone is supposed to indicate the poet's control over his material, Miss Inez's adventuresomeness is a heady quality to encounter. It can sometimes be too good for its needs. Her description of an impa tient woman with Mandarin nails, rasp berry fire tapping boredom like the blind at curbs is almost too glittering to be satisfactory.
