description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP)  Neil Homer Smith, author and World War II foreign corre spondent for the Associated Negro Press, died today in a convalescent home here. He was 63 years old.

title: TV: C.B.S. Flirts With Youth Culture
description: This summer the Columbia Broadcasting System has presented two new series using a musicvariety or comedyvariety format. The Melba MooreClifton Davis Show was shown early in the summer. The David Steinberg Show con cluded its run last Wednes day.

title: Banishing the Mobs
description: No bunch of racketeers, thugs and punks are going to intimidate you as long as I am Mayor of the City of New York, stormed Fiorello H. La Guardia back in 1935. Mayors come and go, but the punks and tinhorns and their syndicalized heirs have demonstrated a tenacity that overcomes one crackdown after another.

title: 8 Groups Set to Appear At Rock Picnic Sunday
description: Rock Picnic will be held from 8 A.M. to 10 P.M. on Sunday at Victory Acres, Travis, Staten Island. Eight music groups will appear be ginning at 1 P.M. Recreation al facilities will be open all day. For more information, call 9794038.

title: Business Briefs
description: Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., said yesterday that it would Shortly increase its aluminum production in Canada by about 28,000 tons annually. The move will raise the com pany's operating rate in Canada from about 86 to 88 per cent of its 1,035,000ton capacity.

title: FRANK L. SPRADLING
description: Frank L. Spradling, a land scape and seascape painter, died Wednesday in Flushing Hospital, Queens. He lived at 10602 63d Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: RYAN PROPOSES SINAI PEACE LINE
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 17  De fense Minister Moshe Dayan urged Egypt today to accept an interim peace agreement along a dividing line drawn across the Sinai Peninsula.

title: U.S. Jury Indicts ExHead of Bank In Fund Shortage
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)  Daniel D. Moore, former presi dent of the closed Surety Bank & Trust Company of nearby Wakefield, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury, which charged him with having mis handled $8.1million in the bank's funds.

title: YALE FELLOWSHIPS HONOR ELLINGTON
description: Yale University announced yesterday the establishment of a Duke Ellington Fellowship Program to encourage the study of AfroAmerican music and help perpetuate the jazz, blues and gospel traditions.

title: YANKEES INVADE LONE STAR STATE
description: For the last month, Manager Ralph Houk has been telling his New York Yankees that Aug. 17 was the key date on their calendar. Yesterday was Aug. 17, and they spent it traveling in leisurely fashion (for a baseball trip) from Kan sas City to the Inn of Six Flags in Arlington, Tex.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Governor Will Consider Special Attorney General
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would care fully consider the Knapp Com mission recommendation that he appoint a special deputy at torney general with powers to fight corruption in the city's criminal justice system.

title: Hammond of Jets To Miss 6 Weeks For Knee Surgery
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 17 The bad news outweighed the good news today at the New York Jets' training camp, where it was disclosed that Gary Hammond would undergo knee operation Saturday.

title: Wholesale Coffee Eases on Price Freeze
description: Wholesale coffee prices de clined moderately yesterday but not:nearly as much as some commodity analysts had expect edin the wake of the Nixon Administration's decision to freeze prices charged by big producers.

title: 5 Chamber Works At the Guggenheim Pleasingly Varied
description: Only the most diehard con servative would have grumbled about the tastefully varied group of 20thcentury chamber works performed at the Gug genheim Museum Wednesday night. All five pieces might have caused a bit of a stir when first played, but now they can be safely savored as easily digestible yet solid rep ertory fare.

title: Carlton Wins His 20th Of Season, 15th in Row
description: Steve Carlton, the Philadel phia lefthander who may be headed for the Cy Young Award as the National League's top pitcher, became its first 20game winner last night by defeating the Cin cinnati Reds, 9.4, before a crowd of 42,635 at Philadel phia.

title: FASHION TALK
description: If Yves Saint Laurent can't get women into skirts again, it's doubtful that anyone can. His Rive Gauche resort collection, shown in New York this week, has some of the newest, sexiest dresses around. They're in printed cotton voile or crepe de chine with flounces, pleats, softly puffed sleeves, offthe shoulder necklines or sur plicewrapped tops. And the short lengths look as pretty is the long.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)A United States District Court judge ruled today that Derek Sanderson, a center, and Gerry Cheevers, a goalie, remain bound to the Boston Bruins of the National Hockey League, at least until Oct. 1 when their current contracts run out.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BELGRADE, YugoslaviaFrom the standpoint of the American interna tional position I believe the very best outcome of this year's U.S. election would be the renewal of Richard Nixon's mandate for another four years in a campaign which allowed Sargent Shriver to gain a national stature sufficient to enable him to run as the principal Democratic candi date in 1976.

title: MRS. BODDIE WINS IN WOMEN'S GOLF
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 17 (UPI) Mrs. Barbara Boddie of Shreve port, La., defeated the defend ing champion, Laura Baugh of 1Long Beach, Calif., 6 and 5, in the quarterfinals of the United States Golf Association's na tional women's amateur tour Inament today.

title: Stage: Much Ado in Pre'17 America
description: A. J. Antoon, the director, has said that theater for him is an invitation to the audi ence to come into his kitchen and eat. By that measure, Antoon's Much Ado About Nothing, which opened Wednesday night at the Dela corte Theater in Central Park, is a feast.

title: HEALTH UNIT LISTS CODE'S VIOLATORS
description: Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, released yesterday the names of 15 more restaurants, gro ceries, supermarkets and other foodprocessing establishments cited for violations of the Health Code.

title: Two New Vice Presidents Are Announced by U.P.I.
description: The election of two new vice presidents at United Press Inter national headquarters was an nounced yesterday by Roderick W. Beaton, the president, fol lowing a meeting of the news agency's board of directors.

title: Giants Shop for New Quarters; Mara Says Shea Stadium Is Out
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Aug. 17A pro football season in which New York's two teams would share Shea Stadium was termed a physical impossi bility today by T. Wellington Mara, president of the Giants.

title: Negro Musicians Stage Aida for Convention
description: Although Verdi's Aida is a tragedy, it has long been a symbol of operatic grandeur and glory for the general public and of significant pro fessional achievement for those involved in opera per formance.

title: Ambassadors Given Overseas Authority Over Drug Matters
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  In an effort to strengthen the state department's hand in fighting the international drugs traffic and halt embarrassing interagency conflicts, the Gov ernment has issued new guide lines that give the United States Ambassador to each for eign country undisputed author ity in narcotics matters.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Stricken L. I. Scuba Diver Flown Here

title: AMERICAN INVESTING LEVELS OFF ABROAD
description: Foreign investments by United States industrial corpo rations are leveling off this year, the economics depart ment of the McGrawHill Pub lications Company reported yesterday.

title: M'GOVERN ASSAYS AID FOR SCHOOLS
description: RACINE, Wis., Aug. 17 Senator George McGovern asked for candor from Roman Catholic educators he met with here today and he got it.

title: Tho Stops Off in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (Reuters). Le Duc Tho, chief adviser to Hanoi's delegation at the Paris peace talks, made a brief stop in Moscow today on his way home. According to Tass, the official press agency, he re ceived assurances of continued Soviet aid to North Vietnam.

title: FRANCIS X. KEEGAN
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., (UPI) Francis X. Keegan, political ad viser and deputy to former Mayor Leo P. Karlin of Newark, died at his home here yester day. He was 67 years old and had lived here since moving from Newark in 1964.

title: Commodity Price Index Rose 0.1 From WeekAgo
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 121.1 from 121.0 last week.

title: $100,000 DAMPER PUT ON POLLUTER
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 17A consent judgment entered today in Supreme Court here levied a record $100,000 state fine agianst N. L. Indus tries for air pollution violations at its Sayreville plant.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Compromise by G.M.
description: General Motors has responded to White House pressure on auto prices by offering to reduce, by better than one third, the increase it had sought to cover the cost new safety and antipollution equipment. But G.M. like the other auto producersis clearly resentful over being singled out for special treatment by the Nixon Administration.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 17 (UPI)The International Tel ephone and Telegraph Corpo ration, which figured in a political controversy over fi nancing of the 1972 Republi can National Convention, has taken out an $11,500, full page color advertisement in the official convention pro gram.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Will Review Safety and Efficacy Of 1,100 Vaccines
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  The Food and Drug Adminis tration announced today a ma jor review of the safety, effec tiveness and accuracy of label ing of more than 1,100 vaccines) and drugs marketed for use in treating and preventing disease.

title: Russian Calls New York Air Worse Than Moscow Smog
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (UPI) The air in New York and Tokyo is worse on normal days than the smog that enveloped Mos cow during the, last 10 days while peat bogs and forests burned east of the capital, Mos cow's chief public health officer concerned with sanitation said today.

title: Lindsay Proposes Amendments To Bill on HighRise Fire Code
description: In response to objections raised by the building industry, Mayor Lindsay yesterday sub mitted amendments to proposed legislation for Me safety re quirements in highrise office buildings.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17The Association of American Rail roads reported freight traffic on United States railroads dur ing last week totaled an esti mated 15.4 billion tonmiles, 5.8 per cent above the correspond ing Week a year ago. Carloadings last week totaled 514,864 cars, 2.2 per cent over last year. The American Trucking Associa tions, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week as 0.5 per cent above last year.

title: An Owner of Design Studio Found Shot to Death Here
description: A man identified by the police as William Finley, 32 years old, part owner of a design studio at 236 West 55th Street, was found shot to death last night on the firstfloor landing of the building's stair well.

title: CONCANNON SENT TO DALLAS IN DEAL
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (UPD The Chicago Bears traded a quarterback, Jack Concannon, to the Dallas Cowboys of the National Football League today.

title: Tatars in Soviet Seek Return to Crimea
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17About 20,000 Crimean Tatars have re portedly signed a petition appealing to the Kremlin for an organized return from Central Asian exile to their historic homeland on the Black Sea and for restoration of the autonomy once given them by Lenin.

title: False Start by Thomas Baffles the Chargers
description: IRVINE, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP)Duane Thomas showed up briefly at the San Diego Chargers' training camp to day, reportedly his second visit since being traded by the Dallas Cowboys.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Senator George, McGovern has decided to visit Wall Street in an attempt to allay some of the fears in the finan cial community over the eco nomic policies he espoused prior to winning the Demo cratic nomination for Presi dent.

title: CHRYSLER EXPECTS JUMP IN '73 SALES
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Aug. 17The Chrysler Corporation displayed its 1973 model auto mobiles here today and fore cast a sales gain of 185,000 vehicles over the 1,775,000 models sold in the current model year.

title: Hybrid Plants Produced By Artificial Cell Fusing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17Bi ologists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have succeeded in growing mature and fertile hy brid plants from artificially fused cells of two wild tobacco species.

title: MUSICUS ASKS AID TO BATTLE CON ED
description: The Municipal Services Ad ministrator, Milton Musicus, sug gested yesterday that a utility be required to pay 1 per cent of any rate rise it seeks into a fund that would go to groups opposing that rise.

title: Japan Planes Leave China
description: TOKYO, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Two airliners returned here to day from Shanghai after mak ing the first commercial flights by Japanese planes to the Chinese mainland since World War II. They had carried here the Shanghai ballet troupe, which staged a month of per formances in Japan.

title: South Korea Debates Park's Leadership
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 11 A running debate goes on in the tearooms, bars, and restau rants of Seoul and wherever politically aware Koreans gath er. The question is whether President Park Chung Hee, who has become increasingly power ful, is serving the nation's best interests over the long term.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Aug. 17  The Republican National Committee approved today delegate plan for the party's 1976 convention that expands its membership and further in creases the relative political power of the smaller, more conservative states.

title: Golf Purse Increased
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) The Houston Golf Association announced today that the 1973 Houston open purse had been raised to $205,000, making the event the third richest on the Professional Golfers' Associ ation circuit. The tournament increased the total purse by $80,000. The winner's share is $41,000.

title: KEY MOROCCO AIDE APPARENT SUICIDE
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 17 King Hassan II, who yesterday escaped the second attempt on his life in 13 months, lost his principal military supporter early today with the death of Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, the Minister of Defense. Official and unofficial sources concurred in saying that the general had committed suicide.

title: BRITISH DOCKERS SPLIT ON STRIKE
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Thousands of British dockers voted today to end their three weekold strike. But the 9,000 men at Liverpool, the second biggest port in the nation, de cided to continue the work stoppage.

title: ICELAND LOSES ROUND AT HAGUE ON FISHING
description: THE HAGUE, the Nether lands, Aug. 7 (Reuters)The International Court of Justice ruled on an interim basis today that Iceland should not extend her territorial fishing limit from 12 to 50 miles after Sept. 1.

title: Protestant Militia Resumes 24Hour Patrols in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 17  The 40,000strong Ulster Defense Association, a Protestant civiian force or ganized on military lines, is resuming 24hour guard duty on streets in Protestant areas of Belfast following a blast in the heart of a Protestant dis trict.

title: HOUSE VOTES BAR TO COURT ORDERS FOR MOST BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Aug. 18The House passed early rhis morning a bill to bar the courts from ordering longdis tance busing of students to desegregate public schools. The vote was 282 to 102.

title: Spassky Wins Early Advantage But Falters Again in Wild Play
description: The 15th game of the world championship chess match was a wild affair.

title: Rockland, Brooklyn Teams To Meet in Benefit Game
description: Semipro football's version of the JetsGiants' game will take place tomorrow night at War rior Field in Rockland, N. Y., when the Rockland Warriors and the Golden Knights of Brooklyn play at 8 o'clock.

title: Dollar Is Firmer in Europe As Gold Price Dips a Bit
description: LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP)The American dollar strengthened against major European cur rencies today and the price of gold clipped.

description: Sports of The Times

title: MRS. JAMES F. RUSSELL
description: Mrs. James F. Russell, a fifthgrade teacher at St. Mel's School, Flushing Queens, died Wednesday night after a long illness. She was 51 years old and lived at 3579 161st Street, Flushing.

title: Weather a Depressant
description: Sales and earnings of Scars Roebuck & Co. set new rec ords for the three and six months ended July 31, but the gains were disappointing, ac cording to the nation's largest merchandiser.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator William Proxmire, a critic of the nation's space program, has become chair man of a subcommittee that has a dominant role in shap ing the space budget. The Wisconsin Democrat now heads the Senate Appropria tions Subcommittee in a shift caused by the death of Sena tor Allen J. Ellender of Loui siana.

title: MRS. IRVING NOT SURE ABOUT HER MARRIAGE
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I.Mrs. Clifford Irving said today she didn't know what would hap pen to her marriage after her husband served a twoanda halfyear prison sentence fol lowing conviction on charges stemming from a fraudulent autobiography of Howard R. Hughes.

title: Prospects for Fishing and Boating This Weekend
description: Clearly, the summer of 1972 is fast becoming rather unusual from the angler's viewpoint. Fish are not ar riving on schedule and when they do show their appear ance is often shortlived. From Long Island north, bluefishing has been spotty, and the same is true of the stripped bass. A constant thesis among the many ad vanced to account for this is that the East's cold, wet spring and its effect on ocean temperatures has had some thing to do with the situa tion.

title: Screen: 'Last of the Red Hot Lovers' at Music Hall
description: In the dismal history of Neil Simon screenplays and adaptations for the screen, "The Last of the Red Hot Lovers" may represent the lowest ebb. I missed "Plaza Suite," but in the other Simon films it always seemed that everybody concernedexcept the audience  got pretty much what they deserved. But nobody deserves "Last of the Red Hot Lovers": neither the actors (for memories of past performances), nor Gene Saks, the director (for the memory of at least a few minutes of "Barefoot in the Park"), or even the writer, whose occasional good ideas and clever lines simply sink into a general gloom beyond his making.Barney Cashman is the lover. He has a wife, kids, a house, a Buick, a successful seafood restaurant and, at 45, a desperate timid fear that life will never offer him any of its illicit goodies. So three times on his mother's charity day at Mount Sinai Hospital, he occupies her midtown apartment and makes assignations. The first is with a sharp-tongued woman, who puts him down. For the second he finds a crazy young theatrical failure, with whom he can't keep up. And the third is his wife's best friend, whose own depressions may one day lead her off the Verrazano Bridge, but never into Barney's mother's fold-away bed.Put them all together, and they make a convenience for a three-act play. They make something of an embarrassment for a non-three-act movie, which adds to them some incredibly misjudged extra materialexternal locations (in Philadelphia, for a New York movie) and scenes from the frustrated private life and thoughts of Barney Cashman.Although Neil Simon is widely thought to be a leader in contemporary kvetch comedy ("the Shakespeare of our time," according to Howard W. Koch, the film's producer), the movies that come out of his plays are almost never funny. Bitter, strident, full of the miseries of city living or suburban living or simply living into middle age, they attempt not so much to understand as to exploit a general unhappiness. And, lacking an uncommon grace in performance and direction (which they always seem to lack), they become yelling matches productive mainly of sharp discomfort.There is obviously profit in that discomfort, and a kind of recognition value (like the dark side to a TV situation comedy) and sometimes a kind of sour wit. I can imagine a very hammy production of "Last of the Red Hot Lovers" that might satisfy for as long as it took to say the lines. But this movie version strives for a dismal realism that plays under the lines and doesn't even support their potential for theatrical excitement.Of Barney's three women, Rene Taylor (the wife's friend) probably suffers least, having a certain durable comedy style of her own. Sally Kellerman, the waspish vamp, has no business attempting verbal wit. And Paula Prentiss, the girl between, is wholly out of the range of her very real capabilities.I think that Alan Arkin does everything wrong that can be done to the role of Barney Cashman, denying him any hint of ebullience or vitality, and leaving him only a loud mouth, a clumsy manner and an attitude that seems to bespeak a perpetually upset stomach."Last of the Red Hot Lovers" opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall.

title: Anxiety Grows Among Uganda's Asians
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 17 The midday sun throbbed on dusty Parliament Avenue. The crippled beggars huddled beneath store canopies. Out side the British High Com mission, hundreds of Indians and Pakistanis, perspiring and frightened, surged around the doorway.

title: Executive Changes
description: William W. Boeschen stein, president of Owens Corning Fiberglas Cor poration, has been elec ted chief executive officer effective Jan. 1, 1973. He will succeed Gen. Lauris Norstad, former commander of the Atlantic Alliance, who will retire on Jan. 1. General Norstad, who is also chairman, will re main a director after his retirement. The of fice of chairman will not be filled. Mr. Boeschen stein, who is 46 years old, has been with OwensCorning more than 20 years. He has served as vice president marketing, executive vice president and was elected president and chief operating officer in 1971. Mr. Boeschenstein's father, Harold Boeschenstein, was president from 1938, when the company was formed, until 1963. He was later chairman. When he retired as a director last year he was named honorary chair man of the board.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The Building and Construc tion Trades Department of the A.F.LC.I.O. announced today that it would not recommend the election of either major Presidential nominee this year.

title: House Honors Athletes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) The United States Olympic team was honored by the House today and was told by Speaker Carl Albert, We have confidence in your victory. About 400 members of the team sat in the visitors' gallery to hear speeches from leaders praising their dedication. Later the team went to the While House for a reception, at which Mrs. Nixon was hostess.

title: BOY DIES AFTER SWIG OF CIDER AT CONCERT
description: The death of a 16yearold Bronx youth who fell ill after having drunk from a jug of apple juice passed around at a free rock concert in Central Park on Tuesday was under in vestigation by the police yester day.

description: GOOD THUNDER, Minn., Aug. 17The farmyard light keeps its nighttime vigil over by the toolshed where the farm's six tractors are rest ing.

description: The dimensions of the worldwide traffic in drugs, as disclosed by the Nixon Administration, provide somber evidence of the monumental difficulties involved in efforts to choke off this poisonous international com merce.

description: LAUREL, Md., Aug. 17 (UPI)Riva Ridge, winner the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes, and Roberto, winner of the English Derby, today became the first two horses to be officially invited to the 22d running of the Washington D. C. International on Nov. 11.

title: RCA Unit Signs Contract
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that its RCA Global Communications, Inc., subsidi ary had signed contracts for $5.7million with the China Na tional Machinery Import and Export Corporation for the in stallation of a new satellite com munications earth station in Peking and the expansion of the existing earth station at Shanghai.

title: Kenny's Condition Fair
description: NEWARK, Aug. 17 (UPI) John V. Kenny, boss of Hudson County politics for a half cen tury, was reported in fair con dition today at St. John's Hos pital, near Springfield, Mo. He had been admitted for a heart disorder. Kenny has been con fined in the Federal Prison at Springfield for Tax evasion.

description: DALLAS, Aug. 17  Jean Westwood, chairman of the Democratic National Commit te6 said yesterday that black supporters of President Nixon were backstabbers.

description: Threats of a slowdown on the city's subway and bus systems and a strike on the Long Island Rail Road were raised by two unions yesterday.

description: STORMVILLE, N. Y., Aug 17Up to the day he was sentenced, Jeffrey Smith re calls, he had never believed he would be sent to jail.

title: PARKER R. BROWNE
description: ALTOONA, Pa., Aug. 17 Parker Richardson Browne, a retired member of the real estate department of the Inter national Paper Company, died Sunday in a nursing home here. He was 88 years old and lived in Boston and formerly in Rye, N. Y.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17The Nixon campaign strategy of dominating the news by bold foreign policy moves is working as planned and keeping Sen ator George McGovern constantly on the defensive.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17The Nixon Administration charged today that contacts between representatives of Sen ator George McGovern and North Vietnamese officials could damage the quest for peace in Indochina.

title: Supreme Court Judge Here Said To Have Evaded Cigarette Tax
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice has been accused by the Attorney General of North Carolina of evading New York taxes by buying ciga rettes through the mall from North Carolina.

description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 17  The Resolutions Committee of the Republican National Con vention began tonight consid eration of a platform designed by the White House and con taining a strong appeal to or ganized labor.

title: BankAmericard in Prague
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 17 (Reuters)  BankAmericard and the Czechoslovak Tourist Organi zation, Cedok, signed an agree ment today allowing the company to operate credit cards in Czechoslovakia, effective Oct. 1, Ceteka News Agency reported today.

title: Soviet Jews in Israel
description: Governor Rockefeller has politicized, without clarify ing, the human drama involved in the largescale move ment of Soviet Jews to Israel in recent months. His represents another unfortunate contribution to the effort by leaders of both parties to outdo one another in vaunt ing their friendship for Jews In general and for Israel in particularan even more assertive effort in this cam paign than in most. Perhaps this bipartisan competition for credit will abate now that the Governor's claim of NixonBrezhnev agreement on Jewish migration to Is rael has so quickly been followed by Moscow reports of a substantial increase in the monetary ransom the Krem lin is demanding to permit educated Jews to leave the Soviet Union.

title: Cosmos No. 514
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 17 (Reuters) The Soviet Union successfully launched the 514th satellite in its cosmos series yesterday, the official news agency, Tass, re ported today.

title: NIGERIA DECLINES TO QUIT OLYMPICS
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 17 (AP)The list of na tions threatening to withdraw from the Olympic Games swelled today, but none of the teams installed in the Olympic Village moved to pack their bags and Nigeria said it would not join the boycott.

title: Business Briefs
description: The GAF Corporation announced yesterday that it and the Milstein family had signed a memorandum of under standing providing for the settlement and termination of all litigation and disputes between them. The disputes and court actions arose last year over the unsuccessful attempt of the Milsteins to gain control of GAF.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: Two large labor groups an nounced Presidential endorse ments yesterday, one for Presi dent Nixon and the other for Senator George McGovern.

title: SINDONA IS NAMED TO BANK'S BOARD

title: Miss Dolan Wins in Golf
description: DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 17 (AP)Marcia Dolan, playing on her home course, the Ridge wood Country Club, won the 54hole Connecticut State wom en's amateur golf champion ship today with a total of 232. Patty Torn of Manchester was second with 241.

title: AMEX AND 0TC DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Trading slowed and prices dipped yesterday on the Amer ican Stock Exchange.

title: Registration Law in State Is Contested
description: The New York Civil Liber ties Union asked the Federal District Court in Brooklyn yes terday to declare unconstitu tional a state law barring voter registration through most of September.

title: Women Duped Into Taking Bomb to Their El Al Flight
description: ROME, Aug. 17An explo sion aboard an Israeli airliner that took off from Rome yes terday was caused by a time bomb concealed in a record player given to two young Brit ish women by men thought to be Arabs, police officials re ported today.

title: H. STEPHEN WELLS, 60, DESIGNER AT TIMES
description: H. Stephen Wells, an indus trial and interior designer for The New York Times from 1957 until his retirement last June, died Wednesday at his home, 3930 Little Neck Parkway, Little Neck, Queens. He was 60 years old.

title: Profits and G.N.P. Rose During Second, Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  Corporate profits before taxes rose $4.9billion to an annual rate of $93.1billion in the sec ond quarter of this year, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: U.S. War Deaths Drop Bat Saigon's Are Up
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 (UPI)Four Ameri cans were killed and 28 were wounded in the war in Viet nam last week, the United States command reported to day.

title: SAILING RACE WON BY RABEN'S SLOOP
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Aug. 17  Hey, wake up! We've won the race, shouted they crew of La Forza del Destino as she breezed into the harbor at 7:38 this morning.

title: James W. Egan Jr. Dies at 72; Former Ad Manager of Times
description: James W. Egan Jr., advertis ing manager of The New York Times from 1942 to 1946 and vice president and advertising director of The Toledo (Ohio) Blade from 1946 to 1950, died yesterday on his 72d birthday at his home in Arlington, Va., after a brief illness.

title: FED ACTS TO SLOW GROWTH OF MONEY
description: The Federal Reserve System, which has been struggling re cently to get monetary expan sion back on the track of mod erate growth that it achieved in the second quarter, has tightened credit somewhat in the last few weeks.

title: Amendment Approved
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 17 (AP)The House approved to day a constitutional amend ment to reduce its size from 203 to 161 members and the Senate's from 50 to 40. The measure was sent to the Senate for agreement on changes made by the House.

title: POLICE WILL NAME CONCERNS IN CITY INVOLVED IN CRIME
description: Deputy Police Commissioner William P. McCarthy said yes terday that the police would make public the names of some business concerns allegedly dominated by organized crime.

title: Police Issue New Restrictions on Use of Firearms After the Shooting of 10YearOld Boy
description: New restrictions on the use of firearms by policemen are to be issued today, a deputy police commissioner told a com munity meeting on Staten Is land last night.

title: Jazz Piano Playing Of Barbara Carroll Brightens Pub Here
description: New York got another full time jazz club this week when Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, which has been dangling jazz before its customers on Monday nights, expanded to a full week of jazz.

title: F.T.C. COMPLAINT TO CITE KORVETTE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Federal Trade Commission accused E. J. Korvette, the big discount chain, today of making false representations to sell home improvements and failing to honor guarantees.

title: Weekly Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $846million up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $767million. Total retail store sales were about $8.392 billion, up 9 per cent from the $7.728 billion in 1971.

title: Margaret Webster Repeats Author Role
description: The tales of her theatrical forebears already told, Mar garet Webster has now fin ished writing an autobiog raphy on the joys of a life consumed as a Shakespear ean scholar and a distin guished director and actress. But, in a tempering blend, she scorns drama critics, fears for the classical thea ter's life and turns seemingly irreverent.

title: News Analysis
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 17 With all the political excitement and social tension of a summer cruise, Republicans are assem bling here for the unaccustomed business of renominating a sit ting President. Even the novelty of the occasion seems muffled in luxurious languor. With the business of the week largely foreordained by the White House and the results in No vember deemed or dained by even higher authority, the loyal, cardcarrying party delegate has been left to choose only his own cocktail wardrobe and locale. And the party lead ers, unable to resist the massed but idle army of the media, are tormented only by the need to choose among Sargent Shriver, Ramsey Clark and Pierre Sal inger for the daily partisan attack.

title: Tradeau's China Visit Expected to Begin Soon
description: PEKING, Aug. 17 (Reuters) Prime Minister Pierre El liott Trudeau of Canada will visit China shortly, it was announced here today at a banquet for Mitchell L. Sharp, the Canadian Secretary for External Affairs.

title: U.S. Raids in North Believed Heaviest of the Year
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 18  American fighterbomber pilots reportedly flew more than 370 strikes against North Vietnam on Wednesday in what appears to have been the heaviest day of raids of the year.

title: Mets Triumph, 21, Seaver Wins 14th
description: The chess mania reached Yogi Berra yesterday in Shea Stadium as Tom Seaver won his 14th game and the New York Mets checked the Atlanta Braves, 21.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 17 (Reuters) The South Afircan Professional Golfers Association decided today to ask the Government for permission to stage an exhibition match between Gary Player of South Africa and Lee Elder, an American black, in Capetown next November.

title: AUDIT DISCLOSED BY CURE FORGAN
description: A surprise audit of the books of duPont Glore Forgan, Inc., the Wall Street investment house, gave the company clean bill of health, it was dis closed here yesterday.

title: Shadow Brook Repeats Spa Hurdles Victory
Olympic Village: Chessboards, Beer and Tea for Free
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 11In Mexico City, two significant words preceding the 1968 Olympics were, uno momentito, said with the thumb and Index finger placed inches apart as a ges tured plea for patience.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: McGovern System: Broad Responsibility for the Staff
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 17 A senior member of Senator George McGovern's Democratic Presidential campaign got a telephone call at 12:15 A.M. on Tuesday, inquiring when and where the candidate's chartered airplane was to go later that day on a swing through the Middle West. The caller was Senator McGovern.

title: Fox in West Virginia Finds It Picked on Wrong Old Lady
description: MINERAL WELLS, W. Va. (UPI)Goldie Daugherty, 63 years old, was attacked by a red fox while picking up kindling near her home.

title: Bridge: Foresight Sometimes Saves Victim Victim of a ThrowIn Play
description: A player who is the victim of a throwin play often finds subsequently that he could have averted his fate if he had exercised some foresight at the right moment. On the diagramed example, reported by the world pair champion, Fitz Babsch of Vienna, West allowed himself to be maneu vered into a position in which he would have sur vived if the fates had dealt him a five instead of a four.

title: 2 ALLEGED GAMBLERS ARE SEIZED IN RAID
description: The police seized two men, $10,000 in cash and alleged gambling and loansharking rec ords yesterday afternoon in a raid on an East Village apart ment described as the wire room of a $1millionayear betting operation.

title: 46 L. I. Artists Brush Up for Politics
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 18It looked a little like a reunion of graduates of the Cedar bar, the New York pub where artists and critics generated abstract ex pressionism during the nine teenfifties. It looked even more like a paintout for the adult and golden age Fun with Art classes of any com munity art center. In spite of a couple of McGovern but tons and one McGovern sweatshirt it didn't look at all like a political rally, which it was.

title: Iceland Plans Fishing Limit Despite World Court Ruling
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 18 (Reuters)The Icelandic Cab inet today decided to go ahead and establish a new 50mile coastal fishing limit for foreign vessels on Sept. 1, despite a ruling by the International Court of Justice yesterday against enforcing the ban.

title: IRWIN KLEIN
description: YONKERS, AUG. 18  Irwin Klein, athletics supervisor for the Westchester County Depart ment of Parks, Recreation and Conservation since 1958, who starred in football and basket ball for New York University in the 1930's, died of a heart ailment Wednesday in Profes sional Hospital. HQ was 61 years old and lived at 42 Croy don Road.

title: James Roosevelt Hails Nixon Record
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 James Roosevelt, 64yearold son of President Roosevelt and himself a former Democratic Representative, says that his support of the reelection of President Nixon marks the first time he has endorsed a Repub lican Presidential nominee.

title: Lieutenant Weds Miss McMahon
description: DENVER, Aug. 18Miss Margaret Mary McMahon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ber nardine Thomas McMahon, and Lieut. Thomas R. Reid 3d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Reid of Grosse Pointe Shores, Mich, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents by Msgr. Michael Harrington of the Roman Catholic Paul ine Chapel in Colorado Springs.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 18 (AP)  Carlos Monzon of Argentina, the world middleweight champion, is an overwhelming favorite to defeat Tom Bogs of Den mark in tomorrow night's 15round title fight.

title: MobInfluenced Businesses Would Fill A List From A to Z, Officials Here Slay
description: If Mayor Lindsay and the Police Department were to name every mobsterowned or mobster  infiltrated business in town, as they have said they might, they would end up with a rather large list, according to those who follow such matters.

title: Tho Meets Chou in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Aug. 19 (Reuters)Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Viet namese Politburo, conferred with Premier Chou Enlai of China in Peking yesterday on his way back to Hanoi for con sultations on the Paris peace talks.

title: ROLAND D. CRANDALL, A CARTOONIST, DEAD
description: Roland Dimon Crandall, who animated cartoons for motion pictures in the 1920's and 1930's, died Monday in Green wich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Old Greenwich.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Incendiary Table Tennis Balls Set Fires in 4 Midtown Stores
description: Six fires erupted in four va riety and specialty chain stores in midtown Manhattan late Thursday night and early yes terday, and police and fire in vestigators said they were caused by identical incendiary devicesPingPong balls filled with flammable liquids.

title: U.S. Swimmers Beat Three World Marks
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18 (AP)The United States women's Olympic swimming team cracked three world relay records tonight as it wound up two weeks of train ing in the University of Ten nessee pool with an exhibi tion meet.

title: Cancer Researchers in Europe Study Cell Fusion to Understand Nature of the Disease
description: Researchers in Britain and Sweden believe they have found evidence that normal cells become malignant through a loss of genetic information,, rather than through the recep tion of some cancercausing message.

title: Armed Cyclist Hijacks Jet; Gets Million, Then Is Shot
description: SEATTLE, Aug 18A middleaged man pedaled a bicycle with a rifle across the handlebars into the Reno Municipal Airport this morning, hijacked a jetliner to Seattle by way of Canada, received $1million ransom after holding the plane for 13 hours, and then was shot and captured by the F.B.I.

title: Mrs. Wood Wed to C. Daggett Harvey
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 18Mrs. Jane Wood Wood of New York was mar ried here this morning to C. Daggett Harvey of Chicago, retired board chairman of Fred Harvey, Inc., the res taurant system. The Rev. J. Wilson Reed Jr., rector of Our Saviour Episcopal Church in Chicago, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Tassos Fondaras.

title: Joan S. Harris Is Bride at Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 18 In the Anabel Taylor Chapel at Cornell University here this afternoon Miss Joan San born Harris, a 1971 graduate of Cornell, was married to Erik Guignemer de Gedde Winterkorn, who expects to receive a Bachelor of Archi tecture degree from Cornell in October. The Rev. W. Jack Lewis, coordinator of univer sity religious affairs, per formed the Presbyterian cer emony.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAINGN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) President Nixon will attend a high school dedication in Michigan next Thursday on his way to California after the Re publican National Convention. The White House said today that Mr. Nixon would slop off in Utica, Mich., for the dedica tion of the Dwight David Eisen hower High School.

title: Virginia Utility Expands
description: The Daniel Construction Company, a division of the Daniel International Corpora tion, announced yesterday that it will build a pumped storage hydroelectric facility for the Virginia Electric and Power Company at a cost of more than $263million.

title: 5 VICTORS RIDDEN BY RON TURCOTTE
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 18Spanish Riddle, with Angel Cordero riding, and Ron Turcotte, with five winners on the card, shared the spotlight today in front of 16,055 custom ers at Saratoga. Spanish Riddle competed in the main event, the Skidmore Purse, and he raced the six furlongs in the record breaking time of 1:08 to score over Silver Mallet, with Tur cotte aboard.

title: Roundup: Tigers Blank Angels and Regain Lead
description: When the Baltimore Orioles replaced the Tigers as the American League Eastern Di vision leaders, on Aug. 11, Billy Martin, the Detroit man ager, warned, Tell them not to get too comfortable. Well be back.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (UPI) Former Agriculture Secretary Clifford M. Hardin has been named chairman of business and industry for the Committee for the Reelection of the President for Missouri, Kansas, Iowa, Minnesota and Nebraska. Mr. Hardin served in President Nixon's cabinet during the first two years of his term.

title: Treasury Aide Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The Senate confirmed today, the nomination of James Smith as Deputy Under Secre tary of the Treasury.

title: Filming Is Allowed At Farm in Maine In Wyeth's Painting
description: ROCKLAND, Me., Aug. 18 A Superior Court Justice today allowed a New York documen tary motion picture company to make films of the Christina Olson, farm and home painted by Andrew Wyeth in his famous Christina's World.

title: Edgar A. J. Johnson Is Dead; Economist and Historian, 71
description: WASHINGTON; Aug. 18 Edgar A. Johnson, professor emeritus of economics and his tory at the Johns Hopkins Uni versity School of Advanced International Studies, died here yesterday at the age of 71.

title: Ulster Snipers Kill 2 Soldiers; Catholic Man Is Gunned Down
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 18Two British soldiers were killed by snipers and young Roman Catholic was as sassinated today in one of Belfast's worst flareups of vio lence since the army occupied Catholic enclaves of the city three weeks ago.

title: MRS. ROGER HARRIMAN
description: YONKERS, Aug. 18  Mrs. Joan Frye Harriman, former educational director for Coats & Clark, Inc., thread manufac turer, and wife of Roger Harri man, a retired Army officer, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, after a brief illness. She was 63 years old and lived at 1 Sherwood Terrace.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  The Treasury announced today that the United States and Japan will hold policy meetings on antidumping here Sept. 11 and 12.

title: George Meany and Morris Hillquit
description: ALBANYIf only Samuel Gompers had listened to Morris Hillquit fifty years ago, George. Meetly would not be in the political bind he is in today. Morris Hillquit, the Intellectual leader of the Socialist party of America from its founding in 1900 until his death in 1933, was a lawyer who represented many of the leading unions in New York. In 1908 he was defeated in a Congressional election in New, York by a hair's breadth, and in 1917 he came close to becoming mayor of New York. As a matter of fact, in 1932 he polled a record 250,000 votes as the Socialist candidate for mayor again.

title: N.C.A.A. CENSURES DUKE AND KANSAS
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP)The University of Kansas, Duke University and Eastern Michi gan were reprimanded, cen sured and placed on probation for one year by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for various rule viola tions.

title: USERS OPPOSING PACT ON COFFEE
description: LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) Consumer nations in the Inter national Coffee Organization agreed unanimously today to fight the 13nation Geneva producer resolve to withhold coffee from world markets.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 18  About 2,000 riottrained para troopers began moving into rows of tents at Homestead Air Force Base today in pre paration for possible duty at the Republican National Con vention next week.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SCORE ADVANCES
description: Wheat futures prices in creased yesterday in response to rumors that the Peoples Re public of China had purchased the grain.

title: Black U.S. Olympians Score Rhodesian Entry
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 18A group of black American trackandfield ath letes denounced Rhodesia's par ticipation in the Olympic Games today and warned that if Rhodesia is allowed to compete, We will take a united stand with our African brothers.

title: Arbitrage Change Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (Reu ters)The Treasury Department said today it would drop a sec tion of its proposed regulations dealing with arbitrage bonds following a meeting between Secretary George P. Shultz and representatives of state, county and city governments.

title: Donald Wilks Weds Joan M. Fitzpatrick
description: PLATTSBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 18Miss Joan Maureen Fitz Patrick was married in St. John's Roman Catholic Church to Donald Kenneth Wilks. The Rev. James Toole, a cousin of the bride, per formed the ceremony.

title: Queens Broker Is Indicted In $1Million Swindle Plan
description: A stock broker who alleged ly swindled at least 35 persons out of more than $1million was indicted by a Queens grand jury yesterday on charges of grand larceny in the second de gree and issuance of bad checks.

title: SENATE APPROVES SHIFT TO METRICS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Senate overwhelmingly ap proved today the partial con version of the United States to the metric system, but the switch to meters, liters and grams may be a long time in coming.

title: KissingerThieu Talks End Without a Disclosure
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18Henry A. Kissinger concluded nearly six hours of talks with President Nguyen Van Thieu and departed for Tokyo today, leaving diplo matic observers as much in the dark as ever about what his trip here had signified.

title: Congress Extends Grumman's Contract With Navy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  A SenateHouse conference committee has given the Grum man Aerospace Corporation and the Navy an extension until Dec. 31 to work out a contract for the purchase of 48 addi tional F14 fighter aircraft.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert W. Haack, former president of the New, York Stock Exchange, has been elected a director of the Marlennan Corporation.

title: MARTIN A. FISCHER
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 18 Martin A. Fischer, assistant sec retary of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Company and the Schroder Trust Company Until his retirement in 1968, died on Wednesday. He was 67 years old, and lived at 7276 141st Street, New Gardens, Queens.

title: STATE JUDGE TO GET CIGARETTE TAX BILL
description: State Supreme Court Justice Murray T. Feiden will be billed for New York cigarette taxes, interest and Penalties, as a result of his having ordered cigarettes by mail from North Carolina, a state tax official said last night.

title: Uganda Making Exceptions
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Ugandan immigra tion officials today continued to process applications for exemptions from the decree banishing Asians from Uganda despite an announcement by General Amin that exemptions would no longer apply.

title: Mrs. Carey Is Wed To Joseph Breen
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 18 Mrs. Mary Harrall Carey of Westfield and Joseph B. Breen of New York, a partner in Emmet, Marvin & Martin, New York lawyers, were mar ried this evening in the West field Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Frederick Christian.

title: Fight for Health
description: In an unusual display of cooperation, guards and prisoners at the Ossining Correctional Facility, better known as Sing Sing, have teamed up to help fight sicklecell disease both inside and outside the prison.

title: Antiques: Venice Is Good Place to Look for Faience
description: Venice is a good place to hunt for objects of the thick earthenware called faience because it is a popular item in a group of fine antique shops there.

title: JOHN J. PLUNKETT
description: John J. Plunkett, a retired member of the delivery depart ment staff of The New York Times, died on Tuesday at the age of 75. He had been em ployed by The Times from 1918 until he retired on Dec. 1, 1960.

title: PRESIDENT SPAYS AUTO PRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Nixon Administration told the auto industry today that it would not be allowed to raise prices in time for the sched uled introduction of 1973 mod els in the second half of Sep tember.

title: Chess Game Is Drawn
description: Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky agreed to a draw after 43 moves of the 15th game in their world chess championship match in Reykjavik, Iceland. The 16th game will be played tomorrow. Details, Page 30.

title: Catholic Priest in Bronx Also a Clubhouse Boss
description: On Tuesday nights, in a storefront in the South Bronx, while bongo drums and fire engines create a din outside, a few dozen men and women, mostly young and mostly Puerto Ricans, gather to deal with practical politics.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: CRANSTON, R. I., Aug. 18 (AP)A union council repre senting 50,000 electrical work ers throughout New England gave a unanimous endorsement Friday to the Democratic Presi dential ticket headed by Sena tor George McGovern.

title: Caterpillar Tractor's, Net Rose In July by 119% From '71 Month
Kissinger Meets With Tanaka
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 19 (AP)Henry A. Kissinger, who arrived here last night from Saigon, met with Premier Kakuei Tanaka today, begin ning talks expected to center on how Japanese recognition of China would affect United States commitments to the security of Taiwan. Mr. Kis singer conferred with Mr. Ta naka at the mountain resort of Karuizawa, northeast of Tokyo.

title: Up in MidAir
description: Ease of access to Central Park is a special prize for all the varied communities around its perimeter and in the city at large, but Parks Commissioner Heckscher has strong arguments in questioning the desirability of pedestrian ramps over 110th Street and Central Park West, at Frederick Douglass Circle. In general, pedestrian bridges are more enticing on the drawing board than in reality. Cre ating special problems of safety and comfort, foot bridges in this city too frequently go unused or turn into hunting grounds for muggers and assorted predators.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 (AP)  The Philadelphia Blazers of the new World Hockey Association challenged the rival National Hockey League's player reserve clause in Federal Court today. The Blazers filed a suit against the Philadelphia Flyers and 15 other N.H.L. teams seeking to have the reserve clause declared invalid.

title: 3 Policemen Hurt in Subduing Man With a Knife in the Bronx
description: Two policemen were stabbed, one of them seriously, and a third was kicked early yester day morning before they sub dued a 34yearold Bronx resi dent who, they said, had threatened to kill any cop who approached him.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Owners Warned to Pay Building Fees

title: Protest Held Near U.N.
description: A group of demonstrators gathered in front of the United Nations yesterday to protest the fees the Soviet Union is levying for emigration to Israel.

title: Giving a Dressing Down for Not Dressing Up
description: Cut your hair . . . forget those phony forties clothes . . . and those funny shoes . . . don't go around New York in jeans. Gillis McGill echoed all those admonitions that mothers of young wom en hear themselves saying over and over again, like broken records.

title: Third Veto
description: For the third time in four years President Nixon has vetoed the bill appropriating money for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Once again, he has accompanied his veto with a message of sour rhetoric about budgetbusting and the evils of inflation.

title: Senate Votes to Keep Law That Helps Small Airlines
description: WASHINGTIN, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Senate passed legislation today to extend a Government loan  guarantee program for small airlines and triple to $30 million the amount that any single carrier may borrow un der it.

title: Mexico's Phone TakeOver Stirs U. S. Investor Concern
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug 18 The Mexican Government's de cision to assume control of this country's telephone company has caused considerable con cern among American investors here.

title: A POLLUTION ISSUE SPLITS CONFEREES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  After three months of hard bargaining; conferees of the Senate and House Public Works Committee reached compromise agreements last night on all but one of the contentious is sues on a new water Pollution control billy.

title: Algeria Believed Divided on Whether to Expel Black Panthers
description: Intelligence reports indicate that there is a sharp split with in the Algerian government over how to deal with expatri ate American members of the Black Panther party after a $1 million ransom airline hijacking July 31.

title: Clarke Gains Bowling Lead
description: WAUKEGAN, Ill., Aug. 18 (UPI)Allie Clarke of Akron, Ohio, averaged 233 for his first six games today to take the lead in the $42,000 Waukegan open Professional Bowlers As sociation tournament. Clarke had high games of 267 and 258 in his total of 1,390, which left him 35 pins ahead of Wayne Zahn of Tempe, Ariz., a winner of 10 titles on the P.B.A. tour.

title: Civic Partnership
description: Municipal history is studded with the mellifluous titles of booster organizations set up by business leaders to assist the Mayor and other elected officials in loudly trumpeted assault on such community maladies as crime, poverty, choked streets and blighted neighborhoods. Normally top executives disappear from these organiza tions after the first round of picturetaking and the groups themselves run swiftly into oblivion, sometimes quietly, more often in a cacophony of complaints over high taxes and other impediments to profits.

title: A. T. & T. Unit Is Granted $35Million Rate Increase
description: The Missouri Public Service Commission has granted the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company a rate increase of nearly $35million. Southwest ern Bell, a unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Com, pany, had sought an increase of $63.5million.

title: TREASURY CHANGE IN BILL SALES SET
description: The Treasury announced yes terday plans to revise the method by which it routinely raises huge sums of money through the sale of its bills.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER YANKS, 112
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. 18 It's becoming apparent that when the Yankees left Yankee Stadium last Sunday they were in such a euphoric state from their sudden success that they forgot one of their trunks the one containing their hit ting, pitching and fielding.

title: Table of G.O.P. Delegate Strength Under 3 Plans
description: News Analysis

title: WALSTON RECEIVES PEROT INVESTMENT
description: Walston & Co., Inc., a large member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that the Charleston Investment Company  a con cern formed by Mr. and Mrs. H. Ross Perothad invested $5million in Walston through the purchase of convertible preferred stock and warrants.

title: WALTER FRANKLIN OF PENNSY IS DEAD
description: Waiter S. Franklin, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad from 1949 to 1954, a period, of troubles for American rail roads, died Thursday evening at his home in. Northeast Har bor, Me. He was 88 years old.

title: Bridge:
description: A defender who, asks him self constantly why the de clarer is proceeding the way he is can sometimes spot the need for brilliancy.

title: No Rigged Trials In Czechoslovakia, Party Chief Insists
description: VIENNA, Aug. 18 (AP)  The Czechoslovak Communist party leader, Gustav Husak, said today that no rigged and unlawful political trials are taking place or are being pre pared in Czechoslovakia.

title: GAR PLATFORM STATES RADICALS RULE DEMOCRATS
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 18 The proposed Republican plat form released today charges that the Democratic party has been seized by a radical clique which scorns: our nation's past and would blight her future.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STELLE O'NEAL
description: Stelle O'Neal, formerly a wellknown buyer of readyto wear apparel in the New York market, died on Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. She lived at 6860 108th Street, Forest Hills.

title: POLICE SEEK THREE IN EL AL BOMB CASE
description: ROME, Aug. 18  Police were seeking a man with an Indian passport and two ac complices today in connection with the attempt to blow up an Israelbound El Al airliner here Wednesday.

title: Pacific Coast Exchange Expecting Growth
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18  William A. Lupien would just as soon not see another week like that of July 17. That was the week everyone seemed to want to buy shares in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and, as the stock's specialist on the Pa cific Coast Stock Exchange, Bill Lupien had to stand by his post and sell.

title: Pirates Sign Brooklynite
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates today signed John Candelaria, an 18 year  old left  handed pitcher from Brooklyn. The 6foot7 inch, 210pound Candelaria was instructed to report to the Pirates' training camp at Bra denton, Fla., next month.

title: Patrick J. Reynolds Dead at 59; Was Times Circulation Manager
description: Patrick Joseph Reynolds, who rose from canvasser to circulation manager of The New York Times, died of a brain tumor yesterday in Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 431 East 20th Street and at Maritoloking, N.J.

title: U.S. Is Said to Tell Soviet Of Its Concern Over Jews
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Secretary of State William P. Rogers told three Jewish lead ers at a meeting today that the Administration had express ed its concern to the Soviet Government over the new, costly fees levied on Soviet Jews seeking to emigrate, Jewish sources said.

title: Police Bar News Parley
description: ALGIERS, Aug, 18 (UPI) The Algerian police prevented Black Panther party members today from holding a scheduled news conference at their villa headquarters.

title: MISS GOOLAGONG GAINS NET FINAL
description: TORONTO, Aug, 18 (Canadian Press)Evonne Goolagong of Australia and Virginia Wade of England, exponents of the serve andvolley game, reached the final today in the Canadian open tennis championships.

title: Laird Reports Nixon Plans Aug. 28 TroopCut Speech
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that Presi dent Nixon would make an other announcement on United States troop withdrawals from Vietnam on Aug. 28.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mansfield Bids Sihanouk Be Restored in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The Senate's Demo cratic leader, Mike Mansfield, suggested today that the United States and China cooperate in restoring Prince Norodom Si hanouk to power in Cambodia.

title: Screen:
description: Will wonders never cease? Stigma, a screen warning about venereal disease; turns out to be not a luridly flap ping sermon but a crackling good suspense melodrama that forcefully nails the real villain an undetected out break on a small island.

title: BANK DIRECTORSHIPS RULED NO VIOLATION
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that it had concluded that the service by Howard C. Harder, chairman of CPC International, Inc., on the boards of both the Chemical Bank and the Peoples Trust Company of Hackensack. N.J., did not violate Section 8 of the Clayton Antitrust Act, which bars interlocking cor porate directorates.

title: Donna, Shaw Is Bride
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Aug. 18In the Bruton Parish Episcopal' Church here to night, Miss Donna Tracey Shaw became the bride of Thomas Alvin Rucker 4th.

title: $2Million in Securities Stolen Aboard Airliner
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (UPI) Securities worth $2  million were stolen from an air liner on a 19minute flight from Chicago to Milwaukee, Brink's, Inc., said today.

title: Chess Is Considered Frivolous By Followers of Fischer's Faith
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 18  Games, including chess, are considered frivolous pur suits, unworthy of the atten tion of the followers of the Worldwide Church of God on its Sabbath.

title: SOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCE
description: Volume remained light but prices improved yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Intelligence Director Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) Vice Adm. Vincent P. de Poix was named today to be director of the Defense Intelligence Agency. The 56yearold officer, a native of Los Angeles, is now deputy director.

title: News Analysis
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 18 Politicians, for whom oversim plification is an occupational hazard, are already busy trans lating the current struggle over the composition of the Repub lican convention of 1976 into a personar contest between Vice President Agnew and Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois. Through four days of committee ses sions, both of the power blocs that were trying to re structure the first postNixon convention to their separate liking kept insisting that it was not a liberalcon servative division or a contest between bigstate and small state leaders, but no one paid much attention to their denials.

title: Dutch Bergman, ExCoach Of Washington Redskins
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Arthur J. (Dutch) Bergman, former Notre Dame football player and onetime coach of the Washington Redskins, died tonight in a suburban Wash ington hospital.

title: Dow Chemical Increases Prices of Two Products
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday it was increasing the price of all grades of per chloroethylene 2 cents a pound, effective immediately for spot customers, and Oct. 1 for con tract customers.

title: F. JULIA SHEARER
description: LOCUST DALE, Va., Aug. 18 F. Julia Shearer, a horse woman and breeder of thorough breds, died yesterday in Gor donsville of cancer. She was 72 years old and lived, at Meander Stables, her farm, near here.

title: Business Briefs
description: Eascogas LNG, Inc., a joint venture of two United States utilities, asked the Federal Power Commission yes terday to clear the purchase of 4.2 trillion cubic feet of liquefied natural gas from Algeria over the next 22 years. The purchase is valued at $4billion.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: In response to queries from the American Jewish Commit tee, President Nixon and Sena tor George McGovern, in sep arate replies, have expressed opposition to the quota sys tem as a means of redressing racial disparity in employment, education and governmental appointments.

title: COALITION TO PUSH ON MINORITY JOBS
description: A group of civil rights and political activists yesterday an nounced the formation of a new coalition to lobby for more construction jobs for blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: State Increases Ski Fees
description: ALBANY, Aug. 18 (UPI) Higher fees will greet the pa trons of stateoperated ski cen ters when they arrive at the slopes for the 197273 winter season. The State Department of Environmental Conservation announced today it had re ceived approval from the State Division of the Budget for the fee rise.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: If a man keeps dangerous animals running wild on his estate, and one mauls a guest's child, he cannot escape responsibility by saying that he had no intention of letting children be hurt. That is generally the law now, and common sense. Subjective intent does not have to be proved, because keep ing wild animals where people go makes it so likely that someone will be hurt.The propaganda from Washington and Saigon makes it sound as though every American raid is hitting the Ruhr or some mighty military Installation. There is talk of destroying indus tries and naval bases.

title: Argentines, Richest Latins, Seek End to Troubles and a New Start
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 17 Argentina once had a long head start over the rest of South America on the road to be coming a modern industrial na tion. These days, with confu sion and considerable bitterness, the country is searching for the internal harmony and na tional will necessary to make a fresh start.

title: Words' Worth
description: HANOVER, N. H.President Pompi dou is worrying about the French language. He is said to have appointed fifteen special committees to find French alternatives to English words.

title: 2 Shot by Transit Police After Attempted Robbery
description: One of three alleged holdup men and a Transit Authority employe were shot yesterday afternoon by two plainclothes patrolmen during an attempted robbery of a Bronx subway change booth, the police re ported.

title: The 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18 Senator George McGovern chal lenged President Nixon today to debate him facetoface in stead of relying upon Adminis tration and Republican cam paign associates to speak in his behalf.

title: Tenneco and Union Oil Plan A New Well Offshore Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 16 (UPI) A spokesman for Tenneco, Inc., and the Union Oil Company of California said today that they would start drilling a new off shore well in northern Peru within 30 days.

title: 2 GIRLS SURPRISE IN U.S. AMATEUR
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 (AP) Cynthia Hill of St. Petersburg, Fla., and Mary Anne Budke of Dundee, Ore., rallied at the end of the day to card semifinal up sets in the 72d United States women's amateur golf tourna ment.

title: Katharine Pool, L. H. Schmidt 3d Married on L.I.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. L, Aug. 18St. Luke's Episcopal Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Katharine Bliss Pool, daughter of Mrs. Philip M. Brett Jr. of New York and. East Hampton and the late Henry Lawrence Pool, to Louis Henry Schmidt 3d, son of Mrs. Joseph V. Buck of Wilton, Cohn., and the late Mr. Schmidt Jr.

title: Notes on People
description: A tearful Edith Irving left the Nassau Coubty Jail, where she had just served two months for her role in the Howard R. Hughes auto biography hoax, and rushed into the arms of her husband, Clifford Irving, who wrote the life story. He said, Hello, darling. How are you.

title: Reds Subdue Mets, 82; Mays Hits 654th Homer
description: The last time the Mets were able to perform with what they fondly remember as their reg ular lineup was June 16 in the opener of a threegame series against the Cincinnati Reds. The Mets, then in first place, won that game and were dreaming big dreams with a wonlost record of 3519.

title: 5Year Freeze on Missiles Backed by House, 329. to 7
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The House, by a vote of 329 to 7, approved today the arms control agreement with the So viet. Union that puts a fiveyear freeze on the number of offen sive missiles.

title: ARMBRO NESBIT YONKERS VICTOR
description: YONKERS, Aug. 18  Any lingering doubt that Armbro Nesbit is the best of this sea son's crop of 2yearold pacers vanished tonight at Yonkers Raceway, as Duncan McDonald drove the Bye Bye ByrdArmbro Impel colt to a threequarter length victory over Steady Air liner in the first division of the ninth annual Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIGN
description: The national chairman of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith sharply criticized yesterday the use of such terms as Jewish vote, Jew ish money and Jewish inter ests by politicians and the press.

title: Personalities: What Pay Freeze?
description: Spiking rumors that he wanted to leave Milwaukee, Kareem AbdulJabbar of the Bucks has signed a new four year National Basketball As sociation contract believed to be one of the most lucrative in the history of professional sports. Though terms were not disclosed, conservative estimates put the size of the package at more than $2 million. By way of compari son, Jerry West recently signed a twoyear contract with the Los Angeles Lakers for $600,000.

title: Few U.S. Concerns Aid Africa Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Aug. 18  Following the growing debate in the last year on American business involve ment in South Africa, several United States companies oper ating in this country have in creased pay and improved working conditions for their black employes.

title: New Work by Roy Medvedev Reported in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18Roy A. Medvedev, the iconoclast his torian whose unauthorized his tory of the Stalinist era won critical acclaim in the West, has reportedly finished a new book on contemporary Soviet society that deals with recent political trends inside the So viet Communist party as well as the dissident movement.

title: City Bank Raises Prime
description: The First National City Bank, as expected, announced yester day that its prime, or minimum, interest rate on business loans would be 5 per cent for the week beginning Monday, up from 5 per cent this week.

title: WINE TALK
description: Finding an inexpensive bot tle of wine in New York's restaurants is becoming al most as difficult as finding one in New York's liquor stores. But it is not impossi ble and the quest is bound to turn up a few surprises.

title: Port Notes
description: The nation's air, rail and bus lines active in intercity passenger trade have been taken to task by Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe for the serious inconveni ences he says some of their passengers have endured.

title: 15 Dangerous Convicts Escape in Sweden
description: KUMLA, Sweden, Aug. 18 (Reuters)All but three of Sweden's most dangerous con victs escaped today from iso lation cells in the country's most modern maximum secur ity prison. One police official said that the present chances of rounding them up were slim.

title: MARKET RALLIES AFTER 3DAY DROP
description: Stock prices rallied modestly yesterday after registering three moderate declines in row. These declines were re garded by many Wall Street analysts as a normal consolida tion process that followed the strong Monday performance carrying several market aver ages to record levels.

title: SoninLaw, 34, Is Arraigned In 3 Slayings in North Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 18The suspect in the slayings of a wealthy North Haven lumber executive, his wire and their daughter, was arraigned in Superior Court here today on three counts of murder.

title: FRANK E. WARREN
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Frank E. Warren, who worked his way up from carrier boy to president of the Houston, Chronicle Publishing Company, died early today in his Sleep while vacationing in Colorado Springs, Colo. He was 52 years old.

title: Bernard Ruttenberg Dies; Aide at WNEW Radio, 36
description: Bernard Ruttenberg, newly appointed director of operations at radio station WNEW, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home here. His age was 36.

title: Javits Says He Isn't Lonely G.O.P. Liberal
description: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen

title: Republican Platform Defender John Jacob Rhodes
description: Man in the News

title: Tender for DLJ Is Oversubscribed
description: Merger News

title: Business Briefs
description: Expansion and modernization programs calling for outlays of $66.2million were announced yesterday by Champion International for two of its overseas affiliates.

title: Sports of The Times
description: TORONTO, Aug. 18It's as if an original Michelangelo masterpiece had to prove its superior to the forged copy. In the hollow quiet of Maple Leaf Gardens, most of the National Hockey League's best players were practicing today, their skates scraping on the milkwhite ice, the puck thudding off their sticks, their shouts muffled in the empty arena. Ordinarily, they would be enjoying the last few weeks before reporting to their teams' training camps. Instead, they were perspiring in preparation for Team Canada's eightgame series with the Russian national team, beginning Sept. 2 in Montreal. Significantly, they were perspiring with en thusiasm, to preserve with perfection the dignity of the original masterpiece.

title: Market Place: Oil Stocks Rise On Broad Front
description: A great deal of discussion has focused on the nation's socalled energy crisis late ly and much of it has impli cations for the stock mar ket. Especially the oil stocks.

title: Pretrial crime could be virtually eliminated by speedy trial.
description: WASHINGTON  Law and order was a major political issue during the Presidential campaign of 1968 and the Congressional campaign of 1970. As one of his campaign promises, Presi dent Nixon vowed to make Washing ton, D. C., a model of safety for the rest of the nation.

title: Britain Sets Up a Board To Assist Uganda Asians
description: LONDON, Aug. 18Robert Carr, the Home Secretary, an nounced today that the Gov ernment was setting up a board to help resettle the Asians with British passports who are being expelled from Uganda.

title: Art: A Funhouse of Laughs in Prints
description: Anyone on the lookout for some comic relief from the hurlyburly of whatever it may be should go to see the Humor in Prints show at Associated American Artists Gallery, 663 Fifth Avenue at 51st Street. The exhibition is a funhouse for all sorts of laughs, from a mild chuckle to a lusty guffaw, and its kind of humor spans every thing from visual slapstick comedy, grotesquerie and caricature to subtler satires and pictorial witticisms.

title: 8 NAMED BY NIXON TO COUNCIL ON ARTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)  President Nixon has named eight persons from the art, en tertainment and television fields to the National Council on the Arts, which advises on the dis tribution of millions of dollars of Federal funds to encourage and support cultural endeavors in the United States.

title: NOSE APPROVES FREER EXPORTING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) The House approved and sent to President Nixon today a bill to liberalize export controls on United States products that are available to Communist coun tries from other Western sources.

title: West Point: On Their Honor
description: We had been at West Point only a day when we were introduced, as a class, to the cadet honor code. Most of the class knew about the code in advance, having read in the catalogue that A cadet does not lie, cheat, or steal, or tolerate those who do. That was simple enough. But was it?

title: POLICE 10 DEPLOY TOTAL MANPOWER IN FIGHT ON GANGS
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that the police would make a new effort against major gangsters by getting every patrolman to observe and report on the movements of organizedcrime figureswhere they live, where they function, where they do business on a day  to  day basis.

title: Violence Surrounding Filipino Tribe Is Reminiscent of America's Old West
description: SURALLAH, the Philip pines, Aug. 15Army troops have deployed in and around this hot, dusty little farm ing community after a flare up of violence that illumi nated once more the problem of minorities in this part of the Philippines.

title: Miss Bourassa Posts 67
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 18 Jocelyne Bourassa, a 25 yearold rookie on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, breezed around Leawood South Country Club in five underpar 67 today for a two stroke lead after the first round of the $20,000 Southgate open.

title: Antibusing Bill Is Kept Alive in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Senator James B. Allen, Demo crat of Alabama, steered an antibusing bill today away from almost certain death in a liberaldominated Senate com mittee.

title: Africans Press Protest
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18 (AP)The Organization of African Unity announced today that it has sent a lastminute appeal to African members of the International Olympic Com mittee to press for the expul sion of the Rhodesian team from the Munich Games.

title: HENRY P. DURELLET OF CZARIST NAVY, 71
description: Henry P. duBellet who in his youth was an officer in the Russian Imperial Navy and who was imprisoned during the Russian Revolution, died Sun day at his home at 534 East 88th Street. He was 71 years old.

title: Team From U.P.I. Enters China for TwoWeek Stay
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 18 (UPI) A United Press International news team arrived in Peking to day at the invitation of the of ficial Chinese press agency Hsinhua.

title: Redskins Beat Eagles
