description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)Bill Kilmer threw two touchdown passes, Sonny Jur gensen tossed another and Mike Bass ran back an interception 86 yards for a score tonight as the Washington Redskins trounced the Philadelphia Eagles, 3410, for their third preseason victory.

title: PUSHOVER IS VICTOR IN CLOSE JUMPOFF
description: READINGTON, N. J., Aug. 18  Mr. and Mrs. Miles Valen tine's Pushover, with Carol Hof mann handling the reins, moved into contention for the open jumper championship today at the Four Seasons horse show.

title: June Steel Employment Up
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) Employment in the steel in dustry was up by about 8,500 workers in June, the seventh monthly intrease in jobs in a row, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.

title: Soviet Orbits Cosmos 515
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Soviet Union launched to day No. 515 in its Cosmos series of unmanned earth satel lites, Tass, the official press agency, said. As usual, no de tails were given.

title: VIKINGS SET BACK BY BILLS, 21 TO 10
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 18 (UPI) Dennis Shaw threw three touch down passes tonight in leading the Buffalo Bills to a 2110 vic tory over the Minnesota Vikings ln a preseason football game. The Vikings played without Iran Tarkenton, their No. 1 quarterback.

title: Man, 26, Has Transplant
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 18 (UPI)A 26yearold man, the 46th heart transplant recipient at Stanford University Hospital, was in fair condition today. The man, who received the heart yesterday, asked that his name not be made public, hospital of ficials said.

title: SHRIVER REBUTTED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18  The White House issued a re buttal today to charges made by Sargent Shriver, the Demo cratic VicePresidential nomi nee, that President Nixon blew an opportunity to end the Vietnam war in 1969.

title: Letters to the editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANT TO BE SHUT BY SIMPLEX WIRE
description: NORTH BERWICK, Me., Aug. 18  The Simplex Wire and Cable Company, which employs 625 persons at its power and control division plant here, will close the plant at the end of the year.

title: Crackdown on Charters Voids Many Return Tickets
description: Thousands of vacationers who bought roundtrip trans Atlantic airline tickets for as little as $150 are discovering that their return tickets are useless because of a Govern ment.crackdown on illegal char ter flights this summer.

title: Who's Trying Harder?
description: A man cycles casually up to a United Air Lines jet the Reno International Airport, boards with an army carbine rifle under his jacket and succeeds in com mandeering the plane.

title: HOUSE SUPPORTS AID TO JAPANESE IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The House, voted today to clear the way for 2,000 Japa neseAmericans to regain $4.5 million in family savings that the Government confiscated three decades ago.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Tortoise shell is sweep ing the fashion and home furnishings fields. Sometimes real and sometimes mock, tortoise is being used for everything from bracelets to .cigarette lighters to dining tables. It's all part of the interest in socalled natural products such as ivory, horn, leather and wood, but tor toise seems to be outrunning all the others in popularity at this moment.

title: Thailand Reports Drowning Of 2 New York City Tourists
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Two American tourists from New York City were reported drowned Wednesday when a boat in which they were riding capsized on the Bangkok River, Thai authorities said today.

title: Chase Manhattan Elects
description: Charles F. Barber, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Smelting and Re fining Company, has been elected a director of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: POMERANIAN BEST IN KEENE EXHIBIT
description: KEENE, N. H., Aug. 18Ch. Sheeba's Little Dragonfly, a 3yearold orangecolored Pom eranian weighing 4 pounds, owned and handled by Sam L. Zaneoff of New York, scored his fourth best in show today at the 21st dog show and obedience trial of the Cheshire Kennel Club, held at Weelock Park.

title: Couple Accused of Having Cocaine Worth $75,000
description: A Washington Heights couple were arrested yesterday after the police said they had found more than five pounds of co caine in their refrigerator.

title: Dead Baby Girl Found
description: The body of a newborn baby girl was found yesterday in plastic shopping bag near sonic garbage cans in an alleyway between 134 and 138 St. Mark's Place in Brooklyn.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company said yesterday it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a regis tration statement in connec tion with the sale of 4,520,000 common shares through a rights offering to shareholders on the basis of one new share for each ten shares held of record Sept. 13. The company said a subscription price will be set on that date. The com pany's stock closed unchanged at 22 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.A.W., in First Installment, Gives $75,000 to McGovern
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI) The United Automobile Work ers has contributed $75,000 to the campaign of Senator George McGovern as the first part of a most substantial contribu tion to the Democratic ticket, Leonard Woodcock, president of the union, said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MAKING OF BLACK REVOLUTIONARIES: A Personal Account, by James Forman. 568 pages. Macmillan, $12.50.

title: SHIVER ASSAILS NIXON ON MIDEAST
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 18Sargent Shriver opened a new Demo cratic courtship of Jewish sup port today, accusing President Nixon of playing politics with the relationship between the United States and the State of Israel.

title: DR. LOUIS KRONMAN
description: Dr, Louis Kronman, a dental surgeon who practiced in Brooklyn for more than 50 years, died Thursday in New burgh, N. Y., after having been injured in an auto accident there on July 14. He lived at 471, Bay Ridge Parkway and had his office at 5102 Fifth Avenue, both in Brooklyn.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Apparatus invented by two engineers for the Sperry Rand Corporation conducts traffic surveillance with a television camera mounted over the road way. Volume, speed and vehicle types are immedi ately known, and a computer can analyze the data for control of lights and signs. John S. Case and Edwin W. Whitfield of the Sperry Systems Man agement Division, Great Neck, L. I., were granted Patent 3,685,012 this week. The camera is aimed at a black and white strip painted across the highway. As vehi cles cross the strip their speed, length and, if neces sary, width are automatically noted. The size indicates the relative number of private cars and trucks, vans or trail ers.

title: GERULAITIS VICTOR AT SOUTHAMPTON
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. Aug. 18Vitas Gerulaitis, the United States junior clay court cham pion, upset fifthseeded Fred McNair of Chevy Chase, Md., 75, 26, 62, today in the quar terfinal round of the United States amateur tennis champi on ships at the Meadow Club.

title: Court Bars Subway Slowdown; L.I.R.R. Strike Still Impending
description: The Transit Authority obtained a court order yesterday tem porarily barring a work slow down Monday by the Subway Surface Supervisors Association,

title: LOUIS ABELSON
description: Louis Abelson, who retired in 1948 as an administrative as sistant at Samuel J. Tilden High School in Brooklyn, died Thurs day at the Hilaire Nursing Home in Huntington, L. I. He was 87 years, old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Henry Leuthardt, Designed Gardens for Williamsburg
description: EAST MORICHES, L. I., Aug, 18Henry Leuthardt, a horti culturist who laid out formal fruit and herb gardens for Colonial Williamsburg, for George Washington's home, Mount Vernon, and for the Cloisters in New York, died Tuesday at the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Pat chogue. He was 84 years old and had lived here since mov ing from Port. Chester, N. Y.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: GIVE A KID A BREAK. THE FRESH AIR FUND.

title: Letters to the editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Iowa to Get Disaster Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) President Nixon declared to day Iowa a major disaster area as a result of recent flooding that caused extensive damage in four counties.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Moscow Dynamo, the first Soviet soccer team to tour North America, played the Dallas Tornado to a scoreless tie Thursday night before 24,742 fans at Dallas Stadium in Dynamo's first game on the tour.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SEAFAIRING To say that there is something doing this weekend at the South Street Seaport is to say very little at all, because there is almost always something doing at the Seaport, which is one of the busier attractions in the city. What is doing this week end is something special one of the major events of the Seaport's year, the sixth annual South Street Crafts Fair.

title: Congress Adjourns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) Congress adjourned today with the Senate quitting at 4:57 P.M. and the House 48 minutes later. Both Houses will reconvene Tuesday, Sept. 5.

title: Moroccans Say General, Termed Suicide, Led Plot
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 18 Gen. Mohammed Oufkir, the late Defense Minister who was long considered a mainstay of the Moroccan monarchy, was named by the Government to night as the man who led the assassination attempt against King Hassan II on Wednesday.

title: Richard Burton as Bluebeard:He Plays Slayer of 7 Beautiful Women Baron Relates Story in Series of Flashbacks
description: Even before Baron von Sepper drove off for the day leaving his pretty young American wife with the keys to his castle, she had already heard strange noises in the corridors and found the baron's mother's mummy decaying in a guest-room rocking chair. So she cannot have been too surpriseda little disturbed, maybeto discover that the small golden key, the one she had been warned never to use, opened the door to a refrigerator full of seven dead women, dramatically arranged, whole or in dismembered parts.They are the Baron's six former wives, and one luckless prostitute, who found their way to the freezer (via decapitation, suffocation, drowning and the like) because he really loved his mother and thus preferred to kill rather than consummate his other relationships. This last bit of analysis comes from the American, as, through 90 minutes of flashbacks, the Baron tells her his story; and it is one of several modern variations upon the traditional tale in Edward Dmytryk's "Bluebeard," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama, R.K.O. 59th Street, and R.K.O, 86th Street Twin 2 theaters.Richard Burton plays Bluebeard, and a cast of international beauties  Virna Lisi, Raquel Welch (as a former nun), etcplay the wives. There is a lot of decorous titillation, on the level, say, of a Playboy center spread, and I guess the real distinction of the movie is that before its ends just about everybody gets undressed  except for Burton and Miss Welch. Among all those bodies there is at least one fine actress, Nathalie Delon, and there may be others. Joey Heatherton plays Anne, the only wife who survives. She is very lovely, and very fresh and open. But for all the use that "Bluebeard" makes of her, she might as well be grooming as the 1970's semi-nude answer to Sandra Dee.Seated at his organ, three Great Danes at his feet, a pet falcon perched high above his head, Richard Burton plays the brooding Baron as if "Bluebeard" were really another skit for "Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* But Were Afraid to Ask." To a certain extent it is. I have rarely seen a horror film so coyly aware of its own camp potential. But it is better at being foolishly serious than at being slyly humorous, and its few good moments come before it admits that its spook lighting and its maybe 3,000 pounds of phony cobwebs are essentially a joke."Bluebeard" seems to be set in Germany between the wars. There is a persecution-of-the-Jews subplot; and the Baron, a brutal party leader on his public side, dresses in black shirt and symbolic armband. The symbol in the armband looks like a swastika, but isn't. I can't imagine what nicety the filmmakers had in mind  unless, perhaps, a desire not to offend Nazis.

title: A.C.L.U. ASSAILS SUIT ON IMPEACHMENT AD
description: A Justice Department suit against the National Commit tee for Impeachment of Presi dent Nixon is the most incred ible violation of the First Amendment yet to come to our attention, the American Civil Liberties Union and the New York Civil Liberties Union said yesterday.

title: Former Assistant U.S. Attorney Will Prosecute the Sherwin Case
description: TRENTON, Aug. 18A for mer assistant United States attorney, Matthew P. Boylan, today was named special coun sel to prosecute the extortion indictments against Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two codefendants.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Aug. 18 (UPI)The Atlantic Coast Conference voted today to rescind its controversial academic requirement for varsity athletes. Only last week, faculty chairmen from the seven member schools voted appeal a Federal Court decision that struck down that academic rule.

title: Southern Pacific Orders $26Million of Equipment
description: The Southern Pacific Com pany announced yesterday that it had placed orders for 1,300 railroad freight cars costing $26million with two builders in the Pacific Northwest. The con tracts are part of the railroad's $196million program for new freight cars and locomotives during 1972.

title: Vulnerable Potentate
description: The second attempted coup in thirteen months against King Hassan II of Morocco increases the vulnerability of a traditional Arab monarchy which has enjoyed substan tial United States support.

title: GAP IS NARROWING IN FUND RESULTS
description: Mutualfund investors con tinued to redeem far more shares than they purchased during July but the gap be tween the two narrowed sig nificantly, the Investment Com pany Institute disclosed yester day.

title: DOCKERS IN BRITAIN VOTE TO END STRIKE
description: LONDON, Aug. 18  Long shoremen all over the country today rebuffed attempts by militant shop stewards to pro long the threeweekold na tional dock strike and voted to resume work.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The Federal Reserve Board announced today that it had stayed until Sept. 1 its earlier approval of an unusual bank holding company acquisition the proposed acquisition by the Royal Trust Company of Montreal of the International Bank of Miami.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP)  The United States dollar declined in Paris but was firm in London and Frankfurt today. The price of gold showed a slight rise.

title: 3 ARE ACQUITTED IN TOMBS UPRISING
description: Three inmates of the Manhat tan House of Detention for Men were acquitted by a State Su preme Court jury yesterday on all charges of leading a rebel lion at the jail in October, 1970.

title: SUGAR INDUSTRY WILL CORRECT ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 To settle a Federal Trade Com mission complaint, the sugar industry has agreed to spend $170,000 for advertisements correcting  or at least clarifying  earlier conten tions that eating sweets before meals helps people reduce.

title: British Bill Rates Rise
description: LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) Average rate at today's ten der of Treasury bills rose to 5.7709 from 5.7687 last week. This weeks 60million offer of 91 days bills met appli cations of 243,685,000. Appli cants for bills dated Monday to Friday at 98.56 received about 47 per cent. Next week 120 million in bills will be offered replacing 60million of matur ities.

title: Music: Entirely Mozart
description: Lincoln Center's mostly successful summertime festi val, which closes tonight with a performance of the Mass in B minor of Bach, took measures Thursday night to keep the balances tipped in favor of Mozart. The Guarneri Quartet played an Entirely Mozart program at Philharmonic Hall, with yeoman assistance from Lee Luvisi, the pianist, in the Pi ano Quartet No. 2 in E flat (K. 493).

title: The Chief of Protocol and His Vife: On the Go 18 Hours a Day
description: WASHINGTON When Emil (Bus) Mosbacher, a champion yachtsman, re signed recently as Chief of Protocol, his place was taken by Marion Smoak, a longtime polo player.

title: RONALD F. LEE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 18 Ronald F. Lee, historian of the National Park Service, died at Jefferson Hospital on Wednes day after a long illness. He was 66 years old.

title: Mrs. King Rallies, Gains Denver Net Semifinals
description: DENVER, Aug. 18 (AP)  The Wimbledon champion, Mrs. Billie Jean King, averted an up set today with a thirdset rally that led her into the semifinals of the $25,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament.

title: Gambler Stabbed to Death In Alleged Queens Robbery
description: An unemployed bartender with a record of gambling ar rests was found stabbed to death yesterday afternoon in his car in a Queens parking lot, the police said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: To the cabbie with the halo (letter Aug. 14): In his 35 years how many times did he remove his halo to ride with the flag up when there were passengers in the cab? How many peo ple did he cut off and endanger? How many red lights did lie run to pick up a fare? But for his statement not far behind a policeman, he should get the Angel of the Decade award.

title: Police Told to Stop Enforcing Most ConstructionSite Laws
description: In an effort to reduce oppor tunities for bribery, the Police Department has ordered its men to stop enforcing all the laws pertaining to construction sites unless pedestrians are en dangered or traffic is impeded.

title: 15th ChessTitle Garne Is Draw
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 18 It took only three moves for Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky to decide today on a drew in the adjourned 15th game of the world chess cham pionship match.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Shriver Says Bug Was Put in Office; Partner Disagrees
description: PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, Aug. 19 (AP)Sargent Shriver said last night that a bugging, device had been found in the telephone of a law associate in his Washington law offices.

title: Japan to Fight Car Smog
description: TOKYO, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Japanese Government, trying to cut back clouds of pollution that blanket urban areas each summer, an nounced plans today for strict standards on auto emissions.

title: Shelling at Dancing Kills 27 Civilians and American
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday. Aug. 19  Rockets fired by enemy gunners struck the Danang air base and a nearby residential area yester day, reportedly killing 27 South Vietnamese civilians and one American airman.

title: MURPHY EXPLAINS GUNRULE CHANGES
description: New regulations prohibiting city policemen from firing warning shots and firing at moving vehicles were de scribed by Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday as an attempt to balance the safety of the policeman with the safety of the community.

title: Plaits Beat Astros, 40
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Philadelphia Phillies scored three unearned runs tonight and defeated the Houston Astros,40, behind the pitching of Wayne Twitchell, a rookie.

title: CRIME GENERATES NIGERIAN DEBATE
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug 19An emotionally charged public de bate over crime and punishment has arisen in Nigeria in recent weeks, overshadowing most of the nation's other domestic issues.

title: Art.
description: FOR the 24 hours or so between Aug. 10 and 11 that it remained in tact, the Valley Curtain designed by wrapartist Christo was a sight to compete with the fancy mountain backdrop arranged here by nature herself. A shimmering orange drapery more than a quartermile long, strung between two slopes in Rifle Gap, it swayed and billowed in the wind as if about to reveal a Wagnerian spectacular staged by the elements.

title: SHOP TALK
description: DOVERWith 16,000 residents celebrating their town's 250th birthday, the party is a week of fun and games. Contests include pickingand prizes forthe best in almost everything. (cakedecorating, sackracing, flowerarranging and ballthrowing are a few).

title: Shorter Reviews
description: For Herbert Kupferberg, the Mendelssohns are the Rothschilds of culture. Their dynasty began with Moses, brighteyed hunchback from the Dessau ghetto who emigrated to Berlin and became one of the 18th century's noted philosophers. The second generation was represented by sisters, Dorothea and Henrietta, who maintained literary salons and indulged in amatory adventures, and by Abraham, wealthy merchant who devoted much of his energies to furthering the career of his son Felix, one of the great composers of all time. phers. The second generation was represented by sisters, Dorothea and Henrietta, who maintained literary salons and indulged in amatory adventures, and by Abraham, wealthy merchant who devoted much of his energies to furthering the career of his son Felix, one of the great composers of all time.

title: Rook Fans Arrive Early, Pose Problem at Festival
description: After getting final clearance from the city Friday for today's rock festival on Staten Island, the promoters of the event found themselves faced with new problemearly arrivals.

title: Winking Aye, Natural Sound Triumph Decisively in Split Signature Stakes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 Bunny Frizell's Winking Aye and William. P. Burke's and Sheila Pierce's Natural Sound scored easy victories in divisions of the Signature Stakes for 2yearold fillies at Liberty Bell race track today.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Thomas E. Dewey had a mustache. Afterwards, that was one of the thousand explanations you heard for Dewey's unaccountable failure to be elected President of the United States that year. It was 1948. To be sure, densely haired men were not the commonplace we know today, but the few who went in for itmustaches, sideburns, long lockstended to be the kind of men America respected. Clark Gable, after all, had a mustache.

title: Valerie Celeste Roast Is Married
description: CONVENT, N. J., Aug. 19St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this morning for the marriage of Miss Valerie Celeste Roast, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Roast of Morris Township, to Thomas Sean O'Connor. He is the son of Justice Frank D. O'Connor of the New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. O'Connor of Jamaica Estates, Queens.bride's sister, was maid of honor.

title: Terry Towne Is Wed on L. I.
description: ROSLYN HARBOR, LI., Aug. 19Miss Marian (Terry) Haitings Towne was married here this afternoon to Clayton Francis Johnson. The Rev. Stark Jones of the. Roslyn Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. William D. Littleford.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  First it was Robert Finch, then Walter Hickel, now George Romney. Disputes.between4he White House and Cabinet members have not been unusual in the Nixon Administration.

title: Prior Bows in Cricket
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club defeated the Prior Cricket Club of Philadelphia yesterday at Walker Park on Staten Island. Staten Island scored 165 runs for five wickets declared. Prior had 95 runs.

title: Coins
description: THE 81st anniversary convention of the American Numismatic Association closed a fiveclay run at the Jung Hotel on historic old Canal Street yesterday,

title: Leith McLean, Sculptor, to Wed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Mr. and Mrs. Gale McLean of Washington and Potomac, Md., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leith McLean, to Charles Classon Adams, son of Mrs. Walter H. Bowes of Washington and Charles Adams of New York and Washington.

title: Books: Wheels
description: THE GREAT MOTORCYCLES: HISTORIES OF 22 FAMOUS MAKES. By Geoffrey Wood and Richard C. Renstrom. 120 pages. Coyle World Library, Bond/Parkhurst (paperbound). Books. $4.59.

title: Licensing Is Urged For Safety Of Boaters
description: COLONIA  Thousands of New Jersey residents are puttering around in boats without any practical instruction ?? exprience these days, and Capt B. R. Henry of the ?? Bureau of Marine Law Enforcement doesn't like it.

title: Gardens
description: WEATHER conditions have been largely responsible for many problems on home lawns this year, with lawn diseases the extreme.

title: BIRD FLIGHT CUES STUDIED BY RADAR
description: A behavioral scientist has reported the development of new experimental technique, employing radar, to identify the navigational cues used by freeflying migratory birds.

title: It's Women's Week at U.S. Gallery
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19It's really kind of ironic, Mary Baker Eddy and Isadora Duncan sharing the same exhibition, the spokeswoman for the National Portrait Gallery said, but I think that just points up the diversity of women's contribution to American life.

title: Nixon Campaign Taking in $100,000 a Day
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19With the help of hundreds of wealthy businessmen and investors, two of whom have contributed nearly $50,000 apiece President Nixon's campaign treasurers are taking in an average of $100,000 a day.

title: American Y.C. Sail Produces Series Of Tight Finishes
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 19Close finishes highlighted the season's 29th Yacht Racing Association championship regatta run by the American. Yacht Club on Long Island Sound today.

title: Moderne is new again
description: The present trend to Depressionera fashionshighwaisted, pleated trousers and slithery crepe dresses is partnered by a similar backward drift in interior design. Art Deco and Art Moderne, those latetwenties and earlythirties forerunners of contemporary design, went unappreciated for decades until they were picked up by collectors. Designer Gayle Kirkpatrick became interested in the period as a source of ideas for women's fashion. And when he tired of the country French look in his Beekman Place apartment, he turned to Moderne. It was appropriate, he says, since the building itself is Art Moderne. He saw the living room as an elegant salon, hence, the long banquette in taupe leather beneath a handpainted mural in the romantic colors of the time. Finding authentic pieces wasn't easy. Prices are astronomical, he says. The livingroom chairs were found in Chelsea in terrible condition. Kirkpatrick had them rechromed and covered in chocolate suede. Mirrors and Lucite furniture (which was first developed

title: Miss Rosemary Clark Luttrell Bride of Eugene Paul Esposito
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., Aug. 19Miss Rosemary Clark Luttrell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Rider Luttrell of Sands Point, was married here this evening to Eugene Paul Esposito, son of Mr. and Mrs Simeon L. Esposito of Milford, Conn.

title: THE 1972 CAMPAIUGN
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 19If the balance of American politics truly belongs to the unyoung, unblack and unpoor, as some political analysts have insisted, then the Republican party's 1972 convention is in step with reality.

title: BILLINNAM HURLS A 3HIT SHUTOUT
description: The meandering Mets drewbut did not especially rewarda remarkable crowd of 50,400 persons yesterday in. Shea Stadium, where they suffered another mauling at the hands of the big red machine of Cincinnati.

title: Peter, Thomas, Joseph, Josephine and Simba, And How They Waited All Day for the Bus
description: SERENGETI, TanzaniaEvery few days or weeks, depending on the health of its carburetor, the disposition of its driver and the state of the roads, an old mudcaked bus chugs across Tanzania, all the way from the little Indian Ocean port of Tanga over the highlands to the shores of filharziainfested Lake Victoria.

title: Controversial Trooper Changes Voted in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 17  A Connecticut board has officially ratified a series of controversial changes in requirements for joining the state police force.

title: Gerulaitis, Mayer Win
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 19Vitas Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens, and Alex Mayer Jr. of Wayne, N. J., scored upsets to reach the final round of the United States amateur tennis championships at the Meadow Club today.

title: Indian Gets H.E.W. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has announced the appointment of a Puyullup Indian as director of the Office of Indian Affairs, Office of Special Concerns. Appointed was George Clark, 45 years old, of Seattle.

title: Sister Attends Anne Gilchrist At Her Bridal
description: EAST HAMPTON, LI., Aug. 19Miss Anne Lawrence Gilchrist and James Russell Tompkins were married here this afternoon, The Rev. Ralph Spinner, a Baptist minister, performed the garden ceremony at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Wetherill Knipe, also of New York.The bride is the daughter also of Alan Gilchrist of Greenwich, Conn. He is a sales executive with Masoneilan International, Inc., a division of StudebakerWorthington, Inc. Her mother is marketing director of Bride's magazine, and her stepfather advertising director of House and Garden magazine.

title: 5th Child for Mrs. Walsh
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Aug. 19 A daughter was born July 26 to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Walsh in the Overlook Hospital in Summit. Mrs. Walsh is the former Susan Bermingham. Her husband is with the International Business Machines Corporation in New York. The child, the couples fifth, has been named Elizabeth Anne.

title: McGovern Expects Thieu To Flee if Democrats Win
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19Senator George McGovern expects President Nguyen Van Thieu and his cohorts to flee Saigon into exile and a Communistdominated coalition to take control of South Vietnam if Mr. McGovern is elected President of the United States on Nov. 7.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Right on, Kevin Conway! Right on to all the people who attempt to produce serious and important theater in a downright hostile environment!

title: Student Weds Gaile A. Gordon
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 19Miss Gaile Andrea Gordon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack L. Gordon, and Craig Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Campbell of Redlands, Calif, were married in the garden of her parents home here today by the Rev. Charles Crawford Smith, minister of the Congregational Church.

title: MORE AMERICANS WED VIETNAMESE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19Marriages between Americans stationed here and Vietnamese women have risen to a peak rate since the beginning of the North Vietnamese offensive four months ago, even though the number of Americans now in South Vietnam is less than one tenth what it was in 1969.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Some laggard market groups finally began to bloom last week as institutions and other investors broadened their market interest beyond: glomour stocks.

title: W.O. Hiltz to Wed Sandra Lee Wright
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 19Mr. and Mrs. William A. Wright have announced the engagement. of their daughter, Miss Sandra Lee Wright, to William Otis Eiltz, son of Harry B. Hiltz Jr. of Garden City and Westhampton and the late Mrs. MariIla Otis Hiltz.

title: Udalls Cove Is Closer to Park Status
description: The western end of Udalls Cove has moved a bit closer toward the protected status of a city park, This came about earlier this month, when Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes approved an official map encompassing the proposed wetlands area

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Unfortunately your article on the musical activities of the Fromm Foundation gave the impression that Perspectives of New Music, which is no longer supported by the Foundation, would go out of existence. Subscribers and followers of Perspectives will be glad to hear that the journal will continue as a medium for articles in theory and criticism of contemporary music. Benjamin Boretz continues as the editor, and Princeton University Press as the publisher.

title: Nursing School Gets Grant
description: The Mount Sinai School of Nursing of City College has been awarded a $250,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to enrich its programs. The new dean of the school, Dr. Marian H. Bogard, who succeeds Dr. Cynthia Kinsella, who is retiring, will take office Sept. 1.

title: Trysail Fleet Off to Larchinont, But It's a Very, Very Slow Race
description: BLOCK ISEAND, R. I., Aug. 19In contrast to Wednesday's brisk run East, today's Governor's Cup Race West seemed symphony in slow motion. Hardly a breath propelled the 14 starters in the second half of the Storm Trysail Club's Larchmont Block Island Larchmont cruise.

title: GENERAL MILLS DUE TO REFUND AN OFFER
description: General Mills has agreed to refund money to consumers for football magazines and sporting materials not received through one of the company's promotional programs, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday.

title: Grips By M. D. Elevitch. 111 pp. New York: Grossman Publishers. $6.95.
description: Grips is exuberant nonsense, unlike some antirealistic novels, which are misanthropic nonsense. Nonetheless, the book lost its hold on me almost immediately after the first chapter.

title: Rome Police Arrest 2 Men In Bombing of Israeli Jet
description: ROME, Aug. 19The Rome police arrested two men today, the bearers of an Indian and of a Jordanian passport, who they believe plotted to bomb an Israeli jetliner that was carrying 148 passengers and crew members to Tel Aviv last Wednesday.

title: Television
description: IN the days BCBefore Cablewatching television at our apartment in Manhattan's West 70's was a bit like going sightseeing in heavy fog. Maybe it had something to do with the house we live in (builtin interference? we used to wonder), or maybe it's just that we're situated in a pocket of poor reception. Whatever the cause in those bad old days, Channel 13 was a sometime thing seen through a glass darkly; movies, aside from the frustration of those brutal commercial breaks, were enough of strain on the eyesight to make each seem likely to be our last picture show.; and on particularly bad nights, Walter Cronkite looked like the Brady Bunch.

title: Pop
description: DOC WATSON: Elementary Doctor Watson! (Poppy, PYS 5703.) In the everconstant rush to latch on to new performers, and to search out superlatives in praise of the finest sousaphone player of the last 300 Years, many of our truly great and lasting traditional musicians get lost. Doe Watson and his son Merle are in all probability the best flat picking guitar team in the United States. Their wideranging repertoire spans from such traditional numbers as Freight Train Boogie to Gershwin's Summertime to such recent tunes as Tom Paxton's Last Thing On My Mind.

title: Obscenity Issue Pending Before the U.S. Supreme Court Slows Drive on Smut in Times Square
description: Mayor Lindsay's campaign against pornography in the Times Square area has been slowed for the time being by an obscenity case pending before the United States Supreme Court.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Aug. 19Tension rose in Belfast today as 5,000 Protestant members of the Ulster Defense Association marched in military formation through city streets to a rally.

title: Georgia Is Rated No. 1 In Moonshine Output
description: ROME, Ga., Aug. 19 (AP)Georgia still leads the nation in the production of moonshine whisky, according to the United States Treasury Department.

title: G. O. P. Delegation to Miami Shows Unity
description: TRENTONIt took two straight losses and an incumbent President to achieve it, but New Jersey Republicans left for their national convention in Miami Beach today exuding a rare degree of party unity that only made the Democrats they left behind seem more divided than ever.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Munich Is a Big Town With a Big Heart and Prices That Are Out of Sight
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 19  Germans call Munich welstadt mit herz, the big town with a heart, and the surge in the city's population in the last decade confirms the love affair.

title: 1 Middlesex Family in 20 Earns More Than $25,000
description: Just one family In 20 in Nes,v Jersey's fastgrowing Middlesex County had an income topping $25,000 at the time, of the 1970 census.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The mezzanine tearoom where the sundaes are as elegant as the frock coats and lifts was omitted from the excellent article on Fortnum & Mason, Princely Emporium on Piccadilly (Travel section, July. 23). We trust this does not mean the disappearance of the tearoom. Where else but at the princely emporium would crushed macaroons be the regal touch to an already magnificent concoction of two kinds of ice cream, butterscotch sauce, whipped cream and a gentle dusting of powdered chocolate?

title: Gardens
description: IT WAS a perfect day. The sky was bright blue. The clouds were bleached whiter than white. The air was crisp, the breeZe cooling and gentle.

title: HandHeld Calculators: Tool or Toy?
description: Look again. The person next to you, apparently holding a tiny radio in his hand, may actually be using a calculator.

description: To the Editor:

title: WALL STREET.
description: Wall Street is buzzing with rumors that some highpriced heads are going to roll at the New York Stock Exchange after James J. Needham takes over as the new chairman and chief executive officer one week from tomorrow.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: DO YOU KNOW ANY IMPORTANT MAN IN BUSINESS WHO DOES NOT READ FORBES MACAZINE?ADVT.

title: Raiders Rout Rams, 349
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (UPI)  Ken Stabler put Oakland ahead with a 30yard touchdown pass to Charlie Smith in the last minute of the second quarter and Daryle Lamonica and Don Milan threw three more scoring passes for the Raiders in a 349 victory over the Los Angeles Rams tonight.

title: Photography
description: IKEEP thinking that Robert Frank's 1959 book, The Americans, contains dozens of pictures of the South Carolina low country. Actually, there are only sevennine if you include two from similar parts of Georgia and North Carolina. But in these nine pictures Frank has captured so much truth about that part of the world that they multiply in my mind until they nearly take over the book.

title: Shorter Reviews; Will There Really Be a Tomorrow?; By Frances Farmer. 318 pp. Putnam's. $7.95.
description: For those old enough to have been film fans in the late 30's or insomniac enough to endure the latelate reruns on TV, mention of the name of Frances Farmer will set old flames glowing. A strikingly beautiful blonde with promise of becoming a fine actress, she appeared in 19 notquitefirstrate pictures, starred in three Broadway shows (Clifford Odets's Golden Boy among them) and then disappeared into the shadows, aet. 30. Later she reappeared spasmodically and brieflyas a hotel reservation clerk, as hostess on a local TV show. In this autobiography, completed shortly before her death from cancer two years ago, she tells the whole story in graphic, horrifying detailher demonic mother, who used and abused her; her days as a student rebel in Seattle; her starletted time during Hollywood's mindless years; her ambiguous marriage to a fellow actor and her affair with Odets; her bouts with the bottle; her stretches in state mental institutions, where she was subjected to every degradation that could befall a woman. A ghastly tale , not to forget.

title: VILLAGE VOICE CHIEF TO HELP M'GOVERN
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, state campaign chairman for Senator George McGovern, announced yesterday the appointment of Bartle Bull, president of The Village Voice, as executive director of Citizens for McGovern in this state.

title: CITY CAMPS SCORED AS RURAL GHETTOS
description: The city was accused yesterday of having exported underprivileged children from ghetto in the middle of the city to another in the country.

title: Travel Notes: After the Flood
description: SINCE the floods of early summer, which washed out weeks of tourist business, thousands of people in Pennsylvania and western New York have been trying to recoup their losses. The word is that vacation business has been pretty good in August, but what is needed is a recordbreaking fall. There are hundreds of stories of the economic hardship wreaked by the floods, which were brought on by, Hurricane Agnes, but just one of them will serve to illustrate how the swamped vacationarea folk have had to fight back.

title: L.I.R.R. Strike Averted as Nixon Names FactFinding Board
description: A Long Island Rail Road strike set for 8 A.M. today was averted yesterday when President Nixon named a threeman factfinding board to investigate a dispute between the company and its 5,000 nonoperating employes.

title: Mistakes by City May Be Costing State $1Million in School Aid
description: The city's Board of Education is making mistakes in arithmetic that may be costing the state an extra $1million a year in aid, a report by State Controller Arthur Levitt charges.

title: Home Improvment
description: MODERN singlehandle (also called singlecontrol (faucets have become extremely popular in recent years for use in bathroom and kitchen sinksand for a number of very good reasons. Aside from the fact that most people find them much more convenient to manipulate (one handle regulates the proportion of hot and cold water, as well as the volume), there is also the fact that these modern faucets have no washers or washer seats that can wear downhence there is much less of a problem with drips or leaks developing, and much less overall mainterequired.

title: Suzanne M. Gallaudet Betrothed
description: BOSTON, Aug. 19Miss Suzanne Middlebrook Gallaudet and Thomas Edward Engel plan to marry Nov. 25. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Stephen H. Swift, the prospective bride's mother.

With active assistance from their semilegendary father, Earl, the Scruggs Brothers have given Nashville another inside shove in the direction of rock by devoting half of this, their second album, to numbers employing distinctly

title: Team Canada Vs. Soviet Union: Pressure on Both Sides
description: TORONTO, Aug. 19 The forthcoming series of eight hockey games between Canada's best professional players and the Soviet Union's national team will be a confrontation between two systemsa capitalist group including some of the highest paid athletes in the'worid and a Socialist team whose players, in a sense, are on civilservice payroll.

title: Woman Is Reported Found Alive Near Body of Lombardi Upstate
description: A 22year old woman was found beside the body of Carlo Anthony Lombardi, a Brooklyn hoodlum, when she was found shot to death in Sullivan County on Aug. 10, the state police said yesterday.

title: SCULPTURE GARDEN HOST TO DANCE BILL
description: Outdoor performance is as much a trap as an opportunity. For the Dances of Lonny Joseph Gordon, seen in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art Friday night, the setting was not hospitable.

title: Congo Republic and Zaire Agree to Resume Relations
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, Aug. 19 (Agence France Presse)  The Congo Republic and Zaire have decided to reestablish diplomatic relations, it was learned here today.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Was it the intention of Avery Hunt in The Bargain Basement at J.F.K. (Travel section, July 30), concerning the North Passenger Terminal used by charterflight passengers at Kennedy Airport, to create doubt as to the reliability and dependability of the charter airlines, which are specialists in lowcost transportation? Substantial savings can be realized without sacrificing quality by shopping in bargain basements of discount stores. The nation's charter airlines operate the same, modern jet equipment as the scheduled airlines do, and in some cases it is more modern. As for maintenance, the same high standards set by the Federal Aviation Administration apply to both the charter and scheduled carriers. Similarly, the flight crews of the charter airlines meet the same proficiency standards as the scheduled carriers crews

title: Art.
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. JUST a hundred years ago Yellowstone was established as. the world's first national park, and now the National Collection of Fine Aits is celebrating the National Parks Centennial Year with an exhibition called National Parks and the American Landscape. It is a handsome, wellorganized display of early. pictorial records of the sites that were or have become national parks (the Grand. Canyon, surprisingly, became a national park only in 1919). About 150 paintings, drawings, and fine old photographs have been assembled to show (of course) the look of the great wildernesses and (less obviously) the impact they Made on American landscape painting through the work of artists who actually accompanied expeditions or otherwise roughed it early in the game.

title: 6,000 New Dictionaries Will Cover the Lexical World From Altaic to Zaire
description: Those who speak of looking up a word in THE dictionary will not be heartened by news that a publishing company is about to produce 6,000 different dictionaries.

title: Black Vote Pushed In Nassau Areas
description: ROOSEVELT, L. I.A different kind of voterregistration drive is pushing through every black community in Nassau, a day after day, house to house search for voters by a dedicated band of black youths.

title: The World
description: LONDONAlthough it is two weeks since Ugandan President Idi Amin declared that 50,000 Asian residents who hold British passports would have to leave within 90 days, Britain is only

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Imagine my surprise! An article on jazz saxophone without a mention of Stan Getz. It's like a discussion of newspapers without mention of The New York Times.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Being a performer has always enabled me to express myself as an individual. Yet when I took part in the April Peace March, I realized how beautiful it felt to be one face in a massive sea of faces! There I stood among thousands, sharing a common cause as well as an umbrella and bits of food and wine to warm our bodies against the chilling rain.

description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 19 Western oil companies held talks today with producing nations to try to avert threatened unfavorable legislation or nationalization of their operations.

title: Margaret Bolz Wed
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., Aug. 19Miss Margaret Elsie Bolz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Bolz of Garden City, and Kenneth Lee Shaffer of York, Pa., son of Mrs. Edna C. Shaffer of Mannheim, Pa. and the late Mr. Shaffer, were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Frederic J. Teichmann in the Gloria Dei Luthearn Church. The couple are accountants with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., in Philadelphia.

title: Reliance on Autos Called Major Problem in the State
description: ALBANY, Aug. 19 The biggest transportation problem facing New York today is still how to encourage people to make more and better use of public transportation instead of their cars, according to Theodore W. Parker, the State Commissioner of Transportation, who is leaving office on Labor Day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rockefeller Brothers Fund Gave $10.2Million in 1971
description: The Rockefeller Brothers fund made contributions totaling $10,287,498 in 1971, the largest amount in its 30year history.

title: The Lord's Pink Ocean By David Walker. 185 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $5.95.
description: The instrument of annihilation in this doomsday novel is no longer the Bomb but the Ecology. David Walker fancies a blight of pink algae smothering the planet Earth, save for spots in Greenland, Siberia and a few isolated hideouts.

title: Devlin Leads in Golf by 2 Strokes with 206
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 19Bruce Devlin of Australia, who plans to pack his clubs and leave the tour for three months after tomorrow's play, apparently means to take leave in grand style. By carding birdies on two of the last four holes in the third round of the $200,000 U.S. Industries Classic, the former plumber from Canberra scored a 69 and took a twostroke lead with a 54hole total of 206.

title: The Other Battleground The Home Fronts: Britain, France and Germany 191418. By John Williams. Illustrated. 326 pp. Chicago; Henry Regnery Company. $10.
description: Like the French Revolution, World War I will clearly continue to define a watershed in Western history. The world was less changed than people thought at the time; but they thought that everything was changing. Worse was to come, but it seemed then that the worst had come.

title: McGovern Gets Pleas, Shakes Greasy Hands
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 19 (UPI)A grizzled old man with grease all over his hands and clothes looked about frantically for something to wipe his hands on.

title: U.S. Blacks Boycott Meet With Rhodesia
description: Black athletes preparing for the Olympic Games, which begin next Saturday in Munich, West Germany, extended their boycott movement yesterday.

title: Science
description: Today when a child asks his parents, What is a star? or How old is the world? he can be given a meaningful answer, thanks to a great accumulation of hardwon knowledge.

title: The Nation
description: Don't worry, we only kill each other, said Bugsy Siegel in 1947 to reassure a nervous contractor who was building a casino for the gangster.

title: SHERIFF IS CLEARED IN PRISONER'S DEATH
description: OCALA, Fla., Aug. 19 (UPI)An allwhite jury cleared Sherif Willis V. McCall of seconddegree murder charges today in the death of Tommy Vickers, black prisoner.

title: They Fled Urban Pressures for a Sanctuary in the Wilderness
description: KILDONAN, B. C.  Jack Edison Hobbs first saw his acre and a half of Canadian wilderness here during rain squall that had lowered the heavens to his hilltop and transformed his mountain stream into a whitecapped torrent.

title: Blacks March in Uganda To Back Ouster of Asians
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 19 Gripping placards and chanting, hundreds of Ugandans surged through downtown Kampala today in a demonstration supporting the Government's move to expel Asian shopkeepers and businessmen.

title: Vietnam Review
description: Henry Kissinger's consultationi in Saigon and the return to Hanoi of North Vietnam's chief Paris negotiator,. Le Duo Tho, suggest that a moment of truth is approachin the long quest for peace in Indochina. After three secret KissingerTho meetings in six weeks, both sides are reviewing the bidding in preparation for the final round of settlement talks before the American election.

title: Miss Parker Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Miss Caroline Rine Parker to Alan H. Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney D. Young of Rockville Centre, L. I., has been announced by the future bride's parents. Mr. and Mrs. Sanford S. Parker of New York. A wedding in October is planned.

title: What's New at the Movies
description: EVERYTHING YOU ALWAYS WANTED TO KNOW ABOUT SEX BUT WERE AFRAID TO ASK, directed by Woody Allen, got 8 favorable reviews (Vincent Canby, Times; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Jeffrey Lyons, WPLXTV; Judith Crist, New York; Penelope Gilliatt, New Yorker; Rex Reed, News; William Wolf, Cue), 7 mixed (Gene Shalit, NBC; John Simon, New Leader; Jay Cocks, Time; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Harry Pearson, Newsday; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service) and 6 negative (Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Andrew Sarrls, Village Voice; Richard Schickel, Life; Arthur Review).

title: Fort Dix Welcomes Girls in Program
description: FORT DIXThis 55yearold military installation, which has given basic train ing to tens of thousands of young men, became a vacation spot this summer for groups of young girls.

title: Nancy Manson Is Bride
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Aug. 19Miss Nancy Ann Manson, daughter of Mrs. John W. Manson and the late Mr. Manson, was married here today to Timothy P. Donaldson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Donaldson of Convent Station. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Richard Anderson, the rector, and the Rev. Albert Wickens of St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: Peter Michael Rooney Marries Wynne Bilby
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 19Miss Barbara Windsor Bilby and Peter Michael Rooney, seniors at the University of Pennsylvania, were married here this afternoon at the home of Mrs. Helen Owen Bilby, mother of the bride.

title: Burkhalter Places First In 1,000Yard Rifle Match
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 19 (UPI)  Army Reserve Limit Col. Sam Burkhalter of Lake Forest, Ill., won the 1,000yard Leech Cup match today at the National Rifle Association championships.

title: TRIUMPH TO KLINE
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Aug. 19 Bobby Murcer was reduced to bunting a plastic cup in pregame clubhouse batting practice tonight, but then went outside and clouted baseball far enough to start the Yankees on the way toward ending their fourgame losing streak.

title: KENNEDY TENNIS LURES TOP STARS
description: The bestand the worstin tennis will be on display. in the Robert F. Kennedy ProCelebrity tennis tournament at Forest Hills, Queens, on Saturday.

title: Residents Are Seeking To Protect South Fork
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I. Fearful that possible overdevelopment might tax the natural resources and destroy the rural resort nature of the South Fork, some area residents have founded an organization to preserve and protect ,the environment.

title: A. PRESS COUNCIL SET UP IN ONTARIO
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 19A group of leading Ontario publishers has just set up a press council to promote the confidence of readers in the newspapers of, the province.

title: Fischer, in Seclusion, Awaits the 16th Game
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 19 (UPI)Bobby Fischer, his lifetime ambition to become the first United States world champion, spent his Sabbath in seclusion.

title: Why Revive Sunny'? Why, for the Songs!
Bank Deposits Museum in Many Branches
description: There is a museum in the city that millions of people have seen, but few know about. Yet it has one of the most extensive collections of 19thcentury maritime Americana in the world.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: Hans Werner Henze is one of the important composers of this age. He is also a very complex personality, as Joan Peyser's article, Henze, Where the Action Music Is, clearly indicates. Contrary to what he alleges, practically all of his compositions have been and are being played on German radio. The Raft of the Medusa had been commissioned by the North GerRadio.

title: Suzanne Cannon Bride in Suburbs
description: WESTON, Conn., Aug. 19  Miss Suzanne Cannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerry Cannon of Southport, was married here this afternoon, to Edward Martin Anderson, son of Mrs. Walter Anderson of Bradford, Pa., and the late Mr. Anderson.

title: Quarrel on Ruhr Disclosed in Papers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19, (Reuters)British management of the Ruhr coal mines in occupied Germany two years after the end of World War II was called pathetic and (failure by Secretary of State George C. Marshall, according to official documents made public this week.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Thank you for Donal Henahan's article about the programs of the Philharmonic with young black musicians. It is indeed high time that something like this got started and I hope that our own Boston Symphony, of which I have just been elected an Overseer, may follow suit.

title: Disabled Jet Lands Safely
description: An American Airlines Boeing 727 jetliner, with 15 passengers and a crew of five aboard; safely made an emergency landing early today at Kennedy International Airport after its nose landing gear failed. An airline spokesman said there were no injuries when the three engine plane, Flight 324 from Baltimore, landed.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Recently I attended a weeknight performance of Mat Supposed to Die A Natuial Death with my college classes. Attendance at the theater was sparse. Some.of my students did not all themselves of the opportunity to see this fine play before it closed, because of their limited financial resources.

title: Illusion and legend; The Sword And The Grail Retold by Constance Hieatt. Illustrated by David Palladini. 82 pp. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $4.50. (Ages 9 to 12)
description: Constance Hieatt's fifth book of Arthurian legend, The Sword and the Grail rescues still another jewel from the dank shadow cast by Alfred Lord Tennyson. A medievalist of distinction, she has created a lucid, moving story from a lode of jumbled sources, and made it accessible to readers too young to cope with the complexities of versions by Andrew Lang, James Knowles, or Howard Pyle.

title: Royals Edge Brewers, 21
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 19 (UPI) Jahn Mayberry hit a homer in the seventh tonight to earn the Kansas City Royals a 21 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Environmental Impact of Sports Complex Is Still a Question
description: HACKENSACKAfter 27 witnesses and 3,600 pages of testimony, the environmental battle over the proposed New Jersey sports complex may be approaching a climax.

title: World News Briefs;More Britons Vote To End Dock Strike
description: LONDON, Aug. 19Dockers at Glasgow and Manchester voted today to return to work, leaving longshoremen in Liverpool as the only port workers holding out against a decision by union leadership to end Britain's 23dayold nationwide dock strike.

title: Eula M. Duke Officer's Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 19Miss Eula Marie Duke and Lieut. John Macomber Bond, U.S.A., were married here this afternoon at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Bond. The Rev. Charles Smith of the Congregational Church here performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I was moved by your story of the bankruptcy in the Virgin Islands ["A Bankruptcy Jolts St. Croix Buyers, July 30]especially by the plight of the Chicago doctor who finds it difficult to continue his four vacations a year. He may not have been business oriented, as he says in the article, but he sure knew a good, taxdeductible way to arrange his vacations.

title: Death Linked to Shove
description: A 27yearold woman was apparently pushed to her death yesterday from a window of her sixthfloor apartment in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section during an argument with an unidentified male friend, the police reported. The victim, Muriel Boyce, was pronounced dead on the sidewalk outside her home at 1045 St. John's Place about 6 A.M.

title: JOHN J. MONIGAN JR.
description: SEA GIRT, N.J, Aug. 19 (AP) John J. Monigan Jr., a lawyer and former president of the Monmouth County Magistrate's Association, died yesterday in Newark after becoming ill at railroad station. He was 58 years old and lived here at 205 Washington Boulevard,

title: Floods and Slides in South Korea Kill at Least 264
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, Aug. 20The national police reported this morning that at least 264 persons were killed yesterday in floods and landslides caused by the worst rains in South Korea's modern history.

title: If You Go..
description: . to the Chateau de Lucens, take Highway 1 (LausanneBern) to Lucens in the canton of Vaud. (The chateau is 18 miles from Lausanne, 38 miles from Bern.) Or take the 45minute train ride from Lausanne. The chateau is open daily except Mondays from 10 to 12 and 2 to 6.

title: Heroin:
description: WASHINGTONWhen campaigning for the office in 1968, Richard Nixon singled out narcotics as America's Public Enemy Number One. Since becoming President, he has lent his prestige to campaigns and Congressional messagesaimed at cutting down the scourge. And in the past three years, the Administration has increased by 1,000 per cent the amount of money spent against drugs.

title: 128Page Football Book Available for $2 a Copy
description: The 128page E.C.A.C. Football Guide for 1972 is off press and orders for Its purchase are being received at the Eastern College Athletic Conference, Royal Manhattan, New York, N.Y. 10036. The price is $2 per copy.

title: Panthers Exchanging Guns for Ballots
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Sixteen months ago, two Black Panthers, Erika Huggins and Bobby. G. Seale, were on trial for their lives in a Connecticut courthouse.

title: MIAMI BEACH
description: MIAMI BEACHThis year's Republican convention is mainly a big anniversary party for Richard Nixon, and even his old competitors for political Maderthip, Governor Rockefeller on the left and Governor Reagan on the right, are joining in the fun.

title: Deputy Named to Head Transportation in State
description: ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP)Raymond T. Schuler has been named State Commissioner of Transportation, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today. Mr. Schuler, now executive deputy commissioner of transportation, will succeed Theodore W. Parker, a retired general, in the $42,475ayear position, effective Sept. 6.

title: Chains Cut, Hogs Stolen
description: RUSHVILLE, Ind., Aug. 19 (UPI)After 41 hogs worth $2,500 were stolen from pens at the RushHenry Stockyards a week ago, Jim Ringer, the operators, had chains stretched across the property to prevent trucks from entering the area. Early Wednesday, rustlers cut three chains and stole 31 hogs valued at $1,450.

title: 26Story Asbury Towers Is Tallest House on Coast
description: ASBURY PARKTopping out ceremonies for a new 26story Asbury Towers being sponsored by the Presbyterian Synod of New Jersey at Eighth Avenue on the beachfront here, will mark what city officials say is the tallest residential structure directly on the ocean btween New York and Florida.

title: COOP ANALYZES OATBASED CEREAL
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 19The various oatsbased granola cereals that have become popular in recent years as a health food have little more nutritional value than some conventional cold breakfast cereals, a home economist says.

description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP)Alex Johnson and Graig Nettles smashed home rung today as the Cleveland Indians ended threegame losing streak by defeating the Oakland A's, 54.

title: Marriage Planned By Andrea Tobey

title: Carlton E. Hill, 68, Editor Of Weekly in Connecticut
description: MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 19Carlton E. Hill, editor and a columnist of the Milford Citizen, a weekly newspaper, died here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 67 Knob Hill Road.

description: The 40,000member Action Committee on AmericanArab Relations endorsed yesterday the Democratic Presidential ticket of Senator George McGovern and Sargent Shriver The Associated Press reported.

description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP)Thistledown race track recorded its second largest daily double payoff of the summer today when the 123 combination paid $1,612.60 for $2.

description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 19United States golf officials are taking a handsoff attitude toward the conflict raging in Japan over that nation's new $300,000 tourney.

description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 19 (UPI)Edward Sullivan, the coinlaundry operator who defied President Nixon's freeze by raising prices a year ago, is selling his business.

description: When a Japanese trade mission visited this country in May with the announced aim of helping Americans increase their exports to Jappan, skeptics felt it had to be some kind of a puton.

description: CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 19Mayor Lindsay, doing some Democratic Presidential campaign work in western New York, today reiterated his plea for reordered American priorities to aid the cities.

description: SOUTH ORANGE Teams of publichealth investigators will begin ringing doorbells tomorrow in three communities to gauge the immunity of residents to some common childhood diseases.

description: To the Financial Editor:The problem of tracking qualified women into executive jobs is not so much that of the corporations as it is that of the agencies. The response of employment agency people (no matter what they call themselves executive

title: Performance Canceled
description: An eye operation on Ella Fitzgerald has forced cancellation of the singer's appear., ance at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel next Wednesday evening. No other performer has been scheduled for that evening.

title: RICHARD M. GREEN, ILLUSTRATOR, DIES
description: MIAMI, Aug. 19Richard Maxwell Green, an artist, died here Thursday of injuries received when he was struck by a car on Aug. 6. He was 51 years old.

description: Miss Carol Strano and Robert Emanuele Ronzoni, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuele Ronzoni Jr. of Port Washington, L. I., will be married in December in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Hillcrest, Flushing, Queens.

title: It's Cricket to Play The Game ori
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I.The batter swung and connected. The ball rocketed across the turf, and a man moved over and gathered it in smoothly. But a spectator in Eisenhower Park here appeared baffled. There seemed to be two, batters, but only two bases. What was going on?

title: Three Approved by Senate For Posts in Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The Senate has confirmed the nomination of Jack F. Bennett of Greenwich, Conn., to be a Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: It is disappointing that The Times has seen fit to open its pages to a manifestation of the Jaggermania now so nauseatingly endemic to our media (Peter Schjeldahl, An Aging Kid Digs the Stones). For some decent people, at least, the spell of this music ceased with the chilling Altamont spectacle when Jagger unleashed his drunken minions, the Hell's Angels, to beat and stomp people, finally killing one.

title: Strollers on South Street Find a Bazaar Surprise
description: For those left in the city yesterday by choice or circumstance, it was a day of sticky streets, crowded subways and a few pleasant surprises.

description: WATERLOO  Colonialstyle towns restored to reflect American life of long ego bear such American names as Williamsburg, Sturbridge and Cooperstown.

title: Marshall Field Marries Jamee Jacobs

The ceremony in the chapel at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Holy Name was performed by the Rev. Timothy J. Lyne and attended by a dozen guests.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: In his article Mozart, Bach and the Great Divide, Donal Henahan states that Mozart knew the music of the Bach sons, but not that of the father almighty. However, if we are to believe The Times own Harold Schonberg, this stylistic chasm was bridged by one Baron Gottfried van Swieten, who introduced Mozart to the music of J. S. Bach in 1781.

title: 8thGrade Girl Captures U.S. Open Billiards Crown
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) An eighthgrader from Brooklyn today won $1,500 and the 1972 women's United States open pocket billiards championship.

title: Miss Chandler, Cobb Cited
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 19 (AP)Jenni Chandler of Birmingham, a diver and Barney Cobb of Richmond, a runner, have been named outstanding girl and boy athletes of the National Amateur Athletic Union Junior Olympics held in Spokane this week.

title: French Fire Kills 8 Elderly
description: RISORANGIS, France, Aug. 19 (AP)Eight elderly persons died and 20 suffered burns or were overcome by smoke when a fire swept through a threestory old people's home here south of Paris early this morning. The police reported. There were 28 persons, many bedridden, living in the home.

title: JAPAN IS ASSURING TAIWAN ON TRADE
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 19In recent days Ambassador Atshushi Uyama of Japan has invited some of Taiwan's leading industrialists to his villa on Grass Mountain just outside Taipei in an attempt to allay fears About Tokyo's approaches to Peking.

title: Naticy McGeorge Wed To Albert Kobylarz Jr.
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Aug. 19Miss, Nancy Lynne McGeorge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. McGeorge, was married here this morning to Albert. G. Kobylarz Jr., son of Colonel Kobylarz, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kobylarz. The ceremony in the United Methodist Church was performed by the Rev. Dean Lanning, assisted by the Rev. John Egan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Tigers Rout Angels, 101
description: DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP)The Detroit Tigers jumped on California's pitcher, Rudy May, today for six runs in the first inning and went on to a 101 triumph over the Angels. Two of the early runs came in on homer by Al Kaline and two on Ed Brinkman's single.

title: Riesel Gets Ecology Post
description: Daniel Riesel, who has been on the staff of the United States Attorney for the Southern district of New York since 1967, was named yesterday to head that office's environmental protection unit. He will be responsible for investigations, prosecutions and civil cases involving pollution and other environmental matters.

title: Chess:Quality of Championship Play Not What Had Been Expected
description: The kind of chess that has been played in the first 15 games of the world championship match between Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky has been extremely good. But it is far from what chessplayers had been led to believe would be exhibited by Fischer.

title: CARDS 3 IN EIGHTH DOWN GIANTS, 74
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (UPI)Doubles by Bernie Carbo, Joe Torre and Ed Crosby highlighted a threerun, eighthinning rally today and John Cumberland pitched onehit relief over the final three innings in leading the St. Louis Cardinals to a 74 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: PingPong diplomacy
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: It isn't only Little Bo Peep who has lost her sheep, but the nation's textile industry as well. Wool fiber appears to be losing out in the longterm prospects of fabrics, even though there is a revival of interest in wool this year.

title: Education
description: SAN FRANCISCOA need for more and better trained lawyersthis was a constant theme at the American Bar Association convention here last week, but little was said about the law schools. Only the law students division, which met in almost complete isolation from the main conference, seemed interested in tackling educational problems.

title: Endowment for Humanities Awards Youth Grants to 29
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)  The National Endowment for the Humanities has announced the first youth grants of $675 to $10,000 to 29 persons Aged 18 to 30.

title: Miss Goolagong Overwhelms Miss Wade in anada Tennis Final, 63, 61
description: TORONTO, Aug. 19 (AP).Evonne Goolagong of Australia put on a display of superb shotmaking today and won the women's singles crown at the, Canadian open tennis championships with a 63, 6.1 victory over Virginia Wade of Britain.

title: Portuguese Find the Spirit of Salazar Still Dominant
description: LISBON, Aug. 13  Four years after the disappearance of Antonio de Oliveira Salazar from the political scene, his authoritarian system  which made Portugal Europe's last colonial empire and its least developed nation  remains firmly in force.

title: Argentina's Lanusse under the long shadow of Peron
description: When I went to live in Buenos Aires as a newspaper correspondent I found I had inherited a paid informant called The Bullfrog. He was an old newspaperman and he practically lived in the Pink House, which is what Argentines call their Government house. The Bullfrog looked for news to sell, and if he could not sell the news to me, he would auction it off to the highest bidder. I paid The Bullfrog to inform my office of news that I might want to buy on short notice. He knew what kind of news that was: nothing less than troops kicking the President out of the Pink House in a military coup.

title: Robert Wacker Weds Miss Mary Barnard
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Aug. 19Miss Mary Elizabeth Wood Barnard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gibson Barnard Jr. of Far Hills and Harbour Island, Bahamas, was married here this evening to Robert Stephen Wacker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edwin Wacker of Indianapolis. Canon James Johnson performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. John's on the Mountain.

title: Steelers Trounce Falcons, 3117, as Hanratty Passes for Two Touchdowns
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 19 (AP)Terry Hanratty threw two touchdown passes and two rookie running backs broke loose on long scoring runs today as the Pittsburgh Steelers defeated the Atlanta Falcons, 3117.

title: 4 Killed Off Australia
description: DARWIN, Australia, Aug. 19 (Reuters)four men died in light plane that dived into runway and burst into flames on takeoff today from Groote Eylandt, an island 400 miles east of Darwin.

title: Dance
description: ESTHETICIANS know a lot of good guessing games, One of these concerns the performing arts, and it begins with the question, What is The Work? Properly, but confusingly, the answer might be that the work is the artist's creation as it is translated via musical score or play script into a performance which is received by an audience. To a scrupulous few, The Work may emerge dimly only through a concatenation of performances. To many, the printed text stands for the play, the musical score for the composition. This is convenient: nearly everyone can read, and many can read music. Therefore critics and interested spectators can examine a particular rendition of a work in terms of what they deduce from the printed page to be the author's intention.

title: Complacent Bar
description: The American Bar Association, at its annual convention in San Francisco, diligently skirted controversy. afforded generous forum to respectably conservative voices from the United States and abroad, and generally gave the impression that there is little wrong with the state of legal process that more money for more lawyers and more judges could not cure. Indeed, it was this air of satisfied consensus that gave such extraordinary audibility to the sideshow provided by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark's report from Hanoi.

title: Flowers of the Sun
description: The sunflowers don't actually take over August, but this definitely is their season in the sun. Native Americans; they now are found virtually everywhere from Maine to Oregon, California to Florida. There is even an alpine species that grows at altitudes up to 12,000 feet. Everywhere, the deep, warm yellow of their petals catches the eye. A little later the hooks and spines on some of their seeds will catch the coat sleeve, the trouser leg or the sock and hitch a ride to still another seedbed.

title: Police Seek Two in Robbery Of $2,000 at Ballet Theater
description: The police were seeking two men yesterday who made off with $2,000 in cash and jewelry valued at $6,000 after a holdup Friday afternoon at the offices of the American Ballet Theater.

title: To the Finland Station A Study in the Writing and Acting of History. By Edmund Wilson. With a new Introduction. 590 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus &
description: None of the eulogies for Edmund Wilson has mentioned what seems to me his most splendid achievement: to have written the last great 19thcentury novel. To the Finland Station: A Study in the Writing and Acting of History, originally appeared in 1940, and it was hailed generally as a sensitive, exciting history of the modern radical movement that reached its climax (or, at least, one of its climaxes) in the Bolshevik Revolution. Now, a generation after, we have a new edition, and an occasion to reappraise the book in the context Of a new age, and I want to argue that it is far more original and more powerful than its first generation of readers could have known. Its virtues are so striking now because they are virtues that are not merely absent, but virtually forgotten, in both the fictional and the nonfictional writing of today.

title: PLATFORM HAILS G.O.P. TAX RECORD OF SOUND REFORM
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 19The proposed economic plank of the Republican platform says that the Nixon Administration has already brought about sound tax reform and that the party will reject deceitful reforms that would raise the taxes of millions of middleincome Americans.

title: HorseLoving Families Race Them
description: FREEHOLDA horselover, according to the late Joe. Palmer, a purist where the English language was concerned, is one horse who loves another horse.

title: Blaze Drives 25 Families From S. Bronx Apartments
description: A twoalarm fire of unknown origin forced 25 families from their homes in a South Bronx apartment house last night.

title: Miss Raine Married
description: Miss Victoria Raine, daughter of Mrs. Jean Sutter Raine of New York and Kenneth E. Raine of Sea Girt, N.J., was married here this afternoon in St, Bartholomew's Episcopal Church to Kyle W. Hitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hitt of Goodlettsville, Tenn. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes performed the ceremony.

title: CONNECTICUT PLANS TO CHANGE LOTTERY
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 17 (UPI) The Connecticut State Gaming Commission is revising the Connecticut lottery in order to simplify its structure and place more prize money into the hands of players.

title: Art.
description: AUGUST is a scary month for art reviewers who must observe a regular schedule of articles. For in August in New York, art shows are nearly as scarce as psychiatrists, and the frightening prospect of having to waffle up.a think piece looms. But this week it's possible to relax. New York University and the city Parks Department have cooked up a likable exhibition that would merit a look even in October. Called Outsized Drawings and Multiples, this collection of works by 18 New York artists will be on view for few more days at the Loeb Student Center, 4th Street and LaGuardia Place.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  A complaint of long standing by Democrats and labor unions is that the Nixon Administratration's wage and price control program holds down wages more effectively than prices. As if in rebuttal, the White House last Monday publicly challenged the auto industry to cancel or scale down its proposed price increases for 1973 models.

title: Staunch Avenger Wins
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., Aug. 19 (AP)Staunch Avenger, owned by Mrs. Annette Mann, charged strongly on the outside to win the. $56,500 Washington Park Handicap at Arlington Park today.

title: F. A. Kissel to Wed Sylvia Talmage
description: FAR HILLS, N.J., Aug. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Prentice Talmage Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sylvia Bill Talmage, to Frank Ashburn Kissel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter F. F. Kissel of Indian Creek Island, Fla.

title: Criminals At Large
description: It used to be that suspense novels dealt primarily with innocent little people pursued by unknown forces.
