description: The Council of Better Business Bureaus recently finilshed what it calls the largest sampling of consumer opinion ever made in the country. What it found was an awful lot of gripes.

title: 4 FATAL STABBINGS LAID TO QUEENS PLAN
description: A 31yearold former mental patient was indicted by a Queens grand jury yesterday on charges of stabbing four young women to death while they slept in their beds in their central Queens homes.

title: Mr. Nixon Renominated
description: In the nomination of President Nixon last evening for a second term and the expected naming of Vice President Agnew today, the delegates to the Republican National Convention are performing their only essential official acts. These are the critical events which confer significance on what is otherwise a social conclave under the Florida sunshine and a prolonged exercise in political selfadvertisement.

title: SAIGON PROPOSES TO FREE 600 P.O.W.'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 (AP)  The South Vietnamese Government today offered to release 600 disabled North Vietnamese prisoners of war.

title: American Can Agrees to Open New Jersey City Plant
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 22Mayor Paul T. Jordan said today that the American Can Company had agreed to build manufacturing plant, probably on a Hudson River site, to replace one that will close in 18 months.

title: New Means Urged to Discipline the Bar
description: Expressing concern over what it termed increasing public cynicism over the legal profession's capacity and will to police itself, a report to the state's highest judicial policymaking body by leading jurists concludes that there is a pressing need for new procedures of disciplining lawyers.

title: Roundup: Ryan Stops Orioles, 20, On 4Hitter to End His Loss Streak
description: Lynn Nolan Ryan, a refugee from the New York Mets, broke a personal fourgame losing streak with a fourhitter as he pitched the California Angels to a 20 victory over the Baltimore Orioles last night.

title: Nixon Appeals to Youthful Voters at Rally Near Miami
description: MIAMI, Aug. 22President Nixon, clearly signaling plans for a major effort to capture the youthful voters, made special appeals to them today in both of his public appearances in Florida.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILTON R. BUSH, 76, TAUGHT JOURNALISM
description: STANFORD, Calif., Aug. 22 Prof. Chilton R. Bush, executive head of the Department of Communication and Journalism at Stanford University for 27 years until his retirement in 1961, died of cancer today. He was 76 years old.

title: Kenyatta Demands Unity
description: MOMBASA, Kenya, Aug. 22 (Agence FrancePresse)  President Jomo Kenyatta warned Kenya's nonblacks today to identify themselves fully with African aspirations or else pack their luggage and go back to their respective mother countries.

title: The Presidencies of Theodore Roosevelt and Harry Truman are strong evidence that what some have described as a whimsical method of selection has in fact served our country well.
description: WASHINGTONTo improve is to change, said young Winston Churchill in defending his numerous party defections. To be perfect is to have changed often.

title: Onion Scores by 4 Lengths at Saratoga
TRANSIT INJUNCTION CONTINUED BY COURT
description: State Supreme Court Justice Nathaniel T. Helman yesterday continued an order temporarily restraining the SubwaySurface Supervisors Association from slowdown on the city's buses and subways.

title: Business Briefs
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press)  Canada had $44.4million commodity trade surplus last month, down sharply from a surplus of $179.7million in July, 1971, Statistics Canada reported today. The surplus for the first seven months of 1972 was $546.6million, down from $1.3billion in the period last year.

title: Many of Saigon's Papers Stop Presses in Protest
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Aug. 22 (AP)  About a third of Saigon's 43 newspapers did not publish today in protest against President Nguyen Van Thieu's new press law.

title: Filion Is Fined $200 For Driving Infraction
description: YONKERS, Aug. 22It is not true that in harness racing the king can do no wrong.

title: CONCERN ON COAST FACES PROXY RIFT
description: A proxy fight for control of the board of the Great Western United Corporation will be waged by N. K. Mendelsohn, founder and former president of one of its principal subsidiaries, Great Western Cities, Inc.

title: STARTING JOB GAINED BY TANNEN OF JETS
description: Steve Tannen played so well in the 3131 tie with the Giants Sunday that Weeb Ewbank, the coach of the Jcts, has decided that Tannen will now he a starting cornerback over John Dockery. It will be up to Dockery and Rich Smells In fight it out for the No. 3 spot in that department, since Earlic Thomas seems set.

title: Young Millionaires Are Big Contributors to McGovern
description: Millions of dollars in donations and loans have flowed into the Presidential campaign of Senator George McGovern, the Democratic nominee, largely from a small group of young millionaires whose wealth is mostly inherited and whose concern is more often with social issues than with a future ambassadorship or Cabinet post.

title: ShortTerm Rates Continue to Go Up
description: Shortterm interest rates continued to sweep upward on broad front yesterday, with advances of various magnitude recorded for Treasury bills. certificates of deposit, bankers acceptances and commercial paper.

title: To Buyers, Looks Are What Matter
description: Foot doctors may be sending up warnings about the hazards of platform soles, but young women aren't listening. A substantial part of the under30 generation is clumping around town on thick soles and high heels, walking stiffleggedly as if on stilts. Most of the young women interviewed yesterday insisted that platforms are comfortable and that they haven't been tripping or turning ankles any more than they did in ordinary shoes. They liked the looks of their legs when they wore platforms with skirts and declared them a necessity with widelegged pants.

title: 3 Youths Held as Another Is Fatally Stabbed on S.I.
description: Three 15yearold youths were arrested yesterday and charged with the fatal stabbing Saturday of another 15yearold an Staten Island.

title: NORWALKY.C.WINS YACHTING TROPHY
description: MANIARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 22  The Norwalk (Conn.) Yacht Club won the Everett. R. Morris Memorial Trophy today when Peter lsler sailed Destination, a Culbertson and Cassian 43foot sloop, to victory in the 16th annual Beach Point Yacht Club overnight race for the junior distanceracing championship of Long Island Sound.

title: Rising Absenteeism in Italy Now Troubles Economy
description: ROME, Aug. 22Many thousands of industrial workers who were due to return to their jobs this week have failed to show up, adding few extra days to their legal threeweek vacations.

title: Uganda Now Says Asians Who Are Citizens May Stay
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 22 The exodus of Asians from Uganda will start within the next few weeks, the British High Commission announced here today.

title: RISE IN PRIME RATE MAY BE IMMINENT
description: A general increase in the prime lending rate of the nation's leading commercial banks to 5 per cent from 5 per cent appears to be imminent.

title: Eliza Pande Is Ousted
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 22The title defender, Eliza Pande, and her runnerup in 1971, Mrs. Pat Walkden Pretorius of South Africa, were beaten today in the second round of the 815.000 Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at Merion Cricket Club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Suggest Fischer Uses Electronics to Weaken Spassky
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 22Boris Spassky and Bobby Fischer adjourned the 17th game in their match for the world chess championship tonight amid assertions by the Russians that the Americans might be using electronic devices and a chemical substance to weaken Spassky's playing ability.

title: University of Notre Dame Gets $9Million Bequest
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 22 (UPI)The estate of a woman who lived in Rochester from 1898 to her death in 1966 has provided the largest single donation ever made to the University of Notre Dame, university officials said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: The history of labor in this country may ?? read as an isolated series of oftenviolent struggles on a darkling plain or as a continuing contest for power between labor and management. Jeremy Brecher, a former fellow at the Institute for Policy Studies, chooses the latter.

title: Okun Declares McGovern Will Restate Tax Policies
description: Senator George McGovern is planning to make a general restatement of his tax reform and welfare proposals next Tuesday in a speech before the New York Society of Security Analysts, a top economic adviser to the Democratic Presidential nominee said yesterday.

title: Leasco Directors Approve A 40Cent Annual Dividend
description: The Leasco Corporation board approved the first cash dividend payment in the company's history yesterday. It will be 40 cents annually, with the initial 10 cents payable Oct. 16 to shareholders of record Sept. 15. A total of 10.7 million shares of Leasco common is outstanding.

title: CRIME FIGHT GETS RESULTS IN TAIPEI
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan. Aug. 22Ten members of the powerful and widely feared Taiwan Garrison Command have been arrested in recent weeks on charges of collusion with smugglers. The arrests resulted from a cleanup campaign pledged by Premier Chiang Chingkuo, son of President Chiang Kaishek, when he took office last May.

title: Jersey City Patrolman Dies As Car Pins Him to Truck
description: BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 22 (UPI)An offduty Jersey Cily patrolman apparently thought his auto was in parking gear before he was pinned against a truck and killed, the police said today.

title: DOW INDEX UP 6.32 AS TRADING RISES
description: The stock market made a brisk advance yesterday spearheaded by sizable gains in sayings and loan and oil issues on steppedup trading.

title: Stockholder Asks Damages On Hartford Fire Merger
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 22 (UPI) A New York City woman asserts that she and other stockholders of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company were defrauded as a result of the company's acquisition by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Rockefeller Names Nixon, His Old Rival
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 22 Governor Rockefeller, the man who fought Richard M. Nixon at previous Republican National Conventions, placed in nomination tonight the name of President Nixon as the man who has brought us to the threshold of a generation of peace.

title: 2 Hold 8 Hostages in a Bank in Brooklyn
description: Two gunmen, apparently seeking the release of a hospital mental patient, held eight hostages for more than eight hours yesterday at a bank in Brooklyn.

title: SMITH, MRS. KING ARE SEEDED FIRST
description: Stan Smith and Mrs. Billie Jean King, the Wimbledon titleholders, were seeded No. yesterday and will defend their singles crowns at the United States Open tennis championships Aug. 30 through Sept. 10 at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: MRS. WILLIAM KORN
description: Mrs. Fannie Mayer Korn, a cowinner in 1963 of the first Louise Waterman Wise Award of the American Jewish Congress, and the wife of William Korn, a real estate executive, died Monday at their home, 875 Park Avenue. She was 85 years old.

title: Ellsberg Says Escalation Was Part of Nixon's Plan
Dr. S. Ralph Harlow Dies at 87; Missionary and College Teacher
description: OAK BLUFFS, Mass., Aug. 22 Dr. S. Ralph Harlow, professor emeritus of religion at Smith College, where he was noted for his courses on the application of Judaic and Christian principles to social problems, died yesterday at his home here. He was 87 years old and lived also at 72 Barrow Street in New York City.

title: 3 SEIZED IN THEFT OF $360,000 BONDS
description: Three men were arrested in the act of stealing $360,000 in negotiable bonds from the brokerage house where one of them worked, and a separate batch of securities worth more than $400,000 was found in their getaway car, authorities here said yesterday.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: Randy Horton of the New York Cosmos was selected yesterday as the North American Soccer League's most valuable player. The announcement was made jointly by the N.A.S.L. and the Sporting News, which conducted poll of league players.

title: Over to You, David
description: A few days before the Democratic convention, I ran into Dean Rusk and he wanted to know, Are we going to see a convention of the Democratic party or a convention of the television reporters? It's a cute question, often asked if seldom so well stated.

title: N.C.A.A. Hires Jernstedt
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 22 (UPI) Tom Jernstedt, the business manager at the University of Oregon, was named director of events for the National Collegiate Athletic Association today.

title: 3,000 Residents Watch, Cheer As 2 Gunmen Hold Police at Bay
description: It was probably the most unusual bank robbery in history.

title: Indicted Chicago Aide, Missing 15 Months, Arrested on Coast
description: GARDENA, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)Fred D. Hubbard, who disappeared 15 months ago while serving as a Chicago Alderman and has been charged with embezzling more than 5100,000 from a Federal prograin he directed, was arrested in a card parlor today by Federal agents.

title: Homicides in City Climbed to a Record of 13 for 24Hour Period Ending at 12:01 Yesterday
description: There were 13 homicides here on Mondaymore than on any other single day In the city's recorded history, according to Dr. Milton Helpern, the Chief Medical Examiner.

title: AMEX STOCKS SUP AS VOLUME GROWS
description: Trading activity picked up. yesterday on the American; Stock Exchange. Prices edged down in the final hour.

title: HOGAN'S REMOVAL ASKED IN 2 CASES
description: William J. vanden Heuvel, chairman of the city's Board of Correction, formally asked Governor Rockefeller yesterday to name a special prosecutor to take jurisdiction of two remaining cases arising out of the 1970 Tombs jail protests.

title: PoetRevolutionary Inspires a Drama
description: AbdalaJose Marti, which the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater presented yesterday as its contribution to Lincoln Center's Community/Street Theater Festival, depicts the passion of Jose Marti, the Cuban poetrevolutionary.

title: New Japanese Premier Urges Vast Changes in Nation's Ways
description: TOKYO. Aug. 22  Besides being Japan's new Premier, Kakuei Tanaka is the nation's current bestselling author.

title: Bridge: New York Experts Excel In Major 72 Competitions
description: It can fairly he said that New York experts have dominated the major national team championships in 1972. A fourman team consisting of B. Jay Becker, Michael Becker, Jeff Ruhens and Andy Bernstein won the Spingold teams in the recent Summer Nationals.

title: I.M.F. Offers Options
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The 20 executive directors of the International Monetary Fund have completed work on what amounts to the first salvo in the impending lengthy negotiations on world monetary reform.

title: Australian Leads U.S. Open
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 22 (AP)Walter Browne of Australia took the lead today in the seventh round of the 12round United States Open Chess Tournament here. He had six and a half points, having won six games and drawn one.

title: Papp Gives Share Of Verona Profits To City in Thanks
description: Joseph Papp, founder and producer of the Shakespeare Festival, brought $5,750 to Mayor Lindsay yesterday, the city's first share of profits of Two Gentlemen of Verona.

title: KLEIN INTERCEDES IN POLICE DISPUTE
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 22Suffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein today stepped into a major feud between they county's Police Department and the Human Rights Commission over charges of rising police brutality.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Master, of Republicans for 1972 Richard Milhous Nixon
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 22The Richard Milhous Nixon who was nominated here tonight to press his claims for a second term finds himself in far different and more promising circumstances than the driven and often uncertain figure who set forth from this same convention hall four years ago to recapture the White House for the Republican party. For one thing, he is old er. Fiftynine years have elapsed since his birth Jan. 9, 1913, in the little farming community of Yorba Linda near Los Angeles.

title: Burgess Tailors Cyrano for Musical
description: Cyrano de Bergerac, the gallant lover whose nose kept getling in the way, will return to New York this season as a musical, Cyrano, adapted by Anthony Burgess author of A Clockwork Orange.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Bank of the Commonwealth, Detroit, still seeking to straighten out its financial affairs, announced yesterday that it planned to borrow $9.3million in special capital notes, to he purchased by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in order to cover the writeoff of prepaid tax benefit account amounting to $9.3million.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS FORM NEW GROUP
description: Joseph F. Crangle, the Democratic state chairman, announced yesterday the formation of a committee to coordinate the campaign of candidates for Congress, the State Senate and the Assembly, and to tie them in with Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign in New York State.

title: South Africa Sells Gold
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  South Africa's Reserve Bank's Governor, Theun is de Jongh, said today the bank had been selling considerably more of the country's current gold production on the free market than called for under the International Monetary Fund gold agreement.

title: 14 Terrorist Suspects Are Slain In a Prison Break in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES. Aug. 22 (UPI)Fourteen alleged terror. ists. including four women, died today in a escape attempt from a military prison in southern Argentina.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BRUBECK AND SONS COMBINE GROUPS
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 22 The Brubeck family ensemble 13 musicians swinging with an abandon that daddy Dave's quartet rarely achievesmade its New York area debut last night at the Westbury Music Fair. The ensemble was a conglomerate made up of the Dave Brubeck Quartet, half of 25yearold son Darius Brubeck's Ensemble (also a quartet) and New Heavenly Blue, a sevenman group from the University of Michigan led by another son, 20yearold Chris Brubeck.

title: Professional Figure SkatingA Young Black Couple Enters the Arena
description: She is 19 years old, he is 23. They are both children of Los Angeles mailmen. They wear each other's friendship rings. They are black.

title: SILVER FUTURES REACH NEW HIGHS
description: Buying by commission houses and short covering sent silver futures prices soaring yesterday to new highs on the Commodity Exchange here.

title: Prices Here Up 0.4% for July, Sharpest Rise Since February
description: Climbing food prices pushed the consumer price index for the metropolitan area up 0.4 per cent in July, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. It was the largest monthly increase since Febuary.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 22 (AP)The new San Diego entry in the American Basketball Association may drop the name Conquistadors in the face of adverse public reaction, the general manager, Alex Groza, said today.

title: Armed Man, 22, Is Seized At Entrance to Convention
Mrs. Nixon Lauds Her Husband For Appointing Women to Office
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 22 (UPI)  Unaware that about 300 youths were outside demonstrating against the ruling class, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon praised today her husband's record in naming women to high Administration posts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A CULTURE COMPLEX IS SET FOR HARLEM
description: The AfroAmerican Studio for Acting and Speech has announced the creation of a complex at 415 West 127th Street that will include an actors training studio, two theaters and accommodations for several cultural groups to serve the Harlem community. Ernie McClintock is director and Marc Primus is associate director of the studio.

title: Mrs. Sarah Furman. 106. Taught at North Carolina
description: HAZLET, N. J., Aug. 23Mrs. Sarah Roundtree Furman, who was born the year the Civil War ended, died yesterday in a nursing home here. She would have been 107 on Sept. 7.

title: Business Briefs
description: The U.S. Plywood division of Champion International announced yesterday that it would start production and logging operations at its recently acquired Bonner, Mont., lumber mill by Oct. 1 with an initial employment roll 400 people.

title: 5.2BILLION ADDED TO BUDGET DEFICIT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23By the time it recessed last Friday for the Republican National Convention. Congress had already added $5.2billion to the budget deficit, a Congressional scorekeeping report disclosed today.

title: 2 STATES IN SOUTH POLITE TO SHRIVER
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 23  Sargent Shriver got a full measure of Southern hospitality but little Southern comfort today as he traveled through Georgia and Louisiana on behalf of the Democratic Presidential ticket.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. SEES CHANCE OF GAINING SENATE
Amtrak Staff Picks New England Route to Canada!
description: The management of Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, has chosen route through New Englandinstead of upstate New Yorkfor the resumption of passenler train service between New York City and Montreal.

title: Rhodesia Is Outraged
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 23The expulsion of the Rhodesian team from the Olympic Games at Munich has raised a storm of angry criticism in sporting circles here. However, the Government of Ian Smith remained aloof from the con

title: Moscow Seeks an Alibi
description: Throughout the quartercentury since the end of World War II, Soviet masters have dominated the periodic competitions for the world chess championship. Inevitably, the feeling has grown in Moscow that having a Soviet monopoly on the chess championship is virtually a law of nature, a dominance as inexorable as the tides.

title: Market Place: On Payment For Research
description: Not so long ago, when the idea of unbundling brokerage fees was under serious discussion in Wall Street, the senior partner of a major firm groused about the matter to a colleague.

title: Part of the Hotel's Past Was Up for Auction, and a Crowd Came to Bid
description: WASHINGTONNow everybody, just wait a minute! cried the harried whitehaired man. Twelve or 15 people at his heels, he looked for a moment as though he would run away in panic.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 23 (UPI)Ken Moore, a marathon runner from the University of Oregon. filed a formal complaint today about the route that has been selected for the 26 mile race in the Olympic Games. New Zealand and West German runners also complained.

title: Democrats Delay Telethon Until September or October
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 23 (AP)  The Democrats have postponed a twohour fundraising telethon planned for national television Aug. 29. John Y. Brown of Louisville, a consultant on the project, said Warren Beatty, the actor who is in charge of special events for the Democratic Presidential nominee, Senator George McGovern, decided to postpone the telecast, apparently for lack of time to prepare a show.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 23 (AP)  Pearl City, Hawaii, scored a goahead run in the fourth inning on an error today, then erupted for an eightrun fifth easily defeat the U.S. Air Force dependents from Madrid, 11.2 in an openinground game of the Little League World Series.

title: javits and Buckley to Aid Nixon Drive
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23Senators Jacob K. Javits and James L. Buckley of New York plan to campaign extensively outside the state for the NixonAgnew ticket although the Senators are at opposite ends of the Republican ideological spectrum and have significant differences with President Nixon on various issues.

title: Theater: Rock vs. Junk
description: With an almost evangelical zeal, Peter Copani's Choices campaigns against drugs. This rock musical was presented yesterday by the Inwood People's Performing Company Street Theater Workshop at Lincoln Center's Community Street Theater Festival. The show will also be staged tonight and tomorrow night in Fort Tryon Park.

title: Chess Game Is Drawn
description: Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky agreed to a draw after 45 moves of the 17th game in their world chess championship match in Reykjavik, Iceland. The 18th game will be played today. Details on Page 30.

title: BEST RELAY TIME OF 72 RUN BY U.S.
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 23 (AP)The Unites States 1,600meter elay team recorded the world's fastest time this year as athletes got their first chance today to work out on the Olympic Stadium's synthetic track.

title: ALFRED WHITE, STAR IN ABIE'S IRISH ROSE
description: Alfred H. White, who 50 years ago played the father ofl the bridegroom in the first fiveyear Broadway run of the comedy, Abie's Irish Rose, died Tuesday in Fort Lauder. dale, Fla., where he had been living in retirement. He was 89 years old.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON AMEX, OTC
description: Prices declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in subdued trading.

title: ANTIU.S.PARIS BID RESISTED IN E.E.C.
description: PARIS, Aug. 23  French efforts to organize Western Europe against America's international economic policy were pressed today in several forms. Indications were that Paris was meeting stiffening resistance from its European partners.

title: At Least 10 Persons Killed In Clashes in the Philippines
description: MANILA, Aug. 23 (UPI)About 40 Moslem outlaws clashed with 15 marines in predominantly Christian province in the southern Philippines yesterday, the Philippine News Service reported.

title: 20.52 Million Californians
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)California's population has climbed to 20.52 million, but a lower birth rate has helped slow the increase. The state Department of Finance reported yesterday that a provisional estimate of the population showed an increase of 239,000, or 1.2 per cent, during the fiscal year ending July 1.

title: NEW MURDER TRIAL IS WON BY 2 YOUTHS
description: Two Brooklyn teenagers who were convicted of murder last April have won a new trial because subsequent investigation by a detective prompted District Attorney Eugene Gold to question the positive identification by a key prosecution witness.

title: V.F.W. Urges Prosecution Of Clark and Miss Fonda
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 23, (UPI)The Veterans of Foreign Wars have accused Jane Fonda. the actress, and the former Attorney General, Ramsey, Clark, of being traitorous meddlers in United States foreign policy and recommended that they be prosecuted.

title: Transcript of Nixon's Acceptance Address and Excerpts From Agnew's Speech
description: Mr. Chairman, delegates to this convention, my fellow Americans:

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: A public offering of 1.2 million common shares of the Control Data Corporation at $76.50 a share was announced yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Hornblower &I WeeksHemphill Noyes, White Weld & Co., and Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis Inc. Net proceeds will be used to reduce outstanding bank borrowings. The company's stock was up 3/8 at 765/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TV: A Night of Specials
description: As the American Broadcasting Company tools up for its extensive daily and primetime coverage of the Olympic Games in Munich, the network has decided to turn most of tonight's schedule over to entertainment specials.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Combustion Engineering, Inc., said yesterday that it had received a contract valued at more than $55million for two 750megawatt steam generating units by Texas Utilities Services, Inc., an agent for the Dallas Power & Light Company, the Texas Electric Service Company and the Texas Power Light Company.

title: Prefontaine's Workouts Are So Good They Scare Him
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 23  Strange and beautiful things keep happening to Steve Prefontaine, as Saturday's opening ceremonies in the Olympics move within sight, free, at last. from the political clouds of the past week.

title: Farasopoulos Happy as Starter
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 23Never had a back who intercepted as many passes as Chris Farasopoulos does in practice, said an admiring Weeb Ewbank recently. That may be why the Jets coach started Farasopoulos at free safely in the Giants game and why he placed him there today in a strictly offensive practice at the Hofstra field.

title: 2 Women Are Bound By Hands and Feet And Fatally Beaten
description: Two women were found beaten to death, their hands and feet bound, in a Queens Village apartment late last night.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23My name's Huckleberry Dick. You ain't heard of me less'n you watched a TV show called the Republican National LoveIn. That show was made by Mr. Walter Cronkite and Mr. John Chancellor and Mr. Howard Smith and lots of other smart TV people, and mostly they told the truth. cepn for leavin out a lot of the more disgustin scenes of crowds of lovecrazed Republicans aflingin themselves on me and alickin my hands on account of my havin done so much to make the country a fit place to love in again.

title: Transit Authority Agrees To Resume Contract Talks
description: The Transit Authority withdrew charges of unfair labor practices against the SubwaySurface Supervisors Association yesterday, and the parties agreed to resume negotiations today on a work contract overdue since July 1.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: About 100 people, most of them children, were taken to a hospital from the municipal swimming pool in Hillside, N. J., yesterday when a valve on a 200pound tank chlorine gas failed and gas fumes spread across the pool area.

title: Hungary's Practical Cuisine: It's for People Who Like to Eat
description: Of the world's important cuisines, Hungarian and Moroccan are probably the least well known outside their countries of origin. This is not because they involve weird tastes and difficult processes, but because Hungarian and Arabic are not widely spoken by Western food experts and thus little progress until lately has been made in writing down the recipes in careful English.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Saigon Bid to Retake Queson Thwarted
MURDER SUSPECT TURNS HIMSELF IN
description: A 17yearold Brooklyn soldier being sought in a triple homicide in Queens surrendered yesterday morning to the Army at Fort Dix, N.J., where he had been absent without leave for more than a month.

title: Gas Sands Are Encountered
description: PARIS, Aug. 23 (UPI)  Elf Erap Group announced today its affiliate, Elf Norge, encountered gas sands in a Norwegian sector of the North Sea.

title: Brundage's Successor Is a Former Journalist and Movie Producer
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 23 (AP)A frank pipesmoking Irish peer with an impish sense of humor takes over the hot seat as president of the International Olympic Committee.

title: VATICAN PAPER SAYS M'GOVERN AIDS HANOI
description: ROME, Aug. 23 (AP)The Vatican weekly newspaper said today that Senator George McGovern's election campaign helps North Vietnam and the Vietcong.

title: Screen: Bullring's Mystical Lure Reclaims Arruza of Mexico
description: In the late 1950's the great Mexican matador Carlos Arruza came out of a self-imposed retirement and began to practice rejoneo, a way of fighting bulls from horseback, and a difficult art in its own right. Riding superb Portuguese-bred horses, Arruza began to appear in bullrings, starting each fight from horseback, as a rejoneador, but making the kill on foot, as a matador. He was again fantastically successful, triumphing finally, in 1966, in the huge new bullring of Mexico City. A few weeks later he died in an automobile accident. He was 46 years old.The events of Arruza's late career were filmed by the American action-movie director Budd Boetticher ("Comanche Station," "The Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond, etc.") in a project that reportedly took eight years. I believe the time span; you can see Arruza's kids growing from childhood to adolescence in the course of the film. Boetticher finished his work in 1967, and there has obviously been another long lapse, because "Arruza" opened just yesterday at the Plaza and Murray Hill theaters. It was worth waiting for. It is a magnificent documentary.It is also a slightly old-fashioned documentary, with some tacky passages of real-life dramatization (all involving the Arruza family), and with an intelligent interest in celebrating its subject and what he does rather than ridiculing him, or pitying him, or deploring his life's ambition. Occasionally the film makes jokes with Arruza, and the voice-over narration (read by Anthony Quinn) identifies his driving forces as ego and pride. But it lets the cruel victories of the bullring speak for themselves. And it is supremely reticent in presenting a life cursed by a need to progress always from triumph to triumph, capable of no reasonable conclusion, and perhaps best ending, the man undefeated, in an accidental death that was no part of the life's meaning.In a good recent study of Budd Boetticher, Jim Kitses, the film critic, compares Arruza with Randolph Scott in so many of the Boetticher Westerns: "like the Scott hero . . . complete and serene when we meet him, the film only recording countless confirmations of who he is." Arruza even slightly resembles Scottas handsome, but slimmer, more delicate, with the look of an introspective, highly educated scientist or engineer.The look is enhanced by his fighting costume, somber gray or black, complementing the ravishingly beautiful economy of his provocative and defensive movements. But the bull is also beautiful, bleeding from the knife stabs of the rejoneador, tortured by the colorful expertly placed banderillas (an Arruza specialty) splaying out from its shoulders like a gaudy flower of pain. The film makes no humanitarian protest over killing bulls. It couldn't. The terror and the fascination would simply undercut any rational shudder of the conscience."Arruza" is not much given to mythologizing, and its interest in the bullring has more to do with the camera's field of view than with anybody's depth of interpretation. And what is held by the cameras of Lucien Ballard and Carlos Carbajal, Boetticher's cinematographers, often in shots of breathtaking duration, becomes virtually an essay in the rewards of seeing clearly and seeing whole. "Arruza" avoids almost all false rhetoric, including the false rhetoric of too much plainness. For this, and for the genuine complexities revealed in its spare and lovely style, it may belong among the last great examples of classical filmmaking.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Arguments for the latest Nixon defense budget represent a classic example of Catch22: Arms control is, as all can agree, a worthy goal, but the only way to achieve arms control is with arms control agreements. To negotiate such arms control agreements, the other side (Russia) must be convinced that it requires such an agreement because we (the U.S.) are strong and determined. To show such strength and determination we need more weapons. Thus, to get arms control we must build more arms. A of flawless Nixonian logic.

title: Airline Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)Passenger traffic on the scheduled airlines was 11 per cent greater last month than in July, 1971, the Air Transport Association said today. The total in scheduled service was 14.96 billion revenue passengei miles. A passenger mile is one passenger flown one mile.

title: Nigerians Expelled From Zaire Say That Some Were Tortured
description: LAGOS, Nigeria. Aug. 23 (AP) More Nigerians expelled from Zaire have arrived in Lagos with tales of midnight arrests, imprisonment, starvation and torture.

title: Near Bank, the Mother of Gunman and the Mother of Hostage Shared Nightmare
description: Mrs. Theresa Wojtowicz and Mrs. Clyde Saunders had never met before, but for one agonyfilled night, the two women were hound up in a nightmare of fear and suspense that unfolded late Tuesday and early yesterday at Avenue P and East Third Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Bridal Held for Miss Pool at Duke
description: DURHAM, N. C., Aug. 23 Miss Amanda Grayson Pool, a research technician for the department of psychiatry at the Duke University Medical Center, was married here this evening to Dr. D. Michael Pehlke, a resi dent in internal medicine at the medical center. The ceremony was performed in the Duke Hospital chapel by the Rev Wesley Aitken. chaplain at the medical center and a Methodist minister.

title: A Car Falls From Street Onto Tracks of Penn Central
description: A car fell onto Penn Central tracks in the Fordham section of the Bronx early yesterday, causing delays and cancellations on the Harlem and New Haven lines.

title: DISPUTE ERUPTS ON KASHMIR AGAIN
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 23  A new dispute has arisen between India and Pakistan over Kashmir, and official sources here say it is imperiling the normalization of relations agreed to by the two countries early last month.

title: Hadassah Elects Its New President
description: More than 3,500 delegates yesterday elected Mrs. Rose Matzkin as president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America.

title: Festival Leader Is Really Its Juggler
description: For anyone responsible for opening 30 shows in two weeks, life is bound to become a series of last minute details. Such is the case with Leonard de Paur, producer of the second annual Lincoln Center Community Street Theater Festival.

title: Surplus Buffalo for Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The Interior Department announced today that it had 110 surplus live buffalo for sale. The auctions are being held at two national wildlife refuges, near Valentine, Neb., and Moiese, Mont., to increase grazing for the herds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: History will record that the 1972 Democratic Convention was a tragedy, and hardly representative of a democratic institution, as was the intent of the reform guidelines. The main tragedy was the selection of a candidate who was not the consensus figure of either the voting public or the political professionals. Instead, a small group of opportunists took over and literally ran a closed club.

title: TWO IN VENEZUELA SUSPEND DRILLING
description: Two major international oil companies announced yesterday that they had suspended exploration in the southern portion of Venezuela's Lake Maracaibo after striking several dry holes.

title: ASIAN HEROIN RING UNCOVERED HERE
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they had uncovered a looseknit narcotics ring based in Chinatown that had been attempting to move into the distribution system for heroin here and capitalize on shifts in the international market for the drug.

title: JUSTICES WIDOWS GET PENSION RISE
description: KEY BIsCAYNE, Fla., Aug. 23President Nixon signed today legislation increasing the pensions of the widows of Supreme Court Justices from $5,000 to $10,000 annually.

title: Advertising:
description: Several young women are going around the city, each followed by two or three men. But in this case it's perfectly legaland part of one agency's advertising approach.

title: Officers Wound Guard
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 (AP) James Weeks, 42 years old, a guard assigned to a construction project, was shot four times by the police today after he fired shots at workers whom he had mistaken for robbers. Mr. Weeks was reported in critical condition.

title: White Sox Hero Clinches 22d for Wood
Hijacked Arab Jet in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Aug. 23 (Reuters)A Southern Yemeni airliner, hijacked yesterday on a flight from Beirut, Lebanon, to Cairo, arrived here today after dropping off three young gunmen and three passengers in Benghazi, Libya. After the Al Yemda Airlines DC6, with 55 passengers and six crew members, landed In Libya, the hijackers surrendered to the authorities.

title: United States Shoe Corp. Raised Profit and Sales 9% in Quarter
Policemen Effectively Use Antiriot Gas To Stem Protest Before It Can Spread
Irish Lord New Olympic Chief
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 23Less than 24 hours after one of his darker moments during two decades in office, Avery Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, announced today his successor, a wealthy 58yearold Irish lord and forTier athlete named Michael John Killanin.

title: 550Million Uranium Sale
description: ALBUQUERQUE. N. M., Aug. 23 (UPI)The Reserve Oil and Minerals Corporation said today] that the Sohio Petroleum Company. its joint venture partner in New Mexico Uranium properties, had signed a letter of intent with a major American corporation to sell 5.75 million pounds of uranium concentrates for about $50million.

title: G.M. Output Hit by Strike
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (AP) General Motors said today production of more than 39.000 automobiles would be lost because of a strike against its assembly plant in suburban Norwood.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Productivity, or output per manhour, in the nonfinancialcorporate sector of the economy rose at an annual rate of 6.1 per cent in the second quarter of this year and unit labor costs declined for only the second time in seven years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Four Vietnam Veterans Protest at Convention
SOVIET WARNS U.S. ON ARMS ACCORDS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23  The Soviet Union warned publicly today against attempts by Washington to put new interpretations on the strategic arms agreements signed here in May.

title: U.S. Shipyards Inefficient, Rickover Tells Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover has told Congress that American shipyards are poorly managed, with many workers loafing on the job, while the Russians are expanding an already far superior shipbuilding capability.

title: ALEXANDER GROSSMAN
description: Alexander Grossman, who retired from the mail room of The New York Times in 1957 after 37 years of service, died Tuesday of a heart attack in nursing home in Miami, where he had been living in retirement. He was 78 years old.

title: Troops Dropped in Laos
description: VIETIANE, Laos, Aug. 23 (AP) Informed sources reported today that Government commandos parachuted on Monday onto the northern edge of the Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos as part of a weekold attempt to gain back ground lost to the North Vietnamese last winter.

title: BOOK IS PUBLISHED BY TWO PRISONERS
description: TRENTON, Aug. 23 (AP)Between them they are serving a combined 118 years in prison, but also between them they have edited a book.

title: HEARING ADJOURNED IN TIMES LABOR CASE
description: A hearing on an application by The New York Times for a preliminary injunction against New York Mailers Union 6 was adjourned in State Supreme Court yesterday until Tuesday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: It will not be long before the various states announce their 19721973 waterfowl hunting seasons, and sportsmen who are unable quickly to identify birds on the wing and in the water should endeavor to sharpen their skills in this respect.

title: Personal Finance
description: The Federal Reserve Board is considering an amendment to its creditcard regulations so that a businessman cannot be penalized more than $50 for unauthorized use of a lost or stolen card.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: The New York Yankees, making a late bid for the Eastern Division championship of the American League. and the New York Mets, struggling to save second place the National League East, will meet in the 10th annual Mayor's Trophy game at Yankee Stadium tonight.

title: Jewish Biologist in Soviet Reported Jailed for Slander
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (UPI)The Moscow City Court has sentenced a Jewish biologist, Ilya Glezer, to three years imprisonment at a corrective labor camp for slandering the Soviet Union, the newspaper Moscow Pravda reported today.

title: Kranepool Blast Gives Solace to Losers
description: The theme of yesterday's lesson for the Mets at Shea Stadium could have been that those who start trouble often can't stop it, for they provoked the Houston Astros to a 74 victory.

title: Atomic Safety Problems Common, G.A.O. Reports
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  Government auditors reported today that one of every three inspections of licensed users of dangerous radioactive materials disclosed safety or compliance problems.

title: City Worker Stranded On Ladder 80 Feet Up
description: A Parks Department employe was stranded SO feet above the ground for over an hour around noon yesterday when the bottom part of a builtin ladder in the Henry Hudson monument gave way under him, the fire department reported.

title: News of Dogs
description: When Ruth and Otto Dube were married 55 years ago, they received a gift of a Boston terrier from Ruth St. Denis, the dancer. We called the Boston Ace, recalled Dube at the recent Southern Adirondack show, where he served as chief steward. The Dubes bred Ace to a champion. We took the four pups to a pet shop, he said, intending to sell them. A dog show judge happened to walk in. He whispered to us not to let them go, that they were show quality pups. Later, I entered one at a showmy firstand when she won a blue, was hooked. The Dubes still are showing. Last year, Mrs. Dube handled a Boston, Dube's Tops Again to his championship.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (UPI)The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics today placed eight schools on probationsix for violation of the N.A.I.A.'s participation policy and two for violation of eligibility rules.

title: McGovern and Daley Meet Privately; Pledge Unity for Democratic Ticket
description: CHICAGO. Aug. 23Senator George McGovern and Mayor Richard J. Daley smiled for television cameras and pledged unity for the Democratic ticket after a private meeting here today but it appeared that they had yet to develop a close working relationship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer in Tombs Revolt Case To Seek Dismissal of Charges
description: A lawyer for one of the twoinmates scheduled to stand trial for his alleged role in the 1970 Tombs uprising said yesterday that he would move tomorrow for dismissal of the charges because District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's recent criticism of the acquittal of three other inmates made a fair trial impossible.

title: Election Ordered in Connecticut Under Plan a Panel Held Illegal
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 23A state judge here today ordered a General Assembly election this November under a plan of apportionment a panel of three Federal judges had ruled unconstitutional.

title: Bank Bandit Slain. 2d Seized at Kennedy, Ending 14Hour Ordeal for 7 Hostages
description: A 14hour ordeal for seven bank employes held hostage by a distraught homosexual and his 18yearold accomplice ended just before sunrise yesterday when a Federal agent shot and killed the accomplice at Kennedy International Airport.

title: IN THE NATION
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23You understand, of course, if you've been watching television from Miami Beach, that President Nixon has put an end to the war in Vietnamso bloody, so costly, so bitterly divisive, says the Republican platform, when Mr. Nixon came to power.

title: Financier Buys All Offers Of Kings Lafayette Stock
description: Edmond J. Safra, the international financier who controls the Republic National Bank on Fifth Avenue, said yesterday that he had acquired all of the 189,673 shares of the Kings Lafayette Corporation that were tendered to him under his offer to purchase the stock at $40 per share.

title: Porter and Thuy to Skip Session of Peace Talk
description: PARIS, Aug. 23 (AP)The chief delegates of the United States and North Vietnam will skip tomorrow's session of the Vietnam peace talks.

title: 5 IN OKLAHOMA RACE FOR SEAT IN SENATE
description: Representative Ed Edmondson, a Democrat; former Gov. Dewey Bartlett, a Republican, and three others will battle for the Senate seat vacated by Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma.

title: The Rosemaler's Art Flowers in This Country
description: At first glance they look like something the Pennsylvania Dutch might have dreamed upall those bright colors and stylized posies. But the designs actually come from Norway and the person who makes them is a rosemalm that's pronounced rosemahler and means flower painter.

title: McGovern Hails Military As Legion Listens Coolly
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23Senator George McGovern tempered his antiwar message with expressions of respect for the military as he knew it as he addressed a polite but largely silent national convention of the American Legion here today.

title: RED REALITY FIRST ON SARATOGA TURF
description: SARATOGA SPRING, N. Y. Aug. 23  The entry of the Cragwood Stable, Red Reality and Larceny Kid, finished one, three in the $30,025 Seneca Handicap today, but only the front end of the result stood.

title: CANADA FIRM SEEKS BIG BOARD MEMBER
description: In a reversal of the more common practice, a large Canadian stock brokerage firm is planning to acquire a New York securities firm primarily to obtain a seat on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ExpenseAccount Padding Vexes Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23Summer in the Soviet Union brings not only sun to Siberia and neartropical heat to Moscow but a surge of convention freeloading and expenseaccount boondoggling that worries the protectors of the state purse and Communist morality.

title: The Proceedings in the U. N. Today
description: Meets at 3:15 P.M. on Bangladesh's application for membership.

title: JOBLESS IN STATE REACH JULY PEAK
description: Unemployment in New York State in July totaled 545,000, or 6.5 per cent of the work force, the highest for the month since 1958, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

title: Screen:
description: There's nothing new about the plot of What's Good for the Goose, which has an aging stuffed shirt of a London businessman turned into a swinger by a pert hippie, then reuniting with his wife as a wiser man. What makes this version so pleasantly entertaining is the cheerfully wise tone and treatment and the puckish appeal of the hero, Norman Wisdom.

title: Vatican: Who Is Clean?
description: ROME, Aug. 23The Vatican Radio indirectly attacked day the International Olympic Committee's decision to Rhodesia from this year's Games. The Vatican wondered whether all the nations scheduled to participate in Munich Olympics were free from the plague of racism from other evils that undermine the freedom, the dignity man and the respect for individual.

title: 8 Churches Join World Council as Conference Ends
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands. Aug. 23The World Council of Churches, closing its 11day conference here, admitted eight new members today, increasing its membership to 261.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Joel J. Sprayregen's impassioned plea for justice for all Soviet Jews [letter Aug. 15] was an eloquent testimony to the ruthlessness of the Stalin regime. However, his closing plea for the right of repatriation to Israel is faulty and misleadingSoviet Jews can hardly he repatriated to a court, try where they have never lived.

title: Bridge: Play off to Fill Last Place In American Team Playoffs
description: A complex technical brouhaha had to be settled before the playoff matches that determine the 1973 North American team could be begun. The teams that had won the three major national team championships became candidate teams, but the fourth position in the playoffs required a tiesplit.

title: Security Tight as Nixon Flies to the Convention
MARK RICHARDSON OF C.P.A. SOCIETY
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Aug. 23  Marl: E. Richardson, former president of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants and executive vice president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, died of pneuMonia yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit. He was 66 years old and lived at 1059 Sunny View Road.

title: Admiral Corp. Will Add Home laundry Appliances
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP)The Admiral Corporation announced today completion of plans to add homelaundry, equipment to its appliance line.

title: G.O.P. Aide Queried on Check In Study of Raid on Democrats
description: MIAMI, Aug. 23A Republican finance official was summoned from at meeting at President Nixon's closely guarded headquarters hotel today for questioning by Florida officials investigating the breakin at the Democratic headquarters in Washington.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Crude and cruel was the Governor's attempt to make political capital out of the problem of Soviet Jewry emigrating to Israel. Considering all the crises besetting the oncegreat Empire State, he had better spend his time on the job. All the major cities in the state are dying, their citizens hurting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Report by House Group on Securities Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Following are excerpts from a 170page House subcommittee report on changes in the securities industry:

title: COFFEE PRODUCERS SEEK QUOTA ACCORD
description: LONDON, Aug. 23 (AP) The major coffee growers in the International Coffee Organization said today that they were willing to trade their Geneva agreement against an equitable 197273 export quota and monetary guarantees to safeguard them against dollar devaluation.

title: Meany Delays Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 23 (AP)George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization, granted today a postponement of hearing into charges that the Colorado Labor Council had violated federation policy by endorsing the Democratic Presidential nominee, George McGovern. The council, representing 120,000 workers, faces suspension or revocation of its charter, expulsion of its officers lor being placed under trusteeship.

title: Money Arrives in Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 23 (UPI)Two Delta Air Lines executives flew into Orly Airport in Paris tonight carrying $1million in ransom that they had recovered in Algeria.

title: Protesters Convict Nixon Of AntiHumanity Crimes
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 (AP)A panel that conducted a twoday Nixon investigation today found the President guilty of crimes against humanity.

title: METALLIC LATHERS WILL VOTE ON PACT
description: Metallic lathers who have been on strike here since July 1 are scheduled to vote today on a new threeyear agreement.

title: TRADEBILL DECLINE SET RECORD IN JULY
description: Total bankers acceptances outstanding dropped by a record $426million in July to a total of $6.6billion, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was the fourth straight month in which these trade bills, whose repayment has been guaranteed by hank, have declined. The drop over the period is $1.3billion.

title: Price Panel Will Include Foreign Cars in Review
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The Price Commission said today that it would expand next month's autoprice hearings to include the cost of foreign as well as Americanbuilt vehicles.

title: Kleindienst Doubts Action On Clark or Miss Fonda
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 (AP) Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that he doubted that anyone, including former Attorney General Ramsey Clark and Jane Fonda, the actress, would be prosecuted under a law forbidding any American except the President from dealing with a foreign power.

title: U.S. Indicts Four for Conspiracy to Influence Yablonski Witnesses
description: CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) A Federal grand jury; indicted four officials of the United Mine Workers union today and named three others as co conspirators in connection with the slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski and his family in 1969.

title: Incongruities of Ordeal Recounted by Hostages
description: Within hours after their 14hour ordeal ended yesterday morning, hostages detained by the two bank robbers described their captivity as a bizarre experience filled with as much laughter as tears.

title: Butz and Reagan Discount Efforts of Chavez's Union
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 (AP)  Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, and Gov. Ronald Reagan of California spoke out today against the boycottlettuce campaign of Cesar Chavez, the worker organizer.

title: Miss Heldman Wins
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 23 (Reuters)Julie Heldman of Houston scored a major upset in the Virginia Slims Newport tennis.championships today by routing Francoise. Durr of France, 6.1, 6.3.

title: Travelers in Japanese Pact
description: The Travelers Corporation, in its fourth major move as an international insurer, disclosed yesterday that it had signed a reinsurance agreement for group life insurance with the Nippon Life Insurance Company of Japan. Travelers already has similar agreements with Riunione Adriatica di Sicurta of Italy, Guardian Royal Exchange Assurance Group of Britain and the NationaleNederlanden of the Netherland.

title: New Rules for Welfare Bar Many Applicants Here
description: Only four of the first 200 welfare applicants at the city's first special center concentrating solely on presumptively employables went all the way through toughened new admission procedures to wind up on relief rolls.

title: FUTURES PRICES OF PLATINUM RISE
description: Platinum futures prices rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the close of the January, 1979, contract, hitting a new high of $162.50 an ounce, compared with $160 the day before. Prices of the other five contracts were within $3 to $4 of the highs for the year.

title: JUSTICES GET APPEAL ON PENTAGON PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)Attorneys for Dr. Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. asked the Supreme Court today to rule on a wiretapping issue in the Pentagon papers trial.

title: Booming Singapore Prepares for Vote
description: SINGAPORE, Aug. 21With industry booming, labor in shortening supply and leaders suggesting that this island republic is now too rich to bel considered a developing country, Singapore is preparing for a national election virtually guaranteed to preserve Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's power for five more years.

title: Stans Denies Role
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 (UPI) Mr. Stans said today that he had nothing to do with the breakin at the Democratic headquarters.

title: TWO PROSECUTORS HAIL CRIME FIGHT
description: The District Attorneys of Manhattan and the Bronx, after meeting with Mayor Lindsay yesterday, endorsed the Mayor's latest moves against organized crime, but indicated they felt he was unrealistic in ordering all mobsters run out of town.

title: Canada Seeks Firm Uranium Prices
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 23The Government is taking steps, presumably in consultation with other countries, to stabilize the sagging uranium market, it was announced here today.

title: Okker and Gorman Bow
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 23A capacity crowd of 2,500 saw Tom Okker of the Netherlands, Torn Gorman, Seattle; Andres Gimeno, Spain, and Patrick Proisy, France, go down to defeat in the third round of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club today.

title: BELLE AMIE TAKES HORSE SHOW TITLE
description: RHINEBECIi, N. Y., Aug. 231 Belle Arnie, a 5yearold chestnut mare owned and ridden by Nancy Baroody of Lakeville, Conn., won the large pony hunter championship today at the Dutchess County horse show with a perfect score of 221/2 points.

title: Man Slain on West Side; Friend Held as Suspect
description: A 38yearold man was shot to death on an upper West Side street early today. A friend, according to the police, after fleeing in a car, was seized by a patrolman who recognized its license plate. He was questioned as a suspect.

title: Pony Leaguer Fans 19
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Aug. 23 (UPI)Carlos Rodriguez set a Pony League world series record of 19 strikeouts today, leading Carolina of Puerto Rico to a 13.2 elimination victory over Vera Cruz, Mexico. Rodriguez recorded five strikeouts in the second inning of the seveninning game when passed balls following strikeouts allowed the batters to reach first base safely. The previous strikeout record was 18 held by two other players.

title: City Names 17 Food Concerns As Violators of Health Code
A Blighted Affair Led to Bank Holdup
description: In the dismal, allmale rooming house at 250 West 10th Street, friends of John Wojtowicz were amazed yesterday that he had been charged with bank robbery and abduction in connection with the attempted robbery of a Brooklyn bank on Tuesday.

title: Rome Police Said to Tighten Control Over Arab Legations
description: ROME, Aug. 23  Police sources said today that controls over Arab embassies here had been tightened in the last few days on suspicion that some had been involved in illegal activities.

title: Navy Contract Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)  An $8.7million Navy contract has been awarded to the General Dynamics Corporation, Groton, Conn., to overhaul the nuclear submarine Whale, Representative Robert H. Steele, Republican of Connecticut, reported today.

title: NIXON ASKS SUPPORT FOR A NEW MAJORITY AFTER AGNEW IS RENAMED AS RUNNING MATE
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 President Nixon opened his campaign for reelection hero tonight by summoning the nation, and particularly the young, the old and disaffected Democrats, to join our new majority.

title: Vote for Brinkley a Welcome Script Change
Appeals Court to Scrutinize Detroit Desegregation Plan
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (AP)Arguments on a controversial desegregation plan for Detroit and 52 adjacent suburban school districts will be heard tomorrow by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

title: Fire Ruins Crusading Editor's Plant
description: MADISONVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 23A crusading weekly newspaper editor's plant was burned down early today in the latest of a series of violent acts against the newsman in the last five years.

title: Litter Trap
description: In the constant battle between the environment and the economythe two seem ever at oddsNew York City's Environmental Protection Administration yesterday announced a smail victory. It unveiled the winner of its twoyearlong litter basket design contest and, in the unveiling, noted that advertising space would be sold on each of the 60,000 trash containers to be stationed at street corners across the city.

title: Liabilities of U.S. Banks To Foreign Units Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)Liabilities of United States banks to their foreign branches totaled $1,772,000,000 for the week ended Aug. 16, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Wallace's Assailant Shifted To Prison Processing Unit
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 23 (UPI) Arthur H. Bremer, the man who shot Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, was transferred today to the Maryland Corrections Reception and Diagnostic Center.

title: Morris Natelson Is Dead at 67; A Director of Lehman Brothers
description: Morris Natelson, a managing director of Lehman Brothers, Inc., investment bankers, died yesterday at his home, 2 Barkers Point Road, Sands Point, L.I.. after suffering a stroke several weeks ago. He was 67 years old.

title: Wall St. Worries: Is a Credit Crunch Coming in 1973?
description: Working quietly as always, and with little public notice, the Federal Reserve Systemwhich is charged with managing the nation's money supplyis wrestling with issues that will have fundamental importance to American business over the next few years.

title: Personalities: Hull Hits N.H.L. With Countersuit
description: Jarred by a lawsuit leveled at him last Friday by the Chicago Black Hawks, Bobby Hull charged back yesterday to slam his former team and the National Hockey League with a countersuit. Hull's action, filed in Federal Court at Chicago, seeks to establish the highscoring forward's right to play for the Winnipeg Jets of the new World Hockey Association.

title: First in Guns, Last In Controls
description: WASHINGTONWhat does it take to make President Nixon and the Congress understand the need for gun control? At least the Democratic party platform discloses some understanding of how to control the abuse of guns. But the Republican party platform mindlessly persists with the notion that a diversity of inconsistent state laws can restrain the killing by gunfire.

title: The American Scorned
description: WASHINGTONMeeting in national convention at Louisville, Ky., early in August, the American party, founded four years ago by supporters of Gov. George Wallace, nominated me as its candidate for President of the United States.

title: EUGENE F. O'NEILL
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 23 (AP)  Eugene F. O'Neill, a tenor on Broadway early in the century, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 84 years old.

title: Virginia Drosten Is Bride on Coast
description: CAMARILLO, Calif., Aug. 23 The marriage of Miss Virginia Shawan Drosten to Patrick Serge Kenadjian, son of Mr. and Mrs. N. D. Kenadjian of Paris, formerly of New York, took place here this afternoon. The Rev. Richard L. Brooks of the United Methodist Church of Camarillo performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. William G. Drosten Jr., mother of the bride.

title: Intact Team
description: On every front, the managers of the Republican National Convention opted for total harmony,preferring the dangers of tedium to those of controversy. Moving smoothly through their planned schedule, the delegates adopted confident platform, smothered the brief dispute over the rules for delegate selection, applauded a carefully chosen range of speakers, and dutifully renominated President Nixon and Vice President Agnew. The decision on the VicePresidency, which afforded the only real opportunity for change, was both significant in itself and symbolic of the party's present mood and direction.

title: Algeria Gives Delta Ransom Taken in Hijacking
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The Algerian Government today turned over to Delta Air Lines $1million in ransom recovered from an airliner hijacking this month, State Department officials said.

title: Horace E. Britton, 62, Dies; Long a Realty Executive
description: BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., Aug. 23Horace Ely Britton, realty executive, died of a heart attack on Sunday. He was 62 years old and had recently moved here from Pelham Manor.

title: Notes on People
description: Six or seven months ago, hardly anyone noticed when former President Lyndon B. Johnson switched from the American Barber Shop to Roy's of Austin, Hairstyling, both in the Texas capital about 65 miles from the LBJ ranch. Then the exPresident's silverthatched hair started to grow down the back of his neck until it puffed out over his shirt collar and was photographed as he met Tuesday with Senator George McGovern. And yesterday the new LBJ hairdo, which its wearer has not publicly discussed, was the talk his barbers.

title: City Picks New Litter Container After 2Year Search
description: After a twoyear search, the city's Environmental Protection Administration has finally decided on a new litter container to replace the current wiremesh model that has been disappearing at the rate of more than 6,000 a year through theft, vandalism and normal wear.

title: Fischer Gains a Draw and Leads Chess, 107
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 23  Bobby Fischer of the United States and Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union drew the 17th game of the world championship chess match today, and it is still not clear to many observers here whether this was a result of a blunler by Spassky or whether he went for the draw because of dangerous complications.

title: Sex Advice Via Telephone Planned for Rhode Island
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 (AP) A telephone service designed to help people solve their sexual problems is being expanded from a local effort to serve all of Rhode Island.

title: MRS. MEIR PLEDGES AID TO SOVIET JEWS
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 23Premier Golda Meir pledged today in a speech to the parliament that Israel would not forsake the Soviet Jews affected by the new order heavily increasing exit fees for educated Jews wishing to live in Israel.

title: 82 Find Road to College Literally Rocky, but Fun
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 23It tastes better if you don't look at it, Tom Tanenhaus said as he doused his flashlight and poked in the dark at the lukewarm, halfcooked hamburger and beans in his mess kit.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 23One of the most intriguing of all the Olympians is Mark Spitz, the prodigiously gifted swimmer from California.

title: Killing of Argentine Prisoners Brings New Political Tensions
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 23 (AP)  The killing of 16 guerrilla suspects yesterday in marine jail brought new hostility today between the two powerful forces that are vying for control of Argentina.

title: MRS. CHARLES ANDREWS
description: HASTINGS ON HUDSON, N.Y.. Aug. 23Mrs. Dorothy L. Warren Andrews, the widow of J. Charles Andrews, treasurer and a director of the Turner Construction Company of New York who died in 1934, died today at her summer home in Waterford. Me. She was S4 years ma and lived here.

title: Dublin Says Relief Funds for, Ulster Went for Arms
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 23 (AP)Ireland is trying to recover from a West German arms dealer about S70,000 voted for relief operations in Northern Ireland but diverted to buy weapons and ammunition, Government report said today.

title: Caution Seems to Temper Spassky's Play
description: After five moves were played in the adjourned position of the 17th game in the world chess championship match in Iceland, Bobby Fischer and! Boris Spassky agreed to a draw by repetition of moves. Spassky could have tried for a victory, but he and his aides apparently felt the chance ofj victory was too small to warrant the risk of losing.

title: Spirited Romp for Invisible Caper Crew
description: Walt Disneyat least his thriving production unithas finally met "The Invisible Man." That's the gimmick of "Now You See Him. Now You Don't" and the children ate it up yesterday at the Guild, which is all that matters.The finale, barreling Keystone Kops chaos, is funny enough for anybody as some science-major collegians, who have accidentally uncorked a spray-on invisibility, pursue spray thieves who stage an "invisible" bank robbery. There are two rib-tickling golf tourneys, too, one with the thick-skulled college president invisibly turned into a Bobby Jones. The second game, minus the helpful spray, is a disaster.The Disney people, with their obvious gimmick, have kept the antics as merry as they are broadand clean. The main students, Kurt Russell, Joyce Menges and Michael McGreevey, are thoroughly appealing, with nimble help from such veterans as Joe Flynn, playing the school prexy, and Cesar Romero, personable as usual, as a natty crook.Now with all due respect to children's intuition and judgment, may we suggest that they now try the Real McCoy, if they haven't already. How about the original "The Invisible Man" on television? There's grand, serious fun, kids. Plussquare or notsomething to think about.

title: Tishman Will Head Jewish Drive
description: Alan V. Tishman, executive vice president of Tishman Realty & Construction Company, has been named head of the maintenance campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, which opens in September.

title: Daily Car Sales Rate Rose By 12% for MidAugust
description: DETROIT, Aug. 23New car dealers reported the midAugust daily carselling rate jumped 12 per cent from a year ago. And the American Motors Corporation announced that it would add 300 workers and step up its production pace for small cars.

title: End to Fixed Stock Fees Is Urged by House Group
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A unanimous House subcommittee proposed today sweeping changes for the securities industry, including abolition by phases of fixed commission rates for securities transactions.

title: MARVIN A. FRANKLIN, METHODIST BISHOP
description: JACKSON. Miss., Aug. 23 (AP)Bishop Marvin A. Franklin, retired leader of Mississippi Methodists, died yesterday, two weeks after suffering stroke. He was 78 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Of the late Edmund Wilson's vast output of published writingscontained, as of now, in some twodozen volumes of criticism, plays, fiction, poetry, diaries, and cultural investigations, with more posthumous volumes yet to comeTo the Finland Station would seem to rank as his masterpiece, if a writer of such catholic interests and variegated writing skills can be said to have produced a single work that stands above all the others. First published in 1940, Wilson's study of the ideas and events leading up to the Russian Revolution or 1917 can now be seen to have inaugurated the series of books exploring other culturesamong them, O Canada (1965) and The Dead Sea Scrolls (1969). And yet To the Finland Station has always seemed to surpass his other books, especially in the pertinence of its content to the contemporary American scene. When it first appeared, it was met by an audience still reeling from the shocks of disillusionment brought on by the revelations of the Moscow purges and the HitlerStalin pact. Today, more than 30 years later, it greets a public revived in its interest in Marxist theory and newly surrounded by the dustdevils of revolutionary rhetoric.

title: McGovern's Security Panel Scores Nixon Defense View
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) A newly formed national security panel for Senator George McGovern criticized President Nixon and the Republican party today for what the group called overemphasizing the need for military force to implement foreign policy.

title: A Legal Aid Effort Begun for Man Held In Slaying of Three
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Aug. 23 (AP)A legal support effort has been started for Guillermo Aillon, the 34yearold Spanishspeaking community leader who claims he is innocent of charges that he killed his estranged wife and her parents.

title: ATMS FAVORED AT 3 TO 5 IN TROT
description: YONKERS, Aug. 23  In thoroughbred racing a jockey is prohibited from riding a horse he owns, but in standardbred racing there is no rule prevent a driver from steering a trotter or a pacer belonging to him.

title: Drulis of Cards Dies at 53
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)Chuck Drulis, a St. Louis Cardinals defensive backfield coach for 17 years, died today on plane taking the team to Houston. Drulis, who was 53 years old, died when the plane was over Arkansas, and his body was taken off at Little Rock.

title: P.S.C. Starts Inquiry Into Cuts In BusySignal Phone Checks
description: The Public Service Commission announced yesterday an inquiry into the New York Telephone Company's decision to limit the use of its verification service on busy signals.

title: Southwest Forest Concern Reassigns Some Executives
description: Southwest Forest Industries, Inc., has reassigned the functions of some of its toplevel executives, effective Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday.

title: Disaster Aid Approved
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP)President Nixon today designated West Virginia as a major disaster area, eligible for special federal aid, as the result of floods in four southwestern counties there last week.

title: Report on Funds Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The General Accounting Office, saying that its investigation was still incomplete, delayed again today the release of a final report on its threeweekold audit of an alleged mishandling of campaign funds by the Committee for the Reelection of the President.

title: ARREST IS RELIEF FOR JERSEY BANK
description: NORTH BRUNSWICK. N. J., Aug. 23Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were back at the Middlesex County Bank today, but the fact that the bank's former, president had been arrested yesterday on charges of converting more than $500,000 to his own use was more a source of relief than of excitement to many at the hank.

title: NASTASE DEFEATS MAYER IN TENNIS
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 23Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania and Manuel Orantes of Spain led the advance into the quarterfinals of the 46th Eastern grasscourts open championships today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: A 25Year F.B.I. Agent Foiled Robbers Attempt to Flee by Jet
description: Richard J. Baker. a veteran of 25 years with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, devised and helped execute the plan that foiled the escape attempt early yesterday morning of the two bank robbers who took nine persons hostage in Brooklyn.

title: DR. ALBERT R. FRITZ, A HOSPITAL FOUNDER
description: Dr. Albert R. Fritz. a retired Brooklyn physician and surgeon who founded with Dr. J. Dudley Fritz, his brother, the Madison Park Hospital, now Community Hospital of Brooklyn, died yesterday in Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at The Cliffs, West Shore Road, Oyster Bay, L. I., and in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Thunderstorms in Milan Cause Flooding and Fires
description: MILAN, Italy, Aug. 23 (AP)A violent thunderstorm lashed. Milan at dawn today, flooding basements and streets, starting several fires and knocking out local and international railway lines.

title: Mine Pay Rise Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The Pay Board approved today a pay and workweek package for some coal mine construction workers representing a 9.54 per cent increase in compensation. It approved a pay schedule submitted under a court order that had turned down increases negotiated in January by the Association of Bituminous Contractors and the United Mine Workers Union.

title: Seoul Drops Aide to Appease North
description: SEOUL South Korea, Aug. 23Yielding to a persistent" North Korean demand, the South Korean Red Cross today replaced one of its seven advisers named to take part in the NorthSouth Red Cross talks scheduled to open in Pyongyang on Aug, 30.

title: CITY AIDES SCORE CURBS ON POLICE
description: Several high officials in the Lindsay administration have expressed displeasure at the Police Department's decision last week to bar patrolmen from enforcing most laws pertaining to construction sites.

title: LARRY BOECK
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 23 (UPI)Larry Boeck, director of the University of Louisville athletic department and former president of the United States Basketball Writers Association, died today. He was 52 years old.

title: MARKET PURSUES A MIXED COURSE
