description: The stock market yesterday finished with advances outnumbering declines by a modest margin although leading market averages finished lower.

title: California Forest Fire Slows as Winds Decrease
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) Decreasing winds slowed the spread of California's largest fire of the year today, but the United States Forest Service said it did not expect containment of the 7,500acre blaze for two or three days.

title: Film: Jealousy Consumes Eccentric Boy in 'Rivals'
description: If you had just the story idea of Krishna Shah's "Rivals," about how an attractive New York widow marries for a second time and how her young son resents the marriage and destroys it, the film might sound merely ordinary. In fact it is terrible. But it is terrible in such eccentric ways and with such a desire to instruct that I can't deny it certain values, though probably never the values it intended.Christine Button (Joan Hackett) runs an art gallery, and her son, Jaimie (Scott Jacoby), a 10-year-old independent filmmaker, pretty much runs his mother's life. One day Christine meets Peter (Robert Klein), a childlike 33-year-old independent guided-tour leader, who hustles her into a guided tour of Manhattan, and, after a whirlwind courtship, marries her.Distraught, Jaimie regresses, gives up moviemaking and begins playing with his electric train. Peter wants to be friends, but Jaimie will have none of him. Jaimie tries suicide, with no luck, and, as an act of revenge, tries making love to his baby sitter. She is quite willing, but Jaimie is only 10, and the resulting failure wounds him deeply. With desperate skill he plans Peter's murder. The plan works but for the wrong victim, and, helplessly, Jaimie stands by as his mother is incinerated in flaming coils of his own 8mm film stock.The source of Jamie's anxiety is a puzzle. An early flashback seems to indicate that it might somehow have been overstrict toilet trainingthe first toilet-training flashback I have ever seen in a movie. But later on we learn that his being born (by natural childbirth) was such a joy for Christine that it may also have been a sexual experience for himand I do believe that is supposed to be why Jamie is so exceptionally fond of his mom."Rivals" tends to be very heavy in psychology and a little flighty about lesser matterssuch as plot, dialogue, characterization and the like. Given its situation, it is of course much concerned with criteria of age differentiation. Everyone seems to be measured on a scale running from infantilism to maturity  so we must not be surprised to notice that Jaimie's psychiatrist's office is a place full of oral, for example gratifications. But the psychiatrist is played by James Karen, an actor probably best known to New Yorkers for his recent television commercials advertising Pathmark food stores. And as we watch him tasting coffee, sipping soda, eating oranges, we forget motivation and explanation, and succumb to a kind of supermarket dj vu.Such mishaps are the only pleasures in "Rivals," and though there are many, they are not enough.

title: Advertising:
description: Now that the Republican convention is over, the electioneeringand pblitical advertisingwill soon be under way at full speed. And on the G.O.P. side, a media buying service has been added to the ad team headed by the November Group, the house agency of the Committee For the Reelection of the President, Inc.

title: Engagements
description: BEATY STUMPF  Mr. and Mrs. Stephan Anthony Stumpf of New York City and Newton, N. J., announce the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jennifer, to Charles Joseph Beaty 3d of Baltimore, Md.

title: G. O. P. Carefully Created Fresh Show for Viewers
All Horse Traders Shun Being No. 2
description: ALMOND, N. Y.  After three days of swapping, haggling, drinking, fighting and more or less good natured lying, the grizzled participants in the 51st Annual Original Horse Traders Convention packed up their loot and Sunuay headed for home.

title: Alabama Black Nominated To Run for the U.S. Senate
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 23 (AP)The predominantly black National Democratic party of Alabama certified a Negro candidate for the United States Senate today, the first to run for that office in Alabama since Reconstruction.

title: Business Briefs
description: Interest rates on conventional home mortgages closed during July increased slightly, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. The effective interest rate on loans to purchase new homes was 7.58 per cent, up from 7.55 per cent in June, while the rate on loans to purchase previously occupied residences averaged 7.50 per cent, up from 7.49 per cent.

title: 2 REPORTERS FOUND WRONGLY CONVICTED
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 23 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has overturned contempt convictions of two Baton Rouge newsmen, ruling that censorship in any form is incompatible with a free press.

title: ExChicago Alderman Waives Extradition in Fraud Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (UPI)  Former Chicago Alderman Fred D. Hubbard waived extradition before a United States magistrate today and will be returned to Illinois to face charges of embezzling more than $100,000 from a Federally funded program.

title: HOWARD MULHOLLAND
description: LYNBROOK, L.I., Aug. 23Howard Mulholland, a lawyer in Brooklyn since his graduation from St. John's Law School in 1928, died yesterday in South Nassau Communities Hospital, Rockville Centre, after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 37 First Street.

title: 2 Leap From Golden Gate
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (UPI)Within 20 minutes yesterday, two unidentified persons plunged to their deaths from the Golden Gate Bridge. A Coast Guard crew recovered one of the bodies. The deaths were listed by the California Highway Patrol as the 455th and 456th known suicides from the bridge, which was completed in 1937.

title: POLICE SEIZE 900 IN MIAMI BEACH
description: MIAMI BEACH, Thursday, Aug. 24Thousands of antiwar demonstrators roamed through the streets last night, but failed in their major goalto delay the session of the Republican National Convention at which President Nixon accepted his nomination.

title: City Center Adds New Group Formed by 18 at Juilliard
description: The Acting Company, a repertory troupe built around the 18 men and women from the first graduating class at the Juilliard School's drama division, will become a constituent of the City Center of Music and Drama.

title: Indian Movement Presents Demands to Nixon Daughter
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  American Indians protested today to President Nixon's daughter, Mrs. David Eisenhower, about their treatment by the Administration and presented a series of demands to her.

title: BigBoard Seat Price Rises
description: The New York Stock Exchange said that arrangements had been made for sale of a membership at $170,000, up $5,000 from the preceding sale last week. Seats currently are $150,000 bid and $175,000 offered.

title: RACE WEEK OPENS WITH FLEET OF 201
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. L., Aug. 23The 40th annual Race Week got off to a splendid start today for the 201 skippers who turned out for competition conducted by the Manhasset Bay Y.C. Southerly winds puffed up to 15 knots but generally were around 8 to provide nearperfect conditions.

title: Japan Desalting Concern Gets $60Million Contract
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 23 (AP) The Sasakura Engineering Company of Osaka, Japan, has been awarded a $60million contract to build the world's biggest seawater desalting plant here, it was announced today by the Hong Kong Government.

title: Pace in Westchester Names a New Dean
description: Dr. Warren F. Goodell, vice president for administration at Columbia University, was named dean of Pace College Westchester yesterday.

title: Day Liner Scuffle Ends in Arrest of 6; Worker Is Injured
description: An altercation aboard a Hudson River Day Line cruise ship returning from Bear Mountain Yesterday afternoon led to the rest of six persons on assault charges.

title: Rhodesian Ouster
description: The withdrawal by the International Olympic Committee of its invitation to Rhodesia to compete in the Games at Munich indicates how profoundly the world has changed since the last Olympics in Germany in 1936. Then teams from all countries competed in a Berlin ruled by Adolf Hitler and his coterie of Aryan supremacists, practitioners of the most homicidal racism in modern history. This year, under threat of boycott by black athletes from Africa, the United States and the Caribbean, the I.O.C. has excluded the team sent by the white minority Government of Rhodesia.

title: Executive Changes
description: Martha Peterson, president of Barnard College, and L. Edmund Rast, president of the Southern Bell Telephone Company, have been elected directors of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: RealLife Death
description: There must be some awful confusion. The 3,000 bystanders who cheered on their favorites at a Brooklyn bank robbery Tuesday seemed to imagine themselves watching a diverting movie or television serial. An even larger group of New Yorkers appeared to regard the record number of homicides in New York Monday as statistic comparable in significance to the day's high and low temperatures and the stock market averages.

title: Compulsory Tests Urged To Detect Student Addicts
description: Dr. Robert W. Baird, director of the Haven Clinic, yesterday urged the Board of Education to immediately adopt a program to prevent the drug problem from reaching a total disaster point which will immobilize any learning by students.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)Ilie Nastase of Romania today moved into first place in the men's division of the $375,000 Commercial Union Grand Prix of Tennis.

title: SAIGON ARRESTS QUESON OFFICERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 25 (AP)A South Vietnamese regimental commander and at least one of his battalion commanders have been arrested for their part in the loss of the Queson valley last weekend, military officials reported yesterday.

title: McGovern Aide to Visit 4 Lands to Assure Them
Town Rallying to Aid Crusading Editor
description: MADIS ONVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 24  The crusading 50yearold editor of The Monroe County Democrat, an independent weekly, was smiling again today and determined to stay here to continue publishing.

title: Job Cutback at Space Hub
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Aug. 24 (UPI)  The Kennedy Space Center will reduce its support contractor work force by 200 people this fall and cut back by another 300 by the end of next June, the space agency reported today. The cuts are in addition to more than 600 spacecraft and rocket workers who will lose their jobs by next June as a result of the end of Project Apollo and work on the Skylab space station.

title: OILERS TOP CARDS ON PASSES, 3324
description: DALLAS, Aug. 24 (AP)Houston scored two touchdowns within a 35second span of the second quarter tonight and Dan Pastorini threw three touchdown passes as the Oilers defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3324, in a National Football League exhibition.

title: 3 on Tombs Case Jury Assail Hogan for Attacking
description: Three members of the jury that was criticized last week by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for acquitting three defendants charged with leading a riot at the House of Detention for Men in Manhattan have circulated a letter among the other jurors attacking the prosecutor's statements and asking him for a public apology.

title: A JUSTICE ANSWERS CRITICISM ON JAILS
description: State Supreme Court Justice Vincent D. Damiani said yesterday that it was manifestly unfair for the Commissioner of Correction to blame the courts for overcrowded jails.

title: Call to Fear
description: President Nixon's acceptance speech to the Republican National Convention was an extraordinary address for an incumbent to deliver. Instead of expounding the accomplishments of his own Administration and explaining how he plans to extend and improve upon them the next four years, Mr. Nixon devoted most of his energies to calling upon the electorate to fear Senator McGovern and the Democrats.

title: The Nobel Speech Is Reported To Be Redraft of Mild Version
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's sharply worded Nobel Prize speech published today is said to be actually a second version written after friends privately expressed disappointment with a milder first. draft.

title: Kenny Barron, on Piano, Show Jazz Talent With Yusef Lated
description: Yusef Lateef is one of the most valid triplethreat men in jazza saxophonist who plays with a strong, open urgency, flutist who blends delicacy with a subtle sense of swing and an oboist who stands alone in the jazz use of that instrument. By himself, he can be the source of varied programing for any group he plays with.

title: MEAT PRICES RISE TO PEAK AT RETAIL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) Retail beef and pork prices increased to record highs in July, raising overall food costs to a new peak. But there were signs that the situation could ease if retailers passed along recent reductions in costs.

title: Moscow Cautions Arabs Not to Take Friendship Lightly
Peking Charges U.S. Planes Attacked Chinese Lifeboat Off Vietnam
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 24 China said today that it had lodged a strong protest with the United States over what it described as an attack by American aircraft against a lifeboat of a Chinese merchant ship, resulting in the death of the ship's captain, a deputy political commissar and three seamen.

title: Advertising:
description: A merger and a potential acquisition crossed ad alley yesterday, indicating that the summer lull has its moments of activity.

title: Increase in Bread Prices Urged by Baking Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) The baking industry asked the Cost of Living Council today to authorize an immediate increase in bread priceseven for companies exceeding Federal profitcontrol guidelinesIto offset rising flour costs they attributed to sales of American wheat tothe Soviet Union.

title: FACTORY IN CAMDEN DESTROYED BY FIRE
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 24 (AP) A generalalarm fire that officials said had been started by arsonists destroyed a large vacant factory and forced 21 families to flee their homes last night.

title: Miss Toussaint in Relay
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 24 (UPI)  Debra Edwards, ranked second in the United States in the women's 400meter dash, has been removed from the 1,600meter relay team in the Olympics in favor of the No. 5 runner, an assistant coach said today.

title: Lifts Interest to 5% in Action Expected to Spread Nationally
description: The nation's major banks, as anticipated, started yesterday to increase their minimum interest charges on loans to their most creditworthy customers to 5 per cent from 5 per cent effective today.

title: Republicans in State Optimistic About a Nixon Victory in Fall
BARKUM OF JETS IN DELAYED DEBUT
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 24  Jerome Barkum, the New York Jets No. 1 draft choice, already has had one opportunity to play against the Dallas Cowboys this year. But he turned it down.

title: 6 Held for Trial on Charge Of Plot to Disrupt G.O.P.
Tent Shelters Sounds and Spirit of an OldTime Revival
description: The Major Deegan Expressway would not seem to be a likely site for an oldtime religious revival. But at East 149th Street below the highway, within earshot of its roar, just such an event has been drawing thousands of South Bronx residents and has been puzzling passing motorists for more than a month.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator Ted Stevens urged the Rules Committee to curb a new type of wheelerdealer on Capitol Hill. The Alaska Republican, noting that there were about 100 Senate employes who ride bicycles to work at the old Senate Office Building and that seven bicycles had been stolen recently, proposed indoor parking, more visible bicycle racks or a claimticket parking system.

title: Soviet Jews Urged Not to Buy Visas
Books of The Times
description: Although a reader of these four books on the Middle East will ostensibly be interested in information and light, so fixed are the divisions in ArabIsraeli politics and so fierce the animosities that these books seem more like ammunition carriers than conveyers of enlightenment. The collection of papers that Russell Stetler has brought together, for example, represents the thinking of the New Left, though some of the contributors, like Isaac Deutscher, can be more characteristically described as the old left. The collection consists of critiques of the new state (The Class Nature of Israeli Society), position papers (a statement on the future of Jews and Arabs by the Popular Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine), excerpts from diaries, newspaper stories and interviews, one by Leila Khaled, who was involved in airplane hijacking.

title: 600 Arrested in Argentine Riots After Slayings of 16 Guerrillas
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 24Argentine security forces arrested hundreds of leftwing labor, student and political leaders today, after a night of student rioting in major provincial cities.

title: A Scout Car Blast in Ulster Kills 1 Soldier, Hurts Another
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  A British soldier was killed and another seriously injured today when guerrillas exploded a bomb under an armored scout car.

title: Chess Play Adjourned
description: Bobby Fischer and Boris Spassky adjourned the 18th game of their world championship chess match yesterday in Reykjavik, Iceland, on the 42d move. Play is to resume today. Details on Page 31.

title: MAN PLEADS GUILTY AS PHONY LAWYER
description: Charles Ross, an avowed heroin addict who successfully defended four men in Brooklyn Criminal Court narcotics cases, pleaded guilty yesterday to practicing law without license.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ISTANBUL, TurkeyTurkey's urban guerrillas seem to have philosophical ties with nineteenthcentury Russian nihilism. Their goal is purely destructiveto bring down the lumbering Turkish social structure.

title: Protesters and Politicians Part After a Final Clash
Death Sentence Overturned
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP)  The Pennsylvania Supreme Court today ordered the death sentence given to a convicted murderer, Anthony Scoleri, changed to life imprisonment as mandated by the United States Supreme Court last month. The state court had originally upheld the death sentence against Scoleri, convicted in the holdupslaying of a South Philadelphia merchant.

title: J. ROY STOCKTON, 79, A BASEBALL WRITER
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Aug. 24J. Roy Stockton, a nationally known baseball writer and sports editor of The St. Louis PostDispatch before his retirement in 1958, died here today at the age of 79.

title: Karl Leads Golf by Shot With Course Record of 65
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 24  Richard Karl, who was Alaska's amateur golf champion while serving in the United States Army as a cook, scored a courserecord 65 today in the $100,000 Liggett and Myers open golf tournament.

title: H.E.W. WILL STUDY SYPHILIS PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Department of Health, Education and Welfare named a ninemember panel today to study a Government experiment in which 400 black men with syphilis went without medical aid for 40 years.

title: PRIMERATE RISE WEAKENS STOCKS
description: A jittery stock market took a severe drop yesterday, with prices suffering their sharpest setback in more than three months. Declines outpaced advances by about two to one.

title: AIKEN TRIUMPHS IN YONKERS TROT
description: YONKERS, Aug. 24George Sholty may not fare as well with Aiken as Duncan MacDonald has with Fresh Yankee, but the former is not complaining... Sholty, who purchased Aiken for $6,500, did not campaign the son of Hickory Smoke as a 2yearold, but so far in his sophomore season, Aiken has won five of 15 starts and has earned $41,892.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 24South Africans, excluded from the Olympic Games since 1964 because of the Government's apartheid policy, were denied today the opportunity of seeing daytoday film coverage of the Munich Games.

title: MARCOS BACKS LAND PAYMENTS
description: MANILA, Aug. 24  President Ferdinand Marcos said today it would be a policy of his government to give just and fair compensation to Americans who would be required to abide by a Supreme Court ruling made last week and surrender ownership of land in the Philippines acquired since Philippine independence.

title: 7 Newark Teachers Freed From 3Month Jail Terms
description: CALDWELL, N. J., Aug.24 (UPI)Seven Newark teachers, jailed for contempt of court on June 28, were released today from the Essex County Correctional Center here.

title: Saigon Loss in Foe's Drive Exceeds 10% of Entire War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 (AP)  South Vietnamese combat deaths reported by Saigon in the 20 weeks of the North Vietnamese offensive exceed 10 per cent of the acknowledged toll for more than a decade of the Indochina war.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities:

title: New Housing Court Reviews City Code
description: The city's new Housing Court, which is to open next April, began its task of revamping administration of the city's housingmaintenance codes as its. advisory council met for the first time yesterday.

title: CHINA WOULD VETO BANGLADESH'S BID TO ENTER THE U.N.
American Airlines Suspends Aide Over Conflict Charges
description: An executive of American Airlines has been suspended pending investigation of conflictofinterest charges, company officials said last night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: C. L. Sulzberger's Aug. 18 column, First Nixon, Then Shriver, unwittingly pinpoints the unfortunate preoccupation of this Administration, namely, its luckless obsession with foreign affairs.

title: Bremer Denied New Trial; $2,000 Needed for Appeal
description: UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Aug. 24 (AP)  Arthur IL Bremer, the assailant of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, was denied a new trial today.

title: Giants Travel Plan Operates on Set Pattern
description: While the Giants pondered their Game Plan yesterday for Sunday's football meeting with the New England Patriots, the team's Travel Plan glided along smoothly on a trajectory arranged months ago.

title: Chief of the Gaullist Party Resigns, Citing III Health
description: PARIS, Aug. 24 (AP)Rene Tomasini, the outspoken secretary general of the Gaullist party, the Union of Democrats fol. the Republic, announced today that he was resigning.because of ill health.

title: Stolen Picasso Recovered
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (AP)  A stolen Picasso painting valued at $36,000 has been recovered and three men have been booked for investigation of burglary, police say. The painting, a 1954 abstract work titled Buste, was taken from the West Los Angeles home of David Geffen last October, the police said.

title: New Plant Rules Proposed To Curb Unusual Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today formal procedure dealing with abovestandard air pollution caused by regulated industrial plants under unusual circumstances.

title: Brewers, Rangers Split
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24 (AP) Dave May clubbed a tworun homer to tie the game in the fourth inning, and then beat out an infield single with two out in the eighth to drive in the winning run as the Milwaukee Brewers nipped Texas, 4.3, today for a split of their doubleheader.

title: Wallace to Get Platform
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 24 (AP)Winton M. Blount, Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Alabama, said today that President Nixon had asked him to deliver a copy of the party's platform to Gov. George C. Wallace. He said at a news conference that he would deliver a copy of the platform to Mr. Wallace at Spain Rehabilitation Center where the Governor is receiving therapy.

title: Nixon Orders an End to Quotas In Hiring by Federal Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) President Nixon has ordered all Federal Government departments to end any systems of quotas for the hiring of Negroes or other minority group members.

title: Stuffed Squash Blossoms Can Begin the Meal
description: In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by recipe.

title: First Neutercane Warning
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP)The National Hurricane Center today issued its first warning on a new type of marine storm  a neutercane  that has boiled up in the North Atlantic.

title: 4 Hurt on Jersey Turnpike
description: SECAUCUS, N. Aug. 24 (AP)  Four persons suffered minor injuries in a collision of a PhiladelphiatoNew York bus, truck and three cars in the northbound lane of the New Jersey Turnpike today, the state police said. The accident.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (UPI)The Chicago Black Hawks asked a Federal judge today to silence Bobby Hull because He's like an evangelist.

title: JAPANU.S. LINKS TERMED STRAINED
description: TOKYO, Aug. 24Yasuhiro Nakasone, Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, warned today that economic, psychological and emotional frictions are risinab between Japan and the United States.

title: Elegant New Cafe With Varied Fare
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $862,000,000, up 7 per cent from the yearearlier $804,000,000. Total retail store sales were about $8,474,000,000, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $7,819,000,000.

title: LYLE B. EMERSON
description: ROWAYTON, Conn., Aug. 24 Lyle Burton Emerson, who retired as traffic manager of the Continental Banking Company in Harrison, N. Y., in 1968, died today at his home, 38 Pine Point Road. His age was 69.

title: StolenSecurities Suspects Waive Court Examination
description: Three men charged with stealing $830,000 in negotiable securities from CBWLHayden, Stone, Inc., waived examination yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court to await grand jury action.

title: Advertising:
description: Advertising in the frenetic cosmetic industry has changed markedly over the last decade but certain things remain constant. And one of them is the advertising approach of Estee Lauder, Inc.

title: AIRPORTPROJECTBIAS CLAIMED IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24  The Greater Newark Urban Coalition announced today that six minority trainees had filed legal action with the Federal Equal Employment Commission charging Local 11 of the International Iron Workers Union with racial discrimination in its hiring practices at Newark Airport.

title: $1 Million Hijacking Ransom Arrives in U.S. From Paris
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Two Delta Airlines executives flew in from Paris today with two black suitcases stuffed with $1million in ransom money I that the airline paid to eight hijackers three weeks ago.

title: The LookAlikes
description: The American twoparty system, for which there is no constitutional provision, may have to be scrapped. The nomination of George McGovern to oppose Richard M. Nixon for the Presidency proves that the system no longer works to check and balance the major factional forces of our society. If we cling to it as it presently operates, with uncompromising minorities positioned to exercise inordinate leverage in both major parties, our Government of free men will be destroyed.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Congressional hearings on gold and the Federal Reserve Bank's intervention to support the dollar will be held in September, Representative Henry S. Reuss announced today. The Wisconsin Democrat, who is chairman of the joint SenateHouse subcommittee on international exchange and payments, said his committee would hold hearings Sept. 1113 to explore such questions as whether the March, 1968, twotier agreement banning official gold transactions in the free market had outlived its usefulness.

title: New YorkMontreal Trains To Begin Runs on Sept. 29
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Daily passenger train service between New York and Montreal through New England will be resumed Sept. 29, Amtrak announced today.

title: ANDERSON BEATS SOLOMON AT NET
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 24Mal Anderson, an Australian who won the United States singles title in 1957, progressed to the semifinal round of the $15,000 73d annual Pennsylvania Lawn Tennis championship by defeating Harold Solomon, of the United States Davis Cup team, 63, 63, today before nearcapacity crowd of 25,000 at Merion Cricket Club.

title: Barclays Is Seeking L.I. Trust In Proposed $60Million Deal
description: Barclays Bank of London, the largest bank outside the United States, is planning to enter the suburban territory of the Eastern Seaboard with the proposed acquisition of the Long Island Trust Company, it was announced yesterday. The transaction would involve close to $60mil lion. Directors of the Long Island Trust Company, Garden City, L. I., agreed in principle to the sale of all its assets, subject to all liabilities, to new subsidiary of Barclays overseas arm to he named the Long Island Trust Company. The cash price is equivalent to $47 for each share of Long Island Trust, which has 1,375,668 shares outstanding.

title: School Busing Order in Detroit Is Held Up as Court Studies Appeal
description: DETROIT, Aug. 24  A courtordered plan to begin busing schoolchildren between Detroit and its suburbs was effectively blocked today when a higher court said that it would not be able to rule on an appeal before schools opened on Sept. 6.

title: Theater: Street Festival
description: Genuine, professional color splashed the Lincoln Center Mall yesterday afternoon in two wellreceived performances for the center's Community/Street Theater Festival

title: Emergency in Santiago
description: Chilean President Allende is now faced by a revolt of the middle class against his Socialist policies. That is the meaning of the widespread strike of shopkeepers that forced him earlier this week to proclaim states of emergency in Santiago and Magellanes Provinces. Mr. Allende obviously recognizes the substantial Chilean middle class as a far more formidable foe than the foreign investors or the native capitalists whose holdings he has expropriated. His decision to back away from his original threat to seize the struck shops is abundant proof of that.

title: A Campfire Ban in Jersey
description: TRENTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)State Fire Warden William B. Phoenix today banned all campfire permits in central and southern New Jersey because of a hazard brought on by a prolonged dry spell.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Sonic members of the Jewish community oppose Senator McGovern because they mistrust his expressions of support for Israel. How can anyone who opposes our military involvement in Vietnam, so the rationale goes, be relied upon to give military support to Israel if, as and when it is needed?

title: CAB DRIVER IN BRONX IS SHOT IN A HOLDUP
description: Holdup men shot and wounded a gypsy cab driver in the Bronx early yesterday after robbing him of $3 in cash and his watch, the police reported.

title: One Dead. 7 Hurt in Chile ln Rural Clashes Over Land
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 24 (AP)One farm worker was killed and seven persons were wounded in an armed clash between peasants and land

title: MUSICAL IS CANCELED BY KENNEDY CENTER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)The Kennedy Center canceled its first musical comedy production of the season today in a dispute with the District of Columbia Federation of Musicians.

title: BENCH HITS 29TH AS REDS WIN, 60
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 24 (UPI) Johnny Bench, Playing third base for the first time this sea son, hit his 29th home run of the year and Jack Billingham today as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Expos, 60.

title: SLEDDING DROPPED FROM 1976 GAMES
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 24 (UPI)  The International Olympic Committee refused today to approve Lake Placid, N. Y., as the site for bobsledding in the 1976 Winter Olympics.

title: Heavy U.S. Trade Deficit Was Shaved During July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24United States foreign trade continued in heavy deficit in July, although there was some improvement over June and other recent months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: F.B.I. Loses LongHair Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The American Civil Liberties Union said today that it had won a Civil Service Commission order to reinstate an employe of the Federal Bureau of Investigation dismissed on the ground that his hair was too long. Robert Fitzpatrick, a volunteer attorney for the A.C.L.U., said he was awaiting word from the F.B.I. whether would appeal the order to reinstate a 22yearold fingerprint clerk, Joseph Hamm, who has refused to trim his hair so did not touch the back of his shirt collar or cut his sideburns no longer than the bottom of the ear.

title: Pakistan Affirms Agreement on Troop Withdrawals
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 24 The Pakistani Government announced today that withdrawals would take place as scheduled from territories occupied by Indian and Pakistani troops since the December war that created Bangladesh.

title: CLOCKWORK ORANGE TO GET AN R RATING
description: Stanley Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange will be withdrawn from exhibition for 60 days beginning about the end of October in accordance with rules governing a change in its rating from X to R.

title: Bond, Here, Bids Blacks Unite And Drive Nixon Out of Office
description: In a strong attack on the President. Julian Bond, the Georgia legislator, urged black people yesterday to come together now to drive Richard Nixon from the White House.

title: MIAMI BEACH
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 24Among the writers of advanced political nonsense at the two political conventions, there seemed to be general agreement on two propositions: (1) The Republicans were going to win easily in November and (2) the conservatives had finally regained control of American politics.

title: Red Smith
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 24On the brightest, warmest day he has seen in Bavaria, S/Sgt. Raymond Russell sat soaking his skinny shanks in sunshine outside the United States quarters in Olympic Village, discoursing upon world travel, upon life in the Marine Corps, upon his hobby of swatting strangers senseless. He enjoys them all, and when he holds forth his listeners enjoy him, as any member of the Congress of the United States would testify. Before the American team left Washington last week, Sergeant Russell addressed Congress, playing upon his audience as skillfully as he plays upon the piano in the International Club here in the village when the athletic youth of the world relax after dark. Ray Russell is a narrow strip of talent, gristle and gaiety measuring 6 feet 4 inches from end to end and weighing 178 pounds, which puts him in the lightheavyweight division as a fist fighter. At 32 he is the grand old man of the boxing squad, 15 years older than Tim Dement and Davey Armstrong, the flyweights, and seven years on the shady side of Jesse Valdez, the welterweight, who has had 239 bouts in 12 years.

title: DR. ARTHUR GATES, A READING EXPERT
description: Dr. Arthur I. Gates, emeritus professor of education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and a leader in developing modern methods of reading instruction, died yesterday in Montrose, N. Y., where he lived. His age was 81.

title: RICE AWARD IS GIVEN TO CHELSEA THEATER
description: The Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn yesterday received the Vernon Rice Award for excellence in the Off Broadway theater.

title: Matthews Winner In 400 Showdown
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 24Angered over reports that he was ducking rival teammates and might be replaced in the open 400meter run for the Olympics, Vince Matthews beat Lee Evans in what amounted to a match race tonight.

title: BACHE PROFITS SHOW DECLINE IN QUARTER
description: Bache & Co., the brokerage house, reported yesterday that earnings in the three months ended July 31, 1972, fell sharply to $836,925, or 11 cents share, from $1,695,131, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: $100,000 IN JEWELS STOLEN IN MIDTOWN
description: Two men armed with a gun and a knife made off with perhaps $100,000 worth of jewels yesterday afternoon after they locked a 60yearold partner of a midtown jewelry firm in a walkin office safe, the police said.

title: Prospects for Fishing and Boating This Weekend
description: AREA ACod and pollack are being taken at the Mud Hole about 15 miles east of Manasquan Inlet. There also have been some sea bass there. Bluefish are running during the daytime off Barnegat Ridge but frequently school tuna have appeared when the choppers haven't. The Jamaica II did extremely well with tiles at Hudson Canyon, 100 miles east southeast of the Inlet on Tuesday and that night plenty of 8tol0pound blues were taken at the Ridge by chummers.

title: Berkeley Council Bars U.S. Flag on City Hall
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 24 (Reuters)This city of 120,000 people bordering San Francisco Bay has officially decided it will not fly the American flag on top of its City Hall, officials said tonight.

title: UPRISING IS QUELLED AT TRENTON PRISON
description: TRENTON, Friday, Aug. 25 (AP)A force of correction officers, armed with mace and batons, subdued eight inmates at Trenton State Prison early today after they smashed television set, chairs and tables in a recreation room.

title: U.S., Mexico Senior Netmen Split Opening Singles Tests
description: The defending United States learn of senior tennis players and their Mexican counterparts split the first two singles matches in the challenge round for the Stevens Cup yesterday at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Excerpts From Nobel Lecture by Solzhenitsyn
Tambourine Club Is Closed by Police; 6 Employes Held
description: The Tambourine Club, a Yorkville night spot that has drawn heavy fire from residents of the neighborhood who charge it is o. hangout for drug addicts, homosexuals and boisterous revelers, was closed by the ponice shortly before midnight yesterday.

title: 148 MEN TO SEEK U,S. TENNIS TITLE
description: First round pairings were drawn yesterday for the United States Open tennis championships, which start next Wednesday in Forest Hills, Queens, but Stan Smith, the defending champion, still doesn't know who his opponent will be.

title: Nathan's Tells Holders of Its Trying Year
description: About four dozen of the 2,700 people who own shares in Nathan's Famous, Inc.the restaurant company that has grown from a Coney Island hot dog stand to a chain that sells half a million pounds of frogs legs a year met in Times Square yesterday, and several were terribly unhappy.

title: $4Million in Rebuilding Begun in QE 2 Interior
description: The 65,863ton Queen Elizabeth 2 is undergoing a $4million interior rebuilding designed to make the vessel more attractive as a luxury cruise ship.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Public schools throughout the city will be open Sept. 6 through Sept. 8, to register new pupils and to arrange for others to transfer. The new term starts Sept. 11. The Board of Education expects a record enrollment of 1,161,500 for the fall term, an increase of more than 12,500 over last year.

title: PLAYERS ADJOURN 18TH CHESS GAME
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 24The 18th game of the world championship chess match here was adjourned tonight when Boris Spassky, playing the black pieces, sealed his 42d move in a complicated position.

title: PRESIDENT SCORES M'GOVERN'S PLAN FOR DEFENSE CUT
SPA RACE IS WON BY COLD COMFORT
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 24Cold Comfort, Alfred Vanderbilt's Canadianbred campaigner,. showed a liking for a surface made sloppy by heavy overnight rains, and ran to a 2length victory in the feature race today at Saratoga Race Track. The event was over seven furlongs and was for older fillies and mares. It attracted a field of five.

title: A DISABLED AIRLINER LANDS IN EAST HAVEN
description: EAST HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 24 (AP)A twinengine DC3A en route from La Guardia Airport to Massachusetts developed engine trouble in flight and made a safe emergency landing at TweedNew Haven Airport about 10:30 A.M. today.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW A DECLINE
description: Stocks backed down along a broad front yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in the sharpest price drop in over a month. Trading volume remained moderate.

title: Pennsy Meeting Closes Without a Decision
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24The Penn Central Company, the parent of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, held its annual meeting here today. It was a stormy and raucous five hour session that mirrored the troubles of the ailing railroad.

title: Spassky Saved by Precise Play After Some Dangerous Moves
description: The 18th game of the world chess championship match was a fierce battle.

title: WILLIAM G. JAMES.
description: William Gilbert James, who retired in 1968 as president of the Brooklyn wholesale drug concern of Towns & James, Inc., died yesterday in New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and a resident of Quaker Hill, Pawling, N. Y.

title: Business Briefs
description: DENVER, Aug. 24 (UPI)The construction industry, at depressed levels a year ago, now appears to have taken the comeback trail at a much faster pace than was anticipated, a private survey showed today. Total United States construction expenditures are expected to increase 15 per cent this year to $125.3billion, according to a midyear economicoutlook study by the JohnsManville Corporation. This represents an upward revision from the $120.4billion anticipated by the company in January.

title: Suspect Is Seized in Killing Of Man, 26, on West Side
description: A 32yearold Manhattan man who allegedly shot and killed another man during an argument in front of 200 West 79th Street was taken into custody early yesterday as he fled from the scene, the police reported.

title: Centennial in Dodge City Recalls Its Raucous Past
description: DODGE CITY, Kan., Aug. 21There was yet another burial up on Dodge City's Boot Hill this weekend.

title: Genesco Net Falls 50%
description: Gimbel Brothers, Inc., reported yesterday a larger loss for the second quarter, while Genesco, Inc., said its fiscal year's net income dropped by about 50 per cent. Both periods ended July 31.

title: 13BUILDING COMPLEX BLOCKED IN FORT LEE
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Aug. 24The Borough Council last night blocked the plans of a developer to construct a 13building 1,700apartment complex on 26acre wooded site here.

title: BeerbohmBeardsley Centenary Passes Under a Mauve Cloud
description: According to the best authorities, Max Beerbohm, the author and artist, and Aubrey Beardsley, the artist and author, were born 100 years ago yesterday; a zodiacal miracle, yet the world turns as though it were another day.

title: Lions, Skins in One of 3 Screen Tests
description: Three of the National Football League's preseason games will be on national teevision this weekend, starting with the DetroitWashington contest tonight (Channel 2 in New York) at 9 P.M.

title: Women's Group to Observe Rights Day Here Today
description: Eight Keep Her in Her Place awards, one of them to Alfred Hitchcock's movie Frenzy, will be presented today by the New York chapter of the National Organization of Women as part of the third annual celebration of Women's Rights Day.

title: SUSPECT IS CHARGED IN 3 QUEENS SLAYINGS
description: Pvt. Ronald Finkelstein, of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, was charged with three counts of murder here last night in the slaying of three youths on Broad Channel Island in Jamaica Bay last Monday.

title: C. Suydam Cutting, Who Made Historic Visit to Tibet, Is Dead
description: C. Suydam Cutting, the first white Christian ever to enter the forbidden city of Lhasa in Tibet died yesterday at his summer home on Chappaquidick Island in Massachusetts of cerebral hemorrhage. He was 83 years old.

title: Riviera Finds Pollution Not Just a Dirty Word
description: SAINTTROPEZ, France, Aug. 21  Like practically everybody else along the French Riviera, Mayor Marius Astezan of SaintTropez is acutely aware that pollution has suddenly turned from a fashionable word into a real problem.

title: A MAGNETIC FIELD ON MARS IS HINTED
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 24  The Soviet Union, announcing the end of the eightmonth mission of its Mars 2 and Mars 3 probes, reported findings today that the planet was even drier than scientists had expected and might possess a weak magnetic field.

title: Brush Fire in California Flares Into Condor Area
description: FILLMORE, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI)The largest brush fire of the season flared into the mountain sanctuary of the rare California condor today, but the flames posed no immediate threat to the birds.

title: Some Won't Stay in Britain
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 24 Fewer than two thirds of the 50,000 British Asians in Uganda are planning to settle permanently in Britain, according to Asian leaders here. The remainder will either travel directly to India or will move on to other Commonwealth or Western European countries after a temporary stay in Britain.

title: CONGRESS TO SEEK DRUGGING CLUES
description: While the New Jersey Racing Commission readied statement on the case, the House Select Committee on Crime announced yesterday it would conduct its own investigation into the suspected drugging of Riva Ridge in the Monmouth Invitational last Aug. 5.

title: EQUITY FINANCING
description: The Howard Johnson Company yesterday announced it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed secondary offering of 1,150,000 common shares. The company's stock was down  at 26 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Real Casualties
description: WASHINGTON  Chivalry in warfare, I suppose, is an antiquated concept. Such notions are impossible for a B52 bomber crew five miles up in the sky. The targets they drop their bombs upon are like grid squares on a map; they bear no physical resemblance to real cities and farms inhabited by real people. Now the crew hardly even have to concern themselves with accuracy; their smart bombs are carried on laser beams. It is called surgical bombing but is not so surgical as to spare the schools and hospitals, and the men, women and children who happen to be in the target areas.

title: NASTASE DEFEATS TANNER IN TENNIS
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 24Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania posted a hardearned quarterfinal victory over Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., 76, 6.4, today in the 46th Eastern grasscourts open at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Stage Hopes Rise As New Season Nears
Agnew Hopes to End Role As an Angry Campaigner
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 24Vice President Agnew drew the outlines of the Republican campaign here today, sketching for himself the stance of an issueoriented platform advocate but reserving the right to resume his role as the party's oratorical aggressor.

title: Knife Fight Staged to Prepare New School Counselors
description: The scene is the boys locker room at a city high school. An argument flares between two boys who belong to rival gangs. They whip out knives and a scuffle begins.

title: Commission Backs Price Adjustments By 4 Auto Makers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)  The Price Commission approved today selective price adjustments by the big four automobile makers to cover the cost of optional equipment that will become standard on 1973 models.

title: Miami Beach PeaceKeeper Rocky Pomerance
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 24It's raining! It's raining! boomed the man in the shocking pink shirt and electric blue slacks, shaking with boyish joy.

title: Hanoi Rejects Offer by Saigon To Free 600 Prisoners of War
description: PAWS, Aug. 24 (Reuters)The North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks here rejected today a South Vietnamese offer to free 600 pick and wounded prisoners of war. Hanoi's deputy chief of delegation, Nguyen Minh Vy, described the Saigon offer as a wellknown tactic.

title: Stuns Asserts He Doesn't Know How Suspect Got G.O.P. Funds
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 24Maurice H. Stans said under oath today that he did not know how $114,000 in. contributions to President Nixon's reelection campaign ended up in the possession of a man arrested in the breakin at the Democratic headquarters in Washington last June 17.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Rabbi David Greenberg (letter Aug. 11) is agitated by the fact that three Jewish leaders support President Nixon and cite his policy on Israel as reason. He also attacks these individuals because they were not delegated to speak on this issue by any constituencies.

title: West German Surplus Up
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, Aug. 24 (Reuters)West Germany's foreign trade surplus widened to 1.62 billion marks ($499million) in July from 1.23 billion marks ($383million) in June and was higher than the July, 1971, surplus of 1.4 billion marks ($434million), the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: Julie Heldman Wins
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24 (AP) Julie Heldman of Houston scored her second consecutive upset today in the $18,000 Virginia Slims grass courts tennis tournament when she defeated the defender, Kerry Melville of Australia, 63, 62, in the quarterfinals.

title: Ford Recalls 2,000 Trucks
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Aug. 24 (AP)  Ford Motor Company announced today the recall of 2,000 1972model light trucks for replacement of front wheel bearings. Only half of that number have been sold, officials said. The others are still in dealer inventories

title: TUNISIAN, IN PEKING, SPURS WALKOUT BY 7
description: PEKING, Aug. 24, (Reuters) Diplomats of seven Eastern bloc nations walked out of banquet tonight when Foreign Minister Mohammed Masmoudi of Tunisia deplored the presence of Soviet and American ships in the Mediterranean.

title: Skittish Market Reacts to the Sharp Climb in ShortTerm Rates
No Wind at Oyster Bay
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Aug. 24 The host Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club waited until 4 o'clock this afternoon before postponing the sixth race in the Soling class North American championships on Long Island Sound for lack of wind. David A. Curtis of Marblehead, Mass., is the leader. The series will probably wind up tomorrow.

title: Soccer's Top Rookie Achieves Goal
description: Standing in the corner of crowded room, surrounded by newsmen and soccer authorities, Mike Winter was speaking in a very low voice, as if he did not want to be heard.

title: G.A.O. LAYS LAXITY TO INTERIOR AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP)  The General Accounting Office reported today that the Interior Department has not effectively implemented its regulations to protect the environment in permits or leases for coal mining on Federal and Indian land.

title: News Club Changes Name
description: The Newspaper Reporters Association of New York City tonight voted to change its name to the New York Press Club. John Shanahan, president, said the new name more accurately reflects the makeup of the membership of the organization, which includes newsmen from all the mass media.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Doctor Who Defied Antiabortion Laws Indicted in Bergen
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 24A Bergen County grand jury indicted an Englewood Cliffs gynecologist today on charges of conspiring and attempting to commit an abortion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Ramsey Clark's criticism of the Administration on his recent factfinding mission to North Vietnam has encountered a barrage of criticism from expected sources. You showed commendable journalistic courage in supporting the substance of Mr. Clark's statement (editorial Aug. 17). It is unfortunate, however, that your editorial diluted your praise by questioning Mr. Clark's judgment, not for what he said, but because of where he said it, to wit, North Vietnam. I find your criticism of doubtful logic.

title: Canada Plans for Asians
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 24  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced tonight that Canada would receive some Asians expelled by Uganda on an emergency basis.

title: Gas Utility to Expand
description: South Jersey Industries, Inc., said yesterday that it planned to construct a $30milion substitute natural gas plant capable of producing a minimum of 125 million cubic feet of gas a day.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert Starr has been appointed executive vicn president of the B. Manischewitz Company.

title: 5 INMATES RELEASE 3 PRISON HOSTAGES
description: EDDYVILLE, Ky., Aug. 24 (AP)Five Kentucky State Penitentiary inmates armed with homemade knives released three prison employes today after holding them hostage for 12 hours behind the barricaded steel door of a prison pharmacy.

title: GOVERNOR NAMES CONSUMER CHIEF
description: Governor Rockefeller yesterday appointed Peter M. Pryor, an Albany lawyer, to be chairman and executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24The Association of American Railroads last week totaled an estimated 15.5billion tonmiles, 5.3 per cent above the 1971 level. The A.A.R. also reported carloading last week totaled 517,522 cars, up 1.9 per cent. The American Truckling Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 2.4 per cent above last year's.

title: M'GOVERN BACKS TEACHER STRIKES
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 24Senator George McGovern, a college professor before he became a politician 20 years ago, told a cheering convention of the American Federation of Teachers today that he supported the right of public school teachers to strike.

title: ORCUTT GOLF WON BY CRISTINE DESCH
description: HAWORTH, N. J.. Aug. 24Cristine Desch of Noyac Country Club won the 13th annual Maureen Orcutt Junior Trophy golf tournament today at White Beeches Golf and Country Club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What a golden opportunity Ramsey Clark, Jane Fonda, et al., missed when in. Hanoi, if they really wanted the bombing stopped. They could have exerted pressure on Hanoi to withdraw their invading troops from the South, which would mean immediate stopping of the bombing.

title: 4 Years With a New Heart
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 24 (UPI)Louis B. Russell Jr. today observed the fourth anniversary of surgery that gave him a new heart. He is 47 years old. He has lived longer with a transplanted heart than anyone else.

title: STOCKFEE PLAN ALARMS WALL ST.
description: Wall Street was predictably alarmed and apprehensive yesterday over a proposal of House subcommittee to abolish fixed commission rates on securities transactions.

title: Bridge: Long PostMortems Called Mixed Blessing for Couples
description: Whether husbands and wives should play bridge together is an oftendiscussed point. It is now more than 40 years since any husband was shot over the bridge table by his wife for unsound bidding. And married couples have the dubious advantage of being able to continue the postmortem long after the game is over.

title: Drive on Construction Graft Aims at Laws
description: The drive against corruption in the construction industry has now developed into a drivel against many of the laws that regulate builders in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have just reread your editorial in The Times of Aug 17: Ramsey Clark in Hanoi. I can recall no occasion, after upwards of seventy years, when you were so mistaken. Ramsey Clark was right in publicly criticizing American war policies in Hanoi, rather than in Washington. Hanoi is not the enemy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The news that the Soviets have raised manyfold the cost of exit visas for educated Jews who desire to emigrate should serve as a lesson to those who think it is possible to conduct normal trade relations with the Russians. Trade and emigration may seem too dissimilar to mention together, but news stories often do these days, and the Soviets certainly have a similar outlook upon both.

title: 9 Skippers Post 2d Victories In Manhasset Bay Race Week
Women's Rights Day
description: Mayor Lindsay has proclaimed today Women's Rights Day in New York City.

title: ATTORNEY EXPLAINS ABSENCE TO JUDGE
description: Moses Z. Yam, a former Queens assistant district attorney, apologized yesterday to District Judge John R. Bartels for failing to appear earlier this month in Brooklyn Federal Court to defend a law client.

title: Clashes Reported in Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 24 (AP)Troops intervened in western Cyprus today to break up clashes between rival groups of Greek Cypriotes. No official information has been released about thd disturbance, but re. ports from Paphos say at least three persons were injured.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILS GRAFFITI VANDALS
description: As Mayor Lindsay rededicated the Prospect Park boathouse yesterday in Brooklyn following a Simillion exterior restoration, he appealed to all New Yorkers to stop defacing buildings and other property with ink markers and paint spray cans.

title: Columbia Assailed For Discharging 30 Campus Maids
description: Representative Bella S. Abzug joined civil liberties and women's groups yesterday in denouncing Columbia University for discharging 30 maids because of what the institution said was its severe financial troubles.

title: Waldheim's Help Asked
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24An appeal was made to Secretary General Waldheim today to urge the Soviet Union to stop imposing heavy exit fees for educated Jews to emigrate to Israel.

title: 127th Dutchess County Fair Is a RuralUrban Blend
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., Aug. 24  Tens of thousands of visitors, 700 cows, 300 sheep, flocks of chickens, scores of horses and dozens of fruit and vegetable growers converged on Rhinebeck this week for the 127th annual Dutchess County Fair.

title: F.C.C. REJECTS STEP IN FIGHT OVER WPIX
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) In a prehearing conference, the Federal Communications Commission Review Board refused today to enlarge the issues in the renewal fight over New York's Channel 11.

title: WHEAT FUTURES RISE, THEN FALL
description: Profit taking sent wheat futures prices tumbling yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after they had opened strong and at one time were above $2 a bushel.

title: Neely Conquers Walthall In Qualifying Net Play
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. Aug. 24Armistead Neely of Tampa, Fla:, defeated Pancho Walthall of San Antonio, Tex., 63, 64, in the quarterfinals of the United States Lawn Tennis Association satellite event advancing semifinalists into qualifying tournaments for the United States Open championships next week.

title: IVER ROSE DEAD; PAINTED CLOWNS
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 24Iver Rose, an artist who painted many scenes of the industrial world and who was known also for his pictures of clowns, children and GlouCester fishermen, died yesterday in Maaschusetts General Hospital, Boston. He was 73 years old and lived here and in Rockport.

title: McGovern's Children: The Quiet At the Center of a Storm
description: WASHINGTONIn the Japanesestyle living room of the McGovern residence in Washington, 26yearold Susan McGovern Rowen was bouncing her pixieish 7monthold son, Matthew, on her lap.

title: KAISER WILL BUY TECHNOLOGY DATA FROM THE SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation has signed an agreement to purchase technological information and licenses from the Soviet Union to manufacture aluminum at reduced costs, a Soviet trade official announced today.

title: Guggenheim Chamber Program Offers 3 SeldomHeard Works
description: Although the Guggenheim Museum plays host to concerts on occasion, it is not on the regular musical beat. It was surprising, therefore, to have August enlivened by a pair of Guggenheim chamber music programs. The second of them, on Wednesday night, brought together three seldomheard worksRavel's Sonata for Violin and Cello, Dvorak's Bagatelles (Op. 47) for Strings and Harmonium and Elgar's Quintet in A minor for Piano and Strings.

title: Survey Finds Majority, in Shift, Now Favors Liberalized Laws
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24In a rapid shift on a politically tempestuous issue, the American public now appears to strongly favor full liberalization of laws that restrict abortions.

title: 2 Freighters Are Damaged In Collision Off cape May
description: CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 24Two freightersone Japanese and the other Greekcollided tonight about 30 miles southeast of here, the Coast Guard said. No injuries were reported, and neither of the vessels was said to be in immediate danger.

title: Wisconsin Team Keeps April Faith in McGovern
JOHN DEARNALEY, 64, OF STOCK EXCHANGE
description: John F. Dearnaley, American Stock Exchange senior vice president in charge of finance, died Wednesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived here.

title: 38 HELD IN SYRACUSE IN A HEROIN ROUNDUP
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 24City, state and Onondaga County policemen, armed with 55 warrants had arrested 38 men and women by late today in what was described by the District Attorney as the biggest single heroin roundup in the history of the county.

title: 3d Suspect Seized In Bizarre Holdup
description: A man alleged to have aided and abetted two gunmen in Tuesday's weird bank holdup in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Kited's Mass TransitAid Suit Taken to U.S. Supreme Court
description: Theodore W. Kheel took his campaign against the Port Authority to the United States Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: So the honeymoon ended, and the marriage manuals didn't work, and the priest who spoke of forever was wrongyou want a divorce. Should you now run to the bookstore and get another guidebook on how to manage your life? Specifically, this book, Uncoupling: The Art of Coming Apart, subtitled so hopefully, A Guide to Sane Divorce?

title: U.S. AIDES REPORT RAIDS NEAR CHINA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Wellplaced Pentagon officials report that United States fighterbombers, in an effort to choke off the flow of war supplies to North Vietnam, have attacked railroad bridges within 25 miles of the Chinese border on a handful of occasions over the last four months.

title: American Party Charge
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 24 (AP)Representative John G. Schmitz of California, Presidential nominee of the American party, said today that the unsung issue of the Vietnam war was that the United States and its NATO allies are furnishing both sides. He said the North Vietnamese and Vietcong was effort was fueled by the Soviet Union's military output, which, he said, is in turn supplied by the militaryindustrial complex of the United States and its NATO allies.

title: CON EDISON CUTS ITS VOLTAGE BY 5%
description: Confronted with record heat and the failure of a major power generator, the Consolidated Edison Company cut electrical voltage by 5 per cent yesterday afternoon throughout the city and Westchester County.

title: Sports News in Brief; Cup Tennis Shifted to Rumania
description: The announcement ended a controversy that had arisen over whether the matches should be played in the United States or Rumania.

title: Market Place: Accounting Act For Everyone
description: When an investor looks at a corporation's accounting statements, he's not looking for the game points of information as the lender, or at the same figures as someone hoping to acquire the company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The way the Democrats and Republicans choose their respective Vice Presidential candidates is a good illustration of the difference between the two parties. When the Democrats make a mistake, they correct it; when the Republicans make a mistake, they repeat it.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 24 (UPI)Lin YungLung today yielded only one hita homer in the first inningand struck out 15 batters as Nationalist China trounced Pearl City, Hawaii, 91, to gain the final of the Little League World Series.

title: JULES YUCKMAN
description: Jules Yuckman, president of Condotti, Inc., textile converters here, died Wednesday in Montefiore Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived here and in White Plains.

title: Nader Says C.A.B. Practices Job Bias; Urges Chief to Quit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Ralph Nader charged today that the Civil Aeronautics Board was a racially and sexually secluded bureaucracy and he called for the resignation of its chairman.

title: RECORD TIME LOST IN STRIKES IN CITY
description: The amount of working time lost because of strikes in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area reached a new peak in 1971 for the 20 years that such statistics have been kept here.

title: Says State Rule Denied Equal Protection to Indigent Women
description: A threejudge constitutional court yesterday rejected a directive by the state's Social Services Commissioner banning Medicaid payments to hospitals for women who elect to undergo abortions.

title: Yanks Beat Mets, 21, on R.00kie's Pitching and a Homer by Ellis
Steel Local for McGovern
description: LORAIN, Ohio, Aug: 24 (UPI)The largest local of the United Steelworkers Union in Ohio endorsed Senator George McGovern for President last night. Local 1104 at the United States Steel Corporation here said that the resolution of endorsement would be sent to the 16th constitutional convention of the union in Las Vegas Sept. 18.

title: Personalities: Wilkens Says, No
description: Lenny Wilkens, the seasoned allstar basketball pro, is refusing to go East.

title: Ashbrook Backs Nixon With Great Reluctance
School Safety
description: Under pressure from the United Federation of Teachers to assign an additional 6,000 security guards to the city's public schools at an estimated cost of $20 million, the Board of Education has come up with a more moderate proposal aimed at reassuring parents and teachers about school safety without turning the 900 schools into armed camps.

title: Business Briefs
description: LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Maurice Schumann, the French Foreign Minister, said here today that he very much hoped it would be possible to hold the proposed highlevel Common Market meeting in Paris in October. He spoke reporters after a twohour talk with British Prime Minister Edward Heath on the projected meeting of the six European Economic Community countriesFrance, West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourgand the four who will join Jan. 1Britain, Denmark, Norway and Ireland.

title: The Tombs Acquittal
description: Despite the acrimonious war of words between District Attorney Hogan and Chairman vanden Heuvel of the Board of Corrections, the acquittal of three inmates accused of leadership roles in the uprising at the Tombs last October was neither a triumph for justice nor, as Mr. Hogan described it, a hideous miscarriage. Echoes of political rhetoric ring through Mr. vanden Heuvel's charge that the District Attorney was motivated by a passion for vengeance'; but there are similar overtones in Mr. Hogan's assertion that the jury which acquitted the three men was guilty of making a political statement.

title: Solzhenitsyn Nobel Lecture Published; It Denounces Soviet Union and the U.N.
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 24Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the I soviet novelist whose works are banned in the Soviet Union, bitterly denounced his country in the lecture he would have delivered if he could have accepted the Nobel Prize he won in 1970.

title: India Sending Envoy to Uganda for a Talk on Asians
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 24The Indian Government, long used to abrupt expulsion orders of migrants of Indian origin by African and Asian countries, has been largely Indifferent to the plight of the Asians in Uganda. But agitated world opinionespecially in Britain and the United Statesis finding a distant echo here.

title: Rogers Rejects Pressure On Greece as Arrogance
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24Secretary of State William P. Rogers, in a policy speech that strongly affirmed continued American military aid to Greece, said today that it would be against the United States interest to put pressure on the Greek Government to change its policies.

title: Don Byas Dies in Europe; Jazz Tenor Saxophonist
description: AMSTERDAM, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Carlos Wesley Don Byas, American jazz tenor saxophonist, who had lived here since 1955, died today of lung cancer. He was 59 years old.

title: Mrs. Nettie Eliza Haley, 85, Bronx Community Leader
description: Mrs. Nettie Eliza Haley, community leader, died Sunday at her home, 780 Concourse Village West, the Bronx. She was 85 years old.

title: Business Briefs
description: A suit charging violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act was filed in a Federal court in St. Louis yesterday against Rubbermaid Commercial Products, Inc. of Cleveland by Contico International, Inc., manufacturers of plastic waste and foodhandling containers.

title: Theater: Exceptional Feminist Play at Street Fete
description: What does street theater do when it rains? When a shower struck yesterday at the Lincoln Center Community/Street Theater Festival, the members of the Streetcorner Society of East Lansing, Mich., calmly chose dry spot under the balcony of the New York State Theater and began their show.

title: MGOVERN TO TALK ON HIS ECONOMICS
description: Gary Hart, Senator George McGovern's campaign manager, said yesterday that the Democratic Presidential candidate would clarify his economic policies next Tuesday but would make no major modifications of those policies.

title: Squeezing Out Lemonade Profit
description: The corner lemonade stand, long a thriving bastion of juvenile entrepreneurship, is bravely holding its own in the face of bitter competition from franchised quickfood operations and fear of violence from big kids. But inflation, apparently, is of only minor importance in lemonade circles.

title: Color Television Becomes Italy's Big Issue
description: ROME, Aug. 25Color television is making its longawaited debut in Italy, but the picture is clouded with lurid shades of highlevel international intrigue, of political backstabbing and of allegations of graft at home.

title: Big Rise in Unsold Homes Seen Cutting Construction
description: A sharp increase in the inventory of new unsold, singlefamily homes in the hands of the nation's builders could portend a further slowdown in construction activity this year, analysts said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Staff Recommends Rejection of A.E.P. Bid for Ohio Company
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today that the commission reject a revised plan for the absorption of the Columbus and Southern Ohio Company by the American Electric Power Company, the big public utility holding company.

title: Dr. Henry Bakst, ExDean Of Boston Medical School
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 25 (AP)Dr. Henry J. Bakst, former dean of the Boston University School of Medicine and an expert on community medicine, died today at his home of heart ailment. His age was 66.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A belief is gaining credence in this countrythat a total ban on or extremely stringent control over firearms, particularly handguns, would reduce violent crime. This premise is based on two incorrect assumptionsthat all firearms owners are criminals, that all crimes are committed with legally purchased weapons.

title: Jessica Lee Waddell Is Wed To Henry Lee 2d in Chapel Hill
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Aug. 25Miss Jessica Lee Waddell, daughter of Henry Lee Waddell and Mrs. Eleanor Waddell, both of New York, was married here tonight to Henry Lee 2d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Walsh Lee of Stamford, Conn.

title: GAF Sells Chlorine Plant
description: The GAF Corporation announced yesterday that it had sold its chlorinecaustic facilities at Linden, N.J., to Linden Chlorine Products, Inc., for an undisclosed sum. Industry sources put the value of the transaction at more than $5million.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: WAKAYAMA, Japan, Aug. 25 (AP)The Babe Ruth senior boys baseball team of Centralia, Wash., lost, 5.0, today to a local team in this western Japan city.

title: La Prevoyante Takes Rich Spinajvay
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 25 La Prevoyante flashed the maple leaf of Canada, a radiant green on the silks of JeanLouis Levesque, Montreal financier, to a queenly triumph in the $58,400 Spinaway today. The success was hardly novel to the speedster ridden by John Lc Blanc, for it was her seventh in an undefeated career.

title: U.M.W. Bank Gave Credit For Bond to Free Boyle
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25A bank owned by the United Mine Workers acted to prevent W. A. Boyle, president of the union, from being sent to jail by extending him credit to allow posting of a bond.

title: Stories Proving Nothing (Continued)
description: Here is another installment of stories appearing now and then that prove nothing:

title: J. P. Stevens Registers a Profit For Quarter to Offset 71 Loss
description: J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., reported yesterday a sharp recovery in its operations for the three and nine months ended July 29, reflecting the broad improvement in several of its divisions this year.

title: Women: Correcting the Myths
description: Now that the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution has been passed by the Senate, after a 49year struggle, and twenty of the required 38 states have ratified this historic amendment, can we conclude that women's equality is now guaranteed?

title: Step for Productivity Taken in Connecticut
description: BRISTOL, Conn., Aug. 25Mayor Frank S. Longo of Bristol, who has complained about waste and inefficiency in government since his election last November, had time clock installed today in Police Headquarters.

title: NADER CITES BASE FOR MILK CHARGES
UNION REJECTS PACT IN BUILDING STRIKE
description: Metallic lathers continued their strike against the Building Trades Employers Association yesterday, after defying the Construction Industry Stabilization Committee and rejecting a proposed threeyear contract.

title: STATE MAKES GAIN ON OVERDUE TAXES
description: ALBANY, Aug. 25 (AP) State officials are making headway in their battle against businesses who do not pay their state taxes on time and they are adding more collectors to do even better.

title: JOSIAH MACY JR.
description: MORRISTOWN, N: J., Aug. 25Josiah Macy Jr., retired corporate secretary of Pan American World Airways, died last evening of cancer at the Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived on Jockey Hollow Road.

title: Market Place: Good Old Days Of 1935 at G.M.
description: Remember that fine old car, the LaSalle 8, that General Motors number that was just one baby step removed from a Cadillac?

title: Holders Approve Note Refinancing By Penn Central
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP)Shareholders of the debt ridden Penn Central Company, fighting for a solvent future, have overwhelmingly approved a plan to refinance $64.3million in Swiss notes borrowed two years ago in a futile effort to save their huge railroad subsidiary from bankruptcy.

title: V.F.W. Applauds Agnew For Position on Amnesty
Plane Hits Wire and Crashes Near AReactor, Bruising 2
description: WATERFORD, Conn., Aug. 25 Two men walked away from the smoldering wreckage of their small plane this afternoon after it hit hightension wires and crashed into a 30foot ditch about 1,000 yards from the Millstone Point nuclear reactor here.

title: Stamford Fire Razes Store
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 15 (AP)One store was destroyed and four others were heavily damaged early today in a fire that caused an estimated loss of $75,000 to $100,000 in the heart of downtown Stamford. Two firemen were treated for minor injuries suffered while fighting the fire that was brought under control after two hours. The Palace Beauty Salon was destroyed. The blaze also damaged a jewelry store, a novelty shop, a Christian Science reading room and an optical company.

title: M'GOVERN ASSERTS NIXON POLICY COST MILLIONS OF JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Senator George McGovern, in a series of speeches and press releases, attacked the Nixon Administration today with charges ranging from one that It had made a joke of women's rights to another that it had doubled the cost of welfare and forced millions of workers out of jobs.

title: MSGR. MAHONEY, 66, A PRIEST 42 YEARS
description: Msgr. Richard T. Mahoney, pastor since December, 1969, of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents, 138 West 37th Street, died Thursday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: TV : OneU pmanship by Channel 13 on the Olympics
description: The Olympic Games begin today, and the opening ceremonies in Munich will be carried live, at 10 A.M., on the network of the American Broadcasting Company. With a large investment of personnel, technology and dollars, A.B.C. will be devoting more than GO hours to special coverage of the games over the next couple of weeks.

title: Raphael Ellender, Artist, Dies; Wrote Text on Basic Drawing
description: Raphael Ellender, author, artist and teacher, died Thursday at Arden Hill Hospital, Goshen, IV. Y. He was 66 years old and lived at 338 West 72d Street.

title: DAVID HARVEY M'TURK
description: MANILA, Aug. 25 (UPI)David Harvey McTurk, an American entertainer and businessman who came to the Philippines before World War II, died, yesterday of virus pneumonia. He was 67 years old.

title: Execution Order Recalled
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 25 (AP)The state Court of Appeals recalled today its order directing the electrocution next Friday of a Miami, Fla., man convicted of murder. The courtappointed lawyer for Robert K. Call, who is in death row at the Kentucky State Penitentiary, had requested the recall on the ground that the United States Supreme Court had banned capital punishment as it is presently enforced.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25United States official monetary reserves declined by $249million to $13.09billion July, with the entire drop coming in the category of foreigncurrency holdings, the Treasury reported today.

title: Move on Wheat Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Government wheat export subsidies, rising along with farm prices because of huge grain sales to the Soviet Union, will be brought under control beginning next week, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Saigon Ousts Commander Who Lost Battle at Queson
