The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation got a cense from the Soviet Union for new technology to produce aluminum.... The Reynolds Aluminum Company said bought the same technology last December.... Newcar sales in the Aug. 1120 period totaled 186,270 units vs. 187,339 units in the yearearlier period.

title: STOREKEEPER SHOT IN EVICTING ROBBER
description: A Greenwich Village storekeeper who attempted to throw an armed holdup man out of his storet yesterday morning was shot in the right leg by the intruder, who escaped.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Along with a letter from a reader who suggested that air passengers traveling overseas for long periods of time be allowed a larger baggage weight allowance (Travel section, Aug. 13), you published a comment from an airline official who said there was no way of knowing how long a person holding a regular ticket would be abroad. But the airlines could easily safeguard against cheating. All they need to do would be to stamp the passenger's ticket with tho weight of his luggage at the time of checkin. On return, when the passenger checks in, the clerk could verify whether the person had been abroad for some time and, therefore, was allowed the extra weight. If the passenger was returning prior to the stipulated time, the airline could demand reimbursement for the extra weight. This method would safeguard the airline and yet permit a larger luggage allowance for those who really are going to be abroad for

title: New &Novel
description: Can you make a suspense novel out of water? Yesif there is enough of it, and if the ins and outs of its seepage, velocity, pressure and evaporation rate have dramatic consequences. The water in question is that in Lake Nasser, 5,800billion cubic feet of it contained by the Aswan High Dam. Which, conjectures Michael Heim, has an undermined foundation that makes it imminently collapsible.

title: 930,123 in Britain Are idle As Jobless Rate Increases
description: LONDON, Aug. 26Britain has 930,123 people out of work this month, an increase of 61,927 since July that drove the unemployment rate up from 3.6 to 3.9 per cent.

title: Bold Place and Roba Bella Win Sections of Pageant Handicap
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 26,, (AP)Bon Etage Farm's Bold Place and Buckland Farm's Roba Bella won the two divisions of the 27th running of the Pageant Handicap for 3yearold fillies today at the Atlantic City race course.

title: Susan Reed Kelsey Married To William E. Errickson Jr.
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., Aug. 26 Miss Susan Reed Kelsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Park Kelsey of Gladwyne, Stone Harbor, N. J., and Montego Bay, Jamaica, W.I., was married at noon today to Willard Edwin Errickson Jr., son of Mrs. Ethel R. Errickson and Mr. Errickson of Philadelphia.

title: PECK'S BAD BOY WINS PREDICTED LOG TEST
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.. Aug. 26The Huguenot Yacht Club's 15th annual predicted log contest was won by Jim Peck, the contest chairman, in his 24foot Bad Boy, the smallest boat in the fleet of 15. He covered the 32mile closed course from Execution Rocks to Lloyd's Point and back to 9.8 knots with 0.9140 per cent error. Jim Moore was second in Ginjime V was 1.1880 per cent error, and W. Henry Sebrell was third in Seago II with 1.3091 per cent error. in Seago II with 1.3091 per cent error.

title: Couple Films Babies, Bears, Temples
description: PRINCETON  Hugh and Suzanne Johnston, creators of documentary and educational films, have a wide range of subject matter in their productions. Workinprogress in the Johnston studio in Princeton, for example, includes sequences of polar bears on the Arctic seaice and forgotten Maya temples in the jungles of southern Yucatan.

title: State Gives Grants To Deal With Trash
description: FLEMINGTON  Six demonstration projects have received state backing in a campaign to find better and perhaps profitable ways of coping with the spate of bottles, jars, aluminum wrappers, newspapers and cardboard that overflow available dumping grounds and foul the air when burned.

title: Turning Career Dreams Into Reality
description: One is assistant to the head of a real estate firm but thinks she would like to get into fashion. She is unmarried. One is a widow with nine children and she dreams of becoming a muralist. Another is a portrait painter who is now working with the designer of model rooms in a department store. Still another is an assistant to director of industrial movies. She too is unmarried.

title: Motschenbacher Out Of First CanAm Race
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug 26A sevenyear string for Lothar Motschenbacher was broken here this weekend as injuries prevented him from running in tomorrow's Road America CanAm race.

title: Denise Drouin To Be a Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Denise Dawn Drouin to James Parnham Fabiani has been announced by the future bride's parents, Edward P. Drouin of Farmington, Conn., and Mrs. Casertano Drouin of Cheshire, Conn. Mr. Fabiani is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dante C. Fabiani of Westport, Conn.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARKTom Groom, an officesupply store owner from Massachusetts, went shopping for a ski chalet in Vermont last winter. But instead of a chalet, he decided to buy a $15,000 cabin on wheels, complete with air conditioning, bedroom, kitchen, bathroom, living roomand television set.

title: McGovern Is Radical or Very Liberal to Many in Polls
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Two opinion surveys indicate that, as of early August, nearly a quarter of the electorate regards Senator George McGovern as radical or very liberal.

title: Paths in Spirituality
description: Unlike some modern theologians, John Macquarrie writes about God as though he believes in Him. And he has an uncanny knack for making that belief real and meaningful. His newest book of 12 brief essays gets to the heart of religious experience, of theology, prayer and worship. It is still as St. Augustine wrote a millennium and half ago: Where I found truth, there found I my God, who is the truth itself.

title: Anne Hoeft Married
description: SKANEATELES, N. Y., Aug 26Miss Anne Waterbury Hoeft and Donald Lee Carpenter were married here this afternoon in St. Mary's of the Lake Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Thomas Guyder The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hoeft Mr. Hoeft is financial chief of the United States Small Business Administration for upstate New York. Mr. Carpenter is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Carpenter of Danville Ill., where his father is a dentist.

title: TRANSPORTATION
description: LOS ANGELES  Ken H. Hayes, a librarian in nearby Orange County, recently bought his 10yearold son $110 bicyclefor the fifth time during the last year The four others had been stolen.

title: Dickey Has Hip Surgery
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) The Houston Oilers quarterback, Lynn Dickey, underwent surgery today on his left hip and is expected to be out of action about eight weeks. Dickey, flown to Boston for the operation at Massachussetts General Hospital, dislocated the hip in Thursday night's game with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: VALUEADDED TAX OPPOSED IN A POLL
description: A majority of American adults support a larger role for the states in meeting public school costs and reducing local property taxes but oppose any national salesor valueadded tax for financing the schools, according to a survey by George Gallup.

title: Taatataata! The Troupers Are Coming
description: REMEMBER those prehistoric Westerns in which, just as the last defenses of the embattled settlers were about to be breached by the yowling heathen throng, somebody inside cocked an ear at the horizon and yelled, Listen! And way off in the distance you could hear, faint but fierce, a brassy little taatataatataaa that meant, oh glory, only one thing: the troopers were coming. The day was saved.

title: Navy Wives Irate at Idea Of Women on Warships
description: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 26Ever since ships were powered by the winds and guided by a flotilla of deities, women have been considered bad luck at seaby men. Now that the man at the top of the United States Navy has reconsidered this notion, the badluck warnings, and worse; have been sounded againby women.

title: HAMMOND BEATEN BY TAIWAN, 6 TO 0
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 (AP)Lin HsingJui collected three hits and Chen ChihShun hurled a fourhit shutout today as Taiwan scored a 60 victory over Hammond, Ind., and won its second straight Little League baseball championship.

title: World News Briefs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 26 (UPI)Argentina recalled its Ambassador from Chile today to protest the flight from here to Cuba of 10 terrorist hijackers of an Argentine jetliner.

title: Letters
description: Regarding Thomas Meehan's The Other July ConventionThe B.P.O.E. in Atlantic City (Aug. 13), the members of private clubs will always set the standards for the admission of new members. This is proper and correct. In New York City there are several Negro and Jewish clubs that a white Christian couldn't join. Had Mr. Meehan taken the position that private clubs are undesirable, he might have had a dubious point

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.The Peking Government cast its first veto in the Security Council last week and, in several ways, it was a paradoxical development.

title: Indian Truck Plunge Kills 8
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 26 (UPI)Eight persons were killed and seven others were seriously injured Saturday when the truck in which they were riding plunged into a river at Rampur Bushahr, about 300 miles north of New Delhi.

title: In the misty future, a real peace?; A visit with Hussein.
description: EAST JERUSALEM: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. This is your captain speaking. From your right window you may observe the Jordan River and the Dead Sea. We shall arrive at Aqaba in 40 minutes. There may be a bit of a crosswind on landing, but we don't anticipate any major difficulties....

title: ...And A Clockwork Orange
description: WALTER CARLOS' CLOCKWORK ORANGE (Columbia, KC 31480). Film composers are almost unanimous in their ambivalence about the mixed joys and blessings of their medium. There isand, in fact, always has been  a paradoxical mixture of remarkable artistic freedom and restrictive limitations that makes composing for the silver screen both appealing and frustrating. That frustration, as much as anything, accounts for the fleeting romances that concert composers like Aaron Copland and Serge Prokofiev have had with film scoring.

title: A Police Captain Interrupts Chase and Kills Armed Man
description: A police captain on patrol alone in Elmhurst, Queens, interrupted what authorities believe was a robbery attempt early yesterday and shot an armed man to death, the police of the Elmhurst station reported.

title: Lovell Gets Gold Medal
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 26 (AP)The American astronaut, James Lovell, received the first gold medal of the 1972 Olympic Games today. Willi Daume, president of the Olympic Organizing Committee, presented Lovell with a special gold medal, saying the astronaut's trip to the moon in Apollo 16 was worth more than 10 gold medals.

title: Fashions of The Times
description: People used to say that fashion ran in sevenyear cycles. By that reckoning, the 1970's were supposed to usher in an era of longer skirts. But a funny thing happened on the way to the cyclewomen discovered pants. The enthusiasm for pants hasn't abated yet (will it last for seven years?), and designers are improving them all the time. They're getting wider and wider, with pleats and high waistbands; sometimes they're cut exactly the way men's used to be, with those little tabs at the top. Pants are being put together better than ever, too, with mantailored jackets, shawlcollared wraps, swingy toppers or bloused jackets cropped at the waist. Sometimes the way to wear trousers is with a sweater set or simply with a shirt and a cardigan sweater tied casually around the shoulders. Casual is a key word. It's partly women's liberation, partly the awareness of war and sociological problems, but nobody today wants to look as if she

title: Semper Paratus (Willing And Able)
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L. I.These warm summer weekends are busy ones for the men of the Coast Guard. Sitting safely on the beach here, we often see their vesselsblue lights flashing and sirens screaming  sprinting on the way to a rescue.

title: Seven Words You Can't Say on TV
description: GEORGE CARLIN used to be a fairly conventional standup comic on the nightclubHollywood circuit. He wanted into movies. He wanted his own TV show. He wore tuxedoes and short hair. Then, as he tells it, the whole thing started to pall. He became exasperated with his middleclass, middleaged audiences and with the limitations they imposed on his material and style. He had been a head all along, he says, and the gap between his private and public selves was making him feel schizy. He thought nostalgically of his early days as a coffeehouse comedian in the Village and began to plot comeback or, better, a goback.

title: The World
description: Argentina was in political turmoil last week. There were student riots in a halfdozen university cities. Army troops broke into the headquarters of the labor union headquarters in Buenos Aires. Hundreds of strident, labor and political leaders were arrested.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Dear Dr. Omniquack, nationally syndicated medical knowitall:

title: Wendy Parmele Wed
description: KINNELON, N.J., Aug. 26 Miss Wendy Gray Parmele, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Bogert Parmele of Smoke Rise, was married here this afternoon to Robert Mark Warburton, son of Mr. and Mrs Frederick R. Warburton Jr. of Fayson Lakes.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Sheldon G. Gilgore's description of the undesirable consequences of the present regulatory scheme for drugs ['Controls Stifle New Drugs, July 2] dismisses the contention that low investment in research and development by the pharmaceutical industry is responsible for the decreasing number of new therapeutic advances. While it is accurate to say that the dollar amount of such research is increasing, what is equally important is the focus of the research effort.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Every writer has his quirks. One anticipates them with fondness or irritation or amusement, as the case may be. In mystery fiction, for example, there is Rex Stout's predilection for breaking off dialogue with a dash. (So he came to me and I never.) There is John Dickson Carr's avoidance of he said. There is Richard Lockridge's cutesy, High Sophisticated Archness. And now there is George Beare's whispering.

title: There as a Real Count Dracula And He Was Not a Good Old Boy
description: IN his classic turnofthecentury chiller about Count Dracula, the living corpse who roamed the forested hills of Transylvania by night and returned to sleep in his coffin by day, Irish novelist Bram Stoker killed off the vampire in the final chapter. But as far as Dracula's fans are concerned, he simply refused to die.

title: Pop
description: MUD ACRES: Music Among Friends (Rounder, 2001). Having left a major record label, Happy and Artie Traum decided to produce an album featuring themselves and their friends doing their favorite songs the way they do them when we get together at parties. Thus they made their way to Rounder Records (who can be reached at 727 Somerville Avenue, Somerville, Massachusetts 02142, just in case your local record dealer doesn't stock their products), who offered them the freedom to do as they pleased. Mud Acres is the result of the Traums association with Rounder and a twoday marathon recording session at a small studio in upstate New York. Participating in equal capacities along with Happy and Artie were Maria Muldaur, John Herald, Eric Kaz, Jim Rooney, Bill Keith, Tony Brown and Lee Berg.

title: Roughing it
description: We've come a long way since a vacation house meant a log cabin in the woods. Vacation houses today are crowded with urban amenities even in the wilderness. A mountain lakeside in Vermont, hidden deep in the woods with not another house in sight, is the setting for this sumptuous retreat. The house, which steps down the mountainside in a series of tiers, is entered at the top level. At the lowest level is a deck with a pool that appears to cantilever out over the lake. Architect Peter Gluck divided the interior in half with two levels in one wing, three in the other. Each level has its own terrace. The two wings with their differing levels were designed to offer each member of the family complete privacy when desiredas well as room for communal activities or quiet conversation. The master bedroom suite is almost a miniapartment at the top of the house. A level down is spacious livingdiningkitchen complex, dominated by the huge fireplace (shown both left and right). In the opposite wing are four bedrooms and bathrooms and a living room for the teenage children. Skylights and expanses of glass let the family get close to nature with all the comforts of home.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The Times editorial of Aug. 13, Economic Anniversary, is like a report card for Richard Nixon which rates him well and notes that ... the N.E.P. appears to be on the way to success in most respects.

title: N.B.A. WILL PLAY AM, 36 TIMES
description: Clubs of the rival National and American Basketball Associations will meet 36 times in preseason exhibition games this year, the commissioners of the two leagues announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Jews Start Fund Campaign For Soviet Immigrants in Israel
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Aug. 26 American Jewish leaders started a fourmonth campaign tonight to sell $152million in Israel Bonds to aid large numbers of Soviet immigrants in Israel and upgrade the living conditions of disadvantaged citizens in that country.

title: Dr. Finch, Paroled in WifeSlaying Seeking Practice in Small Town
description: EL DORADO SPRINGS, Mo., Aug. 23 His voice is authoritative, his mind is quick and his manner is firm, but Dr. R. Bernard Finch is a deeply troubled man. He wants to resume medical practice but has no license and has delayed applying for fear of rejection.

title: Hodgson Says McGovern Is Advocate of Weakness
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 (UPI)Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson told a veterans group today that Senator George McGovern was playing politics with American prisoners of war and advocated a path of military weakness that is a prescription for disaster for the United States.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Despite New York's heat, the stock market shivered last Thursday and dropped more sharply than it had all summer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Thanks to your reviewer for expressingso perceptivelythe discontent that many of us feel, visavis the direction (or lack of direction) taken by the Movement.

title: L.I. Veterans Are Dishing It Out
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I, Scramble one, called out Lou Mayhall, as he placed an order slip on the serving table behind the black range where Joe DeCristofaro was manning the skillets. The order may sound vaguely like that heard in a diner, but there is a subtle difference.

title: UNDINE PLACES FIRST IN LUDERS16 SAILING
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26 Joseph F. Stautner's Undine won the Luders16 Class race by 2 minutes 44 seconds off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today in the season's 30th championship regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets based EastofRye on Long Island Sound.

title: Justice George Arkwright, 83, Of State Supreme Court Dead
description: George A. Arkwright, a former State Supreme Court Justice and Public Service Commissioner, died Friday at his home, 1868 East 24th Street, Brooklyn. His age was 83.

title: Art
description: FEN London districts even the once lordly neighborhoods of Mayfair and Belgraviahave changed so much during the last 10 or 15 years as the povertystricken East End. On a recent sightseeing expedition, conducted by a friend who was horn and brought up there, we were perpetually arriving a little too late to be able to study some historic landmark.

title: Death Around the Clock
description: One of the justifiable killings that have helped swell New York's homicide statistics this year was that of Salvatore Natuarale, a slender, fairhaired youth who died just before sunrise last Wednesday.

title: Liguori Among 6 Named StudentAthlete Finalists
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 26 (AP)Villanova's miler, Marty Liqueri; Penn's basketball star, Bob Morse, and Drexel's lacrosse and football player, Blake Lynn Fergusen, were among the six finalists announced tonight for the 1972 College athletics top ten studentathlete awards.

title: Gibson Wins 15th for Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (UPI)ion Brock collected four hits as he helped Bob Gibson to his 15th victory tonight and paced the St. Louis Cardinals to 93 triumph over the San Diego Padres.

title: Hulme Qualifies for Pole Spot In CanAm Race
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug. 26The Sports Car Club of America, which sanctions the Canadian American Challenge Cup, would have done well today to organize a new class of racingamphibiousas a full day of rain disrupted the qualifying for tomorrow's Road America CanAm.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Anyone who doesn't know that this is the period when the Olympic Games are underway couldn't have been doing much reading, viewing or listening lately. And the same goes for anyone who doesn't know that many companies have tied in their advertising and marketing programs to this quadrennial event.

title: Cookie Sales Aid Study of Ecology
description: The Board of Education allocates about 50 cents a student for the experimental materials used in the summertime marineecology class at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn.

title: CourtsAgencies Relations Found Poor by Panel Here
description: A 16month study by a selected group of judges, lawyers and city officials has found widespread confusion, bad feeling and lack of cooperation and communication in the dealings between the city's courts and scores of public and private agencies.

title: Crash Ties Up Van Wyck
description: An oil truck involved in a collision with several cars at 7:30 last night spilled a large amount of oil on the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens, the police said. The southbound lanes were closed for several hours between Liberty Avenue and Hillsdale Avenue as sand was spread over the oil. No injuries were reported.

title: BIRDS DUST BATHS FOCUS OF A THESIS
description: Scientists have long wondered why birds take dust bathsa sight often seen along country roads in the summertime. Many ornithologists have come to the conclusion that dustbathing is the bird's way of ridding itself of tiny insect parasites that live on its skin.

title: Mrs. Leonhardt Bride of Writer
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 26  Mrs. Mary Gay Labrot Leonhardt of New York, widow of Robert Crawford Leonhardt, was married here today to Robert Lee Sherrod, journalist and author of Washington. The Rev. N. Robert Gill of the First Christian Church performed the ceremony at the Oglethorpe Club.

title: WILDLIFE THRIVES IN KOREAN DMZ
description: SEOUL. South Korea, Aug. 26 The demilitarized zone that separates North Korea and. South Korea has become one of the largest game preserves in the world.

title: Miss Kowsky Wed To Paul Villarreal
description: Miss Claire Maureen Kowsky, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick P. Kowsky of Rockaway Park, Queens, was married yesterday morning to Paul H. Villarreal, son of Mrs. Manuel R. Villafreal of El Paso and the late Mr. Villarreal.

title: LOSS DROPS METS TO THIRD PLACE
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 26  The New York Mets lost a tworun lead in the eighth inning, a ball game and second place in the National League East in that order tonight when they were defeated by the Atlanta Braves, 76.

title: Jews Seek Flood Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)  B'nai B'rith, the Jewish service organization, announced plans today for a oneweek campaign beginning Sept. 25 to raise $500,000 for Jewish institutions damaged by floods resuiting from the tropical storm Agnes.

title: Journal Brings $21,000
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 26 (AP)What is believed to be a world record price for a whaling journal was bid at an auction Tuesday for a Nantucket whaler's account of an 1850 voyage to the New Zealand whaling grounds. It sold for $21,000. The illustrated account by William A. Folger of his voyage on the ship Monticello was bought by an agent for private collection in New Jersey.

title: Marquette Burial Site Unearthed in Michigan
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Aug. 26 (UPI)Archeologists from Michigan State University have unearthed the ancient cellar where Father Jacques Marquette was buried by his Huron Indian parishioners in 1677.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In the reporting of the New Economic Policy's birthday party [Aug. 13], the silence of those who formerly spoke out against controls was deafening.

title: Music and Order Reign at Philadelphia Festival
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 26On the surface, the 11th annual Philadelphia Folk Festival, which began its threeday weekend of concerts and workshops last night on the rolling, wooded, fields of the Old Pool Farm, seemed very much like those of earlier years.

title: An account of the collision of two societies
description: Fire in the lake is the image for revolution in the Chinese Book of Changes, the I Ching, and it's the title of this extraordinary book by Frances FitzGerald. Miss FitzGerald, a young American freelance writer who has spent much time in Vietnam during the past six years, has written partly a history of South Vietnam, partly a study of American policy there, and partly an account of what this policy has done to a people we have destroyed in order to save from Communism. Fire in the Lake is all these and much more: a compassionate and penetrating account of the collision of two societies that remain untranslatable to one another, an analysis of all those features of South Vietnamese culture that doomed the American effort from the start, and an incisive explanation of the reasons why that effort could only disrupt and break down South Vietnam's societyand pave the way for the revolution that the author sees as the only salvation.

title: Medicine
description: It has been a long time coming, but it looks as though modern biology and chemistry are on the brink of exorcizing the devil theory of mental disease, a theory that holds that an outside, willful agent invades the body to drive the victim to uncontrolled, bizarre behavior. In modern dress, the devil theory blames wrong psychological upbringing for implanting the grotesqueries.

title: Julie Wolf of Bangor, Me.,Wed To John de N. Wolf in Bay State
description: HEATH, Mass., Aug. 26 Miss Mary Juliette Wolf of Bangor, Me., was married this afternoon to John de Nervaud Wolf of Cambridge The Rev. John P Miller, the rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Bangor, performed the ceremony in the Heath Union Evangelical Church.

title: Soviet Hunts Wolves by Air
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Airborne Soviet hunters killed 5,000 wolves preying on livestock, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. The hunters, Tass said, shot at packs of marauding.gray wolves from aircraft and helicrafters.

title: PALISADES PARK WILL BE REVIVED
description: The Palisades Amusement Park, only a memory of roller coaster rides and summers past since its facilities and land at Fort Lee, N. J., were sold last year, will be resurrected on Morris County site 50 miles west of New York City, under plans announced yesterday by a new management.

title: Korvettes Said to Use Indicted Dealer
description: The E. J. Korvette discount chain, whose homeimprovement division has come under attack from the Federal Trade Commission, continues to use as a major subcontractor a Long Island concern that was indicted on a grand larceny charge last May.

title: Poll Finds Antistatehood Party Is Rising Again in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 26The Popular Democratic party which dominated Puerto Rican politics from 1940 until 1968 when an internal split caused its upset by a prostatehood party, has defied all predictions and fought back to strong contention in the 1972 campaign, a poll has disclosed.

title: Americans Skating Victors
description: ST. GREVAIS France Aug 26 (AP)Robert Bradshaw and Terry Kubicka of the United States captured first and second places today in the men's freestyle event at an International figureskating competition.

title: JERSEY LABOR UNIT BACKS M'GOVERN
description: NEWARK, Aug. 26  The newly formed New Jersey Labor Committee for McGovernShriver, including a representation from 35 unions, adopted a statement of support for the Democratic nominees this week and made plans for a statewide drive to register voters, raise funds and get out the vote on Election Day.

title: Fittipaldi Gains Pole
description: BRANDS HATCH England Aug. 26 (AP)Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil flashed around the Brnads Hatch circuit at record 115.64 miles an hour today to win the pole position for Monday's Rothman's 5,000 auto race. The Brazilian drove the same Formula 1 Lotus with which he virtually had clinched. the 1972 world driving title.

title: Home Improvement
description: DRIVING a few wood screws would seem to be one of the simplest of doityourself chores, yet many people have trouble because they don't use the right size screwdriver for the job, or because they neglect the basic principles involved in drilling the right size pilot hole for each screw.

title: The Pro Scene
description: Even though average attendance went up from 52,381 a game to a record 55,363 and television audiences, led by the Monday night crowd, were at an alltime high last year, pro football has sought to put further pyrotechnics in the game for its 53d season, which opens three weeks from today. Because of a change in markings, the field will play a little differently, hopefully in favor of the offense.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The proposed hotel at the preIncan City of Machu Picchu in the Andes of Peru, a plan reported in the Notes column (Travel section, Aug. 6), is badly needed [Notes said that a Peruvian Government proposal to build a 200room hotel 500 yards from the ruins, had been attached on esthetic grounds.] When my daughter (a classical archeologist) and I spent a night at the present 18room inn at Machu Picchu last December we were able to visit the ruins both late at night and early in the morningthe only way in which you can really appreciate them. You cannot do this when making a oneday trip from Cuzco, 50 miles away. It is a mistake to go so far to visit the most outstanding ruins in the world without being able to stay overnight. I believe that archelogical ruins have to be excavated, restored and preserved, but I also believe that they have to be made accessible for the many rather than Just for the professionals. The hotels located at the Yucatan ruins in Mexico are a good example of this.

title: Liver Transplant Dies
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 26 (UPDSouth Africa's first complete liver transplant recipient, Hugo Van Der Vijver, died toy day in the Johannesburg General Hospital. Mr. Van Der Vijver, who was 27 years old, received a new liver Aug. 11 from a 19yearold South African who had died in a motorcycle accident.

title: Four novels: naive, meretricious, masterly, aimless
description: Captain Unguentine is a kind of folklegend Yankee: dour, unemotional, workoriented, resourceful as God Himself during the first six days. Mrs. Unguentine, the log maker, perceives him from an unsteady point of view: as drunken wife beater, bore, genius, lover and finally as Earth Father, a force that creates and reabsorbs into itself. One is never quite certain why her point of view shifts. Madness seems more than likely, though the novel's cranky symbolic mechanism may be at work. Crawford commenting perhaps on the way men appreciate their gods. Perhaps.

title: Three Get Lasker Awards For Service to Handicapped
description: A Belgian businessman, an occupational thergpist from India and an American health administrator were named winners of the 1972 Albert and Mary Lasker Awards for distinguished international semice to the handicapped, it was announced yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor. This mishmash of neo Freudian prejudice and stereotypes is a sad excuse for a true commentary on the Movement....

title: Olga Connolly's Story: A Dream About Peace
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 26It's almost incredible that, of all the Olympics I've attended as an athlete, this is the first one in which I've taken part in the opening ceremonies.

title: Tranquility Is a Church in Jersey Holding Auction to Raise Cash
description: TRANQUILITY, N. J., Aug. 26Under the big tent across the road from the church were long rows of stands stacked high with fresh vegetables, homebaked bread and coffee cakes filled with fruit.

title: Seawanhaka Tar In Olympics Test
description: CENTER ISLAND, L.I.Of the thousands of sailors who spend their weekends racing around sound buoys or on cruising regattas from one end of the Island to the other, only one is representing the United States in Olympic yachting this year.

title: MEYER M. TROSSMAN
description: Meyer M. Trossman, who retired recently as an assistant vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, in charge of the Borough Park Branch, Brooklyn, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 1869 83d Street, Brooklyn.

title: Educational TV Expanding, With Innovations
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's Public Broadcasting Authority will be bringing to state schools five full days of educational television this year, for the first time..

title: McGovern Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) The chairman of the Republican National.Committee, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, criticized Senator George McGovern today for failing to repudiate the frightening and sickening tactics of demonstrators at the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach.

title: Ellen Burke Engaged To Jack P. Orlando
description: The engagement of Miss Ellen Marie Burke to Jack Peter Orlando, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ignatius Orlando of New York has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis D Burke of the Bronx and Point Lookout, L. I. A wedding next spring is planned.

title: Hamilton Township Wins
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 26 (AP)Hamilton Township, N. J., downed Prince Georges County. Md., 21, today to win the MidAtlantic regional Babe Ruth hathehall championship.

title: Villemure Wins in Sulky
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 26 Gilles Villemure, the New York Rangers goalie drove his first winner at Freehold Raceway today when he guided Lady Madonna A to a victory in photo finish in the 10th race Villemure is the ownertrainer driver of Lady Madonna A The horse paid $20.40 for $2.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Having just made a trip to Europe, I believe we Americans should leave Europe to the Europeans, We were robbed in Paris and Italy. Did you ever hear of paying 80 or 90 cents for a cup of coffee? I bought about $40 worth of perfume in Paris and was to have received a discount of about $10. A month has passed and I'm still waiting for it. London, on the other hand, is civilized; everything has a price tag on it and they don't try to cheat you. But we should have a campaign against going to Europe; there seem to be more Americans there than Europeans. Everyone I met was American. No more Europe for me; from now on I will travel in the United States, Mexico and Canada. Incidentally, I was fascinated by the article on San Diego (Travel section, 13).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The negotiation of a peace agreement in Vietnam would be vastly improved if a bipartisan approach were employed by Senator George McGovern during the Presidential campaign. The need for peace in Indochina is far greater than continuing the issue of the Vietnam war as central to the campaign.

title: DODGERS TRIUMPH OVER PIRATES, 73
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (AP) Willie Davis cracked three hits, including his 14th home run of the season, as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 73, today.

title: St. Louis Professor, Deported by Mexico, Denies Spy Charge
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26, A political science professor, who has extensive contacts among guerrilla and leftist sources in Latin America was deported from Mexico this week and accaged, he said, of being a foreign intelligence agent.

title: Nixon Proclaims Women's Day After Accusation by McGovern
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 26  President Nixon today issued a proclamation naming today Women's Rights Day and indirectly attempted to answer Senator George McGovern's charge that the Administration has treated the women's moveas a joke.

title: Movies
description: SLENDER, blond, smiling, her face tired but composed, her eyes alive with a wholly inward light, she walks, sways, almost dances among the crowds of shoppers. It is five days before Christmas. a season when everything goes to pot. It is time of year, we are assured, when there is most noticeable a marked tendency toward schizophrenia... Minutes ago the girl had gotten herself fired from a job selling shoes. Now she is happy, free, alone, and quite possibly a little mad. Her name is Rosemonde. She is in her early twenties, an unwed mother, an unsuccessful assassin, and heroine of La Salamandre, a remarkable second film by Alain Tanner, Swiss film director 42 old.

title: Paul Valery: The Later Poems and Prose
description: Built slowly, with a patience appropriate to the pyramid it is, and the pharaoh who lies with his riches within it, the Bollingen edition of The Collected Works of Paul Valdry has now reached the 12th of its projected 15 volumes. More than a dozen prefaces and introductions grace it (by Eliot, Auden and Wallace Stevens. among others almost as distinguished), 12 translators, most of them gifted, have so far contributed their labors, and if, since 1956 when it was the first to appear, the most successful undertaking has been William McCausland Stewart's inspired versions of the Dialogues ($6), works which now seem unimprovable in English as well as French, the most difficult task has been that of David Paul, who has done the major poems, in addition to an excellent prose rendering of Idle Fixe ($5)a kind of extended conversation insufficiently ceremonious and solemn to be a dialogue. Valery's late, unfinished play, My Faust, in Plays ($9.50) is Paul's work, too, as well as the poet's relaxed and anecdotal pieces on the painters, Degas, Manet, Morisot ($6.50). If I say that Mr. Paul has been only intermittently successful with the poems, that is praise, for Valery's poetry, like Mallarme's,is not translatable.

title: Arthur Daley
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 26The one flaw in the Olympic Games is that they open with a showstopper of such matchless magnificence that the mind boggles and the emotions spin with uncontrollable turbulence. It matters not how many opening ceremonies an Olympic watcher has seen: he still gets trapped by the beauty of the pageantry.

title: CAIRO STILL KEEPS TIES TO MOSCOW
description: CAIRO  Egypt remains linked to the Soviet Union by huge financial obligations, the promise of unfinished Soviet aid projects and virtually irreversible trade patterns, political analysts in Western embassies here say.

title: Mrs. Marr Has a Son
description: A son was born Aug. 14 to Mr. and Mrs. William Corbin Marr of New York and Lyme, Conn., at St. Luke's Women's Hospital. Mrs. Marr is the former Miss Kathleen Mary Coville,

title: Actress in Antidrug Drive Held on Marijuana Charge
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 (AP)Terry Moore, the actress, was arrested on a marijuana charge while deplaning here tonight for a brief stopover on trip to Los Angeles, where she said she was to make an antidrug recording, the authorities said.

title: The World
description: SAIGONOn June 19, President Nguyen Van Thieu made a speech vowing that within three months South Vietnam's armed forces would recapture all the territory that fell to the North Vietnamese in the Communist offensive that began March 30. This gives Mr. Thieu three more weeks to fulfill his promise. If Vietnamese gamblers made book on this kind of thing, the odds would be one million to one against it.

title: RAIDERS ENROLL PAIR OF ROOKIES
description: The New York Raiders signed two more members yesterday for the 197273 season. The latest to sign multiyear contracts with the World Hockey Association club are Craig Reichmuth a left wing and Hal Willis, a defensemanleft wing.

title: 9 Young Dancers From Ohio Prove Quiet but Credible
description: The Fairmount Center Dance. Company of Cleveland made a quiet but credible New York debut Friday evening at the auditorium of Julia Richman High School, Second Avenue and 67th Street. The concert was organized and choreographed in large measure by Gale Ormiston, through whom the Alwin Nikolais style of cool and precise movement has been passed to the enthusiastic members of this young company.

title: Peking Assailed in Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, Aug. 26 (AP)Foreign Minister Abdus Samad Azad declared today that China's veto of the Bangladesh application for United Nations membership cast Peking in the role of a preacher of hatred and confrontation.

title: The Mexico of Green Eels, Flutes and Parrots Calling...
description: IT'S 10 o'clock in the morning in Puerto Vallarta. The pier in front of the Hotel Delfin swarms with Mexicans selling cruises aboard the Luz, the big green ferry that makes daily trips to Yelapa, the last cove before the Bahia de Banderas joins the Pacific. We opt for the Palladin, a decrepit but more selective launch.

title: Newest Containerport Opened Here
description: JERSEY CITYWith the arrival of its first containership, Point Breezean area long used as a garbage dump and still surrounded by the flotsam of rotting bargesis in business as New York Harbor's newest containerport.

title: President Delays Strike On L.I.R.R. for 60 Days
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI)President Nixon appointed a threemember emergency board today to help settle the labor dispute that threatens to halt service on the Long Island Railroad.

title: If We Can't Pay Our Artists, We Should Not Have the Arts
description: HAROLD ROSENBERG, in his introduction to The Dedefinition of Art, makes a case for the artist that everyone in this country should be forced to learn along with firstyear math. He says:

title: SIX HOSTAGES FREED BY FUGITIVE COUPLE
description: BARTOW, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP) A Florida jail escape and his woman accomplice released six hostages  a diabetic deputy sheriff and a family of fivein Tennessee today and fled through a wooded area near the Great Smoky Mountains, the authorities said.

title: E. 81st Street Organizes To Fight Tambourine Bar
description: Residents of East 81st Street sat on stoops or gathered in front of brownstones between First and Second Avenue yesterday and expressed amazement that it happened at all.

title: Palmer and Trevino Beaten at Pinehurst
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 26Jack Nicklaus survived through two rounds today but Lee Trevino and Arnold Palmer were eliminated in the United States professional matchplay golf championship tournament.

title: MANHASSET SAIL CANCELED BY CALM
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 26More than 200 boats waited 75 minutes before lack of wind cancelled today's fourth race in Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 40th annual race week.

title: Four novels: naive, meretricious, masterly, aimlessl
description: Dialogue in The Rebellion of the Hanged is out of Clifford Odets, pitched to the cheap seats. B. Traven's revolutionary enthusiasm is a very handsome antique: it has the baldness, the assurance of a keynote speech. Segue under the tramptramp of snare drums and The Peon's Theme, a chacha Marseillaise, played on the electric mouth organ. But them days are gone forever.

title: Air and Sea Pioneer
description: The only way to live life to the full is to do something that depends on both the brain and on physical sense and action, Sir Francis Chichester, Britain's crusty old sea dog, once wrote.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The most astonishing revelation in the history of international diplomacy must be the confessions of the Vance, Harriman and Shriver triumvirate admitting that during the summer of 1968 they had peace in Indochina right in the palms of their hands and not only failed to act on the North Vietnamese offer but neglected to inform their President, Mr. Johnson, or the American people through their press. This duplicity should be investigated by Congress.

title: JOHN ZISGEN IS DEAD; MARITIME LAWYER, 68
description: MAHWAH, N. J., Aug. 26John W. R. Zisgen, a New York maritime lawyer, died Thursday of a cardiac arrest in Good Samaritan Hospital, Suffern, N. Y. He was 68 years old and lived at 9 Winter Road.

title: U.S. Retains Stevens Cup Beating Mexico Net Team
description: The United States team of senior tennis players retained the Stevens Cup yesterday, 41 by winning the last two singles matches from Mexico in the challenge round at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Sherilyn Klaerner Is Married To Henry Allen, Veterinarian
description: DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 26St. Luke's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Sherilyn Kay Klaerner, a student at the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, to Dr. Henry Leigh Allen, who graduated from the school last year.

title: Sir Francis Chichester Dies
description: LONDON, Aug. 26Sir Francis Chichester, who at the age of 65 made a solo voyage around the world in his ketch Gipsy Moth IV, died today, apparently of pneumonia, at hospital in Plymouth, the city from which he began and ended his 28,500mile journey. He would have been 71 years old next month.

title: BIG FIELD LISTED FOR OPEN TENNIS
description: The world's best tennis players start competing Wednesday for $160,000 prize money in the United States Open championships at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. Play will continue through Sunday, Sept. 10.

title: Laws to Aid Migrants Appear to Cut Jobs
description: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Aug. 26State laws drawn up a few years ago to curb exploitation and abuse of migrant workers in this state appear to have speeded up the process of putting the migrants out of work altogether.

title: Dance
description: THE very foundation of the American philosophy of education for the last century has been the doctrine of generalization. American youngsters are required to take a wide variety of subjects in primary school, in secondary school, to an extraordinary degree even at college; and then, and only then, can one specialization, prevails. Somecome a dancer or a doctor.

title: POINT OF VIEW; Why Are We Exterminating DDT?; Ban Called Political Instead of Scientific
description: Only twice in the history of our country has a widely used product whose name has been a hoUsehold word been banned by Government action. The first was alcoholic beverages in 1918 and the second was DDT, the 'miracle insecticide whose use has been outlawed by the Environmental Protection Agency effective next Jan. 1.

title: Pakistan and India Report Progress in Review of Pact
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 26Indian and Pakistani officials, meeting here for the second day today in an attempt to iron out difficulties threatening implementation of the peace pact signed by the countries leaders in July, were reported to have succeeded in separating the political and military issues for resolution at different stages.

title: Where Nothing Is All There Is to Do
description: HAGIA GALENE, GreeceThis small fishing village lies on the western shore of Crete with Africa across the Mediterranean in front of it and the mysteries of the Minnans buried in the hills behind it. In Greek hagia MOWS saint or holy or blessed. Galen is the name of martyr who, it is said, found her peace after being drowned in the sea. For today's traveler, the village's main blessfrig is a total lack of anything that even an American eye would call quaint.

title: 18 Are Slain in Mindanao
description: MANILA, Aug. 26 (AP)Moslem marauders have killed at least 18 persons, two of them marine enlisted men, in three raids since Thursday in two predominantly Christian provinces in the southern Mindanao region. the Philippine police said today.

title: Cantor Joseph Sternberg, Served Synagogues Here
description: Cantor Joseph Sternberg, also known as Yosele Bass, who served synagogues in Providence, R.I., Boston and New York and had given many concerts, died Friday in Knickerbocker Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 309 West 86th Street.

title: Nuptials Held For Mary Clark, W. H. Webster 3d
description: NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26In St. Mary'sbytheSea Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Mary Evans Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Hamilton Clark Jr. of Villanova, Pa., and Northeast Harbor; was married to William Harvey Webster 3d, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Webster Jr. of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. John Haynes performed the ceremony.

title: Suffolk Pushes Stray Dog Hunt
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.Suffolk County, which for years has been the target of a human population explosion, is also undergoing another kind of growth problem: packs of stray dogs.

title: Church's Theater Has No R Films
description: SHORT HILLSFor the teenagers of this affluent suburb 20 miles west of midtown Manhattan, the weekly movies in the auditorium of the Community Congregationtional Church have been a Saturdaynight magnet.

title: Art
description: EVERY summer, the old priest of our parish would give a sermon to the young on the special temptations of summer. He was a man of fixed habits every afternoon precisely at four, he walked his wheezing Airedale down to the ocean and back. In his sermons, he mentioned the long hours of freedom, the relaxed parental guidance, the warm nights that summer entailed. What he especially stressed, however, were all the lightly clad bodies lying on the local beach. He took occasion, too, to give swimmers a practical warning about the dangerous undertow that might carry them off, unexpectedly, in a state of sin. One ought to be prepared for sudden death at all timesbut more particularly in summer.

title: The Nation
description: It was like a doughnut: in the center was the city of Detroit, where the schools housed 285,000 students, twothirds of them black; ringing the city were dozens of suburbs with a halfmillion more students, most of them white.

title: Proposed New York Dog Law Arouses Much Controversy
description: Two meetings held at Commack High School South in Commack, L.I., on Aug 15 to discuss a proposed state dog law drew a total of 1,100 fanciers. Conducting the sessions were Dr. Grant S. Kaley of the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets, and George W. Gloning, counsel to the advisory committee on revision of the law Previous meetings had been held upstate at Watertown, New Hartford Latham and Poughkeepsie.

title: Saigon Editor Slain
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 (AP)Phan My Truc, editor of a proGovernment newspaper who urged other editors to cooperate with tough new press laws, was shot and killed today by an unidentified assassin who escaped on a motorbike. Police sources said preliminary investigation did not disclose a motive for the slaying in a restaurant near Mr. Truc's office.

title: A Much Ado That Often Does
description: AJ. ANTOON'S production of Much Ado About Nothing makes for a thoroughly pleasant picnic in Central Parkthe director does have his girls go picnicking, barefoot, as they try to lure the triggertongued Beatrice into falling in loveand if I wish it were more it is only because the more is tantalizingly there, subtly playing hideandseek with us the whole night long.

title: Television
description: THESE days, Dinah Shore proudly wears a gold medallion bearing the words For Big D. In God We Trust. Burt The effects of her celebrated affair with Kurt Reynolds have obviously been beneficial: she looks marvelous, scarcely a day older than she did when, in bangs and a snood, padded shoulders, swinging pleated skirts and anklestrap shoes, she sang Yes, My Darling Daughter and I Can't Give You Anything But Love, Baby to zootsuited dudes or ponytailed bobby soxers all through the Fabulous Forties.

title: NEW BLOOD TESTS TO HELP CHILDREN
description: NEWARK, Aug. 26  Researchers at the state medical school here have developed an extremely simple method of collecting minute blood samples to test for childhood lead poisoning.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Miss Didion's essay focuses on the application of Marxian analysis to the Women's Movement... for which she cites Shulamith Firestone and Juliet Mitchell (in her book, Woman's Estate). This is a kaleidoscope of the international Movement which, in England, is primarily Marxian, not feminist...

title: New for Home and Shop
description: SUITABLE for either indoor or outdoor use, and designed for recreation rooms, basements, gardens, patios and swimming pool areas, the decorativelooking light strings pictured above consists of eight 5inch plastic globes which each contain a small clear bulb. The translucent globes are made of tough, but lightweightpolyethylene that is almost unbreakable and they come in three colorslemon, lime and orange. The entire string of lights is about 15 feet long, with bulb sockets about 24 inches apart, and additional strings can be plugged together with an addon connector. The bulbs, which draw 6 watts each will last about 1,000 hours, and the plastic globes snap on over the cord itself so that they do not hang on the bulb. The string set is UL approved for both indoor and outdoor use. Party Globes, under $7, at hardware and housewere departments. (General Electric Company, Nela Park, Cleveland, Ohio 44112).

title: Colts Win Near End
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 26 (AP)Mike Curtis intercepted a pass and set up a 20yard field goal by Jim O'Brien that gave the Baltimore Colts a 1613 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers in the final two seconds of a preseason game. tonight.

title: Telling the World
description: There isn't much doubt about what time it is by the clock of the year, regardless of the calendar, when the crows take over the dawn. The songbirds now have sung their songs and the crows have begun to announce that the world will soon belong to their tribe again. Another summer is almost at its end and the crows are announcing it.

title: Coins
description: THE fight to save the New Orleans Mint, or part of it, for a numismatic museum gained many new recruits during the recent convention of the American Numismatic Association in New Orleans. The old coinage building, on the corner of Esplanade and Decatur Street has been practically abandoned.

title: Big Foreign Entry Is Represented In L &
description: The international flavor of the L & M Continental 5000 championship is pointed up by the composition of the field that will run on Labor Day at Lime Rock Park in Connecticut. Of the 30 top drivers in the series, 16 come from countries of the British Commonwealth and 14 from the United States Eleven of these drivers also have experience on the Formula One Grand Prix cir cuit. The Labor Day race will consist of two heats each of 53.55 miles, or 35 laps around Lime Rock's 1.53mile road course. Prize money is expected to total at least $45,000.

title: State Barking Up Wrong Tree
description: COMMACK, L. I.  Suffolk County dog owners, wardens and others are opposed to a proposed state law requiring all licensed dogs to be tattooed with number on their inner right thigh. The owners made their feelings known at a meeting held earlier this month at Commack High School South.

title: M'GOVERN ASSAILS GREEK PORT PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Senator George McGovern continued today his concerted effort to win back those members of  the normally Democratic American Jewish community who have drifted from the fold because of their opposition to his candidacy.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:; Regarding Notes on a revolutionary dinosaur, (Aug. 6): I am an attorney associated with a law firm located in Number One World Trade Center. Neither our office, nor that of any other tenant in the Trade Center is equipped with an electrical switch to adjust any of the lights. The lights can never be turned off by any tenant when he leaves his office.

title: Music Upstages the Rain in Philadelphia
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 27The rains came last night to the Philadelphia Folk Festival for the second year in a row. Last year Hurricane Dora greeted the festival on its opening night and left the festival grounds a muddy quagmire for the remainder of the weekend.

title: Postwar Shock Besets Veterans of Vietnam
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20The flights from Saigon and Danang reach California in 18 hours, telescoping night into day and into night again, and the big jet transports drop out of the gloom of the Pacific sky to land at Travis Air Force Base as another sunrise rims the high peaks of the Sierra Nevada range far to the east.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 27 (LIPI)Deputy Foreign Minister Chiao Kuanhua of China is to arrive here tomorrow for a twoday official visit for talks with President Bhutto, Foreign Office spokesmen announced today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: AUGSBERG, West Germany, Aug. 27In the first half the noise was all Moroccan noiseboos and earache whistles for the referee, chants, songs and rhythmic clapping conducted by a volunteer cheerleader wearing a white yomulka, a flowing white night shirt and elfin slippers turned up at the toes, who whirled a handkerchief overhead faster and faster. Soon after intermission new sounds Intruded. Go! Go! Go! rooters chorused. Get the lead out! a voice bawled, and you knew the Yanks had landed.

title: 35 Architecture Buffs Tour McKim Landmarks Here
description: A group of 35 New Yorkers gathered yesterday afternoon before a nondescript office building at. Il West 35th Street, lighted small birthdaycake candles and sang Happy Birthday to You, Charles McKim.

title: Lennon Adds a Matinee
description: Heavy demand for tickets for the charity performance of John Lennon and Yoko Ono at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday night has prompted the scheduling of a second show at 2 P.M. that day. Proceeds of the concerts will be used to establish small community residential facilities for the mentally retarded.

title: Checkmate Sweeps Four Races, Wins Black Jack Sailing Trophy
On the Need for a Wilderness to Get Lost In
description: TUCSON, Ariz.When I lived in Hoboken, we had all the wilderness we needed. There was the wild waterfront with its decaying piers and abandoned warehouses, the jungle of little bars along River Street and Hurlson Street, the old houseboats, the old ferry slips, the mildewgreen cathedral of the Erie Lackawanna Railway terminal. That was back in 196465. Then came urban renewal which ruined everything left lovable in Hoboken, N. J.

title: 2d Alexander's in Jersey
description: Alexander's, Inc., New Yorkbased retail chain, will open its second New Jersey store this morning in a former Montgomery Ward store site in the Menlo Park Shopping Center in Edison Township.

title: Mrs. Morozova Wins
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 27Olga Morozova became the first Soviet player to win an American tennis tournament when she defeated a countrywoman, Marina Kroshina, 62, 67, 75, in the Eastern grasscourt women's final today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Ellyn Harris Has Bridal at Plaza
description: Miss Ellyn Harris was married here yesterday evening to Stephen Rudolph of London and Philadelphia. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Theater: Busy Royal Shakespeareans
description: LONDON, Aug. 27  The Royal Shakespeare Company is one of the best in Europe, or indeed anywhere else. It exists in London and in StratfordonAvon and also tours the world. Just now it is playing at the Aldwych Theater here and at its own Festival Theater in Stratford; it has a second company here playing London Assurance, and a special touring troupe for Peter Brook's strangely lambent staging of A Midsummer Night's Dream, which is playing Munich for the Olympics.

title: Payments for Foster Care Of Mentally Ill Are Raised
description: ALBANY, Aug. 27 (UPI)Payments to foster families fort mental patients will be increased to $195 a month from 165, beginning Oct. 1, the suite Department of Mental Hygiene announced tonight.

title: Mrs. Natelson Married
description: DEAL. N. J., Aug. 27Mrs. Ruth Natelson of West Orange and Deal, widow of Albert L. Natelson, was married here at borne this afternoon to Benjamin Pollack, a widower of Manhattan. Rabbi Joel S. Geffen, director of Community Services at the Jewish Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony. Mr. Pollack is a lawyer with Lord, Day & Lord, in New York.

title: Books of The Times
description: RANCHO PARADISE, By, John Deck. 310 pages. Hnrcourt Brace Jovamovich. $8.50.

title: At 80, Blanshard Twins Still Back the Unpopular
description: Paul Blanshard, persistent crusader against the Roman Catholic Church. and Brand Blanshard, unflagging opponent of fashionable philosophy, had a special reason to mark time yesterday  160 years were divided equally between them.

title: Miss Aschner Wins
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 27Marilyn Aschner of Holliswood, Queens, reached the round of 16 in the qualifying tournament for the United States open tennis championships today by beating Mimi Kanarek of New York, 62, 75, at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Teachers and City Resume Talks Today
description: Contract talks between the Board of Education and the teachers union will resume today after a 12day recess, with both sides agreed on at least one point: This is the crucial week for fashioning a settlement.

title: Nicklaus Triumphs, Sets Money Record
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Aug. 27Jack Nicklaus smashed a golfing record as he won the United States professional matchplay championship today. In vanquishing Frank Beard by 2 and 1 in the 18hole final, golf's Golden Bear reached a peak in money winnings for a single year.

title: Conservative Party Opposes Housing for Gateway Area
description: The Conservative party said in a statement issued yesterday that the Gateway National Recreation Area should not have any public housing, despite a recommendation by the State Division of Housing.

title: HARVESTER SIGNS POLISH AGREEMENT
description: The International Harvester Company, Chicago, announced yesterday an agreement for the manufacture and sale of its crawler tractors and loaders in Poland.

title: MERRITT T. KENNEDY
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 27Merritt T. Kennedy president of the Armored Carrier Corporation of Bayside, Queens, and a former president of the National Armored Car Association, died yesterday in Manhasset Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived here.

title: MRS. PAUL SYNNOTT
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 27 Mrs. Alice McLoughlin Syn nolt, widow of Paul Synnott, advertising director of Time magazine, died today at Stamford Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TwoThirds Slowing of Growth in City's Relief Rolls Is Hailed
description: A two thirds slowdown in growth of the city's relief rolls during the first six months this year led to official hopes yesterday that management relorms are beginning to pay off. The average monthly rise wits 3.165 persons, compared to 9,137 a month for the last half of 1971.

title: Foe Frees Four Priests in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 27 (AP)The North Vietnamese have freed four French priests captured in the Central Highlands in April. They seemed in good spirits and showed no signs of abuse, an informant said.

title: Japan Tightens Her Economic Grip On Nations of East and South Asia
description: SINGAPORE. Aug. 21With a speed and intensity that have sent chills through her neighbors, Japan has emerged as the preeminent economic force over Last and Southeast Asia a force with overwhelming power and little competition.

title: SPENDING CEILING SCORED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) The Joint Economic Committee of Congress recommended today that Congress reject President Nixon's request to limit Federal spending this year to $250billion.

title: Referee Dismissed in Dispute Over Taylor's Loss
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 27 (UPI)The world heavyweight wrestling champion, Alexander Medved, outpointed the 400pound American, Chris Taylor, tonight, in a decision so controversial that the Turkish referee who officiated was dismissed for the remainder of the Olympics.

title: U.P.I. and Chinese Agency Agree to Exchange News
description: PEKING, Aug. 29 (UPI)United Press International and the official Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, concluded today an agreement to exchange news and newspictures.

title: SAIGON CONFISCATES THREE NEWSPAPERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 27The South Vietnamese; Government announced today that three more Saigon daily newspapers had been confiscated for violating the new press code and that their publishers would be prosecuted.

title: Nuptials in Garden For Joan Rosenthal
description: WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 27 Miss Joan Rosenthal and Melvin Sokotch were married, here this afternoon in a garden ceremony at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Rosenthal, by Rabbi Mark Goldman of Temple Sinai in Lawrence. Mr. Sokotch is the son of Sol Sokotch of New York and the late Mrs. Sokotch.

title: Independent Scrutiny
description: The findings by the General Accounting Office that the Committee to Reelect the President has committed apparent and possible violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act calls for an immediate, fullscale inquiry by investigators of unassailable credibility.

title: Israel Bond Group Meets
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Aug. 27 A twoday conference at the Sheraton Poste Inn, sponsored by the Israel Bond Organization, ended today with a renewed call by Pinchas Sapir, Israel's Finance Minister, for an intensified effort to sell bonds. A total of 350 American Jewish leaders attended.

title: Israel Keeps Hands Off Sinai Arabs, While Developing Tourism and Roads
description: RAS NASRANI, IsraeliOccupied Sinai, Aug. 21 On this promontory, named by Arabs for unknown reasons Head 01 the Christian. two coa?tal defense cannon point their bulky barrels at the rock in the Red Sea grandiosely called Tiran Island and at the Saudi Arabian shore beyond.

title: Steel Optimism Voiced
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27The second half is coming along better than expected, one steel sales official noted last week.

title: Fighter Crashes in Kansas
description: BROOKVILLE, Kan., Aug. 27 (AP)An Air Force F100 fighter plane crashed and burned in a farm field near this central Kansas community today, the authorities reported. Maj. David S. Wilson of Denver, the pilot, ejected before the crash, but suffered lower back injuries, an Air Force spokesman said. The cause of the crash was not immediately determined.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: On the last night of the Republican Convention in Miami Beach, one of the young protesters waved in the direction of the hall and said: Plastic people, with their hotel rooms for $50 a night. That's what you learn to be in America. Why don't the television and papers tell about us?

title: FirstTime Voters
description: I don't think the youth vote is in anybody's pocket, declared President Nixon, and the Republicans at Miami Beach cheered. Well they might, for despite the overconfident early predictions of the McGovern strategists, the political preferences of 25 million young Americans eligible to vote for the first time this year have clearly become an open question.

title: MINISTER IS SLAIN; ROOMMATE IS HELD
description: Policemen responding to screams for help from a Harlem apartment Saturday night found a minister hacked to death. Yesterday, the victim's 23yearold roommate was charged with murder.######### The Frederick Williams, 33, had been struck several times on the head and upper body, according to police, and a small hatchet was found nearby.######## The police said that Mr. Wil!iams and his roommate, Melvin Wade, had apparently argued when the latter attacked the minister in their apartment at 76 West 127th St.########## Mr. Wade was booked at the West 123d Street Station.

title: Escapee and Wife Give Up; Six Hostages Freed Unhurt
description: WHITLEY CITY, Ky., Aug. 27 (UPI)An escaped prisoner and his wife, accused of taking six hostages by automobile from Florida, surrendered today at a remote campsite in southern Kentucky.

title: City Board, Acting on U.F.T. Appeal, Moves to Annul Local School Board's Dismissal of 20 Teachers
description: The City Board of Education, acting on an appeal brought by the United Federation years ago. At that time, general overturn the recent disciplinary dismissal of 20 teachers by the local hoard for Community School District 9 in the Bronx.

title: 35 TAKE A COURSE IN PUBLIC HEALTH
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 27 Once a month for the next two years, 35 health administrators from the East and Middle West will gather at the University of Michigan's School of Public Health for four days of intensive classroom study.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Shriver's Place in the Campaign
description: The mystery guest entrant in the featured match of the Robert F. Kennedy ProCelebrity Tennis Tournament this weekend at Forest Hills turned out, appropriately enough, to be Sargent Shriver. The gallery cheered his aggressive serves and he was a favorite of the big names in the sport, but he muffed some returns and clearly was no professional at the game. The same could be said of his first two weeks of campaigning as the Democratic nominee for Vice President. Mr. Shriver is, at age 56, entered in his first tournament for elective office after a dozen years of watching his Kennedy family inlaws on the political center court. His campaign galleries have been cheering his forceful rhetoric and he has helped win over, some of the big names in the Democratic party's old guard,. but he has bobbled a couple of points and it remains a mystery how much of an asset he will) be to the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern.

title: U.S. PLANS TO OPEN LONDON BANK OFFICE
description: The United States Controller of the Currency, William B. Camp, has announced that his agency is opening an office in London to supervise the increased number of American national banks branches in Britain and on the Continent.

title: LOUIS LAVITT DEAD; LED TEXTILE CONCERN
description: Louis Lavitt, a textile manufacturer who through the Lavitt Foundation had been active in the support of medical education, hospitals and other philanthropies, died Saturday of a heart attack at the Glen Oaks (L. I.) Club. He was 65 years old and lived at 945 Fifth Avenue and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Quarrel Among 3 Women Leads to the Death of One
description: An argument among three Philadelphia women at Jacob Riis Park on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens last night led to the death of one from gunshot wound.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Spur to Free Trade
description: WASHINGTON  Agreement by West Europe and Japan to a new attack on international trade barriers in 1973, picking up where the Kennedy Round left off, was hailed by the Nixon Administration last December as one of its main achievements in liquidating the world monetary crisis which it had precipitated in August.

title: Japan Paces Gymnastics
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 27 (AP)Japan, in a dazzling display of gymnastic skill and precision, piled up a 285.05point lead in the first round of the men's team compulsory exercises at the Olympics today.

title: We Are Not Targeting the Dike System
description: WASHINGTONWhen the President stated on April 30, July 3 and July 27 that United States bombing policy was to avoid targeting of North Vietnamese dikes, he meant exactly that, and his orders are lucidly understood and scrupulously enforced all along the military chain of command.

title: PAPER INDUSTRY GAINS IN CLEANUP
description: In a development it called particularly striking, a public interest research group anflounced yesterday that in its opinion the nation's pulp and paper industry had changed, from a lagging to a leading position in the pollution cleanup effort.

title: COL. F. H. FARNUM OF MAINE POWER CO.
description: CUMBERLAND FORESIDE, Me., Aug. 27 Col. Francis H. Farnum, a retired executive of the Central Maine Power Company and a West Point classmate of General of the Army Douglas A. MacArthur, died yesterday in the Maine Medical Center at Portland. He was 90 years old.

title: 2 New Yorkers Die in Maine
description: BEDDINGTON, Me., Aug. 27 (AP)Two sisters from New York were killed last night in a twocar collision on Route 9. The state police identified the jvictims as Linda P. Stoves, 20 years old, and Elain G. Stoves, 17, of Rosedale, Queens.

title: BELMONT RACING TO START TODAY
description: Thoroughbred racing returns to New York today, when a 42day meeting opens at Belmont Park. Post time is 1:30 P.M.

title: Excerpts From Mayor's Statement on Knapp Panel
description: The events of the past two years already have borne out the value of the commission. It has served as a catalyst for more intensive and sustained anticorruption efforts by the police command and other city, state and Federal lawenforcement officials.

title: Cargo Ship Launched
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 27 (UPI)The 641foot Sugar Islander, the largest drybulk cargo ship ever built in an American shipyard for ocean service, was launched over the weekend. Lockheed Shipbuilding built her under a $15.3million contract. The ship, to be operated in 1973 by Pyramid Sugar Transport, Inc., of New Orleans, will carry raw sugar from Hawaii to the mainland for the California and Hawaii Sugar Corporation.

title: U.S. BLAMES PILOT IN 28DEATH CRASH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) The crash or an airliner at New Haven in 1971 occurred because the pilot, hoping to spot the fogshrouded runway, ignored altitude restrictions and descended too low, Government safety investigators said today. The National Transportation Safety Board also said that all of the passengers could have survived the crash but that they had been trapped by the flames and smoke and had died from asphyxiation and burns.

title: Jews Cautioned on Israel as an Election Issue
description: Leaders of two national groups yesterday cautioned Jewish heads of organizations and the Jewish community as a whole not to permit bipartisan support of Israel to become a political issue in the national elections.

title: Personal Finance: Short Tax Form Is Back
description: Remember the old short form for Federal income taxes?

title: Production Rise Is Reported For Paper and Paperboard
description: Paper and paperboard production for the week ended Aug. 19 increased in comparison with current and yearago periods, according to the American Paper Institute.

title: Angelo Cardinal Dell  Acqua,68, Vicar General of Rome, Is Dead
description: PARIS, Aug. 27  Angelo Cardinal Dell  Acqua, the vicar general of Rome, died in Lourdes today during a pilgrimage. He was 68 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: Let us now praise oldtime radio. For today is the 50th anniversary of the first radio commercial (hurrah).

title: Jets'
description: Al Woodall looked at the rain pouring through the intentionally leftopen roof of Texas Stadium prior to the Jets preseason game against the Dallas Cowboys Saturday night and felt a little sinking feeling in his stomach.

title: Yankees Edge Royals Twice, By 76 Then 98 in16 Innings
description: The Yankees spent an inspiringand incredibleday at the Stadium yesterday.

title: Beame Says Lindsay Budgeting Will Increase Taxes $17Million
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame estimated yesterday that the way Mayor Lindsay's administration balanced the 197172 expense budget would eventually add. about $17million in interest costs to realestate taxes.

title: He's Passing Along Some of His Culinary Expertise
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I.As a youngster growing up in Vienna. Jules Bond rarely was allowed in the kitchen of his parents home. The Hungarian couple who cooked for his Austrian father and French mother invariably pushed young Jules out the doorall the better to make the goulash by you see.

title: Neutercane in Atlantic Intensifies to Hurricane
description: MIAMI, Aug. 27 (AP) Neutercane Bravo intensified tonight and was rechirstened Hurricane Betty, but the storm poses a threat only to shipping in the North Atlantic, the National Hurricane Center said.

title: IND Rider, 60, Is Stabbed For Rebuking a Smoker
description: A 60yearold Bronx man was stabbed in the chest yesterday when he rebuked a passenger for smoking on an IND subway train at 59th Street and Eighth Avenue, the transit police reported.

title: Auditors Find U.S. Lacks Forcefulness In Latin Bank Role
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) A lack of American forcefulness in InterAmerican Development Bank dealings has allowed 22 Latin American members to generally shape policies and dictate terms for borrowing, United States auditors have told Congress.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Coney Termed Unaffected By a 1,200Gallon Oil Spill
description: Coney Island swimming areas were not affected by an oil spill reported in the area Saturday, the Coast Guard said yesterday morning.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Apollo 17 to Go to Pad Today
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 27 (AP)The rocket and spaceships for the final Apollo moonlanding mission will be transported to the launching pad tomorrow for the long checkout leading to a Dec. 6 blastoff. The rocket, with the Apollo 17 command and lunar landing ships cradled on top, will roll out of the assembly building at 7 A.M. The trip to the pad three and a half away is expected to take about Nix hours.

title: CHINA PRESSES U.S. IN LIFEBOAT CASE
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 27China took issue today with a statement by the United States command in Saigon over the alleged sinking of a lifeboat from a Chinese merchant ship by American aircraft off North Vietnam.

title: Joan Murtagh, Michael Frankel, Fellow Law Graduates, Marry
